It is alleged that the American Sheet Steel Company has violated the agreement at these works in removing the limit of output.

Mr. CUTTING leaves no room for doubt as to the attitude of the Citizens' Union toward Mr. GROUT in his desperate resolve to cling to a nomination given to him when he was believed to be a different man from the one he has since shown himself to be.

The British Ambassadorship at Washington. The untimely death of Sir Michael Herbert has left vacant a diplomatic post the importance, attractiveness, and diplomatic status of which are variously valued.

I WAS much amused the other day," said the man with the raveled cigar, "by a conversation that took place in a certain little cafe down town between a fastidious partron and the waiter assigned to the task of serving him.

Very different from usual New York offerings is "Hedda Gabler," which Mrs. Fiske will present at the Manhattan Theatre to-morrow night. It is one of Ibsen's strongest works, and is seldom seen in the English version. Much discussion has waged in regard to the motives of Ibson in depicting the character of the heroine, Hedda Tesman.
HAVANA, Oct. 3 -- The purchase of lands at Guantanamo for the United States Naval Station has been practically completed without the necessity of resorting to condemnation proceedings.

It has been more than a little annoying to those who hope to see Mr. Clyde Fitch take his place in the very front rank of modern playwrights that he will not character in his memory the few precepts of Polonius wisdom that might so easily lead him into the straight and narrow path of dramatic art.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Von Plehve, the Russian Minister of the Interior, carries enough real sins for any one to add imaginary ones. In a communication published in your journal yesterday under the title of "Russian Persecution of Jews," the writer does a gross injustice to Von Plehve.

Barney Oldfield failed to lower or even to equal his world's mile track record of 0:55 4-5 at the automobile race meet at the Empire City track, Yonkers, yesterday afternoon, but he succeeded in making new figures for the distances from seven to fifteen miles, inclusive, besides new track records for five and six miles.

The plans of the Kneisel Quartet for their European tour beginning next March, after they have completed their American engagements, are, of course, not yet completed. They already have in view, however, a series of ten concerts in Holland, four in London, others in Manchester, Liverpool, Birmingham, and Glasgow, besides a number of private engagements in London.
BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- Pittsburg won the third game of the world's championship series here to-day by defeating the Boston Amer- icans, 4 to 2.

DURING recess on the day of the Republican City Convention a party of seven politicians were at luncheon. Among them were District Leader Frank Raymond and Alderman Elias Goodman. The question as to Goodman's candidacy for office being raised, the Alderman said that he would have to limit his political ambition to the office he is now filling.
POUGHKEERSIE, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- The following, prepared by John I. Platt, editor of The Poughkeepsle Eagle, was adopted by the Republican County Convention to-day:

Appearing in "Ole Virginia in 1872" McKee Rankin will be at Proctor's Twenty-third Street Theatre this week. The cast will include Doris Rankin and Ricca Alien. Fisher and Carroll, Irish singers and comedians, will do their best to supply amusement. The Sully family, including two grown persons and two children, will present a comedy sketch.

Stolid, and apparently Indifferent, Samuel T. Hutton, a brawny freight handler, stood a prisoner before Sergt. McNaught, in the Fifth Street Police Station, last evening. Beside him, leaning heavily on two canes, stood his aged mother, the complainant, whose indignation had given her courage and strength to crawl out of her home for the first time in ten years.

Improvement marked the work of most of the football elevens yesterday. The teams which were expected to win did so, but in two instances, the games in which Harvard arid Princeton participated, the scores were not nearly as large as they were expected to be. As a matter of fact, both these elevens were played to a standstill.
THE wife and the kid will be home next week," said the young married man who had been taking his meals at the boarding house all Summer.

Local fire underwriters say in regard to the rate commission just named by the New York Fire Insurance Exchange that the chances largely favor a reduction in existing fire insurance rates, which have been advanced gradually to a much higher level because of the heavy fire losses of the three years ended 1902.

Three men were arraigned before Magistrate Flammer, in the Yorkville Court, yesterday, as the result of a riot which took place Friday evening in a saloon at First Avenue and Fifteenth Street, where several hundred men who had been employed by the Jersey City, Hoboken and Raterson Railway Company were paid for their services.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Monday next the last of the indictments in the Post Office investigation will be returned by the Grand Jury. Ex-Assistant Attorney General Tyner, his wife's kinsman, Harrison J. Barrett, ex-Chief James T. Metcalf of the Money Order Service, and members of a large firm in New York City that has had extensive contracts for postal supplies are expected to be indicted.

Since the erection of the Daniel C. French statue of Alma Mater in front of the library at Columbia University it has been the object of constant care and watchfulness on the part of the college authorities. It is never left unguarded by proctors who watch in relays during the daytime, and at right an extra force of janitors patrol the grounds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under your foreign dispatches I read one headed "Danes Friendly to Germans," in which, according to The London Times's Paris correspondent, a special correspondent at Elsinore is said to have sent to L'Eclair an interesting account of what is represented to be Denmark's altered attitude toward Germany's course.

Pacers were very much in evidence on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning, furnishing the bulk of the sport and carrying off the principal honors of the day. The weather was ideal for driving and brought out a host of road drivers as well as thousands of spectators who lined both sides, of the upper stretch where the fast work was done.

MARIETTA, Wis., Oct. 4. -- During a squall last night on Lake Michigan the steamer Erie L. Hackley capsized, and eleven persons, three of whom were women, were drowned. The Goodrich Line steamer Sheboygan rescued the other seven persons on board the Hackley, all men, after they had drifted all night in Green Bay, clinging to bits of wreckage, and brought them to Fish Creek to-day.

Several thousand men, women, and children were eye-witnesses to the Killing of one negro by another shortly before noon yesterday in West Thirty-sixth Street, near Seventh Avenue, and an even larger crowd took part in an exciting chase of the slayer, which extended over a distance of five blocks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The exodus of farmers from the United States to Manitoba and Alberta, according to offical reports, is increasing. The steady high price of beef, the opportunity to take up large tracts of cheap land, and the gradual decline of productiveness of wheat lands in the Northwest are believed to be causes for this peculiar movement.

The story that went the rounds yesterday to the effect that a well-known Western speculator, together with a coterie of stock brokers, known as the "Waldorf clique," had established a "poker club" in the vicinity of that hotel, caused much comment in police, gambling, and social circles.

BARRE, Vt., Oct. 4. -- One man dying, another suffering from a serious but not necessarily fatal bullet wound, and a third under arrest charged with having fired the shots, is the outcome of the latest clash between the Anarchists and Socialists of this city. The feeling between the two parties has been intense for many months and conflicts more or less serious have been of almost daily occurrence.

NIAGARA FALLS, Oct. 4. -- John Phillips, fifty-five years old, a saloon keeper at Leicestershire, just east of Binghamton, attempted suicide this afternoon at Niagara Falls. He is now under arrest on a charge of attempted suicide.

-- A brilliant example of the animal story that ought never to be told or written, but often is by people who know nothing whatever about animals, to the intense disgust of people who do, is reprinted with irritating credulity by The Cat Journal -- there really is such a journal -- from The Philadelphia Record.
STURGEON BAY, Wis., Oct. 4. -- Purser Blakefield, one of the survivors of the Hackley, who was on the steamer Sheboygan when it reached here, gave a vivid description of the wreck. He said:

We referred recently to the able and suggestive article of Mr. WILLIAM A. NASH in The North American Review on "Congress and the Currency." In the same number Mr. JAMES H. ECKELS, former Controller of the Currency -- and one of the best in a series including some distinguished men -- and at present the President of the Commercial National Bank of Chicago, has an article on "The Government and the Banks."

Something of the past career of Mrs. Marie Layton Johnston, the young woman now locked in the Jefferson Market Police Court prison on the charge of having stolen money from the United States Playing Card Company, came to light yesterday through the investigations of the city Detective Bureau and the private agency employed by the complainant corporation.

VIENNA, Oct. 4. -- As an outcome of the conferences between the Czar and Emperor Francis Joseph at Murzsteg the Governments of Austria and Russia have sent identical telegrams to the Ambassadors of those countries in Constantinople. The telegrams were couched in the following terms:

Now that the National women's championship is over, the fair players of the Eastern section of the country will devote the chief part of their attention this week to the invitation tournament given by Mrs. Clement A. Griscom in honor of the English champion, Miss Rhona Adair. The tournament will be held on the links of the Merion Cricket Club, near Philadelphia, and will begin to-morrow.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says the Arbeiter Zeitung has received a telegram from Novoselitzff, Bessarabia, stating that anti-Jewish disturbances occurred at Mohileff, the chief town of the Government of Mohileff, on Sept. 30.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 4. -- A gigantic graft system, which has been in operation for about five years in the National Tube Works, McKeesport, was exposed yesterday. Thousands of dollars paid to laborers and other employes of the company during that time has, according to the charges, found their way to the pockets of foremen, sub-foremen.

The week's business in securities abounds in anomalous incidents. Among them is the fact that the general tendency of the market for stocks and bonds was different. Among 138 stocks dealt in, and which moved a point or more, 97 advanced in the week which began with registering the lowest average prices of the year for both railways and industrials.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The Department of Agriculture issues this week an interesting bulletin covering the general subject of rubber culture and production in the Cen tral American States and the dependencies. The publication is the work of O.F. Cook, botanist in charge of tropical agriculture, who has made an exhaustive study of rubber culture in every field of production.

Next week there will arrive in this country from England a notable company of Englishmen, the guests of Mr. ALFRED MOSELY, C.M.G., who come to make a careful and systematic investigation, so far as their time, about two months, permits, of our educational system.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The State Department publishes a review of a publication by the French Government concerning inheritances in France in 1902. The review says:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 4. -- President Frank Buchanan, ex-Vice President Butler, Secretary-Treasurer Johnston, James Goakley, and William Burke, members of the Executive Board of the Ironworkers' Union, left for home to-night. The Executive Board met last night, but did no business, and it is expected that the board will meet in New York within two weeks.

Pretty little handkerchiefs that are bargains are of French linen, good quality and sheer, with narrow colored hems, blue, pink, or lavender, and small hand-worked initials in script in color to match the hem. These cost only 15 cents.

Speeding down "Breakneck" Hill, in East New York, yesterday afternoon a two-ton racing automobile struck an embankment, was overturned, and then slid along bottom up for some distance with its operator, a woman, and a boy caught under it. All three were injured, the woman seriously so, and had to be removed to a hospital.

WINSTED, Conn., Oct. 4. -- St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church celebrated with dignity to-day its golden jubilee. Archbishop Diomed Falconio, Apostolic Delegate from Pope Plus X. to the United States; the Very Rev. Edward Bleecke, O.F.M., of Paterson, N.J., Pro incial of the Franciscan Order: the Right Rev. Bishop Tierney of the Hartford Diocese, and sixty visiting priests, besides Mothers and Sisters from all parts of New England, were in attendance.

Preaching on "The City Election of 1903," in St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, of which Mayor Low is a Warden, the Rev. Dr. Reese F. Alsop, the rector, expressed strong praise of the Fusion administration and urged the voters of the city to see to it that it was continued in power.

Lively times are promised at the Fusion conference to be held at 5 o'clock this afternoon, at the old Citizens' Union headquarters in Union Square East, for the purpose of deciding upon new candidates for Controller and President of the Board of Aldermen on the Republican and Fusion tickets.

COLUMBIA, N.J., Oct. 4. -- When Margaret Matilda, the fourteen-year-old daughter of William Smith, appeared at breakfast this morning, her hair "done up" and her skirt obviously lengthened by unskillful fingers attracted the attention of her father.

The two suits brought against the representatives of organized labor in the National Federation and the United Hatters of North America by the American Anti-Boycott Association in the name of D.E. LOEWE Co., hat manufacturers of Danbury, Conn., are regarded by the defendants and by organized labor generally as the most important ever brought in defense of the interests of employers against union conspiracies in restraint of trade.

Sir Thomas Lipton returned from Chicago yesterday, looking a little paler and a little thinner than when he left here, but with his optimistic cheerfulness quite undisturbed. "I went there to stay three days," he said, "but I stayed a month. I was lucky, though, to fall into good hands. I had the best doctors and I could not have been better treated in my own home."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The last annual report of the Commissioner of Pensions, which covers the year ended June 30, 1903, is supplemented with statements and tables from which many interesting facts may be extracted and points of comparison suggested. The report shows that last year the number of persons on the pension rolls exceeded 1,000,000, the highest number reached being 1,000,732.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Officials of the American Bridge Company are interesting themselves in the case of Albert Steiner, a former employe, who went under the name of Charles Lewis, and who was sentenced to a term of ten years in the Massachusetts State Prison at Charlestown. Steiner asserts that his arrest and conviction were the result of mistaken identity.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The campaign in Maryland, which is now in full swing, is one of National Importance to both parties.

Politics disturbed the meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday. The subject was introduced by Delegate Stanton of the Electrical Workers', Union, who wanted to have a committee appointed to visit Charles F. Murphy, leader of Tammany Hall, and Linn Bruce, Chairman of the Republican County Committee, and ask that any candidates on the slates of the two parties who voted for the Pennsylvania Tunnel franchise be scratched off.

A booklet entitled "Municipal Reform and Social Welfare in New York." put out by Edward T. Devine of the Charities Organization Society, and covering the work of the Low administration for the protection of the tenement-house population, is being sent broadcast to show what has been done for life and health among the dwellers in the tenement districts.

The first streaks of dawn were coloring the eastern horizon yesterday morning when Customs Inspectors Galbally and McCaffrey, after several hours' vigil from a stoop across the way, saw the first signs of life in the Chinese laundry at 16 Monroe Street. They sat up, rubbed their eyes, stretched their limbs, and then hurried across the street and into the shop, frightening three Celestials out of their drowsiness.

McKee Rankin and company made their appearance at Proctor's Twenty-third Street house last night. They were seen in a playlet called " Ole Virginia in 1872." Mme. Adgie's lions were on hand. Fisher and Carroll, Irish comedians, caused some merriment. The Sully family, two grown and two youthful, presented a sketch.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- To-day's market was a tame affair, the sales aggregating only 21,516 shares and $52,600 bonds. The business transacted was largely in the arbitrage issues and in Philadelphia Electric, which was a trifle firmer. United Gas was weak and a point lower, caused no doubt by the threatened action in regard to the United Electric Company of New Jersey, the control of which is held by the United Gas Company.

Yesterday's business was a tame opening for a successor to the week which preceded it, and which was so highly contentious and fruitful of records of an objectionable sort. The tone was of that uninteresting sort called "waiting."
It is of the utmost importance that a second victory shall be won for reform in the city government, and that it shall be won with Mr. Low, who won the last and has done so well.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- The members of the Honourable Artillery Company of London were banqueted this evening by their hosts, the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston. Symphony Hall, in which the banquet was served, was artistically decorated, the main feature of the decorations being an electrically lighted golden crown which hung high above the banqueters.

One of the newest leather bags is made after the style of the silk opera-glass bags, which are plaited full into metal frames and close with a clasp. These are made in rich brocades, but the sister bags in leather are simple in appearance. They have plain metal frames, and some are with chain and others with extra long leather strap handles, two of them on a bag.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- While the Government is endeavoring to maintain its resolve not to consider the question of a successor to Sir Michael Herbert at the Washington Embassy at present, there is reason to believe that considerable wirepulling is already going on and that several women prominent on both sides of the Atlantic are becoming interested in the matter.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Seventy-five printing establishments here were partially crippled to-day by the refusal of members of Franklin Union No. 4 Press Feeders to go to work in houses controlled by the Chicago Typothetae. Given the choice of forswearing allegiance to their union or losing their positions, a majority of the feeders failed to report for work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is pertinent at this point of the campaign to ask if history tells us whether Benedict Arnold was possessed of a sense of humor. In fact, it would be an Interesting line of metaphysical research whether a humorous disposition can ever co-exist with a traitorous one.

To, the Editor of, the New York Times: Is it not quite possible that too much significance is being given to the action of Tammany in nominating Mr. Grout for Controller, and his acceptance of the same? Or is it that a totally wrong or uncalled for significance is being given to that action?

The Fusion conference to select candidates for Controller and President of the Board of Aidermen, to take the places of Edward M. Grout and Charles V. Fornes, adjourned last evening without coming to a definite decision, the leading names on the tentative slate being Frederick W. Hinrichs of Brooklyn for Controller and Eugene A. Philbin of Manhattan for President of the Board of Aldermen.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 5. -- At the close of the service at the Euclid Avenue Baptist Church Sunday John D. Rockefeller, approaching the pastor, Dr. Eaton, said: "You know, I was born in Richford, N.Y. There was no religion in Richford. When I was eight years old I moved to a town made up largely of God-fearing people.

MANILA, Oct. 5. -- Trade statistics show that the exports from the Philippine Islands have increased fully 20 per cent, during the last year, the total now amounting in value to $33,696.587. The imports decreased slightly during the same period.

Strikes, following each, other in rapid succession since last year, have caused the closing of the Morse Iron Works and Dry Dock Company, whose plant at the foot of Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, is one of the largest institutions of its kind in the United States. The order to close was issued day before yesterday and went into effect promptly yesterday morning.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The long-expected announcement of the appointments to fill the Cabinet and Ministerial vacancies was made last night, as follows:

Mrs. Fiske has again manifested her admirable independence, and her no less admirable genius, by interrupting her long run of "Mary of Magdala" to give, her last week at the Manhattan to Ibsen's striking and powerful but seldom seen "Hedda Gabler." A large and unusually distinguished audience assemble in honor of the occasion.
LENOX, Mass., Oct. 5. -- Mrs. Edward Wharton gave a dinner last evening for James J. Van Alen of Newport and Mrs. Frederick Sherman of Paris.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Grout's persistent efforts to justify his position on the ground that he informed Mayor Low of the proposition to put him (Grout) on the Tammany ticket and that the Mayor made no objection should deceive no one.

The members of the Old Guard, with a flourish of martial music, marched into Madison Square Garden last night and took possession of the great amphitheatre, which they will hold for a week during their big military fair, through which it is expected to raise funds for the long-desired new armory of this ancient and honorable organization.

The epistolary, controversy as to whether or not Mayor Low did or did not give his assent to Mr. Grout's acceptance of the Tammany indorsement was continued yesterday. Mayor Low issued the following statement in reply to Mr. Grout's statement of Sunday:

The Stewards representing The Jockey Club, and acting for the Westchester Racing Association at the race meeting in progress at the Morris Park course, yesterday were busy with an investigation of charges that have been, made to the effect that the horse The Fiddler, winner of the last race on Saturday at that track, was a "ringer," and was not the-horse, he was represented to be.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Four of the most prominent members of the City Central Republican Committee of Orange, who arc known as active opponents of Major Carl Lentz, Chairman of the County Committee. have resigned.

The defeat of PARKS in the structural ironworkers' convention at Kansas City, with the re-election of President BUCHANAN, promise to end the contention which has kept the building trades in a ferment for many months. PARKS is back in New York. He has washed off every trace of war paint from his face, and now coos for peace as sweetly as the amiable dove in the ballad.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- Rates for money were easy in the market to-day, and there was a good supply. The distribution of $30,000,000 in Government dividends to-day enabled the repayment of the market's indebtedness to the Bank of England. Discounts were easier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The contention over the selection of a United States District Attorney for Delaware was determined to-day when the President appointed John P. Nieids. Mr. Nields has been serving for some time as District Attorney upon the appointment of the Judges of the United States Courts, and his appointment was recommended by Senator Ball, Senator Allee having urged the appointment of Walter H. Hayes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- An armed insane man made a desperate effort to see the President to-day. After a violent struggle in the vestibule of the White House the fellow was overpowered and bundled into a police van. Here he renewed, his struggles, and the two officers with him had to summon aid before he was subdued.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The Duke of Devonshire, Government leader in the House of Lords and leader of the Liberal Unionist Party, has resigned the office, of Lord President of the Council, and the King has accepted his resignation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "An Old Citizen's" indorsement of my letter to THE TIMES on the barking dog nuisance is gratifying; but if "Old Citizen" fancies, as he intimates it may, might, or should have been, that the Department of Health was "stirred up" by that communication, he attributes results to it that the writer thereof was far from sanguine enough to expect.

At the meeting of the West End Association last night the revelation was made that the Grand Jury on Monday of last week summoned Borough President Cantor and Commissioner of Public Works Livingston before them to explain the present condition of the streets.

Miss Clara Connors, once a famous pianist who traveled through Europe, but who has been demented since her parents died, eight years ago, has disappeared. She lived with a school friend, Mrs. Bertha Langdon, a 227 West Thirty-fourth Street.

In a recent report to the Surgeon General, Dr. C.H. BANKS, Burgeon and Medieal Purveyor in the Marine Hospital Service, said that, while the system of inspecting supplies for this organization is, on the while, such as to make certain the obtaining of the things paid for, there is one important exception, and that exception, curiously enough.

At the annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of Columbia University yesterday the reports of the President and Secretary were submitted and approved by the Trustees. President Butler again asks for $10,000,000 with which to further equip the university and put it on a sound financial footing.

Walter M. Wechsler has - bought from Charles H. Dow, as attorney, a one-third interest in the James estate property, at the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Thirtieth Street. The property consists of the small building, about 30 by 50, on the immediate corner, together with an adjoining plot on the street, about 100 by 100, now covered by a two-story stable.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Indications are that all the Western passenger rate troubles will be amicably adjusted within a day or two, and that the Rock Island will be induced to rejoin, the association. The edict is said to have gone forth from New York that these fights must cease, and that amicable relations between the various roads must be re-established so as to bring about a strict maintenance of rates.

We have been asked by some of our readers how we can sustain our confidence in the soundness of the general business of the country in view of the enormous shrinkage of values of highclass investment securities, entailing a loss on the country equal to the total value of these securities multiplied by the percentage of decline.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Lehr have rented for next season the Eldridge villa at Ochre Point, which they occupied during the past Summer.

What will Grout do?" That was the question which was being asked by politicians everywhere throughout the city yesterday. The only answer which can be given to the query at present is that Mr. Grout will fight. He will sacrifice his last dollar and wreck his health, his friends are informed, rather than give any sign of yielding to what he considers the unjustifiable attacks which are being made upon him for his political conduct.

Four laborers were partially buried when several cartloads of water-soaked earth, stone, and brick slid into the deep excavation for the Tiffany Glass and Decorating Company's seven-story marble building at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning, one being instantly killed.

To the Editor of The New Yorks Times: Having read with great interest the editorials published in "All the News That's Fit to Print" during the past week, I have come to the conclusion that Mr. R. Fulton Cutting is greatly to blame for the present political muddle.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- A representative of The Associated Press has been informed at the Servian Legation here that the new Cabinet, though Radical, is composed of two shades of political opinion, four being Fusion Radicals and four Independents, who are an offshoot of the Moderate Radicals.

The commission appointed by President Roosevelt to investigate the condition of affairs at the Immigration Bureau on Ellis Island under the administration of Commissioner William Williams was begun yesterday afternoon at the office of ex-District Attorney Eugene A. Philbin, who is one of the commission.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 5. -- It was definitely stated to-night by the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Navy Athletic Association that there will be a football game between the West Point and Annapolis teams on Nov. 28.

PORT OF SPAIN, Island of Trinidad, Oct. 5. -- Emissaries of President Castro of Venezuela have arrived at Ciudad Bolivar, Venezuela, with orders to collect forcibly not only the taxes, but the Custom House duties already paid by importers from May, 1902, to August, 1903, the period during which the revolutionists occupied that city as a Government de facto.

BIRMINGTON, Ala., Oct. 5. -- Twelve thousand coal miners in Alabama have had their wages reduced, the cut having become effective Oct. 1. Those of the Tennessee Coal and Iron and Railroad Company have been reduced 5 cents a ton, or to 52 1/2 cents, and those in the employ of the Sloss-Sheffield Steel and Iron Company have been reduced to 55 cents.

Increases in appropriations for the coming year amounting to almost $3,700,000 over those of 1903 were asked for by the heads of seven city departments at the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday to consider the budget for 1904.

The Republican Convention to nominate Assembly candidates were held in every Assembly district in New York County last night. The Aldermanlc Conventions of the Republican Party in the forty-four Aldermanic districts of Manhattan and the Bronx, will be held to-night.

Mr, W.J. BRYAN contributes to the discussion of the negro suffrage problem a letter published in The Evening Post, of which that journal remarks that it "adds neither-wisdom nor courage to the discussion of a momentous issue." It seems to us, on the contrary, that Mr. BRYAN'S letter is logical and sensible.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Oct. 5 -- At the seventy-fourth semi-annual General Conference of the Mormon Church to-day Apostle John W. Taylor bitterly attacked Christian Science, evolution, hypnotism, and Presbyterianism. He said the cure for the blight in orchards is to cut off the diseased part and burn it.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The following considerations should make the election of Low as sure as day:

There was a circus at Barnard College yesterday. It was entirely a college girls' affair, arranged and acted by members of the junior class as a welcoming entertainment for the freshmen. This circus took place in the Barnard Theatre in the afternoon, and every member of the troupe, from the ringmistress to the peanut girl, was a Banardite.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the letter of Mr. Sturge in last Saturday's TIMES with much interest. If any railroad corporation should treat animals with as little regard to their comfort and feeling's as the Brooklyn Rapid Transit use the people or Brooklyn the humane society would see to it that their charter was revoked.

GLASGOW, Oct. 6. -- Whatever may be the opinion held regarding the great question which Mr. Chamberlain has raised or the probable issue of his campaign, it is generally admitted that he has opened it in a masterly manner, befitting the momentous occasion, and that he can no longer be accused of nebulosity in presenting his case.
Visitors to Procter's Twenty-third Street Theatre this weeK will read on the programme the following announcement:

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The morning papers devote ample space both to the reports of and to comment on Mr. Chamberlain's great effort at Glasgow, but it cannot be said that the public will gain much enlightenment except from the late Colonial Secretary's own words. Conversion to his views appears as distant as ever from the columns which have hitherto been opposed to him.
LENOX, Mass., Oct. 6. -- The Misses Thompson of New York, who have been occupying the Peters cottage since June, have closed their residence and returned to New York.
McKEESPORT, Penn., Oct. 6. -- At 4 o'clock to-day the last turn at the Demmler Tin Plate Works was made, and the mills have been closed for an indefinite period.

Arthur M. Hunter, formerly a stock broker, of 52 Broadway, who resides at 772 Park Avenue, made an assignment yesterday to Louis M. Ogden. He began business as Hunter Gould in January, 1886, which firm continued for a year, when it dissolved, and Mr. Hunter formed the firm of Hunter Brothers.
Money on call on stock collateral loaned at 2@2 1/2 per cent., with the last loan at 2. Most of the day's loans were at 2 1/2 per cent.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 6. -- In the town election here yesterday there was an unusually brisk business in votes carried on. The votes were bought in a wholesale way, and the managers of one political party were as much to blame as the other.

From the inner circles of Tammany Hall last night came the intimation that ex-State Senator John F. Ahearn has been selected as the probable nominee for Borough President on the Tammany ticket. The Borough Convention will be held in Tammany Hall to-morrow evening, and most of the district leaders last evening at the Democratic Club had received the Ahearn tip.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Henry A. Castle, Auditor for the Post Office Department, to-day completed the trial balance for the fourth quarter of the year, which allows a final announcement of the income and outgo of the entire postal service for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1903. The footings are as follows:

After the announcement that the Morse Iron Works and Dry Dock Company had been forced to close its large Brooklyn plant as a result of strikes, it became known yesterday that the lawyers for the concern had filed a petition in bankruptcy, and that United States Circuit Judge Thomas, sitting in Brooklyn, appointed a receiver Monday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- The intercollegiate lawn tennis championship tournament was begun to-day on the grounds of the Merion Cricket Club at Haverford. The entry list was fair and the contest good. Princeton's entries fared badly, not one of them surviving the two rounds. The summary:

Yesterday's decline in exchange, following close upon Monday's reduction, in the price of bar gold in London, brought the rate for sterling exchange quite close to the point at which we could import gold, should we wish to do so.

The Fusion conference held last evening at the Citizens' Union headquarters decided by a unanimous vote to indorse Frederick W. Hinrichs of Brooklyn for the Fusion nomination for Controller to replace Edward M. Grout on the Fusion ticket, and practically decided to indorse Edward J. McGuire, an assistant in the Corporation Counsel's office, for the nomination for President of the Board of Aldermen to replace Charles V. Fornes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- There is an aftermath of the Post Office investigation which is dreaded as much in the department as anything that has gone before. This is the weeding out of a considerable number of persons who have committed minor offerises and misdemeanors, which make it necessary to dismiss them from office.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Mme. Marie L. Ranke, nee Petif de la Gautrois, who came to Montclair with references from several members of the fashionable set in New York City, in whose homes she had been a tutor in French, and German, was arrested this morning on a charge of larceny preferred by her negro butler.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The stir created in Washington by the struggle at the White House with an armed madman yesterday has not subsided yet, and all the city was busy discussing the episode today. Public sentiment, however, is more or less inclined to sympathy with the lunatic Swede, Elliott.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Although a non-suit was taken to-day before Justice Cochrane in the case against Edward J. Morgan, the actor, and George B. Weaver, President of the Stratford Hotel Company, charged with disorderly conduct and resisting an officer, the incident has confirmed a bit of stage gossip.
Chicago advices state that the Chicago Telephone Company has issued $1,000,000 new stock, thus completing the $2,000,000 voted last Spring.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- The money market shows increased ease, but without appreciable change in rates. Call loans, 3@4 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 6@ 6 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount; clearings.

The Republican and Citizens' Union conventions to nominate candidates for the offices of Controller and President of the Board of Aldermen to take the places on the Fusion ticket of Edward M. Grout and Charles V. Fornes will be held this evening, the former at Carnegie Hall and the latter at Cooper Union.

DENVER, Oct. 6. -- In consequence of rumore that a scandal of wide proportions had developed in the management of the campaign of the Colorado National Guard at the scene of the Cripple Creek strike, Gov. Peabody to-day gave out the following statement:

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 6. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railroad Company was held here to-day, the annual statement approved, and the following Directors reelected: F.H. Davis, New York; John E. Searles, New York, and L.F. Day, Minneapolis.

Price movement in the outside market was downward, with such representative stocks as American Can preferred, Seaboard Air Line issues. Northern Securities, and Interbordugh Rapid Transit declining from 5/8 to 1 7/8, with no recovery except in Northern Securities, which rose 3/4 from the lowest, closing at 86 1/4 a fractional decline from Monday's final sale.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- An electric car on the Marlenfelde-Zossen experimental line reached a speed of 125 4-5 miles an hour to-day, or a kilometer more than the highest previous record. The machinery and roadbed were unimpaired. The engineers are determined to try for still higher speeds and venture the opinion that they will be able to attain the rate of 140 miles per hour.

Suspense in regard to the dividend policy of the United States Steel Corporation was set at rest yesterday by the declaration of a dividend of one-half of 1 per cent, for the quarter on the company's common stock, a reduction of one-half of 1 per cent, from the previous rate, which had been maintained since the inauguration of dividends two years ago.

Inquiry among several investment houses yesterday developed a distinctly hopeful expression of opinion concerning the present phase of the stock market. On market conditions themselves, it was believed that the reaction from the depression that characterized the early days of last week had become permanent, but more than this, there was a general idea that the public was buying once more for investment purposes.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- At the first annual meeting of the Boston Steamship Company this morning the Directors were re-elected. The Treasurer's report, showing assets and liabilities as of Aug. 1. 1903, gave both as $2,436,502, a profit and loss account of $58,397 being included among the assets.
Republican Conventions to nominate candidates for Member of the Board of Aldermen were held last night in every Aldermanic district of Manhattan and the Bronx.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 6. -- James Lynchehaun, who escaped from an Irish prison where he was serving a life sentence for assault, was pursued to this country and arrested and is now fighting against being taken back, took the stand to-day.

Mayer S. Auerbach has bought, through F. Foehrenbach, Jr., from the estate of Nicholas Christy, 134 and 136 West Twenty-fifth Street, a plot 50 by 81 and irregular, now covered by two three-story dwellings.

MONTREAL, Oct. 6. -- A new scandal has been sprung on the Montreal public, and several arrests will probably have taken place before noon to-morrow. Another result will be that several people who had bought coats for the Winter will have to get new coats or go cold.

Papers were filed yesterday in the office of United States Commissioner. Shields against Minnie Maddern Fiske, the actress; her husband and manager, Harrison Gray Fiske, and Paul Heyse, author of the play "Mary of Magdala," asking for an accounting of all the moneys received through the representation of the play in question.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- In affirming a decree of Judge Kohisaat to-day. Judges Jenkins, Baker, and Bunn of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, held that there was no fraud in the transaction by which the American Exchange National Bank in 1896 sold 1,000 shares of American Cereal Company stock, which had been deposited as collateral security for a debt of $30,000 by Ferdinand Schumacher.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- Miss Rhona Adair, the woman golf champion of England and Ireland, who is now in this country as the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Clement A. Griscom at Haverford, sustained her golfing reputation nobly to-day in the first round of the invitation tournament given in her honor by Mrs. Griscom on the long eighteen-hole course of the Merion Cricket Club.

Great reductions in the first and second cabin as well as steerage rates on transatlantic steamship lines are looked for in the near future, because of the withdrawal of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company, the Hamburg-American Steam-ship Company, the Holland-America Steam-ship Company, and the Compagnie Generale Trans-Atlantique, from the agreements of the North Atlantic conference, which fixed the minimum rates for the cabin passengers.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says La Petite Republique publishes the text of two revolutionary manifestoes addressed respectively to the officers and soldiers of the Russian Army in April and August. The first manifesto refers to the shameless clique governing Russia and urges the officers not to lead their men into a fratricidal war with their countrymen.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 6. -- In a convention where Gov. Garvin, the Democratic Executive, was denounced for defaming the State by his recent declarations that wholesale bribery existed here, and where National issues and the necessity for re-electing President Roosevelt and Senator Aldrich were preached, the Rhode Island Republicans to-day nominated the following ticket:

The report of the Erie Railroad Company for the year ended June 30 last, being the system's eighth annual report, has just-been made public. It shows an increase of nearly $3,000,000 in the company's net earnings. The gross earnings in detail compared with those of 1902 were as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- The stock market conditions showed no change. Trading was excessively dull, and prices were almost stationary. An exception was Bell Telephone, an Odd lot of which sold at 55. The last previous sale was made in August at 67, just before the cut in the dividend rate. There was some good buying of Philadelphia Electric, which the Street regarded as significant, although no news developed on the property.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Services in memory of the late Sir Michael Henry Herbert, the Ambassador of Great Britain to the United States, were held at noon to-day in St. John's Episcopal Church. Precisely at 12 o'clock President Roosevelt, accompanied by Mrs. Roosevelt, Miss Roosevelt, Secretary Loeb, and Col. Symons and Commander Cowles, respectively his military and naval aides, entered the church.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- There is practically but one opinion of the reconstructed British Cabinet, and that is that Premier Balfour missed his opportunity to rehabilitate the character of his Government, and that so far as the Unionist policy at large is concerned the Ministry has lost most of its prestige and authority.

BOYESEN -- BARCLAY. -- On Wednesday, September 23, 1903, by the Rev. William Reid Blackie, Adelaide Mott, daughter of James L. and the late Olivia M. Barclay, to Algernon Keen Boyesen, son of the late Prof. Hjalmar Hjorth Boyesen.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 6. -- Among the departures to-day were Mrs. J. Stewart Barney and her mother, Mrs. Van Nest Who have occupied the Eldridge villa during the past Summer; Mrs. Hall, wife of Major Charles Hall, who occupied the stone cottage, and Miss Louise McAllister, who has been visiting Mrs. William Grosvenor.

All the football games scheduled for this afternoon are of the trying out order, but the season has so far advanced that the next series, of contests will be of considerable importance as they will have a distinct bearing on the standing of the big teams this year. Following is the schedule for to-day:

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct 6. -- The advocates of canal enlargement are feeling much encouraged over the gradually developing favorable sentiment in Chautauqua County, which has been considered one of the strong anti-canal counties of the State. This sentiment has been materially strengthened by the recent authorized statement or Justice John S. Lambert, who presided at the Molineux trial.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The golfers of New York City who use the publics links at Van Cortlandt Park feel that a word of commendation should be said of Commissioner Eustis. It is generally conceded that Mr. Eustis has been an efficient officer in his relation to the parks and their improvement, and the golfers feel that he has done all in his power to afford them increased facilities.

Nine of the forty-two automobiles entered for the first annual endurance contest of the National Association of Automobile Manufacturers from this city to Pittsburg, which starts this morning, failed to appear to weigh in yesterday in this city, and it was announced that five of this number had definitely withdrawn from the contest.
LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Money was plentiful in the market to-day, and discounts were consequently easier, with a renewal of the Continental demand for bills.

The new National Bank of Commerce which went into operation yesterday, by reason of the amount of its capital and surplus, the volume of its deposits, and the great interests that are associated in its management, becomes from the very beginning one of the most important financial institutions ever organized.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 6. -- Notwithstanding showers and threatening weather the first game on the home grounds of the world's championship series between Pittsburg and Boston was played to-day, resulting in a victory for the local team, 5 to 4. The weather conditions kept the attendance down, although a good-sized crowd witnessed the game.

The best horses as indicated by public form all but swept the programme at Morris Park yesterday, post favorites winning in five races of the six on the card, but at that the sport was in no way tame, as winners had to light hard and do their very best to get to the post first in two instances.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The body of Sir Michael Herbert, the late British Ambassador at Washington, was Interred-this afternoon in the family burial ground at Wilton, Wiltshire. The funeral was largely private. King Edward and the Prince of Wales sent representatives. Ambassador Choate, Secretary White, and Second Secretary Carter of the American Embassy represented the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- Argument was heard by the United States Court of Appeals in this city to-day on the appeal of the United States Shipbuilding Company from a decision of Judge Kirkpatrick of the New Jersey United States Circuit Court appointing James Smith, Jr., receiver of the shipbuilding company.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 6. -- John W. Newbury and Rudolph Neumann, President and Secretary and Treasurer of the Mercantile Building and Loan Association of this place and Red Bank, were this afternoon sentenced to fines and imprisonment.

PRINCETON, Oct. 6. -- It came out here to-day that Lawrenceville and Andover will renew the athletic relations which were broken off in 1898, due to the distance between these large preparatory schools and a slight unfriendly feeling.

The will of Mrs. Mary P. Lewis, a daughter of the late Edwin A. Stevens of Hoboken, and widow of Col. Edwin P.C. Lewis, at one time Minister to Portugal, was filed yesterday for probate with Surrogate Lillis, at Jersey City. Edwin A.S. Stevens and Charles M. Ghapin are named as executors.

The system of public education in this country is imperfect and vicious, and undermines the religion of our youth. We want our children to receive an education that will not only make them learned, but pious, men and women.

With martial pomp the Honourable Artillery Company of London, 165 strong, and their hosts, the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company or Boston, reinforced, by the Newport Light Artillery, invaded New York State yesterday, and after having everything their own way at the United States Military Academy, at West Point, entered the metropolis in triumph.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- There was a slight increase in the volume of trading today, but it was due wholly to an increased business in the arbitrage stocks, Reading, Erie, and United Stages Steel being quite active. Transactions were also large in Consolidated Lake Superior common, and Philadelphia Electric was again animated.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The financial article in to-day's issue of your paper closes with this paragraph:

That Charles M. Schwab and the banking firm of J.P. Morgan Co. cleared millions of dollars by selling the Bethlehem Steel Works to the now bankrupt United States Shipbuilding Company was one of the many statements made yesterday by Daniel Le Roy Dresser, witness at the hearing ordered by Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick of the United States District Court in the case of Roland R. Conklin and others, first mortgage bondholders, against the shipbuilding combination.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 -- Harvard won from Bates to-day in a rather nondescript game by the score of 23 to 0. Only once did the visitors show any strength, and that was when they held Harvard for downs on their own five-yard line, just in time to prevent Harvard from making a fifth touchdown at the very last of the second half.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 -- The thirty-first annual meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association opened under inauspicious circumstances to-day. A heavy and lumpy track and a downpour of rain delayed the races. Summary:

While the Republican and Citizens' Union Conventions held last night to nominate candidates for Controller and President of the Board of Aldermen to replace Edward M. Grout and Charles V. Fornes on the Fusion ticket were not estopped from carrying out their purpose by any notice of an injunction on behalf of Mr. Grout or Mr. Fornes, they did not lack excitement.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 7 -- United States Senator Foster and other lumbermen, representing timber interests valued at more than $50,000,000, to-day attended a meeting here the object of which was to protest against the Government's policy of creating more forest reserves in the Northwest.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 7 -- Nome advices state that the Alaska Indians and Eskimos are reduced to starvation because of department ignorance at Washington, as crystallized in the Alaska game law passed in June of last year. Statistics have been forwarded to Washington showing that the new law has proved so disastrous to the natives that a move is on foot to secure material amendments to its provisions.

The Independent People's Party, the organization of which William S. Devery is the leading light, held its county and borough conventions simultaneously last night in a hall above "The Pump," in Eighth Avenue, and nominated Thomas Rock for Sheriff and John W. Johnston for Presideht of the Borough of Manhattan.

A score of Ellis Island missionaries, representing several nationalities and creeds, were present yesterday afternoon in Eugene A. Philbin's office at the hearing before the commission appointed by the President to inquire into the condition of affairs at the immigration Bureau. All of them highly commended the work of Commissioner Williams, but most of them had suggestions to make as to how matters on the island could be improved.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I having read carefully your statement on the reduction of one-half of 1 per cent. on common stock of United States Steel, and seeing that two of the Directors had to make an apology for the reduction of same, I would like to state I am a stockholder of the common stock, and I look on the whole matter as a Wall Street trick.

Largest of all the items of the budget, hearing on which was resumed by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday, was the estimate of the Board of Education, presented by President Rogers, which called for $23,260,472 for 1904, as against $20,063,017 allowed last year.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 -- The seventh annual convention of the League of American Municipalities began here to-day and will continue during three days. Robert M. McLane. Mayor of Baltimore, delivered a brief address of welcome, which was responded to by J. Adger Smyth. President of the league and Mayor of Charleston, S.C.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 7 -- M.E. Ingalls, President of the Big Pour Railroad Company, was to-day asked: "In your opinion has the period of uncertainty in the financial market, which was manifested by the flurry in stocks, passed away?"

The chaotic condition of the Democratic organization in Brooklyn was made evident last night, when Martin W. Littleton, the Democratic candidate for Borough President, made his first campaign speech at the Seymour Club, Senator McCafren's organization in the Fourteenth Assembly District, at 186 Bedford Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 7 -- Miss Rhona Adair, the English and Irish woman golf champion, continued her winning career to-day in Mrs. Clement A. Griscom's invitation tournament at the Merion Cricket Club by defeating Miss Pauline Mackay of the Oakley Country Club, near Boston, by 4 up and 3 to play.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 7 -- Samuel Holmes, a contractor, to-day filed a bill in equity against the Journeymen Stone Cutters' Association, Pittsburg branch, to restrain it from interfering with his workmen. He also entered suit for $10,000 damages against Frederick Schaubhul and Lewis Ruoff, officials of the branch, for interfering with his employes while at work.

LEXINGTON, S.C., Oct. 7 -- The defense in the case of J.H. Tillman entered upon the presentation of its testimony to-day. Solicitor Thurmond announced when the trial was resumed that the State had no further evidence and would rest. Nine witnesses for the defense were heard. It is estimated that the defense will consume the remainder of the week with its witnesses.

The result of the speed trials on the Zossen-Marienfelde Railway, showing that it is possible with electric propulsion to attain a speed of 125 4-5 miles an hour is very interesting; but it is probable that a great deal more importance will attach to the achievement in popular judgment than really belongs to it.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 -- An extension of seven months' time is asked of their creditors by the banking firm of J. William Middendorf Co. of Baltimore and John L. Williams Sons of Richmond, Va. The Advisory Committee in a circular Issued to-day shows that the assets of John L. Williams Sons exceed the liabilities of that firm by $894,345.70.

Thirty-four contesting cars and two piloting vehicles started from Weehawken yesterday morning in the first annual endurance run of the National Association of Automobile Manufacturers from this city to Pittsburg. Every type of pleasure automobile was represented, from the light runabout, weighing less than 900 pounds, to the heavy touring car of more than 2,800 pounds.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- A decision involving a very large amount and reversing the finding of the United States Circuit Court was sent down to-day by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in the case of the Western Union Telegraph Company and others vs. the American Bell Telephone Company.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Continuing his fiscal campaign, Mr. Chamberlain last night addressed a meeting of 4,000 persons in the Town Hall of Greenock. He spoke for an hour and a quarter, and dealt particularly with the questions of retaliation and reciprocity.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The Times's Russian correspondents describe a courtmartial which has just been held at Taganrog on twenty-three Socialists, including a youth of nineteen years old and two young women, who were accused of taking part in the strike riots at Rostoff last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- It has often been said that when a crank makes a scene at the White House or around the person of the President of the United States and the newspapers are filled with accounts of the affair the incident arouses all the other cranks in the country and they begin to write to the President all manner of crazy letters or to migrate in the direction of Washington.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Henry B. Wenck, a comparatively poor carpenter, was notified to-day by the receiver of the Navesink National Bank of this place that notes purporting to be drawn by him to the amount of $30,000 are about to fall due and calling on him to appear and take them up. This notification was a surprise to Mr. Wenek, who claims he never made the notes.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- The money market presents no new feature. The tone remains easy, but no actual change in rates is noted. Call loans, 3@4 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 6@6 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount @ par. Clearings, $21,841,481; balances, $1,147,171.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 7 -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company was held in the office of President Milton H. Smith at noon to-day. The majority of stock was represented by proxies placed in the hands of various stockholders and officers.

In every instance where the more important college football teams played yesterday the result was very one-sided. None of the big elevens was scored against, so that they have a clear record so far this season. No serious difficulty was looked for by any of the principal 'Varsity teams from the players who opposed them, and the contests yesterday were nothing more than practice games for them.

Racegoers enjoyed or suffered, as the case might be, more than their usual share of excitement and uncertainty at the Morris Park race track yesterday, for all that the crowd witnessed of the contests came when the horses were finishing, fog shutting the horses out of sight through the earlier running.

Scenes that counterparted a busy day on the Stock Exchange occurred yesterday at a great silk auction at 87 and 80 Leonard Street. Buyers of the greatest houses in the country, from Maine to California and Florida, were there, and, beginning at 10 o'clock in the morning, had by 4:45 P.M. bought in no less than 13,000 pieces of silk.

The Morristown Horse Show will be the event of to-day in the suburbs. In town there will be the wedding of Miss Elizabeth Lefferts and Capt. Sladen. At Ardsley on Hudson there will be the children's fete in aid of the Stony Wold Sanitorium.

TRENTON, Oct. 7 -- Charles Dougherty of 16 Crawford Street, Newark, fourteen years old and undersized, made so good a witness in the $75,000 damage suit of Arthur J. Hogan against the United Electric Company, on trial in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, that Judge Kirkpatrick called the little fellow to him and said:
The fourteenth annual report of the Wabash Railroad Company has just been issued, being for the year ended June 30 last. It shows earnings, expenses, c., compared with those of 1902, as follows:

WIDEWATER, Va., Oct. 7 -- The sixty-foot steel-built flying machine, the climax of years of exhaustive study in the efforts of Prof. Samuel P. Langley, Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, to solve the problem of mechanical flight in mid-air, was launched to-day, and the experiment, carefully planned and delayed, for months, proved a complete failure.

A century ago New York was the third city in the United States. Philadelphia and Boston surpassed it in population, in manufactures, and in commercial importance. The building of the Erie Canal raised New York to the first place. Before that waterway was opened it cost in the neighborhood of $100 to transport a ton of freight from the lakes to this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The State Department has not received direct confirmation of The Associated Press's information from Yokohama, but officials say they would not be surprised to receive such confirmation at any time from Minister Conger. They say they are fully prepared to believe the news that Russia has served notice on China that she will not evacuate Manchuria until her latest demands are granted.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Conscious of the "very sad and significant mistake" which I make, I have not the slightest hesitation in saying of Columella's phrase Tauri effeti that it is absurd in form and a "bull," indeed. It is exactly parallel to a phrase I read the other day in a newspaper -- "an ancillary administrator."

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 7 -- A crowd of 12,322 persons occupied every seat in the grand stand and bleachers and every available foot of standing room, and then overflowed into the field three or four deep to witness the second game here of the championship series. Except for the high winds it was an ideal day for baseball.
A. Goodman has sold 27 and 29 West One Hundred and Twelfth Street, two five-story flats on plot 50 by 100.11.

After Mrs. Marie Layton Johnston, wife of Dr. Albert M. Johnston, the Fifth Avenue dentist, had been committed to the Tombs yesterday under five indictments charging grand larceny and forgery, a new and perplexing feature was added to the already troubled situation of which for many days she has been the central figure.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 7 -- Mrs. J.J. Post, Miss Mahoney, and H.C. Mahoney have returned from Europe, where they have been since early Summer, and are at their cottage on Bellevue Avenue.
The following securities were sold yesterday at public auction by Adrian H. Muller Son at the New York Real Estate Salesroom:

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 7 -- Invitations were issued in Stockbridge to-day for the wedding of Miss Irene Bottsfield of Stockbridge and Chicago to Bernard Hoffman of New York at the home of the bride, on Interlaken Road, Saturday, Oct. 17. Mr. Hoffman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hoffman of New York.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 7 -- The high water in Lake Union at 6 o'clock this morning burst through the dam's retaining walls at the side of the first gates at the head of the Government canal. The gates are still standing, but the flood has eaten a big channel around the lock.

YOKOHAMA, Oct. 7 -- According to information received here the Russian Minister at Peking, M. Lessar, has informed the Chinese Foreign Office that Russia will never evacuate Manchuria unless her latest demands are granted.

DARMSTADT, Oct. 7 -- In the presence of a notable gathering, which included an Emperor, an Empress, a King, and two Queens, the marriage of Princess Alice of Battenberg and Prince Andreas of Greece was celebrated to-day according to the rites of the Lutheran and Greek Churches.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Supplies of money were plentiful in the market to-day, and discounts were controlled by Continental competition for bills.

Trading in the outside market was centred principally in Greene Consolidated Copper, Northern Securities, and Seaboard Air Line common, and these stocks along with practically the entire list were heavy and declined, with the principal loss in Seaboard Air Line common. International Mercantile Marine preferred, which sold on Tuesday up to 18 1/2, was yesterday traded in at 16 3/4, a decline of 1 2/4.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Oct. 8. -- At a meeting held to-day and presided over by George Westinghouse, the Canadian Westinghouse Company, Limited, was organized, with a capital of $2,500,000. The new company is a consolidation of all the Westinghouse interests in Canada, which heretofore have been conducted individually.

Falling the merely Personal interest of his first play this year, Mr. William Collier last night brought out a new piece agitating the question of his father. To do this he was obliged to abandon the sober modern wear and racy dialogue in which he has so long been welcome and familiar and don the more variegated trousers and the less variegated slang of 1840.

BOSTON, Oct. 8. -- The money market continues to work easier, but the demand for funds shows no material increase. Call loans, 3@4 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount @ par.

ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 8. -- The seventh annual meeting of the stockholders of the Norfolk and Western Railway Company was held to-day. Over 83 per cent. of the whole stock was represented in the meeting. Henry Fink of New York, Chairman of the Board of Directors, presided, and A. J. Hemphill was Secretary.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- The arguments in the Alaska boundary arbitration were finished at 3:40 P.M. to-day. Jacob M. Dickinson of American counsel concluded with an eloquent peroration, dealing with the bonds of amity between the United States and Great Britain.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The Foreign Office informs The Associated Press that it has heard nothing of the reported gathering of Russian warships at Masam-Pho. The Foreign Office reiterates that Government advices give no indication of the possibility of a Russian-Japanese outbreak.

NORFOLK, va., Oct. 8. -- Following a confession of judgment in the Court of Law and Chancery for $2,333:16, by the Bayshore, Terminal Company in favor of Henry E. Finck of Baltimore, suit was entered in the United States Court to-day for the appointment of a receiver for the Bay Shore Company.

Lieut. Col. James Parker, Assistant Adjutant General, upon the completion of his duty as umpire during the manoeuvres at West Point, Ky., will proceed to Fort Riley and report to Major Gen. John C. Bates for assignment to duty as umpire during the army manoauvres to take place at Fort Riley.

A Stock Exchange seat, it was announced yesterday, has just sold for $52,500. This is a drop of about $7,000 from the price at which several seats were sold a short time ago, and a decline of over $30,000 from the highest price at which the seats have sold.

Activity was at a low ebb yesterday in the trading in outside securities, and the weakness displayed on the Exchange was reflected in the outside market. With the single exception of Standard Oil, which rose 2 points every stock showing a change was lower, with especial weakness in International Mercantile Marine and Seaboard Air Line issues.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Much interest was manifested here over the endurance run of automobiles from New York to Pittsburg, in which Binghamton is the second day's objective. At 4:50 o'clock this afternoon the two pilot cars of the run reached the city. They reported that roads were in a frightful condition.

With Tammany Hall conducting an agressive warfare for the annihilation of the Hugh McLaughlin organization in Kings County, and with McLaughlin, aided by James Shevlin, John L. Shea, and Martin W. Littleton, making a bitter fight to oust Senator Patrick H. McCarren from the organization because of his pro-Tammany proclivities, Brooklyn yesterday became the storm centre of the Mayoralty campaign.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 8. -- D.C. Moon has been appointed Assistant General Superintendent of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern. Indiana, Illinois and Iowa, and Lake Erie. Alliance and Wheeling lines, with headquarters at Cleveland. The appointment takes effect Oct. 10. H.A. Boomer succeeds Mr. Moon as Assistant General Superintendent of the Lake Erie and Western.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 8. -- Rumors which have been current for some time affecting the relations of William B. Given, President of the Lancaster County Railway and Light Company, with that company, culminated to-day in the announcement that Mr. Given has tendered his resignation as President and that serious discrepancies, amounting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--The State Department has been informed that the American-Chinese commercial treaty has been signed. An imperial Chinese decree has made the treaty effective so far as China is concerned, but it must be ratified by the United States Senate before ratifications can be exchanged and the treaty put in operation.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Payne Thompson closed their cottage to-day. Mrs. Thompson left for Roslyn, L. I., and Mr. Thompson for a two months' hunting trip in Wyoming.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--"Graft" evidence poured in to-day when the City Council Investigating Committee opened its session. Before the Aldermen had been togther two hours detailed charges were offered against several city employes. John J. Brown, who has been Acting Police Pension Clerk, is on the rack as a result of accusations of extortion.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- J.F. Arondoz has been arrested by United States Secret Service Agent George W. Hazen. Arondez was taken from the Japanese ship Nippon Maru as she came alongside her clock from the Angel Island quarantine station. The arrest was made at the request of George J.G. Marslly, Consul of the Netherlands at this port.

The Republican nominations of Frederic W. Hinrichs, Fusion candidate for Controller, and Edward J. McGuire, Fusion candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, were filed with the Board of Elections yesterday by George R. Manchester as Secretary of the Republican Convention, at 3:30 o'clock in the afternoon.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 8. -- Judge Gray of the Coal Strike Commission has appointed Carroll D. Wright umpire in connection with the question of the short working day on Saturdays in the Schuylkill region. Mr. Wright was the umpire in five matters recently decided.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 8. -- Leading representatives of the national and international organizations of building and repairing trades met this afternoon in conference for the purpose of bringing their respective organizations into an international federation having for its object the arbitration, adjudication, and conduct of building trades affairs.

Without a hitch in the programme as laid down by Charles F. Murphy, the Tammany Hall- County and Borough Conventions, held last night in the Fourteenth Street Wigwam, ratified the slate by naming John F. Ahearn for Borough President and Mitchell L. Erlanger for Sheriff, and renominating Justice Henry Bischoff, Jr., for the Supreme Court bench.
There is one young man who loves music better than gold, and it was this fact which yesterday caused the transference of himself and a fellow-burglar from a barber's shop to a prison cell.

The present political campaign promises to become a real circus before it is much older, with a menagerie as an addition to its other attractions. It was Great Oak Johnson of the Acorns who first hit upon the idea of supplementing the entertainment in the big ring by exhibiting a live tiger as an argument.

The Directors of the Interurban Street Railway Company, lessor of the Metropolitan Street Railway system, issued the company's first annual report yesterday, for the year ended June 30. In giving out the report President H.H. Vreeland commented upon the fullness with which the results of the company's operation were given.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 8. -- The Boston Americans and Pittsburg Nationals now are tied for the world's baseball championship honors, as the visitors won to-day's game by the score of 6 to 3. Although a high wind made matters uncomfortable for the spectators, another large attendance was registered at the turnstiles, and ground rules again were adopted.

"You're as good as I am, as bad as I am: but as good as you are and as bad as I am, I'm as good as you are as bad as I am," said the Earl of Denbigh to Col. Hedges of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery of Boston as he entered a carriage with the Colonel at the Waldorf-Astoria, bound for the luncheon given by the Old Guard at Claremont yesterday afternoon.

"Neither the firm of J.P. Morgan Co. nor any partner ever had any connection with the inception, organization, or financing of the United States Shipbuilding Company, nor have they ever received or owned any of its securities. As managers of the United States Steel Syndicate, we held the Bethlehem Steel Company stock until a purchaser could be found.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- In the suit of Gould's Western Maryland Railroad against the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad for diversion of traffic, David Parke, formerly freight and coal billing clerk and general agent of the Baltimore and Ohio at Piedmont, West Va., testified to-day. He said:

In making up their minds whether they will vote for or against the expenditure of $101,000,000 for the improvement of the canals, the farmers of New York should think for themselves. If their thinking is done for them in the offices of great railroads, if they accept without challenge or examination the statements made to them by hired speakers at mass meetings organized by the opposition, they will be grievously misled

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Circuit Attorney Folk of St. Louis, whose efforts to secure the punishment of grafters have been partly hullified by the escape of some to foreign countries, called at the White House to-day to urge upon the President the negotiation of extradition treaties to secure their return.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 8. -- Daniel V. Miller, late Assistant Attorney for the Post Office Department, and Joseph Johns, lawyer, were indicted by the United States Grand Jury to-day, charged with conspiracy to commit an offense against the United States.

LEXINGTON, S.C., Oct. 8. -- James H. Tillman went on the stand to-day as a witness in his own behalf in his trial for the murder of N.G. Gonzales. It was just one hour before adjournment that his counsel asked that the defendant be called. With perfect self-composure, he arose from his scat among his attorneys and walked to the clerk's desk to take the oath.
Sir Thomas Lipton sails for Liverpool this morning at 7 o'clock on the White Star liner Cedric, and last night he risked another attack of appendicitis in order to say good-bye to all his friends.
LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Rates for money and discounts were easy in the market to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 8. -- The second round of match play in the invitation golf tournament given by Mrs. C.A. Griscom at the Morion Cricket Club was concluded to-day under miserable weather conditions. When the matches were started a gale of wind was blowing from the south, and by the time the first pair reached the sixth tee, heavy rain began to fall.

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- It is learned in authoritative quarters this evening that the terms of a general treaty of arbitration between France and Great Britain have been concluded between Foreign Minister Delcasse and the authorities in London.

Our State Department seems to have determined to let Russia "stew in her own juice" as regards the evacuation of Manchuria. The integrity of China is not formally threatened by the Russian occupation, and our own commercial rights and interests are sufficiently safeguarded by the commercial treaty with China, which was to be signed yesterday.

D. Kellogg Baker, seventy-two years old, committed suicide yesterday morning in the Everett House by shooting himself in the head. He had registered at the hotel the previous night. A note directing that his widow, who lives at the St. James Hotel, 109 West Forty-fifth Street, and his nephew, Lucien S. Bayliss, a lawyer, of 76 William Street, be notified, led to his identification.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Oct. 8. -- The House of Representatives has passed the Coast-wise Trade bill, which prevents ships of those countries which discriminate against British shipping from carrying cargo and passengers between New Zealand ports.

Stock Exchange business turned yesterday upon two factors, one of which had been long anticipated and which most had thought would be beneficial, and the other related to ancient history, uncovering a peril from which the public had escaped. It might have been thought, as it was thought and said by good judges, that progress by the Steel Trust along a road which it should have taken sooner would be beneficial.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for Francis M. Jencks the four-story dwelling 569 West End Avenue, 20.2 by 100. The buyer will ocpupy the house.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 8. -- Driving is the chief pastime of the cottagers who are lingering in the Berkshires for the beauty of the foliage. The roads are in fine condition, and automobiles are dally passing through Lenox with tourists from New York. The hotels are still filled, and the season will be prolonged until well into November.

The dispersal sale of August Belmont's racing stable and the thoroughbred yearling horses reserved by the owner from the produce of his breeding farm in Kentucky, was hold by the Fasig-Tipton Sales Company in the paddock of the Morris Park race track yesterday before the races, and in spite of the wretched weather drew a large attendance, made up almost exclusively of horsemen representing both East and West.
