Many suggestions and some efforts, more or less sincere, have been made to correct the evils complained of, but the trouble continues with apparently unabated malignancy.

NEWPORT, Oct. 12 -- Col. John Jacob Astor has rented for the season of 1904 the Havemeyer villa, Friedheim, on Bellevue Avenue, which he occupied the past Summer, Col. and Mrs. Astor had taken the villa with the intention of entertaining in an extensive manner, but the death of Mrs. Astor's mother in the Spring placed the family in mourning, and there was no entertainment given during the season.

FREEHOLD, N.J. Oct. 12 -- The trial of David Lamar of New York and Long Branch; his brother-in-law. Bernard Smith, and "Monk" Eastman and Joseph Brown of New York, all of whom were indicted for an assault on James McMahon, a former coachman for Lamar, was begun here to-day before County Judge W.A. Heishey.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The last stage of the Alaska Boundary Tribunal's proceedings began this morning at the Foreign Office, when the Commissioners met in secret session to consider their verdict.

Chairman M. Linn Bruce of the Republican County Committee learned yesterday from his assistants, whom he has at work on the registration figures, that ten Republican districts which furnished a very large percentage of the vote for Mr. Low in 1901 showed a falling off in registration for the first two days as compared with the first two of 1901 of 23 per cent.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Mr. Chamberlain is resting at Highbury, his residence at Birmingham, and is not engaged to speak for another fortnight. He will utilize the interval to elaborate his scheme and prepare a reply to the objections raised by his opponents.

Though it will be the general verdict that Mr. GROUT, in finally surrendering to the Tammany demand that he shall support the Tammany candidate for Mayor, is where he belongs, it is still interesting to trace the way by which he got there, and the motives that have impelled him on his curious course.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I presume that the most effective time for registering a kick is just before election, and I therefore desire to Know whether THE TIMES will be generous enough to offer its assistance to the 300 or 400 young men whose names are on tie eligible list of the Board of Education for appointment.

Other newspapers in numerous other cities having taken up the question of THE NEW YORK TIMES, "When may a man in New York City be considered rich?" it now appears as if we may have a settlement of the question when a man is rich in any part of our beautiful and prosperous country.

OTTAWA, Oct. 12 -- R.L. Borden, the Conservative leader, inquired in the House to-day if the Government had taken any means to ascertain the truth at the press cable from London attributing certain statements to Mr. Aylesworth, one of the Canadian Commissioners, in connection with the Alaska boundary case.

Justice Bischoff of the Supreme Court delivered an address at the monthly meeting of the Phi Delta Phi Fraternity of New York City at the Marlborough Hotel last night. It was in the form of a "Brief for the People" in "The Court of Public Opinion" in the case of "The People of the United States vs. the Spirit of Mob Rule."

Despite the untoward weather of the past few days, the avenue has lost its deserted appearance, for many of the fashionable set are already settled in their city homes. The incoming steamers have been bringing back to their native shores numbers of those who habitually spend their Summers in Europe but their Winters in New York.

Figures summarizing the activities of the New York Clearing House, which began a new half century of its existence yesterday, furnish an interesting index of the financial development of the city in the important period just closed.

According to William F. King, one of the Directors of the Merchants' Association and a member of the firm of Calhoun, Robbins Co., the country to-day is in a generally prosperous condition, which will not be affected by the Wall Street depression, Mr. King said:

Refusing to heed the strongest protest made by emissaries from Tammany Hall and also declining to see Charles F. Murphy, ex-Sheriff William F. Grell last night launched his independent candidacy for Sheriff, with the avowed object of doing everything in his power to defeat the Tammany nominee, Mitchell L. Erlanger.

With the fact in mind that Columbia's football eleven has two hard games this week, one with Swarthmore to-morrow and the other with Amherst on Saturday, Coach Morley did not spare his men in yesterday's practice, but gave them the hardest sort of work. A shake-up seemed imminent, and it was forthcoming, Landers being taken from centre and being replaced by Tomlinson, the guard.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 12 -- Dr. W.P. Thirkield, Corresponding Secretary of the Methodist Freedman's Aid and Southern Educational Society, in delivering the opening address before the Evangelical Alliance to-day, charged that the outrages on the part or negroes in the South were due to the chain-gang prison system.

James V. Dignowitz, who is known as "The Mining King of Mexico," was arrested yestarday at the Waldorf-Astoria and arraigned before Justice Leventritt, in the Supreme Court to answer an action brought against him by Eugene Davis, First Vice President of the Mexican Mining and Exploration Company, to recover $100,000 damages for slander.

A burglar scare which threw the entire neighborhood into a state of great excitement, and in which a fusillade of pistol shots figured, occurred yesterday morning in the Arlington Avenue district of East New York.

Fresh from a laurel-winning tour of European tennis courts, a special journey of the German Emperor to witness their play, and the knocking off of a German Countess's hat with a smashing stroke of the hurricane American kind, Wylie C. Grant and Robert Le Roy returned home aboard the Anchor Line steamship Columbia, which grot In late on Sunday.

Extensive reductions are being made daily in the track and shop forces of the New York Central, the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern, the Lake Erie and Western, West Shore, and other affiliated Vanderbilt roads, and in fact a similar cutting down of expenses is being put into effect on the principal railroads of the country, including the Southern Pacific.

Borough President CANTOR has accomplished a useful and memorable public service in securing, after much tribulation, an appropriation from the Board of Estimate and Apportionment sufficient to begin the construction of pipe galleries for lower Broadway, in connection with the rapid transit subway now building in that thoroughfare.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 12 -- Over the first dusty roads, under their first glimpse of the sun, fifteen of the competitors in the great annual endurance test of the National Association of Automobile Manufacturers reached Erie this afternoon early. At least five more are expected to-night. The run of to-day was over ninety-six miles of hard dry roads with not one piece of bad driving to be encountered or overcome.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Canadian tariff changes are set forth in a recent report submitted to the Department of Commerce by George W. Shotts, commercial agent at Sault Ste. Marie, on the new customs act recently passed in the Dominion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Aside from extensive military preparations by both nations, the Japanese Legation here is not advised that either Russia or Japan has as yet committed any act of war. The Japanese Minister is being kept constantly advised by cablegrams from Tokio of the situation, and, realizing its gravity, he is moving with great caution.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says the rumors that the Sultan is disposed to resist the Austro-Russian scheme of control in Macedonia are acquiring consistency.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 12 -- The waters of the flood to-night had fallen more than four feet from the high-water mark of Saturday, and were still receding. Their going down revealed many strange features and freaks and several pathetic incidents of the disaster to the men who were working to rescue the few persons still isolated in the upper portions of their homes or the mills and factories.

One of the most important decisions rendered for some time, and one which importers of all classes of goods have been anxiously expecting, was handed down yesterday by the Board or General Appraisers. By it commissions charged for the purchase of goods in Europe by importers agents and brokers are no longer included in the dutiable value of importations.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 -- The feature in the market to-day was the heavy liquidation in United Gas Improvement and a 3-point break in its price to the lowest figures quoted for it in years. The movement was not unexpected, and while the bears were responsible for the start of the movement, there was large, selling of the stock, which had been carried as collateral in loans.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 12 -- Frank Buchanan, President of the International Association of Bridge and Structural Ironworkers, arrived in Pittsburg to-day from Indianapolis. Mr. Buchanan denied that he was here to order a general strike of the structural ironworkers in sympathy with New York locals now out as a result of a dispute with some of the large contracting firms of that city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A general feeling of dissatisfaction on the part of the French people with the mediocre degree of mental and moral altitude attained by the majority of the members of the Chamber of Deputies has caused a revival of the agitation in favor of a change in the method of representation by a substitution of what is called "scrutin de liste" for the present system of "scrutin d'arrondissement."

Scarfs of the different furs are soft and pliable and tie once. In the smaller articles of fur nearly as many are lined with satin as with fur. A pretty little Persian lamb collar or scarf is broad at the back with a point top and bottom. This is worn high around the throat or doubled to half the width.

BUFFALO, Oct. 12 -- "The Fortune Hunters," the new musical comedy in which the Hawthorne sisters made their debut as stars at the Teck Theatre to-night, made a hit, and the Misses Hawthorne received many curtain calls. The music is by John Mason Strauss and is bright and generally tuneful, the lyrics and topical songs being especially melodious.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 -- "Trades unions may cease to work for reasons satisfactory to their members, but if they combine to prevent others from obtaining work the combination is unlawful."
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day; partly owing to the settlement. Discounts were firm.

The weakness of the Stock Exchange market was largely reflected in the trading in curb securities, and as a result several new low records were made, about equally divided among active and inactive issues. The most prominent stock of the day was Greene Consolidated Copper, which was quite active and decidedly weak.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12 -- While Special Policeman Albert Sendkoski of 299 Littleton Avenue was on duty at a Polish wedding ceremony at 232 Springfield Avenue last night he was accosted by Xavier Stravlnski of 50 Hayes Street, who informed him that his pocket had been picked of a gold watch.

The opening of the new Lyric Theatre last evening was made especially notable by the appearance there of Richard Mansfield, an actor who is a conspicuous figure -- if, indeed, not the most conspicuous one -- in that small coterie of players who stan forth as symbols of dignified ambition, as contrasted with so much that is merely meretricious, in the general scheme of American theatricals.

Whether or not the war between Russia and Japan is so imminent as now appears, there are facts which should not be forgotten and which should and will determine American sympathies in the event of such a conflict.

There is news afoot of a Tammany campaign attack upon the administration of the Police Department under Commissioner GREENE. This is deeply interesting, for the plan of attack, when it is made known, must throw a revealing light upon the policy and intentions of Tammany.

A company numbering about 200, including Presidents or members of the Faculties of nearly all of the prominent universities of the United States, Presidents of Boards of Education, sociologists, students, and educators from a number of American cities, gathered last night at the banquet given at Sherry's to Mr. Mosely's British Educational Commission by President Butler of Columbia University.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 12 -- It is estimated that the flood has caused a los sof nearly $1,000,000 along the Delaware River. Nine bridges, each built at a cost of from $50,000 to $100,000, which spanned the river at various points between here and Eastern, were carried away. Their wreckage is strewn along the river tanks for fifty-seven miles.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- The money market shows little change. The banks display an increased disposition to put out time loans, but no material concession in rates is observed. Call loans, 3 @ 3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5 @ 6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2 @ 6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; NewYork funds, par and 5 cents discount; clearings, $18,191,622; balances, $1,596,554.

The exchange of congratulations in the meeting of the Central Federated Union in this city on Sunday last over the fact that organized labor had forced the Morse Iron Works into a receivership was an extremely instructive incident. From the report of the meeting in the news columns of THE TIMES the following extract is made as worthy of repetition for the information of whom it may concern:
The Frank L. Fisher Company has sold for Betts Baldwin to Henry A. Davis of Utica the seven-story apartment house known as the Iowa, at 135 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, 50 by 90 by 100.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 12 -- The Great Northern will spend $1,000,000 in preparing Smith's Cove, Washington, its Pacific steamship port, for the trans-Pacific lines, which will go into service within eighteen months. The improvements will occupy a year and a half and will make the Smith's Cove Harbor one of the finest on the Pacific.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While I note with approval your intention of republishing Mr. Low's admirable letter of acceptance, permit me to call to your attention (and to that of Mr. Low as well) a serious omission.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 -- Four indictments against a Police Captain were voted by the Federal Grand Jury. At least ten more indictments will be found against him during the week. Participation in the naturalization frauds is the charge. Back of the indictments is the most shameful story of debauchery in the Police Department for political ends on record in the annals of St. Louis history.

The Board of General Appraisers handed down a decision of much importance to linen importers yesterday and one which will release many importations which have been held up by the same dispute. The decision, which was written by General Appraiser de Vries, admits "union" linen goods, that is, goods composed in part of cotton, to classification as manufactures of cotton, in cases where cotton is the component material of chief value.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 13 -- "Yes, I am on my way to join the Rev. Alexander Dowie and the Zionist hosts in their crusade on vice and sin in New York City," remarked the Rev. William D. Gay to-night. "I am thoroughly convinced that Zionism is the only true religion, and its teachings will prevail.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- Reports indicating net earnings of $1,490,831 for the nine months ended June 30 were made at the annual meeting of the Massachusetts Gas Companies hero to-day. President Weld, referring to an effort now being made to annul the sale of the Boston companies, formerly controlled by J.E. Addicks's interests to Kidder, Peabody Co., said that the transaction was in full accordance with the ruling of the courts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Miss Mae C. Wood, who has left here for New York, has been receiving letters from Senator Platt for a long time, she says. Clerks in the department often saw Senator Platt take Miss Wood out riding on days when the Senate adjourned early. It was generally understood that she went to be married to the Senator, and she even went so far as to prepare her trousseau.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The prospect of an immediate outbreak of Turco-Bulgarian hostilities, according to the Sofia correspondent of The Times, diminishes with the approach of Winter. There is evidence of a desire on both sides to postpone the day of reckoning. Public attention in Bulgaria is being diverted to the impending electoral struggle.

While the games scheduled by the several college football teams for to-day are hardly significant, surprises have already disturbed calculations, and the various elevens are at the stage where decisive performances are in order to establish that confidence which is necessary for the more important contests near at hand.

The sale of the properties of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company to satisfy the Speyer loan has been obviated. This announcement was made last night at the Waldorf by a member of the committee representing Philadelphia stockholders in the corporation, as a result of a four hours' conference between attorneys of the two sides in the afternoon.

With loud hurrahs and long-continued hand clapping the members of the Medical Society of the State of New York last night voted to end the conflict which has raged between their society and the New York Medical Association for nearly a quarter of a century. Dr. D.B. St. John Roosa offered the resolution which meant an amicable settlement of the differences between the two organizations.
NEWPORT, Oct. 13 -- Mrs. Vanderbilt and Miss Gladys Vanderbilt returned to The Breakers this evening from a visit to New York.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The members, counsel, and attaches of the Alaskan Boundary Tribunal were entertained by the Lord Mayor of London, Sir Marcus Samuel, at a banquet at the Mansion House to-night. Almost all those associated with the case, from Lord Chief Justice Alverstone down, were present, though Attorney General Finlay and Sir Edward Carson were notable absentees.

Another series of international tennis competitions appears likely to be played, as the Intercollegiate Lawn Tennis Association has decided to send a challenge to Oxford and Cambridge for a series of team matches. This action was decided upon at the annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Association, and the draft of the challenge is now being prepared with the view of putting it before the English universities for their acceptance or rejection.

President Samuel Gompers and Vice President Duncan of the American Federation of Labor, having failed in their efforts to harmonize the labor factions in the building trades of this city, principally because of the continued power of Samuel J. Parks, last night made public a letter to the unions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Another attempt to extort money from prominent residents of the North Side became known to-day, when It was announced that John G. Garibaldi of the commission house of Garibaldi Cuneo had undergone, a month ago, an experience similar to that of Mrs. Orville and Mrs. Babcock.

MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- United States Commissioner of Immigration Robert Watchorn, stationed at Montreal, has denied admission to the United States to the twelve glass blowers held here, and recommended that they be taken to New York and deported to England. Unless the department at Washington decides otherwise, this course will be pursued.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Mayor Hinchliffe this afternoon estimated that the damage caused by the flood in Paterson would reach $3,000,000, exclusive of the loss of wages to those who are kept out of work.

The steamship Verona, which arrived yesterday from Japan and China, brought in fifteen survivors of the Uruguayan bark Salvador Talavera, who were rescued after she had been dismasted and had become waterlogged. The rescue was made in a sea running mountains high by volunteers from the crew of the steamship.

A good cause loses by understatement. Our neighbor The Sun would make twice the headway it is now making against President ROOSEVELT if it would speak out loud and bold about the mighty wrongs and gigantic crimes that have been perpetrated in the White House. The Sun dwells too much upon unconsidered trifles of the Executive policy, like these:

Jacob Oppenheimer has sold for Samuel E. Jacobs the northeast corner of St. Ann's Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street, and the southeast corner of St. Ann's Avenue and One Hundred and Fortieth Street, two five-story flats, each 30 by 100. The price is reported as $35,000.

We were regretting the other day, in finding ourselves unable to make any comparison of the fighting strength of the Russian and Japanese fleets in Oriental waters, that naval experts had not arrived at a "unit" of fighting force, compounded of the various elements of speed, battery power, and armor protection, which go to make up the efficiency of the modern man-of-war.

London cannot be charged with responsibility for the relapse in yesterday's stock market, as it was with the weakness on Monday. Yesterday's market opened strong, with assistance of buying on both London and local accounts. But within an hour or so the process of jettisoning was resumed and extended to industrials generally with specification of the Steel stocks to the second and third generation of the affiliated enterprises.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 13 -- To-day's harness racing was marked by close and exciting finishes. With two or three exceptions every heat was won by a neck or less. Cotillion, the favorite in the 2:17 class pacing, was forced to travel six miles to win the race. The first four heats of the race were won in succession by Dutch Mowery, Cotillion, Irish Jack, and Reaver.

It has not always been easy for those who looked to the independent theatrical movement for better things, to applaud the plays produced at the Manhattan. Meander and Mrs. Hatch afforded slender foothold for the rooter. Captain Molly and the Rose of Plymouth Town evoked the deep damnation of fainting praise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Department of Agriculture has directed that a consignment of cherry fruit color from Posen, Prussia, and purporting to be entirely vegetable in character, be denied admission at the Port of San Francisco.

A correspondent in Manila called attention, in a letter which we printed on Monday, to a very serious and a very pressing danger to the development and prosperity of the Philippines. Unless Congress shall meanwhile order otherwise, trade, not only between the islands and the United States, but between the islands themselves, will on the 1st of next July, it appears, become legally American coastwise trade.

ARMENTIERES, North France, Oct. 13 -- This town was to-day given up to riot, pillage, and incendiarism as a consequence of the weavers' strike. Nothing this morning foretold the serious disturbances about to occur, but at noon the strikers, not receiving answers to their demands from the employers, broke out into the wildest excesses.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- "Doctor" White helped the Nationals win their seventh game of the series to-day, one of his gifts turning into a run, a very wide throw and a wild pitch scoring two more. Wicker held the Americans down to one hit an inning. Score by innings:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- There will be ten seats contested in the House of Representatives, that number having been entared with the clerk for hearing. The papers in each case are prepared for action by the committees to which they will be referred when the House committees are announced.

By an adroit move in the Brooklyn Democratic family quarrel. Senator Patrick H. McCarren yesterday paved the way for a graceful retreat on the part of the McLaughlin men from, their position of opposition to the full city ticket, but at the same time made it plain that unless Mr. McLaughlin, with his lieutenants.

ZION CITY, Ill., Oct. 13 -- Amid the most intense religious frenzy and excitement that has ever shaken Zion City the first train of the restoration host left Zion for New York this morning. It carried no passengers, but eight cars loaded with trunks, cooking outfits, and household furniture, for "Dr." Dowie intends to leave part of the host in New York City.
Strange tales are told of what men in the U.S. Railway Mall Service sometimes find.

In order to discover why Miss Mae C. Wood of Washington had come to this city to seek United States Senator Thomas C. Plait on the eve of his wedding, two would-be interviewers sent last night to the Senator's apartments in the Fifth Avenue Hotel a note requesting that he issue a statement, in view of the many reports published during the day.

An audience of 3,000 men and women squeezed into Cooper Union last night to give their enthusiastic indorsement to the ticket headed by Mayor Low. The big crowd in its political composition was as mixed as is the present political situation, but Mayor Low and the Fusion candidate for Controller, Frederic W. Hinrichs, could not have desired a more hearty-reception.
Was there ever issued from a political headquarters an appeal for funds which honest men could so heartily answer as the one we print below?

A board to consist of Col. Joshua W. Jacobs, Lieut. Col. Charies S. Smith, and Major William L. Marshall, will convene at Sandy Hook proving grounds, Oct. 20, for the purpose of examining into the condition of the present trestle and reporting upon the advisability of entirely rebuilding the trestle connecting the proving grounds with the mainland at Xavesink Highlands.

At a meeting held last night in the United Charities Building, in East Twenty-second Street, attended by some 300 Democrats representing nearly every Assembly District in Manhattan and the Bronx, a movement was set on foot looking toward the formation of an Independent Democratic Party in Greater New York similar to the old County Democracy.

An unusually large crowd of bowlers attended the opening of the Metal District Bowling League's tournament at Maurice John's Nassau Street alleys last night. The attendance was augmented owing to the fact that the regular games in the Life Insurance League tourney were rolled simultaneously at the same place on adjoining alleys.

The substance of Judge BISCHOFF'S timely and admirable talk on mob law is that the indulgence in the spirit of the mob is not justified or even excused by the law's delay, but that the prevalence of the mob spirit makes it an imperative duty to reduce as much as possible the law's delay.

Secretary William R. Prendergast of the National Association of Credit Men has sent out to the members in the last few days a digest of the resolutions adopted at the last National convention, and which comprise the subjects for legislative work during the approaching sessions of Congress and of the Legislatures in the several States.

In yesterday's trading on the Stock Exchange the tendency of the industrials to decline while railroad stocks showed more or less strength was again in evidence. It is true a number of railroad stocks appear among the issues which yesterday showed net losses, but in nearly every such instance the stock is one which is seldom active.

A suit by the city against the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company for an accounting is to be instituted by Corporation Counsel Rives at the instance of Mayor Low. It will be based on a report made public yesterday, of the Commissioners of Accounts of an investigation of the affairs of the defendant corporation which was ordered by Commissioner Robert Grier Monroe of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The trend of to-day's early information regarding the Far Eastern situation is less alarming.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- There was an increased demand for money in the market to-day. Discounts hardened, owing to the political uncertainty regarding affairs in the Far East, the financial position in America, and the state of the foreign exchanges.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- The money market remains quiet and comfortably easy. Call loans, 3@3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 1/4 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 5@10c discount; clearings, $23,234,328; balances, $1,256,777.

From the perusal of ex-Secretary LONG'S article upon "The New American Navy," published in The Outlook of Oct. 10, one gets the impression that Secretary LONG regarded Assistant Secretary of the Navy ROOSEVELT as a very pushing and impulsive officer. The ex-Secretary depicts Mr. ROOSEVELT as actually panting to get at the Spaniards in the early months of 1895.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- The Boston Americans shut out the Pittsburg Nationals to-day and won the world's baseball championship, to the almost frenzied delight of 7,000 enthusiasts. While the attendance at all the previous grames of the series has been larger than to-day, the demonstration which followed Dineen's striking out of "Hans" Wagner in the ninth equaled any college football game.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- There was an increased demand for money in the market to-day. Discounts hardened, owing to the political uncertainty regarding affairs in the Far East, the financial position in America, and the state of the foreign exchanges.

It is a common saying that "lightning never strikes in the same place twice." That seems to be one of the differences between lightning and theatrical success, if one may judge from the result at the Majestic Theatre last night, where the new extravaganza,. "Babes in Toyland," had its first production before an audience that for two hours and a half took everything that came its way and then greedily cried for more.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Interest today was centred largely in United Gas Improvement, which, under good commission house buying, advanced from 76 1/2 to 78 1/4, reacting 3/4 later in the day. Liquidation was continued, but in reduced volume. An official denial was made that there had been any thought of reducing the dividend, as earnings are larger now than last year, when 9 per cent, was earned on $30,700,000 capital.

Broadway is to have aerial pipe galleries from the Post Office down in connection with that section of the rapid transit tunnel. The first of the bridges which will carry the pipes already spans Fulton Street, and all last night workmen were busy trussing and otherwise strengthening it.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- The State Board of Canvassers met at 2 o'clock this afternoon and went over the returns from the Constitutional amendment election of Sept. 22. All the eight Constitutional amendments offered were defeated by varying majorities.
ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- A decision was handed down to-day by the Court of Appeals in the case of People vs. Pierson, declaring dependence upon faith-healing in case of sickness to be criminal negligence.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 13 -- The courtroom was crowded this morning when the trial was resumed before Judge Heisley and a jury of David Lamar, Bernard Smith, "Monk" Eastman, and Joseph Brown, indicted for assault on James McMahon, Lamar's former coachman. The Jury had been carefully guarded in the Court House throughout the night.

Creditors of Daniel Le Eoy Dresser, representing $1,200,000 in claims against the firm of Dresser Co., met yesterday afternoon at 71 Broadway, in the office of Stanley W. Dexter, referee in bankruptcy. This is the first meeting the creditors have had since they agreed to elect B.B. Whitney trustee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Doylestown National Bank of Doylestown, Penn., which was closed on July 30, was to-day authorized by Mr. Kane, Acting Controller of the Currency, to resume business, and the receiver has been instructed to turn over to the new Board of Directors all of the assets of the bank in his possession.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14. -- Holy Cross made the first score of the season on Yale to-day. Reed kicking two place goals from the field from the thirty-five-yard line in the second half. The Yale Varsity made five touchdowns in the first half and a safety and the substitutes added one more touchdown in the second half, the final score being 36 to 10.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the year ended June 30 last was made public yesterday after the annual meeting of the stockholders, at which all the retiring Directors of the company were re-elected. The report makes no reference to the litigation going on between the company and the Pennsylvania Railroad over the removal of the Western Union lines from the Pennsylvania's right of way.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- In a speech on "Good Citizenship" at the annual banquet of the Commercial Club at the Auditorium Hotel to-night, ex-President Grover Cleveland vigorously arraigned certain tendencies of the time.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Consul General Guenther, in a report dated at Frankfort, Germany, Aug. 19, says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Secretary Hitchcock to-day issued an order which will turn the first shovelful of earth in the great work of establishing irrigation systems throughout the West under Government auspices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The annual report of the Register of the Treasury shows that an aggregate of $15,065,750 of the registered bonds are held by foreigners. Of this amount $3,911,250 are credited to individuals and $11,154,500 to foreign insurance companies.

Yesterday was decidedly gay in town and the fashionable restaurants were crowded with well known people, many of whom came in to attend the Iselin-de Neufville wedding. The entire Roxburghe-Goe-let party, with the exception of the English relatives, were among those who arrived in town yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- New York exchange was at 20c premium before and 25c premium after clearings, Time and call loans, 5 1/2@6 Per cent.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The facts known in St. Petersburg in regard to the Far Eastern situation, say The Times's Russian correspondents, all point in the direction of warlike preparations and the prevalence of alarm and anxiety.

Stocks irregular. Call money easy, 1 3/4@2 1/2 per cent. Yesterday's stock market was characterized by a reduced volume of business and so much uncertainty of tone that there was something in it at different times to please both bulls and bears. The moments of strength were interpreted to signify that the market was receiving support, and was responding to it.
FREEHOLD, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- David Lamar, "Monk " Eastman, and Joseph Brown, on trial before Judge Heisley for assaulting James McMahon, all testified in their own defense to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The amount of 3 and 4 per cent, bonds so far received at the Treasury for refund into 2 per cent. consols is $6,156,000. The amount of fives received for redemption is $7,810,400.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say the postponement of the Czar's visit to Italy was undoubtedly due to the Far Eastern crisis as much as to the tactics of the Italian Socialists.
The Trustees of the New York Public Library held their regular monthly meeting, the first since the Summer vacation, yesterday afternoon at the Astor Building, Lafayette Place.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 14. -- Since the United States Steel Corporation has declined to take over a half interest in the Clairton Steel company, now owned by the Crucible Steel Company, the officers of the Crucible Company have announced that they will go ahead with the original plans to make the property a powerful competitor of the combine, and will themselves raise the necessary funds to do so.

UTICA, Oct. 14. -- Michael F. Cleary of Troy was appointed to-day receiver of K. R. McLaren, knit goods manufacturers at West Sand Lake, near Trov. Nothing is known as to the assets and liabilities. The firm, which was founded about thirty-five years ago, is now composed of heirs of the original members.

The first fatal accident of the metropolitan racing season occurred at the Brighton Beach race course yesterday afternoon, when in the sixth and last race of the day's programme, run about 4:40 o'clock, Jockey Frank Miller was thrown from the horse he was riding and was jumped on by another horse in the contest, and so injured that he died on the racing association's grounds fifteen minutes later.

ZION CITY, Ill., Oct. 14. -- Dowie's restoration host, burdened with bandboxes, blanket rolls, and Bibles, evacuated Zion City to-day and is now moving 3,500 strong on Satan's stronghold in Manhattan Island.

PARIS, Oct. 14. -- Republican France gave a royal reception to-day to King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Helena. From the moment when the train bearing the Italian sovereigns stopped at the Bois de Boulogne station until the nation's guests were safely conducted to their apartments in the d'Orsay Palace Paris resounded with acclamations of welcome, the booming of guns, and the playing or the national anthems of Italy and France.

NEWPORT, Oct. 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. R. Livingston Beeckman, who purchased the E.R. Wharton villa on the Cliffs and are having extensive repairs and improvements made, are here to look over the improvements. They are at the Muenchinger King cottage, and others at that cottage are Mr. and Mrs. C.B. Alexander, Mr. and Mrs. F. K. Sturgis, and Mrs. William Post of New York and Mr. and Mrs. E. Gargin of Boston.

To the followers of the fortunes of the big college football teams the most interesting event in yesterday's games was the fact that Yale was scored against by the Holy Cross eleven. It was Yale's first experience of this kind since the season opened, and was mainly due to two fumbles by substitute players in the second half, each of which gave Holy Cross a chance to score.

The Governors of the New York Stock Exchange held a session for nearly six hours after the close of the Exchange yesterday afternoon, adjourning shortly before 9 o'clock. The usual listing of securities was attended to, but fully five hours of the meeting were devoted to hearing witnesses and then consulting over some matter between two or more Stock Exchange houses.

-- Replying to an editorial suggestion that perhaps the fears and dangers of white women on Southern farms had been somewhat exaggerated, a correspondent of Harper's Weekly, writing from San Antonio, Texas, says: "I am a farmer's wife, and I wish to say that neither the dangers nor the fears are exaggerated.

The principal movements of interest in the trading in outside securities yesterday was the continuation of the weakness in several of the street railway stocks, New Orleans Railways common, which fell a point lower than the previous low record, selling at 8, while a still larger drop occurred in St. Louis Transit, which was traded in at 13 1/2, the former low record being 15, made this week.

ABERDEEN, S.D., Oct. 14. -- L.T. Parr of Rockford, Ill., has announced that he has closed a deal for 32,000 acres of land in Southwestern North Dakota for the Dowieites of Chicago, who propose to colonize the land and establish a "Zion" in Bowman and Billings Counties.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 14. -- A statement was issued by the officers of the Fidelity Title and Trust Company to-day that an injunction restraining the payment of depositors granted last July had been continued by Judge F.B. Hall of the Superior Court for thirty days. The original restraining order was for ninety days and would expire next Saturday.

Gen. Henry Harrison Boyce, soldier, politician, and publisher, was killed in Bowling Green yesterday afternoon by a Broadway car. The General had just eaten luncheon at Delmonico's with ex-Secretary of the Navy Benjamin F. Tracy, his close friend, and started for the offices of the Navy League, across the street, when the accident happened.

NEWPORT, Oct. 14. -- Mrs. Winthrop Chanler was nominated by the Democratic city convention as a member of the public school committee for three years from January next. There is already one woman on the Newport School Board, Mrs. Victor Sorchan, a well known Summer resident. Mrs Chanler has been actively interested with her in the public schools, particularly in the decoration of school rooms.

"You are a heap nearer the truth than perhaps you realize," said Mr. JEROME on Tuesday evening to the auditor who cried to him that he "could not stay away." He could not, because he is an honest man, and because he knows better than most of us what the fight for decent government means.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Dr. Francis Landley Patton, formerly President of the University, was inaugurated President of Princeton Seminary to-day.

Following news of the dissolution of the Stock Exchange firm of Kilbreth Farr yesterday afternoon, announcement was made by President Thomas of the Exchange of the suspension of John C. Kilbreth, who was the board member of Kilbreth Farr, and has been a member of the Stock Exchange since 1882.

Importers of Austrian bent-wood furniture who have been having a good deal of trouble lately with the customs authorities, won a victory yesterday at a hearing before General Appraiser Thaddeus S. Sharretts. Some time ago duties on these goods were advanced in taxable value by the Board of General Appraisers anywhere from 50 to 100 per cent.
LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Money was plentiful in the market to-day and rates were easy, which affected discounts.

One of the most active champions and defenders of the practices of Christian Science writes to The Evening Post to say that PIERSON, whose conviction of faith cure murder has been affirmed by the Court of Appeals, is not a Christian Scientist, but one who describes himself as "a member of the Christian Catholic Church, of which Dr. DOWIE is overseer."

A singular "communication" to a bureau of foreign correspondence in London professes to proceed, and we make no doubt actually proceeds, from the Japanese Embassy in that capital. According to this version of the Japanese position:

BOSTON, Oct. 14. -- The money market is without material change. Call loans, 3@3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 51/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 5 cents discount, Clearings, $23,711,812; balances, $1,894,757.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Maryland politics is occupying much of the time of the President just now. There is a factional contest among the Republicans of that State that threatens to result in the loss of the Legislature and the consequent defeat of a Republican successor to Senator McComas, whose term will expire with the Fifty-eighth Congress.

In his letter accepting renomination from the Citizens' Union Mayor Low made the following significant statements concerning the public health of New York and the efficient work of the Health Department under his administration:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- There was a further shrinkage in the volume of local trading to-day. Prices in the main were firm. A prominent exception was Philadelphia and Erie, which sold at 49, over 16 points below the last previous sales, although a report is current that private transactions in the stock have been made at 55.

In his second day of testimony regarding the affairs of the United States Shipbuilding Company, Daniel Le Roy Dresser made the direct charge that Charles M. Schwab had wrecked the trust. This accusation was the feature of the session, which was held in the office of Samuel Untermyer, at 30 Broad Street, yesterday morning and afternoon.

What had promised to he a long-drawn-out legal squabble over properties valued roughly at $1,250,000 on the west side of Broadway, in the neighborhood of Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets, has been ended by the purchase on the part of the United States Realty and Construction Company of all the other interests in the syndicate controlling these holdings.

We do not see that the Chamberlainites have any reason for surprise at the attitude finally taken by the Earl of ROSEBERY in the contest they have forced on the United Kingdom. Where did they expect he would stand when the issue was made clear, as now it has been?

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Harvard defeated Wesleyan by the score of 17 to 6 on Soldiers' Field this afternoon, running up just half the number of points made against the same team by Yale last week and in turn allowing her own goal line to be crossed by the visitors, inasmuch as the halves' in both games were the same.

PORT ARTHUR, Oct. 13. -- The review by the Viceroy, Admiral Alexieff, on Sunday of 76,000 soldiers who participated in the manoeuvres, was the final act of last week's "war game." This force, the greatest Russia has ever concentrated in the Far East, was massed on the plains outside this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Kyrle Bellew called upon President Roosevelt to-day. To-night Mrs. Roosevelt, accompanied by Sesretary of the Navy Moody and Justice and Mrs. Holmes, occupied a box at the National Theatre and witnessed Mr. Bellew's interpretation of "Raffles, the Amateur Cracksman."
LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The arbitration treaty between Great Britain and France was signed here yesterday by the Foreign Secretary, Lord Lansdowne, and the French Ambassador, M. Cambon.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The Japanese Government has issued a denial of the alarmist reports of the imminence of war with Russia in a dispatch from Tokio, dated Tuesday, and sent to the Japanese Ministers abroad. It says:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 4. -- The Manhattan College eleven of New York was defeated here to-day by Rutgers in one of the roughest games ever seen on the local field. The score was 8 to 6. The visitors were unfortunate in having several of their men hurt so badly that they had to retire, Capt. Mullen having his cheek bone froctured.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14. -- The local eleven won from Lehigh to-day by a score of 12 to 0. Princeton's offense, though strong at times, was erratic. Lehigh showed her metal by holding Princeton on the five-yard line once and preventing a touch-down. Generally Princeton plowed through Lehigh's line with apparent ease and scored once in each half.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 15 -- The closing day of the Lamar-Eastman trial brought quite a number of Eastman's friends to town, their coming being heralded by a telegram from inspector McClusky. They did not make themselves conspicuous. They came simply to give their friend an ovation if he was acquitted, it was said.

Sustaining in every particular the charges brought by the firm of E. C. Randolph, the Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange yesterday morning made public a decision suspending from membership for one year Leopold Zimmermann of the firm of Zimmermann Forshay, brokers and international bankers of 11 Wall Street, and for ninety days each Leonard Shafer and Sigmund H. Rosenblatt of the same firm.

Report has been made to the various police centres of the country by Haskins Sells, certified public accountants at 30 Broad Street, asking for the arrest of Clarence H. Leonard, a messenger employed in their offices, who has disappeared with $10,076, which he is charged with obtaining by the forgery of their name at two downtown banks.

NEWPORT, Oct. 15 -- Dr. and Mrs. Henry Burton Jacobs, the latter formerly Mrs. Robert Garrett, are here to inspect their new villa which is being built on the site of the old W.R. Travers cottage on Narragansett Avenue. The house has already been one year in building, and will not be ready for occupancy until early next Summer.

The contention that has been pending between the military and naval academies in regard to terms under which the football teams of those institutions should meet has been settled after conference between the representatives of the two academies, and announcement was made yesterday at Washington that a game will be played next month under the conditions that have heretofore obtained and on the usual date.

Amalgamated Copper was the only stock in which there was much business done in thousand-share lots yesterday. In other words, the relapse of business to dealings in the ordinary unit as a rule may be taken to signify a comparatively normal market, not so much disturbed as recently by either liquidation or professional short selling for the fall.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Money was plentiful and in good, demand in the market to-day for settlement requirements. The recent liquidation on the Stock Exchange left the lenders with increased resources. In addition nearly $17,500,000 in dividend and interest payments was released.

Parish, Fisher, Mooney Co. have sold for William Rosenzweig and Bernard Klingenstein 313 Madison Avenue, adjoining the southeast corner of Forty-second Street, a four-story dwelling on lot 17.6 by 95. The sellers acquired the property at auction about a year ago for $101,000, a price which was regarded at the time as remarkably, high.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- The Directors of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company to-day declared a general dividend of 1 1/2 per cent on the second preferred stock of the company, payable Nov. 10. This is the first time in the history of the road that a dividend has been paid on the second preferred stock.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 15 -- Owing to an attachment for $250,000 which has been placed on the plant of the Household Sewing Machine Company here by trustees of the William J. King estate, the machine works have been shut down for an indefinite period and 300 hands are idle.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The dinner given by the Pilgrims' Society to the Alaska Boundary Commission at Claridge's Hotel last night proved the most notable assemblage of Englishmen, Americans, and Canadians ever brought together in London. In addition to the members of the commission, the British Cabinet Ministers, the United States Ambassador, and many of the most prominent representatives of English public life were present.

In what was seemingly an even division of the Brighton Beach races yesterday between favorites and non-favorites, three of each capturing first places, provision was begun by long-headed horsemen for a long and cold Winter that is close at hand.

In the trading in curb securities yesterday there was a decided decrease in activity, though the trading which was done showed a firmer tone. Several new low records were made, one in Greene Consolidated Copper and the other in Havana Tobacco common, the latter selling down to 20 and the former declining to 13 7/8.

To allay doubts anent the validity of the election of the Rev. Dr. David H. Greer as Bishop Coadjutor of New York, The Churchman will voice to-morrow the opinion of Bishop Potter and the New York convention in a defense of the legality of the methods pursued in Dr. Greer's election.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 15 -- In his decision of the celebrated Bunel legacy case in the United States District Court, Judge John F. Philips of Kansas City administered a scathing rebuke to the contending heirs.

On the day after the shooting of GONZALES by TILLMAN was reported, THE TIMES took occasion to observe: "This crime is so far from being approved in Columbia that an attempt took form to avenge it by another, and to follow a murder by the lynching of the murderer. That would only have disgraced the community still more deeply.

Army. A board is appointed to meet at Fort Sam Houston for the examination of officers for promotion. Detail: Col. Constant Williams, Twenty-sixth Infantry; Major Thomas R. Adams, Artillery Corps; Major Joseph I. Gaston, First Cavalry; Major Charles F. Mason, Surgeon; Capt. Thomas S. Bratton, Assistant Surgeon; First Lieut. George D. Arrowsmith, Twenty-sixth Infantry, Recorder.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Maryland politics again occupied the attention of the President to-day. Those who called at the Executive Office did so on invitation and represented both factions.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 -- Josephine Meade, a student of the University of California, was shot and killed to-day by Paul Schmidt, aged twenty-five years, who afterward committed suicide.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- With impressive ceremonies, an equestrian status of William Tecumseh Sherman was unveiled here this afternoon in the presence of official Washington, the President at its head, and thousands of veterans, members of the Societies of the Armies of the Tennessee, the Cumberland, the Ohio, and the Potomac.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 15 -- The big automobile endurance test from New York to Pittsburg by way of Cleveland ended here to-day, when the first machines in the long ride began to reach the city. The committee having the arrangements in charge changed the finishing point from the east end to Ridge Avenue, Allegheny.

A few affairs of small moment in the suburbs and the tri-weekly meet of the Meadow Brook hunt are all that can be recorded of the happenings in society yesterday. The Savoie went out with a number of passengers, including George W. Vanderbilt.
District Attorney Jerome made public last night the following appeal to the voters, urging them to register:

A bad cause poorly served, will be the comment of pretty much every sincere and intelligent voter upon the speeches made by Mr. McCLELLAN and Mr. GROUT in Tammany Hall on Wednesday evening. Both of them attacked the administration of Mr. Low. Mr. GROUT knows very well and has publicly declared that it has been a good administration.

-- Reduced to its simplest terms, the decision of the New York Court of Appeals is on authoritative assertion that a person under legal obligation to provide another person with medical attendance cannot fulfill that obligation except by securing the services of a person licensed by the State to practice medicine.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Gov. Murphy and the legislators assembled here in extra session to-day have been at loggerheads all day. The Chief Executive has asked that attention be paid to a measure to incorporate Long Branch as a city and an act passed to furnish money for the erection of the State tuberculosis sanitarium in North Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Among the visitors to the White House this morning was Kirk Munroe, the author. He enjoyed a pleasant talk with the President and told him of his recent tour through the Far East, where he made a special study of the Russo-Chinese conditions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Employers and labor representatives of National reputation were in attendance to-day in Steinway Hall at the opening session of the National Civic Federation conference, which is to discuss and debate questions affecting wage earner and capitalist, in an effort to better relations between them, and to right industrial evil.

Beaten and at bay Hugh McLaughlin and his lieutenants, who for years have controlled the Democratic Party organization in Kings County, made it plain last night that they would go down, fighting, to defeat, and will not give in until Senator Patrick H. McCarren has demonstrated plainly on next Monday night that he controls the situation.

The study of the engineers of the Pennsylvania Railroad of the practical problems involved in tunneling the Hudson and East Rivers for the vast system of terminal improvements they have in hand has somewhat modified the ideas at first favorably considered. The Hudson River tunnel still remains in a sense the "submerged bridge" of the original scheme, in that it is supported on screw piles at intervals.

BUFFALO, Oct. 15 -- Seven trainloads of John Alexander Dowie's Restoration Host, bound for New York, arrived here to-day, and after spending a few hours at Niagara Falls, resumed their pilgrimage to New York.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Louis Sinclair, M.P., Joint Honorary Secretary of the House of Commons Commercial Committee, who had just exchanged congratulations with Baron d'Estournelles de Constant (who headed the international arbitration group of the French Parliament which visited London in July) on the signing of the Ango-French arbitration treaty, said yesterday that the committee's next work would be to endeavor to arrange an arbitration treaty with the United States.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 15 -- George B. Cox, the noted Republican leader of this city, with a number of associates, to-day purchased from Cleveland men the entire control of the Cincinnati Trust Company.

With a man's life at stake, a dying woman testified against him Wednesday night, court being held in her room on the top of the tenement house 16 1/2 Hamilton Street. By order of Judge Foster of the Court of General Sessions the testimony of Mrs. Catharine Brown to the effect that she had seen Patrick O'Shea kill William McMahon was taken.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Princeton's annual Fall track games were held this afternoon on 'Varsity Field, and though track and weather conditions were favorable no good time was made.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- A correspondent of The Daily Telegraph on the Macedonian frontier has sent his paper a long description of the refugees arriving at Rilo Monastery, after fasting for days and sleeping in the open air with the thermometer at 34 degrees, and their gratitude to the monks, who shared with them their black bread and salt and exhausted all their resources to succor the hungry fugitives.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The Earl of Hard- wicke has been appointed Under Secretary of State for India and the Earl of Donoughmore has received the appointment of Under Secretary of State for War.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- The money market remains quiet and unchanged. Call loans, 3@ 3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@ 5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2 @6 per cent; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 5 cents discount. Clearings, $24,470,014; balances, $1,857,719.

The American Asiatic Association at its annual meeting yesterday instructed its officers to prepare a memorial to President Roosevelt urging him to take vigorous action to maintain the "open door" in China, and in particular to insist on Russia's keeping her pledges as to the evacuation of Manchuria.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Ex-President Grover Cleveland was received with lusty cheers by the students of Armour Institute today. He made a speech which brought the students to their feet, cheering with Might and main. The uproar was terrific, but Mr. Cleveland showed that he enjoyed it.
An era of change and reorganization begins to-day in the office of the Board of General Appraisers, and there is much speculation among the clerical force as to how far it will go.

Even after one of the three one-time "dummy Directors" of the United States Shipbuilding Company had admitted on the witness stand that he thought the Bethlehem Steel Works were located in Homestead, the throng of listeners at the shipyard examination did not realize what Samuel Untermyer, lawyer for the complainants, was trying to accomplish.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Washington will witness to-morrow the dedication of the new speedway by the horse lovers of the city. The speedway is an institution which was asked of Congress by horsemen here for years, and the common spirit of sportsmanship in Congress and out finally prevailed in the form of a liberal appropriation for constructing one of the finest roadways in he South.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Caps Miryne Reld. an export troin his Mexican War and Texan Itanger experience, as well as Southwestern Indian fighter knowledge, translated Gabriel Berry's (Luis de Bellemare) "Le Coureur de Bois" as "The Wood Rangers." there are two in the story.

Trading in curb securities was favorably influenced by the strength on the board, and improvement was noted very nearly throughout the entire list, but there was practically no increase in activity. Northern Securities was more active than in a number of recent sessions, and on transactions falling little short of 3,000 shares advanced 3/4, closing at 85 ex dividend of 1 1/8.

ENGLEWOGD, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Despite lowering clouds and threatening weather the carnival at the Field Club for the benefit of Englewood Hospital this afternoon was a big success, more than 2,000 being present.

The only point in the administration of Mr. Low which Tammany can with any plausibility criticise is the fact that there are more children at the present time who are not provided with full schooling than there were two years ago. Tammany seizes on this point and declares that there are "87,000 children for whom there are no seats in the public schools."

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- Prof. W.H. Squires of Hamilton College, in accepting the Democratic nomination in the Second Assembly District of Oneida, gives some advice to voters. He says: "The people's money should be handled in all cases with rigid economy. A public office is a business trust to be administered with the same fidelity manifested in conducting a strictly private enterprise.

Charles Seribner's Sons are issuing to-day Gen. John B. Gordon's "Reminiscences of the Civil War"; "John S. Sargent; A Collection of Sixty Reproductions in Photogravures of His Finest Paintings," with a critical introduction by Mrs. Alice Meynell; a new edition in one volume, entirely reset of "Rembrandt, His Life.

"If you wish to prevent separation, you must put a tax on food." This is the declaration made by Mr. CHAMBERLAIN at Glasgow. It raises the vital question of the future of the mightiest and the most prosperous and happy empire that the world has ever seen. What do the colonies themselves really think of it?

One wonders if had there been no Mrs. Wiggs, would there still have been a Sally Mrs. Tubbs? If there had been no Miss Lucy, would Miss Violet Van Wyck and her accompanying love affair with Robert Blair have come to light? We wonder, and as we wonder, we doubt. Sally, alas, can never receive her deserts at the hands of her readers, for she is overshadowed.

Superintendent of Elections George W. Morgan said yesterday that his bureau had a legitimate interest in the good faith of men selected as Inspectors of Election, but when he was asked whether it was true that he was making an investigation to ascertain to what extent, if any, the Republican district organizations had been certifying Tammany men as Republicans, he refused to discuss the matter.

WE often hear and rend of the queer ideas foreigners have of our country, and the ridiculous notions they have about us and our ways, but really they are not one bit more ridiculous than the notions the people of the Eastern States have in regard to that part of their own country lying west of the Mississippi.

At a hearing held yesterday before Refree Stanley W. Dexter, at the instance of he creditors of Daniel Le Roy Dresser as head of the firm of Dresser Co., it was brought to light that the securities put up for Mr. Dresser, after his assignment, by the Richmond Real Estate and Development Company were of trifling value.
NEWPORT, Oct. 16. -- Mrs. Julian T. Davies has returned from New York and has as her guest at Pinecroft Mrs. W. Prall Thompson of New York.

PRINCE HENRY'S visit to Boston last year had one unexpected consequence in bringing into notice a quiet wearer of the Iron Cross, who at the age of eighty-four, after bravely serving her own country and his in army hospitals, was earning her living by designing pattern for embroidery and giving lessons in neediework.

Were it not that few young women of the present day consider themselves in the line of improvement, Dr. Warner's talks to "The Young Woman in Modern Life" might prove instructive and helpful reading. Dr. Warner is not in favor of the New Woman. For him the homely -- that is, the domesticated -- woman holds ample charms.

Among the many varying chapters on writers, English and American, in "Recollections, Personal and Literary" by Richard Henry Stoddard, which is edited by Ripley Hitchcock and introduced by Edmund Clarence Stedman, the one on Lowell is interesting. The writer tells of his first meeting with Lowell.

The London book auction season began Oct. 6, with an interesting sale by Hodgson Co. This week Messers. Hodgson are selling a portion of the library of R.L. Farsoon, the same sale including a selection from an old country library, which includes Purchases "Pilgrimes," 1625; Hakluyt's "Voyages," 1599-1660, (without the map.) and other early books of travel treasured by collectors of Americana.

AMERICAN LITERATURE -- American critics have now been writing about American literature for something like a hundred years, and their work has been charcterized, as a rule, by an exaggerated consciousness of the existence of the present literature on the other side of the ocean.

A man of Justice not merey, a woman of nerves and sentiment, another man, Kent, Son of the stern tribune who weighed men in the balance and meted out their deserts; Rosamond, the nffianced of this younger man, and one Jane Harding, an old teacher or of Kent's and afterward his accuser, these are the dramatis personae of importance in Miss Alice Brown's romance.

For the first time in many days the stock market yesterday showed a decided upward tendency. Early in the day the market was dull, but during the afternoon transactions were made on a much larger scale, and in spite of the dull morning, the total sales amounted to about 725,000 shares.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- An attempt to inject the Socialistic propaganda into the proceedings of the conference of the National Civic Federation to-day was sharply checked by Samuel Gompers, the presiding officer. It was made by several persons in the audience, who took advantage of the general discussion of the "open" shop to air their views.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Attorney General Cunneen to-day received the resolutions adopted last night by the Tammany Executive Committee regarding alleged intimidation of Democratic voters by the Superintendent of Elections for the Metropolitan Election District. The resolutions charge that a large number of Democratic citizens heretofore registered as voters have been summoned to the office of the Superintendent of Elections and subjected to intimidating language.

In the early days of transit by cable car in Chicago it used to be computed that the system cost a life a day. That is a considerable price to pay even for a more rapid transit for the passengers who survived. But it seems that the practice of allowing automobiles to run at large about the town is becoming quite as expensive in New York.

Longmans, Green Co. are about to issue "Three Frenchmen in Bengal; or, the Commercial Ruin of the French Settlements in 1757." by S.C. Hill, B.A., B.Sc.. Officer in charge of the Records of the Government of India, author of "Major General Claud Martin." This account, we are told in the preface, is taken almost entirely from, hitherto unpublished documents.
BOSTON, Oct. 16. -- Prices of fish soared to-day. There was only one schooner in with a catch when the market opened. She was the Teresa and Alice, Capt. George Perry.

The Rev. John Watson, (lan Maclaren.) Author of "Beside the Bonnle Brier Bush." has published a pamphiet in which he expresses the bellet that the world is on the eye of the "geatest religious revival since the days when all Rome succumbed to the teachings of Christ in the first century."

MRS. ROGER A. PRYOR'S book, "The Mother of Washington and Her Times," is now definitely announced by the Macmillan Company for publication Nov. 4. The work, it is said, does not deal with the oft-told customs of tidewater Virginia, but with those of the interior, amid which Mary Ball was born and grew into womanhood.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 16. -- Two lawsuits relating to the Consolidated Lake Superior Company's troubles have now been filed, one here, the other at the Soo, both attacking the agreement with the Speyer syndicate and the mortgages and bonds, and asking that they be declared beyond the power of the company, contrary to law and of no effect and be set aside.

Tales of treasure trove, of pirates and shipwrecks, and of secret delving for sunken wealth, along the harbor and its adjacent waters have entranced old and young since New York was old New Amsterdam, but fitted to fill a chapter with the best was the story that came ashore yesterday from the dingy wrecking schooner Fly and her consort, the old fireboat John Fuller belonging to the Baxter Wrecking Company of 308 West Street.

Thomas Bailey AIdrich's new volume of miscellaneous notes and essays, endtitled "Ponkapog Papers," will be brought out by Houghton, Miffin Co. Oct. 28. The author tells us that he has chosen this title not because the contents of the boot were written within the limits of the old Indian reservation, but because "there is something typical of their unpretentiousness in the modesty with which Ponkpapog assumes to being even a village.
Messrs. Harper Brothers published yesterday two novels, a volume of short stories, a fairy story book, and a new edition of Lewis Carroll's nonsense verses.

Books for the young people are beginning to come in and as usual the greater number and the best are for the boys. The strenuous life of the young man begins at an early age, and he is continually making history for himself in a way who is written up into fiction makes for action and good reading.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- The money market is quiet and rates hold steady, in spite of the abundant supply of funds. Call loans, 3@3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 5 cents discount @ par.

THE moral of Elinor Glyn's new book, "The Damsel and the Sage," (published by Harper Brothers,) is: "Everything depends upon the point of view" This moral is set forth in a short parable which nestles in the centre of a page and is signed, cryptically, with the initials "C.S.C." It is a moral which everyboty will not accept.

The Hague Tribunal showed a very proper spirit in acknowledging the efforts of the United States to give it some importance and dignity by giving it something to do. It was at our instance that a question of long standing between ourselves and Mexico was submitted to the tribunal.

ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- That Summer vacations and Winter trips to the South are fruitful sources of typhoid epidemics was the belief expressed to-day by Secretary Stuart of the State Health Board, in connection with an outbreak of typhold in the town of Athens, Greene County.
VIENNA, Oct. 16. -- A newspaper of Bucharest announced to-day the betrothal of the Grand Duke Cyril, son of the Czar's uncle Vladimir, to the divorced Grand Duchess Victoria of Hesse.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Money was easy in the market to-day. The impression that the Bank of England was about to draw in a large sum from the market stiffened discounts.

ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- The fight which raged determinedly between the dual educational departments of the State during the last session of the Legislature has broken out afresh, in anticipation of the coming session of the Legislature, and promises to be fought to a finish next Winter.

A readable volume of gossip about a fascinating period of French history is this of Col. Haggard. Dealing with the reigns from Francois I. to Louis XIII., and concerned for the most part With the history of that reckless soldier and equally reckless admirer of women, Henri IV., there is naturally much of scandal in the book.

THE Life and Times of Thomas Jefferson," by Thomas E. Watson, is a vastly entertaining polemic, and undoubtedly directs attention to many generally neglected facts. Mr. Watson declares in his prefance that his object is to emphasize the part of the South in the revolution -- a part which the writers of history in the North have ignored or minimized.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The Duke of Devonshire, late Lord President of the Council, has conditionally accepted the Presidency of the Unionist Free Food League, which is organizing a campaign against the fiscal policy of Mr. Chamberlain and Mr. Balfour.

Three persons were severely hurt, and a score of others were cut by flying glass and bady shaken up, when a north-bound Eighth Avenue electric car crashed into an east-bound Fourteenth Street horse car last night. Both cars were crowded with passengers, the Eighth Avenue car containing about fifty, while thirty, mostly women, occupied the cross-town car.

Mr. Howelts's latest story deals with themes he has dealt with before, but with the freshne is and originality of treatment that make every new book from him a promise of new pleasure. He has treated them in "Letters Home" with even more than his usual sensitivenes of perception and charm of expression.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 16 -- The jury in the Lamar-Eastman case came into court at 4 o'clock this morning with a verdict of not guilty. The jury went out at 9 o'clock, and at midnight Judge Heisley went to his home in Long Branch. He left word with the Court Clerk to accept the verdict if the jury should reach a conclusion.

(Copyright 1903) LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Sidney Colvin is selecting the most interesting examples of drawings by the old masters treasured in the galleries of Oxford University and in the wonderful library of Christ Church College for reproduction in color in a book which Henry Frowde will publish, probably in four portfolio parts of twenty drawings each.

The first number of the new Popular Magazine, published by Street Smith, will contain the first half of a "football story." "The Rockspur Eleven," by Gilbert Patten, and short stories by Morgan Robertsen, Charles Agnew McLcan, William Montgomery, and W. Bert Foster.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- According to the most moderate estimate, says the Sofia correspondent of The Times, there are now 22,000 refugees in Bulgaria from Macedonia and the Valiyyet of Adrianople, of whom 19,000 have arrived in the past few weeks. The fugitives are mostly old men, women, and children.

In a riot which occurred last evening, the result of a strike at the rag factory of Steinberg Brothers, 5 First Street, several girls were stabbed, one of them so seriously that she had to be taken to St. Vincent's Hospital.

Although Hugh McLuughlin continued last night to talk opposition to the McCareen plan of indorsing, the McClelian, Grout, and Fornes ticket at the meeting of the Kings County Democratic Committee, called for Monday night, it became known during the evening that McLaughlin, is more than willing to let his opposition die out, but that James Shevlin continues to be the stumbling block to party harmony.
SUBJECT -- David's joy over forgiveness. Psalm xxxil.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Officers and Directors of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company will resign in a body following the acceptance to-day of conditions imposed by Speyer Co. for the extension of sixty days to complete the projected reorganization.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Complaint has been made to the Treasury Department that the Dominion Iron and Steel Company of Canada has been exporting bounty-paid steel into this country.

William H. Baldwin, Jr., President of the Long Island Railroad Company, yesterday applied to the Board of Elections of the Third Election District of the First Assembly District, Brooklyn, to be allowed to register and vote, in that district. His application was rejected.

That sixth sense, which is as sure and yet as elusive as the missing link, has been located at last by Mrs. Hubert Bland E. Nesbit as the Literary Sense. It is a sense, an instinct, which we all possess; a something which, especially in the times of great emotions, prompts us to act, to speak, to move and feel as characters in books might act, speak, move, and feel.

Of the many errors made by betting race-goers at the Brighton Beach track yesterday, one which was specially irritating and provocative of argument concerned the relative merits of the costly disappointment River Pirate, recently cast off from the stable of Perry Belmont, and injunction, weeded out of James R. Keene's stable about the same time.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 16 -- James B. Jones, forty years of age, formerly a detective attached to the Central Office of the New York Police Department, and believed to have been in the service of the Pinkerton National Detective Agency, attempted to hang himself thrice in an hour in a cell at Worcester Police Headquarters to-night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Issues of passes by the Western roads during the year 1904 will be greatly restricted and passes to shippers or merchants will be entirely discontinued according to a decision reached to-day at the annual pass meeting of the executive officers of the Western roads. The meeting is being held at an early date to preclude all possibility of roads anticipating its action.

MR JANVIER thinks it is not likely that "the highly untruthful impression" of the Putch cofoiustes of Manhattan given by "very subdy meladous" but delightful Knickerlocker history of New York will ever be effaced.

Mr. G.W. Ogden has written a story of the era, (the late sixties,) in which the sieamboat traffic of the Mississippl, ("one-fifth of the world's commerce,") was ruined by the advert of the railroad. His Monugue and Capulet are, respecitvely, a promoter of railroad enterprise and an owner of steamboats.

Nearly a score of years ago the journal of Maric Bashkirtseff produced one of the most remarkable sensations of the latter part of the century. It claimed to be the "exact, absolute, and faithful truth "in regard to the outer and inner life of a young girl of much beauty, considerable artistic gifts, a passionate heart, and an extraordinarily acute and daring intellect.

It was decided by the Grievance Committee of the motormen and firemen on the elevated railroad system after two conferences with officials of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company yesterday to deferall action until Monday, when another conference will be held. Neither the employers nor the men want a strike at the present time.

BOSTON, Oct. 16. -- The arrest of 350 Chinamen in this city last Sunday night was characterized as "high-handed" and "outrageous," and the United States immigration officers and the Boston police officials were sereverely criticised by various speakers in Faneuil Hall to-day. The meeting was called in protest against the proceedings of the authorities by Col. S.W. Nickerson, Chinese Vice Consul in this city.

Within the past few days there has been buying of high-class investment securities both for domestic and foreign account, and while this buying is only one of the influences which contributed to yesterday's improvement in the stock market, it is one of the most powerful of those influences both upon prices directly and upon market sentiment.

The crowding incidents and mysteries of this story at what happened to a slender young Lieutenant of cavalry, who combined fine soldierly qualities with repose of manner and a taste for entomology, will keep the reader trying to read ahead of himself, as it were, in his eagerness to find out what is really, going to happen.

IT has been said that this book is the longest biography ever written of a living man. We can well believe that it is the longest book over written about a living man, but to term it a biography is somewhat misleading.

A number of important football games will be played to-day, and as the season advances interest in the results is increasing every week.
