Official announcement of the appointment, however, will not be made until Monday, when the King will formally sign his commission.

Those who think that DOWIE is making a mistake in disgusting the soberminded and decent people of New York by his unseemly conduct at Madison Square Garden do not understand his "little game." He is doing what he found profitable in Chicago. Primarily he wants the largest possible amount of free advertising he can get, and he is getting it.
BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- American capital is interesting itself in the development of "King Solomon's Mines."

In connection with the arrival in this city of Addison F. Bright, general representative of English celebrities, a story was told yesterday, which is vouched for by some of the persons interested, and which casts a new light upon the dramatization of "The Amateur Cracksman," which is now serving Kyrle Bellew as a medium for his histrionic effort.

ALTHOUGH Hush McLaughlin, who for nearly half a century has ruled the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn, is reputed to be worth close to $10,000,000, he is not a man who spends much money on living expenses or dress, the latter at times becoming almost shabby.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me, in the interest of truth and fair play, to register a word of protest against the vicious resort to racial animosity which I find in the campaign hook of Tammany Hall, called "Father Knickerbocker Adrift"? Referring to the Tenement House Department, the campaign book charges that the "Jews employed there are the objects of personal animosity of Velller," (the first Deputy Commissioner.)

Felix Weingartner will conduct the fifth concert and rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society on Jan. 29, 1904. Although he will remain in this country only ten days he has received a number of offers to direct other concerts in New York, Philadelphia, and Boston. Weingartner has made it a rule never to seek the aid of soloists at the concerts of the Kaim Orchestra, which he conducts in Munich.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report, by whomsoever furnished, printed in to-day's TIMES, concerning the ex-convict, Vincent Cody, who has just died in Bellevue Hospital, bristles with mistakes, most of which it is perhaps now scarcely worth while to attempt to straight- en out.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 24 -- The Lenox Hunt Club held an interesting meet at Tanglewood this afternoon with a run of three miles over several of the estates. The chase led over several high fences and through by-ways, but the riders kept well with the pack. In the run were Miss Rosamond Dixey, George E. Turnure, William B. Osgood Field, Arthur Sturgis Dixey, Charles A. Bristed, and Samuel Frothingham.

Delegates from at least 150, and perhaps from 500, associations of employers, citizens' associations, and other organizations formed to resist illegal methods, excessive demands, or other undue aggressions by labor organizations, will meet in Chicago Thursday and Friday to form a National organization, which shall systematize the work that is now being done by 500 disconnected units and establish a clearing house for news of methods, victories, and defeats.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The memory of Dr. Henry H. Gate is gradually unfolding, and he has a complete recollection of all he did on the day last April on which he disappeared up to the hour he Was evidently sandbagged.

SCRIBNER writes for the newspapers for a living -- sometimes. Sometimes he merely writes for the newspapers. It all depends upon the men who make the Sunday papers whether Scribner smokes good cigars or plug tobacco in a pipe.

At last a new billiard champion of the first magnitude looms above the limited horizon of that sport which for so many years in this country has shown but two stars, Jacob Schaefer and George F. Siosson. The new champion is George Sutton, the one-time Chicagoan, but more recently of Paris.

THERE has been found, presumably to a garret, a hitherto unpublished manuscript by Samuel Taylor Coleridge. It appears to have been the intention of the poet to write a second "Rime of the Ancient Mariner," showing now that famous old salt on an occasion subsequent to the one commemorated in immortal verse met another wedding guest, this time a lady.

To the Editor of The New York Times: About the year 1825 one Jacob Cochrane, a "New Light" preacher, ranged over York County, Me., teaching doctrines in many respects similar to the theories of Dowie. His personal appearance was attractive, a man of ready wit and much shrewdness, a fine singer, a graceful dancer, and ready speaker.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- Ohio is now on the last lap of a political campaign that is attracting the attention of a large part of the country, creating interest among politicians almost as great as the municipal fight now going on in New York City, where Tammany is battling for its very existence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The State Medical Society, at its meeting yesterday, is alleged to have "put itself on record as favoring *** the passage of a law which will prevent" so-called eye specialists from attempting to treat patients whose cases should be attended to by licensed physicians."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Lieut. Robert E. Peary, United States Navy, in an address to-night before the National Geographic Society of this city, discussed plans for his next expedition to the north pole. He said that the possible routes to the north pole have dwindled to three, and in his own personal opinion to only two.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Mme. Marcella Sembrich opened her American tour with a sons recital this afternoon at the Auditorium before an audience that taxed the seating capacity of the theatre and all possible standing room. Mme. Sembrich was welcomed enthusiastically, receiving an ovation at the close of each part of the programme.

The position in which the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union has been placed owing to the rearrest or Samuel J. Parks and the practical turning down by the Iron League of President Buchanan of the International Union has decided the latter to take new action.
Ernest G. Judkins, bookkeeper for the Kineo Company, had a remarkable experience with a bull moose on the carriage road to Deer Head Farm, two miles from Kineo.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Wesleyan defeated New York University this afternoon by a score of 6 to 0 in an interesting and hard-fought game. Until the last whistle blew the game was anybody's, and the "rooters" kept things lively on the side lines. The work of the officials was rather unsatisfactory to both teams and there was considerable delay on their account.

A Porter Who Refused a Tip. A GOOD-LOOKING porter who is in command of a parlor car running westward did something notable the other day -- he refused a tip. It is believed among travelers that the event was unique. Few colored porters are built that way.

CANAL DOVER, Ohio, Oct. 8 -- We talk about the "homing" instinct of animals. It may be worth while to ask which is the true home of the migratory birds, the North or the South. In the Spring they are moved by a seemingly irresistible impulse to migrate northward to their Summer breeding grounds, and in the Fall the impulse to go south appears to be no less powerful.
The extent to which Italians have invested their savings in real estate in this city is only partially revealed by the records, yet the total has grown enormously in the last four or five years.

An interesting polo game was played on the field at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday between the Squadron A team and the Yale Polo Club. A large number of spectators watched the game, staying to the close, when darkness had already gathered to such an extent that it was almost impossible to see the ball.

The Stock Exchange will resume business to-morrow upon a higher, range of prices than on the previous Monday. Industrials are now where they were a fortnight ago, and rails where they were at the opening of the month. In the interval the market has had some nasty knocks, of which only those received last week are specially pertinent here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The other evening the writer and his wife went to one of the public schools in Brooklyn where one of the regular course of lectures being given to the public, was held, but we were refused admittance because we were so careless as to possess a child of six years of age.

Amid denunciation from angry shareholders, officials of the New York Building-Loan Company, at a stockholders' meeting yesterday, succeeded in passing a resolution framed by the Directors and designed to take the concern out of the hands of the receiver by a levy of $755,000 on the stock.

Not all of the dangers encountered by the actors in "The Best of Friends" at the Academy are confined to the scenes of warfare. To be sure, there is an element of excitement for half a dozen of the players in the facing of a powder barrel, over which Agnes Booth, towering in womanly indignation, holds a lighted candle while she taunts the wicked villain who, at that moment, is decidedly "in her power."

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Every train has brought its quota of visitors to Lakewood this week, and the hotels now open are doing a big business. About 400 delegates of the Presbyterian Churches of New Jersey have met here in Synod this week from Tuesday to Friday, and it has been found difficult to place them at the hotels, there being but a small number of rooms which could be rented for transient purposes.

TOM HARSTICK'S fate was not deserved. He was a good fellow -- too good to be hounded by such a pitiless Nemesis that at last he needs must take refuge in suicide. No man ever killed himself under conditions quite so distressing us those which bedged him about.

Preparations are being made by the Silk Association of America to present arguments before the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the "raw silk" case against the Pennsylvania, Reading, and other railroads. The commission has designated Nov. 4 as the date for the hearing, which will be held in this city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A constant reader of your editorial page. I have looked for some expression, criticism, or explanation of the action of the Citizens' Union organization of the Twenty-first District in refusing Judge Bennet an indorsement and in combining with Tammany Hall to elect its own candidate, Mr. Seaman.

John Alexander Dowie returned last night from his trip to Boston, where he went to see his wife and son off on a steamship for Liverpool on their trip to Australia. His followers understood that he would arrive at the Grand Central Station at 8 o'clock last night, and there was a large delegation on hand at that hour to meet him.

According to Gov. Odell and Dr. Lewis, President of the State Board of Health, many million dollars worth of industrial enterprises are threatened as a result of the report which is to be made on Tuesday by Prof. Landreth, consulting engineer of the State Board of Health, in regard to the much-discussed pollution of the waters of Lake Champlain by the pulp mills in that region.

It is said -- and said truly -- that the present situation in the Stock Exchange cannot be attributed to any excessive speculation. In the case of the debacle in American securities, the connection between excessive commercial and speculative activity may easily be traced, but if in our own depression in stocks the connection between cause and effect is less apparent it is still not difficult to discern.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 24 -- Lou Dillon, the trotting sensation of the season, reasserted her claim to first place on the trotting turf to-day when, by creating a new world's record of 1:58 1/2, unaided by a wind shield, she beat the five days' old world's record of the trotting king Cresceus by three-quarters of a second.

Mr. Low spoke with the utmost frankness in regard to the enforcement of the excise law in his speech in Williamsburg on Friday evening. It is not easy to see how any reasonable man can find fault with the position he has honestly and courageously taken. It is absolutely the only one open to the executive of a city like our own, administered under the laws of the State.

Dry goods jobbers who were called upon by a TIMES reporter this week spoke of business as quiet, but they were hopeful that the dullness is nearing an end. Purchasers who were locking for bargains are fairly numerous in the district, and there is no dearth of small purchases at favorable prices, but there was an absence of important transactions.

DALNY, Manchuria, Sept. 7 -- It is very probable that this new Russian town is not on any of our maps at home except those published in the last two years, as the place has not been in existence more than that length of time under its present name and with its pretensions toward being classed as a town that is a rival of Port Arthur.

ADRIAN H. JOLINE, in his Meditations of an Autograph Collector, published last May, tells of an angry letter of Horace Greeley dismissing a printer, which that individual used successfully for years, owing to the chirography, as a recommendation. So it is of the public expressions of Tammany Hall.
Ex-Gov. F.M. Drake of Iowa has just given $5,000 to start a Bible college in India. He had previously given $5,000 each for Bible colleges in China and Japan.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 24 -- At the matinee races held at Narragansett Park this afternoon under the auspices of the Narragansett Park Association Prince Alert, the bay gelding owned by James Hanley of this city and the second fastest harness horse in the world, clipped a quarter of a second from the world's record for a half mile.

Frank O. Reinhart of Princeton won the intercollegiate golf championship yesterday in the final round played on the links of the Garden City Golf Club. He beat W.C. Chick of Harvard by 4 up and 3 to play. The final round was 36 holes, twice as long as the preceding rounds had been.

BELGRADE, Servia, Oct. 8 -- These Srbi, or Servians, are natural-born politicians. If they could be transplanted to New York they would in time all become Aldermen and Assemblymen and drive the Irish out of politics. The highest ambition, of every normal Servian citizen seems to be to serve his country for 15L a day in the capacity of a representative in the Skupshtina.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The Cornell football team had the easiest sort of a task to defeat the Western Reserve University, team of Cleveland, Ohio, on Percy Field to-day by a score of 41 points to 0. As soon as the scoring began the Cornell players were pulled out and substitutes put in their places.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Bishop Potter of New York, who is here in attendance upon the conference of Bishops of the Episcopal Church, gave to a correspondent of The Newark News a statement in regard to "race suicide," the home that seems to be passing, and the autonomy of the American woman. The Bishop said:

The circumstances of the marriage of Henry Wilder Healy, a prominent member of the Heights society set in Brooklyn, who became engaged to Miss Laura Hubbard of Englewood, N.J., and then married a young woman of Milwaukee, Wis., were explained yesterday by the young man's father, A. Augustus Healy, of 198 Columbia Heights.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Oct. 24 -- The Nacion of this city to-day published a dispatch from Quito, dated yesterday, as follows:

TUXEDO PARK, Oct. 24 -- The week at Tuxedo was full of entertainment. On Monday evening several large dinners were given at the clubhouse. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mortimer entertained a party of ten, including Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Lorillard, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Rives, Mr. and Mrs. Stuart A. Coats, and J. Gordon Douglas.

Now the New Amsterdam Theatre is ready to open, and Klaw Erlanger will dedicate it to-morrow evening with "A Midsummer Night's Dream."N.C. Goodwin playing the role of Bottom Perhaps the most distinctive feature of this production of the gay Shakespearean play is the accompanying music.

There was incorporated at Albany a few days ago a company the purpose of which is to introduce on a large scale in this country what is known as a ferro-concrete construction -- a system that has been extensively tried abroad, principally in France and by which entire buildings are erected of concrete, strengthened with steel rods.

At the meeting of the Male Teachers' Association, at Shanley's, last night, held to discuss "Shall the Teaching Profession be Further Effeminized?" the speakers did not launch forth into any tirades against the woman teacher, but admitted her usefulness, though protesting that she should be confined to instructing the younger pupils.
The Terraces, Aug. 5 Dearest Jean: Such a walk as that one proved to be! Let me see if I can give you any idea of it:

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a general complaint here that letters posted in the United States for Great Britain are frequently understamped -- in fact, those having a large correspondence with your country have to reckon upon a considerable payment in the course of the year for such letters.

When the new building of THE NEW YORK TIMES is completed next Spring it will be not only the second tallest structure in the city, but one of the handsomest as well. The architect has expended the limit of his resourcefulness to beautify both interior and exterior. In detail's and in general effect the skyscraper will be excelled by none in its artistic effect.

CARLISLE, Penn., Oct. 24 -- The Carlisle Indians defeated Swarthmore to-day by 12 to 5 in a fiercely fought game. Swarthmore put up a plucky game, and the Indians won a well-earned victory. Coach Warner had but four of the first team in, trying out a number of substitutes for the Harvard game.

Trading in curb securities was very limited, and, with the exception of Tennessee Copper and Greene Consolidated Copper, both of which were quite active and very strong, each rising several points, there was very little interest shown. Standard Oil continued its upward movement, and after opening at 658, reacted to 656, a fractional grain, on the transfer of twenty shares.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- John Alexander Dowie arrived in this city from Boston about 6:30 o'clock and remained here for nearly two hours in order to accept an invitation extended by an organ building company, which recently installed the Newberry memorial organ at Yale, to hear an organ recital by Prof. Henry Shelley of New York.

The great ceiling for the Aldermen's Chamber at the City Hall is nearing the point when it can be gone over for the last time by the designer, Mr. Taber Sears. It is so large that the Vanderbilt Gallery at the Fine Arts Building had to be used as a studio, and even then the canvas had to be painted in three separate pieces.
Robert J. Hillas, Secretary of the Fidelity and Casualty Company, has been elected Vice President as well.

Twenty customs cases on which 25,000 suspended protests depend are on the calendar of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second District, which began its session in the Federal Building last Tuesday. Some of these will probably be heard this week.

The biggest trade auction sale of Oriental rugs in the history of the trade will be held to-morrow in the salesrooms of H.S Tavshanjian, at 33, 35, and 37 East Seventeenth Street by Wilmerding, Morris Mitchell. They will sell Mr. Tavshanjian's entire stock, which is valued at about $465,000.

BUTTE, Mont., Oct. 24 -- The Amalgamated situation took a sensational turn today when the idle miners held a special meeting to discuss the grave question as it affected them. A thousand of them filled their union hall and five thousand more packed the street in front of the meeting place.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- The United States Shipbuilding Company has filed an answer in the Circuit Court in this city to the suit to foreclose a mortgage on the Union Iron Works for $15,000,000, brought by the Mercantile Trust Company of New York.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Although the iceboating season on the North Shrewsbury River is several weeks off, the yachtsmen are busy getting their boats in readiness for the Winter's sport. Many new boats are being built, and nearly all the old boats of the fleet are being overhauled.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- New York State's general hospital for the treatment of incipient tuberculosis is practically completed, and will be ready for the reception of patients with the advent of the new year. It is situated at Ray Brook, Essex County, in the Adirondacks, and represent the initial effort of New York State to care for incipient tuberculosis.

The nominal character of yesterday's market appears from the fact that the most active stock, Amalgamated, declined an eighth upon sales of about 17,000 shares. No light was thrown upon its dilemma, but there was suggestion that the stoppage of work, which was alleged to be a stock-jobbing manoeuvre, was in fact designed to prevent the appointment of an operating receiver.
ROME, Oct. 24 -- King Alfonso of Spain has caused inquiries to be made as to the attitude which the Vatican would adopt should he decide to visit the King of Italy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Yale's annual Fall regatta for class crews at Lake Whitney this afternoon was won by the 1906 crew which defeated the Harvard freshmen at New London last year. The distance covered by the eights was seven-eighths of a mile, and the four-oared crews rowed one-third of a mile, but a high wind prevented any approach at the record Summaries:

Once upon a time the name of Jamestown must have been very sharply shortened. Within the memory of many people now living James was pronounced "Jeems"; in fact, we believe that that was the accepted pronunciation of our Virginia forefathers. But "Jim" must have been the diminutive of "Jeems," as well as of James; at least we judge so, because what is popularly known as "the Jimson weed" really is the Jamestown weed.

Columbia furnished the unlooked-for in college football yesterday by her clean defeat of Pennsylvania on the Polo Grounds. There as elsewhere throughout the country the attendance was beyond expectations, and never in the history of the game locally did Columbia attract such a large and representative assemblage.

CARLISLE, Penn., Oct. 24 -- Dickinson defeated Franklin and Marshall here to-day by the score of 18 to 6. Horn won the toss and Dickinson kicked off. The visiting full back then started down the field for a touch-down, carrying the ball more than half the time himself, and advanced it by short runs outside of tackle until it was Franklin and Marshall's ball on Dickinson's ten-yard line.

WEST POINT, Oct. 24 -- For the first time in three years Yale defeated West Point at football to-day by a score of 17 to 5. The New Haven team went into the game minus the services of two valuable players, Bloomer and Kinney, and the cadets consequently felt confident of doing as well as they did in the last two annual contests, when tie scores resulted.
Army. Capt. William O. Haan, General Staff, and Second Lieut. Grayson M.P. Murphy, Seventeenth Infantry, are assigned to duty in the Military Information Division or the war Department.

PRINCETON, N.J. Oct. 24 -- Princeton defeated Dartmouth this afternoon by the score of 17 to 0. From start to finish it was anybody's game, as Dartmouth put up one of the earnest fights seen here in some time. In the second half the local eleven, excepting her two touch-downs, was outclassed, the New Hampshire men tearing through the Princeton line for sixty yards before she lost the ball.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the two letters alleging the failure of the conference of the National Civic Federation, held last week in Chicago written by your special correspondent "J.C.B."

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

Several fast half miles were trotted and paced on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday afternoon, when the Road Drivers' Association of New York held the first of a series of five Saturday matinees. The card of twelve events was an excellent one, and with few exceptions every horse entered came to the post.

NO other bird on wings could sing like the larks of Ardmore. But one Day they beard Eileen Oge O'Ruark singing in the meadow, and they grew so jealous of her voice that ever since then, mind you, they fly so far up into the sky tnat it is only the angels can hear them.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Fifteen hundred sausagemakers at the Union Stock Yards struck to-day. Work was stopped in the sausage departments of the big packing houses, and it is the declared purpose of the union to tie up the industry in each of the nine packing centres of the country.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- E.M. Applegate, Clerk of the Prerogative Court, has recently found on file a certified copy of an ancient document which bears the impression of the original seal of that court and goes far to clear up some of the mystery in connection with the legend on the die now in use.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 24 -- The Naval Academy football team gave the most satisfactory exhibition of football this afternoon that it has shown this season, and yet sustained its first defeat. Its opponents were the stalwart eleven from Lafayette College, and the score by which they lost was 6 to 5.

The last week of October will have one large social function, and that in the suburbs -- the ball on Friday evening at Tuxedo. Preceding the ball there will be many dinners and a number of house parties, and the rooms at the club are all taken for the occasion. The greater number of the guests will remain over Sunday.

On more than one occasion since the war the Attorney General of Cape Colony has been called to account by members of the Afrikander Bond for suppressing certain literature imported at Cape Town for circulation among our Dutch fellow-subjects, more particularly those in the remote districts of the country.

Chicago is now undergoing a municipal housecleaning of which it has long been sorely in need. The citizens' reform movement has gradually accomplished the object it has so long had in view, powerfully aided by the recent frank admission of that most surprising chief magistrate Mayor HARRISON.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The Comedie Francaise is departing from its traditions, and is now giving "Blanchette," a play which has already had a successful run at Antoine's Theatre. M. Brieux, the author, has, however, altered the denouement with the object probably of striking a truer social note, and Blanchette now, after being driven from her father's house no longer abandons the paths of virtue, but returns a penitent.

There are two features of the campaign now in progress which have commanded very little attention from the general public, but which have had a compelling interest for the politicians. To the so-called organization men they have been of almost overshadowing importance because their effect reaches far beyond the issue of the present contest.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The weather is still very unsettled, but the Autumn season is now in full swing.

MONTREAL, Oct. 24 -- Sir Charles Tupper, predecessor of Sir Wilfrid Laurier in the Canadian Premiership, on his return to Canada to-day, after having taken part in Mr. Chamberlain's fiscal campaign, said in an interview:

NEWTON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- A mysterious attempt to commit a double murder, the intended victims being husband and wife, was made last night near Centreville, fourteen, miles from this place. The woman is dead and the man is so seriously wounded that the doctors say he cannot recover. The motive for the crime is as yet unknown.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire a short space in your columns to say a few words upon the approaching election for Mayor of Greater New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read in the papers lately a great many criticisms on Mr. Gompers's theory that no matter what else happens in the industrial world the workman's wages should not be reduced. The workman must live; usually he has little surplus laid by, and if his wages seem higher than formerly, he has to spend more.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An interview with State Senator George R. Malby of Ogdensburg in last Sunday's issue of The New York Sun contains so many misleading statements regarding the proposed canal enlargement that the writer would like to answer a few of them that a fair understanding of the matter may be had by the voters.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a very gratifying circumstance that amid the heated political contest of to-day and during a driving rainstorm twenty thousand persons attended the inauguration of Seward Park.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Give a living reason why one should vote for Tammany Hall, for McClellan, for Grout.

YOKOHAMA, Sept. 22 -- It is a most pleasant sensation to find one's self once again entering the Shimonoseki Straits with the prospect of a trip through the Inland Sea, where nature has been so lavish in her bestowal of beautiful things to be admired. Then, too, there is always this interesting place to look forward to as a chance of final enjoyment before taking the steamer for a transpacific voyage.

The "life of a New York fireman" is shown in a capital novelty introduced at Proctor's Twenty-third Street Theatre yesterday. It may be described, for want of a better name, as a pictorial drama, with the title "A Fireman's Christmas Eve," suggesting the incidents of the principal scenes.

To the Editor of The NeW York Times: The communication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of this morning of the Rev. Joseph H. McMahon compels me to abandon my habit and reply. Waiting until nearly two years after our marriage, the Rev. Mr. McMahon is busying himself mightily in a matter very sacred to us.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Officers of the Elmira Reformatory openly declare that the resignation of Dr. Frank W. Robertson as Superintendent of that institution was due to threats made against his life.

MARION, Ind., Oct. 25. -- Jesse McClure, a farmhand, murdered his two sons, aged five and seven years, this afternoon, leaving their bodies in a fence corner. While a mob was forming to capture and lynch him, McClure drove on a run to this city and gave himself up. Sheriff Williams, fearing violence, started for Indianapolis with him this evening.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Mrs. Thomas A. Edison, wife of the inventor, will give an unusual Hallow-e'en party in the stable of her residence, Glenmont, in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, next Saturday night. Each guest will have to pay, and the proceeds will be added to the building fund of the Orange Methodist Church, of which Mrs. Edison is a member.

The election of a new Board of Directors and the adoption of the reports of the Executive and other committees were the principal matters of interest at the twenty-ninth annual meeting of the United Hebrew Charities of the City of New York, held in the Hebrew Charities Building, at Twenty-first Street and Second Avenue, yesterday morning.

The Brooklyn Bridge police force has been cut down again, and now the men that are left there are wondering when some more of their number are to be taken away. The latest order came Saturday night, and by it the three men who have done duty at the two Park Row roadway crossings and the sidewalk between these two points have been taken off.

The reports received at both Fusion headquarters are to the effect that the opposition to Mayor Low which was at one time shown among the Germans on account of the excise situation has prac- tically disappeared, and that what there is left of it will be removed by the can- did statement of the Mayor on Friday evening.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst preached yesterday morning at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church upon the issues involved in the present municipal campaign, saying in part:

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 25. -- The Pacific Express Company yesterday had to close the office at tiongview. The people refused to give drinking water to the noaunion men installed there, and they had to be withdrawn. The company " turned down " emphatically propositions of Texarkana and Little Rock Boards of Trade to submit the strike to arbitration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although you differ in opinion in your editorials from Mr. Cockran on questions of taxation, I wish to add to his list more tenements of the east side of which I happen to be the landlord.

Three hundred German lodges and socie- ties were represented yesterday at a meating held in the afternoon in the Teutonia Aesembly Rooms, for the purpose of booming William F. Grell as the independent German Democratic candidate for Sheriff. Several speeches were made in behalf of Grell, and a collection taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses of an active campaign for the time before election day.

Excitement ran high on the Hariem River Speedway yesterday morning, when three runaways occurred within a few minutes of one another. The road was crowded with vehicles, and that only one resulted seriously was considered almost A miracle by the thousands of spectators, but was due in a great measure to the work of the mounted police.

The usual epitome of the business of last week discloses a marked contrast between the bond and stock markets, and warrants some inferences regarding the stock market not hitherto ap- parent. Among seventy-six stocks which moved a point or more, and which there- fore are representative of the general market's tone, forty advanced.

SOFIA, Oct. 12. -- Sofia and its vicinity have been from the remotest times the stamping ground of various races. The Ugrish barbarians, the refined Greek merchants, the Roman soldiers, the Slavic peasants, heathens, Mohammedans, Christians, and Jews all passed in kaleidoscopic array within sight of the nearby Vitosh Mountain; all lived and struggled here, the new-comer usually doing his utmost to destroy, or at least to obliterate, that which his predecessor had built.

Columbia awaits with eager interest the coining of Saturday, when her eleven lines up with Yale at the Polo Grounds in the leading game of the local football season this year, and Columbia only hopes to win. Yale, of course, will rule a favorite for the contest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your leader "The Tammany Argu- ment" in to-day's issue, particularly that part wherein you attempt by an analysis of figures to show to a doubting public that Mr. Low's re-election is assured, does not appeal to me as conclusive -- nor, I dare say, to a great many of your readers.

The decision of the engineers now em- ployed as motormen on the electric trains of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad not to take immediate action on the strike proposition which they have had under discussion for some days, but to await the arrival of the Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and leave the decision to him, is wise and commendable.

The Grand Field Council of the Volunteers of America, under Gen. Ballington and Mrs. Maud Booth, will convene in Pittsburg on Sunday and during the following week. The organization has philanthropic institutions in various cities throughout the country. The annual reports show that over 400 women have been cared for and over 3,000 beds have been provided for young women in the Homes of Mercy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Intelligent service to God and to the State was the subject of an address by President Roosevelt to the 7,000 persons who attended the public open-air missionary service at Mount St. Albans this afternoon on the close of the Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul. The President was accompanied by Mrs. Roosevelt, Admiral Dewey, and Brig. Gen. John M. Wilson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The sun dance last Summer near Eagle City, Oklahoma, where two scientists, Prof. Mooner of the Smithsonian Institution and Dr. Dorsey, Director of the Field Museum of Chicago, are said to have hired an Indian to torture himself and reproduce the old-time sun dance of his people, is to be ventilated in Congress this Winter.
LENOX, Mass., Oct. 25. -- John Sloane is entertaining his nephew, the Rev. Henry Sloane Coffin of New York, at Wyndhurst.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 23. -- The Northern Pacific Railway is getting a number of important branch lines constructed at the cost of the communities to be served, providing the railroad will lay tracks and operate the lines.

Early this year a commission, consist- ing of Messrs. HUGH H. HANNA and CHARLES A. CONANT and Prof. JERE- MIAH W. JENKS, was sent out by the Department of State to discuss in the capitals of Europe the introduction of the gold exchange standard into China and other silver-using countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The annual report of Gen. George L. Gillespie, Chief of Engineers, United States Army, for the year ended June 30, 1903, dealing with fortifications and river and harbor work has been made public. He refers first to the work of constructing fortifications that has been going on under the general scheme of the Endicott board, and adds:...

Every man in the Detective Bureau at Police Headquarters is interested in the notification that there is a reward of $2,500 for whoever can give information leading to the apprehension of the thieves who recently robbed the firm of Knight, Frank Rutley, auctioneers in London, of Jewelry valued at $100,000.
To the Editor of The New York Times: On Sunday the Rev. Dr. Minot J. Savage said:
Through Morris Brown, candidate of the Social Democratic Party for Controller, the Central Federated Union got unexpectedly into a hot political debate yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- This city is having a hot Mayoralty fight between three candidates, and the business arid professional men are strongly with Charles S. Banks, the regular Democratic nominee. Their views with regard to the contest, especially as regards ex-Mayor Michael J. Dillon, the independent candidate, are expressed by one prominent citizen as follows:

An interesting golf match, will tie played on Wednesday on the links of the St. Andrew's Golf Club. It will be the fifth semiannual handicap competition, open to members of the University Club. The St. Andrew's Golf Club, many of whose members are college graduates and members of the University Club, was the originator of this event, and it has met with great popularity among alumni golfers in this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The Department of Agriculture has brought out the first in- quiry into the adulteration of food, drugs, and liquors authorized under the new food law. The subject is olive oils and the adulterants that are used in goods sold throughout the country.

"Mike" Egan of Jersey City, who recently returned from Ireland after successfully defending his title to handball champion of the world, was matched again yesterday. He and James Fitzgerald of San Francisco are to play a match at the Olympic Athletic Club, San Francisco, the winner of the best in fifteen games to be declared champion.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Is it true that railroad freight rates are lower during the time the Erie Canal is open for traffic?

Hugh McLaughlin was very much incensed at a report published in a morning paper to the effect that he would go to Florida before Election Day. When asked whether the report was true he answered quickly:

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Russians, says the Moscow correspondent of The Times, are apparently satisfied that the frequent drafts of men and munitions from the home Governments to the Far East are not destined to take part in a military picnic. Russian financial and business circles, which are the real interested quarters, display apprehension, and do not share the confident optimism of the leading press organs.

Of fourteen men burled by the collapse of the roof in the rapid transit tunnel at One Hundred and Ninety-fifth Street on Saturday night ten are dead and the remaining four seriously injured. Blasts had been made in the section under Fort George hill, and a few minutes later a gang of twenty-two men had gone into the tunnel to clear away the rock dislodged by the blast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Postmaster General Payne announced, to-night that it has been decided to investigate the New York Post Office as the nest chapter in the work now going, on in the Post Office Department. "This is something that we have had in mind for months," said Mr. Payne.

ALBANY, Oct. 26 -- Reports received here to-day tell of snowfalls in all the cities and towns north of here during the past twenty-four hours. In this city the first snow of the season fell, with the thermometer at the freezing point, and the wind blowing a gale from the northwest. There were several brisk flurries during the afternoon, but the snow was wet and melted as soon as it reached the ground.

William S. Devery had made a speech to his followers from the Twenty-fourth Assembly District in the back room of a saloon at 1,059 Second Avenue last night, and was entering his carriage when a committee of women from the Woman's National Rescue League intercepted him and announced that they had some pertinent questions to ask.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Judge Kohlsaat of the United States District Court to-day referred the case of the Acme Harvester Company of Peoria to Referee McCulloch of Peoria, to report as to the solvency of the concern and the advisability of appointing a receiver. Attorney S.O. Levinson declared that the petition was filed so that the concern might be further embarrassed.

There is an interesting and encouraging contrast between business upon the Stock Exchange yesterday and yesterday week. On the earlier Monday there was liberal selling of other people's property upon the theory that they would sacrifice it upon the bad news from Baltimore. Yesterday the news from there was that the embarrassed institutions' affairs were wearing a better aspect, and that prospects were promising for resumption by both trust companies.

Although the tension or the relations of Russia and Japan seems to have been somewhat relaxed, the war cloud has by no means disappeared. Many persons will be inclined to attach, more importance to the action of "Lloyd's" in advancing the rates of insurance on vessels bound for Oriental waters than to any of the gossip so industriously collected and disseminated at European or Asiatic capitals.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The Times's Russian correspondents say a memorial for the purpose of vindicating the Jews against the aspersions cast on them in the official accounts of the Gomel riots has been forwarded to the Ministry of the Interior by the Jewish Society of Gomel.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Several people were injured -- none dangerously, however, as by a miracle -- in a railroad smashup that occurred in the Orange station of the Lackawanna Railroad this morning at 8:30 o'clock just as the rush of commuters to the metropolis was at its height. The swift Paseaic and Delaware Express crashed into the Hackettstown local train as it was moving out of the station.

-- Our British friends are still worried by a fact Which to us whatever we may have thought about it in the past, now seems little more than amusing -- the fact that when the great fight between the North and the South was in progress here, a very large number of Britishers who considered themselves particularly knowing were unfortunate enough to back the loser somewhat heavily.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26 -- The annual stockholders' meeting of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company, a Connecticut corporation, was held in this city at noon today. There were present E.H. Sanborn, Second Vice President, who was in the, chair; Judge Lynde Harrison of New Haven, Charles E. Orvis of Philadelphia as Secretary, C.E. Graves of New Haven, and six newspaper reporters, two or three of whom held proxies of stockholders.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- With the production to-night of "The Orchid," George Edwardes successfully inaugurated the new Gaiety Theatre. The date of opening was originally set for to-morrow, but it was advanced one day to suit the convenience of King Edward.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Slason Thompson, head of one of the bureaus of the General Managers' Association, recently addressed a letter to the railway companies, asking the Question: "Are there a million owners of railway securities is the United States?"

In submitting to Mr. D.M. PARRY a series of questions to which specific answers were requested, the Central Labor Union of Indianapolis probably thought they were digging a pit for the person addressed. Undoubtedly the pit was dug, but those who fell therein were the interrogators.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- Trading continued excessively dull and prices generally were unchanged. There appeared to be a free offering of certain securities around the present level of quotations, and in only a few cases do buyers seem disposed to raise their bids. A fractional advance by Philadelphia Company and a gain of 1 1/8 by United Gas Improvement were the only changes from Saturday's finals worth noting.

It is rather early in the season, but strawberry shortcake is out. It is one of the delicacies for the Thanksgiving feasts, and in generous chunks is to be seen in the candy shops in the form of bonbon boxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Secretary Monday to-day announced that he had decided to divide the contract for furnishing armor plate among the three bidders, namely, the Carnegie, the Bethlehem, and the Midvale Works, all of Pennsylvania.
BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- The money market is gradually working easier. There are no material reductions in rates.

WASHINGTON, Oct 26. -- Justice Brown of the United States Supreme Court to-day delivered the opinion of the court in the case of Clara Perry vs. Cornelius L. Haines, involving the question as to whether the admiralty jurisdiction of the Federal courts extends to canals and canal boats. The court held that it did.

It is to be hoped that the Republican leaders fully understand the responsibility of their party for the adoption of the improved and developed waterways of the State and the consequences that will surely follow if they allow that immensely important enterprise to be defeated.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Members of the International Association of Machinists, through their President, James O'Connell, were informed to-day by the National Metal Trades Association that until they conceded "the open shop and the right of the individual to work where he pleases" there can be no joint trade agreement between the two organizations.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- The trial of Countess Isabella Wesierska Kwilecki, belonging to a rich and aristocratic Polish family, on the charge of pretending to have borne a son and presenting him as the heir to an estate at Wroblewe. Province of Posen, consisting of 10,000 acres and having a yearly rent roil totaling $15,000, began here this morning.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 26 -- The first performance of "Captain Charlie" was given by Aubrey Boucicault at the Court Square Theatre to-night. It was not a smooth one for Mr. Boucicault, and his associates frequently showed nervousness that robbed of their force many of the points made by Mr. Sayre in his lines and made the action halting.

The vital principle and substance of the contest between Fusion and Tammany are faithfully represented in the single issue of the enforcement of the excise law. The whole question is whether we shall maintain in this city a government of men or a government of laws.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- There is to be added to the art treasures of the White House Theobald Chartran's painting of the scene when the peace protocol at the close or the Spanish war was signed in the Cabinet room. H.C. Frick has tendered the picture as a gift to the United States, and President Roosevelt has accepted it for the Government.

The Battery Place Realty Company has bought from the Stephen Whitney estate the four-story buildings 4 and 5 West Street and 6 and S Washington Street, on a plot 48.10 by 179.8. The properties edjoin the Whitehall Building, owned by the Battery Place Realty Company, and have been acquired with a view to protecting the light and air of that structure along its northerly side.
BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- It has been announced that Emperor William will have erected a monument to the memory of Herr Krupp, the gunmaker.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- An order has been issued, says the Sofia correspondent of The Times, for the complete demobilization of the Bulgarian reserves, who return to their homes to-day, (Tuesday.)

There was a large and demonstrative Fusion meeting last night at Cooper Union, under the auspices of the Henry George Democratic Committee of One Hundred. Lawson Purdy, Secretary of the Tax Reform Association; Cyrus L. Sulzberger, Fusion candidate for President of the Roard of Aldermen in Manhattan; Henry George, Judge Samuel Seabury, and others spoke on the abuses under Tammany, and pointed out what had been accomplished to improve the city under Fusion.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 26 -- To-day's programme at the Driving Park was devoid of special feature. Major Delmar, the two-minute trotting gelding, was expected to try for his own record, but, owing to the prevalence of a strong wind, the event was postponed until to-morrow.

The Fusion rally under the auspices of the Citizens Union at the Academy or Music, Brooklyn, last tight f drew out an audience which completely filled that spacious edifice. District Attorney Jerome was the star orator of the evening. When be appeared on the stage the entire audience, women as well as men.

Mayor Low began his last week of campaigning last night with an automobile tour through the Borough of Queens, addressing meetings in Broadway Lyceum, Flushing; Warwick Hall, Corona, and Schuetzen Park, Astoria. He covered in all thirty miles, and where the roads were good the automobile in which the Mayor traveled, and which belonged to Dr. H.F. Owsley of Flushing, sped along at the rate of twenty miles an hour.

ALBANY, Oct. 26 -- Attorney General Cunnee to-day made public an important opinion upon various questions relating to the use of voting machines, particularly with reference to procedure in the emergency of a breakdown of the machine. In connection with the opinion Mr. Cunneen said:

Tammany is carrying on a campaign by poster. A great many of the statements printed on its posters are shameless falsehoods. Here is a specimen: "LOW and CUTTING favor Sunday recreation only for the aristocrats who live in mansions and belong to clubs." That statement could be made only with wicked intent to deceive.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Willard J. Saunders of Dickinson Centre, N.Y., the Democratic candidate for member of the Assembly from Franklin County, is making his canvass on the issue of opposition PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 26 to the policy of allowing individuals to purchase and hold, for their exclusive use, immense private parks in the Adirondacks.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 26 -- The National Baseball Commission, with Chairman August Hermann, Henry J.E. Bruce, Harry C. Pulliam, President of the National League, and Ban B. Johnson, President of the American League, present, was in session here all day and adjourned to night.

Having just finished a successful run at the Columbia Theatre, in Brooklyn, the Wells-Dunne-Harlan company made its appearance at the West End Theatre last night. It was warmly welcomed and showed up at its best in the Hoyt play, "A Black Sheep." Otis Harlan is in his original role of Hot Stuff.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Sheriff Joseph C. Andress of Newin, N.J., has been traveling through Western Sussex County and a part of Pike County, Penn., to-day searching for clues to the identity of the person who shot Mr. and Mrs. Victor E. Bevans at their country home near Bevans, N.J., on Friday evening last, killing Mrs. Bevans and seriously injuring her husband.

BUTTE, Mont., Oct. 26 -- F. Augustus Heinze this afternoon offered to arbitrate the whole mining controversy here with the Amalgamated Copper Company, each side to appoint two men and these four to choose a fifth, the decision to be final and binding on both parties.

On the only occasion on which Sir Henry Irving ever had a performance booed in his London Lyceum, it is said that a friendly voice cried out from the pit, "It's not meant for you Guv'nor!" In America the right to applaud does not involve the right to hiss; but there were many at the Broadway Theatre last night who were in a mood to cry "Boo" to the "Dante" of MM. Sardou and Moreau.
William Dalton, Commissioner of Water Supply under Mayor Van Wyck. and Tamroany leader in the Twenty-fifth Assembly District, on Saturday sent this letter to Mayor Low:

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Money was increasingly scarce in the market to-day as a result of the Bank of England absorbing supplies and a better demand on month-end Stock Exchange requirements. Rates hardened. Discounts were firm.

Five thousand persons were crowded into Grand Central Palace last night to listen to Col. George B. MoClellan and his associates on the Democratic city ticket, together with W. Bourke Cockran, who made his second speech of the campaign. William Hepburn Russell also spoke. The crowd gathered early, and by 8 o'clock, when Col. McClellan arrived with his campaign manager, the big hall was filled.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26 -- In a give and take encounter between William Jennings Bryan and Judge Henry Stoddard, the attorney for the contestant or the will or Philo S. Bennett, the charge, was flatly, made by Mr. Bryan and repeated to Judge Stoddard's face, that the contest or the will was on account of Judge Stoddard's lack of interest in free silver doctrines.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- There was a further curtailing of the force to-day at the Pencoyd Iron Works. One hundred men, whose duty it has been to weigh the product of the works, were dismissed, leaving only fifty still engaged in that department.

Higher prices were the rule in the trading in curb securities yesterday, with the exception of the market leader, Greene Consolidated Copper, which closed at a fractional loss. American Can preferred was fairly active, and advanced a point. Standard Oil was again in demand, and on a sale of about, sixty shares rose 9 points, to 665.
FORT RILEY, Kan, Oct. 26 -- Fort Riley still belongs to the Government. The enemy made a desperate effort to capture it today and had not secured it at the time the hait was called.

The Fusion movement is particularly fortunate in its candidate for the President of the Borough of Manhattan. The office is an extremely important one, second only, in many regards, to that of Mayor. Its incumbent has immediately in charge many of the intimate interests of the people of the borough, especially the extension, repair, and maintenance of its streets, their paving, the care of the sewers,

On the calendar of the United States Circuit Court for tie Southern District of New York, which began its session yesterday, there are 195 appeals from decisions of the Board of United States General Appraisors, which, if decided and not carried on appeal to the Circuit Court of Appeals, will clear up many thousands of the suspended protests now before the board.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 -- From shortly before 1 o'clock to-day until the closing hour, 3 o'clock, runs were made on the savings departments of three banks of St. Louis, and at the same time more than the ordinary amount of withdrawals by savings depositors were noticeable in the other banking institutions.

Fire practically wiped out two whole city blocks, including several stores and private residences, last night in the section bounded by Riverdale Avenue, Church and Ackerman Streets, King's Bridge. Twenty houses in all were destroyed, causing a property loss estimated at $150,000.

Mr. BRYAN'S political opponents have never brought any charge against him except of being a misleading and demagogic politician. He was long ago epigrammatically described as a man without private vices or public virtues. There is, we believe, no considerable or respectable section of the American people who would gladly or readily accept, or would incline to believe, accusations against his personal character.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- A dispatch of interest to American Catholics from the correspondent of the Diario of Madrid at the Vatican is forwarded by the Madrid correspondent of The Times.

Manufacturers of cotton goods declared yesterday that the market was decidedly stronger as a result of the jump in the price of raw cotton. A week ago 3 1/8 cents bid and 3 3/8 cents asked were the quotations on cotton cloth regulars.

Hugh McLaughlin issued another statement yesterday in which he insisted that the campaign in Brooklyn was being made on a moral issue solely, and again accused Charles F. Murphy, Tammany's leader, of falsehood. He said in part:

Although there was no formal presentation of figures at the meeting of the Tammany Executive Committee in Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon, practically all of the district leaders in the course of the day told Mr. Murphy what their tentative estimates of the McClellan vote would be. These figures would show that the election of Mr. McClellan is counted on by the Tammany leaders by approximately 30,000 plurality.
No citizen should fail to see that the re-election of the Fusion administration will be of much greater importance and benefit even than the electioin two years ago.

A fruitless effort was made yesterday to bring about some decided action by the Aldermen in the matter of granting a franchise to the New York and Port Chester Railroad Company. It was the intention of Alderman Herbert Parsons, in case a meeting was held, to move that the Railroad Committee be discharged from further consideration of the matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is one point, and one point only, in the letter of "Maurice Herbert," published in to-day's issue, which calls for notice, and that because the statement has been repeated so often by our Tammany Hall friends that an elucidation of it by so calm a reasoner and well-informed a political prophet as Mr. Herbert should be of great interest.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 27. -- Joseph Chamberlain addressed another large meeting in the Hippodrome here to-night. It was held by the Workingmen's Conservative Association, and the 5,000 persons present gave the speaker an enthusiastic reception.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Money was much wanted in the market to-day. Discounts were firm.

There is nothing sweeter to the bookmaker than was the result of the single stake decided at the Aqueduct race track yesterday, when at the finish of the Nassau, Gaviota, the outsider of the three horses than ran, got up in the last stride, and, in the picturesque language of the betting ring, "skinned the lamb."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Bible speaks of two classes of angels, which may, be appropriately designated "Angels of Light" and "Angels or Darkness." Recently I have received, through the mails, two political documents, entitled "Father Knickerbocker Adrift" and "Protect Your Homes."

DENVER, Oct. 27 -- Harry Payne Whitney has taken to mining in earnest. At present he represents the Whitney-Ryan syndicate's interest in the Guggenheim Exploration Company and allied corporations, interested in smelting, mining, and the manufacture of lead products, and he is not going to be a silent partner.

In an admirable little speech on Monday evening Mr. LAWSON PURDY, who is one of the most trustworthy and accurate authorities on questions of taxation in the city, exposed the misrepresentations of Mr. COCKRAN as to alleged favoritism in valuations of real estate.
NASHUA, N.H., Oct. 27 -- The closing meet of the New England half-mile circuit opened to-day under rather unfavorable conditions. The weather was cold, and a high wind blew all day.

Controller Edward M. Grout failed in an attempt to cross the bridge early yesterday morning, after a "whirlwind" speechmaking tour of Brooklyn. It was late when the Controller left, a meeting place in South Brooklyn to return to the Hoftman House, in company with his friend, ex-Senator William J. La Roche, who had been with him all the evening.

Maennerchor Hall, in East Fifty-sixth Street, was the pivot about which the Fusion campaign revolved last night, for each member of the Fusion ticket in the course of his own individual campaign orbit stopped off there to make a speech. The meeting was under the auspices of the German-American Union of Manhattan, of which the component societies are the German Republican County Committee, the German-American Municipal League, and the German-American League.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- Hovagin Maroukin, assistant editor of Young Armenia, upon being advised to-day of the murder of Sagatel Bagouni in London, said that the crime was the outcome of a split which occurred in the revolutionary party in 1902. The party was formed to secure the freedom of Armenia, and in 1902 it split over the question of Socialism.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Miss Grace Elcox daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Elcox, and Harry Day Bowman of New York were married in St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, at 5 o'clock this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jonathan N. Meeker, pastor of the Market Street Methodist Episcopal Church of Paterson.

OMAHA, Oct. 27 -- City Attorney Wright has been instructed by the City Council to commence foreclosure proceedings against the Omaha Belt Railway Company to enforce the collection of $5,000 taxes levied against its property. The road encircles the city, and is controlled by the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- The attendance at brokerage offices to-day was the largest in a long time, and the customers were there for business, although their operations were mainly on the New York market, in which they were free buyers of Rock Island, Southern Pacific, Metropolitan, and the Eries, which issues, for the day at least, were in favor.

MUNISING, Mich., Oct. 27 -- The Gilchrist steamer Manhattan, while endeavoring last night to find shelter under Grand Island, Lake Superior, burned near Beacon Light. The crew was taken off safely by the tug Ward. The Manhattan was built in 1887, and was worth about $50,000.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 -- James L. Blair, whose chances for recovery were considered exceedingly doubtful Monday night, now has an even chance for recovery, according to a statement of his physician, Dr. George Homan, made late to-night. When dawn broke at Airdrie this morning Mr. Blair seemed nearer death than at any time since his collapse of last Saturday.

Up the State there has been a very active agitation against the proposed expenditure of $101,000,000 to deepen and enlarge the Erie Canal to a capacity sufficient to allow the passage of 1,000-ton barges. In the rural counties a large adverse vote is expected. It is estimated that the project will be defeated unless 250,000 votes in its favor are cast in this city and 40,000 in Erie.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Naval Constructor H.G. Smith, now on duty in the Bureau of Construction and Repair, will shortly resign in order to accept a position with the shipbuilding company of which Rear Admiral Bowles, who has resigned as Chief Constructor of the Navy, is to become President.

NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 27 -- Edward M. Shepard made the principal address tonight at the Democratic ratification meeting held at the New Rochelle Theatre. He denounced the resignation of State Senator Charles P. McClelland to accept a Government position and declared that the election of his successor was a matter of not only State, but National, politics.

LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 27. -- The firm of Horace L. Shattuck Son, hardware, bicycle, and automobile dealers of Lowell, Boston, and Providence, has assigned. The firm is one of the oldest in the city, and while the main business here is in hardware, in the other cities, especially at the Summer branch in Newport, the trade is confined almost exclusively to bicycles and automobiles.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Sagatel Sagouni, President of the Armenian Revolutionary Society, was murdered at the doorstep of his lodgings, in Nunhead, an unpretentious little suburb of London, last evening.

A general charge was made by M. Linn Bruce yesterday that Tammany Hall was bringing in thousands of men for purposes of colonization. The Citizens' Union announced that it would stand ready to pay $30,000 for violations of the election law.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The belief that the proposed investigation of the New York Post Office has for its object the removal of Postmaster Van Cott is not credited in Administration circles here.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision denying the appeal of Albert T. Patrick in the matter of the probate of the will of William M. Rice, of whose murder he stands convicted. The court concurs in the judgment of the lower courts that the alleged will offered by Patrick is a forgery.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- It is possible that George N. Harvey, Superintendent of the Pawnee Indian School in Oklahoma, may be removed from his office.
A correspondent wishes us to expose the fallacy of the argument used by the Tammany speakers, which he states as follows:

Daniel Le Roy Dresser testified yesterday morning at the bankruptcy hearing before Referee Stanley W. Dexter. At first he was asked to tell what he knew of the scheme for establishing the Richmond Real Estate Development Company, of which he was to become President on condition that certain securities, alleged to be worth $850,000, were deposited for the benefit of the creditors of Dresser Co.

The formal opening of the William H. Davis Free Industrial School for Crippled Children at 471 West Fifty-seventh Street, took place yesterday afternoon. A housewarming and reception was held in the school by women interested in the work. Mrs. William S. Hawk gave the large four-story building, which the school now occupies, in memory of her father, William H. Davis.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- Some time after the recent conclave the Vatican was surprised by a report from the United States that a high prelate of the Church there had spoken repeatedly of the possibility of several Americans being nominated to be Cardinals.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 27 -- Adolph Friedman, an American who had recently been conducting a Summer garden here, and who was arrested in this city yesterday, at the instance of the United States authorities, on the charge of fraudulent bankruptcy in New York, has been released from custody.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A dispatch from Gen. MacArthur, dated at Manila, Dec. 28, 1900, has just come to light in the War Department which casts a doubt on the sincerity of Japan's friendship for the United States in the operations against the insurgent Filipinos.

Before the final adjournment was taken yesterday in the trial of Samuel J. Parks, walking delegate of the Housesmiths' and Bridgemen's Union, on a charge of having extorted $500 from Louis Schmitt, Treasurer of the Tiffany Studios, to settle a strike, the jury box had been filled and Assistant District Attorney Rand, who is conducting the prosecution, had made his opening address to the jury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- At the thirty-first annual meeting of the American Public Health Association here to-day Gen. George M. Sternberg, Surgeon General, United States Army, retired, delivered an address in which he said the great prosperity of some of the Southern States during recent years had been due to their protection from yellow fever, which formerly operated as a serious barrier to industrial and commercial progress.

Following the lead of the Stock Exchange market, the trading in curb securities at the opening showed higher prices, and improvement continued practically throughout the list, until the rumors of trouble in St. Louis caused a sharp reaction, and the list as a whole showed closing prices near to the lowest for the day.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The base political trick of Tammany Hall by which it secured Grout and Fornes upon its ticket is only equaled by its false and fraudulent statements with which it is trying to influence independent citizens to vote for its subservient candidates. Its misrepresentations are an insult to the intelligence of the people.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 27 -- The capital stock of the United States Glass Company was to-day reduced from $5,000,000 to $3,200,000 by the retirement of the entire preferred stock of $1,000,000 and $800,000 of the common stock. Bonds in the sum of $770,000 were also voted to be issued for the purpose of retiring the preferred stock.

Wilbur F. Wakeman, the Secretary of the American Protective Tariff League, is responsible for the circulation of a story that the sub-contractors on the rapid transit subway have contributed to the Tammany campaign fund to the extent of either $50,000 or $55,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The presence of Alfred L. Skitt of New York in Chicago today has disclosed a possibility that the settlement of the street car franchise here, so far as the Union Traction Company is concerned, may be accomplished by a new company to be formed by Mr. Skitt and men whom he represents.
GUANAJUATA, Mexico, Oct. 27 -- Great excitement was caused here to-day by an attempt on the life of President Diaz, who was a guest of the State Government during the festivities here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- William Rossell, a member of the Finance Committee of the Chicago Federation of Labor and formerly business agent of the International Association of Machinists, is at his home suffering from an attack made upon him by four unidentified men. Rossell, after being drugged, was horribly beaten by the quartet, who then left him lying in a gutter for dead.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 27 -- The auxiliary schooner yacht Atlantic, owned by Wilson Marshall of Bridgeport, Conn., a member of the New York Yacht Club and Larchmont Yacht Club, arrived here to-day from New London, having made a record run.

Although there was little of a formal nature going on yesterday, there were many fashionable folk in town. Miss Goelet and Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt were among those who name in from the country. Mrs. Ogden Goelet, who has made a flying trip to Newport, joined her daughter, and Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt, who are located at Millbrook for the Autumn, will be here a few days.

The first gun in the campaign of Whistler exhibitions is fired this week by Mr. E. G. Kennedy at the Wunderlich Gallery, Fifth Avenue, near Twenty-sixth Street. The walls are filled with etchings, for some of which much larger sums are paid than for the average painting made by artists of repute; the tables contain portfolios of lithographs drawn by the departed master on the stone and printed under his direct supervision.

"In all dramatic art," said Mr. Eugene Presbrey in his neatly carpentered little speech last night, "there is a great deal of collaboration." It sounded like the beginning of an essay in dramatic criticism. But it wasn't, just then at least, for Mr. Presbrey dropped suddenly into sheer compliment.

Little Hugh Sinclair, the child whose father, Dr. Daniel A. Sinclair, took him from his mother at Pine Hill, N. Y., early last Summer, soon after the husband and wife had separated, was placed in the custody of the mother by a decision rendered yesterday by Justice McCall in the Supreme Court.

Stocks rise and react. Call money easy, 2 1/2@3 per cent. Business upon the Stock Exchange yesterday was both more active and better distributed, but the tone was uncertain. There was no chill in the forenoon, the disposition to continue the advance being apparent, but as the day progressed the news became unfavorable.

Louis Minsky has resold the block front on the east side of Madison Avenue, between One Hundred and Second and One Hundred and Third Streets, 200.10 by 100. This completes the resale of the entire block bounded by Madison and Park Avenues and One Hundred and Second and One Hundred and Third Streets, purchased by Mr. Minsky from Jacob Ruppert about a month ago.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 27 -- The champion pacer Dan Patch, unbeaten, son of Joe Patchen, to-day gave his greatest display of speed and stamina. He established new figures for the half-mile record recently set at 0:57 1/2 by Prince Alert, over the Providence, R.I., track, and half an hour later he circled the local mile course and created a new world's wagon record to supplant his own mark of 1:59 1/4.

When Messrs. Klaw Erlanger announced that they intended to produce a work of Shakespeare's with all the appurtenances of musical comedy of the Beauty and the Beast type, a fear was not ungrounded that the appurtenances would prove impertinences and that they would turn out to be less of beauty than of the beast.

-- That automobiles are injurious to, roads is a charge which, so far as we have seen, has never, in this country, been included among the many counts in the indictment against the new machines. Therefore MARSHAL HALSTEAD, the United States Consul at Birmingham, has done well in calling attention to certain observations credited by The London Car Magazine to the County Surveyor of Surrey.

BOSTON, Oct. 28. -- Thomas W. Lawson made another statement to-day to the miners' union at Butte, in which he says that F. Augustus Heinze and his brother, A.F. Heinze, have repeatedly negotiated with him for the settlement of the differences between them and the Amalgamated Copper Company by purchase by Mr. Lawson or the Amalgamated Company of Mr. Heinze's mining properties.

Tammany calls itself the "Regular Democratic Organization of the County of New York." Under that title it has issued its circular appealing to each individual addressed to "vote for the Democratic ticket." Here is the gist of the argument in the circular:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 28. -- Lou Dillon, queen of the light harness turf and holder of the world's trotting record, to-day added one more to the long list of her world's marks, when at the Memphis Driving Park she closed her season's campaign by lowering the record for trotting to wagon to 2:00.
The following is the answer of Lord Alverstone to the second of the questions decided By the Alaska Boundary Commission, "What Channel Is the Portland Channel?"
LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Money was in fair supply in the market to-day in spite of the payment of u2,000,000 of new Treasury bills yesterday. Discounts were firm on rumors of further gold exports.

It appears that the dwellers in the Bronx are warmly interested in the procurement of a franchise for the New York and Port Chester Railroad Company to operate its road through that borough upon the ground that it will largely increase their facilities for transit.

BOSTON, Oct 28. -- The marriage of Miss Rosamund Blanchard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Duncan, and Count Carlo von Courten, Lieutenant in the Bavarian Army and Gentleman in Waiting on the King, took place at noon to-day in the vestry of St. Cecelia's Catholic Church, at the Back Bay.

The arraignment yesterday in the Jefferson Market Court of Alexander Sachs, seventeen years old, of 67 Ludlow Street, brought to light another chapter of a story of real life in New York on the lines of Dickens's narrative of Fagin, the Artful Dodger, and kindred characters in "Oliver Twist."

Variations of open-table billiards, combined with several innings of deft line nursing, brought A.M. Charles to the end of his string of 150 points ahead of his opponent, W.B. De Young, yesterday in the amateur tournament at Maurice Daly's academy. The match was in the Class C Division of the competition, at fourteeninch balk line, with two counts allowed within the restricted spaces, and Charles counted his 150 carroms, leaving De Young at 124.

Only one football game of importance was played yesterday, that being held at Annapolis, between the Naval Cadets and the Georgetown College team. It resulted disastrously for the cadets, Georgetown winning by 12 to 5.
Changes in stations of officers of the Corps of Engineers:

Superintendent of Elections Morgan sent a letter yesterday to M. Linn Bruce, President of the Republican County Committee, to the effect that Tammany would attempt to make sure of the election of the Democratic ticket by wholesale corruption of Assembly district leaders on the Republican side.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Among the important questions that will come before the Fifty-eighth Congress will be the policy of the Government with regard to railroad building in the Philippines. The island Government will urge the need of a railroad system through the larger islands as soon as capital can be induced to undertake the work.

Measured by the excitement it aroused, the event at Aqueduct yesterday was the closing race, awarded to the odds-on favorite. Oarsman, after long debate by the Stewards, on the score that Stonewall, the horse who finished first, had fouled other horses in the race. The justice of the official decision was open to debate, and much debated by the home-going crowd, for the race was full of foul and rough riding.

The coterie of specialists in the various issues listed on the Stock Exchange have adopted a device whereby they are now known to their fellows according to their several preferences. The scheme is a small name plate worn on the lapel of the coat with the name of the stock specialties in the centre, inclosed by a gold border.

The Board of United States General ApPraisers handed down a decision yesterday concerning the classification of narrow-width silk ribbons. The case has been before the board for a long time, and many protests hinge on it. It has already been settled by the courts, but the importers have reopened the question in this case, and will probably appeal from the board's decision.

Abraham M. Morgenroth has sold the two seven-story apartment houses on the north side of Ninety-fifth Street, 225 feet west of West End Avenue, on plot 125 by 100.8. The buyer is Myron H. Oppenheim, who gives in part payment the plot 100.11 by 100, at the northeast corner of West End Avenue and One Hundred and First Street.

The entire force of the New York State Insurance Department, under Chief Examiner Isaac Vanderpoel, was engaged from Jan. 2 to Sept. 21, 1903, in investigating the details of the Mutual Life Insurance Company's transactions. According to Mr. Vanderpoel's report the officials of the corporation gave him every assistance, and he arrived at conclusions showing that the management was conspicuous for conscientiousness and care.

Frank S. Gardiner, Secretary of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, which is conducting a vigorous campaign on behalf of the proposed canal improvement, yesterday called attention to the latest moves which have been made by the opponents of the proposition that the State should issue the bonds necessary to cover the expense of the improvements.

ST. LOUIS. Oct. 28. -- The condition of James L. Blair showed continued improvement to-day, and there was relief evident in the atmosphere of the beautiful home near Kirkwood. Though the patient did not rest well all night, he did get some sound sleep.

Before a courtroom crowded with members of the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union several witnesses yesterday swore that Samuel J. Parks, walking delegate of the organization, extorted $500 from Louis Schmitt.
