Treasurer of the Tiffany Studios, and incidentally offered to betray the cause of the men whose interests he was paid to protect.

To-day the most important convention ever called to discuss the relations between employers and wage earners meets in Chicago. Its immediate object is to form a National federation of employers' associations. The paramount issue it will defend is that of the open shop.

Mayor Low addressed five meetings in Brooklyn last evening, opening his tour of the borough at Prospect Hall, in Prospect Avenue, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, and making his last speech at the Palace Rink in Grand Street, near Wythe Avenue, Williamsburg, in the heart of the district controlled by State Senator Patrick H. McCarren.

WASHINGTON, Oct 28. -- The fact that the Republican National Committee is expected to assemble in Washington during the first ten days of December has given rise to many reports and considerable speculation as to what will be done by the committee regarding the Presidential campaign of next year.

TIFLIS, Russian Transcaucasia, Oct. 28. -- Prince Galitzin, Governor General of the Caucasus, had a narrow escape from assassination yesterday on the outskirts of this town. Three natives stabbed the Governor General thrice. They fled, but were subsequently shot down by Cossacks.

Before 4,000 persons in Carnegie Hall last night, at the mass meeting of the Independent Democracy, Col. George B. McClellan declared that he would not continue Gen. Francis V. Greene in office as Police Commissioner in the event of being elected Mayor. He also attacked the administration for the condition of the streets of the city, and promised that if Mayor he would prevent the present torn up conditions and the interruption of traffic.

BOSTON, Oct. 28. -- The money market Shows no change, Call loans, 2 1/2@3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 3/4@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@ 6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 2 1/2@3 per cent.; New York funds, $1@$1.05 premium. Clearings, $20,857,397; balances. $1,501,356.

MADRID, Oct. 28. -- Velasco, the milltary commandant at Bilbao, telegraphs the Government that at daybreak this morning the garrison occupied all strategic position. He reports that the cavalry repeatedly charged the rioters in the old part of the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- The stock market, though dull, was firm, but prices were not appreciably changed in the active stocks. Advances in such stocks as did advance were as a rule only small fractions, but Lehigh Navigation was 2 points above its last previous sale, and Philadelphia and Erie 1 point lower.

Dr. J.H. McCormick of the State Board of Health of Kentucky said on Tuesday in Washington before the American Public Health Association that an official investigation into the subject made by him disclosed the fact that the blankets in sleeping cars are cleaned only once in six months. Assistant Division Superintendent S. Wilson of the Pullman Company here said yesterday that the doctor was mistaken.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Charles Burr Todd of New York, an author, wandered into Police Headquarters here to-day in a dazed and delirious condition, and is now being cared for at St. Elizabeth's Asylum for the Insane. Mr. Todd was unknown to the officials at the City Hall, and it was not until Gen. H.V. Boynton, an old friend, heard of his being at Headquarters that any one was found to identify him.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Representative Littauer of New York and his counsel, John G. Milburn of Buffalo, had an extended conference to-day with President Roosevelt.

Mr. McCLELLAN says that if he is elected no party and no set of men "shall dictate his policy." For two years no party and no set of men have dictated Mr. Low's policy, and those that have undertaken so to do have failed.

John Alexander Dowie last night, at his services and meeting in Madison Square Garden, denied that he and his host will depart from New York before the time first announced. To prove this he exhibited the contracts on the tickets with the railroad companies. His preaching at the night service consisted in telling how great he was, and he dwelt largely on his astute sense of business in the establishment of Zion City.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "Guards, stop those people! Don't allow any one to leave this place! I'll show them who's master here!" Thus roared Dowie at the first meeting.

That full text of Lord ALVERSTONE'S judgment on the crucial questions submitted to the Alaskan Tribunal is now at hand. The two questions are the second and the fifth. The former simply inquires: What channel is the Portland Channel? The latter, which is encumbered with much verbiage, in effect inquires whether the framers of the treaty of 1825 meant to exclude Great Britain from the coast.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 28. -- Two teams of women golfers, representing the Philadelphia and New York Women's Golf Associations, met to-day on the Country Club course for the honor of challenging the Boston team for the Griscom Trophy, which the Boston women won last year. This is the fourth annual competition for the cup.
LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The American conductor, Emil Paur, received a great reception last night at an orchestral concert in Queen's Hall. The critics this morning give unreserved praise to his work.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- Count Lamsdorff, the Russian Foreign Minister, arrived here at 9 o'clock this morning, accompanied by a large suite. In spite of the early hour M Delcasse, the French Minister for Foreign Affairs, was at the railroad station to extend a personal greeting to the Russian Minister.

Col. McCLELLAN should really be more careful how he takes typewritten misinformation about municipal affairs from Tammany headquarters and gives it out in his speeches on his own authority. The practice is liable to make him very ridiculous. On Tuesday evening he made an incursion into Queens.

The significance of yesterday's stock market lay not in its price movement, but in its tone under trying conditions. Reassurances from St. Louis are convincing to any willing to be convinced, even though the disturbing features which are published are not those of most serious import.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 28. -- Deputy United States Marshal Bauer this afternoon received from, the District Attorney at Cincinnati a warrant for Mrs. Samuel Bosswell of this city on the charge of using the mails to defraud, but she was too ill to be taken into custody.

Aggregate shipments of $2,950,000 were made by New York banks yesterday to St. Louis, New Orleans, and Chicago through the Sub-Treasury. The amounts were $2,100,000 to St. Louis, $650,000 to Chicago, and $200,000 to New Orleans, and the St. Louis shipment, together with the total of all, constituted records not here to fore approached in New York for movements of currency to a single point and to all points in a single day.

Police Commissioner Greene announced yesterday that he had taken precautions to prevent illegal voting. "If," he added, any citizen has reason to think that the police reports are not correct or that any person has illegally registered or is expecting to vote fraudulently or in any way violate the election law, if he will send the names to Police Headquarters or to the Captain of the precinct they will be immediately, investigated.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 28. -- Annapolis met defeat to-day on the football field by the stronger team of Georgetown College, the latter winning by the score of 12 to 5. This makes the second and worst defeat Annapolis has received this season. All the scoring was done in the first half, and only once was either goal dangerously threatened during the second part of the game.

William Travers Jerome struck his stride of 1901 last night, when he went to Brooklyn and made four addresses in the cause of Fusion. Two of the speeches were made in churches. "I haven't teen in so many churches since I first put on pants," said the District Attorney at his last meeting. In all four meetings he was greeted with unbounded enthusiasm.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- An oracular official telegram from Constantinople, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, announces that Turkey has suspended the demobilization of her troops, but will probably resume it again before long. It is supposed in Vienna that the Sultan, filled with loathing for the Austro-Russian scheme of control, wishes to promote the belief that he will fight rather than yield.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28. -- The run on the savinds departments of the trust companies seems about over. The rush was terrific in the morning, but by 1 o'clock the uneasiness of small depositors seemed to have been removed. At that hour there were only a few depositors withdrawing daily balance accounts or giving notice of withdrawal of savings deposits.

The latest information from Philadelphia is to the effect that the negotiations between the builders and the representatives of the unions connected with the building trades have reached a deadlock. The employers properly refuse to abandon the principle of the open shop, and very wisely in view of what appear to be the conditions in sight; and the unions refuse to relinquish the weapon of the sympathetic strike.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Lord Strathcona, Canadian High Commissioner, has accepted the nomination to the Chancellorship of Aberdeen University. The nomination was offered to Andrew Carnegie, who declined it in favor of Lord Strathcona.

The land department of the Detroit, Mackinac and Marquette Railroad Company announces that it is prepared to receive tenders of the company's land grant bonds to the extent of $500,000 par value for the purpose of retiring this amount of the issue, of which the total now outstanding is $2,771,000.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- It is said to be the intention of President Stickney of the Chicago Great Western Railway to extend his line from Omaha to Denver next year.

A conference between Superintendent of Elections George W. Morgan and Police Commissioner Greene was held yesterday afternoon at Police Headquarters, and one of the fruits of it was the adoption of a plan for the verifying of the reports from the registration lists where any doubt exists in regard to any name or names thereon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Commander Booth-Tucker received the news of his wife's death first upon calling at the headquarters, all efforts to reach him earlier having failed. He came here from New York and was met at the railway station by Salvation Army officials and taken in a carriage direct to headquarters.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The news of the death of Mrs. Booth-Tucker reached the International Salvationist headquarters here through a dispatch of The Associated Press. The heads of the international departments immediately met, held a short service, and dispatched a cable message of sympathy to the Salvation Army headquarters in New York.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 29. -- A cablegram was received here to-day announcing another big fire in Bluefields, Nicaragua, entailing a loss of $350,000, the majority of the sufferers being American merchants who also have offices in this city. This is the third time in three years that Bluefields has been visited by a disastrous fire.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- After being arrested on the charge of attempting to burn his drug store in Lestershire today, Truman H. Wheeler took poison in the Court House in this city this afternoon and died about an hour later in the County Jail.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- George L. Watson has declined the commission of the prominent Clyde yachtsman (previously referred to as contemplating challenging for the America's Cup) to design a cup challenger on the ground that it is hopeless for British or other over-sea challengers to continue to contest for the trophy under the measurement rule by which challengers have been rated.
BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- At a Republican rally in Tremont Temple this evening Secretary of the Treasury Shaw was the principal speaker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The disclosure made in Gen. MacArthur's dispatch to the War Department, dated Dec. 28, 1900, to the effect that the Chancellor of the Japanese Consulate at Manila during the Summer of 1900 made overtures to the insurgents for certain desired concessions, has caused some perturbation among diplomats here, and there is a good deal of curiosity to know more of the incident.

The defense of Samuel J. Parks, walking delegate of the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union, now an trial before Judge Newburger in the Court of General Sessions on a charge of extorting $500 from the Tiffany Studios to settle a strike, opened yesterday with the defendant himself taking the stand and denying that he was guilty of the crime with which he is charged.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Emerson, somewhere alluding to the gusty political speaker of his day, said: "So hot, my little Sir." While genuinely great issues are at stake in this campaign, it seems to me that they have too often been belittled and obscured by absurd and unjust denunciation and by scurrility and abuse.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Seventy-five lives and six vessels constitute Gloucester's tribute to the perilous waters of the North Atlantic during the twelve months just ended.

There was a greater diversity in the trading in curb securities yesterday than on the previous day, but this was not accompanied by any increase in activity. A number of issues showed losses, particularly Northern Securities, which at one time was 88 bid, but no sale took place until within a few minutes of the close, when a few hundred shares sold at a loss of 1 1/4 at 86 3/4.

A correspondent who in former years has made advance estimates of the city vote which showed a remarkable approach to correctness sends us, in tabulated form, the results of his examination of political conditions and the registration figures this year. Our correspondent has not attempted a prediction or a forecast.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 29 -- The Clement A. Griscom inter-city golf trophy for women will remain in Boston for another year, as a team from that association which captured it from New York last year fairly overwhelmed a team from the Philadelphia association at the Country Club to-day by a score of 46 to 5.

Several decisions affecting the classification of objects of art and of a similar nature were handed down yesterday by the United States General Appraisers. Those of most importance were written by Judge Waite, and affected the classification of marble vases and of wooden church statuary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a Democrat, who considers manhood as a first, and party affiliation as a second condition in a true American citizen's life, I must confess that Tammany's Democracy is just as much related to real and earnest Democracy as Dowieism is to true and earnest Christianity.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- The Russian Foreign Minister, Count Lamsdorff, and M. Delcasse, the French Minister for Foreign Affairs, went together to Versailles this morning and spent most of the day there. The officials of the Foreign Office purposely selected Versailles, as affording a quiet retreat, for the continuance of the conferences under agreeable circumstances.

Edward J. Carpenter, recorded at Police Headquarters as of many aliases and "grafting" occupations -- 4,862 Rogues Gallery -- was wounded in four places at 1 A.M. yesterday in the cafe of the Rossmore Hotel by an ex-convict, Thomas Lannahan, or "Doe" Nailor, who used a revolver. Carpenter was taken to the New York Hospital, and an operation for laparotomy disclosed that six intestines were perforated.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Oct. 29. -- Thomas Bechtel, who was held awaiting investigation of the murder of his sister, Mabel Bechtel, at their home a few days ago, committed suicide this evening in his cell in the Central Police Station. The police consider this act a practical acknowledgment of Bechtel's guilt.

Tammany has made a "call" for funds from corporations and from persons doing business whose work is subject to official supervision. Coupled with this is what is construed as an intimation that, in case of McClellan's election an opportunity will be afforded for a "liberal" enforcement of the laws and ordinances of the city.

The Commission on Law's Delay appointed by Gov. Odell to devise the best means of expediting the administration of justice held its first public meeting yesterday afternoon in the Chamber of Commerce. Chairman Wheeler H. Peckham presided and all of the members were present.

Many close bowling contests were decided last night in the bowling tournaments with which New York abounds. The best score of this season, and practically, that of this year, was 264, the highest individual score. WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Secretary Hitchcock to-day received a telegram from Portland, Ore., announcing the indictment of three more persons in connection with the public land frauds in that State. The telegram gave the names of the persons indicted as Emma L. Watson, Guy Huff, and Norman Williams.
LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Money was in active demand in the market to-day for Stock Exchange and month-end requirements. Discounts wore steady.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Sir Thomas Lipton has definitely withdrawn his offer to present a cup for a transatlantic yacht race in 1904, and has made way for the German Emperor, who will present a cup through the New York Yacht Club and the Atlantic Yacht Club. This result was attained by the following interchange of telegrams, the first being from Sir Thomas Lipton to Emperor William on Oct. 27:

Andrew H. Green yesterday isued an open letter to the electorate of New York City, in which tie advised a negative vote on the canal referendum. The total cost of the canal, including the interest on bonds, Mr. Green states, will be at least $155,000,000, of which not less than $100,000,000 will fall on this city.

NEWTON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- George Jagers, who was arrested at his home yesterday in Peters Valley and brought here to the county jail charged with the murder of Mrs. Victor Bevins, has neither eaten nor slept since his arrest. The authorities today were searching for his brother Joseph. They want him, it is said, to testify against George.

The average weight of the Yale rush line that will face Columbia to-morrow will be 202 pounds, this being one of the heaviest lines that the Yale team has put on the field. Whether Batchelder or Miller will play right guard will be decided only on the day of the game. Morton will take his old place at left guard, and Roraback will play centre.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- A slightly firmer tone is noted in the money market. Call loans, 3@3 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 3/4@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 2 1/2@3 per cent.; New York funds, par. Clearings, $19,425,567; balances, $1,160,720.

TORONTO, Oct. 29. -- Capt. Sartoris's published letter has brought a hornet's nest round his ears. Some of the newspapers good-naturedly ridicule his pithy remarks on the United States talking Canada, and numerous correspondents are after him through the press with a sharp stick. The Captain sends another letter to-day to The World in which he says:
PITTSBURG, Oct. 29. -- The verdict of the Coroner's jury on the death of City Recorder Joseph Owen Brown was reached at 6:45 this evening after fourteen sittings and is as follows:

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- Serious rioting occurred this afternoon in front of the Bourse de Travail (Labor Exchange) in the workingmen's district. The Prefect of Police says forty-five policemen were wounded, and that over 100 rioters were injured, a number of them seriously. Thus far 100 arrests have been made.
FORT MADISON, Iowa, Oct. 29. -- The remains of Mrs. Booth-Tucker have been brought here. Twenty-seven other persons badly injured, were also brought to this city.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 29. -- The slump in the coke trade was more marked last week. Production dropped 30,000 tons, and the shipments were over 30,000 tons less than the previous week. There were not as many ovens blown out this week as has been the rule, but production was retricted by a larger number of ovens being in operation only five days.

Reckless as he is in campaign utterances, Mr. McCLELLAN does not venture to say that Gen. GREENE has not been an honest and efficient Police Commissioner. A good citizen bringing charges against a Police Commissioner would naturally and inevitably make a lax enforcement of the laws the matter of his accusation.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler made a stirring campaign speech last night at Waverley Hall, Waverley and Myrtle Avenues, Brooklyn. Dr. Cuyler is eighty-four years old, and his step is faltering. When he spoke to the friends who helped him from his cab to the hall they had to bend near to him so that they mighthear, so weak and low was his voice.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- Thomas W. Lawson is evidently angered by Mr. Heinze's answer to his amended proposition of yesterday. In a telegram sent to Edward Long, President of the Butte Miners' Union, this evening, he said:
CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- In his history of Gen. William Booth and the Salvation Army, Commander Booth-Tucker devoted a brief chapter to his wife: Of her he said:

ELMIRA, Oct. 29. -- In appointing Col. Joseph F. Scott, Superintendent of the Massachusetts reformatory for boys at Concord, as the new Superintendent of the Elmira Reformatory to succeed Dr. Frank W. Robertson, whose resignation was last week accepted, the board has selected a strong personal friend of former Superintendent Z.R. Brockway.

The new decoration of that ceiling of the City Hall which hears the debates of the Aldermen should have visitors enough this week, for the President of the Borough, the architect of the Borough, the contractor to whom the decorations were let, and the painter who designed and executed the ceiling's adornment each and severally issued cards for Thursday, Oct. 29. from 2 to 8 P.M.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- Stock dealings assumed insignificant proportions today, the sales aggregating only 10,254 shares and $57,300 bonds. Prices were irregular. Bergner Engel preferred was up 1 and Philadelphia Traction advanced 5/8. International Smokeless Powder was 3/4 Power and Electric Storage Battery broke 2 7/8 to 46, recovering 1 on the next sale.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the determined and titanic competition for the natural proportion or more of the transportation traffic, not only between our own and other parts of this country, but also with our foreign competitor to the north, we must recognize the working of natural laws and direct our efforts to secure their aid, if success is to be ours.

Edmund G. Hammersly of Philadelphia was appointed ancillary receiver of the McKinley-Lanning Loan and Trust Company of Philadelphia yesterday by Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court. The company has its, home office in Philadelphia, and has for a dozen years been engaged in the business of loaning money upon Western farm property.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Roosevelt demands militant honesty," vide Washington news in your issue of this date. I am glad to know that he has demanded it. I hope that he will not merely continue to demand it, but that he will do something to make honesty militant, and triumphant, too.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 -- The Harvard Fall handicap track games were held on Soldiers Field this afternoon. The games were discouraging, for with the exception of the quarter mile, which was won by B.L. Young, a freshman, with a handicap of twenty-five yards, none of the '07 men came to the front.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- The case of Naval Ensign Hussner, who was recently imprisoned for killing an artilleryman who failed to salute him properly, has resulted in the issuance of an imperial decree against the abuse of private soldiers by officers.

Yesterday's stiffening of the call money market under repeated shipments to St. Louis and other points, the pressure of cotton bills, and sales of stock reported to be for foreign account, all operated together to produce a second break in foreign exchange, which had declined to 20 points the day before.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say much speculation has been provoked in political circles in St. Petersburg by the news that M. Witte has succeeded in obtaining an interview with the Czar at Darmstadt.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 29 -- Eleanor Robson appeared at the Lyceum Theatre tonight in the first production of Israel Zangwill's comedy, "Merely Mary Ann." Miss Robson's work completely won the audience. She was admirably supported.

Army. A board is appointed to meet at Fort Myer for the examination of officers for promotion. Detail: Col. Winfield S. Edgerly. Second Cavalry; Major John F. Gullfoyle, Twelfth Cavalry; Major James D. Glennan, Surgeon; Major Augustus P. Blocksom, First Cavalry: Capt. James S. Wilson, Assistant Surgeon, and First Lieut, Charles G. Harvey, Second Cavalry Recorder.

Carnegie Hall was well filled last night on the occasion of the Fusion mass meeting held under the auspices of the Plaza Republican Club of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District. There were few vacant seats except in the boxes. The upper galleries were packed.

Charles F. Murphy, leader of Tammany Hall, dropped into the Grand Central Palace for a few minutes last night. A mass meeting of German-American Democrats was in progress, with G.F. Wahle as presiding officer. From where the Tammany leader sat, in one of the rear boxes, it could be seen that at least half the seats down stairs were vacant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Senator McCumber of North Dakota, who arrived here to -day, believes that the National prosperity of the past few years is abnormal, and there is surprise throughout the country that there has not been a reaction.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 29. -- Mrs. Emma Booth-Tucker, Consul in America of the Salvation Army, wife of Commander Booth-Tucker, and second daughter of Gen. William Booth, founder of the army, was killed in the wreck of the east-bound California Train No. 2, near Dean Lake, Mo., eighty-five miles east of Kansas City, at 9:30 o'clock last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Application was made to-day in Springfield for articles of incorporation of the Chicago Railways Company which, it is said, will be the financail factor in the solution of the problems confronting the Union Traction Company and its underlying corporations. The Commissioners making, the application are Nathan C. Johnson, W.E. Cooper, and Archibald G. Thiselton.

BUTTE, Mon., Oct. 29. -- Two appeals to the Supreme Court in the MacGinnis injunction suits against the Boston and Montana Company have been perfected in record-breaking time. The injunction orders were made by Judge Clancy last Friday, and to-day by stipulation of the attorneys on both sides, the two big records, each consisting of nearly 400 pages of typewritten matter, were settled.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this hour of grave danger, when the most sacred heritage of a free and independent people hangs trembling in the balance, there is only one ground on which all patriots, all lovers of civic purity and good government, all exponents of public and private virtue can stand without loss of self-respect or betrayal of their principles.

The editor of The Wine and Spirit Gazette, Mr. J.P. SMITH, publishes in The Evening Post a remarkable letter declaring that "the best interests of the liquor trade require that the non-political and non-partisan character of the liquor business be strictly maintained."

Although no quorum was present at yesterday's special meeting of the Board of Aldermen, called for the purpose of forcing an issue on the subject of the New York and Port Chester Railroad franchise, the thirty-six members who answered the roll calls were together long enough to engage in wrangling, showing the political bitterness that has been aroused over the tangled situation.

Readers of Mr. Morley's "Life of Gladstone," a work that abounds in the high quality of candor and is perhaps the best full biography of a great man ever written, cannot fall to be struck by the evidence it affords of the extraordinary Slowness with which Mr. Gladstone came to his mental maturity.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 -- Before a United States Commissioner to-day Vahtan Krikorian, the Armenian poet, journalist, and orator, who was arrested yesterday upon his arrival from London, where Sagatel Sagouni was murdered on Monday, demanded to know on what charge he was being held.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- One person dead and possibly two, a dozen persons injured, and a property loss of more than $200,000 is the result of a fire which occurred at noon to-day in the block bounded by the Schuylkill River, Race, Vine, and Twenty-third Streets.

That a city liKe Allegheny has shown an apathy in dealing with its local epidemic of smallpox which rendered it necessary for the State Board of Health to threaten a strict quarantine against it, imprison its population, and paralyze its industries and business, is a fact less difficult of satisfactory explanation than it would be bad New York not shown like apathy in 1900.

A NEW edition of this admirable bock is one of several signs of a Bushnell revival following hard upon the centennial anniversary of Bushnell's birth. April 14, 1902. Originally published in 1880, It was long since out of print, fortunately in one respect, for Dr, Munger, in the preface to his "Horace Bushnell," 1800, wrote that were this biography still on the market he should not have undertaken his own book.
THE TORCH. By Herbert M. Hopkins. Pp. 308. Indianapolls: The Bobbe-Merrill Company.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 30 -- The Rev. Dr. Edwin S. Lines, Bishop-elect of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, will be consecrated at Grace Episcopal Church. Walnut and Broad Streets. Newark, on the morning of Nov. 18, the services to begin at 10:30 o'clock. This announcement was made by Dr. Lines at a meeting of the Standing Committee of the diocese, which was held in the rectory of Grace Church this morning.

PERICLES AND ASPASIA. By Walter Savage Landor. Privately printed. Decorated title page. Photogravure frontispiece. Initial letters. Folio. Pp. 235. Lioen boards. Hand-made paper. Uncut. Paper labels. New York: Scott-Thaw Company.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 30 -- The Town Board of North Hempstead this afternoon voted to lease to William K. Vanderbilt the approach to Success Lake, which he desires closed. The lease is to run for ninety-nine years. In return Mr. Vanderbilt agrees to enlarge and improve the approaches to the lake at the other end.
THE YELLOW VAN. By Richard Whiteing, author of "No. 5 John Street" and "The Island." One volume. New York: The Century Company. $1.50.

BALTIMORE, Oct 30 -- At a Democratic mass meeting held to-night speeches were made by Edwin Warfield, the candidate for Governor, and a number of leading Democrats, including Senator Gorman. An immense crowd was present, and the speaking was, preceded by stereoptlcan views illustrating the association of white and negro delegates at the late Republican State Convention.

THE Illuminative phrase which serves as a title for this brief article is quoted from some confessions of Sir Leslie Stephen, K.C.B., in the third installment of his reminiscences contributed to The Atlantic Monthly.

It fell to the lot of Mr. Hermann Hart Wetzler to open the musical season in New York with the first of his series of orchestral concerts, which he gave last evening in Carnegie Hall. He has this year, as he had last, a large orchestra, composed of good men, with Mr. Leopold Lichtenberg as first violin, an artist whose reappearance as a public player is most welcome.

United States District Attorney Youngs, Miss Amy Wren, his stenographer, and Post Office Inspector Little, three witnesses who have been wanted by the counsel for the defense in the Beavers case, yesterday appeared at the hearing when it was resumed before Commissioner Hitchcook in the Federal Building, and were put on the witness stand.

MARY AUSTIN, in bar now book, "The Land of Little Rain," just published by Houghton, Miffin Co., has described that section of our country lying in Southeastern California between broken ranged of the Sierras beyond Death Valley and extending far into the Mojave Desert.

Lovers of football have some splendid games in store to-day, but the great game in which the widest amount of interest is centred is the Yale-Columbia game in this city at the Polo Grounds. The meeting of Princeton and Cornell at Princeton and Harvard and the Carlisle Indians at Cambridge will be notable matches, but they are forced to give way from the standpoint of general football importance, to the local event.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The fourth-coming new book by Thomas Hardy will be a poetical drama in six acts. This will be the famous writer's first venture in that field. Macmillan Co. will soon publish the book.
A SEQUENCE IN HEARTS. By Mary Mass. 12mo. Pp. 333. Philadelphia: The J.B. Lippincott Company. $1.50.

IN GLANCING at the three large volumes which make up this book of 1,968 pages one thinks, with a sign, of the brief, clear, interesting narrative in which Pintarch was wont to tell the story of a hero's life; and yet who would wish that less ample scope and verge were given to the character and the career of the greatest English statesman of the Victorian era?
FOI R-IN-HAND. A Story of Smart Life in New York and at a Country Club. By Geraldine Anthony. 12mo. New York: D. Appleton Co.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Money was scarce in the market to-day. Discounts were strengthened by the shortage in the loanable capital and the decline in the rate of New York exchange.

Huston Asinari have sold for the Wells Realty and Construction Company of Philadelphia the Markwell Hotel, a new ninestory structure at 220 and 222 West Forty-ninth Street, 40 by 100.5. The buyers give in part payment 330, 332, and 334 Eighth Avenue, east side, between Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh Streets, five-story flats, with stores, on plot 65 by 100.

Samuel J. Parks, walking delegate of the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union, was convicted of extortion for the second time yesterday by a jury in Judge Newburger's court, where he has been on trial since last Monday on the complaint of Louis Schmitt, Treasurer of the Tiffany Studios, who charged that he was compelled under unlawful threats to pay Parks $500 in order to be allowed to do business in this city.
THE HEART OF ROME. A Tale of the "Lost Water." By Francis Morion Crawford. In one volume. Pp. 390. 12mo, New York: The Macmillan Company. $1.50.
THE BEATEN PATH. A Novel By Richard Lawrence Makin. In one volume Cloth, 12mo. Pp. 544. New York: The Macmillan Company. $1.50.
SILVER LININGS. By Nina Rhoades, 12mo. New York: MeClure, Phillips Co.

Following the recent announcement that nine stories are to be added to the Tribune Building, details were made public yesterday of the acquisition of considerable adjoining property on Frankfort Street, over which the nineteen-story building will be extended, making it one of the largest office structures in the city.

MR.YEATS elsewhere has confessed himself jealous for Ireland whenever the legends some other land were made beautiful by a modern writer, and in the present volume of verse he has himself preserved in his own haunting measures the stories of Baile and Aillnn, of the old age of Queen Maeve, of Cuchullain and his son with the pale face and the red hair, set against the Background of the dim gray mountains that he loves.

In the course of his speech last night in Terrace Garden George B. McClellan took up the statement of the day before issued by Police Commissioner Greene, in which the latter declared that McClellan, as Mayer, could not remove the Police Commissioner without showing that the public interests demanded it.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- George L. Watson, the yacht designer, is inviting estimates for building a new racing schooner. Haste is stipulated, the intention being to have her in readiness for the trans-Atlantic race for the cup offered by Emperor William.
HIGHWAYS AND BYWAYS IN SOUTH WALES. By A.G. Bradley. With Illustrations by Frederick L. Griggs. Cloth. Pp. 418. New York: The Macmillan Company. $2.

The hearing Instituted by the creditors of Dresser Co. was continued yesterday morning in the office of Stanley W. Dexter, referee in bankruptcy, at 71 Broadway, and the lawyer for the creditors. J. Aspinwall Hodge, continued his questions relative to the formation of the Richmond Real Estate Development Company, the organizers of which came to Mr. Dresser's aid with a proposition to deposit for the benefit of the creditors securities valued at $830,000.

BUTTE, Mant., Oct. 30 -- James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railroad; United States Senator Paris Gibson, and Gov. Joseph K. Toole of Montana arrived here to-day in Mr. Hill's private car and held a conference with United States Senator W.A. Clark.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The Autumn Salon was opened to-day at the Petit Palais by the Minister of Fine Arts, M. Chaumie. The attendance was large and fashionable. A number of paintings are exhibited by American artists, including portraits by J.W. Alexander and landscapes by Albert Dakin Gihon.

I HAVE never been able."says Prof. Newcomb, "to confine my attention to astronomy with that exclusiveness which is commonly considered necessary to the highest success in any profession." Nevertheless he seems to have done very well, his rank as an astronomer not being second to that of any other man of his profession in this country.

The first part of the library or the late Howard T. Goodwin, sold Thursday, Friday, and Saturday of last week in Davis Harvey's auction rooms, Philadelphia, brought only about one-tenth of the original cost -- a result chiefly due to the presence of numerous elaborate subscription books, which seldom sell well in the open market.

Ginn Co of Boston have attempted one of the most ambitious series of school traders ever put before the educational world in the publication of a set of text books written by L.H. Jones, A.M., President of the Michigan State Normal College. The series is strong in Illustration, and what commends the first book of the set more than anything else is an elaborate scheme of color Illustrations.
CHILDREN OF MEN. By Bruno Lewling. New York: McClure, Phillips Co.

PITTSBURG. Oct. 30 -- The structural iron workers of Pittsburg will not heed the call to strike. Local No. 3 has contract with local firms until next year, and the officials say they will not break them by acting in sympathy with the Eastern locals. The structural mills will be hard hit by the Eastern strike, as contractors will stop pending in specifications when erection work ceases.

THERE are always beaps of books for the banies each year, for the little ones, the medium-sized ones, and the big ones. They are very good Looks, too, as a rule, and it i fortunate that there are babies enough to use them all, for many of them are quite as interesting, with their pictures and jingling rhymes, for the older people, and without the little ones they would have no excuse for enjoying them.

HUGH McLAUGHLIN is most fortunate in the tactics Tammany employs against him. The right of free speech is held sacred in every part of this Union by all its people, and that right Mr. MURPHY in his blindness and folly has denied to the Democrats of Kings County. Tammany forbids the Democratic candidate for President of Brooklyn Borough to be present and speak at regular Democratic mass meetings in this campaign.

That special meeting of the Board of Aldermen was not held yesterday, although it was called for the consideration of a single question. The result is apparently as satisfactory to that good Tammany man. Alderman SULLIVAN, as it is unsatisfactory to that equally good Tammany man, President HAFFEN of the Bronx.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge and ex-Senator George Turner, two of the American Commisisoners to the Alaska Boundary Tribunal, returned to this country yesterday on the steamship Cedric of the White Star Line. The third member of the commission, Secretary of War Elihu Root, will return shortly.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 30 -- After a conference between members of the Liberal Party which lasted three days, and which was attended with much heated discussion, it has been resolved to accept the amendments to the programme of the military party suggested by Emperor Francis Joseph and approved by Count Stephen Tisza, the new Hungarian Premier.

PUEBLO, Col., Oct. 30 -- By an act of train wreckers an east-bound Santa Fe passenger train known as the Colorado-Chicago "Filer." in which was one car filled with Eastern bankers homeward bound from California, was derailed at 1:30 o'clock this morning at Apishapa Creek, thirty-five miles east of this city.

Stocks dull and heavy. Call money firmer, 2@5 per cent. Forecasts of the bank statement indicating the loss of the larger part of the surplus reserve through the greatest known loss of cash for a week was the feature of yesterday. Room traders and blackboard watchers yawned vapidly as they waited vainly for something shocking to happen.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 30 -- Believing that his company has in sight tin ore worth $100,000,000, W.C.J. Bartels has arrived from Nome en route to New York to collect and rush around Cape Horn electric and other machinery for an immense smelter plant which, he wishes to get in operation next year on the shore of Bering Sea.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The remarks made Sunday morning by the Rev. Dr. Brooks of St. Mark's Colored Methodist Episcopal Church, in West Fifty-third Street, are open to severe criticism by all classes of good men, lovers of a republican form of government by the people and for the people.
ELEANOR LEE. A Novel. By Margaret E. Sangster. In one volume. Pp. 322. 12mo. Cloth. New York: Fleming 11. Revell Company. $1.50.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One thing is sure to take place if the Citizens' Union ticket wins, and that is the retention in office of the conscientious and able Street Cleaning Commissioner, Major John McG. Woodbury, and his equally honest and most efficient deputy, Capt. Francis M. Gibson.
THE MARK. By Aqulla Kempster. Illustrated, New York: Doubleday, Page Co.

Nearly 2,000 lots of rugs and carpets had been sold at the salesrooms of H.S. Tavshanjian when the auctioneer ceased his labors at 6 P.M. yesterday after five days of the special sale. To-day the sale will go on, and then there will be one week's intermission in order to allow the removal of the goods already sold.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The Autumn ball was given to-night at the Tuxedo Club. The large circular ballroom was artistically decorated with cedars decked with carefully selected tinted oak and maple leaves, which banked the ballroom. In an arbor and on the stage opposite two orchestras played alternately.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: YOUR correspondent from Newport, in her letter of Oct. 20, under the heading. "The Vice of Reading," has touched upon an important point in the consideration of the subject, Courses outlined in serious reading, which are numerous, are useful in their way, but you cannot force the frivolous reader into becoming an admirer of the classics.

If there was any doubt that the canal, question could arouse intense enthusiasm in this city, the doubt was destroyed by a great gathering that assembled in Cooper Union last night to hear a series of addresses by distinguished orators and wellknown business men invited to give their views under the auspices of the Canal Association of Greater New York.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: A few days since I was reading Dr. Nchemlah Grew's "Cosmologia Sacra," published in 1701, and in the first paragraph of Chapter III., writing "Of the Principles of Bodies," he says: "As there is no Maximum whereunto we can go, but God only; so there is no Minimum, but a Point; which hath no Dimensions, but only a "whereness, and is next to nothing."

WASHINGTON. Oct. 30 -- Representatives of the shipbuilding companies who have contracts to build war vessels are frequently required to visit Washington to consult the navy authorities in connection with their business, and it frequently happens that their presence here gives, rise to reports that they are gathered for ulterior designs on the Navy Department or schemes to be pushed before Congress.

There was suggestion of the best and most pleasant days of the Summer racing season in the sport at the Aqueduct track yesterday, and, though results were to the disadvantage of the betting visitors, the crowd was warmed to the point of enthusiasm by sharply contested races and track record breaking performances.

NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 30 -- At the meeting held here to-night in the New Rochelle Theatre in the interest of the regular Democratic nominees, and particularly in behalf of the candidacy of William Temple Emmet to succeed ex-State Senator C.P. McClelland, Martin W. Littleton and William C. Osborne were the chief speakers.

MR. G.K. CHESTERTON has made an amazing discovery. It is nothing more nor less than that Mr. Kipling has not a particle of patriotism. Now, there is one thing that is more characteristic of Mr. Kipling's verse than another, it is its intense patriotism.

Howard B. Rathbone writes with the zeal and accuracy of one who knows in the November number of Country Life in America on "The Training of a Hunting Dog." Mr. Rathbone is a practical trainer, who soon crushes the unagination and the sense of humor in a setter pup. He is also a skillful photographer of animals, and his pictures of young hunting dogs enduring the discipline of training are admirable.

REMARKABLE in many ways is the volume which tells of the labors of Francois Coillard, a member of the Evangelical Mission of Paris, which has been most intelligently translated by Catherine Winkworth Mackintosh.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Fusion, as I understand it, is only another word for strictly business methods in the administration of the government of our municipality. Such being the case, one is simply amazed that any official of Fusion should issue permits for the erection of poles or masts in the streets from which to suspend partisan banners.

MADRID, Oct. 30 -- Sir Henry Mortimer Durand, the British Ambassador to Spain, who has been appointed Ambassador to the United States, was interviewed to-day by a correspondent of The Associated Press in the library of the British Embassy here. The embassy, formerly a convent, faces the Senate Building and the Statue of Canovas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Welsh miners who came over on the steamship Haverford and all others that can be apprehended are to be deported. This is the decision of Commissicner Garfield, acting as Secretary, to whom the case was appealed.
PA GLADDEN. The Story of a Common Man. By Elizabeth Cherry Waltz. 12mo. Pp. 338. New York: The Century Company. $1.50.

Although a National strike of structural iron workers has been ordered for to-day by the International Association, there were indications last night that peace might be restored in the building trade by the capitulation of Local No. 2 of the Housesmiths and Bridgemen -- Samuel Parks's union -- which has fomented most of the trouble.
Paul Miller, twenty-two years old, who is under indictment for grand larceny and burglary in the third degree and who was awaiting trial in the Queens County Jail, made his escape Thursday night.
THE CIRCLE IN THE SQUARE. A Story of the Burden of the South. By Baldwin Sears. In one volume. Pp. 306. 12mo. Cloth. A.S. Barnes Co.

The estimated loss of currency by the local banks during the past week exceeds $15,000,000 and this amount so closely approximates the surplus reserves as shown by last Saturday's bank statement that the question is asked how far the loss in cash will wipe out the reserves held in excess of requirements.
SUBJECT -- David's grief over Absolom. II. Samuel, xxiv., 33.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 30 -- Long shots were in evidence at Latonia to-day, and Kilmerie, at 5 to 2, was the only short-price horse winning. Galba, which was coupled in the betting with Creoline, ran into the fourth jump, throwing Jockey Albert Songer. The boy was slightly injured. The racing was exciting, made so by the many close finishes during the day.

Mention has been made of the preface of W.B Yeats to the second edition of Lady Gregory's collection and translation of the cycle of Irish legends which she names after the hero, "Cuchulain of Muirthemne," Umpored by Charles Scribner's Sons.) Mr. Yeats speaks in that preface of the judicious selection of the form of English in which to clothe the epic of the thrice-wonderful deeds and adventures of the Irish hero.

Andrew Carnegie, his wife, and little daughter were passengers on the White Star Line steamship Cedric, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool. As Mr. Carnegie paced the deck of the steamship on her way from Quarantine to the dock ho looked the picture of health, and he said that he felt ten years younger than when he started on his "vacation" last July.

The second part of the Right Hon. Sir George Otto Trevelyan's important history of "The American Revolution, (from an English point of view,) is to be issued next week by Longmans, Green Co. This is in two volumes and includes the period from 1770, when the news of the battle of Lexington reached England, through the religious question and the settlement thereof in 1787.

Mr. Yeats speaks in that preface of the judicious selection of the form of English in which to clothe the epic of the thrice-wonderful deeds and adventures of the Irish hero.

This is in two volumes and includes the period from 1770, when the news of the battle of Lexington reached England, through the religious question and the settlement thereof in 1787.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May it not be that there is much truth in the Tammany assertion that the present contest for the election of city officials is of national import and interest?

PRINCETON, Oct. 31. -- A conference on athletics was held at Prof. Fine's house this morning. Those present were: Princeton -- Profs. Fine, McClenahan, and McClure; Harvard -- Prof. White; Cornell -- Prof. Dennis; Columbia -- Prof. Kemp; Pennsylvania -- Profs. Smith and Geyelin; Brown -- Profs. Hill and Melklejohn.
PARIS, Oct. 20. -- Not a single discordant note has disturbed the enthusiasm and cordiality of the Italian sovereigns' reception by the Parisian populace.

Never before, probably, in the history of the city has the system of inspecting and supervising the milk supply been as thorough as it is to-day. Every discovery in the science of sanitation is being taken advantage of, the number of Inspectors is being increased as swiftly as possible, and the Board of Health is beginning to get the sale of milk under its control.

A week of disturbing news leaves the Stock market where it found it, so far as prices go, but with renewed demonstration that the Hquidation through which we have passed has fortified the situation against any ordinary stress. Neither railways not industrials end the week 1/2 of 1 per cent on the average below where they began it.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Miss Laura Wick, who had been invited to name the Manchuria, built for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company by the New York Shipbuilding Company at its yard here, stood for more than seventy minutes to-day with a bottle of champagne in one hand and a bunch of American Beauty roses in the other, waiting for the vessel to move down the ways.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To controvert the opinion of an antagonist sheltered behind the anonymous plural pronoun and the editorial (small type) columns of THE TIMES, whom I am compelled to consider as that unknown quantity X, is an uphill charge, but in this case right is might. "Eppur si muove."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The second part of the library of the late Howard T. Goodwin, which will be sold Nov. 12, 13, and 14, promises from the catalogue just issued to be of much more interest than the first part, sold last week. Rossetti's "Germ" is the most important rarity. There were only four numbers of "The Germ"published, although under another name the magazine continued for a short time.

TUXEDO PARK, Oct. 31. -- A large number of the well-known society people who came out to Tuxedo on Friday for the Autumn dance remained over to attend the concert given this afternoon by Mrs. Charles. B. Alexander at her cottage. The programme was rendered by Mrs. Cheatham Thompson, assisted by David Bispham, anfl proved a great success.
BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- Prof. Mommsen wrote an interesting and hitherto unpublished letter to me when the United States granted Cuba's independence. I had written to the Professor:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The communication of A. Singer in your issue of Oct. 26 suggests to me some remarks upon the cases of a large number of persons who come to the United States from other lands. Citizenship in the United States should not be founded upon sentiment alone.

Through the efforts of the police and the State Superintendent of Elections, wholesale colonization was discovered yesterday, it is asserted, in various Assembly Districts in Manhattan and the Bronx. Through the testimony of more than a thousand witnesses -- landlords, house agents, and janitors -- hundreds of illegal registrations were discovered, there being 350 in the Fifth Assembly District alone, where Capt. R.C. Dorsch of Superintendent Morgan's staff, examined 600 witnesses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To the close observer it seems a little singular that many New Yorkers -- who are generally so alert and well informed -- should be apparently so comparatively ignorant of the relative sizes and importance of some of the cities of their own Nation.

The immediate effect of the decision of the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union on Friday night to make one more effort for peace, according to International President Buchanan, was the postponing of the National strike yesterday morning.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 31. -- It may be a source of surprise to the business community to know that Cincinnati is a close third, if not actually second, in the volume of the wholesale clothing trade in the United States.

TIPPING has become so thoroughly engrafted upon American customs and manners that most even-tempered folk have ceased to fight against it and have even come to apologize for it on the ground that those who take tips have such low wages that they must have something besides in order to live.

A crowd that overflowed Durland's Riding Academy, in West Sixty-sixth Street, last night attended the closing Democratic rally of the last week of the campaign, and with an expenditure of considerable effort the demonstration was brought to the pitch of some of those which had preceded it in point of numbers and enthusiasm.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 31. -- Jerry H. Green of Perth Amboy, Secretary and Treasurer of various corporations organized by R.C. Penfield, the Ohio promoter including the Great Eastern Clay Company of New Jersey, committed suicide by in haling gas and shooting himself about 8:30 o'clock this morning.

Our able but somewhat headlong brethren of the Chicago press have been discovering that charges of plagiarism are dangerous weapons which, like the enchanted spear of the Irish hero, may turn upon the careless handler and wound him -- or like the executioner's sword that HEINE tells about, a gruesome thing which had to be burled when It had slain its one hundredth victim lest it should destroy the hangman.
The last month of Fall has by universal acceptance been called by our English brethren "the melancholy days." One of the greatest of English humorists has quaintly satirized the month:

Hardly a railroad in the country has increased the mileage operated directly under its own management as rapidly as has the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad within the past three years. The average mileage operated during the fiscal year ended June 30. 1900, was 1,401. The following year showed 1,687 miles.
In the first programme book of the Chicago Orchestra's season appears the following significant sentence at the close of a statement relative to the endowment fund:

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 31. -- Disregarding the claims of the Democratic leaders of Kentucky, who say they will re-elect Gov. J. C.W. Beckham by a majority of 17,000, and the claims of the Republican leaders, who say they will elect Col. Morris B. Belknap by 5,000, it seems safe to say that the Democratic ticket will be elected by about twice the majority claimed by the Republicans for their ticket.
The Kneisel Quartet will begin their New York season -- their twelfth -- with a concert in Mendelssohn Hall on Tuesday evening, at 8:15 o'clock. The programme will be as fellows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Col. James O'Hara of the Artillery Corps was to-day retired from active service on his own application, after forty years' service. His retirement promotes Lieut. Col. A.W. Vogdes, Major R.H. Patterson, Capt. Hamilton Rowan, and First Lieut. Conrad H. Lanza, each of the officers named advancing to the grade above that now held.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 31. -- The general officers of the Big Four state that they did everything possible to-day for relief of these suffering directly and indirectly on account at the Lafayette special wrecked at Indianapolis.
The Rev. Dr. H.P. Mendes, in a sermon delivered yesterday at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Seventieth Street and Central Park West, referred to the municipal campaign.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was considerably surprised to notice in THE TIMES of the 28th inst. an article with the startling caption, "Japan America's Enemy? Official Evidence that She Encouraged Filipino Rebels. Wanted Coaling Stations," I cannot see anything in the letters you print to warrant any such headlines, which undoubtedly will leave a false impression upon certain minds.

IT has been a matter for reproach among Henderson's friends that he is a man of such small family. The man who figured in the riddle of our youth, which told us that "brothers and sisters had he none," wasn't a circumstance to Henderson. Not only was he destitute of brothers and sisters, but likewise of uncles, aunts, and cousins, unless you counted in those of the third and fourth degree.

Charging that Charles F. Murphy had falsely told him that Grover Cleveland would write a letter favoring George B. McClellan if he were nominated for Mayor. Hugh McLaughlin yesterday afternoon declared that the Tammany leader was not a man whose word could be depended upon.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- The Democrats actually hope to carry Massachusetts next week, which is something they have done but five times in the last fifty years, and then only on what the football players call "flukes."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Princeton defeated Cornell this afternoon by the overwhelming score of 44 to 0. During the first fifteen minutes of play neither team showed great superiority, but from then to the end of the game Princeton scored with perfect ease. With the men in perfect condition and the total absence of fumbling, the eleven played with precision and accuracy.

THE last few cold days have brought furs out in abundance. Siberian squirrel is still one of the most fashionable furs, but it is trying to most people, as it requires a decided coloring to stand its dull cold tones. Moleskin is peculiarly adapted as a fur for Autumn wear, as it does not look so heavy or so warm as the longer-haired varieties.

M. LINN BRUCE, Chairman Republican County Committee -- Though I have no estimates to make public, I may say that I believe Mayor Low will be elected by as large a plurality as last time. In fact, to sum up all my ideas. I would say that if the citizens who have registered will go to the polls and vote, Mayor Low will be elected by a greater plurality than he had two years ago.

NEWSPAPER reporters have so many narrow shaves that they learn to love danger. What other men style "heroism" is to them a mere matter-of-fact monotony of drudgery. It is regarded as unprofessional to dodge an assignment, no matter what its difficulties or perils.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- In Pennsylvania there is practically no contest on the State ticket. The Republican candidates are: For Auditor General -- William P. Snyder of Chester; State Treasurer -- William L. Mathues of Delaware; Judges of the Superior Court -- Thomas A. Morrison of McKean and John J. Henderson of Crawford.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Poor old Tammany shown its unprogressive and back number qualities by its advertising exploitations. If it had any sense whatever, especially any advertising sense. It would know that, no matter how well a poor thing is advertised. It cannot be made to go except to induce a trial.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 31. -- Two persons were killed and nine injured, two perhaps fatally, and half a dozen farmhouses were demolished by a tornado that formed three miles north of Hydro, in Caddo County, last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- In view of conditions which are rapidly shaping in New York, a great deal that is profitable may be learned in Chicago. Matters have not there reached the acute stage which characterizes them here, but it is probable they will soon do stand that they will have to be dealt with there as here:

Commissioner McDougall Hawkes of the Dock Department yesterday afternoon asked District Attorney Jerome to investi gate the circumstances under which several communications, including a letter from Senator Platt to Deputy Commissioner Wallace of the Dock Board in reference to a pier transfer had found their way from the files of his department to the headquarters of Col. McClelian, where a fac-simile photograph of the Platt letter was given cut yesterday afternoon as a campaign document.

A contest has been instituted in Brooklyn over the will of John Loughran, who was President of the Manufacturers National Bank, that borough, by a granddaughter, Mrs. Mary E. Cummings. She alleges that Mr. Loughran's daughter. Mary E. Loughran, procured the execution of the will by fraud and undue influence.

THE colored gentleman with the pink rose in his buttonhole who presides at the weighing machine in the department store wrote the woman's weight down on a slip of paper and handed it to her with the air of a sage delivering himself of an oracle. She took it, read the secret written thereon, and put the paper carefully away in her pocketbook.

The payment of unwarranted rates of interest by one of the Baltimore trust companies that failed two weeks ago was assigned as the specific reason for the embarrassment of the company. The fact has no small local interest because of a similar policy pursued by some of the banking institutions in this city.

West Street is a great thoroughfare of commerce, as indigenous to New York as Cheapside is to London. It has its own peculiarities that are not to be seen anywhere else except in New York. The truckmen who do daily business in the street have individualities as pronounced as the London cabby.

Mr. J.A. Hobson as the guest of the New Reform Club, speaking after a recent visit to America, described it as the richest country the world had ever seen, and remarked that the tact that it was the largest free trade area in the world was one of the causes of its great prosperity. America struck a visitor by its abounding vitality and its fullness of ideas.

HAVANA, Oct. 24. -- Tuesday afternoon, the 20th, the little forts to the west of the city, evacuated by the Americans a few days previously, were formally turned over to the Cuban military authorities. Major Brown, who commands the United States troops in the Island, and Lieut. Meyers, the ordnance officer, were the American representatives in the transaction.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Among the November out-of-town weddings will be that of Miss Amy Harris Jessup. daughter of Mrs. George A. Jessup of Scranton, Penn., who is to marry Livingston Whitney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Whitney of Morristown, N.J., on the 10th.

The failure a fortnight ago of the International Bank and Trust Company of America, with headquarters here and a chain of nine banks in Mexico, has called to general attention the question of corporation laws in the several States making a specialty of such legislation, and in particular to the case of Delaware, proud mother of a goodly family of promotion offspring, of which the institution mentioned is the one most famous.

With the introduction of moleskin, which is the fad of the season this year, there have been brought out two other low-priced furs of similar appearance, the musk mole and petit gris mole, making three practically new furs, which is a rare occurrence in one Winter. The introduction of moleskin is an evolution.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 31. -- Michigan and Minnesota, after playing one 01 the most desperate football games seen in the West in years, left the prospective Western championship a matter for conjecture by finishing with a tie score, 6 to 6. Fully 30,000 spectators witnessed the struggle on Northrop Field.
BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- The money market is harder than it was even a week ago. The local banks were liberal shippers of currency during the week, but they were well prepared.

For the sixth season of the symphony concerts tot young people, opening at Carnegie Hall Saturday afternoon, Nov. 28. Conductor Frank Damrosch announces programmes designed to show the development of music from Josquin de Pres and Palestrina, masters of the choral contrapuntal style, to Richard Wagner, creator of the music drama.

"Wink White Idoorepo! Does that mean anything to you?" asked the comic opera comedian, Frank Daniels, as he printed the words on a piece of paper and held them up to view. His listeners confessed that the words did not convey any intelligible impression to their minds.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- At a meeting of window glass workers held in this city to-day a universal scale of wages for the blasts of 1903 and 1904 was agreed upon, and for the first time in many years rival organizations of the craft got together and agreed upon a line of action for the benefit of all concerned.

It is a matter of wonder to many New Yorkers what becomes of the Captains. officers, and crews of the Coney Island steamboats. Glen Island liners, and other public pleasure craft during the Winter. Over and over again during the Summer tens of thousands of excursionists depend upon the reliability and skill of these men to save them from accident and even death.

AS ONE of our young English visitors lately strolled up Fifth Avenue, above Fifty-ninth Street, talking lightly to a bright girl at his side, he came upon an incident that drew from him and his companion two flashes of well-justified cynicism.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The members of the Alliance Francaise, who seek so earnestly to promote the study of the French language by Americans, might take a hint from Switzerland. An inexpensive and very effective method of teaching the German language to the French-Swiss and the French language to the German-Swiss is that of exchanging children.

ROMANCE is most enjoyed when you stumble over it in some dull, commonplace corner. It is like the little flower that struggles through the city's cobblestones, and blooms on the selfish, cold street of trade -- as the old-fashioned novelist hath it.

Col. McClellan spoke last night at Carson Hall, Bedford Avenue and Fulton Street, Brooklyn, before the Kings County Workingmen's Association. He looked tired and worn out when he finished his speech, and he apparently welcomed the opportunity to hurry home after John J. Delany, his campaign manager, had made a short address.

There was very little activity in the curb market yesterday, no trades being reported in Northern Securities or Greene Consolidated Copper, two usually active stocks, while the very sharp break in Standard Oil and the advance in United Box Board preferred were the only changes of more than nominal fractional proportions.

Yesterday was a half holiday, preceding a holiday in London on Monday, and Election day here, Tuesday. As the market had been in a deadlock on Friday, there was every reason for expecting a continuance of its comatose condition unless something happened to arouse it, and nothing of that sort occurred.

The unusual number of new theatres which have been, or are to be, opened to the public this Fall has prompted a more or less general curiosity to know how much and along what lines advancement ever the older structures has been made. In descriptions of the new playhouses already circulated, very few of the ornamental features have been omitted.

The corps of lawyers appointed by the United States Government to assist the Commissioners of this country at the Alaska Boundary Tribunal, and which consisted of John M. Dickinson, John W. Foster, Robert Lansing, Hannis Taylor, and O.H. Tittmann, returned to this country yesterday on the American Line steamship Philadelphia.

The growing tendency to increase net earnings is more noticeable than ever in this week's reports for September, but the returns are not yet beginning to reflect that decrease in expenses which is expected within a few months. With the exception of the statements of the coal roads, the net gains reflect chiefly the saving of a fair proportion of the groad increases.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31. -- Ohio may take one of those political somersaults for which she is famous this Fall and by an unexpected Democratic majority elect Tom L. Johnson Governor and send a Democrat to the Senate to fill the place now held by Marcus A. Hanna. Ohio voters have a habit of doing strange things once in a while and this is not unlikely to be one of those years.

The elaborate poll of a part of the voters of the city by three newspapers shows varying results. One figures the election of Low, another of McClellan, and the other deduces results highly advantageous to Low in Brooklyn and figures so closely in Manhattan as to practically forecast the election of Low.

The Fusion and Tammany campaign managers in Brooklyn yesterday gave out their final estimates as to the vote to be cast on Tuesday, the former claiming the borough for Low by 40,000 and the latter giving McClellan a plurality of 2,300.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am very glad indeed that Mr. Depew has departed from his habit and replied to the correspondence in your Sunday's issue, because it is pleasant to receive his positive denial that there was any deception in the violation of what is a very well known rule in the Catholic Church in France as well as in this country.

A modern theatre, a theatre up to date, is the New Amsterdam on West Forty-second Street near Seventh Avenue. The facade is decorated with sculpture by George Gray Barnard, and the entrance hall, which, with elevators and box office, occupies the entire Breadth of the fifty-foot lot, has a frieze of twelve panels in relief by Hlnton Perry.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I was much amused at the amount in Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES of the speeches given at the meeting of the Male Teachers' Association at Shanley's on Saturday night.

Transactions in stocks on the Now York Stock Exchange for the month of October aggregated 12,671,051 shares, as against 10,713,440 shares in September, 14,464,876 in August, 14,780,116 in July, 15,535,904 in June, 12,464,587 in May, 12,42,583 in April, 15,020,632 in March, 10,927,021 in February, 16,006,389 in January, 15,719,742 in December, and 17,117,313 in November of last year.

An interesting addition to the mass of legal opinion already delivered on the rights of investing clients and the responsibility of brokers accepting funds for investment purposes, was made last week when the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn ruled for the plaintiff in the case of Katherine H. Newman against one John T. Lee, a member of the Consolidated Stock Exchange.
MRS. BENTLET married Bentley solely that she might help him. She never put it to him straight that such was her motive, but every day she told herself so.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very much pleased with your article in last Sunday's TIMES advocating the ceding to the Canadians of the two islands in the channel recently declared to belong to them, but for some reason, unknown to a layman, declaring that only two of the four islands in the group went with the channel.

Security markets have been accused of stubbornly refusing to recognize factors which usually make for strength and buoyancy. It Has been a persistent claim that effect would have been produced by trade movements, the comparative ease in money, favorable crop progress, and undeniably good railroad earnings, under normal conditions.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 31. -- Colorado is voting only for one member of the Supreme Bench, and none of the three party candidates has made a vigorous canvass or has addressed more than a half dozen campaign meetings since nomination. Little interest has been taken by the public at large in the election, and on account of the peculiar nature of the contest no one can forecast the result.

Two handsomely dressed women, one about forty-five years old and the other thirty, were knocked down and fatally injured by a runaway horse attached to a grocery wagon at One Hundred and Thirtieth Street and Eighth Avenue late yesterday afternoon. Both women died a few minutes after their arrival in the J. Hood Wright Memorial Hospital.

The Senate as the guardian of the rights of the States and the agent for the exercise of the sovereignty surrendered by the States to the Union at the foundation of She Government -- that is the central idea of the very interesting and informing aricle by Senator LODGE of Massachusetts in the current number of Scribner's Magazine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The "Church of the Presidents," as the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church is known, because of the large number of Presidents who have worshipped there, will observe its one hundredth anniversary during the week of Nov. 15 with Historical addresses by men conspieuous in National affairs, a historian of National reputation, and ministers who hold high positions in the organization of the Presbyterion Church of the United States.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31. -- Upon the election Judges almost as much as upon the people depends the political fate of Maryland in the State election next Tuesday. The citizens will do the voting or rather try to do it, and the men in the polling booths will decide, whether or not their votes are to be counted.
