Mme. Adelina Patti will give the opening concert of her American tour to-morrow evening in Carnegie Hall. Mme. Patti's company includes, besides herself, Miss Vera Margolies, pianist; Mr. Wilfred Vrigo, tenor; Miss Rosa Zamels, violinist; Miss Kathleen Howard, contralto; Mr. Claude A. Cunnlngham, baritone, and Mr. Anton Hegner, cellist.

The plan of bringing over several wellknown European conductors to conduct the concerts of the Philharmonic Society has revived interest in the eight concerts and public rehearsals to be given this season to such an extent that the renewals of subscriptions have been larger than usual. It is even stated that the number of new subscribers indicates that the present season will be the most successful in the history of the organization.

BERLIN, Oct. 22. -- It is with genuine pleasure that the successful appearance hero of a Boston violinist. Miss Marie Nichols, is noted. The Berlin critics are quite unanimous in praise of her rendering of the pieces which she played before a large audience at the Beethoven Hall on Monday evening.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 31. -- October days in Lakewood are drawing to a close after a beautiful month, in which many people have visited the resort and many old friends have returned to hotels and cottages. Social gatherings of prominence for the coming month are already being announced, and golf and other sport programmes are being arranged.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 31. -- To the non-par- tisan observer there has been a humorous side to the bitter campaign on the race question in Maryland now closing.

White there is an acknowledged scarcity of almost everything else in the food line this Winter, peanuts are plentiful. They are taking up more room than anything else just now, in many of the commission houses around Washington Market. The crop from Virginia is just coming in -- and Virginia peanuts are the best in the world.

HENRY FENNINGTON TOLER. who has gone into the scheme of trying to secure the New harlem waterfront for the heirs of the twenty-tree original freeholders, is a well-known elubman. For some years he lived at Short Hills, and he is a champion golf player and one of the stars of the baitusrol Club.

The purchase of adjoining property to protect the light and air of tall buildings has come to be regarded as a matter of course, but never was there a more aggravating chain of circumstances than that leading to the acquisition of 4 and 5 West Street and 6 and 8 Washington Street by the Battery Place Realty Company, owners of the Whitehall Building.

Under the general title of "Municipal Reform in Typical American Cities" THE TIMES has recently published a series of fifteen articles, contributed by as many different writers, each setting forth the methods and results of efforts recently made to improve the character of the city government with which the writer is especially conversant.

DR. T.A. DARLINGTON, rector of Christ Episcopal Church of Brooklyn, tells of a puzzling question propounded by one of the members of the infant class in his Sunday School. The teacher had been explaining the power of the Almighty, when one of the youngsters piped out:

The interesting announcement is made that Edward Elgar's new oratorio, "The Apostles," which was produced at the Birmingham Festival last month, will be heard in New York this season. The Oratorio Society will sing it at a special concert, not included in its regular series, for the City History Club, in February.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday and approved the budget for 1904. To carry on the City Government next year will cost $106,674,955,09, the largest amount ever appropriated for that purpose, and $9,555,923,99 more than the amount appropriated for the current year, which was $97,119,031,10.

Timothy McCarthy, the fellow-Walking Delegate of Samuel J. Parks in the Housesmiths' and Bridgemen's Union, who has been jointly indicted with him for extortion, and whose bail bond of $2,000 was forfeited by Judge Warren W. Foster of the Court of General Sessions a couple of days ago, surrendered himself yesterday and was released on $2,000 eash bail.

For the first time in four years, since the inter-city, golf team matches have been held twice a year between the Metropolitan and the Philadelphia Golf Associations, the Quaker players succeeded yesterday in defeating the New York golfers. The second half of the seventy-two hole match was finished on the links of the Morris County Golf Club, at Morristown, N.J., and the visitors won by a score of 27 holes to 21.

OF course it was nobody's business; nevertheless after they had gone all through the flat and admired the furniture and the curtains and draperies, the woman who holds to the belief that thoughts shut up are bad for the mind said to the hostess: "It Is very nice; but it must have cost a good deal."

The establishment this year of an automobile racing circuit for the first time in the history of the sport in this country has incidentally been the means of breaking more racing records by far than during any single previous year:
PARIS, Oct. 31. -- The season remains unprecedentedly rainy and dull.

ALBANY, Oct. 31. -- When an application was made before Supreme Court Justice Herrick to-day to prevent the Attorney General regulating the compensation of the receiver's attorneys under the receivership of the Anglo-American Savings and Loan Association, it was shown that $41,000 was paid in counsel fees to the attorneys for the receivers of the company in 1901 and 1902.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The President to-day issued his annual Thanksgiving proclamation, in the following terms:

It is of course quite proper that our good Sir THOMAS LIPTON, who had announced his intention to give a challenge cup for yacht racing across the Atlantic Ocean, should defer to the German Emperor's expressed desire to award a similar trophy, and should waive his own claims accordingly.

York and Adams will present a funny dialogue act at Proctor's Twenty-third Street house this week. As a special feature Emma Carus, once star of the New York Theatre stock company, appears in a singing act. Manning's Entertainers, a quintet of acrobats, will present "Hotel Uproar." The Allisons will be seen in "Minnie from Minnesota."

The contest between the present management of the American Malting Company and the stockholders, who desire a change of management, has become very heated. The Stockholders' Committee claims that a great majority of the stockholders are dissatisfied with the management, and that they are receiving their proxies.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25. -- The Government has offered to purchase the Vera Cruz and Pacific Railroad, which lost its financial backing through the recent suspension of the Maryland Trust Company of Baltimore.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 31. -- The Springlike weather of the past few days has caused serious talk of a revival of surf bathing. While it is not likely that anything will come of it, there is one brave and athletic young woman who has not missed a dally dip since the beginning of the bathing season early last Summer.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 31. -- The cadets of the Naval Academy played the poorest game this afternoon since the era of modern football and paid coaches began at the Academy, and were defeated by the team of Pennsylvania State College by a score of 17 to 0. In the first half Whitworth made a touch-down and a goal from the field and Forkum kicked the goal from the touch-down.

Charged with having taken tiger's teeth and claws to the value of $1,000 from a showcase belonging to the Order of Acorns, at 501 Broadway, Thomas W. Lawrence and William F. Greenwood were arraigned before Magistrate Barlow in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

Elections will be held in twelve States on Tuesday. Full State tickets are to be voted for in Massachusetts, Ohio, Maryland, Rhode Island, Iowa, Kentucky, and Mississippi. In Pennsylvania, Nebraska, and Colorado a Justice of the Supreme Court, Regents of the State University, or minor State officers are to be chosen.

The difference between fair capitalization and over-capitalization is never more graphically stated than when Chicago and Alton issues an annual report, as it did this week for the year ended June 30, 1903. The old Chicago and Alton Railroad Company was a splendid property. The new Chicago and Alton Railway Company represents the same property, excepting for a sixty-three mile addition.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- Two more mills at the Pencoyd Iron Works were closed today. Two other mills are still running, and there are orders on hand which will keep them busy for another week at least. In all probability, according to the present outlook, they will also be closed on Saturday next.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The world loves and admires a bold, courageous, and honest man. Such a man has Brooklyn in Martin W. Littleton, a candidate for the Borough Presidency.

Mme. Adelina Pattl, the Baroness Cederstrom, arrived here last night on the steamship Etruria of the Cunard Line to make her farewell tour of this country. The steamship passed into the upper bay after dark and the officials of the line notified Capt. Pritchard that he was to remain at Quarantine over night.

At one time or other in the last quarter of the calendar years 1899 to 1902, inclusive, there developed a flurry in the money market. It may be said to have been almost continuous during the panicky period which brought the first year of the series to a close, for no week passed without rates soaring to a high range, extreme figures running from 9 per cent, to 186 per cent.

Sometime this week a letter will be sent out to the 10,000 odd importers in the United States, calling upon them to join in the formation of a National Association of Importers, the object of which is to maintain their rights under the tariff law. Already more than 2,000 importers at all the leading ports of entry have been interviewed, and all have expressed themselves as warmly in favor of the plan.

Manufacturers and employers of labor all over the country are pleading with the labor unions to go slowly and conservatively while the present scary feeling as to business conditions lasts. To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you not call the attention of the President of the School Board to the fact that the grammar of the pupils in the public schools in the grammar departments is simply vile, and that it grates awfully upon the nerves of their parents at home? I have a little girl who has been attending the public schools of this city for many years.

There was an unusual display of the Aurora Borealis early yesterday morning, and coincident with it the lines of the telegraph and cable companies were seriously affected. Though the Northern Lights faded with the drising of the sun, the influences which produced them did not lessen their activity, and the disturbance of the electrical communication lasted until a late hour in the afternoon.

(Copyright, 1903.) LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The English habit opening conversation with remarks concerning the weather has had something more than conventional usage to stify it this week. Several days of heavy, almost incessant rain created general depression, which was only slightly initigated by the grim satisfaction with which the public received the announcement by a leading meteorologist that this year has broken the record as the wettest once scientific observations were instituted.

Among the minority who believe that the American manufacturers may wisely push the foreign business is L. Loebenstein of the Cedar Cliff Silk Company, which has offices at 722 Broadway and mills at Paterson, N.J.

The clubhouse of the Colonial Club, at Seventy-second Street and Broadway, will be sold at auction Wednesday, judgment of foreclosure having been obtained by the Equitable Life Assurance Society, which held $190,000 of the club's first mortgage, twenty-year, 5 per cent. bonds, interest upon which was defaulted.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 30. -- One Judge of the Supreme Court and two Regents of the State University are to be elected at the November election in Nebraska. Judge J. B. Barnes of Norfolk is the Republican candidate for the Supreme bench and the present Justice, J.C. Sullivan, is the Fusion candidate.

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- The first night at the Gymnase has come and gone and left a good deal of disappointment behind it. In times past this house, the "Theatre de Madame," was one of the most fashionable and popular in Paris and no premiere was more eagerly looked forward to or more sought after.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- A significant fapt is noted in the Treasury statement issued at the close of business to-day. It is that the receipts and expenditures of the Government for the first four months of the present fiscal year are practically the same, the surplus being so small as to be only a fraction of the aggregate.
OH, aren't they perfectly splendid! exclaimed Ethel, her eyes and cheeks glowing with enthusiasm as she watched the burly, mud-covered ruffians fussing over the football.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31. -- Harvard defeated the Carlisle Indians by a single point on Soldiers' Field this afternoon in a most exciting and stubbornly fought contest. On Monday the destruction of the present stands will begin, and hereafter the historic old gridiron will exist only in the memories, 0f those who have witnessed its gruelling and honorable struggles.

MRS. RONALDS of London has lost a tooth. This is not very startling information, but it has exercised many of her friends. Mrs. Ronalds in losing that tooth escaped being very badly hurt. She was in a small railroad accident and was knocked down in the railway carriage by the force of the bumping of the trains.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of "Observer's" observation in last Sunday's TIMES, regarding the difficulties under which the motormen on the surface cars in this city work, and the remedy therefor, I would like to add a few remarks. "Observer" noted the extreme, difficulty the motorman had in bringing his car to a stop in time to avoid sacrificing a human life.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31. --The campaign in Maryland came to a close to-night after a six weeks' period of speechmaking in every county and in the City of Baltimore, almost unprecedented in the history of the State for enthusiasm and partisan activity. The Democrats had their last grand rally last night, and to-night the Republicans had a final great gathering in Music Hall.

James Speyer, head of the banking house of Speyer Co., who returned Friday from an extended European tour, in a conversation with a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday outlined the trend of foreign sentiment toward the United States at present, and stated certain evidences that had come to his attention indicating a growth of sentiment in the direction of the tariff policy laid down by Mr. Chamberlain.

The closing mass meeting in Broklyn, held last night under the auspices of the Republicans at the Academy of Music, both in the size of the crowd and in the enthusiasm, was conceded by Timothy L. Woodruff, who presided, and others who have been managing the campaign over there to have been the most important yet held.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The University of Pennsylvania defeated Bucknell at football to-day by the score of 47 to 6, in halves of 35 and 20 minutes. Bucknell's touch-down was made a few minutes before the close of the game, after Pennsylvania had dismissed one-half of the regular team and filled their places with substitutes.

The bank statement did not fully reflect the large loss of cash to the interior reported on Friday. The decrease in reserve held was $8,694,800, or about $6,000,000 less than the estimate of the currency movement indicated. A part of the discrepancy is due to the average system, and there was probably a considerable gain in cash from local sources.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Henry A. Castle, Auditor for the Post Office Department, who has resigned, says in his annual report that the defects in accounting methods make infinitely greater postal abuses than those already disclosed not only possible but safe. The report says the aggregate transactions of the postal service during the fiscal year were $1,026,731,408, as follows: Revenues, $134,224,443; expenditures, $138,784,488; total amount of money orders issued, $388,865,584; money orders paid, $364,856,893.

Fierce Indians, Scouts, half-breeds, United States regulars, and the wives and sweethearts or all of them appear in the play to be given at the Manhattan Theatre this week, "John Ermine of the Yellowstone." James K. Hackett will have the lending role. Frederic Remington, the artist, whose Western types are widely known, has had a share in the building of this American drama.

The Association of Manufacturers and Distributes of Food Products held its quarterly meeting in New York a few days ago and devoted almost the entire day to planning a legislative campaign at Washington this Winter for the passage of a National pure food law. This association is composed of thirty-six of the largest manufacturers in the United States of Jams, jellies, preserves, canned fruits and vegetables, and table condiments, such as catsup.

Election week is never a great social success in New York. Many of the men who are at house parties or in the country will come in early on Tuesday to vote, and then pass the rest of the day out of town. There are many attractions. The fox hunt to-morrow at Meadow Brook will be followed by a breakfast, and in the evening there will be a ball.

The United Liberty League yesterday made public a statement of Fritz Lindinger to the effect that when Capt. Robert Tighe was a candidate for promotion from Sergeant, Michael Hines, the Republican leader of the Second Assembly District, had told him that the promotion could be had only on the payment of $2,000.

Not a little of the sensation caused in London by Mr. Barrie's new play, "Little Mary," is due to the fact that with regard to a certain organ of the anatomy English folk are far more squeamish than we, though English writers are never tired of girding at what they think American prudery in speech.

Impressions that the Cuban commission, recently in New York to negotiate the $35,000,000 loan needed for the payment of the veterans of the late war, failed of the immediate accomplishment of its purpose because of the existing state of the money market, or because New York capitalists approached were skeptical of the venture, are hardly borne out by the account of those who have been familiar with the commission's work.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 31. -- Brown surprised Williams by winning by the score of 22 to 0 at Andrews Field here this afternoon. The two teams seemed to be very evenly matched as to weight, but the Brown men played a fast, consistent team game, and made holes in the Williams line repeatedly, Line up:

Mr. Daniel Frohman wishes it to be Known that although the prices of admission to the concerts of the New York Symphony Orchestra are to be low, the programmes are not of a so-called "popular" character. They are intended to approach the highest type of symphonic programme.

The jury of acceptance for the coming exhibition of American paintings at the Carnegie Art Galleries in Pittsburg has selected 151 pictures, including works by John W. Alexander, "Autumn"; by William M. Chase, "When One Is Young" and "Still Life"; by Thomas, Eakins, "The Oboe Player" and "Ruth"; by Cecilia Beaux, "Portrait of Richard Watson Gilder" by Ben Foster.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 31. -- Dartmouth found Wesleyan an easy proposition on the football field to-day, winning by a score of 34 to 6. The home team scored four touchdowns in the first half and one in the second, having put in several substitutes. The Wesleyans were weak on the defense. Dartmouth showed her usual strength on the offensive, but fumbled badly at times and was penalized twice for off-side play.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The demand for money increased steadily through the week, owing to the payment of u2,000,000 fresh Treasury bills, the stocks settlement, and the end of the month, which is always accompanied by the calling in of funds by the banks for the purpose of the monthly balance sheets.

In the carpet trade the manufacturers, selling agents, and retailers are all wondering what will be the new scale of prices which is to be announced before the middle of November. Because of the high price of wool and its scarcity, both in this country and abroad, there is a widespread feeling that prices will be advanced.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Anti-Low, in a communication which you publish this, morning, take exception to the Fusion claim that taxes have been reduced. They gentleman walls that property which he owns was raised in valuation to the extent of 113 per cent, and that he was unable to secure a reduction.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Money was in keen demand in the market to-day. Discounts were firm, owing to the weakness of New York exchange and fears of early exports of gold to the United States. The Statist observes:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 31. -- While there is little question about the result of the state election on account of the overwhelming majority which the Republicans usually have, there is some question about how much the Democrats will reduce that majority and the gains they will make in the State Legislature.

ROME, Oct. 31. -- The Vatican is expecting in the near future a solution of the most important questions in which it is interested in the Philippines, namely, the purchase of the friars' land and the depacture of the friars.

The futile defense of SAMUEL PARKS in the prosecution of the indictment for extortion in connection with the Tiffany Studio Building appeared to rest wholly on the assumption that in demanding a cash payment of $600 as the condition of permitting the construction to proceed PARKS acted not for himself but for his union.

Last Wednesday afternoon a seeker after amusement wandered into the beautiful New Amsterdam Theatre, where "A Midsummer Night's Dream" is playing, bought a seat, and procured a programme. On opening the programme he discovered that the play is by William Shakespeare.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31. -- The Mayoralty contest in San Francisco is interesting because it is a three-cornered fight, but it is puzzling the prophets to predict the outcome, because of the uncertainty of the large labor vote.
AFTER a recent performance of "The Princess of Kensington" in Rochester James Powers met with a party of friends, and the talk naturally turned to the stage.

BERLIN, Oct. 31. -- President H.S. Pritchett of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has the distinction of being the first foreigner to ride on the motor cars used in the high-speed electrical experiments on the Marienfelde-Zossen military railroad.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31. -- Charles W. Moores, United States Commissioner, ruled to-day that the crime for which James Lynchehaun was sentenced in Ireland was a political crime, and that Lynchehaun should be released from custody. Mr. Moores decided that the assault on Mrs. McDonnell by Lynchehaun was incidental to a popular movement to overthrow the landlord system of Ireland.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 31. -- A striking example of the law's delay came up in the Superior Court yesterday before Judge John M. Thayer in the action brought by John Hurley and wife of Stamford against the contracting firm of Dwight Dailey. The complaint was first returned to court in April, 1894, and has been resting there ever since.
W.W. Cottingham, LL.D., has been Superintendent of the Public Schools in Easton, Penn., for half a century. A banquet was given in his honor isst Wednesday evening.
Predicting that he will receive 250,000 votes, insuring his election as next Mayor of New York. William S. Devery last evening closed his campaign with another automobile tour over the west side.

Only in its possible relations to the campaign of next year is the election to be held in New Jersey on Tuesday of political moment. In the state field, the contests are only for legislative honors. Six Senators and a new House of sixty Assemblymen are to be chosen. Haines of Burlington. Hand of Cape May, Gebhardt of Hunterdon, Strong of Middlesex, McKee of Passaic, and Martin at Sussex retire from the Senate.

ONE morning a dusty stranger appeared at the gorge where a lately -formed syndicate of prospectors had get up their hastily constructed works six months before and were doing a fine business in the wildest haste. The man carried a note for Charley Wayne, a Junior partner, and was followed, or rather led, by a doff the like of which no man at Black Bend had ever seen.

Team racing proved an interesting feature of the second Fall matinee of the Road Drivers' Association, held yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River Speedway. Three of the fastest teams on the road were matched, with the result that two of the best-contested heats ever stepped on the Speedway were witnessed.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 16. -- The birth of a second son to Prince Albert has brought forth widespread manifestations of loyalty to the royal family from all classes of society. It was an interesting sight last Sunday to see people representing every degree in the social ladder thronging to sign the register at Prince Albert's palace.

The first visit to New York of the Boston Symphony Orchestra will take place this week, and its two concerts will be given in Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening and Saturday afternoon. Mr. Gericke will, of course, conduct; there will be new faces in the orchestra, however, the new first violin, Mr. E. Fernandez-Arbos, the new first 'cellist, Mr. Krasselt, and the new first lin, Mr. Ferir, will be in places previously otherwise occupied.

Hurled from a racing motor car going at something approximating a mile a minute, Albert Champion was seriously injured yesterday at the second annual speed meeting of the Long Island Automobile Club at the Brighton Beach race track. The accident occurred in the first mile of the pursuit race and was attended with sensational features.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 31. -- Fifteen persons were killed and more than fifty injured, some fatally, this morning by a collision between a special passenger train on the Big Four Railroad and a freight engine with a cut of coal cars.

W.G. McGee, who is at the head of the Department of Anthropology of the St. Louis Exposition, has been in New York during the week past for a meeting of the American Ethnological Society, and while here discussed in outline the plans which he and his assistants are working out for the arrangement and co-ordination of the vast exhibits that come under his direction.
BOSTON, Nov. 1. -- Trinity Church instituted its new method of Sunday school work to-day. In a general sense it is an adaptation of secular school methods to those of the Sunday school.
One thing unquestionably the administration of Mayor Low has done for the schools of the city -- it has driven corrupt politics from the management of them.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 1. -- A fierce battle was fought yesterday afternoon on Little Lightning Creek, near its junction with the Cheyenne River, forty-five miles north of Lusk, in Eastern Wyoming, between Sheriff Miller of Weston County and posse of six men and a band of Crow Indians under Carries Elk.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- A preliminary statement with regard to the investigation of public land frauds in the Pacific Coast States was made at the Interior Department to-day, with Secretary Hitchcock's approval. The annual report of Land Commissioner Richards, also made public to-day, contains some facts about these land frauds.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- The negro element's celebration of Hallowe'en was responsible for the killing of the Chief of Police of Morgan Park, a suburb of Chicago, and a threatened race war to-day. It was only after a desperate struggle between the police and an armed mob of enraged whites that a lynching was prevented.

We are very far from saying that Mr. Justice BREWER of the United States Supreme Court is the only jurist, in his position or a like one, who holds, practically, that the object of the law is rather to administer justice than to maintain lawyers. It does, however, seem that his efforts in that direction are such as to make him conspicuous among such jurists.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say that M. de Plehve, the Minister of the Interior, has issued a confidential document to the Minister of Public Instruction pointing out the existence of widespread dissatisfaction faction in the schools of the empire.

PEKING, Nov. 1. -- The Chinese Government is greatly disturbed at the reoccupation of Mukden, the capital of Manchuria, by Russian troops. The Foreign Office is appealing to friendly foreign legations for help and advice, admitting its own helplessness in the matter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The report of Gen. Allen, chief of the constabulary in the Philippines, contains matter of interest to anti-imperialists. Gen. Allen says that the United States must not reduce the number of troops in the islands for a number of reasons.

Twenty-five dead bodies were taken out of the tenement house at 426 Eleventh Avenue, between Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Streets, yesterday all of whom were suffocated in the fire which began shortly before 2 o'clock in the morning. One woman, who jumped from a third-story window, is dying in the house at 536 West Thirty-fifth Street.

to the Editor of The New York Times: Some misleading statements have appeared in the press concerning the attitude of the German-American Reform Union of the Twenty-first Assembly District (whose President I am) in the matter of the contest for Judge of the Municipal Court for the Twelfth District, embracing the Twenty-first and part of the Nineteenth Assembly Districts.

A week of unusually disturbing news had of unexpectedly good outcome in the price movement. It is only necessary to mention the trust company disturbance in St. Louis, and the bank statement wiping out half the reserve, after the largest loss of cash recorded for any week.

The Rev. Robert L. Paddock, present rector of the Church of the Holy Apostles and formerly of the Pro-Cathedral in East Houston Street, where he was a leading figure in the anti-vice crusade of two years ago, while introducing Jacob A. Rlis to his congregation last night, created a sensation by announcing that word of efforts on the part of the gambling syndicate to resume had come to him.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- The assurances of support received to date for the reorganization of Consolidated Lake Superior Company are accepted by the officials of the company as a sure sign of the formation of the new forty-million-dollar company.

The campaign now closed has been remarkable in the political history of the city. For the first time in many years a reform administration has been presented for a second term with the united support of the opponents of Tammany. United action secured the election of Mayor STRONG in 1894, but division in 1897 was followed by defeat.

Jealousy over a woman and a feud of long standing between the two men fighting for her favor are believed by the police of Coney Island to have been the causes of a fire that swept bare fourteen square blocks of the island between 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon and 8 o'clock last night. One person, a nine-year-old girl, is believed to have perished.

The first annual report of the Rock Island Company, being for the year ended June 30, covering the operations of the lines forming the Rock Island system not including the St Louis and San Francisco system, which, though controlled by the Rock Island Company. is operated independently, has just been made public.
NORTH SYDNEY, N.S., Nov. 1. -- Two lives have been lost by an extraordinary accident at Dominion No. 2, the largest of the Dominion Coal Company's collieries.

NEW ROCHELLE, Nov. 1. -- The only Senatorial election to be held in the State is in the Twenty-second District, where the contest to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Charles P. McClelland to accept a Federal appointment has been conducted vigorously on both sides.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 1. -- A serious condition confronts this city as a result of a dead-lock between Mayor Charles Henry Leeds and the Common Council in respect to appointments of members of the Board of Appropriation and Apportionment.
CRESTLINE, Ohio, Nov. 1. -- Crestline and vicinity was thrown into a panic to-night by a terrible explosion at 8 o'clock. Many buildings were shaken and in some instances the walls fell.

ROME, Nov. 1. -- There was a fire at 8:30 o'clock this evening in that portion of the Vatican containing the Hall of Inscriptions, where the Pope gives his audience and which is adjacent to the famous Pinacoteca, or Gallery of Pictures. The alarm caused much confusion and excitement in the Vatican, and the firemen of Rome were called to help put out the flames.

Not since that Sunday afternoon almost exactly six years ago, when an immense gathering crowded the Grand Central Palace to attend the memorial service for Henry George, has there been held in this city such an impressive service as that which took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall in memory of Consul Emma Booth-Tucker of the Salvation Army.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The Press Association to-day learns that a plot' for the removal of four Armenian members of the Huntchakist revolutionary society was arranged at a meeting held in New York seven months ago of the Alfarist, or physical force, faction of the society, and was revealed to the Huntchakist section through an error in sending a report of the meeting to a branch at Milford which had secede to the Huntchakists.

We hope that the attitude of listlessness end entire inactivity toward the canal improvement on the part of the Republican and Democratic organizations in the State is due not to hostility no real indiffernce, but to the fact that no State campaign has been made this year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Senator Mitchell of Oregon is not one of those who think Congress this Winter should shun considerable legislation.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 1. -- William Bailey of New Richmond, Ind., substitute player on the Purdue University football team, died this afternoon from internal injuries received in the Big Four wreck yesterday. This is the sixteenth death.
This is the sum by which the borrowing capacity of the City of New York has been advanced under the administration of Mayor Low.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- Prof. Theodor Mommsen, the historian, died at Charlottenburg at 8:45 o'clock this morning. He passed away without regaining consciousness. The change from, life to death was observed only by his physician, who watched all night long with the family.

Germany and Italy have special reason to mourn the death of THEODOR MOMMSEN, the one because he has been an honor to German research for half a century, and through his privileged position as Secretary of the Berlin University was able to protest against the efforts to suppress free thought and free speech in Prussia; the other because of his great services to the history of Italy from pre-Roman times down to the Middle Ages.

To the Editor if The New York Times: Mr. Grout, while in accord with the Fusion Party, was very outspoken regarding the Van Wyck Dock Board. Since his nomination by Tammany Hall he has not once referred to it. Impression No. 1: That If reelected as Controller Mr. Grout will not take any steps nor will he assist in the punishment of Messrs. Murphy Co.

Upon Charles M. Schwab a large part of the blame for wrecking the United States Shipbuilding Company is placed by ex-Senator James Smith, whose report as receiver of the trust will be filed this morning in the United States District Court, presided over by Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick in Newark, N.J.

While Charles F. Murphy, leader of Tammany Hall, declined last night to make public the estimates of the Tammany district leaders for the vote in their respective districts, he stuck by his statement of the day before that McClellan would carry Manhattan and the Bronx by 86,000 plurality and would carry every borough of the greater city.
An exceptionally interesting account of Maude Adams's early stage appearances is contributed by John Maguire, the well-known Western manager, to The Salt Lake Herald.

The Central Federated Union had a narrow escape yesterday from being drawn into an indorsement of John Turner, the Anarchist who was arrested recently, after making a speech at the Murray Hill Lyceum, under the new law for deporting Anarchists, passed after President McKinley's assassination.

To the Editor at The New York Times: You do well to Interest your readers In the affairs of New Rochelle. The nearer the public mind gets to the primary working of our political system the clearer will be the vision of its defects and the nearer the remedy.

BILBAO, Nov. 1. -- Never in the history of Bilbao has there been a strike of such momentous consequences to the ironworkers of Spain as that which terminates to-day. The miners will no longer be compelled to live cooped up in the barracks provided by the mining companies, and they will no longer be forced to purchase from the company stores food which has often been declared unfit to eat.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 1. -- Mayo Lake, adjacent to Stewart River, in British Yukon, has its bottom lined with gold. How to secure its golden riches is the problem now confronting the engineers of Klondike and adjacent districts.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit an outsider to explain why, in his opinion, the Greater New York Fusion ticket is doomed to be defeated at the polls next Tuesday?

"Buffalo Bill," Major John M. Burke, and fifty of the Indians of the Wild West Show returned to this country Saturday night on the Cunard liner Etruria. The show has been on tour in England since last Spring, and, with the exception of the returning members, is in Winter quarters, where it will remain until next Spring.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- A fierce fire destroyed the large plant of the Avil Printing Company at 39, 41, 43, and 45 Market Street, to-night, and six adjoining dwellings, and damaged a dozen others, entailing a total loss of $450,000. Several persons were hurt at the fire, and two others were injured by being knocked down by horses in a stampede from a nearby horse bazaar.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 1. -- Nine world's records were broken and many season's records made during the recent eight days' meeting of the Memphis Trotting Association. The track was in its best condition. The new world's records made were:

HAVANA, Nov. 2. -- The regular session of Congress opened this afternoon. The message of President Palma contained 14,000 words, and its recommendations are chiefly of a general character. The muchdiscussed loan taxes are not gone into at length, and no amendment to the loan law is suggested.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- President Roosevelt received the indorsement of Alexander J. Dowie, the Zion prophet, today in an interview granted at the Executive offices to the members of Dowie's business cabinet, who are on their way from New York to Zion City.

At the opening, at 33 East Broadway yesterday afternoon, of the second of the branch library buildings provided for by the five-milllon-dollar gift of Andrew Carnegie, Arthur E. Bostwick, Chairman of the Circulating Department of the New York Public Library, drew attention to the fact that there was less fiction and twice as many scientific books drawn in the Chatham Street section than in any other circulating library in New York City.
BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- Emperor William has sent to Prof. Mommsen's widow the following dispatch:

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Nov. 2. -- Worked into a frenzy by an altercation with one of his brothers, Benjamin Franklin Weissinger, living on a farm several miles from this city, this afternoon shot and killed his two brothers, attempted to kill his sister and a sister-in-law, and held a large posse of police at bay for nine hours before he was captured.

There were some substantial gains made in some parts of the list in the trading in curb securities yesterday, but the approaching holiday restrained any activity in trading, and the gains were made on very small totals. There was some activity in bonds, New Amsterdam Gas 5s advancing 3/4 and American Maltings 6s selling at 98.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Sir Chentung- Liang-Cheng, the Chinese Minister here, acting under instructions from his Government at Peking, has been particularly active" recently in the effort to interest the United States Government on China's behalf in her Manchurian troubles. He was at the State Department to-day in pursu- ance of that object.

The French Line steamship Gallia, which started on Sunday for Italy, but returned several hours later, was yesterday lightered of her cargo and her passengers were discharged, preparatory, to sending her to dry dock.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Nov. 2. -- Notices have been posted by the Dunbar Furnace Company announcing that, beginning Nov. 1, a cut of 5 per cent, in the wages of their 500 employes became effective. More than 500 men are thrown out of employment by the shutdown for an indefinite period of the Trotter Coke Works, one of the largest of the Frick Company plants in the region.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 2. -- The telephone rang at the police station shortly after noon to-day, and Sergt. Daniels, who answered the call, heard a pleading voice say:

Capt. Hussey of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station, with Detectives Boyle and Meehan, raided an alleged poolroom on the parlor floor of the three-story brownstone house 215 West Thirty-eighth Street yesterday, taking thirteen prisoners, three of whom were charged with keeping and maintaining a poolroom, and the others with disorderly conduct.

Every woman who has large and heavy house plants should have one of the fibre saucers or trays on wheels. These hold the pot sufficiently high above the carpet to keep the moisture from injuring it, and it will require no other stand. These are advantages, but the greatest is in the ease with which even the largest plants are moved.

Beyond any other that any of us has ever known, this municipal campaign has been fought upon the clear-cut issue of right against wrong, of honesty against "graft." of decency against filth. In no other has the moral sentiment of the community been so freely and fully voiced from the pulpit.

-- Several kind and patient correspondents have presented evidence which we have no right or desire to question in support of the contention that French mothers use "sage" in all the cases of emotional emergency when English-speaking mothers would use "good," and, as promises must be kept and we promised to confess defeat if such evidence were presented, we hereby confess defeat -- as to usage.

In the best race of his career, and a performance far out of the ordinary even in this season of successes for two-year-olds in races for horses of all ages. Hello won the last event of the Aqueduct programme yesterday in such style as to set the very enthusiastic among the spectators to predicting triumphs for the victor over the first rank of next season's three-year-olds.

Magistrate James G. Tighe, in the Butler Street Court. Brooklyn, yesterday decided against Lawyer Benjamin Steinhardt of Manhattan in the criminal proceedings brought by him with a view to stopping betting at the race tracks. The gist of the decision is that betting at the tracks is not criminal so long as no voucher passes between the bettor and the bookmaker to show that a wager has been made.

In line with rumors that Rock Island and Union Pacific interests are shortly to obtain definite representation in the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Directorate, a story was given general publication in Wall Street yesterday to the effect that two of the four Atchison Directors whose terms expire at the time of the coming meeting were to retire from the board to admit of the advent of representatives of the two roads first named.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of to-day, and likewise in other issues, have appeared letters from voters announcing their intention of repudiating this year the Illusion ticket, although in the last election they voted for Mr. Low. These public-spirited men state as their "cogent reason" for this measure a trifling raise in taxes or in house rent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Oct. 31 the total debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $920,402,501, which is an increase for the month of $2,649,956. The debt is recapitulated as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- The loss of the Avil Printing Company, the establishment of which was destroyed by fire last night, will closely approach $500,000. Investigation to-day showed that the establishment had been completely gutted.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Owing to there being no improvement in conditions, tie independent manufacturers of pig iron in Eastern Pennsylvania and New Jersey to-day decided to continue through the present month the restriction of output agreed upon at the last conference.

A retiring board is appointed to meet at San Antonio, Texas. Detail: Brig. Gen. Frederick D. Grant. Majors Lorenzo W. Cooke, Thomas K. Adams, and Charles F. Mason, Surgeon; Capt. Thomas S. Bratton. Assistant Surgeon; Capt. Charles D. Roberts, Seventh Infantry, Recorder.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Bird S. Maguire, the Oklahoma Delegate, will find an entirely now Statehood situation confronting him when he begins his campaign this Fall in behalf of Oklahoma.

This campaign for manliness and decency in New York would not have been complete without the assistance of JAMES C. CARTER. Mr. CARTER is no longer a resident of the city of which for half a century he has been one of the ornaments. But, like Mr. JEROME, he "could not stay away" when such an issue was to be decided.

After ten years Mme, Adelina Patti has returned to America and made her reappearance last evening in the city where just forty-four years ago she won her first triumphs as a youthful artist, and started upon a career that has scarcely had an equal in musical annals.

Ogden Clarkson have sold for the estate of William T. Garner to George H. Robinson 6 East Seventeenth Street, adjoining the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue, a four-story stone-front building, on lot 25 by 92.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- William H. Moody, Secretary of the Navy, delivered an address this evening before the Harvard Political Club on "The Administration of a Navy." The club is a non-partisan organization for the study of questions of government and politics.

Gold imports, the money market, and the shipbuilding report almost monopolized attention yesterday, to the comparative neglect of the stock market. Its volume was small and its tone strong. Pennsylvania was the most active property, improving naturally upon the declaration of the regular dividend.
LONDON, Nov. 2. -- There was an immense gathering of Salvationists at Congress Hall, Clapton, to-nieht, at a memorial service for Mrs. Booth-Tucker.

Acting Battalion Chief Daniel C. Conway nearly lost his life, and his driver, Fireman Luke Henry, was severly cut on both hands by falling into the cellar of the fivestory brick building at 42 Vesey Street, where a fire was raging last night. Chief Conway was severely burned about the face, head, neck, and hands, and was driven to the Hudson Street Hospital in his own carriage, where his injuries were dressed.

The appalling calamity by which twenty-five persons were suffocated by smoke in the tenement house slightly injured by fire on Sunday morning should emphasize without argument the need of such an enforcement of the tenement house law as the Low administration has given us under the intelligent direction of Commissioner DE FOREST.

Throughout the election betting yesterday and last night, during the progress of which something more than $200,000 was wagered, McClellan ruled the favorite at odds fluctuating from 10 to 9 to 10 to 7, closing with the McClellan bettors offering 10 to 8 1/2 and the Low people holding out for 10 to 7. The McClellan contingent was augmented by several commissions to hedge on bets formerly made on Low's election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Postmaster General Payne said to-day that for three days inquiry has been proceeding on the charge that Third Assistant Postmaster General Madden has sold freak stamps and made several thousand dollars in that man- ner.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- Republicans and leaders of the independents charge to-night that the Democrats are prepared to resort to all sorts of tricks and dishonest practices in the polling places to-morrow to win.

Rest was the medicine prescribed for Columbia's football players yesterday, and needed it was after their hard game with Yale on Saturday. Richard S. Smith, the Morningside Captain, tore the cartilage in his knee and probably will not be able to play for some time. Those who saw the Yale game will not wonder that Smith was injured; he was the life of the defense and was at the bottom of every scrimmage.

An owl which flew in by a window and perched on the foot of her bed frightened a woman to death in Gouverneur Hospital last night. The woman was Mrs. Elizabeth Forschleischer, forty-one years old, of 349 Madison Street.
VIENNA, Nov. 2. -- Arrangements for the formation of an Austro-Hungarian petroleum cartel have been practically completed.

The National City Bank engaged $1,000,000 gold yesterday in London for import to this city, and the long-delayed movement of the precious metal to this city was thus inaugurated. The decline of last week in sterling exchange paved the way for yesterday's engagement, and it was even said that the transaction was arranged on the basis of Saturday's figures rather than on those resulting from the sharp drop that occurred in sterling exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The October Treasury statement was issued to-day, it shows that the available cash balance has decreased since Oct. 1 $10,779,781, the total of that balance standing at $228,637,402, which is exclusive of the reserve fund held to maintain the greenbacks.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- A contest that has been begun over the will of J. Sperry Willing, formerly an official of the Fidelity Trust Company, and a cousin of Edward Willing, father of Mrs. John Jacob Astor, promises to be an interesting litigation. A hearing has been set down for Wednesday morning before the Register of Wills.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- There was good and lively interest to-day certreing principally about Box Board. The knowledge that Diamond Match interests are to work for the rehabilitation of Box Board brought many converts to the stock, especially the preferred. S.B. Chapin Co., who have been in close touch with the situation from the start, did much of the buying.

Claiming a triumphant election as Mayor of New York, William S. Devery closed his campaign yesterday at his headquarters, at Eighth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street. It was late in the afternoon before he left his house close by and went to the clubrooms, where there was a large crowd of retainers waiting to see him on strictly private business.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Nov. 2. -- Pluralities ranging from 1,000 to 1,500 are claimed for both the Republican and Democratic tickets in to-morrow's municipal election. On account of the bitterness which has marked the campaign an exceptionally heavy vote is looked for.

A flood of light is let in upon "the intricacy of higher finance" in the report of ex-Senator JAMES SMITH, receiver of the United States Shipbuilding Company. Receiver SMITH calls the organization of the company "an artistic swindle." In support of the charges that it was a swindle he adduces facts which hardly seem to admit of any other explanation than dishonest intent.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 2. -- Reports have come from Lusk to-night that another battle has been fought with the Indians who invaded the State to hunt game and kill cattle. It is said that a posse met a band of about seventy-five near the Horseshoe Ranch and that in a fight nine of the Indians were killed and ten captured, the others making off in the direction of the Rosebud Agency.

Scores of passengers were gravely imperiled and elevated railroad traffic in the Bronx was tied up for a considerable period at 8:10 o'clock yesterday morning, when a southbound Third Avenue, train was run into by a locomotive of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's Harlem River Branch, going in the same direction as they were about to roll out upon the Harlem River Bridge at First Avenue over the same switch.

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- The firmer tone shown by the money market the latter part of last week still continues. The demand is at a minimum. Call loans, 3@4 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 4 3/4@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, par@5 cents discount; Clearings, $20,374,148; balances, $1,998,733.

Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S plan is beginning to bring responses from the colonies. New Zealand and the South African colonies have acted on it, and the Government of Australia have taken the matter up and indicated what they are prepared to do, which is what New Zealand has done -- not reduce any tax in favor of England, but put an extra tax on the imports from other sources.

No more valuable service to the cause of permanent honest and efficient government in this city can be made to-day than a vote under the Citizens' Union emblem, which is the Statue of Liberty. Every vote so cast will recognize the useful and intelligent work done by this admirable organization, and strengthen it for the promotion of its essential purpose, the defense of the interests of New York first and party considerations afterward.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Though tardy, it may even yet be not quite too late to draw the attention of voters through your columns to one fortunate fact in regard to the Fusion ticket, namely, the collective, high quality of the nominees, Low, Hinrichs, Sulzberger, McGuire, and Trautmann.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The Peking correspondent of The Times says the action of Russia in throwing off the mask and resuming authority at Mukden, whither once again troops have been moved from the adjacent railway to guard the city gates and occupy the palace and official yamens, causes the Chinese Government lively alarm.

By a majority vote of nearly 250,000 in 53 of the 61 counties of the State the $101,000,000 barge canal improvement referendum was adopted by the electors yesterday. The counties up the State rolled up a majority against the proposition, but New York County gave a majority in favor of 203,749; Brooklyn, 128,580; Queens, 12,500, and Richmond, 6,058, which greatly overbalanced the up-State opposition.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 -- Interest in the result of the Ohio election was centred in Cuyahoga County, the home of Senator Hanna, Mayor Johnson, Myron T. Herrick, Republican candidate for Governor, and John H. Clarke, Democratic candidate for the Senate. The result is a Republican landslide, the county having reversed its position of a year ago and elected the counts ticket by a plurality of approximately 4,500.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Being an old subscriber, I have followed the trend of your valued paper for many years, and have admired the determination with which you have exposed existing evils until sufficient public spirit had been roused toward their extermination. May I ask why the subject of the recent hazing at Annapolis has suddenly been hushed up?

"Whom do you suppose they have elected?" asked Susan B. Anthony, the veteran woman suffragist, interrupting her own speech as the sound of bombs penetrated the crowded parlor at the Hotel Majestic where the New York Equal Suffrage League ws holding an Election Day meeting yesterday afternoon.

The annual convention of the Tennessee River Improvement Association here was by all odds the most satisfactory and most important of any meeting of that body yet held. The greatest interest possible was shown by the people, and there was a larger attendance of leading public and professional men than has even been known.

So rapidly did the returns come in last night at the McClellan headquarters, in the Bartholdi Hotel, and at Tammany Hall, and so plainly did they show the election of Col. McClellan from the very beginning, that it was considerably later in the evening before the Tammany braves could start full tilt on their rejoicing.
BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- Massachusetts re-elected Gov. John L. Bates and the entire Republican State ticket by 199,393 to 163,544 for Col. William A. Gaston, the Democratic candidate.

Expectations raised by the preliminary totals for September led to conclusions different from those based on the August record. They have in large measure been realized by the complete returns now published. Copper is shown, not with any increase this time, but with a sharp decrease of $331,932.
Elections in States other than New York resulted as follows:

BRIDGEPORT, Nov. 3 -- Mayor Dennis Mulvihlll, known as the " Stoker Mayor," was carried in a triumphal procession to-night during the celebration of his re-election to-day. With him practically the entire Democratic ticket was carried into office.

The managers of the Citizens' Union campaign in Brooklyn were enraged last night at the turn affairs had taken, and declared that the result could not have been brought about except through Republican treachery. Abner S. Haight, Vice Chairman of the City Committee of the Citizens' Union, was especially vigorous in his denunciations.

Meadow Brook and Morristown were the two points of pilgrimage for the very fashionable set yesterday. The Meadow Brook steeplechase brought together the entire Long Island colony. After the races there were a number of dinners at the club and adjacent places, and then many members assembled at the club to get the election returns.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the questions asked by the Civil Service Commission of the candidates for the position of assistant engineer on the rapid transit subway was this: "After a blasting, how would you detect the stability of the rock in the roof of the tunnel?"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- John B. Steinhard, who has been officially identified with Cuba during and since the occupation of the Island by the United States, has returned from Havana. He reports that there is a feeling of confidence among the people that the reciprocity treaty will be affirmed by the United States Congress.

Team racing was the special attraction on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning, when 5,000 spectators gathered on the upper stretch to see Swift, 2:07, and King Chimes step in company with the champion trotting team composed of Mattie Lynn Holt and Algonita. Three fast heats were trotted, Swift and King Chimes losing the first by a length, but winning the second and final easily.

Col. George B. McClellan, Democrat, was elected Mayor of the City of New York by a plurality of more than 61,000 over Seth-Low, his Fusion opponent, and all the Democratic city ticket was elected with him.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 3 -- Bitter feeling over the election in Kentucky to-day led to fights in which several persons were killed and many were wounded.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The news of the apparently successful revolution on the Isthmus was not a surprise to Dr. Herran, the Colombian Charge, when it was told to him just before midnight. He said he had expected it and had fully warned his Government, adding:

The body of Consul Emma Booth-Tucker of the Salvation Army, which lay in State at the headquarters of the army at 120 West Fourteenth Street all day on Monday, was yesterday taken to Woodlawn and placed in the receiving vault. About one thousand members of the organization travelled to the cemetery by special train, and took part in the funeral services, which were attended by about three thousand other sympathizers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The following cablegram was received at the State Department at 10 o'clock to-night from the United States Consul at Panama:

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 3 -- Returns received in Louisville up to 10 o'clock to-night indicate the election of Gov. J.C.W. Beckham, the Dempcratic nominee, and the entire Democratic State ticket by from 15,000 to 20,000 votes.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Nov. 3 -- The trial of State Senator Frank Farris on the charge of bribery began this afternoon. It required but a short time to select the jury. Five minutes before 2 P.M. John A. Lee, ex-Lieeutenant Governor and star witness for the State, accompanied by his brother, Robert E. Lee, entered the courtroom.
The Mayor's power of removal under the present charter (1901) is very sweeping. It is thus defined in Section 95:

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Money was in better supply in the market to-day, the banks lending freely. Discounts were very firm on the purchase of $1,500,000 in gold in the open market yesterday for New York, together with increased fear of withdrawals from the Bank of England for the United States and the expectation that the balance of the arrivals of gold from the Cape and Australia will be taken to America.

State Superintendent of Elections George Wilson Morgan, after all the returns were in last night, said that this had been one of the quietest election days on record in this city. In all, 282 arrests for violations of the election law had been reported to him by his deputies during the day. Of the prisoners in these cases, only about 10 per cent. were held when arraigned in court.

Some consoling hope of good administration during the next two years might remain to us if there were a particle of ground for the belief that GEORGE B. McCLELLAN, inspired by his great opportunity, might harden his heart and stiffen his backbone against the vulgar, corrupt, criminal mob that put him in nomination and with Democratic assistance has borne him to the Mayor's chair.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 -- Although complete figures will not be received until to-morrow, it is evident late to-night that the Republicans have made a sweep of the State. Myron T. Herrick, the Republican candidate, has been elected Governor over Tom L. Johnson by a majority in the neighborhood of 100,000.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 3 -- The courtmartial which convened at the Naval Academy yesterday for the purpose of trying the three midshipmen who are charged with hazing is getting through with its work rapidly.

Col. AUSTEN of Brooklyn was so much irritated at a public meeting in Brooklyn the other evening by the misconduct of some of the audience who remained seated, or covered, or both, during the performance of "The Star-Spangled Banner," that he administered to them a well-deserved rebuke.

The trap shooters of the Crescent Athletic Club "took advantage of the pleasant weather and turned out in stronger numbers at the Bay Ridge grounds than at any other time this season. The Shooting Committee, of which C.J. McDermott is Chairman, had arranged an attractive programme, including two special features -- a contest for the Election Day Cup and one for the Stake Trophy, presented by T.W. Stake.

The joy in the Tenderloin was without bounds last night. The first returns which Predicted a victory for Tammany were taken as the signal which the proprietors in the "White Light" District have been waiting for for two years, and the resorts which have been running very quietly for a long time threw open their doors and made preparations to celebrate the Victory in their own way.

Steeplechasing of the most exciting sort, with falls at the jumps and into the Liverpool, held the interest of a great crowd at the annual meeting of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club, at Hempstead, L.I., yesterday, and the greater portion stayed until the final race was run in the gathering twilight.

New Jersey Republicans came within an ace of repeating their old-time score in yesterday's struggle for the contest of the Legislature. They have had sweeping majorities in both branches for four or five years past. As the result of yesterday's election, they have sweeping inajorities again, that in one house is ordy just not so sweeping.
Ranald H. Macdonald has sold for Mrs. Elizabeth A. Wilcox 2,752 Eighth Avenue, a five-story tenement, with stores, on lot 23 by 100.

In the United States Circuit Court of Appeals the case of the Government, as appellant, against the Tartar Chemical Company was argued yesterday. Howard T. Walden appeared as attorney for the company and Assistant District Attorney Lloyd for the Government. The question at Issue is whether Algeria is an integral part of France or merely a colony, and therefore not entitled to the benefits of the reciprocity agreement between the United States and France.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 3 -- The first meet of the Morris County Hunt to-day was a success and the scene around the Morris County Golf Club all the afternoon was one of much interest. It is estimated that between 500 and 600 women, in handsome gowns, were present, while men in red coats and riding breeches were observed on all sides.
These expressions of opinion were obtained from Democrats as to the result of the city election:

In the mildest of Autumn weather the senior and junior cross-country championships of the Amateur Athletic Union were decided yesterday at Travers Island, under the auspices of the New York Athletic Club. In the senior class John J. Joyce of the Pastime Athletic Club won the individual honor, while the New York Athletic Club captured the team championship.
In the editorial columns of the leading New York newspapers this morning the results of the election are dealt with in part as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 3 -- Ex-President Grover Cleveland did not vote to-day until late in the afternoon. About 3:30 Mr. Cleveland was driven from his home, on Bayard Lane, to the fire engine house on Chambers Street -- the voting place for the Second District, in which Mr. Cleveland lives.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 -- The Consolidated Coal Company of Maryland, the largest concern in the community-of-interest arrangement made recently between it and the Somerset and Fairmont Coal Companies, has just completed an important deal in the purchase of the majority of the stock of the Metropolitan Coal Company of Boston.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3 -- The elections in Virginia, which were for members of Assembly, have resulted in a Democratic sweep of the State. There were few contests, the field as a rule being left open to the Democrats. At 11:30 of clock the outcome at the hardest fought points was still undecided.

Two negroes, one of them accused of shooting a boy, were so severely beaten by a crowd of white men at Sixty-eighth Street and Amsterdam Avenue yesterday that they had to be taken to Roosevelt Hospital. The boy who was shot was Jeremian Healy, sixteen years old, of 776 Tenth Avenue.

Prof. Carl Lumholtz, collector of Indian antiquities for the American Museum of Natural History, has just returned from Europe, where he has been, to follow up his investigations into the decorative art of a primitive people whom, from a scientific point of view, he discovered in a little valley in the southern end of the Northern Sierra Madre Mountains of Mexico.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- Reports that the Board of Directors of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company were in hearty accord with the plan of reorganization drawn by F.F. Rothermel, Samuel M. Clement, Jr., and Joseph De F. Junkin, attorneys for the Moffly committee, received official confirmation to-day when announcement was made that the board at its meeting directed President Shields and Vice President Sanborn to co-operate with the Moffly committee in every way possible.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Princess Radziwill today issued a writ demanding u1,400,000 from Lords Rosebery and Grey and Alfred Beit, Dr. Jameson. L.L. Michell, and B.A. Hawksley, trustees of the estate of the late Cecil Rhodes, under an agreement alleged to have been made on or about June 20, 1899, between herself and Mr. Rhodes.

Attired only in her nightgown, Mrs. Della Lupow, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, calmly entered the apartment of her friend and landlady. Miss Mary McWilliams, at 270 West Fourth Street, made herself comfortable upon the lounge, and remarked:
BALTIMORE, Nov. 3. -- At 1 o'clock this morning the returns from Baltimore city and the Maryland counties are meagre, owing to the length of the ballot.

W.R. Thurston won the special club golf handicap yesterday on the Larchmont Yacht Club links. It was a thirty-six-hole contest, and Thurston played from scratch, his score being 147 strokes. He made a new record for the course in one of the rounds, 77 strokes. The players who finished with cards are:

"A Clean Slate," which opened last night at the Madison Square Theatre," had nothing to do with that clean slate the advent of which was so blatantly announced by fishhorns and kazoos in the street outside. It was a matrimonial slate, or rather two matrimonial slates, both of which were prepared for the cleaning in the first act by divorces for cause.
WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 3 -- Mrs. Myra McHenry, wife of an Augusta attoruey, who now makes her home here, is under arrest charged with disturbing the peace.

Why use a razor? Why pay the barber 15 cents for a shave and 10 cents extra for not cutting your throat? The answer isn't "Let your whiskers grow." either, for Dr. Wolfram B. Dreyfus, chief chemist of the Department of Public Charities, has compounded, a little mixture which, if rubbed over the face, will do the trick as quickly and as well as the finest Sheffield razor.
First Lieut. Albert B. Henderson, Assistant Surgeon, will report to the Army Retiring Board for examination.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 4 -- With a score of 29 to 0, Williams easily defeated Hamilton to-day. During the first half Hamilton made a plucky fight, but in the second was clearly outclassed. Williams played many substitutes in the second half. Heavy plunging by Peabody, Durfee, and Gutterson were the features.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oklahoma, Nov. 4 -- Upon opening the safe of the Bank of Chickasaw Nation at Tishomingo, which closed its doors last week. Receiver Foster found but $50, which was in silver. The bank was the official depository of the Chickasaw Nation and had a capital stock of $50,000, with large private deposits.

Our entanglement with the Panama Canal undertaking has somewhat swiftly brought us to the point where we must either withdraw at once from the miserable business, or, shutting our ears to the voice of conscience and to the reproaches of civilized mankind, plunge on in the path of scandal, disgrace, and dishonor.

DERBY, Conn., Nov. 4 -- An overheated machine in the drying room of the A.H. C.B. Ailing Compay woolen mill late this afternoon set fire a quantity of loose material and caused a fire which damaged the plant to the extent of $30,000 and crippled the service of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company between New York and Boston for several hours by melting about 200 wires.

The Municipal Art Society has issued the report of its City Plan Committee on needed transit changes for New York. After criticising some of Chief Engineer Parsons's suggestions to the Rapid Transit Commission, and discussing the general policy that it considers proper for the city authorities to pursue, the committee outlines its own plans for alleviating the traffic conditions, manifested within the east few years.

Columbia's football men resumed regular practice yesterday after three days rest. Their work was comparatively light, however. R.S. Smith, the Captain, was not at the field, as he is confined to the house with a bad knee, and it is not likely that ho will be able to play any more this season.

NASHUA, N.H. Nov. 4 -- Favorites won in straight heats in the three events at the Nashua track to-day. The racing was uninteresting. In the second heat of the 2:14 pace Chum Boy fell and broke a leg. Summary:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A number of Republican Senators and Representative arrived to-day, some of whom called on the President and expressed gratification with the result of yesterday's election. The President seemed especially pleased with the result in Ohio, and sent Senator Hanna a congratulatory telegram on his great victory and the assurance of his return to the Senate upon the expiration of his present term.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- There was a little more activity in the trading to-day, but it was due largely to the dealings in Reading and United States Steel. With the exception of Consolidated Lake Superior and Union Traction, the purely local stocks were neglected, but those in which dealings did not take place were, as a rule, fractionally lower.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Generally speaking, death brings together friends who by some unhappy misunderstanding have been separated. The lamentable accident to Consul Emma BoothTucker afforded an opportunity of cementing divided lives, and forever breaking down the barriers which distressing misconceptions had erected.
The following report of the Standard Milling Company for the year ended Sept. 30, 1903, was made public yesterday.

Ex-Lieut. Gov. Woodruff issued a typewritten statement yesterday, in which he declared that the statements made by the Brooklyn Citizens' Union leaders to the effect that defeat was brought about by Republican treachery were untrue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The report of the Commissioner of Education for the last fiscal year places the total number of pupils enrolled in the common schools during the year at 15,925,887, or over 20 per cent. of the entire population.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst yesterday predicted that the administration of George B. McClellan as Mayor would be marked, despite any present intention, of the Mayor-elect, with the characteristics that distinguished Robert A. Van Wyck's term of office, and that the people of New York at the ensuing municipal election would again overthrow Tammany.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- The money market shows a slightly firmer tone in consequence of the heavy drain from the West. Call loans, 3 @ 4 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5 @ 6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 6 per cent; Clearing House loans, 3 per cent.; New York funds, par. Clearings, $22,067,664; balances, $1,574,148.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- An individual who is believed to have been the murderer of Sagatel Sagouni, President of the Armenian Revolutionary Society, who was assassinated on Oct. 26, shot and killed two Armenians close to the headquarters of the Hentchakist Society at Peckham Rye, a suburb of this city, this afternoon, and then shot himself dead.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times, in a telegram in regard to the Supao case, says the Municipal Council has addressed a communication to the Consular body pointing out that the defendants have been in custod" four months and have not yet been tried, a state of affairs which cannot continue indefinitely.

Nearly a thousand dogs passed muster before the critical eyes of the judges yesterday in Madison Square Garden. The second day of the Ladies' Kennel Association's show was characterized by greater rivalry and greater interest than on the preceding day. The attendance was much larger, the number of spectators assuming the dignity of a crowd early in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Japanese Minister has received the following official statement regarding the alleged dealing between an official of the Japanese Consulate at Manila and the insurgent leader, Trias, as reported by Gen. MacArthur in December, 1900:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Six men were blown to pieces and ten were injured this afternoon in an explosion which reduced to an almost total wreck the United States Naval Arsenal on Iona Island, in the Hudson River, three miles from this place.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A brief dispatch regarding the disaster on Iona Island, by which several men lost their lives, was received by Acting Secretary Darling tonight. It came from Capt. Perry, the acting commandant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, who simply repeated the following telegram received by him late this afternoon from the island:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Mrs. John W. Foster, who returned from London a few days ago, gave a tea this afternoon complimentary to the Chinese Commissioner to the St. Louis Exposition, Wong Kai Kah, and his wife, who recently arrived in Washington. The guests were limited strictly to the members of the Chinese Legation, including the sixteen-year-old daughter of the Minister.
According to Boston dispatches the Berkshire Hill Paper Company has been organized at Adams, Mass., with a capital of $150,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- The distinguishing feature of the Massachusetts election was the decrease in the vote of the Socialists throughout the State. The party had conducted an active campaign. Last year John C. Chase of Haverhill polled more than 30,000 votes as candidate for Governor, and John Quincy Adams, who had second place on the ticket, went about 10,000 ahead of this.

Policeman John J. O'Connell of the East Eighty-eighth Street Station yesterday stopped a runaway on Madison Avenue after having been dragged from a point half way between Eighty-fifth and Eighty-sixth Streets to Eighty-seventh Street. He held the reins until his weight brought the horses, which were attached to a victoria, to a halt.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 4 -- A stand of 4,000 Winchester rifles and 1,500,000 rounds of ammunition were shipped from Morgan City, La., sixty-five miles west of here, three months ago, on board an American schooner, which cleared for Progreso with a cargo of lumber.

PANAMA, Nov. 4 -- The revolution which occurred here yesterday, and which resulted in the proclamation of the independence of the Isthmus of Panama, was not unexpected. Since Sunday last all kinds of rumors had been in circulation, but it was not until Tuesday night that the hour so long looked forward to by the inhabitants of Panama arrived.

A revision of the unofficial election figures of the vote for Mayor and Controller, which follows, establishes that George B. McClellan had a plurality over Seth Low of over 63,000, and Edward M. Grout about 60,000 over Frederick W. Hinrichs. The vote is shown in the following tables:

Yesterday's stock market developed very little difference in tone or prices between "election on" and "election off." This applies even to the group of stocks which were to be especially benefited by Tammany's success and "friendliness." Early in the day there was a brief spurt in which those who were spry enough might have sold some shares at a profit, but it was all gone before the day was done.
COLUMBUS, Nov. 4. -- The Republican plurality in Ohio is about 115,000 for Governor, and the majority in the Legislature on joint ballot for Senator is 93.
COLON, Nov. 4. -- The opinion of everybody here is that the Isthmian canal is now assured.

Fusion prophets reproached for their failure to foresee the magnificent triumph of Tammany may present the sufficient excuse that Satan had declined to honor them with his confidence. Foresight of a great community's intention to take such a backward step can be demanded of no good man.
