Early in the evening the massive gates fronting on Fleet Street shut with a clang, but later the King drove in by the back way from the deserted Thames Embankment unostentatiously and unobserved.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 7. -- The race of the Democratic aspirants for United States Senator to succeed Senator Louis E. McComas has now begun in earnest, with Isidor Rayner claiming to be in the lead. Gov. John Waiter Smith, ex-Gov. Elihu E. Jackson, Gen. L. Victor Baughman, and ex-Congressman Joshua W. Miles are among those who are after the great prize, and more candidates may appear before the new Legislature meets Jan. 1.

We are strongly of opinion that whatever else may have been established by recent discussion, no conclusive case has yet been made, out for the immediate argency of change. Mr. Chamberlain, the foremost advocate of fiscal innovations, has himself admitted that the adoption of retaliatory duties might be delayed without, any great harm being done.
Time money rates, 6 per cent. for thirty days to six months.

EXETER, N.H., Nov. 7. -- In a hard-fought contest Phillips-Andover was defeated by Philips-Exeter in the annual football contest between the two academies here to-day by a score of 14 to 11. During the first half Andover was almost entirely on the defensive, Exeter scoring on a safety by Veeder.

Who are the men in America now living who have made a name for themselves? Have such men risen from the lower strata of society, so to say, and achieved prominence through their individual efforts, or have they received some outside impetus or encouragement, as by inheritance or social surroundings, which has forced them to the front?
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- To-day's advices to the State Department indicated a regular development, of the new Government of Panama.

One army officer, one navy officer, and one civilian are to compose the committee charged with the reform of the British Army. The naval man may seem to be an anomaly. But if the British public concludes that the British Army cannot be trusted to work out its own salvation, who in the face of the recent disclosures can blame the British public?

An order of civil arrest against Thomas A. Ennis and Charles F. Stoppani, Consolidated Exchange brokers doing business under the name of Ennis Stoppani at 34 and 36 New Street, was issued by Justice Amend on the complaint of Gustav A. Helm of 780 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, served by Deputy Sheriff Walgering, and vacated by order of the issuing Justice all within an hour yesterday afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great deal is heard nowadays about cat shortage on railroads, and congestion of freight at important terminals. In fact, railroad men generally in charge of transportation are "walking the floor" just now and at their wits' ends to meet the emergencies as they arise.

ROME, Nov. 7. -- On the eve of Monday's Consistory a rumor is in circulation here that in addition to the Appointments of Mgrs. Merry del Vel and Callegari to the Cardinalate, which it is already known will be made, other Cardinals will be named. The rumor has it that the new Cardinals will be Americans; that is, they will belong to the American Continent.

PARALLEL lines of steel glistening in the afternoon sun like polished arm or stretched away north and south. Coming in from the east the tracks of the Transit Company were-rapidly approaching the new pier, which reached out into the bay like a great arm. Hundreds of men worked along the new road, digging, shoveling, hammering; dozens of teams hauled sand and gravel, making high mounds of them at convenient places.

Let the irate driver of horses say what he will let the funny man with a pencil evolve cartoons as he may, the automobile is here and will not depart until aerial navigation becomes the fashion. The automobile is with us to stay and we should make the best of it, for what says the poet?
EVER notice how many men hang on to their morning papers on a rainy day?" inquired a Harlemite.

Mrs. John M. Holcombe, on retiring from the position of Regent of Ruth Wyllys Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, which she had held for several years, read an elaborate paper, at Hartford, Conn., in which she pleaded that their State should be-known as "the Constitution State," and no longer referred to as "the Wooden Nutmeg State."

TAUNTON, Mass., Nov. 7 -- Angered beyond his powers of control, Walter E. Bassett, an eleven-year-old boy, to-day shot and Instantly killed Peter Clark, a schoolmate of his own age. The tragedy was the outcome of a quarrel between the two little fellows.

MR. WOODBEE GOODE and wife occupied one of the two-by-four Harlem flats with their two children, a boy of two and the baby brother, eight months old, together with their two pets, a frisky fox terrier and a poll parrot.

While Mrs. Vellyard Johnston, colored, of 233 West Sixty-first Street, was at a grocery store yesterday afternoon, a fire, which was started in some unknown manner, suffocated her two-year-old-daughter Viola, and rendered unconscious the other two children, Willrie, four years old, and Fannie, six.

There has been a remarkable fall in the stocks of the United States Steel Corporation, as our financial columns have indicated recently, and in some quarters this is regarded as preliminary to the collapse of the greatest "trust" in the world. The corporation was, it may be recalled, formed in March, 1901, and united thirteen wealthy American iron and steel companies, the greatest of them being the Carnegie Company.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7. -- The local market was extremely dull, but prices remained steady. Only fractional changes occurred. The Street seems to be devoid of any special feature. Money on call at 5@6 per cent. Complete transactions for the day, amounting to fifteen shares of stock and $50,000 worth of bonds, were as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Articles in the daily press of this city in relation to corruption in the city and the labor troubles have interested me greatly, and as I am an old railroad man, the thought has occurred to me, does there exist the same relation between the railroad official and the walking delegate as has existed between the George A. Fuller Company and Sam Parks?
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7. -- It is reported that Mrs. James L. Blair will resign the Chairmanship of the Board of Lady Managers of the World's Fair shortly.

PARIS, Nov 7. -- Before giving a formal recognition by France of the new Republic of Panama, Foreign Minister Delcasse has decided to secure a specific declaration that the new regime will carry out Colombia's former obligations in connection with the canal and other French property interests.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I hope you will not consider it an impertinence in one with such a name as I subscribe to this letter -- a name that does not belie my condition -- to offer a few comments and suggestions upon the civic election.

MUNCH, munch, munch, grind, grind, grind," was the tune the man's teeth played on the freshly roasted chestnuts. There had been comparative peace in the car till he began that unconventional prelude to the evening meal which probably awaited him at the end of the route; but no sooner did a whiff of the chestnuts strike sensitive noses than the passengers laid aside their papers and eyed the bag and its contents greedily.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov. 7. -- A team match between Westfield and Cranford was the final event for the season at the Westfleld Golf Club this afternoon. The visiting team won by 12 holes to 10. The results:

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Rates for money hardened in the market to-day, and repayments to the Bank of England materially reduced the supplies, which will be further depleted next week by the payment or the Transvaal loan installment. Discounts were firm on the condition of the Continental and American exchanges.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- The Yale freshmen overwhelmed the Princeton freshmen at Yale Field this afternoon, winning by a score of 10 to 0. The game was well fought, by both teams, though Yale was much stronger on offense. Princeton held on downs on their own two-yard line once and on their five-yard line once, and lost the ball on a fumble once on Yale's three-yard line.
BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- No German warships have been ordered to Santo Domingo from here. But the commander of the German squadron in West Indian waters may have sent a veshel thither.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 7. -- The chief interest which St. Petersburg now seems to take in the Far Eastern situation is in regard to the attitude of the United States.

WHY do we whistle? Some, of us do not, because we cannot -- though most of us think we are warblers of divine melody. The really artistic whistler, he who knows when the occasion is ripe for him to purse his lips and give his safety valve free vent, is not the tooter of things frightful and heartrending.

The Philharmonic Society will begin its sixty-second season this week. The first public rehearsal and concert will be given on Friday afternoon and Saturday evening. The occasion will have a double significance, for it will mark an important departure in the history of the society and will introduce a distinguished conductor to New York.

We confidently hope that our German friends will not consider that their efforts to establish the German language as part of the public school curriculum in this and other cities are offensively caricatured by the resolution offered by a member of the Boston Common Council, Mr. GRADY, to the following effect:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial in THE TIMES of Oct. 29. 1903, under the caption "The Issue of the Open Shop," is instructive and is conclusive in its logic. Possibly its premise may be questioned, but any questioning of the viewpoint from which it treats the subject will tell with multiplied force against the viewpoint from which the trades unionist treats it.

It was necessary last week to take an unfavorable view of the showing of the St. Louis and San Francisco. It is not for any one to know or to proclaim whether the plans of that company are destined to failure or to success; it is suggested merely that the management is not adopting that conservative method which guarantees safety.

A practice which, quite unknown probably to most people, has been pursued by the managers of ocean steamship companies is one that insures for the ships of the different lines distinctive, or what may be called family, names -- names intended to suggest at once the particular line to which this or that steamship or group of steam-ships belongs.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Death due to blood poisoning in rather peculiar circumstances ended the suffering of Mrs. Agnes Hudolsky of East Jersey Street last night. During the windstorm of a few weeks ago the woman tried to haul in a clothesline on which the family wash was hanging.
It is reported that the Casualty Company of America is contemplating the advisability of applying for admission to several Trans-Mississippi States.

The week's price movement as a whole made good progress toward the year's previous lowest average upon two chief moving causes -- the conditions in the iron trade and the money market. The election was much discussed in the earlier portion of the week, but its effect upon the list was unimportant.
I NEVER knew a woman capable of keeping anything to herself," grumbled the man with sandy whiskers, who had just discovered that his wife had a let a harmless cat out of the bag.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Albert Shaw's interesting remarks on the policy of the political reformers of Boston in a recent issue of THE TIMES having caused much comment in Boston, it is perhaps apropos to point out that while Dr. Shaw's Idea of political wisdom is approved by probably every adherent of the present movement in Boston, he has not been informed of the real reasons in the matter.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Dartmouth won from Amherst to-day by 18 to 0 in a hard-fought game. The home team was lighter than Dartmouth, and failed to play as strong a game. The features were long runs by Dillon, Patteson, and Hubbard. The line-up:
I NEVER knew a woman capable of keeping anything to herself," grumbled the man with sandy whiskers, who had just discovered that his wife had a let a harmless cat out of the bag.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- In response to the request of the department for a report regarding the recent Indian troubles in Wyoming Gen. Kobbe, commanding the Department of Dakota, to-day forwarded a dispatch from Major B.H. Cheever, Sixth Cavalry, at Pine Ridge, in which he says the trouble was mostly the Sheriff's fault and that the Indian prisoners at Newcastle should be released.

How heavy can fall the shadow of a great name may be seen in Germany during the present year. The intense activity of the Kaiser in furthering the erection of monuments to his grandsire, to the various ascending lines of Hohenzollerns, and even to his own father and mother, persons with whose aspirations and views of life he had little sympathy, have roused the admirers of BISMARCK.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With our help -- certainly not without it -- there is about to be admitted to the family of nations a State that is as ill fitted for any of the duties of nationality as the history of the world has perhaps ever seen.

In the designing and constructing of the modern office building there is no one feature which deserves so much attention upon the part of those interested as the elevator equipment of the structure. In all tall buildings the rental value of the upper stories depends entirely upon the efficiency of the elevator service.

The decrease of $11,413,000 in loans brings that item down to the lowest point this year, since the statement, of Jan. 24, when loans were $890,448,100. In the week ended April 25 loans were $900,635,100. Liquidation, appeared to be general, since thirty-seven banks out of the fifty-five in the Clearing House Association showed reductions in loans.

The Rev. Marco N. Popoff, pastor of the Congregational Church in Sofia, Bulgaria, and the Rev. D.N. Furnajieff, pastor of the Congregational Church at Kustindil, Bulgaria, arrived here on the Campania yesterday, commissioned by the Bulgarian Evangelical Association to raise funds for the relief of the Macedonian refugees, of whom there are said to be about 250,000 in the direst want.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- It is said here that if the Russo-Japanese negotiations end satisfactorily, as is now expected, it will be due in great measure to the British Government's pledge of its good offices toward the raising of another large Japanese loan in London.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 8 -- The clubhouse of the Morris County Golf Club was destroyed by fire to-day. The flames started about 10:30 o'clock in the morning, and the house was burned to the ground in about an hour. About half the furniture was saved. The loss will probably reach $5,000.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- While the drawbridge over the Seneca Canal at Cayuga was open to-day to permit the passage of several boats the engine pulling passenger train on the New York Central Railroad which is due here at 11:48 A.M. went through the draw and into the canal. None of the crew or passengers was seriously injured.

Those who are still seeking an answer to the question asked some weeks ago in these columns, When is a man rich? will undoubtedly be interested in the case of the longshoreman who was brought before the Police Magistrate in Harlem a few days ago, on the charge of drunkenness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Mayor-elect McClellan of New York is getting ready to take a strong hand in the Cuban reciprocity matter. There is considerable divergence of opinion about what the proper Democratic attitude on that subject shall be, and Col. Mc-Clellan, who was the chief figure in the fight on the Democratic side in 1902, will endeavor to commit the party to his views.

ROME, Nov. 8 -- Pope Plus this afternoon held another of the receptions inaugurated by him this Autumn in order that the people of Rome might have his blessing. At an early hour the large Court of San Damaso was so full that not another person could be squeezed in. It is believed that there were about 20,000 persons in the court and many were turned away.

Congress will meet to-day in extraordinary session, but it will be some days before the House committees can be named and the House be ready for actual work. The Senate, being a continuous body, can proceed to any business that may be laid before it or which it chooses to take up.

The first big public demonstration by the National Art Theatre Society since its formation last Spring was held last night at the Herald Square Theatre. Chairman J.I.C. Clarke announced that he had practically the promise of certain wealthy men to endow the theatre, then Bronson Howard defended managers for pursuing a commercial policy, while, on the other hand, Sydney Rosenfeld called them ignorant.

Bishop Grafton of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Fond du Lac returned yesterday on the steamship Deutschland from Russia, where he has been trying to forward efforts to bring the Anglican and Russian communions into closer relations. He was accompanied on the trip by his chaplain, Father S.W. Fay.

If the pie market opens this morning with bullish tendencies, but withal unsteady and feverish, as has been its tenor for a week past, it will be despite the efforts of nearly 200 lunch-room keepers who met yesterday afternoon to devise ways and means of throwing off the yoke of the Pie Trust, which, they declare, is adopting methods tending to put a staple delicacy out of the reach of the masses.

BEIRUT, Oct. 5 -- While the news from Macedonia fills us with new horrors every day and affairs in the Valiyyet of Beirut continue to give cause for painful anxiety on the part of all the peace-loving subjects of the Sultan, fresh disturbances in Mount Lebanon have occurred to augment the other troubles of the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- It was learned in official circles to-night that the United States of Colombia has lodged a protest with the State Department against the action of this country in connection with the events which have occurred on the Isthmus of Panama.

LYNN, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Through an accidental invasion by the police early to-day what is believed to be an extensive swindle was brought to light. William S. Wells, forty-five years old, is under arrest charged with printing lottery tickets, larceny, and obtaining money under false pretenses.

In the Far East they have some very interesting legends, about almost everything, and they are great believers in the "has beens" as far as they understand them. So we find various stories to account for the peculiar cut of their wardrobes, their hats, and their footgear coming in for as much of it as the jackets and skirts.

Police Inspector McClusky said yesterday afternoon that James Abeel of 239 Central Park West, is the man whom the detectives are looking for on the charge of impersonating a member of the Goelet family while paying attention to Miss Eleanor Anderson, and forging the name of J.B. Van Every, Vice President of the Western Union Telegraph Company.

Secretary of War Elihu Root, the last American member of the Alaskan Boundary Commission to return to this country, arrived yesterday on the steamship Celtic of the White Star Line. Major Gen. Corbin, the new Commander of the Department of the East, went down the bay on a revenue cutter to meet the steamship.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 8 -- A general strike in the Northern Colorado coal field was declared to-night. In all about 1,275 men in the northern field are idle or will be to-morrow morning. The action of the miners was a surprise to the operators. Alter the conferences, in which practically every demand except the eight-hour day was granted to the men, they determined to strike.

Immense quantities of apples are now arriving in New York daily. Shipments are much larger than usual at this season, as shown toy the figures. For instance, on Friday 21,177 barrels were received in New York, compared with 3,833 on the corresponding date last year. Since Jan. 1 total receipts in this market have been 1,407,144 barrels, compared with 717,154 barrels during the corresponding period a year ago.

The full force of the strikes in this city to be ordered on behalf of Local No. 2 of the International Association of Bridge and Structural Iron Workers against tha Iron League will be felt to-day, according to James Crowley. Chairman of the local Strike Committee. A meeting of the committee was held last night at 305 West Twenty-sixth Street.

A notable bit of engraving on wood has been finished by Mr. Henry Wolf. It is a companion piece to his charming woodcut Evening Star," which, like this one, has not been published anywhere, but is sold in limited number of proofs carefully printed by the engraver himself, and may be had of the artist at 152 East Eighty-sixth Street or of the leading printsellers, such as Wunderlich, Keppel, Klackner,

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Kins Edward's birthday honor list is extremely uninteresting. No new Peers or Privy Councilors have been created, but there is a long list of promotions, decorations, and knighthoods for service rendered in the various public departments. Vice Admiral Lord Charles Beresford has been promoted from Commander of the Bath to Knight Commander of the Bath.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8 -- According to statistics prepared by the Exposition management, the number of World's Fair visitors who can be accommodated is now approximately 50,000. This estimate is based on present known accommodations for guests. By the time the Exposition opens it is thought that there will be facilities for a much larger number.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 8 -- It has been practically settled that following the consecration of Bishop-elect Edwin S. Lines on Nov. 18 the episcopal residence of the Newark Episcopal diocese will cease to be in East Orange. Dr. Lines and his family have already taken under consideration several houses in this city.

A service in memory of Mrs. Emma Booth-Tucker was held yesterday afternoon in the Majestic Theatre by the West Side Young Men's Christian Association, which had invited Mrs. Russell Sage and others to bear tribute, as the notice read, to a modern heroine whose recent tragic death is mourned by the people or two continents."

There being a difference of opinion between Commissioner WOODBURY and the members of the Retail Dry Goods Association as to his duty in the matter of removing ashes and rubbish from their stores, they had a perfect right to apply to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for the mandamus refused them in a court below requiring the Commissioner to render them the service they want.
Before entering prison SAMUEL PARKS, the convicted walking delegate of the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union, was interviewed and is reported to have said, among other things:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Republicans are preparing for an expected Democratic attack on the Administration's connection with the Panama revolution. Resolutions will be introduced from the Democratic side calling upon the President for information and for papers. Every effort will be made to show that the President deliberately incited the State of Panama to rebel and then prevented Colombia from putting down the rebellion.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Responsible officers of the two branches of Congress have everything in readiness for the assembling of that body at noon to-morrow.

A gentleman who is particularly interested in the social and political problems presented by the curious variety of race origin among the population or New York sends us a compilation bearing on this subject from the census of 1900. The 1,007,670 males twenty-one years of age or over he finds to be made up as follows:

Edouard Colonne, first of the six European conductors engaged for this season by the Philharmonic Society, arrived here yesterday on the Deutschland. He will direct the first public rehearsal of the society on Friday afternoon, and the first concert on Saturday evening.

-- Whatever royalty, deep down in its heart, may really think about itself nowadays, and however clearly its more intelligent representatives may appreciate their own belatedness, crowns are still such comfortable wear that it is most unlikely that any possessor of one of them would take the enormous risk of making publicly any sort of a jest concerning another member of the sacred caste.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 8 -- A silk banner, which appears to symbolize the cause of the followers of the Prince of Orange, has been found under the hearthstone of an old building which is being torn down in the rear of 197 Thomas Street.

WILLIAMS, Iowa, Nov. 8 -- A successful fiat money scheme is in vogue here. Williams is a pretentious little city, where aluminium dollars, half dollars, quarters, , are in common use and pass current. They are redeemable at several of the more prominent stores of the place. The scheme is a local one of the merchants to increase the volume of money in circulation in the community, and "to move the crops."

Lou Dillon queen of the light harness turf and holder of the world's trotting record l:58 1/2, made her initial appearance on the road and stepped her first race on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning to the delight of an immense crowd, drawn by the promised debut of the famous mare.

The week's price movement is pleasanter to review than the daily markets which composed it. The impression of weakness given by several days' bad business in conspicuous stocks is not borne out in retrospect. Twelve shares contributed about three-quarters to the total 1,969,682 shares sold, and of the twelve live advanced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The announcement that the Hawaiian sugar crop of 1902 is 420,000 tons, or 840,000,000 pounds, lends special interest to some figures recently presented by the Bureau of Statistics covering the growth of sugar production in Hawaii under the close commercial relations with the United States established by the reciprocity treaty in 1876, and further developed by annexation in 1898.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 -- The police are investigating the cause of the death of Martin Loew, twenty-seven years old, a student in the Dental Department of the University of Maryland, whose lifeless body was found to-day in his room at his boarding house. His roommate, Ephraim Stone, twenty-three years of age, was lying unconscious beside the bed.
BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Emperor William yesterday underwent an operation for the removal of a polypus from his larynx.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- The will of William L. Elkins, the financier, who died on Saturday evening, was opened to-day, but members of the family declined to say anything about its provisions. It is understood, however, that the bulk of his estate will go to his children, George W. Elkins Mrs. George D. Widener, Mrs. Sydney F. Tyler, and his daughter-in-law, Mrs. William L. Elkins, Jr., who was Miss Kate Felton of California.

If the Government of the United States were bent on convincing an unthinking world that the revolt in Panama was undertaken solely to secure the construc- tion of the Panama Canal on terms ac- ceptable to our Government, it would hardly act or talk in a way different from that it has adopted.

LANCASTER, Ohio, Nov. 8 -- Four children were killed by an explosion of nitroglycerine at Buck's Run in Hocking County to-day. The dead are Oscar Bohn, Charles Bohn, aged fourteen and twelve respectively, their eight-year-old sister, and the nine-year-old son of Robert Conrad.

Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst told his congregation yesterday morning not to feel too downcast over the Fusion defeat in therecent election. As proof that he was not altogether discouraged himself, he had directed the choir, come, what might, to begin yesterday's service with the joyful anthem "Sound the Loud Timbrel," , which they did.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- In his annual report Capt. Charles Young, Acting Superintendent of Sequoia and General Grant National Parks of California, in which many giant trees are located, urges the acquisition by the Government of the land in those parks which is owned by private individuals.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says that the Czechs, who have been awaiting the end of the Hungarian crisis in order to demand for Bohemia the equivalent of whatever should be granted to the Magyars, have just launched a full-sized programme of national requirements.

HILLSDALE, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Passengers on the Erie "theatre train," which leaves Jersey City at 12:20 in the morning, had a bad fright and long delay between Hillsdale and Woodcliffe this morning, when the engine, in charge of Engineer Charles Rickley, dropped one of her driving wheels, which tumbled down the bank nearly 20 feet high.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Money was wanted in the market to-day in connection with the payment of the Transvaal loan call tomorrow and the payment of L500,000 of London County Council bills, which absorbed all the available supplies. Discounts were firm on the dearness of money, the decline in New York exchange, and the expectation that the Bank of England will raise its discount rate to 5 per cent, on Thursday.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 9 -- Charles F. Murphy of New York, leader of Tammany, arrived here this afternoon. He came for a rest and refuses to talk. He will remain three weeks.

The decision of the Alaska Commission may have an important effect on the sentiment of the people of Canada as to Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S campaign for protection. The chief plea, made by Mr. CHAMBERLAIN for the return of Great Britain to the policy of tariff taxation in the interest of special industries in the colonies was that that was the only way in which the colonies could be kept in the empire.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 -- Medical students and physicians filled the western police station to-night at the inquest in the case of Martin Loew, the dental student who was found dead in his lodging house, Sunday morning, under circumstances that led to the suspicion that rough treatment he might have received at an initiation into a Greek letter society composed of sudents of Maryland University might have had something to do with his death.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Congressman J.R. Williams for President is the issue upon which the Illinois Democracy expects to present a united front in the next Democratic National Convention. It has the indorsement of Mayor Harrison, and at the same time removes the Mayor from the field of possibilities for either first or second place on the next Democratic National ticket.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- King Edward (who was born Nov. 9, 1841,) celebrated his birthday at Sandringham, where there was the usual dinner to the tenants of the estate, at which the King, the Queen, and other members of the royal family handed round the dessert.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Victor and Robert Mc Kay. the two sons of Gordon McKay, the millionaire inventor of shoe machinery, are practically cut off by their father's, will from all share in his estate, while Harvard University will eventually receive the entire estate, valued at several millions of dollars, the interest of the fund to be used to promote applied science.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas K. Slicer spoke last night before the League for Political Education, at 23 West Forty-fourth Street, on the condition of New York after the election. He said in part: "The adventure has landed on an undefended coast, and the good citizen watches and waits helplessly while this adventurer gorges himself in anticipation.

ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- In February last the State Railroad Commission investigated the matter of improving the condition of passenger transportation in New York City. In June the commission made a report of its investigations and to-day has made a second report with reference especially to the capacity of the electric power houses of the several street railways.
NAPLES, Nov. 9 -- The new Minister of Finance, Signer Rosano, committed suicide by shooting himself last night. He was found dead this morning in his room, a revolver at his side.

The big factory, of Herman Behr Co., manufacturers of sandpaper, glue, and emery paper, in Tiffany Place, between Degraw and Harrison Streets, Brooklyn, was destroyed yesterday afternoon by a fire which caused a heavy property loss and at which a number of firemen, narrowly escaped death under falling walls.

SAGINAW, Mich., Nov. 9 -- Dr. E.W. Light, a prominent dentist of this city, committed suicide Sunday night at his home,813 South Jefferson Avenue, after fatally shooting his wife and daughter, Ruby, a young girl of eighteen. The tragedy was not discovered until noon to-day, when a friend in Bay City, alarmed by a letter he received to-day from Dr. Light, came here and entered the Light home.

Last week a certain number of negroes met in Boston and passed resolutions for the formation of a negro party independent of all other parties. Two of the leaders in the meeting were negroes who had been convicted of a disturbance of the peace at a meeting addressed by BOOKER WASHINGTON.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Democratic steering committee of the Senate was in session for two hours to-day, the greater part of which time was devoted to consideration of the situation on the Isthmus. The question was discussed in all its aspects, especial attention being given to the allegation that this country has been instrumental in producing the revolt at Panama and Colon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial this morning on the subject of the merchants and Commissioner Woodbury does not fully state the facts and indicates a misapprehension on your part. The circumstances which led to the action against Commissioner Woodbury may be briefly summed up as follows:

There was a very feverish, and excited cotton market yeterday. Prices moved up and down again with bewildering rapidity, and the transactions were on an enormous scale. At the opening December cotton was pushed up to 11.11 and the July option to 11.19, due to higher prices in London, and a scramble of the bears to cover, but soon afterward the market began to slump.

That a serious accident happened yes- terday at the grade crossing of a north and south surface line and one running east and west need not occasion surprise. The wonder is that such accidents are not rather the rule than the exception. There are a great many perilous crossings of this character in New York -- those at Fourteenth, Twenty-third, Thirty-fourth, and Forty-second Streets being conspicuous.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Secretary Hay, during a call at the White House this morning, placed in the hands of the President the Colombian protest against the course pursued by the Washington Government on the Isthmus and its attitude toward the new Government of Panama.

Inclined as one is to curse the luckless conjunction of stars (to say nothing of managers) which has resulted in introducing to us the greatest living Hamlet in a dramatized novel, the appearance of Forbes Robertson last night at the Knickerbocker as the blinded hero of "The Light That Failed" is nevertheless to be reckoned as one of the few momentous events of the current season.

"The Red Feather" came to the Lyric Theatre last evening with the blare of trumpets, the clash of cymbals, the resonance of a chorus singing at the top of its voice, a dazzling splendor of superb costumes, and an abundance of handsome young women -- a comic opera upon which everything has been lavished in an apparent effort to outdo all that has been previously accomplished in these lines.

PASS CHRISTIAN, Miss., Nov. 9 -- Mrs. Peter Labouisse, the young matron of New York who was attacked last Thursday by Sam Adams, a negro who was soon afterward lynched, spent to-day in this resort. Although not injured in the struggle, Mrs. Labouisse's nerves are still completely unstrung.
NEWPORT, Nov. 9 -- Mr. and Mrs. George B. De Forest, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel, and Mr. and Mrs. S.E. Huntington closed their cottages to-day and went to New York.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 9 --Sutter Brothers, the embarrassed tobacco firm, purchased much of the Onondaga crop. They had a large warehouse at Baldwinsville, employing hundreds of hands part of the year.

Hickey and Nelson are the chief feature at Proctor's Twenty-third Street Theatre this week, being supported by Lewis and Ryan, Keno, Welch and Montrose, Barr and Evans, and others. A revival of Mansfield's success, "Prince Karl," was made at the Fifth Avenue last night; Major Doyle heads the vaudeville bill.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- The weekly statement of the local associated banks as issued to-day shows a loss in the reserve excess of $986,288. The New York reserve fell off $1,080,286. Loans scored only a nominal shrinkage of $78,000 and deposits increased $3,353,000. Comparative figures in detail are:

An interesting illustration of the tendency which is inducing a gradual substitution of electricity for steam in the operation of railroads originally built and equipped for locomotive traction is furnished by the New York Central management in its announced plans of electrically equipping its suburban branches in the central and western parts of this State to save its local traffic, which has been heavily cut into by independent trolley lines.
DENVER, Nov. 9 -- More than 10,000 coal minors in Colorado went on strike to-day for an eight-hour day, increased wages and other concessions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The amount of 3 and 4 per cent. bonds so far received at the Treasury for refund into 2s is $8,774,750, and the amount of 5s received for redemption is $10,362,100.
ROME, Nov. 9 -- The first Secret Consistory of the new Pentificate was held today.

Under the title of "Military Graphics," Col. LARNED, Professor of Drawing at West Point, contributes to the current numbers of The Journal of the Military Service Institution two papers of singular interest. The civilian who undertakes the reading of them under the natural impression that the writer aims to magnify his own office, will be convinced that it is an office of which the importance in modern war is very difficult to overrate.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- It is predicted that the Consolidated Lake Superior Company's plan of reorganization will be declared operative by the Moffly Committee on Tuesday next.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- The latest news regarding the condition of Emperor William is that it remains satisfactory. He worked several hours this afternoon on Government business and wrote a long telegram to King Edward congratulating him on his birthday.
BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Reports in theatrical circles that Nixon Zimmerman are contemplating withdrawal from the theatrical syndicate find credence here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Republican move in the House to-day, when Chairman Hitt introduced a resolution calling upon the President for all papers dealing with the Panama revolution, was intended to have the effect of drawing all the ammunition from the Democratic guns.
The annual dinner of the British Schools and Universities Club of this city was held at Delmonico's last night in honor of the birthday of King Edward VII.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A conference of significance and Importance was held at the executive offices to-day between President Roosevelt and Senator Hanna of Ohio. The President formally requested Senator Hanna to retain the Chairmanship of the Republican National Committee, and to conduct the campaign of next year.

-- A correspondent of The Evening Post who signs himself "Idealist" takes our good neighbor and occasional ally somewhat severely to task for printing as an advertisement just before election the full text of Mr. McCLELLAN's speech in Durland's Academy. After praising The Post for the fearlessness with which it had "pointed out the disreputable means by which Tammany Hall recruits itself financially, and the loathsome character of its blood money," the idealist says:

The securities of the United States Steel Corporation furnished Wall Street with sometHing of a sensation yesterday. The bonds as well as the preferred and common stocks made new low records on transactions which made up more than one-half of the entire transactions on the Stock Exchange.

Gen. ALLEN, the Chief of the Philippine Constabulary, in his interesting annual report, just published, strongly deprecates the proposal of a further reduction in the number of American troops in the islands. That number he puts at 18,000, although, according to the latest official returns from Washington, it is but 13,480.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Secretary Wilson of the Department of Agriculture was an curly caller on the President to-day. He has just returned from Texas, where he went to investigate the condition of cotton and learn the results of the fight the planters are making against the boll weevil.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- John Hyde, statistician of the Department of Agriculture, who represented the department at several important statistical conventions in Europe last Summer, is ill in London and under the care of a specialist.

Surrounded, by the dirt of years and an accumulation of worthless odds and ends, although she had been reputed in the neighborhood to be worth more than $500,000, the body of Mrs. Mary J. Oliver, an aged hermit of Harlem, was discovered by the police last night.

The resolution of inquiry introduced by Mr. HITT of Illinois and promptly passed by the House, relating to the events in Panama, was precisely what was expected and what the friends of the Administration were bound to propose. The Administration, in response, will submit to Congress what it suits the President to have the public know and nothing more.

COLON, Nov. 9 -- Dr. Manuel Amador, Minister of Finance, and Federico Boyd, a member of the Junta, have been appointed by the Provisional Government a commission to go to Washington and arrange with the United States on canal and other necessary treaties. They will sail to-morrow on the steamer City of Washington.

Carpet prices went up yesterday from 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 cents per yard on nearly all lines. One or two manufacturers did not declare an advance, but may do so later. This was the opening of the Spring trade to the department stores and retailers. The number of buyers in the city, who have come from all parts of the country, is believed to be nearly 500.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 9 -- An audience which packed the Parsons Theatre to-night loudly applauded Channing Pollock's adaptation of Frank Norris's "The Pit," but after it was all over the people were of the opinion that sundry changes would have to be made if readers of the book are to be considered.

The week's market opened under the same influences as depressed it last week. There were rumors of lower prices for steel goods, and it was stated that the iron production has now been reduced 49 per cent. And Steel Trust securities made low records upon all three varieties. The dealings in them were large, comprising a full half of all the business done on a day of moderate activity.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- Mary Comey, who asserts that she is the widow of John Lucas, the paint manufacturer, who died worth about $3,000,000, is the plaintiff in a suit against his estate for dower rights, and the trial was begun to-day in the Orphans' Court.

Wall Street expects developments of considerable importance from a meeting of the Board of Directors of the International Mercantile Marine Company to be held to-day. It is expected that Herr Ballin, managing director of the Hamburg American Line, who recently arrived in this city from Europe, will be asked to attend the meeting to confer on the present status of the Atlantic steamship business, in which conditions are said to be very unsatisfactory.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 --The local market drooped in sympathy with New York. Prices did not so off a great deal, but operations fell off and commission, house business was very dull. Nearly one-half of the trading was in the steels, and the local dealings were largely of a professional character.
PARIS, Nov. 9 -- W.K. Vanderbilt's Morroko took second place to-day, in the race for the prix Cyclemens at the St. Cloud meeting.

BOSTON, Nov., 9 -- The twenty-third annual convention of the American Federation of Labor, which was opened in this city to-day, and which will continue probably for at least fourteen days, got into working order before an adjournment was taken late this afternoon. President Samuel Gompers delivered his annual address to the delegates and Secretary Frank Morrison and Treasurer John B. Lennon presented, their annual statements.

ROME, Nov. 9 -- Since the formation of the new Cabinet the Socialists had attacked Signor Rosano, charging him with corruption in his political career challenging him to disprove the charges, and adding that otherwise they would bring the matter up at the opening of the Chamber of Deputies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- When Clerk McDowell of the House banged the gavel on his desk and stilled the roar of voices on the floor at noon to-day, the galleries were crowded and ornamented with gorgeous feminine hats and pretty dresses for the opening of the special session of Congress, called to consider the Cuban reciprocity agreement.

With the exception of Standard Oil, all the stocks traded in in the outside market yesterday either remained stationary or advanced, and the general tone of the market as regards activity was somewhat better than in the very recent past. The only very active stock was American Can. A little interest was shown in the bond market, though the half-point gain in American Malting 6s was the only advance recorded in this department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The second called session of the Senate of the Fifty-eighth Congress opened with a function which lasted hardly a quarter of an hour. For two hours before noon the Senate Chamber was a scene of animation, as the large galleries steadily filled with serried lines of brilliant costumes and the desks on the floor as steadily were massed with huge bouquets and elaborate floral designs.

Experts said yesterday that there has never been a finer exhibition of chrysanrthemums seen in New York than that of the American Institute and Chrysanthemum Society of America, which opened its doors in the Herald Square Exhibition Hall, Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Streets, on Broadway, at 3 o'clock, to continue to-day and to-morrow from 10 A.M. to 10, P.M.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day. The condition of New York exchange caused a rehardening of discount rates, but much of the business was subject to the prospect of a change in the Bank of England's rate of discount.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 10. -- The alleged will of Francis Bradley of Cliffside was thrown out of court to-day by Judge Zabriskie. The court says that Mr. Bradley never signed the document purporting to be his will, and that the entire will and all the signatures attached to it were written by one and the same person.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- George B. McClellan will go on the Ways and Means Committee, and the part which he takes in the Cuban reciprocity fight among the Democrats will have all the prestige and influence which comes with that post. He will be in the same position he was in when he led the fight in the Fifty-seventh Congress, with the added prestige resulting from his election as Mayor of New York.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The Court of Appeals sustained the State Railroad Commission in its grantal of the certificate of public convenience under Section 59 of the railroad law to the New York and Port Chester Railway Company. The case is a proceeding in certiorari brought by the New York City and Westchester Railroad against the Railroad Commission.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Distress in the Valiyyet of Monastir is more severe than was generally supposed, says the correspondent of The Times at Sofia. At Rezen there is the utmost misery, and in the western districts of Okhrida conditions are even worse.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- There seems to be a singular want of information at all points to-night on the Isthmus situation. Mr. Hay has had no advices from Mr. Beaupre at Bogota for two days, and is beginning to be suspicious as to the conditions which prevent communication.
BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- An exhibition was opened to-day at the Museum of Industrial Art of the objects presented to Harvard's Germanic Museum as supplemental to Emperor William's gift.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The State Department to-night received a cablegram from Minister Powell at Santo Domingo, dated at 4 P.M. to-day, reporting the situation at Santo Domingo to be extremely serious. The dispatch, it was stated, was the first which the department had received on the day it was filed since the disturbances began.
ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- The Governor to-day appointed Adolph J. Rodenbeck of Rochester as a Judge of the Court of Claims to fill the vacancy caused by the death or Charles T. Saxton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Both the Republican and the Democratic Senators held caucuses this afternoon after the ten-minute session of the Senate, in which no business was done beyond the reading of the President's message on Cuban reciprocity. The Democrats met in Senator Gorman's room and were occupied with arranging among themselves their various committee preferences.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 10. -- Judge Penfield, Solicitor of the United States State Department, continuing his argument to-day before the Venezuelan Arbitration Tribunal, declared that the maxim that war gave preferential rights had long been abandoned, and the American Government was now confident that the decision of the tribunal would be in accordance with the clearest principles of justice and right.

It developed yesterday that the proposed production of Richard Wagner's "Parsifal" at the Metropolitan Opera House has aroused the disapproval of certain clergymen in this city, who, according to the Rev. Dr. George L. Shearer, Secretary of the American Tract Society, have formed themselves into a committee resolved to oppose vigorously the presentation of this opera.
Details will be found on another column relative to the sale of a group of Avenue A tenements by Col. John Jacob Astor.

According to W.D. Sporborg, a lawyer of 69 Wall Street, the private detectives who have been employed to ferret out the mystery of "J. Ogden Goelet, Jr.," are now watching James Abeel, the young Texan named a few days ago as the man who posed as a Goelet and paid court to Eleanor Anderson, telegraph operator in the Grand Hotel.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed the conviction of Al. Adams of New York City, the socalled "Policy King," and he must complete the sentence which he has been serving in Sing Sing Prison since April.

In the trading in curb securities yesterday the only considerable change was the drop of a point in Northern Securities, but the balance of the list was somewhat weak, and a number of fractional declines were made. About 1,000 shares of Greene Consolidated Copper sold at an advance of 1/8, while the rest of the, copper stocks were comparatively quiet.

A notable advance in ship construction is marked by the successful installation in the Deutschland of a series of water-tight, doors between bulkheads, which are opened and closed either automatically or by hydraulic pressure controlled from the bridge, and which when closed are said to render the ship practically unsinkable.

Success for three favorites exactly balanced failure by a similar number of post choices at the Jamaica race track yesterday and left the crowd of "regulars" who made up the attendance in a fairly satisfied frame of mind, though incidents of a nature to ruffle the betting portion of the attendance cropped up in several of the events.

Transactions to almost double the amount of those of Monday were recorded on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but once more it was true that the market was practically confined to a very few stocks, the two most active issues, United States Steel and Pennsylvania, supplying together 518,895 shares out of a total in all stocks of 847,034 shares.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The President to-night had a conference with a number of the leaders in both houses of Congress. Those who called on him at the White House were Secretary Moody, Speaker Cannon, Senators Allison, Aldrich, Platt of Connecticut; Spooner, Hanna, Hale, Lodge, and Wetmore, and Representatives Payne, Dalzeli, Tawney, and Hemenway.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Horace C. Butterworth, physical director of Northwestern University, has tendered his resignation to Dr. O.F. Long, Chairman of the Board of Athletic Control of the university. Mr. Butterworth will not retire at once, but will continue his work during the remainder of the college year.

Park Commissioner Willcox said yesterday that he would go before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on Friday and seek an appropriation of $1,500,000 for the establishment of a great park on the southern end of Staten Island, reaching from the hills to the shore and comprising some 4,000 acres, or four times the size of Central Park.

At a meeting yesterday of the Central Organization of the New York Liquor Dealers Association at Terrace Garden, Fritz Lindinger resigned as President. Martin Kane, who has acted as First Vice President of the association for a number of years was elected President, subject to a final election at the January meeting of the association.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- While the Czar of Russia was at Darmstadt recently a committee of expelled Finns, composed of Count Mannerheim, Eugen Wolff, and the Rev. Magnus Rosendal, the well-known writer and speaker, endeavored to secure an audience with his Majesty for the purpose of presenting a memorial.

The Long Island Kennel Club opened its bench show at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, yesterday, and the exhibition, if not the largest ever held in Brooklyn, is conceded to be one of the most interesting. Nearly 700 canines have been entered for the valuable prizes, and so well did the judges do their work yesterday that two-thirds of the classes were completed and the awards distributed.

That was doubtless a disgusting spectacle which was witnessed in Fifth Avenue yesterday, when some hundreds of curious women engaged in what it is scarcely an exaggeration to call a riot. The authorities were not at all to blame. The police "protection" provided for the wedding seemed to be ample, consisting as it did of more than a hundred policemen.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 10. -- The Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe arrived here at 10:30 o'clock, the steamboat General making a special trip for their accommodation. They are at Ochre Court, where they will remain for a few days.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 10. -- Gov. Toole this afternoon called a special session of the Legislature to meet on Dec. 1 at Helena to pass laws to relieve the industrial condition in Montanu caused by the shutting down of the Amalgamated Copper Company's properties.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The President's message was read in both Houses to-day and was given close attention. It is devoted exclusively to the Cuban reciprocity treaty and the reasons for calling the Congress in extraordinary session are briefly and concisely set forth. The speedy enactment of legislation required to give the treaty effect is earnestly urged.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Representative Littauer of New York to-day renewed his request of President Roosevelt for a reopening of his glove contract case in the Department of Justice. The Attorney General has not seen his way clear to reopen the case in the way Mr. Littauer and his attorney, John G. Milburn of Buffalo, desire.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10. -- The Germanic Museum at Harvard University proposed years ago by eminent German-Americans and fostered by Emperor William of Germany and Prince Henry of Prussia was dedicated to-day. Within the museum are valuable gifts from Emperor William, Prince Henry, and other distinguished Germans.

A new decision on the much disputed question of commissions was handed down yesterday by the Board of United States General Appraisers. It was written by Judge Henderson M. Somerville, and concurred in by General Appraiser Fischer. A lissenting opinion was filed by Judge Byron S. Waite.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Preliminary returns to the Chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the Department of Agriculture on the production of corn in 1903 indicate a total yield of about 2,313,000,000 bushels, or an average of 25.8 bushels per acre, as compared with an average yield of 26.8 bushels one year ago, 16.7 bushels in 1901, and a ten-year average of 23.0 bushels.

To the Hon. George B. McClellan: THE NEW YORK TIMES of to-day, speaking editorially of the latest manifestation of the new and alien spirit of imperialism in this democratic Republic, uttered these inspired words:
A man who has recently arrived from the Isthmus yesterday related a remarkable episode of recent occurrence.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- A bulletin on the condition of Emperor William, issued this morning at the new palace, Potsdam, says there is a slow improvement in the appearance of the left vocal cord and adds that the Emperor to-day resumed his usual morning walk in the park. The bulletin is signed by Drs. von Leuthold, Moritz Schmidt, and Ilberg.

In the accomplishment of the Administration's policy and purposes upon the Isthmus of Panama events move at Washington consistently, logically, and with the smoothness of a perfect piece of machinery. The President and his Cabinet advisers, so far as appears, are of one mind. Senator MORGAN, the inveterate opponent of all our meddling with Panama, is deposed from his Chairmanship of the Senate Committee of Interoceanic Canals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Mrs. Roosevelt left this morning for New York, where she will meet her sister, Misa Carow, on her arrival from Europe. Mrs. Roosevelt and Miss Carow will spend a few days in New York, and will return to Washington on Wednesday of next week.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision which will seriously affect the business of those who loan money without security upon notes of salaried persons at rates of interest above the legal rate of 6 per cent. In the cases of Ella Beebe and Leah Van Linda of New York City, six Judges, Chief Judge Parker alone dissenting, sustain the judgment of the courts below.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A report of an interview in your paper of Monday does me an unintentional injustice and so thoroughly misstates my views in one important particular that I must ask of you the insertion of this denial of a statement made in it. I am reported as saying that "the Russian knows that the only way to save Russia from Jewish domination is to persecute."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- An important conference concerning the Panama situation was held at the White House to-day just prior to the formal meeting of the Cabinet. The participants in the conference were president Roosevelt, Senator Hanna, and members of the Cabinet.

The beet-sugar Senator who could successfully answer the appeal or satisfactorily refute the argument of the President's message asking Congress to ratify the treaty with Cuba would have to be a very skillful and extraordinarily able speaker. The message of Mr. ROOSEVELT is an almost perfect statement of the reasons which should impel Congress to favorable action upon the treaty.

Miss May Goelet, the only daughter of the late Ogden Goelet was married yesterday afternoon to Henry John Innes-Ker, eighth Duke of Roxburghe, in St. Thomas's Church. Fifty-third Street and Fifth Avenue. The ceremony was performed a little before 3 o'clock by Bishop Doane of Albany, and the Rev. Dr. Stires, rector of St. Thomas's.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- A large volume of business was transacted on the Stock Exchange, with the United States Steel issues, Reading common, Pennsylvania, Cambria Steel, and Consolidated Lake Superior common absorbing the bulk of attention. The arbitrage stocks followed New York prices, while the principal locals held about steady, fractional concessions being made in only a few instances.

Yesterday's stock market closed better than was promised by an opening of the recent familiar sort. All the Steels made new low records in the early trading upon a large volume of business. The preferred broke to 50, but the common stuck stubbornly at 10, although it showed no rallying power when the attempt to force it lower was abandoned.

DULUTH, Nov. 10. -- Lake Superior did an unexpectedly large volume of business in October. The traffic of the lake was 4,470,000 tons, making this year to Nov. 31, 370,000 tons. For the same period of 1002 it was 439,000 tons less, and for the corresponding months of 1901 it was 6,837,000 tons smaller than for the present season.
NEWPORT, Nov. 10. -- Dr. and Mrs. Alexander S. Clark, Mr. and Mrs. Victor Sorchan, Frederick Pearson, and Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Dyer. Jr., closed their cottages today and went to New York.

A few days ago word came from Philadelphia that the venerable business house of D. LANDRETH SONS, seedsmen, had assigned. The announcement had unusual interest from the fact that the concern had been continuously in trade for more than a century, haying been founded in 1784; also as raising, on the explanatory statement of counsel, a question of business ethics which concerns every one in productive or distributive industry.

There was a decided falling off in activity in the trading in curb securities yesterday, and only two stocks showed even moderately large transactions. Losses were the rule, and the severest loss of all was that sustained toy Northern Securities. At the opening a number of stocks showed advances, which were afterward lost.

Robert Grau, in a statement sent out yesterday, says that Mme. Patti had nothing whatever to do with the case in which she was served with a subpoena on Saturday. The matter, he says, rests between him and a man who offered to raise for him a large sum of money required for a deposit in London According to Mr. Grau, the sum was not raised as agreed.

FALL RIVER,Nov. 11 -- Notices were, posted in the cotton mills of this city this afternoon announcing a general reduction of 10 per cent. in wages, to take effect Nov. 23. About 30,000 hands are affected.

The demand of the Czech agitators for a larger recognition of their "nationality" in the affairs of the Austro-Hungarian monarchy is evidently natural. It emphasizes the troubles of the monarchy, of which this is only one, and not the most Important.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Dispatches from Minister Beaupre at Bogota state that there is great excitement at Colombia's capital and in some of the interior towns, growing out of dissatisfaction with the Government in failing to ratify the canal treaty and thus precipitating the secession of Panama.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Advices reaching the War Department from Manila indicate that before he sails for the United States on Dec. 23, Gov. Taft will have succeeded in settling one of the most vexatious problems connected with the acquisition of the Philippines -- namely, the adjustment of the claims of the friars for their extensive property holdings in the islands.

Abraham Gruber, Republican leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District, served notice last night that at the next meeting of the Republican County Committee, one week from to-night, he would denounce R. Fulton Cutting for arrogance and treachery in the Mayoralty campaign.

The entire Princeton undergraduate body, headed by a brass band, paraded to 'Varsity Field yesterday afternoon, where they saw the last practice of the team before Saturday's big game with Yale. Spurred on by the inspiring songs and cheers of the students the team played such a fierce game that the strongest scrub eleven could do absolutely nothing against them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Russian Ambassador and Countess Marguerite Cassini, who arrived from Europe yesterday, are now at the embassy in Rhode Island Avenue.

NEWPORT, Nov. 11 -- Reginald C. Vanderbilt has sent a string of horses to New york to be exhibited in the New York Horse Show, which opens at Madison Square Garden next Monday. Among them are White Oak Maid, Muzette and Iris which have won many prizes for Mr. Vanderbilt; Impudence, and Astonishment and Surprise.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- Pennsylvania Railroad stock was forced down from 57 1/2 to 56 to-day, that being the lowest price the shares has sold at since 1898, when it when it went to 55 3/8. The slump was expected in the financial district. New York made enormous sales, nearly 300,000 shares changing hands during the day.

Any one who studies the provisions of the reciprocity treaty with Cuba, to which Congress is now summoned to give force by the necessary legislation, must toe struck by the extremely moderate character of the concessions made by the United States compared to the much more liberal terms accorded by Cuba.
SANTO DOMINGO, Tuesday, Nov. 10 -- The city is closely besieged by the revolutionists and commerce is paralyzed.

NEWPORT, Nov. 11 -- The Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe spent the day quietly at Ochre Court, receiving hosts of cablegrams and telegrams of congratulation, and in the afternoon taking an automobile drive on Bellevue Avenue and out on the island. They dined alone this evening.

The statement put forth by Secretary HAY on Nov. 6, explaining and attempting to justify the action of the President toward the insurrection upon the Isthmus of Panama, contained this recital of the causes and the course of the uprising:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 11 -- William Anderson, or a man who said he was that person, accompanied by a second one. who he said was his counsel, came down on the early morning train to-day to see Miss Eleanor Anderson, in the barricaded house of the McIntosh family at East Long Branch.

The Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum has added to its property at Fordham Heights by the purchase of a tract of about forty-five lots at Tee Taw Avenue and East One Hundred and Ninetieth Street. The lots are a part of the Moses Devoe estate's holdings, and were to have been sold at auction yesterday.

Stocks unsettled. Call money, 3 1/2@5 1/2 per cent. There are several notable characteristics of the current stock market. One is the strong contrast with the recent period when there was no news but stocks were simply sold for what they would bring by people who had to have money, whatever it cost.

One of the closest bowling games of the season was rolled last night in the American National tournament when the Roseville team defeated the Corinthians by a single pin, the respective scores being 933 and 932. In Columbia tourney Daly of the Linwood team rolled 267, the highest mark reached so far in this season's contest on Schlusing's alleys.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- The financial situation was disturbed to-day by the weakness in Pennsylvania, which was ascribed to the operations of "a Philadelphia bear pool" in the stock. Inquiry among all the important houses here could not have this report confirmed and it was openly asserted that if there was any selling by Philadelphia it was the execution of orders received from New York.

The first strike of importance ordered by the bricklayers unions for the last twenty years went into effect yesterday on all the contracts of the George A. Fuller Company. About 1,000 bricklayers are said to be out, but this will affect the laborers and a number of other trades, and in a few days it is expected to render several thousand persons idle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The tidal wave of protest against Senator Smoot of Utah made its appearance in the Senate to-day, when several Senators presented petitions asking that that good faith of the Mormon Church be inquired into in connection with the consideration of the Utah Senator's right to a seat.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- The formal welcome to Charles Sanger Mellen on his return to New Haven, his former home, as the President of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, was in the nature of a banquet tendered by the Chamber of Commerce to-night, affording an opportunity for nearly 300 business men to meet him.

It would be interesting to know just what The London Mail meant when, in commenting on the Roxburghe-Goelet wedding, it said: "The Duke of ROXBURGHE, with his simple English bringing up, makes an odd figure in the crowd, almost, a pathetic one, lacking even the reassuring consciousness of ante-nuptial settlements."
ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- The annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Albany is in session to-day at All Saint Cathedral.

Official announcement was made late yesterday afternoon of the result of the conferences of the various steel pools, so called, which have been meeting in this city during the last few days in an effort to arrange a new price schedule on steel products. The announcement was made on behalf of the steel manufacturers by Willis H. King, Vice President of the Jones Laughlin Steel Company of Pittsburg.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Although it is certain that if the beet-sugar Republicans should stand together as they did a year ago, they could, with Democratic help. pass the amendment repealing the differential on refined sugar, so many of them have surrendered to the White House that the Cuban Reciprocity bill probably will have plain sailing.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The Sofia correspondent of The Times says the Austro-Russian communication to the Porte insisting that the reform scheme for Macedonia be accepted in its entirety has not been modified, and makes a categorical reply accepting or rejecting the scheme in toto inevitable, though efforts may be made at a later stage to attenuate the various provisions.
BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- The money market shows increased firmness, and local rates are now about the same as those prevailing in New York.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 11 -- A claim in favor of the Importers and Tradesmen's National Bank of New York against the estate of Sturgis Whitlock of Fairfield was filed to-day, and it is asserted that this transaction grows out of the collapse of the United States Shipbuilding Company.
DULUTH, Nov. 11 -- Wheat -- To arrive, No. 1 hard,:78 3/5; No. 1 Northern, 77 1/3c; No. 2 Northern, 74 5/8; December, 74 1/3c; May, 76 3/8@76 1/2c.

"When I return I shall take up the fight for the Democratic Party on the same lines on which I have fought during the past several years, but I shall not be a candidate for renomination," was part of the statement made by William Jennings Bryan on the steamship Majestic yesterday, just before he sailed for a six weeks' visit to Europe.

"Coffee had the peculiar effect on me of thickening the blood and lessening it in quality, in other words drying it up," says a young lady of Shelton, Neb., "and so long as I used the drug, coffee, I had terrific headaches, frequently accompanied by sour stomach and a very bad breath.

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 11 -- The depression in the sailing shipping trade is so serious as to have led to a drastic proposal on the part of Liverpool owners for an international combination whereby a certain proportion of the sailing tonnags of Great Britain, France, and Germany should temporarily be laid up, with the view of improving the freight market.

United States General Appraiser Fischer yesterday handed down a decision as to countervailing duties on imported goods. The merchandise in question was paraffine imported by Muller, Sehall Co. of New York. Some of it was manufactured in Germany from petroleum of Russian origin, both of which countries impose import duties on American petroleum, and some was manufactured in Belgium from Russian petroleum, Belgium imposing no import duty.

For the first time in many days Wall Street gave more attention to some other stock than to United States Steels. These issues were relatively strong yesterday, but the trading in them fell off to such an extent that although still large they represented a relatively small proportion of the total.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- The most sensational athletic news that has been announced at the University of Pennsylvania for a long time was given out to-night by the Football Committee, which declared in an official statement that A.L. Smith, the big full back, has been declared ineligible for the remainder of the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A dispatch from Honolulu to The Evening Star of this city gives a curious insight into Hawaiian politics. Referring to the death of Robert W. Wilcox, the Hawaiian Delegate to the Fifty-seventh Congress, and the leader of the Home Rule Party, the dispatch says:
BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- Prices on the Boerse to-day were weaker. Iron shares broke upon large selling orders from the Rhine country. Canadian Pacific was lower.

Several persons interested in one way or another in Wagner's "Parsifal" were willing yesterday to discuss, the attack which has been made upon that opera by the Rev. Dr. George L. Shearer, the Rev. Dr. David J. Burrell, and other clergymen in this city, who regard its production on a public stage as a mockery of Christian ideals.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Reports from the centres of the cotton mill industry throughout New England indicate that to-day's announcement at Fall River that a 10 per cent. reduction in wages had been decided upon by the cotton manufacturers there, to go into effect Nov. 23, has caused general uneasiness, due to the belief that an equal reduction at other places is inevitable.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 11 -- Mrs. Evelyn W. Murray, owner and occupant of the old Snyder Frelinghuysen farm on the road from Somervilla to South Branch, is disposing of the live stock on the farm by having it put to death, although the stock is in the best of health.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- Gov. Odell when informed of the suicide of Gen. Hughes expressed great regret. It will be necessary for the Governor to call a special election for member of the Assembly to succeed Gen. Hughes.

The Rev. G. Campbell Morgan, who will take up the evangelical work in which Dwight L. Moody was engaged for so many years, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Oceanic from Liverpool. Mr. Morgan will make his headquarters at Northfield, the old home of Moody, and will there carry on the main part of his work.

Daniel Leroy Dresser's testimony was continued again yesterday at the hearing of the Dresser Co. creditors, in which J. Aspinwall Hodge, as counsel for the trustee, E.V. Whitney, is trying to ascertain what are the assets of the failed firm. Mr. Hodge largely confined his questioning to the disposition of the shipbuilding stock in the possession pf the Dresser firm at various times.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- An explosion of dynamite late last night wrecked the house at 735 Wood Street and seriously burned James Patton, aged thirty-one years, of St. Mary's, Elk County Penn. Ten other inmates of the lodging house became panic-stricken and ran into the street in their night clothes.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- One of the greatest triumphs of dirigible ballooning was achieved to-day, when the Lebaudy brothers' airship in 1 hour and 41 minutes covered the forty-six miles separating Moisson and the Champ de Mars, Paris. The balloon attained an extraordinarily high speed, dashing through the air sometimes at the rate of two-thirds of a mile a minute, the mean speed being twenty-nine miles an hour.

Mr. SAMUEL GOMPERS in his address as President at the Boston meeting of the National Federation of labor announced the position of organized labor as to wages during possible industrial depression as follows:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your Knickerbocker correspondent, who is evidently a member of the Cetacean Trust, is off his base.

BOSTON, Nov. 12. -- President Roosevelt's name and his action in the so-called Miller open shop case were brought before the convention of the American Federation of Labor to-day, when several delegates criticised his decision not to act against non-union labor in Federal employment.

The Clyde Line steamship Cherokee, which on her last trip to Santo Domingo became tarried in the meshes of the Santo Domingan revolution, arrived here yesterday with the story of her troubles, and is now docked under the Brooklyn Bridge on the Manhattan side. Secretary of State Hay and United States Minister Powell also were drawn into the mess, and with their assistance Capt. Daniel Archibald and the Cherokee came out on top.

Final practice of the college football teams for the big games to-morrow, and the last practice of the season for two of the leading elevens, Columbia and Princeton, was held yesterday on the several training grounds, but in each case the work of the day was confined to light exercise and signal practice.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Six persons were injured at the Ogden Street crossing of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad here this afternoon when a switch engine weighing 110 tons broke through the structure and tumbled twenty, feet into the street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission's independent inquiry into the reasonablenss of freight rates fixed by ten railroads running between St. Louis and Texas common points came to a temporary stop to-day, owing to the suggestion of Commissioner Prouty that a bill in equity might be filled against the defendants if it were shown by the evidence that they had made an illegal agrreement in bringing about the advance.

In the matter of excitement the racing at the Jamaica track yesterday paid big returns for the price of admission, but as the regulars who made up the attendance were there for things other than amusement the afternoon proved rather disappointing, in spite of the head finishes, unexpected happenings, and a fight in the betting ring thrown in for good measure.
ROME, Nov. 12 -- Pope Pius X. held his first public Consistory to-day. Five Cardinals, including the Papal Secretary of State, Merry del Val, received their Red Hats.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- Regarding the condition of Emperor William the following bulletin was issued this morning at the New Palace, Potsdam:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Somehow I missed the interview in THE TIMES with Bishop Grafton, but nevertheless I would like to express to him my thanks for the noble spirit which animates his letter. There can be no doubt that the " crafty, wealth-getting spirit of Jacob " is abroad in Russia; and that, at bottom, this is the cause of all the Jewish suffering in Russia.
CHESTER, Penn., Nov. 12 -- The announcement was made to-day by the Crozer family of Upland of the marriage in Paris of Mrs. Samuel A. Crozer, Jr. to Viscount Maurice Guillauine.

There is practically nothing on the tapis socially in town to-day, but this evening Mrs. Astor will give a dinner for the Dowager Duchess of Roxburghe and her daughter, Lady Isabel Innes-Ker. Tomorrow, there will be two important weddings -- that of Miss Fanshawe and L.L. White in Trinity Chapel; and that of Miss Carlie M. Schenck and Dr. Daniel W. Wynkoop in Grace Church Chantry.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 12 -- While a small party composed of intimate friends of the family was being entertained at dinner at the cottage of Edward De Witt Walsh, a New York broker, last night, Mrs. Wanc De Grier Walsh, his wife, who had done the honours as hostess during the evening committed suicide by sending a bullet through her heart.
