WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs decided to-day to open the door wide to the charges that E.G. Rathbone, formerly Director of Posts for Cuba, desires to present against Gen. Leonard Wood. The committee will receive at the meeting next Thursday all comers who want to make charges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The National Sociological Society to consider the race problem which has been in session here since last Monday, and which has been attended by students of the problem from different parts ou the country, closed its sessions to-day by the adoption of a series of resolutions on the subject.

A concert was given in Carnegie, Hall last evening by Mr. Edwin Grasse that exhibited an altogether remarkable musical talent in a fashion to secure the instant enthusiasm of a very large audience. There was an eager friendliness in the greeting it gave the concert-giver; but he soon furnished abundant reason to admire his accomplishments upon purely impersonal grounds.

It is at once interesting and pathetic to see how completely helpless, in the grasp of his bureaucracy, is the nominal " Autocrat of all the Russias." He has managed to make it manifest that he is a perfectly well-meaning man, that he desires peace with all the world, and particularly that he desires the advancement in civilization, including political civilization, of his own people.

COLON, Nov. 12 -- The Royal Mail steamer Orinoco arrived here this morning bringing news of Gen. Torres and the Colombian troops she took from here after the proclamation of the Republic of Panama. The soldiers behaved well on the voyage.

Engagements of gold for import amounting to $2,250,000 were announced yesterday, making the total secured on the present movement $5,700,000, all of which has been supplied by the London market. The engagements announced yesterday were for the most part secured from the Bank of England, as had been the previous day's engagement by the National City Bank.

Among cotton cloth, and especially print, manufacturers and the selling agencies, the wage reduction at Fall River is regarded as an important step toward restoring conditions to a basis where business may again be carried on with some profit. All are awaiting the decision of the labor unions.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 12 -- In conformity with the wishes expressed by the Holy Father, Pius X., Cardinal Gibbons has ordered a collection for the Catholic University to be taken up in all the churches of his archdiocese on the first Sunday of Advent, Nov. 29. 1903. It is believed that similar letters will be issued by the other Bishops of the United States to the faithful of their diocese.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The great question that is just now agitating the public mind is, " Since when has secession entered into the hearts of the officials at Washington that they aid and abet-not to say concoct and plan -- the seceding of the Province of Panama from the mother country?
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 12 -- A fire broke out on the torpedo destroyer Lawrence tonight, which barely missed the magazine. The boat was moored in the midst of the flotilla.

Several more witnesses appeared yesterday at the hearing of the Dresser Co. creditors in the office of Referee in Bankruptcy Stanley W. Dexter, at 71 Broadway, and testified that Milton C. Quimby, promoter of the realty company that was to tide D. Le Roy.Dresser over his difficulties by depositing $850,000 worth of worthless securities, had declared Mr. Dresser's sisters to be behind the scheme. Then Quimby was recalled to the stand.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12.--Whatever may be the ultimate outcome of the Isthmian complications, it is evident the canal has received a serious setback, and its construction is likely to be delayed.

Stocks weak. Call money, 2 1/2@5 1/2 per cent. Yesterday's stock market offered few features which distinguish it from its disheartening predecessors, or promise improvement. The main feature was general weakness, stimulated by especial weakness in Pennsylvania. It is now yielding about 5 per cent., and is selling at the price level prevailing when it was paying 5 per cent., and below its price much of the time on that dividend basis.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 12 -- Two clearly expressed explanations of the conditions that are confronting the steel trade of this country, the one affecting the current prices and the other the more serious question of wage reductions, were made to-day by one of the high officials of the Jones Laughlin Steel Company.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Capt. K.W. Woodward of the Cornell's cross country team to-night announced that the team which will represent Cornell in its dual meet with the University of Pennsylvania at Ithaca to-morrow will be composed of W.E. Schutt, D.C. Munson, E.T. Newman, C.F. Magoffin, T.M. Foster, B. Smith, and K.W. Woodward. The distance run wil be five miles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not feel that I am a" croaker " or a " pessimist," and I imagine that I have plenty of 'company who know that, as individuals and as business corporations, we have been going "too fast," and that vast numbers are now being "brought up with a round turn" because they would not " put on the brakes."

ALBANY, N.Y.. Nov. 12. -- Gov. Odell this evening appointed Deputy Controller Otto Kelsey to be Controller in place of Nathan L. Miller, recently, appointed Justice of the Supreme Court. The appointment is for the balance of the term ending Dec. 31, 1904, The salary of the office Js $6000 a year.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 12.--The officials of the textile unions have already prepared to bring the question of the acceptance or resistance of the 10 per cent, reduction before the members, and to this end the Textile Council, which is composed of three delegates each from the Spinners, Carders'. Loom Fixers', and Slasher Tenders Unions will meet Saturday evening at 7 o'clock.

Certainly nobody ought to complain that Mr. W.J. BRYAN has gone to Europe. It would have done him no harm if he had gone earlier. That naval officer was not altogether without reason who advocated an amendment to the Constitution providing, as an additional qualification for members of Congress, that before entering upon their duties they should spend at least a year abroad.

The management of the American Malting Company was indorsed at a stormy meeting of the stockholders in Jersey City yesterday by a vote of 155,000 shares to 103,000. The meeting had been marked for a final trial of strength in the contest which has been waging between the two parties for more than two years past.
The annual report of the Rutland Railroad for the year ended June 30 last was issued yesterday. It shows the following statement of earnings and expenses:

RIGHT TO SHOW HOSTILITY OF WITNESS -- On the trial of an action brought by Leander Brink against William D. Stratton and Horace W. Corey and others to recover on a promissory note, several witnesses gave testimony tending to impeach the character of the defendant Corey for truth and veracity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Senator Allison to-day appointed the following committee to reorganize the committees of the Senate: Hale, Chairman; Gallinger, Hansbrough, Burrows, Foraker, Penrose, Foster, (Wash.,) Quarles, and Scott.

Supreme Court Judge Keogh yesterday decided in favor of Mary Burke in her suit against the City of New York and sixty-three firemen to recover the amount assigned to her brother, the late Thomas P. Burke, a, lawyer, by the firemen.

Yesterday the trading in curb securities was somewhat broader than on any day this week, but American Can stocks were the only ones on which particular interest was centred, owing to their activity. The market appears to hold relatively firm around prices now prevailing. This was shown in the trading in Northern Securities, which advanced a point, notwithstanding the heavy selling of the stock on Wednesday.

BOSTON, Nov. 12. -- The Castle Square Theatre management gave away a $1,500 grand piano to one of the patrons to-night for making the most, accurate guess as to the total attendance of the last month. The attendance was 81,152, and the winner guessed 81,153. The attendance was 78 9-10 per cent of the capacity.

-- Whenever anybody -- say a newspaper person who occasionally finds the seat of the scorner an interesting, if not exactly a comfortable, resting-place for his weary bones-ventures a few derisive words about the Society for Psychical Research, he invariably draws upon himself a bruising shower of names belonging to men variously great who are or have been connected with it either as officers or members.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- The money market continues very firm, with business extremely quiet. The demand both from speculative and from mercantile sources is very moderate. Call loans, 5@6 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 6@6 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5@6 per cent.; New York funds, 5c premium; clearings, $23,101,646; balances, $1,021,355.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y. 12. -- William Shiells, a special Deputy Sheriff of Sullivan County, employed on the 18,000 game preserve of Chester W. Chapin of New York City, was-seriously shot yesterday by one of a party of three hunte'rs whom he was trying to arrest.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The Senate was crowded to-day owing to expectation that Premier Combes would make a declaration as to the further purposes of the Government concerning the religious orders.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 12. -- The handicap at a mile and an eighth was the star event of the day at Latonia, and was won by Reservation, the favorite. Bardolph surprised the handicappers by securing the place at 15 to 1. Thane, backed from 2 to 1 to 9 to 5, was not in the money. John Yerkes was run up from $5OO to $900 in the first race, but was retained by his owner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The Democratic attitude on the Cuban bill, as well as its general policy on public questions, is to be the subject of a caucus of the minority members of the House Saturday night. A meeting of the minority members of the Ways and Means Committee was held to-night for the purpose of outlining several amendments to the Cuban bill.
ALBANY, Nov. 12. -- Certificates of election expenses filed to-day with the Secretary of State include these:

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Money was wanted in the market to-day, owing to its being Stock Exchange pay day, but rates eased when it was announced that the Bank of England's rate of discount was unchanged. Discounts were slightly easier, though there were further withdrawals of gold from the Bank of England for America in addition to yesterday's $750,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- The local market persistently refused to become demoralized to-day. Prices ruled lower for the general list, but Electric Storage Battery was up 1, United Companies of New Jersey 1, while United Traction, Philadelphia Electric, Philadelphia Company, and Lehigh Valley held their own, no pressure being exerted against them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- An informal report received at the State Department from Charles Pepper, Special Railroad Commissioner of the United States, dated at Lima, Peru, Oct. 17, states that the project for an intercontinental railway is growing in importance every day.

Mr. Edward Kemeys is at work in Washington, D.C., on a series of groups depicting wild beasts in conflict. His latest design, enters the realm of goblinry and witchcraft. It is a struggle between a wolf and the uncanny creature which is wolf by night and man by day, the werewolf of folklore, who is still feared among the peasants of Eastern Europe and Western Asia.

BOSTON, Nov. 12. -- At the dinner of the Economic Club to-night the topic was The New Forms of, Arbitration Between Organizations of Employers and Trades Unions, and the principal speakers Were John Mitchell, President of the United Mine Workers of America; John Graham Brooks, the writer on economic subjects, and President John F. Tobin of the Boot and Shoe Workers' Union.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial which appeared in last Sunday's TIMES you allude to the students of Trinity College, Dublin, painting the statue of King George, opposite the college gates, green.
Five customs decisions by Judge Townsend of the United States Circuit Court were filed yesterday, and in each case the Board of United Stales General Appraisers was reversed.

We await with interest, and almost with impatience, the issue of the State paper in which Secretary HAY will defend the recognition of the independence of Panama to be accorded by the President to-day, when he receives Mr. BUNAU -VARILLA as the Minister Plenipotentiary and Envoy Extraordinary of that republic.
By the accidental explosion of a bottle of magnesium powder, Thomas W. Taylor, a photographer, in Brooklyn, had his right hand blown off at the wrist yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Constant scenes of disorder over a district approximately fifty square miles in extent resulted to-day from a strike by the employes of one of the two principal surface street railway companies in Chicago. All along the lines wherever cars were started strike sympathizers made desperate onslaughts on the crews, beginning at dawn of day and continuing as long as cars remained on the tracks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Brig. Gen. William Crozier, Chief of Ordnance, hag submitted his annual report to the Chief of Staff of the Army.

The-three passages selected for our present consideration, although not closely connected as they stand in the Scriptures, all bring before us in a very striking and connected way the sin of intemperance. They declare concerning it a great fact, a wise admonition, and a simple remedy.
LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The Sofia correspondent of The Times says the journal Otzix publishes strange revelations in regard to the relations of the late Zankovist Ministry and Russia.

When District Attorney Jerome entered the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night 350 members of the Delta Upsilon fraternity, dining there in their sixty-ninth annual convention banquet, jumped to their feet and gave him a welcome after the fashion of college boys that made the walls ring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- As a result of the many conferences that have been going on in Administration circles during the week and after a thorough discussion of the whole matter in the Cabinet to-day, it has been decided that it shall be the policy of the Administration to hold that the President has full powers under existing law to negotiate a treaty with the Republic of Panama.

WILLIAM ROSCOE THAYER, author of "The Dawn of Italian Independence" and editor of The Harvard Graduates' Magazine, has begun to prepare for publication the letters of the late John Fiske, and asks persons owning letters written by the distinguished historian either to lend him the originals or to send copies to him at S Berkeley Street, Cambridge, Mass.

In "Gallops 2" David Gray has introduced a number of well-bred, wealthy persons, fond of horseflesh and good judges of thoroughbreds. In a scries of seven short stories he has told some interesting and entertaining things. The book is similar in character and tone to a former volume by Mr. Gray, henceforth to be called "Gallops 1" to distinguish it from the present collection.

Some two years since a committee was appointed by the American Unitarian Association at its annual meeting "to consider and report upon the condition and progress of unsectarian education in American schools, academies, and colleges," and this book in due time resulted from that action.

PANAMA, Nov. 13. -- Jose Augustin Arango, President of the Junta, on receiving the news of President Roosevelt's reception of M. Philippe Bunau-Varilla as Minister of the Republic of Panama, expressed great gratification, saying that this act of President Roosevelt made possible the negotiation of a canal treaty, and that such negotiation would probably be completed before the Panamanians held a convention to elect a Legislature and adopt a constitution.

NCHANTED gardens are they which surround the chateaus of the Bourbons. Elizabeth W. Champney has strolled through them "until the mossy statues have whispered to her the secrets hidden in the charming bosquets."
BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- The Frankfurter Zeitung prints the following details of the operation on the Emperor, obtained apparently from Dr. Schmidt, who is a citizen of Frankfort:

HIS fat volume by the author of "The True Thomas Jefferson" contains a vast quantity of miscellaneous information, ranging from gossip to statistics with numerous interesting photographs -- all the result of travel during the Summer of 1901 in Denmark and the rest of Scandinavia.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13. -- The feature of to-day's trading was the comparative activity of Seaboard Air Lines securities, affected by the movement in New York. The preferred gained 2 points over the prices of the preceding day and the common showed an advance of 1 1/4 points over the last preceding sale, though it lost a fraction of the gain at the closing.

The trading in curb securities yesterday was just as diversified as on Thursday, but there was less activity displayed and substantial losses were recorded. Standard Oil declined 5 1/4 and Tennessee Copper sold at 28, but these losses were more than offset by the advances in Seaboard Air Line, Interborough Rapid Transit, Greene Consolidated Copper, and Hackensack Meadows, which sold from 10 3/4 to 13, with a reaction to 12, an advance of 1 3/4.

It is a horrid mockery of all that is worthy and noble in human life that a career so distinguished and beneficent as that of Mr. ANDREW H. GREEN should be ended by the bullet of an ignoble assassin. For him, in the deepest and sincerest sense, the whole city will mourn. We called the late Mr. HEWITT our first citizen.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Frank Glasser, foreman on the grounds of the Pelham Manor Golf Club, was inspecting the golf links this afternoon, and when near the Hunter Island Inn heard shooting in Golf Club woods.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Locally there was liberal trading again in Can stocks. Some 2,000 shares of common changed hands again early around 3, while a fairly good business was done in the preferred at steady prices. Boxboard preferred was fairly active. Recently there has developed adverse criticism to the project of the new selling company of Boxboard.

A good deal of unnecessary apprehension was excited by the announcement that Judge AUTEN of Pennsylvania, in hearing an appeal from a court below, had rendered a decision to the effect that the award of the Anthracite Strike Commission was without force, and binding upon neither the operators nor the miners.

The crisis in the steel situation being over, the United States Steel Corporation's officials are devoting their attention to the proposed reduction in wages. In this connection it became known yesterday that representatives of the steelworkers of several of the mills which hate been shut down for some time have made a proposition to the Steel Corporation by which they would accept a reduction in wages provided the mills be started up again.
In its weekly review of trade conditions Dun's Review says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The Ways and Means Committee to-day reported the Cuban Reciprocity bill. The vote in committee on the bill was 14 to 2 for a favorable report Mr. Metcalf (Rep., Cal.,) was present, but did not vote, and Messrs. Robertson (Dem., La.,) and Cooper (Dem., Texas,) voted against the bill.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The bridging of the gap between "Mother Goose" and Dickens, so airily brushed aside by "A Reader" in last week's issue, is of greater moment than casually appears. Because there is no evident superficial evil arising from, the liberty allowed the youth of to-day in the selection of books for themselves is no assurance that harm is not being done.

CHICAGO. Nov. 13 -- Twenty-five cars, run on the Wentworth Avenue line, without damage to the cars or injury to the non-union employes operating, them, was what the Chicago City Railway Company was able to accomplish to-day with the assistance of the Police Department, despite the sympathetic, strike of firemen.
ROSELLE PARK, N.J., Nov. 13. -- Miss Hazel Van Der Hoef of Roselle Park is under the care of physicians at her home, suffering from wounds inflicted yesterday by a savage bulldog.

COLON, Nov. 13. -- Cutters from the American warships here were dispatched this morning to stop the German steamer Markomannia, which was seen two miles off towing a gasoline launch toward the harbor. It was thought that the Markomannia was coming from a Colombian port, but it appears that she had been chartered at Bocas del Toro to bring the Alcalde of that port to Colon.

BOSTON, Nov. 13. -- The money market is quiet, with rates practically unchanged. The engagements of gold for import have, however, caused a slightly easier feeling. Call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent. Time loans, collateral, 5@6 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 6 1/2 per cent. Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The rates for money were easier in the market to-day, but there was less demand owing to the Stock Exchange requirements being satisfied. The supply, however, was not large. Discounts were unsettled. New York's inquiry for gold was less pronounced in consequence of the slight recovery in the rate of exchange.

Andrew H. Green, the "Father of Greater New York," was shot and kilted in front of his home, at 91 Park Avenue, between Thirty ninth and Fortieth Streets, yesterday, at 1:35 o'clock, by a negro, Cornelius M. Williams. It is believed that the murderer is insane.

Fred Taral, Henry Spencer, and Eugene Snedeker, American jockeys, who have been riding in Europe for the past six months, returned to this country yesterday on the steamship Furst Bismarck of the Hamburg-American Line. Taral had his wife and son with him. Speneor also was accompanied by his wife.

The vanguard of the Yale-Princeton football enthusiasts began to arrive in New Haven yesterday, and last night the streets were crowded with groups or cheering and singing graduates of the two universities. Passengers arriving by train to-day will have no difficulty in getting to the game. Cars will run under fifteen seconds' headway from the New Haven station to the campus and to Yale Field.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13. -- When the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union Convention opened to-day at the Ninth Street Baptist Church there was a noticeable absence of that interchange of amenities between the Mayor and the National officers which is a customary order of business at conventions.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- William Ogden Green, 386 Ontario Street, connected with the real estate trust firm of Ogden. Sheldon Co., is a nephew of Andrew H. Green. He left for New York this evening.
In a publishers' note at the beginning of this book it is stated, that the volume "was due, as many books are, to the instigation of the publisher," and it is added:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Representative Livernash of California, a new member, made an effort in the House this afternoon to bring on a skirmish over Panama, but was knocked out before he could bring himself into earnest action.

"The High History of the Holy Graal," translated from the old French by Sebastian Evans, LL. D., is published here by E. P. Dutton Co. This version is translated from the first volume of "Perceval le Gallois ou le conte du Graul," edited by M.C. Potvin for La Societe des Bibliophiles Beiges, in 1860, from a manuscript in the library of the Dukes of Burgundy at Brussels.

The second volume of Mr. Stanwood's "American Tariff Controversies" continues the discussion of tariff legislation down to the act of 1897. The tariff of 1842, the author observes. "was a good revenue law, as well as a good protective measure." His handling of the Tariff act of 1846 shows more partisanship than any preceding part of his work.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- The Cornell cross-country team won a decisive victory of the University of Pennsylvania runners here to-day by a score of 10 to 37, over the Renwick course of four and one-half miles. The Quakers were entirely outclassed, as six of the Ithacans finished before a single opponent crossed the tape.

United States General Appraiser Fischer handed down a decision yesterday on the classification of pocket memorandum books, slate books, memorandum books wlth a small, mirror and a pencil attached, and lithographically printed religious pictures in metal frames, all imported by B. Ilifelder Co.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 13. -- The Fidelity and Title Trust Company, one of the chain of banks promoted by Leonard imboden, will resume its regular functions as a banking house next Monday, after passing through a period of four months under an injunction prohibiting the paying out of any money.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- New York has three candidates for the place on the Ways and Means Committee shortly to be left vacant by Col. McClellan's resignation, or the new place which is expected will be created. They are William Sulzer, Townsend Scudder, and William R. Hearst.

Before seven weeks have passed, if Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons's calculations are correct, an experimental train will be run in the Rapid Transit Subway between City Hall and One Hundred and Fourth Street, or possibly as far north as One Hundred and Fiftieth Street and Broadway.

The wars or nations, the intrigues state, soft words of love, and with all, the song of the sword, and you have the ingredients of Harris Dickson's "She That Hesitate?." Peter the Great, mighty and cruel, but showing his best and tenderer side in the story, makes the background of royalty.

In connection with the strike of the street-car employes in Chicago we have an instructive illustration of the way in which disorder and crime are employed to terrorize employers. So far as the records show, the strikers are not committing any crimes against life, property, or the public peace.

BRISTOL, England, Nov. 13. -- Premier Balfour was the principal speaker at a dinner here to-night In celebration of the anniversary of the birth of Edward Colston, the eighteenth century philanthropist. He devoted himself principally to the fiscal question, but did not advance any new arguments.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Nov. 13. -- The mail steamer which has just returned here form Labrador brings no news of the expedition to explore the interior of Labrador, headed by Leonidas Hubbard,. Jr., of New York, which staffed from Rigolet, Labrador, on Aug. 1. All the settlers believe the party perished.

For the last day but one of the gracing season the New York tracks the results at the Jamaica course yesterday were so gratifying that the "regulars," who were out in full force, grew almost sentimental over the delightful weather and the fact that in spite of the favorable conditions presented by the Indian Summer, the turf year must end to-day, according to law.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Gottieb Hansacker and Walter Gettell were arrested shortly after last midnight and subsequently identified as being two of the party of three hunters who shot Deputy Sheriff William Shiells on the game preserve of Chester W. Chapin of New York, in Sullivan County, Thursday afternoon while he was arresting them for killing a deer.

BOSTON, Nov. 13. -- A mass of resolutions was delivered to the Secretary of the American Federation of Labor to-day, and in order that the various committees might consider them the convention was adjourned until to-morrow one hour alter the delegates had assembled. The business of the convention was in grave danger of being seriously blocked by the resolutions, which numbered 281.

"An Indictment of the British Monarchy," by an "Anglo-American," In the current number of The North American Review, has the merit of being a readable article. It involves a very good account of the surface facts of modern English life, and its accusations of incompetence against the royal family will anger nobody who reads it.

Mr. Garland's story is romance of a fascinating sort, but hardly a presentation of cold, hard facts, and not, by any means, to be taken as a leaf out of the every-day life in a Rocky Mountain mining town. It bears about the same relation to the pursuit of the miner that "The Virginian" does to that of the cowboy.
Albert Grenz will not be three years old until Jan. 17, but he has crossed the new Williamsburg Bridge, according to his story of his adventures.

ST. PETERSBURG. Nov. 13 -- There is much satisfaction here at the results of the Czer's visit abroad, it is believed that a complete understanding was reached with Germany and France regarding the Near and Far East, making for peace and rendering Russia's roar secure in the event of future hostilities with Japan.

J.F. Taylor Co. have lust published four new volumes in their Library Edition of the novels, poems, and memoires of Charles Kingsley. They are "Hypatin," "Yeast," and the "Poems." The editions of Kingsley's writings will be complete in fourteen volumes, arranged as follows: "Hereward the Wake," two volumes; "Alton Locke," two volumes; "Westward Ho!" two volumes; "Yeast," one volume.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13. -- The messenger boys of the Harvard Square office or the Western Union Telegraph Company have struck and girls are employed to deliver telegrams.

Stocks rally sharply. Call money easier, 4@5 per cent. Yesterday's stock market showed characteristics resembling the earlier days of the week, but differing much in details. St. Paul was attacked and Pennsylvania was covered, just as Pennsylvania, was attacked and Steel was covered on the day before.

As Mr. Egerton R. Williams, Jr., says in his "Hill Towns of Italy," (12mo pp. 398, illustrated, Houghton, Mifflin Co., in box, $3 net.) Central Italy is most Interesting. It includes not only Rome, on her seven hills, and Florence, but also "that wonderful region of mountains extending between those cities for 150 miles, reaching from the Mediterranean to the Adriatic."

Decrease in Transactions. -- Yesterday's market showed considerable reduction in activity the total in all stocks being about 580,000 shares, as compared with 768,141 shares on Thursday. Pennsylvania, still the leader in activity, also showed much smaller transactions, though yesterday's trading still amounted to a very large total, 166,360 shares.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- President Roosevelt to-day formally received M. Philippe Bunau-Varilla, the duly accredited Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of Panama to the United States. The reception of the Minister marked the birth of the new Republic of Panama into the family of nations and paves the way for negotiations between the United States and the infant republic precisely as they may be conducted between any two sovereign nations.

FALL RIVER. Mass., Nov. 13. -- Sales in the print cloth market for the week will reach a total of about 250,000 pieces, composed of a fair amount of regulars, wide and narrow odds, with deliveries extending up to the 1st of April.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- Of the 24,247 shares of stock dealt in on the local Exchange to-day no less than 19,428 were contributed by Reading, Pennsylvania, and the United States Steels, the first-named selling to the extent of over 10,000 shares. Business was almost at a standstill aside from the operations of the arbitrages and room traders.

A RADCLYFFE DUGMORE, the well-known artist-naturalist and sportsman, whose pictures of outdoor life have been appearing in Country Life in America and The World's Work, has made arrangements with Doubleday, Page Co. to continue with his services in the interests of these magazines.

The State Historian, Mr. Hugh Hastings, has edited still another volume of the "Public Papers of Georeo Clinton, First Governor of New York." The series is published by the State of New York as Appendix N to the third annual report of Mr. Hastings, Gov. Clinton held office from 1777 to 1805, except during the years 1795 to 1801, when he yielded to John Jay.

"Auatralind: Wanderings in Western Australia and the Malay East," by Henry Taunton, will be brought out in a few days by Longmans, Green Co. This is an account of travels in Australia, in which the author describes bush life, animals, birds, trees, the people and their customs, their weapons, their mode of life, their dress,

It is rather cheering to find the inventor of the international novel, for such Mr. Henry James unquestionably is, returning to his first love after his recent and numerous excursions in London society. In "The Ambassadors," which has just been put between covers, after finishing a year's course in The North American, he makes this return.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: IN the October number of Harper's Magazine is an article by Prof. Woodberry upon "The South in American Letters," which is noteworthy as an example of a new method of destructive criticism.

When the Board of Estimate and Apportionment resumed its sessions yesterday after a long recess the proposed widening of Fifty-ninth Street to provide an adequate approach for the new Blackwell's Island Bridge and the proposed establishment of Hamilton Park in the "Lung block" were the most important matters considered.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- John Helmess could not attend his wife's divorce suit in Judge Tuthill's court to-day because Mrs. Helmess, who is head of the department in which he is employed in a downtown department store, would not let him off.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Dartmouth defeated Harvard by the score of 11 to 0 to-day in the first game within the inclosure of the big new stadium. It was an ominous and dismal inauguration and gloom rests deep in Crimson hearts tonight.
THE nomination of Joseph G. Cannon of Illinois for Speaker of the House recalls an apt reply he made to a friend during a heated controversy concerning expansion.

The promised rules for driving on which Commissioner Greene has been working for some time were made public yesterday, and copies were sent to every police station in the city, where they can be obtained by any citizen upon application. The regulations have been printed in the form of a small cardboard folder for the pocket, and are illustrated with two or three simple diagrams.

Locomotive company officials are credited with the statsment that orders on hand will keep the works actively engaged for many months to come. It is pointed out that while the demand for cars has slackened, the demand for locomotives has been well maintained, and on a relatively large scale. It is hot difficult to understand why this should be if the records be consulted.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Nov. 29. 1891, in speaking of Niagara Falls, William Drysdale asserted that there was no more "roar" to the falls than there would be to a two-foot stream, and insinuated that the chroniclers of Niagara "roar" were considerable of a humbug.
IT DOESN'T always pay one either to be economical or overindustrious. A lady in Harlem has just found that out.

WEST POINT, Nov. 14. -- In a lively and well-contested game between Eastern and Western football teams played here today the West Point Cadets defeated the Chicago University eleven by the score of 10 to 6. It was a lucky victory for the army, however, as it was the result of an interference with a fair catch on the part of a Chicago player during the last few minutes of the same.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 14. -- About the most interesting event of next month will be the bachelors' ball, given in Washington Hall on the evening of Dec. 28. The first bachelors ball in Morristown was given last year, and was such a decided success that the young men concluded to make it an annual event.
LONDON, Nov. 14. -- King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Helena of Italy, who are to arrive in England Nov. 17, will be received with ceremony unusual even in the case of crowned heads.

TUXEDO PARK, Nov. 14. -- During the week there have been numerous house parties and several bridge-whist entertainments. Dinners have also been given by Mr. and Mrs. William Pierson Hamilton, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mortimer, Mr. and Mrs. William B. Dinsmore, Jr., and Mr. and Mrs. William Kent.

PURDY TOWNSHIP, or, rather, the inhabitants thereof, wondered how Caleb and the Squire escaped getting mixed in their "papers." When Purdy Township or any part of it had business to transact which required writing or figures, it involved "drawing up the papers," "going over," or " looking over" them.

Had Edward Eigar been able to accept an invitation of the Oratorio Society he would have been present as guest next Thursday night at the Carnegie Hall performance of his "Dream of Gerontius." But the English composer was too busy, probably with his new symphony and the promised third part of "The Aposties," to make even a short American trip, and so he cabled a few days age his thanks and regrets.

United States General Appraiser Charles P. McClelland yesterday sustained an advance of more than 100 per cent. in the valuation of an importation of growing palms from Italy by Luiji Gazzo. of 154 Bleecker Street. Under the law the goods will be confiscated by the Government.

Since the death of Mariano Fortuny there have been few painters resident in Spain who have won great distinction in foreign countries. It is as if the unfortunate management of the land under the young King were keeping Spain poor, and thus making it almost impossible for artists to exist within her borders.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 14. -- Michigan defeated Wisconsin by the score of 16 to 0 this afternoon in one of the cleanest football games ever played here. Wisconsin held Michigan in the first half, but in the second half Hammond kicked a goal from placement twice, and Michigan scored one touch-down after Schofield, Wisconsin's full back, had fumbled a kick-off on his own 25-yard line and dropped the ball.

BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- Progress in disposing of resolutions was made to-day at the convention of the American Federation of Labor. Many matters still await action, however, and when late to-day the convention adjourned until Monday, at the end of its sixth-day session, only about 40 of the 280 or more resolves introduced had been passed upon.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 14. -- Princeton added fame to her glorious football history by defeating Yale this afternoon by the score of 11 to 6. It was one of the most remarkable games ever played. Each side made a touch-down from which the goal was kicked in the first half. This was the extent of scoring, and the teams left the field after the first period of play with the score standing.

The greatest day of the college football season was celebrated yesterday on gridirons throughout the country, when the teams that for weeks past have been training met in what for most of them will be the last important contests that they will engage in this year.

Did you ever hear of the horse that leaped through the roof of Lanty Lafferty's forge? Why, then, I'll tell you. Of all the queer things that ever made talk at Crag-A-Phooka that was the queerest, and it's small wonder that some of the people wouldn't give in to it, although the hole in the roof was there for many a day to speak for itself.

KOBE, Oct. 21. -- The chief topic of conversation heard on all sides is the negotiations being carried on by the authorities. So well guarded are all the channels of information that what is usually known as the inner circle has been reduced to the size of a period, which in this case, as in the rules for punctuation, means a full stop, to the issuing of news.

Senor Manuel Galvan. Dominican Consul General in this city, has received from his Government advices that the Ports of Macoris, Sanchez, Samana, Puerto Plata, and Monte Cristi have been closed. By this decree the only ports left open to shipping are Santo Domingo, the capital, and Azua.

The Prohibitionists of Minneapolis, Minn., are striving to have the Prohibition National Convention held in their city, next Summer. They fire finding rival aspirants in the Prohibitionists of Baltimore.
WHAT a cozy home you have!" said his bachelor friend as he entered Mr. Benedict's house for the first time.

Kyrle Bellew was kept busy yesterday opening letters from English actors offering their services to the benefit which Mr. Bellew is planning for Mme. Janauschek. The prospects for the success of the affair are said to become brighter with every letter, and it is likely that the public will have an opportunity to see in one afternoon most of the prominent English actors now in the United States.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 14. -- So warm and balmy are these November days at Lakewood that the rosebushes on George J. Gould's estate have been deluded into sending forth fresh buds as though it were June. Blossoms are to be seen on the fruit trees in the village, and in the near-by villages stawberries and raspberries have made their appearance.
SIR HENRY IRVING has come and gone. For just so long as he remained in New York, just so long was the local stage enriched with the full ripe trait of great dramatic art.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The splitting of the Republican Party in Alabama into two factions, one of which favors the President and the other of which is booming Senator Hanna for the Presidency, is said to be responsible for a new policy which the Administration is following in that State. The old Republican organization, which was the subject of the President's attack on "Lily Whiteism,' is outspoken against him.
THE Boss, bag in one hand and gun case in the other, banged into his office early on Monday morning. Ho stood his luggage beside his desk and sat down to read his mall without a word.

The recent election opens an opportunity for Democratic success in 1904; the late vote clearly discloses the principles upon which the coming contest will turn. The people of this country are devoted to the Constitution as it is, and are ready to obey all its limitations. Conservative opinion is in the ascendant; violence in all its forms, official and personal, is in disfavor.

Shipping germs to farmers throughour the country is a new departure in the work of the Department of Agriculture. The germs are not the sort that produce disease; they do not float about in the air endangering human life, nor have they any of the attributes unskilled folk are wont to think of in connection with bacteria.

LAVENDERS and heliotropes are among the most modish colors worn, and the youngest girls are coming out in the deeper tones, notably Miss Cynthia Roche, who is wearing a velvet sown in rich heliotrope and a huge cartwheel hat of the same velvet, laden with purple ostrich plumes.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 14. -- The threatened lock-out by the Builders' Exchange League against all crafts affiliated with the Building Trades Council became effective today, throwing 8,000 men out of employment. With the 2,000 men on sympathetic strike, 10,000 are now idle.
Time money rates, 6 per cent. for all dates from thirty days to six months.

Now that the first and in many respects the most important stage of the work of erecting the new building of The New York Times, that is, the sub-surface structure, has been practically completed, attention may be called to some of the difficulties which have been met and overcome in this sixty-feet-deep "hole."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- By a vote of 95 to 15 the House Democrats, at their caucus to-night, decided to support the Cuban Reciprocity bill after making a fight to knock out the five-year clause, -and to put on the amendment removing the differential on refined sugar. They also agreed to oppose unitedly any rule which the Committee on Rules may bring in strangling amendments.
To the Editor of the New York Times: Is your reasoning in to-day's editorial under the caption of "Mr. Low's Legacy" sound so far as Richmond Borough is concerned?

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14. -- For the tenth consecutive time the football eleven of the Harvard freshmen class defeated the Yale freshmen to-day by the decisive score of 17 to 6. The Yale eleven played a determined game all the way through, but were not able to make headway against the terrific play of the Crimson players.
LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Money was fairly plentiful in the market to-day and the demand was moderate. Discounts were steady, withdrawals of gold for Egypt being offset by u500,000 leaving Bombay to-day.

The entire silk ribbon importing trade was upset last week by an order from the Secretary of the Treasury to all collectors of customs and appraising officers that hereafter silk ribbons should be classified as trimmings at 60 per cent, ad valorem, instead of as formerly as manufactures of silk not specially provided for, at 50 per cent.

The football season at the colleges has progressed so far without important characteristics. The new rules have not made the game more interesting to the spectator, except for making the ground look more like a checkerboard than a gridiron. Nor have they removed the most decided drawbacks of the game to the player.

ALBANY, Nov. 14. -- Arthur L. Andrews of this city holds the position of Corporation Counsel under the city administration, and is serving as referee in the cases against the so-called squatters on State land in Township 40, Hamilton County. During this week he has taken evidence in sixteen of these cases.
Hooray, Hooray, Hooray; Tiger, sis, boom, ah, Princeeton!"

CONNELSVILLE, Penn., Nov. 14 -- The lowest week's record on coke production since 1893 was made last week, when the output dropped to 110.000 tons, a decrease of nearly 30,000 tons, and scarcely 45 per cent. of the capacity of the region.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Damages to the amount of $10,500.01 are what D.B. Gray of Walnut Street. Philadelphia, demands from the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, the Central Railroad of New Jersey, and the Pullman Company in recompense for what he terms his "heroism, calmness, and forethought" in saving life and property in the wreck at Westfield on Jan. 27. 1903.

By its victory over Yale yesterday the Princeton team was scored against, but it was the last one of the big college elevens to lose its clear record for this season. Michigan and Princeton share the honors of having been scored against only once this year. Following are the records of the leading teams up to date:

ALBANY, Nov. 14. -- It is likely that the aid of the courts will be invoked to decide who was elected to the Assembly in the Second District of Oneida County. The candidates voted for were Prof. W.H. Squires of Hamilton College. Democrat, and Jay A. Pratt, Republican.

PARIS, Nov. 14. -- Panama Canal securities, after the exceptional advance of the last eight days, became stationary yesterday and turned downward to-day. The reaction appears to be due to the publication here of dispatches referring to possible complications and delays in the ratification of the new canal treaty with Panama.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- A wedding, the news of which caused surprise in this city to-day, was that of Miss Harriet Crowninshield Coolidge and Isaac Norris, Jr., of Bryn Mawr. The ceremony was performed at Media. It was the couple's second wedding to each other.

The second of the two quartet concerts to be given by the Mannes String Quartet (David Mannes, Ludwig Marum, Jacob Altschuler, and Leo Schulz) at Mendelssohn Hall on Dec. 1 and March 16 will be of altogether remarkable interest as the only appearance of Richard Strauss in chamber music.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14. -- So successful has been the preliminary work with the new 24-inch Clark "mirror" for the Harvard Astronomical Observatory, that a second and similar telescope has been ordered by that institution.

The examination of witnesses for the defense in the proceedings broujght by District Attorney Jerome, as a citizen, for the removal from office of Justice Herman Bolte, of the Second Municipal Court, was continued yesterday morning before Referce W.H. Willis at 115 Broadway, with August Dreyer as the first witness.

In a communication to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, Gilbert Ray Hawes, counsel for Cosima and Siegfried Wagner in the action now pending against the Conried Opera Company, says that among other treasons why he is seeking to restrain Mr. Conried from producing "Parsifal" is that its production would constitute "a flagrant violation of honor and good faith, as well as breach of contract."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept 30. -- An interesting debate took place in the New Zealand House of Representatives the other night on the Coastwise Trade bill, which is designed to enable the Government to impose restrictions on the ship of foreign countries in regard to carrying goods along our coasts.

Last week's price movement cannot be discussed upon its merits because it had none. But it abounded with demerits and striking details, which, being recalled, seem like a bad dream, and with an ending which probably few observers of the stock market remarked without surprise.

Although arrangements for the obsequies of Andrew H. Green, who was murdered on Friday by the negro Cornelius M. Williams, were made by the family last night after the arrival from Chicago of Mr. Green's brother, Oliver Bourne Greene, many persons, among them officials of various city departments, expressed the hope that a public funeral would be accorded the "Father of Greater New York."

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 14. -- In the Supreme Court to-day Chief Justice Gummere granted a rule to show cause why a writ of certiorari should not be issued reviewing the action of the Monmouth County Grand Jury in indicting William Delaney, alias "Monk" Eastman; Bernard Delaney, Herbert Thompson, Joseph Brown, and David Lamar, who were charged with assault with intent to kill the broker's coachman.

MISS HELEN CANNON, who will preside over the home of her father. Representative Cannon. Speaker of the House, is a very accomplished woman, who has passed a great deal of her life abroad and who has also lived much in Washington. She is a good musician and a very clever conversationalist.

Notwithstanding the drawbacks of labor difficulties, there are now projected, in process of construction, or ready for opening, church buildings in Manhattan and the Bronx with an aggregate cost of almost $4,000,000.

SHORTLY after the telephone was put in at Ottawa, Canada, a lady about to give a large dinner had occasion to call up the confectioner, named Rogers. It was her first experience with the phone, so instead of giving the call number, she gave the name. She got Rodgers, instead of Rogers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From an article in your paper of Wednesday I note that Commissioner Lindenthal says: "The volume of passenger traffic passing daily over the bridge is very large, yet it is carried with a marked absence of friction or overcrowding."

NEW ROCHELLE, Nov. 14. -- The "Candy Man," a musical comedy, with one eye on Broadway, was produced here to-night at the New Roehelle Theatre. A fair-sized audience, which included enough New Yorkers to require a special train to take them back home, submitted amiably to the first performance operation, forgiving easily some very crude work, and generously applauding everything that was good -- and some of it was excellent.

WE were sprawled in various attitudes of comfort before the old-fashioned fireplace in Jack Burton's smoking den, and between whiffs at our pipes and sips of the apple toddy which Jack has a peculiar knack of brewing, we had talked of sports, politics, women, and, as midnight drew near, of the supernatural.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 14. -- Lovell Hall, a lawyer of this place, on Nov. 7 wrote as follows to President Roosevelt regarding the Panama Canal question:

After purchases which have covered a period, of nearly two years, the acquisition of the four blocks bounded by Seventh and Ninth Avenues, Thirty-first and Thirty-third Streets, by the Pennsylvania Railroad, or by its subsidiary corporation, the Pennsylvania, New York, and Long Island Railroad, is practically complete.

Feeble, bent, and gray, Elizabeth Hannigan, seventy-two years old, of 300 Avenue A, was arraigned before Magistrate Ommen in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday charged with being a pickpocket. The complainant against her was Mrs. Lizzie Koller of 521 East Fifteenth Street, who alleged that Mrs. Hannigan took a purse from her pocket while she was in a Fourteenth Street department store on Friday.

CAPE HAITIEN, Haiti, Nov. 14. -- The French steamer St. Simon, with Gen. Jiminez, head of the Dominican revolution, on board, has left Port-au-Prince, Haiti, with the intention, according to report, of forcing the blockade of Puerto Plata, on the northern coast of Santo Domingo.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 14. -- About 3,000 witnesses and 50 lawyers will appear at the trial, which, opens next Thursday, of the persons arrested on the charge of participation in the massacre of Jews at Kishineff in April last.

Harry L. Hillman, Jr., of the Thirteenth Regiment and New York Athletic Club, the quarter-mile amateur champion of America, broke the world's quarter-mile indoor record at the Fall games of the Thirteenth Regiment Athletic Association, held last evening at their armory, Sumner and Jefferson Avenues.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In last Sundays TIMES your Paris correspondent refers to M. Delcasse, the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, as one who has made a great man of himself by improving his opportunities. It may be added that if M. Delcasse has known how to improve his opportunities, those opportunities have not been few.

The formal inauguration of the large dining hall on the tenth floor of the new Republican Club, at 54 West Fortieth Street, which occurred last evening, took the form of a complimentary dinner to President Louis Stern, whose energetic work was largely responsible for the erection of the new building.

Sales of securities at auction last Wednesday showed a considerable increase over those of the previous week, but relatively, few of the items in the list of sales represented issues in which there is very wide interest. Among the securities offered were lots of bonds which are regularly listed on the Stock Exchange, and several of these found buyers.

Of late there has been a great deal said, on more or less acceptable authority -- notably Mr. RUS, Dr. RAINSFORD, and Dr. PARKHURST -- on the tendency toward moral and social degeneracy which results from what is popularly known as "flat life." Just what good may be expected to result from this is not clear; equally is it a matter of doubt that much of what is said on this subject is true.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Four thousand spectators saw Brown defeat Syracuse this afternoon by a score of 12 to 5. The contest was marked by brilliant plays, among them a sixty-yard run for a touchdown by Burrill, the Syracuse end. Brown was unable to get near the Syracuse goal in the first half.

ALBANY, Nov. 14. -- The State Prison Commission to-day made public a resolution passed by it in which it denounces as "contrary to public policy and decency" the practice of confining truant children in common jails. The matter gains interest from the fact that this is the second time the commission has called attention to the custom in the single city of Oswego.

SCENE -- The foyer of a Broadway theatre. Time -- 8 P.M. Enter, among several hundred other first nighters, a tall woman dressed in black and white, a short woman dressed in gray, and a sturdy boy aged three dressed in brown velvet.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14. -- Although large financial interests in Baltimore are closely connected with the Seaboard Air Line, the announcement from New York that Thomas F. Ryan and Blair Co. had secured large interests in the property caused no little surprise in the Street, owing to the long and bitter struggle between Ryan and the management headed by John L. Williams.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The position throughout the week has been dominated by the American demand for gold, the renewal of which immediately caused fears of a rise in the Bank of England rate. At first the demand was confined to the bullion market, but when the whole supply there available was bought buyers went to the Bank of England and took bars and eagles in considerable amounts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Again the Consumers League must call the attention of New York women to their opportunity to aid both working girls and merchants. November, with its better weather than December, its freedom from, the Christmas turmoil, is upon us, and our Christmas buying now may be of untold value to hundreds of our sisters.
LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The Hon. Rupert Guinness telegraphs The Associated Press from Valence, France, in response to an inquiry as to whether he intends challenging for the America's Cup:

There is to be no ceremonial on Wednesday of the twentieth anniversary of the adoption by the railroads of "standard time" in this country, a change from the old system, where in every locality the people had been accustomed to live their lives by the solar schedule, with the result that there was endless confusion in timetables.

The question as to who shall administer the estate of Patrick Sheedy, the supposedly poor livery stable keeper, whose death revealed an abundance of bank books showing him to have been worth $36,000, has involved, in a bitter controversy a large number of his relatives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- At the meeting of the Notional Republican Committee on Saturday, Dec. 12, the time and place or holding the next National Convention will be agreed upon. The National Committte meets to organize, fill vacancies, and attend to the usual routine of business the preceding day.

There has been a lot of foolishness written -- and preached -- about rich men. One would suppose from many of these writings that a man was bad just because he was rich. When a very rich man does an act of charity it is called "advertising," and when he spends money it is called "sinful extravagance," and when he doesn't spend his money it is called "stinginess."

Ten concert seasons have passed since Frank Damrosch founded the Musical Art Society, but there is no sign that the supply of ancient ecclesiastical music is running low. Twenty programmes have been arranged, and at each concert the society has given several choral works not previously heard; this it will also do at the coming concerts in Carnegie Hall on Dec. 17 and March 10.

The Administration is evidently reluctant to send troops to the Isthmus. It was announced in Washington on-Nov. 11 that the War Department had completed its preparations for dispatching an armed force. In some unauthorized way the news leaked out that the order to send troops had actually been given, but that was hastily contradicted.

Three letters threatening the Rev. Giuseppe Cirringione, pastor of the new Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception at William's Bridge, with kidnapping or assassination unless he paid $3,000 to a band of blackmailers were received, in as many weeks by that clergyman, and on Friday night he mysteriously disappeared from his rectory.
John Heckle Sons have been appointed Cincinanti agents of the Mechanics Fire Insurance Company of Philadelphia, to succeed John F. Runck.
GABE was lying upon his back, his hands clasped under his head, gazing unthinkingly at the sky. He was twenty-five-years old and barefooted.

TOKIO, Oct. 17. -- It was a comparatively few years ago that an audience with the sovereign of Japan was an unheard of thing. The idea of exclusiveness predominated in this country, as the sovereign was as believed to be the Son of God, and was as sacred almost as any of the idols one finds such objects of veneration and reverence in Eastern countries.

In "Lady Rose's Daughter," a dramatization very different from the novel whence it takes its name, Fay Davis, at the head of the Empire Theatre Company, will appear in the Garrick Theatre to-morrow evening. The author of the play is George Fleming, who dramatized "The Light That Failed."

Prof. George F. Atkinson of Cornell University returned yesterday from Europe, where he has been studying rare types of the higher species of fungi. He was a passenger on the American Line steamship New York. Prof. Atkinson's studies have carried him over England, France, and Sweden.

This afternoon the annual meeting of the Horse Show Association will be held and many men who otherwise would have gone to the country over Sunday will remain In town. There will be a collation and speeches. The Horse Show commences tomorrow. Socially it will be a brilliant affair, and will maintain the prestige it has always had in years gone by.

Panama is distant from Bogota about 400 miles, as the crow flies. But the Colombian soldier does not march as the crow flies. Should he attempt to make his way to the seat of what it would be absurd to call disturbance overland he would have to cross three mountain ranges rising above the capital, which is itself 9,000 feet above the sea.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 14. -- The heavier and stronger eleven from Buckhell College won from the team of the Annapolis Naval Academy in the football game here this afternoon by the score of 23 to 5.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bishop Grafton, in his defense of Russia, says: "A racial difficulty exists in Russia which the Government regrets." If Russia truly regrets, why does she discriminate against millions of her own subjects principally because they will not conform to the Greek Orthodox faith?
TUCSON, Arizona, Nov. 14. -- Mrs. Cora Casey, wife of Alexander Casey, a mining man and capitalist, committed suicide last night by taking carbolic acid.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14. -- The Trustees under the will of George Brown, who died in 1859, have filed suit in Circuit Court for construction of the will of Mrs. Grace Ann Greenway, who died Sept. 9, leaving an estate valued at $254,245

ROME, Nov. 14. -- Pope Plus to-day received in private audience Father Boniface Krug, formerly of St. Vincent's Arch-Abbey, Beatty, Pennsylvania, and now Abbot of the famous Benedictine Abbey of Monte Cassino, Province of Caserta, Italy, he being the first American to hold that position.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov., 14. -- It was only the trading in the arbitrage list, and more particularly Pennsylvania and Reading, that saved the local market to-day from complete stagnation. Other, than the speculation in the shares named, the dullness prevailing represented practically a complete, suspension of speculative interest.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Nov. 14. -- One of the finest London picture exhibitions for many years opened this week at Agnew's galleries, consisting of twenty-five pictures, the majority of the first rank, by Gainsborough, Reynolds, Hoppner, Raeburn, Romney, Turner, and others. Most have not been exhibited since their first appearance at the Royal Academy, and one large canvas, Turner's "Dutch Fishing Boats," has never been exhibited before.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Lieut. and Mrs. Crosley entertained at dinner this evening in honor of their guest, Baron von Wrede Melchede of Germany.

The Columbia Club, Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, opened the season last night with a concert, followed by the production of the garden scene from Gounod's "Faust," the singers being in full costume. At the conclusion of the music supper was served, after which there was dancing.

Almost the last thing an ordinarily peaceful citizen who finds himself railroaded to a station house late at night should do is to send for his lawyer. Yet, as experience proves, this is the first thins a man unaccustomed to the ways of police stations thinks of.

Saturday's bank statement was much more favorable than had been expected. The decrease in loans was larger than had been looked for and the loss of cash was smaller than was indicated by the reported movements of currency. Analysis of the detailed statement shows that there was general liquidation.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 14. -- The cotton manufacturers of Rhode Island, following the recent action of Fall River mill owners in deciding on a reduction of 10 per cent, in wages Nov. 23, to-day ordered a general cut-down, affecting practically every mill in the State, and several in Massachusetts and Connecticut.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Feb. 10, 1840, the day that her Majesty Queen Victoria was married to Prince Albert, I went to Reading, and was then and there bound apprentice to Mr. John Snare of 16 Minster Street, in that town, printer, bookseller, , for the term of seven years.

Considering what are the powers of Congress -- in the long run it can control the entire Government, if the people be behind it -- it is curious how little is clearly known by most of us as to its composition, the origin, characteristics, and occupations of its members. In the current number of The North American Review Mr. S.J. BARROWS asks, and tries to answer, the question: "Is Our National Congress Representative?"

EL PASO, Nov. 14. -- W.C. Cockrell, son of United States Senator Francis H. Cockrell of Missouri, Has recently become a citizen of Mexico and forsworn his allegiance to the United States. Mr. Cockrell passed through here last night on his Way homo for a vislt after an absence of six years, which long residence in Southern Mexico has given him the right, of naturalization in that country.
GLAD to see you. Mr. Hartley. Step this way. Sir; your table's all ready. Sir. Shall I bring a cocktail?" Hanky nodded. "Yes, Sir. A Martini. Sir. Just a dash of absinthe.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 14. -- Phillips-Andover closed its football season to-day with an easy victory over Lawrenceville Academy of Lawrenceville, N.J. The score was 23 to 0. The visitors were much the lighter team, and were not able to suceessfully rush through Andover's line. Summary:

Justice Clarke's recent decision in the matter of an injunction affecting the depth of excavations for a new residence at 10 East Fifty-fifth Street has led to some additional inquiry as to the exact plans which are to be carried out at that point. Trowbridge Livingston are the architects of the house that is causing all the trouble as well as of the Hotel St. Regis on the adjoining Fifth Avenue corner.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- For the third time this season the University of Pennsylvania football team was obliged to sip of the bitter cup of defeat. This afternoon, on Franklin Field, eleven Indians from the Carlisle School of Industrial Training defeated the Quakers by the score of 16 to 6.

During the past week the question has been frequently raised. "How is it that exchange can decline to the exceedingly low figure of 482,90 without resulting in heavy gold imports? Why have not all the bankers who go in for gold operations availed themselves of these low rates to buy really largo quantities of gold on the other side for Import?"

There has come into the financial markets within recent years a class of security which is but rarely a first-class investment, but is more than a pure speculation. It is what may be terifled a speculative investment, and is known as a collateral trust bond. Such bonds are not new in kind, but the issue of them in late years to pay for stocks representing the control of various railroad companies has been very general.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The views of Charles de Lesseps, as given in your paper to-day from what he expressed to a representative of Le Gaulois of Paris, are interesting and even pathetic. Of course, he has been hoping that the great work of the Panama Canal begun by his great father could be finished by France.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 14. -- Columbia's football team won a victory over Cornell to-day by a score of 17 to 12, on Percy Field, but the margin was closer than the figures indicate.

Not for many months had life been so full of interest to the boarders at Mrs. Varnum's house -- an old drab house in a northern corner of Harlem -- as now. Two new boarders came within the month; and such boarders! Both were of such stuff as Broadway and Fifth Avenue strollers are made. The little company about the long, narrow dining table had fluttered happily since the man came.

Much satisfaction has been expressed in Washington over official assurances from Berlin that Germany did not regard our performances on the Isthmus of Panama as any concern of hers, that she would make no protest or objection to the separation of Panama from Colombia under our kind ministrations.
JOHNNY BOYLE stopped just outside the door and looked perplexedly back into the crowded ehop.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest an editorial in your issue of 11th inst., under the heading "A Question of Business Ethics," and as I think it treats of an important subject I ask the favor of a short space in your columns for a reply.
PARIS, Nov. 14. -- The weather still remains fine, but Winter is commencing unmistakably. Paris is becoming very full, though Americans are less numerous than usual at this season.

Announcement of the dissolution of the brokerage firm of Zimmermann Forshay, the Exchange members of which, Leopold Zimmermann and Sigmund H. Rosenblatt, were suspended from the Stock Exchange recently for one year and for three months, respectively, on account of the curb deal in the bonds of the United Railways of San Francisco in the Spring of 1902, was made yesterday.

Prominent among, the results achieved in the remarkable racing season that has just closed for patrons of the metropolitan turf have been the successes earned by horses restored to racing after having suffered injuries that, according to old ideas, should have destroyed their usefulness on the race track forever.

DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 14. -- All important shippers of iron. ore in the Lake Superior country were through last week, except for a few scattering mines, or for a few thousand tons here and there, to complete allotments of individual mines. The total shipments up to Nov. 1 had been 22,400,000 gross tons, and it is probable the year will close with a total barely reaching 24,000,000 tons.

A well-dressed woman, apparently about fifty-five years old, walked into the elevated station at Myrtle Avenue and Bridge Street, Brooklyn, last night, sat down in the waiting room, and was discovered unconscious two hours later by the station agent, Miss Carrie Graham. Miss Graham said that she noticed the woman come in and sit down, and saw her a little later, and supposed she was waiting for friends on the train.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Happening to be an alumnus of Trinity College, Dublin, I noticed the statement made some days ago by your editor that the students were sometimes in the habit of painting the statue of King George, before the gates, green. I looked upon it as an amusing blunder that nobody but a local man would notice.

The New York Horse Show, the event of the year for patrons of the horse in ring competition, and the first great public function of the season for fashionable society, will open to-morrow in Madison Square Garden, and through the week following the reign of the horse in the metropolis will be on.

Stocks irregular. Call money nominal, 4 per cent. Yesterday's stock market was doing pretty well, upon expectations of a bank statement which might not be so bad as indicated, until the figures appeared showing that the surplus had increased instead of disappeared. This was not only less bad than, forcast; it was too good to be credited as a natural showing.

FREDERICK LATHAM, who is staging "Babette," the new romantic comic opera by Victor Herbert and Harry B. Smith, in which Fritzi Scheff is to be starred by Charles B. Dillingham, has been associated in the past chiefly with grand opera and he unconsciously fancies that American chorus girls understand all the technical terms used on the foreign operatic stage.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 14. -- Yale players and coaches were too depressed to-night to say much about how the game was lost as Princeton were too happy to talk how it was won. The Tigers fairly bubbled over with joy and sans and cheered all the way to the station in their bus. On the train McMasters said:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 14. -- The will of William L. Elkins, the financier, who died last Saturday, was filed for probats to-day with the Register of Wills of Montgomery County, where Mr. Elkins resided. The value of the estate was not mentioned in the document, the sum stated being $100,000 and upward.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 14. -- Rutgers defeated New York University to-day at football at New Brunswick by the score of 18-15. The game was hard fought, and while the Rutgers team showed evidence of good coaching the New York men were severely handicapped by their loose playing due to the lack of a coach for two weeks.

MANILA, Sept. 25. -- For excitement Eastport, L.I., is a very whirlpool of distraction compared with Manila. Americans in Manila have to make their own amusements, and are making a very poor job of it. Except drinking there is very little to ease the monotony of life, and even drinking has degenerated into a kind of monotony.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Had I not known Bishop Grafton, I would not have believed that his was the hand that penned the epistle to THE TIMES of the 11th of November, concerning the Jews in Russia.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Nov. 14. -- Promises of new and startling disclosures in the Missouri boodle scandal were given to-day when the Grand Jury returned several more indictments in connection with the notorious alum bill bribery. Out of the 106 true bills brought in by the jury, it is said that five at least related to the boodle charges.

Three firms have a virtual monopoly of the game trade in New York. All of them are within a stone's throw of each other in Washington Street, near Duane. Other commission men sell game, of course, but these three firms can handle the market as they please.
THE teacher was trying to communlcate to a class of small children an idea of faith, and, to better illustrate it. she held up an orange and said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: An editorial in to-day's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES tells of the unveiling in Posen, the capital of the Grand, Duchy of Posen, of a monument to Bismarck. The editorial says that the German press tells the Poles that they should love Bismarck. No such reminder from the German press is needed.

There is much dissatisfaction with the export trade in cotton cloth. Statistics indicate a heavy decline in the business, and most of the manufacturers and exporters say that the situation is growing steadily worse. Opinions vary as to the cause and the remedy that should be applied.

It seems probable that after all, the hope of Sir Henry Irving will be realized, and the Lyceum Theatre will continue to be devoted to serious drama. It is stated that a syndicate will take over the house, with a view to having ft restored and fitted for, this, purpose.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- One result of the street car strike on the South Side has been to revive the talk about municipal ownership. Not only is Mayor Harrison talking it, but the labor bodies have begun again to advocate it.

BRISTOL, R.I., Nov. 14. -- Capt. Charlie Barr, late commander of the successful cup racer Reliance, visited Bristol to-day, arriving at 11:15 from New London. He came to Bristol to talk with Designer Herreshoff about the fitting out of the racing schooner Ingomar, owned by Morgan P. Plant of New York.

Jacob A. Cantor, President of the Borough of Manhattan, announced yesterday that he would take several days shortly to go through the State in order to meet the Democratic county leaders and endeavor to point out that ex-Senator David B. Hill's leadership had been disastrous.

As a prelude to the formal opening today of the nineteenth annual exhibition of the 'National Horse Show of America, in Madison Square Garden, guests and members of the organization to the number of about 400 yesterday afternoon assembled in the big building for the luncheon given each year by the Directors of the association and the informal inspection of the horses and preparations for the show which occupy Madison Square Garden for the week.

We congratulate the country on the attitude of the Democrats in the House of Representatives, formally adopted and declared in caucus, as to Cuban reciprocity. It is manly, intelligent, and patriotic, and. it gives substantial encouragement to the hope that we shall have a National opposition party with which sensible men can work.

The arrangements for the funeral of Andrew H. Green were completed last night In deference to the wishes of the family the funeral will not be a public one, as the term is usually understood, but the City Government will be officially represented at the services to-morrow morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- John Sharp Williams, the new leader of the Democracy in the House, was kept busy to-day receiving congratulations on the success of the first test of his leadership, find particularly on the victory he had won in his fight to make tariff reform the issue of the next Presidential campaign.

There is a magazine published in Durham, N. C., through the initiation of an organization of the young men of Trinity College of that place, which should be in the hands of every Northern man who wishes anything like a clear and trustworthy impression of the movement of opinion among the educated class in the South.

The fishing schooner Carrie E. Parsons of the Fulton Market fishing fleet is reported to have been lost in the great-blow at sea of Oct. 8, with the eighteen hands on board. At the time of the blow the vessel was fishing off the Winter Quarters Lightship, and nothing has been heard from her since.
There are two curious assumptions running through all the utterances of the Administration so far with reference to the precipitate and decisive action taken by it in and of the Panama revolt.

With the holiday season a long way ahead, and Christmas to be survived, it seem curious to see signs advertising "Easter novelties" in the Broadway shop windows of the wholesale district. A few left-over Easter articles from last year are placed with the signs, not for sale, but as a guarantee of good faith.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The cotton exported from the United States during the month of October averaged in value $2,000,000 a day. The preliminary statement issued by the Department of Commerce and Labor through its Bureau of Statistics shows the total value of cotton exported in October to have been $60,283,412, as against $42,000,000 in October, 1902.

Although Capt. Michael E. Foody and precinct detectives from the Wakefield Police Station, reinforced by men from Headquarters, spent all of yesterday in an attempt to discover a clue to the whereabouts of the Rev. Giuseppe Cirringione, the missing pastor of the Church of the Immaculate Conception at First Street, near White Plains Road, William's Bridge, none was found.

They were interesting but not encouraging figures which we reported yesterday morning on the decrease in cotton exports, and it is not strange that the views of the trade with reference to the situation should be a little confused.
