The bill that Senator LODGE has introduced to take off the duties on all imports from the Philippines, except those on sugar and tobacco, is a step in the right direction. In the present state of Philippine industries, which are neither varied nor highly developed, the burden of taxation is particularly heavy and unjust, while the difference to American industries is Insignificant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The rejection of the nomination of Leonard Wood to be Major General would result in a complication which would be very embarrassing to the War Department and Would make a large number of officers whose promotions were consequent upon that of Wood decidedly uncomfortable.

Princeton's football eleven ranks almost as the undisputed football champion of the Eastern colleges by reason of her splendid, if somewhat lucky, victory over Yale on Saturday. True it is that Yale and Harvard have still their game to play, but Harvard's form all season, culminating in a defeat by Dartmouth, gives little basis for a belief that the Crimson has any chance to come out victoriously with Yale.

LONDON, Sov. 16. -- As, says the Sofia correspondent of The Times, the rigorous exclusion of foreign newspaper correspondents from the interior of Macedonia appeared to defeat its own object, the Porte recently resolved to allow carefully chosen journalists, whose loyal sentiments were beyond suspicion, to visit specially selected districts accompanied by a "guard of honor."

The Sunday Schools of St. Mark's Episcopal Church celebrated their eightieth anniversary last night, and during the course of the exercises Bishop Potter told of an old banner that had been found in the tower of the church bearing the date of the foundation of the schools -- Nov. 15, 1823. Up to that time, last Summer, he said, the officials of the church were not quite certain as to the date of foundation.

The "Woibancas" football eleven of Empire Square and a number of their friends who live in the vicinity of Sixty-fifth Street and Broadway created a small-sized riot on the Ninth Avenue elevated line last night, according to the police, and five of the number were arrested and charged with disorderly conduct.

James L. Gardner, a graduate of the South Carolina Military Academy at Charleston, walked into the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station early yesterday morning, and giving the Sergeant a list of people from whom he said he had obtained money by forgery, asked to be locked up, as his conscience was hurting him more than he could bear.

-- Of intense interest, certainly, were the remarks made on Friday before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment by the Rev. Father JAMES B. CURRY in antagonism to the destruction of the so-called "lung block" on Cherry Hill, near his church, and the creation in place of it and several other picturesque old buildings of another small park.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 15. -- President John Skelton Williams of the Seaboard Air Line Railway system, who returned here to-day from New York, said to-night:

H. Meyer, with an allowance of six minutes, won the five-mile road handicap of the Mohawk Athletic Club yesterday. The course was laid out on Jerome Avenue as far as One Hundred and Eightieth Street and back to the clubhouse, at Walton Avenue and One Hundred and Sixtieth Street. Meyer finished about forty seconds ahead of W. Platt, the second man.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- From early this morning until dark to-night the Chicago City Railway Company succeeded in maintaining a regular service on its Wentworth Avenue line, which extends from Seventy-ninth Street to the downtown district, a distance of eight miles.

The Knickerbocker Field Club football eleven defeated the Mohawk Athletic Club team by a score of 18 to 0 at Olympic Field, One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street and Lenox Avenue, yesterday. The game was one of the fastest witnessed on the grounds this season. The Mohawk players outweighed their opponents, but they lacked in team work.

A meeting of the Zlon Educational League was held last evening at 61 Rivington Street to discuss the question of Jewish emigration from Russia. Dr. Isadore Singer, editor of the Jewish Encyclopaedia, and Dr. W. E. S. Fales were the principal speakers. About 200 Jews were present, and Albert Sonberg, President of the league, presided.

There was plenty of high-class sport on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning when the cream of New York City's trotting and pacing stock, including the world's champion trotter, Lou Dillon, 1:38 1/2, turned out ready and anxious to win new honors.

Last week's price movement was discouraging on Monday, and Saturday, and in between, but it was not a reflection of anything which happened or is expected to happen. The week was given over the mixed news and disturbing gossip, while prices were played with by professiionals and semi-professionals in the absence of the public.

PANAMA, Nov. 15. -- United States Consul General Gudger arrived here this evening and was met at the railway station by a great number of persons, including the members of the Provisional Government, army officers, and other prominent persons, Gen. Obaldia was also among those present.
Those who are watching the progress of the suits begun by the American National Anti-Boycott Association will be interested in the following brief summary of the situation at this time.

Herman Joch of 308 River Street, Hoboken, gave an elaborate engagement party Saturday night, at which the engagement of his daughter Mary, seventeen years old, to a wealthy silk and lace importer of New York, was formally announced. At the time of the party Mr. Joch's daughter was married already, and not to the man to whom she was announced to be engaged.

A notable addition of paintings has been made to the collections of pictures, sculpture, Phoenician glass, and Oriental porcelains and lacquers at the Museum of Fine Arts, near Prospect Park, in Brooklyn Borough. The greater part consists of canvases by old masters lent by various collectors, not all of whom are citizens of Brooklyn.

The announcement that there will be no more reductions at present in iron or steel prices is interesting, but how much or little importance should attach to it as forecasting the course of the trade during the next few months is a matter of judgment.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 . -- More than 6,000 persons tried to get into Tremont Temple today to hear the Rev. Dr. Poindexter S. Henson, formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y., preach his first sermon here since accepting the pastorate of Tremont Temple. It is estimated that 4,000 people heard Dr. Henson, while 2,000 were unable to gain admission.

After clinging to a capsized catboat for more than an hour in the ocean off Coney Island Point yesterday afternoon seven men of a fishing party of nine were picked up by passing craft, two of the men beingmissing. The rescue was effected with difficulty because of the choppy sea and the "tide drift" at the point.

LAREDO, Texas, Nov. 15. -- Dr. R.D. Murray, the Senior Surgeon of the United States Marine Hospital Service, was seriously injured here to-day as the result of a runaway accident, Because of his advanced age his injuries may prove fatal.

In an upper room, in the residence of Dr. A.L. Nelden at 13 East Twenty-ninth Street, last night, sleeping peacefully, was a man who, according to Dr. Nelden, will, if nothing untoward happens, be lying tonight alongside a Western miner and minus a goodly portion of one ear. The miner needs one ear to complete a set.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Julia St. George, known as the "Grandmother of the Stage," whose name was a household word in the middle of the last century, died yesterday at the St., Pancras Workhouse. She was eighty years old. The inquest resulted in a verdict of "chronic alcoholism."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Senor Bunau-Varilla the Minister from Panama, to the United States, announced to-night that the banking house of J. Pierpont Morgan Co. had been appointed fiscal agents in the United States of the Republic of Panama.

Stocks firmer. Call money harder, 4 1/2@6 per cent. Yesterday's stock, market is well enough described in the accustomed phrase regarding the bank statement -- "better than expected." The indications had been that this week's business would begin with a continuation of the bear pressure and decline which marked the close last week.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 16 -- The record for the 100-yard dash for female collegians was broken to-day by Miss Laura Clement, class of 1907, in connection with the annual field day events of Wellesley College. Miss Clement covered the distance in 0:13 1-5. The previous record, held at Vassar, was 0:14 2-5.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The intention of the Republican majority in the House to force a vote on the Cuban Reciprocity bill without allowing the minority too much latitude debate was put into effect to-day. Representative Dalzell offered a rule providing that the bill reported from the Ways and Means Committee should be considered to the exclusion of all other business until 4 o'clock Thursday, when a vote should be taken without intervening motion.

PANAMA, Nov. 16 -- Rear Admiral Walker, who is practically President Roosevelt's representative on the Isthmus, and Consul General Cudger, who is here to direct the relations of the United States with the de facto Government, called at the Palace this afternoon and in the name of the United States Government paid their respects to the members of the Junta.

The annual report of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad,for the year ended June 30 last was made public yesterday at the annual meeting of the stockholders. This is the seventy-seventh annual report, and it shows the largest gross and net earnings from operation in the history of the company.

President MARROQUIN deprecates the secession of Panama from Colombia as "not even the result of a popular feeling," He would like the world to believe that it is a causeless rebellion. But, as a matter of fact, the student of the history of South American republics would be puzzled to name another which had so many and such palpable reasons of being "in sight."

President MARROQUIN is doomed to disappointment. The dispatch which he sends in behalf of the Government and people of Colombia to the Senate and people of the United States, protesting against measures taken by us which have resulted in the secession and independence of Panama, will not be heeded.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Senator Dietrich and Edward Rosewater of Omaha have arrived in this city, and to-night all inquiries as to the indictment of the Senator were referred to Mr. Rosewater, who declared that the indictments were the result of a political quarrel.

As the first of several developments conangent upon the hearings in the Shipbuilding suit there is now in prospect, according to report in well-informed circles yesterday, an examination by the Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange of the accountants on whose reports, ostensibly, the representations were made when listing was outlined for the stock and bonds of the United States Shipbuilding Company.

Horace S. Ely Co. have sold for the Havens Relief Fund Society 72 Varick Street and 422 to 426 Canal Street, being the southeast corner, three and four-story buildings, on plot 50 by 73.11 and irregular. Buyer for New House on 100th Street.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Money was not abundant in the market to-day and the rates were firm. Discounts were firm on the withdrawals of gold for Egypt, though the question of shipments to New York was a dominating factor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16.--There was liquidation in this market that looked as though it might come from important interests, but the real source of the selling was kept carefully concealed. It was evident in Philadelphia Traction, Philadelphia Electric and United Gas Improvement, but made no appreciable change in prices, with the exception of the last named, which was forced off 7/8 to 77 1/8.

Triumphant over dismal weather and gloomy forecasts, the opening of the annual Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday basked in the favor of fashionable New York and surprised even the most enthusiastic of the lovers of the horse by the strength of its appeal to popular patronage.

The first day of the season was a bit gloomy, but there were notwithstanding many people in town, many of them coming for the Horse Show. The Duke and Duchess of Roxeburghe are booked to sail to-day. Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs W.E. Carter of Philadelphia, and Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Brown are among those who are here for the week's principal function.
Alderman Doull, who has been acting as Chairman of the Board of County Canvassers, last night gave out the official vote of New York County as canvassed by his board.

Because of the somewhat erratic performances of the leading tennis players of this country during the season that has just closed, the work of the Ranking Committee was filled with many perplexing problems They held several meetings at the Waldorf-Astoria, to decide upon the order in which the men should be placed on the list for 1903.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Justice Day of the United States Supreme Court to-day delivered the opinion of the court in the case of Controller Adams of the State of Tennessee vs. the Pullman Palace Car Company. The case pertained to the Tennessee State laws of 1887 and 1889 providing for the taxation of sleeping car companies doing business in the State.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Encouraged by the successful operation of a regular service on the Wentworth Avenue line to-day the management of the Chicago City Railroad announced to-night that an effort would be made to-morrow to resume traffic on the Cottage Grove Avenue line.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A minority report, setting forth, the views of Messrs. Williams of Mississippi, Swanson of Virginia, McClellan of New York, and Clark of Missouri, on the Cuban bill, was filed in the House to-day.

Lafayette Camp No. 140, Division of New York, Sons of Veterans, met last night at the Hotel Marlborough at a dinner, where, at the conclusion of the menu, they were addressed by ex-Speaker David B. Henderson, Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, and others. The topic of the evening was "Gen. W.T. Sherman."

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- In spite of the innocent character of their relations with the Humberts, the publication by the Figaro this morning of the names of the persons referred to in the letters and other documents in the dossier constituting the case against the convicted persons created something of a sensation.

The Traction Issues -- The strong upward movement in the shares of the Metropolitan Street Railway, the Metropolitan Securities Company, the Manhattan, and the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company continued yesterday. These shares were bulled on a renewal of the old reports that the companies mentioned were to be consolidated into one gigantic corporation, to include the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

KARACHI, India, Nov. 16.--The expedition commanded by Col. Younghusband, which is being prepared in India to support the British mission to Thibet, starts in a few days. It has been ordered to occupy the Chumbi Valley, the key to Thibet, and to advance on Gyangtse, an important centre, 150 miles from Lhassa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Senator Frye, President pro tempore of the Senate, found in his mail this morning a protest from President Marroquin and Secretary Jaramillo of the Colombian Government against the unfriendly attitude of the United States on the Isthmus of Panama.

The observations of even a few minutes during the rush hours last evening of the conditions established at the New York terminal of the Brooklyn Bridge by the new trolley loops were sufficient to show that some improvement has resulted. Allowance must be made for the fact that no one in the multitude had yet acquired the habit of going unerringly to the right post to wait for the particular car he wanted.

The cotton market experienced a severe decline yesterday. Prices broke from 24 to 32 points below Saturday's closing and 33 to 40 points below the high figures reached on Friday last. The break was due not to any bear pressure, but rather to the tremendous receipts of cotton, both here and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The President to-day sent to the House, in response to a resolution offered by Mr. Hitt, such of the papers dealing with the revolution in Panama as he thinks it not incompatible with the public interest to publish. There is not a single document which antedates the actual outbreak of the revolution, except the telegrams of Nov. 2 and 3 announcing that it was about to break out.

The Art Club of Philadelphia has opened its fifteenth annual exhibition with a collection of 126 pictures and some pieces of sculpture. Mr. Robert Henri contributes several shore and surf pictures from the New England coast, and similar scenes are shown by Mrs Edwin W. Redfield, Luis Mora, and George Elmer Browne.

PEKING, Nov. 16 -- The foreign diplomats at Peking are awaiting developments in the Russo-Japanese negotiations with the keenest interest, but are not sanguine of tueir success, because they are unable to see what terms are possible unless one nation distinctly surrenders.

Princetbn celebrated her football victory over Yale last night in a manner the town of Princeton had never seen before. Early in the morning not only freshmen and sophomores, but juniors, seniors, and many graduates begin gathering wood. Rain fell heavily all the afternoon, but still the work went on, and the result was the largest bonfire Princeton has ever seen.
HAVANA, Nov. 16 -- President Palma transmitted to Congress to-day the budget for the fiscal year of 1904.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 -- The Rev. J.S. B. Hodges, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, which has the richest and most fashionable congregation of any church of that denomination in Baltimore, Sharply criticises the extravagance of society weddings in an article in his parish publication just out, and which is circulated among the members.
BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- Two spirited debates enlivened, what would otherwise have been a dull session at the convention of the American federation of Labor at Faneuil Hall to-day.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 16 -- The Federal Grand Jury this evening returned true bills against United States, Senator Charles H. Dietrich and Postmaster Jacob Fisher of Hastings, Neb., charging them with conspiracy and bribery, in connection with the appointment of Fisher to the position of Postmaster.

Kelly Miller, Professor of Mathematics at Howard University of Washington, D.C., made the chief address yesterday at the meeting of the Congregational ministers; held in the Hotel Chelsea, 224 West Twenty-third Street. His topic was "The Negro Problem of To-day from the Negro Standpoint."

At the annual meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union, which was held in the Grand Union Hotel yesterday, many applications for reinstatements were considered. These requests came from suspended althletes, who were ruled out for many causes, but the majority of the applicants were those who incurred the penalty of nonmembership, on the ground of professionalism.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- It was demonstrated beyond doubt this afternoon that the President will have no trouble with the Democratic minority in the Senate over the Panama situation.

Theologians, students, Egyptologists, and archaeologists await with interest the publication in England of Part IV. of the Oxyrhyncus Papyri, as it will contain the text of the newly discovered Logia, or sayings of Christ, and other papyri which were taken from a mound at El-Hibeh, Egypt, by Drs. Grenfell and Hunt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- In connection with the centennial anniversary of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church in this city to-night a public meeting was held, which was attended by many of the bestknown officials in the city. They included President Roosevelt, Secretaries Hay, Shaw, Moody, Hitchcock, and Cortelyou, Attorney General Knox, the greater number of the Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States, and Senator Frye.
Controller Grout was back at his desk in the Finance Department yesterday afternoon, after his two weeks' vacation at Hot Springs, Va.

The statistics of our export trade for the month of October make it perfectly plain why gold is coming this way. The total value of merchandise exported during the month was $160,370,059, figures which have been exceeded, toy but one month in our history, the exports for October, 1900, being $3,000,000 greater.

The United States courts are to be called upon again to decide whether, for customs purposes, sake, the national tipple of Japan, is beer or wine. They have already decided that it is wine, but that does not seem to have satisfied either the Treasury Department or the importers, so a new case has been made by the Board of United States General Appraisers.

The soda water fountain industry has had a good year, according to the report of the American Soda Fountain Company, which was issued yesterday. The balance sheet for the year ended Aug. 31 last shows as follows:
Major Tames B. Alishire, Quartermaster, will proceed to Chicago on business pertaining to the inspection or animals being purchased under contract.

Despite the statement that the steamship Cherokee would be sunk in the event of her trying to enter any of the five ports in Santo Domingo which are held by the revolutionists and have been declared closed by the Dominican Government, the Clyde Line officials have declared that the steamship will sail on Wednesday and will enter these ports to deliver the United States mail and any cargo which she may carry for those places.
KARACHI, India, Nov. 16 -- The viceroy, Lord Curzon of Kedleston, and his party, escorted by four battleships, sailed to-day on their tour of the Persian Gulf.

Don't shoot the novel dramatist. He's doing her best George Fleming, who ushers upon the stage the work of Miss Constance Fletcher, had an impossible task in dramatizing "Lady Rose's Daughter" and failed to bring to it the supreme art that he, or she, showed the lack of in the stage version of "The Light That Failed."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 -- President E. H. Harriman of the Southern Pacific Railroad has given notice that the annual meeting of the company, which was postponed last April on account of the Keene injunction, is not to be held until April, 1904. Under the by-laws of the Directors, the officers of the company hold over until their successors are appointed.

After all the most limited monarch has his international uses. EDWARD VII. is without doubt the most strictly limited monarch in Europe, and yet he has distinctly promoted international amity, during his short reign, by his personal exertions. His visit to Paris and his visit to Lisbon both did good.

What is called a rubber shirt for The automobilist is made something on the style of an outlngr shirt. It has an opening at the upper part of the front and fastens snugly with a broad underlap. The sleeves are gathered around the wrist, and there is a straight standing collar, which ties with a silk braid or ribbon in front.

At the one hundred and thirty-fifth annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York held last night at Delmonico's, Secretary of the Treasury Leslie M. Shaw, responding to the toast, "Our Merchant Marine," declared as to the policy of the "Administration regarding the proposed Panama Canal:

BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- The money market shows scarcely any change. Firmness is the rule. Easy money is not expected until well after the turn of the new year. Call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral, 5@6 per cent; time loans on mercantile paper, 6@6 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 15 cents discount.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17. -- There was not much of a market here to-day outside of Reading, which absorbed nearly one-half of the day's business, Pennsylvania, and the United States Steel shares. The liquidation which was apparent yesterday was absent to-day, and United Gas Improvement developed some strength on denial that William L. Elkins's estate was liquidating its holdings (between 3,000 and 4,000 shares) of that stock.

The Massachusetts Bureau of Statistics of Labor has just published an interesting report on the representation of the various nationalities in the productive and distributive industries of chat State, which contains some surprises. The United States census of 1900 showed that of the total population of Massachusetts, 2,805,346, the number of foreign-born citizens was 840,324, or 30.17 per cent., and those born of foreign parents 1,625,572, or 57.95 per cent.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 17. -- The longest plank in the platform adopted to-day by the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union called for the expulsion of Senator Smoot from the United States Senate and National action to suppress polygamy. The plank reads:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- A startling statement is made in regard to the efforts of the Mormons to get Senator Dubois to reconsider his decision to oppose the seating of Senator Smoot of Utah. It is stated on trustworthy authority that an emissary of the Church was recently sent to Washington to see Dubois and urge him to desist from his attack on Smoot.

LONDON, Nov. 17. --Supplies of money were rather more abundant in the market to-day, and rates were easier. Discounts were steady on a better supply of bills, a strong American demand for gold, and renewed talk of a rise in the Bank of England's rate of discount on Thursday next.

At the annual meeting of the officers and Trustees of St. John's Guild yesterday afternoon the officers were re-elected as follows: William Sherer, President; William T. Wardwell, First Vice President; Dr. Abraham Jacobi, Second Vice President; James E. Chandler, Secretary, and Isaac N. Seligman, Treasurer.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Peace negotiations looking to an amicable settlement of the struggle between the management of the Chicago City Railway and its striking employes were begun this afternoon, and the indications to-night are that both sides to the controversy will agree to submit their differences, to arbitration.

Judge Lacombe, in the United States court, yesterday signed an order requiring the Compressed Air Company of 21 State Street and Henry Monkhouse, a Director, with other co-defendants, to appear on Friday to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed for the corporation.

The suggestion is no doubt startling which was promulgated in a Washington dispatch we printed yesterday that Panama should buy herself off from Colombia with the ten-million-dollar bonus which we had agreed to pay Colombia for the right of the way of tine canal. Doubtless that suggestion will elicit shrieks of agony from the interesting Isthmian Junta, the members of which had already, in their minds, apportioned and appropriated that respectable sum.

Pennsylvania Railroad. -- The shares of the Pennsylvania Railroad again contributed a large portion of the transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday, nearly one-fourth of the entire trading being in the stock of this company. Various reports and rumors were circulated affecting the property.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The event of the, day in the Cuban reciprocity debate, was the speech of Mayor-elect McClellan of New York, which will probably be his only speech, this session. It was not so long nor so elaborate as his speech in the debates of 1902, but it was more pungent.

In the arraignment of Charles F. Rideal, formerly President of the Abbey Press Company, in the Tombs Police Court yesterday afternoon the step from publishing books was shown to have led to strange occupations. The charge against Rideal is the theft of 25,000 yards of cloth, valued at $2,000.

Meagre as is the response of the President to the House resolution calling for the Panama correspondence, the papers sent to the Capitol abundantly prove an- tecedent knowledge of the revolution on the part of our Government. At twenty minutes to 4 o'clock in the afternoon of Nov. 3 Assistant Secretary of State LOOMIS cabled to our Vice Consul General at Panama, and to our Consul at Colon: "Uprising on Isthmus reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The President is considering candidates for the Panama Canal Commission. He had a call to-day from Representative Wiley of New Jersey and James Mapes Dodge, President of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. They urged the selection of John Birkinbine, a Philadelphia engineer, to a position on the commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The revolutionists of Santo Domingo to-day applied to the State Department for recognition by the United States. The application was presented to the department by J.M. Giordan, who represented himself as the Provisional Agent of the Revolutionary Government, of which Gen. Jiminez is the head.

The Board of Election figures of the vote cast at the city election on Nov. 3 show that those moralists who deplored the apathy of the voter, as disclosed in what they assumed to be an unusually large number of stay-at-homes, are altogether in error. The total registration was 626,581, the total vote 599,520.

-- As a defense for the business world against the charge of a laxness of moral principle amounting to general dishonesty, the Rev. Dr. SLICER, in a magazine essay on the ethics of subordinates, presents the facts that something like nine-tenths of all business is conducted on credit and that bonding companies make money by guaranteeing the fidelity of employes, agents, and trustees.

BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- A special bench show by the Boston Terrier Club was opened at Horticultural Hall here to-day. The exhibition will continue three days. Many famous entries appear on the lists. The awards to-day were:

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- King Victor Emiranuel and Queen Helena of Italy reached Portsmouth on the royal yacht Victoria and Albert shortly before 11 o'clock this morning, amid salutes from the ships and land batteries in the harbor.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The Rev. Dr. David J. Burrell of the Marble Collegiate Church of New York, a Yale graduate, paid a warm tribute to Capt. John De Witt of Princeton's championship football team in the course of a lecture at the Theological Seminary to-day. Illustrating the need of making haste in preparing sermons, and yet of being deliberate in thought, he said:

Dr. A.L. Nelden of 13 East Twenty-ninth Street, who was all ready yesterday to take an ear from a Pennsylvania for $3,000 and stick it to a Western miner who had lost one of those appendages, left the city suddenly in the afternoon with both parties to the ear transfer.

Prompt and explicit denials from practically every interest concerned followed the publication yesterday of a statement that a settlement was impending in the shipbuilding suit, and positive assurance was given, by the attacking party, which now assumes to act in the interest of all the holders of the first mortgage bonds of the ship combine, that the fight would be pushed to a finish.

Mayer S. Auerbach has resold 132 and 134 West Twenty-fifth Street, a plot 50 by 81, now occupied by old three-story dwellings. Mr. Auerbach bought the property several weeks ago from the Nicholas Christy estate. The new purchaser will erect a store and loft building on the site.

Thibet is really much more of a "hermit kingdom "than Korea is getting to be, more "out of the movement" than any country can be which has a seacoast and harbors. It is isolated by the mountain ranges which surround it, and of which the chief are the Himalaya, on the south and the Kuen-Lun range on the north.

The Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, none too fortunate this season in the matter of weather, had an uphill fight yesterday to overcome the effects of the damp, but in the end the crowd gathered, and at the best part of the night made a brave showing in the big hall.

Brig. Gen. William H. Carter is relieved from duty as a member of the General Staff, to take effect Dec. 31. In the meantime he will proceed to England and France to study the remount systems in those countries under the direction of the Chief of Stall, and not later than Dec. 31 Will proceed to Manila and report for duty.

The United States Steel Corporation, so it was learned yesterday, is now booking orders for export to foreign countries at the rate of 25,000 tons a week. A large share of these orders are for structural steel, plates, rails, and products of the nail and wire mills. The exports of the latter products have always been considerable, but during the last few months they have shown a very heavy, increase.

In the presence of a large delegation of representatives of the city departments and of societies the funeral of Andrew H. Green, who was murdered by the negro Cornelius M. Williams on Friday last, was held in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, yesterday morning. Men identified in one way or another with municipal affairs comprised the major portion of the attendants at the obsequies.
PANAMA, Nov. 17. -- Dr. Pablo Arose- mana, who has been appointed legal adviser to the Panama Commission, now at Washington, left Panama to-day, and sails tonight from Colon on the Seguranca.

Yesterday's stock market developed neither new facts nor new characteristics, but added something to Monday's demonstration that there is increasing disposition toward improvement when artificial pressure is removed. The gossip was confined pretty strictly to denials of assertions giving sensational aspects to familiar facts.

A dispatch from Berlin reports on the authority of the, correspondent of the Frankfurter Zeitung that the Pennsylvania Steel Company has taken, in competition with Krupp and several other German and Belgian concerns, the order for 20,000 tons of steel rails for the Mecca Railway.

COLON, Nov. 17. -- Eleven irreconcilables of the common class were arrested on the streets of Colon to-day and shipped on the Trent to Cartagena without being given time to go home for their clothing or to say farewell to their families.

The attitude of the American Federation of Labor toward the business of insurance is not likely to be quite intelligible until the full proceedings of the Boston convention appear in print, and perhaps not then. It appears that an application by or on behalf of the organized insurance agents for affiliation met with violent and successful opposition.

The organized efforts now being begun to encourage the immigration of farmers and farm laborers into South Carolina are in the right direction, and can undoubtedly be made effective if intelligently pushed.

The Merchants' Association has taken up the cause of the ribbon importers whose business has been much affected by the recent executive order by Secretary Shaw that hereafter ribbons shall be classified for customs purposes as trimmings at 60 per cent. duty, instead of as manufactures of silk at 50 per cent., as has been the uniform practice since 1897.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- A party of Delaware and Hudson officials to-day completed arrangements whereby the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company will have freight connections with New England over the Delaware and Hudson Line.

PAYMENT TO DE FACTO OFFICER. -- By a decision of the Court of Appeals, rendered on the 10th of this month in the case of Frank J. Martin against the City of New York, it will be possible in some instances for municipalities to defend successfully actions brought by reinstated clerks or employes to recover the salary of their places.

During Horse Show week there is very little on the tapis except dinners, supper parties, and a few small entertainments. Society took a great deal of interest in the departure of the Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe, who sailed on the Kaiser Wilhelm II. yesterday. Mrs. Ogden Goelet will follow in a few weeks.

Members of the special commission of the Republic of Panama arrived here yesterday on, the steamship City of Washington en route for the capital, where they will un dertake to negotiate, a new canal treaty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The heavy downpour of rain and a very ordinary card confined the attendance to the regulars at Benningrs to-day. Form players secured the better of the bookies, four favorites earning brackets. Burdette and Cloverland, both played heavily, won their races. Track heavy. Summaries:

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 18. -- Spot cotton, moderate demand; sales, 7,000 bales; speculation andf export, 600 bales; American, 6,000 bales; receipts, 56,000 bales; American, 49,000 bales; middling upland, 6.10d. Futures opened firm, 10@12 points advance. Closed steady, net 12 1/2@13 1/2 points higher November, 5.97: November-December, 5.91@5.92: December-January, 5.88; January-February and February-March, 5.86@5.87; March-April, 5.86: April-May and May-June, 5.95@5.80; June-July, 5.85: July-August, 5.84, Manchester yarns steadier. Cloths firm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Dixie Stakes, which was to have been the feature to-day at Bennings, proved a disappointment. On account of withdrawals "Father" Daly had a "walk-over," galloping Colonsay, with Odom in the saddle, over the course, and receiving the purse. Scratches reduced most of the fields to small numbers, and as a result winners were easily picked.

Stocks higher. Call money easier, 5@5 3/4 per cent. One of the best of the journals local to Wall Street now makes a specialty of republishing daily the tales upon which the bears operate, with elaborate additions in primer fashion of the reasons why the stories are impossible of truth and unworthy of print.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Robert J. Wynne, First Assistant Postmaster General, in his annual report to the Postmaster General, recommends that Congress authorize clerk hire allowances at all third-class Post Offices.

Columbia's sophomores scored an easy victory over the freshmen in the annual Fall under class dual track meet at South Field yesterday afternoon. The second-year athletes rolled up 84 1/2 points to the freshmen's 46 1/2. On the track not one 1907 runner won, but the shot-put, pole-vault, and hammer-throw went to the defeated class.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The opposition to the Cuban bill was heard in the House to-day, and in vigorous speech. The features of the day were the speeches of Mr. Grosvenor of Ohio, who opened the discussion in advocacy of the bill, and Mr. Fordney (Rep.) of Michigan, who spoke in opposition.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 18. -- Ex-President Cleveland and his entire party, consisting of Dr. Van Dyke of Prihceton, Messrs. Jones and Gettings of Baltimore, and President Seelinger of the Back Bay Gunning Club, on the grounds of which the party is hunting, may be arrested by the game warden of Princess Anne County on a charge of violating the new game law of Virginia.
The Mutual Association of Woolen and Worsted Overseers held its annual banquet and election of officers in Boston yesterday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18. -- Remarkable cures of consumption are said to have been effected in Russia by Kisel Zagoranski, formerly a mining engineer and now specially licensed by the Russian Medical Department to practice medicine in cases of tuberculosis.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- There was a shaky feeling around the State Department to-day over the situation of Minister Beaupre at Bogota.

BOSTON, Nov. 18. -- In historic Faneuill Hall to-day, at the end of a session remarkable because of the fervor of its oratory, the attempt of the Socialist delegates to have the organization pledge itself to Socialism was signally defeated at the convention of the American Federation of Labor.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- The first session of the conference of Charities and Correction of New York State to-day was devoted to a discussion of the treatment of criminals. The report of the Committee on the Treatment of the Criminal by Frank W. Robertson, Superintendent of the State Reformatory, Elmira, was read by Dr. E. V. Stoddard of Rochester, President of the State Board of Charities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Representative Douglass introduced a bill to-day authorizing the President, to appoint a commission of three residents of New York City to select a site in that city for a branch Post Office, the report of the commission to be made within sixty days to tho Postmaster General.

An attorney identified with the shipbuilding suit put into circulation yesterday a report to the effect that the case had been settled. The statement was of well-defined detail and asserted that the terms would he as follows:

Ernst Kraus, the celebrated German tenor, was too tired to talk when he arrived on the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse on Tuesday, but he had something to say about himself and Mr. Conried's opera plans yesterday afternoon. He is much interested in the coming production of "Parsifal," though he himself will not take a part in it.
At the Jerome Reservoir constructing hearing before the Aqueduct Commission yesterday the case on the part of the Merchants' Association was closed. Commissioner Curtis presided.

The Horse and the Portrait Shows having divided the attention of society yesterday, there was little else to chronicle than arrivals and departures. Many of the fashionable set who have not been in town are moving in gradually, although this season is one of the very latest Known in the social history of this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- It is the general belief in high official quarters that there will be a revolution in Colombia, and that the further dismemberment of the republic is not far off. To-day dispatches were received at the State Department from unofficial sources stating that there is a well-founded report at Panama that the Departments of Cauca and Antioquia are likely to separate themselves from Colombia and to ask to join Panama.

Dr. Josiah Strong was inaugurated yesterday as the first President of the American Institute of Social Service at the home of the institute, 287 Fourth Avenue. Spencer Trask presided. After an invocation by Dr. Lyman Abbott, brief addresses were made by Miss Caroline Hazard, President of Wellesley College; Dr. Albert Shaw, William R. Corwine, and Miss Mary Woolley, President of Mt. Holyoke.

After a series of meetings which came to a culmination late yesterday afternoon, announcement was made last night that the offer of Blair Co. and Thomas F. Ryan to supply all necessary funds to the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company had been accepted and that an amicable arrangement had been reached by which all the interests in the road had been assured of appropriate representation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Senator Smoot is a keen observer of the great wave of protest against his remaining in the Senate. He is in his scat promptly with the opening of the Senate every day, and he listens calmly to the reading of all the W.C.T.U. petitions that are presented by his Senatorial friends.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 18. -- Brown was unable to defeat the football team of the Springfield Manual Training School of the International Young Men's Christian Association here this afternoon, the game ending in a tie with the score 6 to 6. The visitors scored first on a fumble. Brown scored in the second half by clean, straight football.

Interests here connected with the Consolidated Lake Superior reorganization plan, on which an extension has been recently granted to Dec. 1, were confident yesterday that sufficient funds would be obtained to make the plan go through.

Judge Thomas in the United States Circuit Court yesterday overruled the demurrers interposed to the indictments against Abraham S. Rosenthal and Martin L. Cohn, comprising the firm of A.S. Rosenthal Co., and Charles C. Browne, formerly an examiner of merchandise in the Appraiser's department at this port.

-- Dentistry is so commonly supposed to be, if not quite an American invention and monopoly, at least a specialty that Americans have developed to the despair of all competitors, that it is distinctly surprising to find it stated by that high authority. The Post-Graduate, that "the condition of the profession of dentistry" in this country "is really very different from what the friends of science and humanity could wish."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Secretary Moody to-day announces his decision in the matter of the protest of Paymaster T. Biscoe against the language used by Rear Admiral Evans, commander in chief of the Asiatic station, in reviewing the result of the court-martial on Assistant Paymaster Rishworth Nicholson.

In the discourse of Don FEDERICO BOYD there is a fine quality of frankness that will commend him to the esteem and confidence of the American people. "We knew, of course, that American men-of-war would be there to see that the traffic across the Isthmus was not interrupted by fighting, and we knew that for that reason the landing of the Colombian troops would not be permitted.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- "The prospects for a speedy settlement of the strike of the employes of the Chicago City Railway are not as hopeful as they were yesterday."

J.M. Giordani, who calls himself confidential agent of the Provisional Government of Santo Domingo, said yesterday that negotiations were being carried on in Washington with the view of annexing that republic to the United States. A representative of President Gil of Santo Domingo, he added, had been in Washington and had seen Secretary Hay.

The statement that the United States Realty and Construction Company was reducing the working force in its operating department was confirmed yesterday by Robert E. Dowling, President of the company. He said the cut in the working expenses was to be made through the entire organization, chiefly affecting the clerical force, stenographers, draughtsmen, and others in positions generally regarded as least stable.

Mrs. Alfred Houghton Clark, twenty-four years old, wife of the well-known portrait painter of 545 West Forty-ninth Street, attempted to commit suicide late yesterday afternoon by leaping from the Recreation Pier at the foot of West Fiftieth Street. She had been walking with her husband and mother, and the artist, who plunged after his wife the instant he saw her struggling in the water, succeeded in rescuing her after a desperate fight.

M. Andre Michel, the gifted French art authority, who came to America as the official lecturer of the Federation de l, Alliance Frangaise aux Etats Unis, gave his twelfth conference on French art at Harvard College on Tuesday, and arrived in this city yesterday to begin his series of lectures in New York and Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Representative Jenkins of Wisconsin to-day introduced a bill establishing the "Fredericksburg and Adjacent National Battlefields Memorial Park, in the State of Virginia," including the battlefields of Fredericksburg, Salem Church, Chancellorsville, The Wilderness, and Spottsylvania Court House.
PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Nov. 18. -- A 10 per cent. reduction in the wages of all of the employes of the Andover Iron Company, whose furnace is located here, was announced to-day.

Prices Higher. -- Such consolation as Wall Street derived from yesterday's strength in the stock market was to a certain extent modified by the almost universally expressed opinion that the day's market, as its predecessors had been, was made almost entirely by professional traders.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Trouble said to have originated with the street car men's union and aiming to induce school teachers not to use cars on the South Side lines during the strike, has resulted from the action of Miss Ida Stodder, head assistant in the Hendricks School, Forty-third Street and Shields Avenue, in riding to her home on a Wentworth Avenue electric car on Monday afternoon.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- The Rev. T.J. Early, rector of the Catholic Church of Irvington, has forbidden the children of Catholic parents in his parish to attend the sewing school which for years has been maintained by Miss Helen Miller Gould. The school has some 300 children attending it, and Miss Gould has devoted much of her time and energies toward its development.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18. -- The closing day of the thirtieth National convention of the Woman's Christian - Temperance Union found the delegates late in assembling, but interest in the proceedings was unabated. At the preliminary meeting Mrs. E.M. Adams of Kansas spoke on "The Question of the Hour, or White Slaves."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The annual treat, the Grosvenor-Clark set-to, was on to-day in the House. Once in every session Gen. Grosvenor and Champ Clark have a verbal duel as to which party is going to win the next election, and the event is always anticipated with pleasure. The Missouri whirlwind usually begins it, and the General follows.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- The slight increase in activity noted in the local market to-day was due to heavier dealings in the arbitrage stocks. It seldom occurs that so many different issues of these shares are traded in on the local exchange. The home stocks were neglected, but prices were firm and fractionally higher.

It is not easy to divine the operation of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S mind or the state of his emotions, but we should say that he can hardly be gratified with the reception of the portions of his message written before the culmination of the insurrection in Panama and given to the public in connection with that event.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Secretary Hay and Philippe Bunau-Varilla, the Minister from Panama, at 6:40 o'clock this evening signed the treaty providing for the construction of the Panama Canal by the United States. The ceremony took place in Secretary Hay's study. The Panama Minister arrived at Mr. Hay's house promptly at 6 o'clock, having made an appointment with the Secretary for a conference at that hour.

The market for curb securities was considerably broader yesterday. Improvement was shown in various stocks, with a few declines, most of which were only fractional. There were a few transactions in the bond list, which holds firm. Standard Oil was quite active, about 65 being traded in up to 677, with a reaction to 675, the closing price of Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The State Department has been, sounded on the question of whether or not the United States would accept the territory of the Dominican Republic. No direct offer has been received as yet by the department. When it is received it will be rejected.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 18. -- The monetary situation shows no material change. Business is exceedingly dull and rates hold firm.
The common and preferred stocks of the American Bicycle Company have been stricken from the lists of the Stock Exchange.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- St. George's Hall, the magnificent Norman gallery of Windsor Castle, in which many foreign sovereigns have been entertained, was the scene to-night of a State banquet, the first elaborate function marking the royal welcome to King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Helena of Italy.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 18. -- The centre of interest in the indictment cases of United States Senator Charles H. Dietrich and Postmaster Jacob Fisher of Hastings, Neb., alternated to-day between Omaha and Washington.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Money was in increased supply in the market to-day, but the demand was moderate. Discounts were steady, being strengthened by the new issue of u2,000,000 of three months' Treasury bills next week, this offsetting the effect of the rally in New York exchange and lessening the fear of gold exports to America.

Charles F. Noyes of the Lovejoy Noyes Company reports the sale of the property 219 Pearl Street and 2, 4. and 6 Platt Street for the estate of James L. Truslow. The plot, 3,500 square feet, has frontages of over 80 feet on Platt Street and 20 feet on Pearl Street, and is now covered by three separate store and loft buildings.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 18. -- The Rev. Dr. Edwin S. Lines was consecrated Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark in Grace Church to-day in the presence of more than 1,000 people, including ministers and laymen of the Episcopal Church and representatives of other denominations. Six Bishops, representing the Dioceses of New York, Albany, Connecticut, New Jersey, Delaware, and Missouri, took active part in the ceremony, together with more than 200 clergymen.

The report of the British Commissioner to South Africa, Mr. BIRCHENOUGH, is the most reassuring document which has been given to the public about the industrial condition and prospects of the vast region now reduced to allegiance to the British crown. Particularly striking is the statement that South Africa, of the British dependencies, already ranks second among the customers of the mother country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Having returned to the United States from a tour of inspection of the Consuls and Consulates of the United States in England, Holland, Belgium, France, and Germany, Third Assistant Secretary of State Peirce has submitted to the Secretary a report on the general situation as he found it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Diversion of the grain business from Missouri River and Kansas territory to the Gulf ports threatens serious trouble between the roads leading to the Gulf and those running to the Atlantic seaboard.

Chauncey M. Bishop, left end of the Columbia 'Varsity eleven, won the annual punting contest on South Field yesterday for members of the university football squad. Bishop has done, the best punting for Columbia all the season and it was expected that he would win. The competition was won by Harold Weekes last year and by E.B. Bruce the year before.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Nov. 15 you print a very interesting account of "the lost Velasquez" and Mr. John Snare. I remember Mr. Snare back in the 70s and early 80s. At that time I was in the employ of the Scribners, and used to meet him frequently in their store at 651, and later at 743.

A story of alleged peculiar "own your own home" operations came to light in Brooklyn yesterday in connection with the arrest in Jersey City on Wednesday night of Arthur A. Voorhees, a real estate agent.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The welcome of King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Helena, of Italy to London, as the guests of the Lord Mayor and Corporation, to-day was of a remarkably cordial character. From the moment of their arrival at Paddington Station, except when traversing Hyde Park, the royal procession passed beneath one long canopy of bright colors, enhanced, here and there by triumphal arolies.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 19 -- Wheat, No. 1 Northern, 81 1/2 c; No. 2 Northern, 80@80 1/23c; May, 78 1/4c. Ryc, No. 1, 56 @50 1/2c. Barley, No. 2, 65c; sample. 41@62c. Corn, No. 3, 45 1/2c; May, 41 7/2@42c.

After to-day the Horse Show will be on the wane. To-morrow there will be a number of parties arranged for the football match at Cambridge between Yale and Harvard. House parties will also be given by Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Mrs. Ogden Mills. Mrs. Charles B. Alexander, and Mrs. Richard Mortimer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Late this afternoon the State Department received a cablegram from Minister Thompson, dated Necropolis, Brazil, announcing that he had been officially advised that the Acre boundary treaty would be signed. The cablegram was as follows:
The annual report of the United Fruit Company for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 last was made public yesterday. The report shows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Cuban Reciprocity bill was passed by the House this afternoon by a vote approximating unanimity, only 21 votes standing up to be counted in the negative.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Money was not abundant in the market to-day owing to the influence of the higher rate of New York exchange and the absence of an advance in the rate of discount of the Bank of England. Discounts were firm in view of the coming issue of Treasury bills.
Money on call on stock collateral loaned at 51/4@6 per cent. With the last loan at 5 1/2 per cent. Most of the day's loans were at 5 1/2 per cent.

The defect of irregularity in the negotiation and signing of the treaty with the Republic of Panama is readily curable, and will, of course, be cured as soon as the Government of the new republic is fully organized. Panama has now no treaty-making powers; it has only a provisional Government.

In a billiard match at the 14-inch balkline game in which the competitors alternated in the lead, Louis A. Servatius defeated Lee S. Bennett last night in the tournament at the Metropolitan Academy, Sixty-sixth Street and Columbus Avenue. The final score was 200 points to 196.

Onoto Watanna's story, "A Japanese Nightingale," transferred from its bindings to a richly lacquered box, decorated with abundant color, and illuminated with much of the rich resource of modern stagecraft, was made visible for the first time last evening at Daly's Theatre before an audience that was large, obviously friendly, and quite ready to applaud.

Stocks strong. Call money, firmer, 51/4@6 Per cent. It is a congenial task to record that stock market prices have advanced for now four consecutive days. It would be pleasant to add that it reflected some change in the conditions which have depressed prices, but that is impossible.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 10 -- The Duc d'Orleans, it is announced, intends hereafter to establish his headquarters in Brussels, where several leading royalist exiles, including the Comte de Lur-Saluces, are now residing. The Belgian Government has, however, informed the pretender that no hostile demonstrations against the French republic will be tolerated here.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 19 -- As a result of conferences held in this city between trainmen and officers of the Big Four Railway, it is announced that a general increase in wages has been decided on. It is not stated when the increase will go into effect or what it will amount to.

The request of the steel manufacturers of this country for a reduction by the railroads of the freight rate on iron and steel products from interior points to the senboard for export was partly granted yesterday by the railroads at a long meeting which was held at the offices of the Trunk Line Association in this city.

A case involving the duty on goods which arrived in this country on July 24, 1897, the date on which the present tariff law went into effect, was decided yesterday by Judge Henderson' M. Somerville of the Board of United States General Appraisers against the importers.

The commission on the causes and cures of the delays in the administration of justice in Manhattan and Brooklyn, otherwise the First and Second Judicial Departments, has amassed much relevant and valuable evidence on the subject matter of its inquiries. There is, we think, no doubt that the Trial Judges are industrious and do as much work as they can do under the system that now prevails.

This month's contribution to Spalding's Athletic Library is both useful and opportune, as it treats, of bowling in many of the game's essential details. The Bowling. Guide contains an epitome of the loading points of this more than ever popular indoor pastime, and to novices, particularly, the rules on scoring will furnish plenty of opportunity for study.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 10 -- Another determined effort is being made here to transform the Republic of Moresnet into a second Monte Carlo. A joint stock company has been formed for this purpose in Belgium, and no pains will be spared to render the miniature commonwealth as attractive a resort for the knights of the "tapis vert" as Monte Carlo itself.
PANAMA, Nov. 19 -- Two events of great magnitude to them cheered the hearts of the Isthmians yesterday.
President Durand of the Cornell Athletic Council last night gave out the following statement:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The State Department has received a cablegram from Minister Beaupre, dated Bogota two days ago, saying that the excitement was abating.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The Council of Foreign Bondholders has received a communication from Amsterdam saying that the Chamber of Commerce there will request the Government of the Netherlands not to recognize the Republic of Panama until some arrangement is arrived at whereby the new republic assumes an equitable share of the Colombian debt.

Benjamin F. Romaine of 52 East Fiftieth Street is minus a servant and a Yorkshire terrier. The animal is described as a prize winner, weighing two ounces less than three pounds. Her ears are a fawn-tan color. The top of her head is silver. Her eyes are brown, appealing and sympathetic when her bang is brushed away from them so that they can be seen.

The plot of five lots at the northwest corner of Broadway and Ninety-sixth Street has been leased by the Higgins estate to Edward Miller. The lease dates from Feb. 1, 1904, and covers a term of eleven years with privilege of renewal for forty-two years. The annual rental for the first part of the term will be $7,000.

It was learned yesterday afternoon that an important conference of the defending interests in the shipbuilding suit had been held during the day as the result of which, the suggestion was, a proposition may be made to the first mortgage bondholders who are backing the prosecution before Special Examiner Henry D. Oliphant.

Mrs. Mary T. Clark, wife of Artist A.H. Clark, who attempted suicide Wednesday evening by jumping into the North River, at the foot of Fiftieth Street and who was subsequently rescued by her husband, was removed to Bellevue Hospital last night and placed in the psychopathic ward.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 19 -- Thirty-one men were killed and at least fifteen injured in a head-on collision between a freight train and a work train on the Big Four Railroad between Mackinaw and Tremont this afternoon. Bodies of twenty-six of the victims have been taken from the wreck, which is piled thirty feet high on the tracks.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- The University Gun Club team, defeated the University of Pennsylvania team this afternoon in a fifty-bird match by the score of 238 to 215. The Princeton team was composed of Archer, (Captain;) Stutesman, Gaines, Pell, Pardoe, and Munn. Archer made the best score, killing 46 birds out of 50 at unknown angles; Stutesman, second, with 42.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The cold spell continued to-day at Bennings, but the consistency with which horses have been running to form attracted one of the largest crowds of the week. Jocund, played heavily at 1 to 2 and 2 to 3, furnished the only upset of tho day, Lord of the Valley, a candidate for the Grand Consolation Stakes, winning at the good, price of 10 to 1.

The jumping classes, which were scattered through the programme, furnished by far the most interesting of the day's ring events, the actual competition over hurdles appearing to appeal vastly more to popular enthusiasm than did the contests where technical requirements were decided by the judges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Farmers' National Bank of Henrietta, Texas, has been closed by direction of the Controller of the Currency. Miller Weir, National Bank Examiner, has been appointed temporary receiver.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- President Roosevelt to-day received in the East Room of the White House about one hundred and fifty representatives of the German societies of Washington, to whom he delivered a brief address.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says the speech on Wednesday by Count Tisza, the Hungarian Premier, seems to have strengthened the position of the Austrian Premier, Dr. von Korber, in Austria just as it has improved Count Tisza's in Hungary.

Market Still Professional -- The better feeling manifested in Wednesday's market was still more evidently displayed yesterday, and from the opening the market presented an appearance so different from that which it has been showing of late that there was perhaps some ground for the belief expressed in some quarters that the reign of the bear was over.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- In describing the exact state of the market, Joseph Wharton, owner of several large furnaces in the western part of the State, said: "Pig iron cannot be made in this part of the country for the price it brings in the open market, except by a few favored furnaces which have their own supplies of ore and fuel and are of recent construction.

Improvement was made by very nearly all the stocks traded in yesterday in the curb market, but there was a curtailment of activity. A number of issues reacted, and practically all closed substantially below the high levels of the day. Standard Oil sold up to 680, but closed the day 5 points lower, at Wednesday's final price.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 19 -- Prof. Spencer Bassett of the Chair of English in Trinity College, at Durham, N.C., has tendered his resignation, and the Trustees will act on it Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Senate Military Committee to-day entered on an investigation into charges made against Gen. Leonard Wood, and the understanding that the proceedings would be public attracted a number to the committee room.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Frederick C. Lum of New Haven has been appointed temporary receiver of the L.D. Brown Son Company, manufacturers of silk thread and cloth.

Mrs. Harriet Maxwell Converse, the author, who devoted many years of her life and nearly all of her fortune to the study and care of the Indians of the Six Nations, in New York State, died alone in her lodgings, at 450 West Twentieth Street, late Wednesday night. Her death occurred under circumstances similar to those which attended the death of her husband, Franklin Converse on Sept. 5.

ATTACHMENTS AGAINST FOREIGN CORPORATIONS -- By Section 1,780 of the Code of Civil Procedure an action against a foreign corporation may be maintained in this State by another foreign corporation, or by a non-resident, only where the action is brought to recover for a breach of a contract made within the State, or relating to property situated here at the time, or where the cause of action arose within the State.

What was announced as the practical withdrawal of the George A. Fuller Company from active building operations becomes a perfectly natural and intelligible incident of business policy when studied in the light of facts relating to the situation and outlook in the building industry.

Controller Grout last night announced the awards in the issue of $7,500,000 of city bonds, the bids for which were opened at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The issue was oversubscribed three and one-half times as the bids received aggregated sixty-five in number and $25,581,090 in amount. In the awards the average price received by the city for the 3 1/2 per cent. bonds was $101.05 as against $102 at the last sale in the Summer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Mrs. Carrie A. Nation visited the White House and the Senate to-day, and as the result of her conduct in the Senate Chamber Judge Kimball in the Police Court mulcted her for $25 on a charge of disorderly conduct and breach of the peace.

In the judgment of the convention of the American Federation of Labor, assembled in Faneuil Hall, organized labor and Socialism are not the same thing. Resolutions calling for the adoption of the principles of Socialism were rejected by delegates representing a voting strength of 11,282 against 2,185.

BUFFALO, Nov. 10 -- The fourth New York State Conference of Charities and Correction practically concluded to-night with the election of officers. A message of sympathy was sent to retiring President Mulry, who is ill in New York. Syracuse was selected as the meeting place of 1904, and the date decided upon by the Executive Commutes was Nov. 15.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- There was general satisfaction at both ends of the Capitol to-day over the signing of the Hay-Varilla treaty.
ELKHART, Ind., Nov. 19 -- The Indiana National Bank did not open for business this morning, C.H. Bosworth, National Bank Examiuer, has been directed to take charge of the institution.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The Yachting World, urging a reformation of the rating rule for America's Cup races, declares there is no prospect of any further challenges unless the New York Yacht Club revises the conditions, with the view of giving the challenging yacht, which has to cross the ocean, a more even chance against the defender, which never leaves home waters.

The pleasure that people take in fashioning trinkets to adorn the person -- necklaces, rings, brooches, gorgets, diadems -- is not the same pleasure that makes people buy ordinary jewelry. The question of the intrinsic value of the stones and metals hardly enters into it. The attraction is the personal element, the creative act.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To show vividly the flagrant breach of good faith on the part of the United States Government by its action in assisting the rebels of Panama, I beg leave to give the text of Article XXXV of the treaty, between New Granada (Colombia) and the United Slates, signed at Bogota on Dec. 12, 1864:

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 19 -- Gen. Luis Torres, the retiring Governor of the State of Sonora, Mexico, who has just returned to Hermosillo, Mexico, from a visit to the City of Mexico, where he held an important conference with President Diaz, says that the Mexican Government is seriously considering the problem of export tax upon gold.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 19 -- An important development in connection with the indictment last Monday by Federal Grand Jury of United States Senator "Dietrich and Postmaster Jacob Fisher of Hastings, Neb., for conspiracy and bribery, was the sudden summons late to-day of United States District Attorney Summers to -Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 19 -- Local prices did not respond to an appreciable extent to the improvement in New York. Neither was there any increased activity, the arbitrage Stocks under the head of Reading absorbing the bulk of attention. Electric Storage Battery sold at 48 1/2@48, against sales last week at 47, but it was the only stock to make more than a fractional gain.

Official announcement was made yesterday afternoon that the contract between the United States Steel Corporation and G.P. Morgan Co. as syndicate managers for the conversion of preferred stock into bonds had been canceled, and that no further stock conversion would take place. The announcement was made in an official statement given out by E.H. Gary, Chuirinan of the Board of Directors of the United States Steel Corporation.

COLON, Nov. 19 -- Gens. Reyes, Ospina, and Holguin, appointed as Commissioners by the Colombian Government to come to the Isthmus and negotiate for terms at peace looking to "the saving of the national honor," arrived here to-night on the French steamer Canada. The Peace Commissioners left Savanilla yesterday without knowing the result of the conference between the Peace Commission from the Department of Bolivar and the members of the Junta on board the Mayflower.

A new biography of the celebrated composer, Frederic Francois Chopin, by J. Cuthbert Hodden, author of "Haydn," "George Thomson: The Friend of Burns," C., is about to be added to the Master Musicians Series by E.P. Dutton Co. In writing this memoir, the author says in his preface he has "purposely avoided the sentimental gush which has been so largely written about Chopin, and has rigidly confined himself to facts."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 20. -- President Hermann of the National Baseball Commission to-day decided that Pitcher Ambrose Putnam, who jumped from Spokane to the New York American League Club last Fall, belongs to the latter club for next season, but only because the New York Club drafted him this Fall.

The desire to know more about Dante, to comprehend and appreciate his great poem, seems just now to be in the air hereabouts. Dante is one of the favorite subjects, if not the most favored of all subjects, with literary clubs and classes. There is no accounting for the recurrence of such subjects in the popular mind.

MR. ALBERT VANDAM, who died the other day at Paris, was certainly a clever journalist, but when that is said there is not much more that can be truthfully said in his praise as a writer. His "Englishman in Paris" was written in such a way as to produce the impression that it was the work of Sir Richard Wallace, who had died a short time before its publication.
THERE was a strange lack of proportion between the energy, activity and usefulness of Mr. Sterne's life and the amount of public recognition meted out to him in the way of official position.

Mr. Clement, in his introduction, says his book "is intended to portray Japan as it is rather than as it was." He recognizes that the past in Japan cannot be ignored in speaking of the present, that the majority of the Japanese people are at present little affected by the "new ideas and ideals."

With, this lesson we begin the study of the life and work of Solomon, the son of David. The study will present to us not only new, interesting and important historical fact, but, also an entirely new phase of spiritupal life. For no one character, -- or series of historical facts, -- ever sets forth the whole truth concerning the relation of God to His people, or of their relation to Him.

For over an hour last evening the Sixth Avenue elevated road was blocked from Franklin Street to the Battery, causing an irregularity in the running time of trains north of Franklin Street and delaying thousands of people. The cause of the block was the blowing out of a fuse in the motor box of the first car of a six-car southbound train at Chambers Street.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Money was more abundant in the market to-day and the demand slackened. Discounts were steady. The easier rate of exchange on New York revived the nervousness regarding the American demand for gold, and the buying of consols was consequently checked.
William Watson, the English poet, dedicates his new volume of verse, "For England," to the Right Hon. Leonard Courtney in the following letter:

The Stockholders' Committee of the United States Realty and Construction Company, consisting of James H. Hyde, A.D. Juilliard, F.P. Olcott, James Speyer, and James Stillman, met yesterday afternoon and elected Mr. Speyer Chairman. Members of this committee as well as the officers of the corporation itself would make no reply to inquiries as to what the committee's plan of action will be.

The theory that Motorman Cahill of the Bay Ridge train, which ran into another train on the Fifth Avenue Elevated Railroad in Brooklyn on Thursday night, fell dead at his post from heart disease or apoplexy a moment or two before the collision occurred was advanced yesterday in efforts to explain the cause of the accident.

It is a pity that the case of Gen. LEONARD "WOOD, whose name is now before the Senate on the nomination of the President for promotion to Major General, should be complicated with irrelevant considerations. In the Senatorial opposition the claims of Mr. RATHBONE upon the allegiance of his personal friends in the Senate seem to cut an altogether disproportionate figure.

II The New York Times Saturday Reiecw of Books: I have been watching the public prints for comments, on Prof. Woodberry's article on " The South in American Letters " in the October Harper's. but Mr. Abernathy's letter In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURPAY REVIEW of Nov. 14. protesting against this effort "to blot out a whole section of National litemture " is the first that has come to my notice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Master Prim and Goldsby were the first long shots to win purses of the meet at Bennings today. Master Prim graduated from the maiden class with 30 to 1 quoted against him, and Goldsby won the hurdle race at odds of 40 to 1. Only two horses started in the three-year-old event, which Merry England won from Buttons quite handily.

Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge's important collection of Shakespeareana to be sold Dec. 7, as already announced in our London cable letter, is limited to twelve lots. Lot No. 1 is a folio document dated Dec. 31, 1598, addressed from Whitehall to the Chancellor of the Exchequer and bearing the signatures of the Earl of Essex, John Whitgift.

The contract for equipping the New York Central suburban lines with electricity has been secured by the General Electric Company. Information to this effect was secured in Wall Street yesterday, although the parties interested maintained a mysterious silence.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 20. -- The details of the big consolidation of window glass interests of the country are rapidly being worked out, and it is expected a selling agency, to be known as the Manufacturers Window Glass Company, will be doing business on Dec. 12.

No one who has followed the expression of Southern sentiment will be surprised at the enforced resignation of Prof. SPENCER BASSETT from the Faculty of Trinity College, Durham, N.C. He is one of the contributors to and the editor of The South Atlantic Quarterly, from which we recently quoted striking passages relating to the negro problem in the South.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books. " The Beaten Path " is not primarily a novel involving a study of the present in. dustrial sltuation, like dozens that nave preceded it in these latter days. The author has evidently a higher aim and the book a broader scope. A second perusal, which you suggest as desirable, would undoubtedly brine out this fact.

VERY fair-minded student of American history will be thankful to Gen. Gordon for the publication of his reminiscences of the civil war, not only because of their historic value, but also because of the genuinely human and unpartisan spirit manifest on their every page.

THERE is anything concerning the well-being of an establishment that is not to be found in Emily Holt's "Encyclopaedia of Household Economy," (McClure, Phillips Co.,) then it is not apparent upon the surface.

TRENTON, Nov. 20. -- A new move was made to-day in the Universal Tobacco Company case. The complainants, McAlpin and others, who are asking for the appointment of a receiver and an accounting by President Butler of the company and of Butler's brother, made application to Vice Chancellor Reed for permission to take testimony in the case in New York State.
MESSRS. A.S. BARNES CO. are understood to be undertaking an important series of books relating to American history, written by the participants and by some of the most famous explorers of the West.
