WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Nov. 23. -- No light was thrown to-day on the mystery of the murder of W.H. Clendennen, the telegraph operator at Brown's tower on Thursday night.

Two armory athletic records were broken last night in the games of the Twentysecond Regiment Athletic Association, held in the armory, Broadway and Sixty-eighth Street. Walter Kohn, a member of Company A and a Columbia University athlete, won the half-mile regimental championship in 2:02, breaking the best previous record by two-fifths of a second.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Fierce fighting, in which the police used their clubs freely and twice their revolvers, marked the reopening of the State Street cable line by the Chicago City Railway to-day.

The Trinity Building property, at 111 Broadway, which was sold several months ago by the United States Realty and Construction Company to the Equitable Life Assurance Society, will be reconveyed by the latter to the realty company in the near future.

For the first time in Columbia's history the football eleven may undertake a Western trip this year, according to a rumor which was prevalent on the campus yesterday. The team will, it is said, go West during the two weeks' vacation at Christmas, and play the University of California and Leland Stanford Junior University.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Claude E. Guile, law partner of Collector of the Port Nevada N. Stranahan, and Corporation Counsel of Fulton, was removed from office to-day by Mayor Foster. It is regarded as a blow against Collector Stranahan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Senate today confirmed nominations for promotion in the navy and all the military nominations not held up by the Wood investigation. They number between 160 and 170, and include Brigadier Generals as well as other officers down to the rank of Second Lieutenant.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- The local stock market was not very animated, with little more than 10,000 shares changing hands, but there was considerable activity in bonds. The Schuylkill River East Side 5s were particularly active, it being the last day for making deposits for exchange into the new 4s, and the price advanced to 113.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Nov. 6 I was arrested upon the complaint of Contractor Henry E. Fox, charged with extortion, and placed under $1,000 ball by Magistrate Zeller. At a hearing before Magistrate Baker this morning I was discharged.

Details will be found in another column relative to the proposed reconveyance of the Trinity Building, at 111 Broadway, by the Equitable Life Assurance Society, to the United States Realty and Construction Company.

With the exception of one or two weddings, there is but little of interest socially on to-day's calendar. A number of people came into town for the opera, but there are still many remaining at their country residences who will not open their town houses until after Thanksgiving.

Stocks irregularly higher. Call money firm, 4 1/2@7 1/2 per cent. There was something in yesterday's market to please the tastes of all, except possibly those difficult people who prefer to feel the ground firm beneath the feet, rather than to find it firm and soft in spots, and unreliable whether firm or soft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- A hitch has arisen between the House and the Senate leaders over the plan to adjourn on Wednesday. It has struck some of the House leaders that they can keep Congress constructively in session by refusing formally to adjourn and by adjourning for three days at a time.

Except in the first and the last hours yesterday's session of the stock market was a very quiet one. Prices, however, were almost without exception strong, and the few issues which did decline, one or two of them severely, had apparently no sympathetic influence upon the rest of the list.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Declarations that President Roosevelt was using his position to advance his personal views, that he fostered the revolution in Panama, and that he had not kept faith with Congress in the recent interpretation of the Spooner law were made on the floor of the Senate to-day.

Dr. DONALD SAGE MACKAY was fully justified in his protest from the pulpit on Sunday against the recklessness of human life that is permitted to be shown in the streets of New York. The example of London which the preacher cited is in point only to a certain degree. It is true that the public conveyances of London are much slower than those of New York.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- The suit of "Tod" Sloan, the American jockey, against the French Jockey Club came up in the Civil Court to-day. Sloan claims $40,000 damages for being warned off the turf in connection with Count de Saint-Phalle's Rose de Mai winning the race for the Prix de Diane at the Chantilly races, May 17, 1903.

Justice Dickey, sitting at Motion Term of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, granted an order yesterday afternoon, directing the service of a summons on ex-State Senator John McCarty by nailing the summons on the door of the country home of the Senator in Goshen, N.Y.

In comparison with the opening of last week's market in outside securities there was a decided decrease yesterday in the number of issues traded in, and little activity was shown in any part of the list. Changes for the day were about evenly divided between advances and declines, all of which were fractional except the 2-point drop in United Copper.

The mind of Pension Commissioner WARE seems to work rather uncertainly regarding the relation of his appointees to partisan politics. It is reported that he has recently decided that his medical examiners are not subject to the President's order forbidding activity in such politics because, by an opinion of the Supreme Court a quarter of a century ago, such examiners are not officers of the United States.

ROME, Nov. 23. -- When the Cardinals composing the Congregation of the Propaganda met to-day they received a sharp reminder that they have at their head in the person of the Prefect of the Propaganda, Cardinal Gotti, a churchman of clearly defined and strong opinions. Those present at the meeting were Cardinals Agliardi, Vannutelli, Steinhuber, Segna, Pierotti, Cassetta, Martinelli, Satolli, Mathieu, della Volpe, and Gotti.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 23. -- Indictments for peonage were returned to-day in the Federal Court against some of the most prominent people in the southern part of the State. The indicted people include a member of the Legislature, an ex-Sheriff, and a lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Political conditions in New York are under review at the White House in a series of conferences between the President and New York Republican leaders. Senator Platt and State Chairman Dunn had a conference with Mr. Roosevelt to-day, in are course of which word was sent to Gov. Odell that the President desired to see him.
BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- J.B.G. Becker of Hockley, Texas, has been appointed Government Inspector of Cotton on the plantations of German East Africa. His headquarters will be at Dar-es-Salaam.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 23. -- Gov. Peabody received a telegram from Gen. Bell to-day stating that the military authorities had positive evidence that several of the Miners' Union members now confined at Camp Goldfields are guilty of plotting the explosion at the Vindicator Mine on Saturday. Fourteen men have been arrested by the soldiers since the explosion on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Senate standing committees were announced today. There have been few changes, as far as the older members of the Senate are concerned, and the new members have been provided for according to the long-established practice of adding them at the bottom of some of the more important committees and placing a few at the head of committees that rarely meet and have no business worth mentioning referred to them.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Chicago's new theatre, the Iroquois, was opened to-night with the extravaganza "Mr. Bluebeard."

ALBANY, Nov. 23. -- Gov. Odell, in a conference this afternoon with prominent advocates of the greater Erie Canal project, said that before any bonds are issued he intended to assure himself that the work can be done within the $101,000,000 estimate. He further promised to do all in his power to carry out the will of the people as expressed at the polls at the recent election.

The stable of famous show horses owned by Dr. J.L. Wentz of Scranton, Penn., was sold at public auction last night at the W.D. Grand offering in the American Horse Exchange. A crowd that completely filled the big salesroom gathered to witness the dispersal of the Wentz establishment, which for the past four or five years has been one of the most prominent in the country.

The efforts to effect the settlement of the street railway strike in Chicago have thus far been unsucessful, but it is gratifying to note that the parties to it are much nearer together than they were at the outset. The absurd and impossible demands of the men have been modifled to the following, which do not seem to offer many insuperable obstacles to a settlement:

Russian administration is accumulating precedents of national perfidy in all parts of the world in which there are Russian interests, But the Russification of Finland remains the most signal example, and the process is carried on with a brutality which is entirely worthy of its shamelessness.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Nov. 24. -- This evening a desperado, believed to be the murderer of William Clendennen in the New York Central tower, asked Vincent Sharp, a miller at the little town of Curtin, Center County, to get him some change out of his safe.

The police of Brooklyn are investigating a report that several "telephone" poolrooms exist in that borough. It is said that several of these resorts are maintained in the vicinity of the Borough Hall, and that only those who are known as being able to afford to lose money are admitted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Major E.G. Rathbone, ex-Director of Posts in Cuba, who is waging an attack on the nomination of Gen. Wood before the Senate Military Affairs Committee, to-day took up another line of approach by addressing an open letter to Senator Platt, Chairman of the Committee on Relations with Cuba, asking for action on his petition for an investigation of his conduct while an official in Cuba.

BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- The North German Gazette to-day says that the Budget bill for 1904 estimates the customs and excise duties at 811,682,980 marks, being an estimated increase of 1,430,100 marks, compared with 1903. The customs receipts are expected to total 490,869,000 marks, an increase of 18,306,000 marks.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Cut wires, plugged cable slots, and manholes filled with debris caused the City Railway Company all manner of trouble to-day in operating its State Street car line.

LONDON, Nov. 24.--A dispatch to the Central News from Vienna says it is authoritatively announced there that if Turkey does not accept forthwith the AustroRussian demands the two powers will proceed with, their own forces to establish order in Macedonia. All the signatory powers of the Treaty of Berlin, it is added, will first be asked to co-operate.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe have arrived at the Hotel Ritz from London. They are recipients of many attentions.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 24. -- An answer and counter claim filed in the Superior Court to-day in the case of George W. Smith's appeal from the Commissioners on the estate of George F. Gilman, the eccentric Black Rode tea merchant, discloses the business relations between them prior to Mr. Gilman's death.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Mayor Harrison today declared that the city would enter the electric lighting field at once in competition with the gas and electric companies.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 24 -- Negotiations were practically closed to-day for the purchase of the Star Theatre by B.F. Keith of New York and C.E. Kohl of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Senator Gorman put through a resolution in the Senate to-day, calling for the printing, as a document for use in the canal debate, of the special message of President Franklin Pierce in 1856, counseling the absolute neutrality of the Isthmus. Several Senators gave notice they would make speeches.
In his speech at the dinner of the Universalist Club Mr. JOHN MITCHELL said:
Fully a score of passengers were thrown from their feet and two were injured yesterday morning when the Pennsylvania Railroad ferryboat New Jersey crashed into her slip at Jersey City.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The Duke of Devonshire presided and was the principal speaker at a great demonstration in Queen's Hall here to-night, under the auspices of the Free Food League. It was the Duke's first public speech since his resignation as Lord President of the Council and the first really important meeting of the Free Fooders as an offset to the active propaganda of the Tariff Reform League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The House leaders, having been stiffened up by the Speaker, stood firm against the Senate today and carried out their threat of preventing a final adjournment of the extra session of Congress.

OMAHA, Nov. 24.--A special train of nine private cars, carrying officials of the Harriman lines and other railroads, started West to-day over the Union Pacific Road, en route to Ogden, near which city the ceremony attending the driving of the last spike of the Lucien cut-off on the Central Pacific will take place Thanksgiving Day. At Salt Lake the train will be met by a large party of Southern Pacific officials.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- In its criticism of "The Birds" of Aristophanes, which was revived at the new theatre at Cambridge last night with great success, The Times says:

The "hammering" which the Steel Corporation has received during the past few months is probably not yet at an end. But it requires no very intimate knowledge of the position of the corporation and of what has been going on within it, as well as outside of it, to warrant the conclusion that the causes which have engendered distrust from the point of view of Wall Street have ceased to operate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Gov. Odell is recognized to-night as the leader of the New York Republicans in everything but the name.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- The Cornell football team was given an enthusiastic send-off to-night when it left on the 9 o'clock train for Philadelphia for the game with Pennsylvania on Thursday. Fifteen hundred students marched to the station to cheer the players and coaches. The hopes of victory, however, were given a setback to-day when it was announced that Davitt, the centre rush, would not be able to leave Ithaca with the team.

The extent of the work accomplished during the past year by the Children's Aid Society was shown yesterday by the society's report, given out at its annual meeting, held in the Chase National Bank Building, at 13 Nassau Street.

There was nothing out of the ordinary in the scores rolled last night in the bowling alleys where the prominent tournaments. are being held. To-night only a few of the club teams will roll, most of the tourneys having no games scheduled until Friday night. Following are the scores rolled in the principal leagues last night.
William E. Finn has sold to Weil Mayer the plot 146 by 100 on the south side of One Hundred and Third Street, 100 feet west of Lexington Avenue.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- The trial of the action instituted by the estate of Luther R. Marsh against Robert Dolson and E.E. Conkling as executors of the estate of Clarissa J. Huyler came up in Justice Marean's court here to-day.

HAZLETON, Penn., Nov. 24 -- The Duplan silk mill, where about 250 of the 400 employes went on strike Friday last because of a misunderstanding as to wages, was closed down indefinitely to-day by the company. Manager J.F. Spillman and some of the girls who continued at work were assaulted by strikers as they neared the plant this morning.

The report that Prof. Franz von Lenbach had suffered a slight attack of apoplexy was received with sympathy and concern wherever people live who care for modern paintings. Fortunately, the strong constitution of the Munich master soon overcame the attack, and after a trip to Italy he took up his brushes once more and applied himself to his work with all the vigor which has stood him in good stead for the past twoscore years.

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- After hanging fire for a year the appointment of the well-known Republican leader of Montgomery County, Jacob Snell, as agent and Warden of the Eastern New York Reformatory at Napanoch, Ulster County, was made to-day by Superintendent of Prisons Cornelius V. Collins during the absence of Gov. Odell in Washington.

Under virtually the same terms and conditions as were agreed upon last July, the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday granted a franchise to the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company to run a tunnel under the North River from Exchange Place, Jersey City, to Cortlandt Street, Manhattan.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Money was in active demand and tolerably plentiful in the market to-day. Discounts were maintained.
The estimates on the present cotton crop were enlarged yesterday by the following circular on the actual growth and commercial crop of the present season, which was issued by J.H. Parker Co.:

People are leaving town for house parties over Thanksgiving Dr. and Mrs. W. Seward Webb will have one at Shelburne and Col. John Jacob Astor and Mrs. Astor are to have another at Ferncliff. James Henry Smith will entertain a number of friends at Tuxedo. In town Mrs. Astor will have a family dinner, Miss Gould will celebrate Thanksgiving at Irvington and Mr. and Mrs. George Gould have guests at Georgian Court.
BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- Money market conditions are unchanged. Rates hold firm, and business continues at a minimum.

The Abernethian Society of London has been advised that Dr. OTTO SCHMIDT of Cologne has succeeded in isolating the specific parasite of cancer, and established the fact that what have been regarded as the relatively numerous mioro-organisms hitherto observed in these morbid growths, and which have been more or less vaguely associated with the disease, are really one family, but assume different shapes under different conditions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- An exciting finish between Fuller on Meistersinger and Redfern on Highlander, in which the former excelled, was the only feature at Bennings to-day.

Market Weakness Again. -- Practically all the strength which the market had shown on Monday disappeared yesterday, and the day's net losses were so numerous, and in some cases so severe, that many were inclined to the belief that the market was as much as ever in the power of the bears.

COLON, Nov. 24. -- A person who is in intmate association with Gen. Reyes, and who is thoroughly familiar with the interior of Colombia, speaking to The Associated Press correspondent to-day concerning the probable course which Gen. Reyes will pursue at Washington, said he thought that Reyes would make every effort, no matter how hopeless, to effect such a settlement of the Panama situation as would preserve the integrity of Colombia.

Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court yesterday handed down an opinion wherein he refused to grant the injunction asked for by Frau Cosima Wagner and Siegfried Wagner, heirs of the late Richard Wagner, the composer, restraining Manager Hcinrich Conried from producing the dramatic festival play, "Parsifal."
ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- State Engineer Bond said to-day that he would proceed at once to advertise for bids for the canal enlargement work.

Mr. HENRY NORMAN, M.P., makes rather a diabolical suggestion to Mr. BALFOUR, through the medium of The London Times. Mr. BALFOUR has committed himself to the policy of retaliation, or rather to the policy of keeping at hand the weapons of retaliation, though he has not yet seen his way to go the whole protectionist hog of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN.

Openly accusing Charles M. Schwab of attempting to bribe Lewis Nixon to approve the Sheldon reorganization plan for the United States Shipbuilding Company, Samuel Untermyer, lawyer for the complainants in the suit against the trust, plied Mr. Nixon With questions that resulted in making yesterday's resumed hearing the most sensational session of the many held before Special Examiner Henry D. Oliphant, in the law library of Guggenheimer, Untermyer Marshall, at 30 Broad Street.

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed the decision of the lower courts refusing an order to reinstate on the New York police force John C. McGee, familiarly called "Suspender Jack, the Cowboy Cop."

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- The Pittsburg Reduction Company, against which the United States Supreme Court recently rendered a decision for infringements upon patents held by the Cowles Electric Smelting and Aluminum Company of Cleveland, made a settlement of the case to-day. The amount involved was about $3,000,000, but a compromise was reached on an amount not made public.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Money was much wanted in the market to-day for settlement and month-end purposes. Discounts were strengthened, partly owing to the weakness of New York exchange.

The regrettable incident of the street-car strike in Chicago has ended as might have been predicted when the police seriously undertook the task of compelling respect for law. The men have gained nothing that might not have been had for the asking. It is not even certain that the question of wages will be arbitrated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 25 -- "Bob" Fitzsimmons and George Gardner did not draw a crowded house to-night when they battled for the light-heavyweight championship before the Yosemite Athletic Club. The fight lasted to the limit, twenty rounds, when Fitzsimmons was given the fight on points.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 -- Ex-Post Office Inspector James E. Erwin, who was indicted in Washington, D.C., for alleged complicity in postal frauds with G.W. Beavers and August Machen, was to-day discharged from custody by United States Commissioner Peacock on the ground that there was not sufficient evidence to warrant his extradition to Washington for trial.

Business upon the Stock Exchange began yesterday with a continuance of the decline in the minor industrials "personally conducted" by the bears. The declaration of the usual dividends is now the recognized signal for a selling movement, and Railway Steel Spring was yesterday's case in point.

Cornell's team of long-distance runners won the intercollegiate cross-country championship yesterday over the course of six and a quarter miles at Travers Island. Harvard's team was second, and Yale, Princeton, Pennsylvania, and Columbia finished in the order named. The time of W.E. Schutt of Cornell, who was the first runner home, was 33:18.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Local trading was small, and the arbitrage stocks, in which most of it was done, were down and back again, following the New York quotations. The purely local issues were virtually neglected, except for Fairmount Park Transportation, several lots of which sold at 19 3/8, a gain of the fraction, attention being called to the stock by the attractions of the new speedway and their effect on park trolley traffic.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. C.A. Newell of Middletown celebrated the seventy-first anniversary of their wedding to-day.

The approaching holiday had its effect in the trading on the curb market yesterday. There was little activity shown in the trading with the exception of Greene Consolidated Copper. The entire copper group showed net losses for the day, with new low records in two of them -- Greene Consolidated and Montreal and Boston.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Speaker Cannon has played his trump card and has removed the last serious objection to his policy of keeping Congress in session against the will of the Senate. He has let it be known that he will announce the House committees on Monday instead of waiting until the regular sessions.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- Emperor William has changed his voice, modulating it so as to reduce the pressure on the vocal chords. He now speaks in a somewhat lower pitch, his utterances resonating against the cavities of the mouth, or, using a musical phrase, against the mask. He has not yet trained himself fully, and he may take the services of a teacher, so that he can apply correctly the method taught in voice culture.

Nobody, we imagine, who has followed the course of the attempt to prevent the production of "Parsifal" in this city can fall to be gratified that Judge LACOMBE has found himself constrained by his judicial duty to frustrate that attempt. The attempt of a monopolist to continue a monopoly is natural enough, though the copyright laws of all countries fix a term beyond which monopoly in the subjects of copyright shall no longer be lawful.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The single-handed effort by Senator Newlands to have sentiment created in favor of Cuban annexation meets with more success than he anticipated. The Republican Senators are taking the idea seriously and an intermittent debate, with several set speeches, will be forthcoming.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Dr. William Shaw Stewart, one of the founders and former Dean of the Medical-Chirurgical College here, died to-day of heart disease.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- David Be lasco's new play "Sweet Kitty Bellairs," founded on Egerton Castle's book "The Bath Comedy," was presented for the first time at the Lafayette Opera House tonight before a crowded house, which included Secretaries Shaw and Cortelyou Count Cassini, Senators Platt of Connecticut, Depew, Spooner, Hopkins and Bailey and Speaker Cannon.

The market for demand sterling exchange again declined sharply yesterday, and the recession brought prominently forward the question of additional gold imports. The Street heard rumors of the engagement of about $5,000,000 in gold in London, but confirmation of the reports was lacking. As a matter of fact no such amount of gold is available in London.
LONDON, Nov., 26 -- The Japanese Legation states that, while the Russo-Japanese negotiations are proceeding satisfactorily it is likely that weeks will elapse before they are concluded.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- Prof. Schmidt of Frankfort, who performed the successful operation on the Kaiser, is one of the most noted laryngologists in Germany. He first attracted public attention at the time when, he went to San Remo, Italy, with Crown Prince William, now the Kaiser, to attend the operation on the late Emperor Fred-, erick.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Pennsylvania and Cornell will line up on Franklin Field to-morrow for their annual Thanksgiving football contest. Perhaps never since the two teams have been playing in this city has there been such uncertainty as to the result of the game. In most of the former contests Pennsylvania has always been a decided favorite.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- Thousands of men employed by the paper mills of New England and New York State are idle because of a shut-down of mills at numerous points. The International Paper Mills, operating twenty-eight mills in New York and New England, has announced a suspension of operations at all points for one week.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Nov. 25 -- The murder of William Clendennen in his lonely lower on the New York Central Railroad near Jersey Shore, which has been puzzling the detectives of the New York Central for six days, may be solved by the mother of the dead man.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 25 -- Preparations are being made for a change of Presidents, and the change will probably come within the next few months. Porfirio Diaz, after occupying the Presidential chair over twenty-five years, is thinking about retiring, letting the mantle fall upon the shoulders of Jose Yves Limantour, Minister of Finance.

Insurance companies are much concerned over the bill introduced in Congress by Senator Dryden of New Jersey, and the measure was condemned at the monthly meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation held yesterday in its rooms, 203 Broadway. Philip S. Tilden introduced the resolutions, declaring that while the bill is ostensibly designed to prevent the use of the mails by wildcat insurance companies, it would cause gross injustice to reputable concerns.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The inaugural meeting of the American Club, formed for the purpose of entertaining prominent American visitors to Paris, was held at the Hotel Continental to-night and was attended by the most prominent among the American residents. A banquet followed Ambassador Porter accepted the honorary Presidency of ths club and Consul General Gowdy was elected honorary Vice President.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- The money market is unchanged except for a slightly firmer tone.

SAVANNAH, Nov. 25 -- In the United States Court to-day Judge Speer issued a rule for contempt against President Milton H. Smith of the Louisville and Nashville Road, W. Hale, Superintendent of the Seaboard Air Line Railway, and W.B. Denham, Superintendent of the Atlantic Coast Line Railway, ordering them to show cause why they should not be attached for contempt for disregarding the order of the court.

John Wanamaker has bought from Willlam E. Finn the large parcel of vacant property on the east side of Broadway, opposite Waverley Place, part of which was formerly the site of the Colonnade Hotel and the rest of which was used several years ago by the "Old London Street" exhibition.
Details will be found in another column relative to the purchase of the Old London Street property on Broadway by John Wanamaker from William E. Finn through Broker Leopold Well.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 25 -- The Austrian and Russian Ambassadors here have received the reply of the Porte to the Macedonian reform proposals of the two powers. It accepts in principle all the nine points of the reform scheme.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Lord Rosebery spoke to 3,000 persons on the fiscal question at the Surrey Theatre last night. There were 20,000 applications for tickets, the issue of which had to be limited to the capacity of the theatre. Lord Rosebery afterward addressed a large overflow meeting. At both meetings he was enthusiastically received, and all through his speeches he was warmly cheered.
KIEL, Prussia, Nov. 25 -- The German antarctic exploring steamship Gauss, which Commander Peary, United States Navy, may possibly purchase for his north pole expedition, arrived here to-day.
The Iron Age in its issue to-day comments upon the conditions in the iron trade as follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Senator Cullom, in taking up the Cuban reciprocity resolution in the Senate to-day, made it the unfinished business, so that it will come up for discussion from day to day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The President has vindicated Judge John C. Pollock of the charge of playing poker and winning at it, and has named him for Federal Judge in Kansas.
ATLANTA, Nov. 25. -- Ex-Secretary of the Interior Hoke Smith and Attorney D. W. Rountree were the principals in a fight late this afternoon in the United States court room.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 -- The midshipmen had a short line-up this afternoon, with no scoring and plenty of signal work and formation drills. The coaches again shifted the team to such an extent that the indications are that the Navy eleven will meet West Point with a very different set of men than have played together this season.

"The talk at the White House, has clarified the whole situation in New York State," said Gov. ODELL on his return from Washington. The fog having been cleared away as the result of the Governor's interview with President ROOSEVELT, through the purer air political objects now come clearly into view.

BARABOO, Wis., Nov. 25 -- The Illinois Iron Mining Company, near North Freedom, has shut down its plant, throwing 400 men out of employment. The mine is owned by the Deering Harvester Company. The pumps are being removed and the mine allowed to fill with water.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 25 -- Much excitement prevailed, but fortunately no loss of life or injury for any of the audience resulted from a fire which broke out in the Avenue Theatre this evening during a performance. Harry Davis, owner of the theatre, places the damage at about $15,000. principally from water.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Although a basis of settlement of the strike of the employes of the Chicago City Railway Company was decided upon at 1:30 this morning, and the agreement was ratified by the men a few hours later, the only cars operated to-day were manned by non-union crews under police guard.

In spite of the high price of the turkey, Thanksgiving this year is to be made as joyous and memorable and as full of good cheer to the poor in the city as any Thanksgiving of the past, while the religious significance of the day will be observed by services in many churches.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Commissioner Ware of the Pension Office thinks ninety days in a public office sufficient time to give a man a liberal education. Having had an experience beyond that period he has decided to retire and give others a chance to acquire the knowledge and experience that come from the administration of the post of Pension Commissioner.

An echo of the coal strike was heard yesterday at the Appraiser's Stores, when Judge Henderson M. Somerville of the Board of United States General Appraisers rendered a decision on an importation of coal briquettes.

James H. Hobbins, sixty-eight years old, Treasurer of St. Alban's Protestant Episcopal Church, at Summit Avenue and One Hundred and Sixty-fourth Street, in the Borough of the Bronx, mysteriously disappeared Tuesday night, and his wife and many of his friends are convinced that he has committed suicide because of trouble in the church, which he took so greatly to heart that for weeks it is said he has hardly slept.

In the heart-to-heart talk which Senator PLATT had with a reporter of The Brooklyn Eagle, and which we transferred to our columns yesterday, the veteran statesman unbosomed himself with unusual freedom, it appeared that he had, as DANIEL WEBSTER once expressed it, "emptied his bosom of every political sentiment that therein existed."

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Nov. 26 -- Owing to the faot that the ground was hard frozen to-day and that the severe going recently had pretty well used up many of the horses owned by members of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club, the run scheduled for the Meadow Brook hounds was abandoned, and all meets arranged for the Winter were called off, though the club will hunt when the weather permits.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 26 -- The largest crowd ever in attendance at a football game in this part of the State witnessed the game to-day between Kentucky University and State College, the former winning by 17 to 0. The game was interesting throughout, but the team representing State College was made up mostly of out-of-town men, while the University team was compose of the men who have played on their team all the season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Friends of the irrigation law are disturbed over a bill introduced in the Senate by Senator Hansbrough to amend the Timber and Stone act.

St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, at Pleasant Plains, S.I., was crowded to its fullest capacity last evening, the occasion being a double wedding of the twin daughters of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Manes.

W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr., with his thirty-horse power Mors racing automobile, proved the winner in the third annual hill-climbing contest of the Automobile Club of New Jersey at Eagle Rock, West Orange, N.J., yesterday morning, making the mile uphill in 1:36 3/4, and reducing the former record of 42, made by W.J. Stewart in a locomobile in 1901, by more than a minute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Lehigh vanquished Georgetown this afternoon by the same score that gained her supremacy in football over Lafayette last Saturday, by 12 to 6. The game was played chiefly in Georgetown's territory, and Lehigh failed to make at least one or two more touchdowns by fumbling.

Those whose patriotic service takes the shape of manning the outer walls of our system of industrial protection and whose lives, fortunes, and sacred honor are pledged to resist to the utmost any attempt to break down or undermine the tariff are notified that something has just happened in connection with the work of the Board of United States General Appraisers which should not be permitted to pass unnoticed.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 26 -- On an order of dismissal, issued by plaintiff, the suit of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York against James L. Blair and his wife was to-day taken off the books of the United States District Court.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 26 -- The fight against the passage of the Cuban Reciprocity bill has been abandoned by the Louisiana sugar planters, who charge President Roosevelt with having caused a loss of $2,000,000 to the sugar industry of this State owing to his rigid stand in favor of the measure.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 26 -- With a magnificent field of golfers, including the present National champion, Walter J. Travis; the former National, and present metropolitan champion, Findlay S. Douglas, and a grand array of lesser club champions, the Country Club of Lakewood formally opened its new eighteen-hole course to-day by holding its first big tournament.

Considerable excitement was caused in the aristocratic section of Green Avenue, near Broadway, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, when a patrol wagon stopped in front of the handsome cottage occupied by the Florida Club, and a squad of police, headed by Capt. Miles O'Reilly, commanding the Ralph Avenue Station, alighted.

The news from Mexico that President DIAZ thinks of resigning his high office in favor of LIMANTOUR, Secretary of Finance, will be hailed by friends of our sister republic as one more example of the wisdom which has marked the long career of PORFIRIO DIAZ. Doubtless the President is familiar with EMERSON, for he reads English perfectly, though shy to engage in English conversation.

Thanksgiving was passed by Senator Thomas C. Platt in taking dinner with Mrs. Platt and witnessing "The County Chairman" at Wallack's. So far as known, the conference with Senator Hanna did not take place. Postmaster Van Cott saw Senator Platt, as did a few other personal and political friends.

Twenty-five costumed members of the Frogtown Rangers, an organization of youths belonging in the vicinity of Tenth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, carried their, skylarking so far in a Thirty-fourth Street cross-town car last evening that the conductor, Alfred E. Smith, locked the doors and sent for the police.

Pretty chilly place for a Colombian," remarked Don Francisco de P. Manotas with a quizzical smile and buttoning a heavy ulster tightly about him, as he walked down the gangplank of the Atlas Line steamship Adirondack, which arrived here yesterday from Colombian and Central American parts.
PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry appointed to investigate the Humbert affair assembled today.
Regal shoes for women are sold only in Regal stores for women -- stores that are wholly separate from the men's stores.

The antelope house at the Bronx Zoological Park was opened to the public yesterday. The building, with its collection, constitutes one of the finest features in the park. The building is 142 by 78 feet, and corresponds in style and material with the other buildings in the park, being of cut stone, buff brick, with terra-cotta trimmings.
Ever since the opening of the Harlem River Speedway Thanksgiving Day has been regarded as a field day among the road drivers that frequent it, and yesterday was no exception to the rule.

There is never very much of consequence on Thanksgiving. Town was dull yesterday. There were a few family dinners. Mrs. Astor had her usual Thanksgiving dinner, and Mrs. Robert G. Remsen and Mrs. Vanderbilt had friends and members of the family. But the majority of people went out of town, and the reports from Newport, from Tuxedo, from Hempstead -- where there were some dozen house parties -- gave descriptions of gayeties.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 26 -- Dartmouth completely outclassed Brown at Varrick Park to-day, winning the last of the big New England football games of the season by the remarkable score of 62 to 0. Dartmouth, by her victory over Harvard and her strong work in the game with Princeton, has shown that hence forth, she must be classed with the big college teams.

Thanksgiving Day dawned clear and cold, just the right sort of a day to infuse the proper spirit of the occasion into all who were not in actual want. And there was little excuse for being in actual want, for thousands of free dinners to the poor were served in every part of the city, and turkey, too, was general, despite the high prices of the birds.

PANAMA, Nov. 26 -- El Cronista, an old Conservative newspaper, publishes a song article on the career of Dr. Manuel Amacor, Minister of Finance of Panama, in which it is proclaimed that he is the only possible candidate for the Presidency of the Republic.

Has President ROOSEVELT lost political strength in the West? Undoubtedly he has lost strength in the East. New England's enthusiasm for him seems to have taken on a wintry quality. That he has lost in New York is plain to everybody who listens to the speech of people.

Admirers of burned wood articles can now gratify their desire for them ad libitum, for they are appearing in great varirty in all the leading department stores. Especially desirable for Christmas gifts are the desk sets with holly designs. The red of the berries is effective on the brown wood, and, at the same time, the designs are so small as not to look out of place on even the tiny stamp boxes.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Before a crowd that nearly filled the big grand stand at the American League grounds on Huntington Avenue to-day the Holy-Cross College football eleven defeated the Tufts College team by a score of 32 to 0.

The principal football games which were played yesterday virtually closed the present season, the only important game remaining being that between the army and navy to-morrow in Philadelphia. The big Thanksgiving Day game in the East was the meeting of Pennsylvania and Cornell in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2G.-The Thanksgiving Day card- at Bennings to-day was one of the beat that will be offered during the present meeting, and Included a steeplechase for gentlemen riders and a handicap steeplechase, besides " The. Washington Cup " race at two miles and a quarter on the flat.

Mr. McDOUGALL HAWKES, to whom as Dock Commissioner the Metropolitan Railway has applied for permission to employ the overhead trolley along West Street, is abundantly justified in refusing even to entertain the application until he is furnished with a technical report, presumably to be submitted to his own expert advisers, setting forth in detail the causes which render operation of an underground trolley along that thoroughfare impracticable, as the corporation alleges it to be.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Thanksgiving among the social colony of Tuxedo Park was a very lively day. The early morning trains from New York brought a good crowd of guests to the clubhouse and to the cottages, and a few came out by autos.

COLON, Nov. 26 -- The test of the decree closing the ports of the Department of Bolivar to vessels from Colon reached here to-day. It prohibits until further notice all traffic or business between the ports in that department and the "rebel department" of Panama, and says:

Fire of unknown origin broke out last night in the cellar of one of two buildings occupied as an orphan asylum by the Franciscan sisters of the Immaculate Conception attached to the Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church, at 343 Seventh Street, Jersey City. The sisters occupy a three-story frame building in front and another in the rear.

The brief official statement to be found elsewhere in this issue of the plans of the New York Central management relative to what in the technical slang of the day is known as "the electrification" of the terminal of that railroad and its allied lines delivering passengers in this city at the Grand Central Station is interesting and important.

The small boy looks upon public holidays as occasions on which the freedom of the city is given to him and he is released from the obligations of the law. It is odd how he has managed to distinguish each holiday with a separate specialty of nuisance. On the Fourth of July he endeavors to deafen all citizens who are compelled to stay in town and to burn up the city at night.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 26 -- Dickinson defeated Lafayette at football here to-day by the decisive score of 33 to 0. The visitors excelled both in offense and defense. The home players did not play with the snap and dash that has characterized their work all season.

The first of the People's Symphony concerts was given last evening in Cooper Union Hall before an audience as large as the hall could accommodate. The programme was entirely devoted to the works of Berlioz, in honor of that master's one hundredth birthday, now close at hand, and the performance was one of the best that has been heard at these concerts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The constantly increasing difference between the current receipts and expenses of the Government is causing uneasiness among the leaders in Congress as well as the Treasury officials.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Thanksgiving Day was celebrated by the American Society in London at a banquet at the Hotel Cecil tonight. There were over 400 covers. William Jennings Bryan was the guest of honor.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Money in the market to-day was in strong demand for Stock Exchange requirements. The continued fall in New York exchange again hardened discounts.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 26 -- Scenes of indescribable confusion marked to-day's session of the lower house of the Diet. They originated in the proposal to hold two sessions daily. The members of the Extreme Left vehemently protested, and several of them were suspended for disorderly conduct by the President, to whom many insulting epithets were applied.
Elizabeth A. Wilcox has sold the six-story apartment house 742 and 744 St. Nicholas Avenue, 60 by 100, taking in part payment 528 Canal Street, a four-story business building.

An unusually big field of golfers appeared on the links of the Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island, yesterday, to compete in the special Thanksgiving Day handicaps for Class A and Class B players. Victor Garret won the Class A event with a net score of 83 strokes, C.T. Stout making the lowest gross score, 90 strokes.

Mrs. Mary Cusick and her friend Mrs. Julia Ward, friends for many years, died yesterday afternoon within half an hour of each other at their home, 172 Perry Street. Their deaths were due to poison, presumably taken through eating tomatoes and peas that had been improperly canned.

The first official statement regarding the contract between the General Electric Company and the New York Central for the equipment of the latter's lines with electricity as a motive power was given out yesterday. The statement reads as follows:

APPLETON, Wis., Nov. 26 -- All the print paper mills in the Fox River Valley region and throughout the West shut down today for three days, by agreement, for the frankly announced purpose of curtailing production and preventing a slump in prices which would result from piling up a surplus.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- While Coach Stagg lay bundled up in blankets in a closed carriage at Marshall Field to-day Coach Yost's Michigan University football players overwhelmed the Chicago team in the annual Thanksgiving Day contest by the score of 28 to 0. All records for attendance were broken, fully 20,000 enthusiastic spectators braving a heavy snowfall to see the game.
Yesterday (Thanksgiving Day) being a National holiday no financial business was transacted in the United States.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 26 -- William Wyman, a wealthy and philanthropic citizen, died to-day at his country seat, Homewood, of a complication of diseases.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- State Civil Service Commissioner John E. Kraft, the only Democratic member of the State Commission, is determined that Mayor McClellan shall not be embarrassed by civil service rules promulgated by the present Municipal Commission of New York if he can help it, and, at a meeting of the State Commission to be held at Hotel Manhattan, New York, to-morrow will file a bitter protest against the sweeping changes, proposed.

BREDGETON, N.J., Nov. 26 -- One man was killed and two others so injured that there is very slight chance of their recovery by the blowing up this morning of the separator bowl in the Arctic Ice and Milk Plant.

In THE TIMES the other day one of our correspondents, Mr. A.J. LAMOUREUX, very pertinently suggested that Secretary of the Treasury SHAW had put "the cart before the horse" in his demand for American ships as the only means of getting American trade with South America.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- Anti-Austrian demonstrations, which began in Italy some days ago owing to the prohibition by Austria of the establishment of a free Italian university at Innsbruck, are assuming a grave character.

Charles Mock of the Century Road Club of America received two prizes in the fifty-mile handicap road race, held under the auspices of the Century Road Club of America yesterday. Mock, who was on scratch, received first time prize, as he covered the distance in 2:40, and also got twelfth-place prize. Mock's time was fast, considering the fact that he rode against the wind.

OGDEN, Utah, Nov. 26 -- One hundred and two miles of track, composing what is known as the Ogden-Lucien cut-off across Great Salt Lake, was formally declared completed to-day, and made a part of the Harriman system.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The members of the British Parliament, who, with their wives and daughters, are returning the visit to London of French Senators and Deputies representing the international arbitration group, were tendered a reception at 5 o'clock this afternoon at the Elysee, Baron d'Estournelles de Constant introducing the visitors individually to President and Mme. Loubet.

The strike of the livery stable drivers in four of the largest stables and a general lock-out which followed were settled yesterday, the cabmen practically gaining all they demanded. The Mason Stable Company granted the demands early in the day, and their employes returned to work at 6 o'clock yesterday evening.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- In the House to-day the Democrats took advantage of the present inaction of Congress to accentuate the division among the Republican leaders.

It was a disagreeable little batch of figures that confronted the Treasury officials and the leaders in Congress on the morrow of Thanksgiving Day. They showed the receipts and expenditures since the beginning of the fiscal year in comparison -- in contrast, rather -- with the corresponding period of last year to be as follows:
Grover Cleveland, in the following letter to The Brooklyn Eagle, declares his "unalterable and conclusive" determination not to be the Democratic nominee for President again:

-- Mr. BRYAN, taking luncheon in the British capital with great lords and statesmen and diplomats, if he has any sense of humor -- which it's doubtful if he has -- must meditate with quiet mirthfulness on the number of the roads to international eminence, and the extreme queerness of the zigzags by which certain of the roads lead there.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 27 -- The prolongation of the Russo-Japanese negotiations at Tokio, which have been delayed by Viceroy Alexieff's return to St. Petersburg, is due to the inability to reach an understanding regarding Korea.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- There was a bold daylight robbery on Thursday at Gray Tower, the splendid home of William Welsh Harrison, near Glenside, and jewels valued at more than $17,000 were carried off while the family was eating Thanksgiving dinner.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Rates for money were firm and the supplies were not abundant in the market to-day, but the keenness of the demand was somewhat abated. Discounts were firm and quiet, the weakness of New York exchange renewing the apprehension of considerable further with- drawals of gold.

JAMAICA, L.I., Nov. 27 -- The mystery as to the death of Frederick Flandermeyer, who was found dead beside his motor cycle the night of Oct. 22, was explained to-day at the inquest before Coroner. Ruoff in Jamaica. Albert Obercomski, a farm hand, said that the night in question he was run down by a cyclist at the place where Flandermeyer's body was found.
Major William H. Hart, Commissary, will repair to Washington and report to the Commissary General for duty in his office.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The timber toppers and the combination harness and saddle horses provided the chief interest to-night at the Horse Show of the Riding and Driving Club of Orange. Two classes of jumpers were shown, and in both Wild Heather, a dark-brown gelding with a tremendous length of leg created no end of amusement and excitement.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Mr. Cleveland's announcement that he would not accept a third term seemed to be generally approved to-night among those Democrats who were in the city.

The Townsend-Downey Shipbuilding Company, whose yard is at Shooter's Island, closed down unexpectedly on Wednesday night, throwing 1,200 men temporarily out of employment. A notice posted at the yard says that work will be resumed again on Monday, and the men are ordered to report on that day.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Premier Balfour, in a speech last night, expressed in pointed language the universal British apprehension of Russian aggression, especially in relation to India.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 -- Clarence W. Dickerson was this afternoon appointed receiver for the Henry McShane Manufacturing Company, the largest manufacturers of chime bells in the country, and extensively engaged in the manufacture of brass and other metal compounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- There is considerable uneasiness among friends of the President regarding the feeling in Indiana toward his future, and there is an apprehension that Mr. Roosevelt's strength in that State is not progressive.
To the Editor of The New York Times: If you will permit me to say so, it seems to me you wholly mistake the purpose of the illiteracy test for Immigrants.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Five of the horses of the Keenes' stable, Cap and Bells, Dalesman II., Dazzling, Hurst Park II., and Out of Reach, left Newmarket to-day for the United States. The rest of the stable will be sold at Tattersall's Dec. 8, and are expected to bring good prices at auction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- This was the coldest day of the season at Bennings, and none but the regulars turned out. Only one favorite, and that odds-on, won Sam Craig won the handicap at a mile and a furlong handily from River Pirate. Track fast. Summaries:

The Townsend-Downey Shipbuilding Company, whose yard is at Shooter's Island, closed down unexpectedly on Wednesday night, throwing 1,200 men temporarily out of employment. A notice posted at the yard says that work will be resumed again on Monday, and the men are ordered to report on that day.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Nov. 27 -- The doors of the Leavenworth prison will open at 5 o'clock to-morrow morning for Oberlin Carter, formerly a Captain of Engineers in the United States Army, convicted by a court-martial of conspiracy to defraud the Government. He has finished a term of five years' imprisonment, having a credit of ten months for good behavior.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Brigadier Gen. Tasker H. Bliss, in his annual report as President of the Army War College says detailed study of the military problems confronting the United States should form an important part of the work of the college under the direction of the Chief of Staff.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Major James E. Runcie, retired, once the close friend of Brig. Gen. Leonard A. Wood, appeared to-day before the Senate Military Committee which is considering President Roosevelt's recommendation that Gen. Wood be made a Major General.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- There was a little more activity in the local market, but not much of interest wag displayed.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 -- Clarence W. Dickerson was this afternoon appointed receiver for the Henry McShane Manufacturing Company, the largest manufacturers of chime bells in the country, and extensively engaged in the manufacture of brass and other metal compounds.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Nov. 27 -- The doors of the Leavenworth prison will open at 5 o'clock to-morrow morning for Oberlin Carter, formerly a Captain of Engineers in the United States Army, convicted by a court-martial of conspiracy to defraud the Government. He has finished a term of five years' imprisonment, having a credit of ten months for good behavior.

Seffor BUNAU-VARILLA, now somewhat prominent in the public eye, in an article contributed to The Independent, throws some new light upon certain features of the Panama Canal undertaking which is certainly interesting and, may be important. What he says is entitled to respectful consideration for the reason that he is an engineer of acknowledged qualifications and varied experience, and has studied the Panama, routs very thoroughly.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Chained wrist to wrist, their clothing covered with blood and dust and dirt, two beardless boys, Peter Niedermeier and Harvey Van Dine, sat tonight in the presence of Mayor Harrison and Chief of Police O'Neil, calmly confessing to their, share in a three months' career of crime which has included eight murders, the wounding of five other men, and a long series of robberies.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 27 -- Mrs. Katie Ray, twenty-one years old, of 10 McWhorter Street, daughter of Morris Flynn, a well-to-do contractor, is locked up in the Third Precinct Station House to-night on suspicion of having killed her four-year-old niece. Those who have been investigating the case believe the young woman is insane.

"Fort Galvin," a curious little structure built of paving stones at the foot of West Sixteenth Street, was attacked by the police forces last night. The garrison, which consisted of old John Galvin, a character as odd as the habitation which he had built and named after himself, did not surrender until the enemy had begun to batter down his ramparts.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Nov. 27 -- J.S. Rogers of Port Norris, who disappeared over a year ago, leaving debts to the extent of $30,000, and who it was believed at the time had committed suicide, reappeared at his Home yesterday. He has commenced paying off the money he owes. Where he has been during the interval and how he recouped his fortune he declines to tell.

Exchange yesterday provides further encouragement for those whose judgment of securities is governed by this factor. Upon the other hand, there was ample proof that the prevailing moments of strength were artificial, and the recurring weakness as well. In other words, the market continues professional, not reflecting independent or settled opinion in either direction.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 27 -- New records for the new golf links of the Country Club were made in fast order to-day during the match play competitions for the three cups. In the morning Findlay S. Douglas made the record of 77 strokes for the course, playing with John M. Ward. The golf was too fast for the latter, and Ward was beaten by 7 up and 6 to play.

"My mother always gave her children coffee to drink from the time they were old enough to hold a cup, consequently I used it from the time 1 was 2 years old to my 18th year," says a young lady of Potomac, Ill.

He is a convinced Democrat, and his views of the operation of the merit system are naturally modified -- we will not say tainted -- by his partisan proclivities.

There was quite a falling off in activity in the trading in outside securities yesterday, with consequent irregrularlty in price movement. Though the declines for the day outnumbered the advances, there was a good strong undertone in a number of issues. Among the copper stocks Union was the most active, dropping to plain 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Major James E. Runcie, retired, once the close friend of Brig. Gen. Leonard A. Wood, appeared to-day before the Senate Military Committee which is considering President Roosevelt's recommendation that Gen. Wood be made a Major General.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- In the House to-day the Democrats took advantage of the present inaction of Congress to accentuate the division among the Republican leaders.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Faculty representatives of the conference colleges known as the "big nine" began their annual business meeting to-day. The members spent several hours in discussing a communication sent by Superintendent E.G. Cooley of the Chicago Board of Education, requesting that action be taken to prevent colleges from inducing high school students to leave secondary schools before graduation in order to join athletic teams in colleges.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 27 -- Justice of the Peace William Snyder was called before Judge Scott in the Quarter Sessions this morning and sentenced to three months in jail on each of two indictments, charging him with extortion of $5 from a Polander complained of before him. The man wanted the case suppressed, and Snyder, it is alleged, charged him $5 for each allegation, agreeing to withhold the papers from the Grand Jury.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- To say of a man that he "sold his vote" is not slanderous of itself, according to a decision of the full bench of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts, announced to-day. The court further holds that in order to recover damages in such a case the person of whom the words are spoken must allege and prove special damage.

Last week our attention was fixed upon the unique position Solomon occupied in history. He was to be the builder of "The Temple." Whatever else he might do or be was subordinate to this. If was a position of high honor. Spiritually, it is the position every one "beloved of the Lord" occupies to-day, and every one is "beloved."

Bristol is somewhere in the West and Treasurer H. Leroy Ran- dall is absent from town, caused a run on the bank to-day, between fifty and sixty depositors drawing out their deposits.

Nearly all the house parties are being continued and there is nothing of importance happening in society at this week end. The guests for Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt's house party at Idle Hour start this morning. Mr. and Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish will keep their quests at Garrison's-on-Hudson over Sunday.

The seventeenth annual convention of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and Maryland yesterday began a two days' session at Columbia University in this city. Nearly 1,000 college professors and Principals of high schools and secondary schools had registered up to last night.

President Roosevelt's coming to New York to attend the funeral of his uncle, James King Gracie, was the occasion for turning out 560 policemen, under command of Inspector Brooks, and yet it was possible for a man to get near enough to the President to hand him a paper. The man carried a traveling bag which, on examination later, was found to contain three cans, of about the size of fruit jars.

"I have not for a moment been able, nor am I now able, to open my mind to the thought that in any circumstances or upon any consideration I would ever again become the nominee of say party for the Presidency.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27 -- James K Hackett's play "John Ermine of the Yellow-stone" will close after to-morrow night's performance at the Pabst Theatre. The star will then go to New York to rehearse a new piece, with which he hopes for more success.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The twentyfive passengers who were riding on a Public Service Corporation car to-night never saw death so close at hand as when they were stalled for two or three awful moments on the Broadway crossing of the Erie Railroad in the path of an approaching express. The engineer of the train brought his thundering charge to a stop within ten feet of the helpless trolley car.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- There was a little more activity in the local market, but not much of interest wag displayed.

Mme. Adelina Patti demonstrated her business ability yesterday afternoon. According to the letter of her contract, she insisted upon the payment of $5,000 before she would budge one inch toward the stag of the West End Theatre, in West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, where she was advertised to give her farewell concert.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- With the members or both teams in prime condition and eager for the fray, the army and navy football elevens arrived here to-day, ready for their annual game to-morrow on Franklin Field. The West Point players, numbering twoscore men, were the first to get here.

JAMAICA, L.I., Nov. 27 -- The mystery as to the death of Frederick Flandermeyer, who was found dead beside his motor cycle the night of Oct. 22, was explained to-day at the inquest before Coroner. Ruoff in Jamaica. Albert Obercomski, a farm hand, said that the night in question he was run down by a cyclist at the place where Flandermeyer's body was found.

The seventeenth annual convention of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and Maryland yesterday began a two days' session at Columbia University in this city. Nearly 1,000 college professors and Principals of high schools and secondary schools had registered up to last night.

Fast, aggressive, and at times skillful hockey marked the opening game of the season between the teams of Columbia University and the Hockey Club of New York at the St. Nicholas Rink last night, the Hockey Club winning by 6 goals to 4. There was rough playing, too, and in the second half Aitken, one of Columbia's most versatile players, received Quite a scare.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- There is considerable uneasiness among friends of the President regarding the feeling in Indiana toward his future, and there is an apprehension that Mr. Roosevelt's strength in that State is not progressive.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The battleship Maine has suffered another injury. The inability of the ship to make more than 12 knots an hour on her recent cruise to Colon was due to an accident to her engines which occurred before her departure.

The announcement of Prof. Sir WILLIAM RAMSAY, in his lecture before the London. Institution, that the element radium is capable of transmutation by the processes of radiation into the element helium, would be the most sensational of recent scientific statements if the facts upon which it appears to be based were not already familiar in the speculations of the chemists and physicists who have studied the fascinating and perplexing phenomena of radio-activity.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- With the members or both teams in prime condition and eager for the fray, the army and navy football elevens arrived here to-day, ready for their annual game to-morrow on Franklin Field. The West Point players, numbering twoscore men, were the first to get here.

Mme. Adelina Patti demonstrated her business ability yesterday afternoon. According to the letter of her contract, she insisted upon the payment of $5,000 before she would budge one inch toward the stag of the West End Theatre, in West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, where she was advertised to give her farewell concert.

Last week our attention was fixed upon the unique position Solomon occupied in history. He was to be the builder of "The Temple." Whatever else he might do or be was subordinate to this. If was a position of high honor. Spiritually, it is the position every one "beloved of the Lord" occupies to-day, and every one is "beloved."

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27 -- James K Hackett's play "John Ermine of the Yellow-stone" will close after to-morrow night's performance at the Pabst Theatre. The star will then go to New York to rehearse a new piece, with which he hopes for more success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The battleship Maine has suffered another injury. The inability of the ship to make more than 12 knots an hour on her recent cruise to Colon was due to an accident to her engines which occurred before her departure.

-- Mr. BRYAN, taking luncheon in the British capital with great lords and statesmen and diplomats, if he has any sense of humor -- which it's doubtful if he has -- must meditate with quiet mirthfulness on the number of the roads to international eminence, and the extreme queerness of the zigzags by which certain of the roads lead there.

The announcement of Prof. Sir WILLIAM RAMSAY, in his lecture before the London. Institution, that the element radium is capable of transmutation by the processes of radiation into the element helium, would be the most sensational of recent scientific statements if the facts upon which it appears to be based were not already familiar in the speculations of the chemists and physicists who have studied the fascinating and perplexing phenomena of radio-activity.

The entire ribbon trade is upset by the uncertainty regarding the classification for customs purposes of imported silk ribbons. As has already been told, the Treasury Department, basing its attitude on the "Pe Vries" decision, which affected only "baby ribbons," has ordered appraising officers to hereafter classify all silk ribbons as "trimmings" instead of "unenumerated manufactures of silk."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the article against reckless automoblists two and a half columns in length, published by you on Nov. 22. It is the part of the critic to praise as well as censure, but one looks in vain for a good word in favor of the modern motor car, which is rapidly becoming a great factor in our modern life.

Officially inaugurating what in future years is to be the annual athletic competitions and amateur games of teams representing the public gymnasiums and playgrounds attached to ten parks of the City of New York, an athletic meet of unlimited scope, in which thousands of east side children took part yesterday afternoon, occupied Seward Park, at East Broadway and Canal Street.
HAVE you any belief in premonitions or in this business of being able to forecast future events from dreams and things?"

Delegates from building contractors' associations in forty or fifty cities will meet in Chicago on Dec. 10 to take part in the organization of a National building contractors' association, the aim of which will be to regulate the many abuses in the building trade and to provide for National co-operation in handling problems as they arise.

Master Henry Wolsky, the Russian boy violinist, has been engaged to play at the concert to be given at the Beethoven Maennerchor Hall to-day by the Hinrichs Orchestra. He will play the Andante and Finale of the Mendelssohn concerto. This will be young Wolsky's last appearance in this city before going on tour.

Many frequenters of the little East River Park that overlooks Hell Gate and the river in the vicinity of Eigthy-sixth Street have noticed with regret recently that the stump of the big poplar tree shattered by lightning last July has been cut down and no memorial left to mark the site of what was, perhaps, the oldest tree on Manhattan Island.

Delay in performing contracts incurred through the conditions prevailing in the labor and material market during the past two years and the injury to the shipbuilding industry, caused by the recent revelations regarding the promotion of the United States Shipbuilding Company were the causes officially assigned yesterday - for the shut-down of the works of the Townsend-Downey Shipbuilding Company at Elizabeth, N.J., by which over 1,000 men are thrown out of work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your admirable analysis of the financial situation in THE SUNDAY TIMES of Nov. 22 is most encouraging, and I am sure that you will join your readers in congratulating the South upon the elimination of the chief danger to its continued prosperity.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The tower of the German building at St. Louis will be equipped with cast steel bell chimes, consisting of three bells, which have just been completed at Bochum and tested by Prof. Theodor Krause, the Royal Musical Director, and found worthy of the great renown of German bell founders.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The slur that appears on your editorial page this morning directed against that venerable statesman, excellent Christian, and sterling American, Senator George Frisble Hoar of Massachusetts, is, it seems to me, entirely out of place in a newspaper that professes to be independent, and should not be allowed to pass without a protest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- When Speaker Cannon announces his committees it is expected it will be found that he has interfered, more than new Speakers usually do with, the make-up of the committees. But with regard to two committees, both important, there is much gossip, in view of the scandals which have hung around them for a year and Mr. Cannon's intentions with regard to them are the subject of much inquiry.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the people of the United States sanction the Panama affair and the action of President Roosevelt, our historians will have a great deal of their work to do over. The denials of the right of secession and the denunciations of the Southern people will all have to be eliminated.

DULUTH, Nov. 28. -- There is already ample assurance that spirited competition may be expected in the bidding for Chippewa Reservation pine, to be sold under - the Morris law at Cass Lake, Minn., Dec. 5 and 28.

The Committee of One Hundred, which has a record of successful accomplishment in connection with the transfer system, announces that it will hereafter devote its energies to the bringing about of reform in connection with the over-crowding of cars. This is a most necessary public service, but it is one attended with exceeding difficulties, since the cooperation of the public in bringing it about cannot be expected or enlisted.

WILLIAM, the tramp, was seated on a little bank by the side of the highway under the shade of a big elm. The day was warm, but not uncomfortably hot; he was eating a frugal yet satisfying lunch of bread and cheese, and nearby ran a brook from which he could quench his thirst when he had finished eating.
PARIS, Nov. 28. -- The efforts, of Alfred Dreyfus to secure a judicial examination of his case have at last been crowned with success.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- There are several counties in the State in which considerable portions of the proposed barge canal will not follow the course of the present Erie Canal. These are the counties in which the "canalized" Mohawk River, Onelda Lake, the Oswego and Seneca Rivers, Onondaga Lake, , lie, and include Schenectady, Montgomery, Herkimer, Oneida, Oswego, Onondaga, Cayuga, Monroe, Wayne, and possibly other counties.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- The absolute break between Mayor Weaver and the Quay-Durham organization is fully accomplished. There have been rumors of it, threats and ultimatums for months, the Mayor always carrying his point until the present time, when Israel W. Durham, the organization leader, has finally thrown down the gauntlet to the Mayor and the lines of battle have been drawn.

Representatives of Harvard, Yale, Columbia, Princeton, and Brown Universities have met, and arranged the schedule of matches for the Intercollegiate Hockey League championship. The opening contest of the adopted schedule will bring the skaters of Princeton and Brown together on Saturday, Jan. 9.

In the new Christian Science Temple, at Ninety-sixth Street and Central Park West, which has been reared largely through her efforts, and Is to be dedicated to-day, Mrs. Augusta E. Stetson, who organised the First Scientist Church in this city, and was its pastor for sixteen years, was kept busy yesterday denying the reports regarding a threatened split in the congregation growing out of her attitude on certain church matters.

THE number of brides at the first performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last Monday evinced the popularity of matrimony in New York society during the past year. Of course, the most notable were Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt and Mrs. Henry A.C. Taylor. Mrs. Vanderbilt chooses to drees very simply without any display of jewels, but in exquisite taste.

Among feminine appendices the reticule is one particularly subject to depredation, and holds out inducements there-to which it requires considerable moral courage to resist. Instances of the snatching away of this pendulous receptacle by the wayfaring thief who darts around the corner and is gone are repeated from day to day, but they convey no heeded warning to those most concerned.

NEW materials for separate blouses include some very fine and sheer woolens in all-over embroidery in eyelet-hole designs. These are to be most simply made, and are to have silk slips of the same, or a contrasting color, worn underneath them. Jeweled buttons matching the color of either the silk slip or the blouse are used on them.

Importers of wines and olive oils are complaining bitterly of the inadequacy of the pure food law passed at the last session of Congress as a preventive of the importation of adulterated food products. The law, they declare, is all right as far as it goes, but it does not go far enough. It excludes the adulterated goods all right, and causes a great deal of trouble to the importers in doing so.

Dr. MORGAN DIX, in his sermon at Old Trinity on Thanksgiving Day, after enumerating our reasons for National thanksgiving, took appropriate occasion to mark and emphasize some of our National dangers. The newspaper report summarized his remarks on these as follows:

The Lotos Club gave a banquet last night in honor of the new Chinese Minister, Sir Chen-tung-Lung Cheng, which the club members and their guests who have been present on previous occasions say surpassed any previews effort, not that it was more elaborate, but because from start to finish there was more fun and good-fellowship than at any other.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial in to-day's issue on "The Steel Corporation," while the writer has no sympathy with a bear campaign of misrepresentation, he is interested to sec the facts told about this corporation and the truth laid bare with regard to its organization, management, earnings, and capitalization.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Walter J. Travis carried off the honors of the golf tournament which was finished to-day on the links of the Country Club of Lakewood, winning in all three prizes. He won the chief trophy, the Country Club Cup, this afternoon, beating George T. Brokaw, the ex-Princeton golfer, in the final round by the score of 5 up and 4 to play.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Killed in the street by a bullet intended for fleeing burglars, and deserted by a messenger boy friend, appears to have been the fate of seventeen-year-old George Reynolds, son of Capt. Peter Reynolds, of the St. Louis Police Department. Young Reynolds was found this morning in an unconscious condition in Van Buren Street, near Franklin, and died as he was being taken to the Samaritan Hospital.

Recent events on the Isthmus of Panama have called attention to the extreme slowness of postal communication with the cities of Central and South America.
