Only a few points in Asia and semi-civilized Africa are so far distant in time as several of the South American capitals, and the remoter towns of some South American countries are harder to reach by mail than almost any regular Post Office in Africa or Asia.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Although no public announcement of the fact has yet been made, it is understood that Lord Roberts is about to resign as Commander in Chief. He has been much more ill than generally known, is still abed, and the condition of his health requires him to spend the Winter in a Southern climate, probably the Riviera.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The week end at Tuxedo among the fashionable set was full of merriment. Many who came out for Thanksgiving remained over to enjoy the social functions and to participate in the first skating of the season on the Wee Wah Lake. All day Saturday the ice was crowded with, a merry crowd, and the weather, which was perfect, tended to keep the crowd at Tuxedo.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- Seiior Calderon, ex-Minister of Finance of Colombia, and fourteen other Colombians, including the officials here of the republic, have united in a letter appealing to the French public against the recent events at Panama.
PARIS, Nov. 28. -- Reports from the Riviera say the weather there is steadily fine, and Nice, Cannes, and Monte Carlo are rapidly filling up.

AT first sight it looked like a handful of rude boxes jumbled together helter-skelter, bound by a jutting shelf; at nearer view it took the outlines of a crazily built dwelling with a liberal expanse of veranda occupied by seven men so densely enveloped in smoke that their features were entirely obscured, for the balmy air was too still to stir the pungent vapor of their pipes.

It was the East against the West in inter-scholastic football yesterday, and the West won by the overwhelming score of 76 to 0, in the game between the Boys' High School of Brooklyn and the North Division High School of Chicago at Washington Park, Brooklyn. The tally would unquestionably have been larger had not fifteen minutes been cut from the second half on account of darkness.

HORATIO CAMPBELL'S private secretary was a very nice yuung man. His name was Harrison Bright. Mr. Bright, unlike many young men who are "nice," was also intelligent. He had been in Mr. Campbell's office for five years and enjoyed his employers entire confidence.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28. -- It was learned in financial circles to-day that of the bills payable, aggregating $233,508, of the Henry McShane Manufacturing Company, the bell founders, for which a receiver was yesterday appointed, not more than one-half represents indebtedness to banks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read your editorial comment of the 21st concerning the attempt to remove Prof. Bassett of Trinity College, North Carolina, because of his article upon Dr. Booker T. Washington.

Fully twenty people who had paid for passage on the American Line steamship St. Paul, which sailed yesterday morning, were left on the pier after the vessel sailed. The regular sailing time Is 9:30, but the vessel was five minutes late in leaving her oock. Her nose had hardly passed the end of the pier when a crowd of disappointed passengers, most of them holding third-class tickets, came running down the pier.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reading my paper this morning I ran across a well-written letter by Mr. Charles de Kay, speaking of the unfairness of comparison between the old and modern pictures shown at the portrait show in Madison Square.
The trade in medium grade cloaks and suits has suffered an unprecedented slump during November, and the manufacturers who had been figuring on a prosperous year are now revising their estimates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Senator Quay had a short conference to-day with the President about routine matters, according to his own statement. He was asked on leaving the President regarding the recent publications as to his probable candidacy for another term in the Senate, and met the inquiries with replies that were evasive.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of to-day advocating the submission to The Hague tribunal of the question whether the new Republic of Panama should assume any part of the Colombian debt, reference is made to precedents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 13th inst. some excerpts from an address of Dr. Andrews, President of Nebraska University, appeared, in which he is reported as saying on the subject of President Roosevelt's "race suicide" agitation:

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Two sessions of the Horse Show of the Riding and Driving Club of Orange attracted large gatherings of the fashionable set of the Oranges to-day. In the afternoon the children had their turn in the ring with their ponies under saddle and to harness. Ginger, a spirited little bay gelding, shown by Everett Colby, captured the coveted blue rosette in the class in harness and also under saddle.
To the Editor of The New York Times: An interesting letter from "Ed. R." states that Trinity College, Dublin, is an Orange institution; then proceeds to show what it was, in his day.
Prince and Princess Troubetskoi, who have been in Albermarle County, Va., during the Summer, will pass the Winter at Douglaston, L.I. The Princess Troubetskoi was Miss Amelie Rives.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Thanksgiving week, as usual, brought a long quota of visitors to Lakewood, for the air was crisp and sharp and exhilarating. It was delightful to be out of doors, and everybody took advantage of it, while the golfers were agreed that weather conditions had never, more auspiciously favored the opening day of the great Fall tournament of Lakewood.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 28 -- " Dancing in the barn " is very nearly what was accomplished on Thanksgiving Eve, when about 200 members of the social colony gathered in Washington Hall on the occasion of the first assembly of the one hundred and twenty-fifth season. The hall was truly rural in aspect, cornstalks being used for decorations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Jules Levy, the world-famous cornetist, died at his home in this city to-day. The cause was apoplexy. He leaves a wife and three children, all of whom were with him when the end came. The decedent was in his sixty-sixth year.

The close connection between our own and foreign money markets during the past week has caused not only a great deal of investigation and study of such subjects as gold movements, arbitrage, , but has been productive of some interesting comparisons of our own and British methods of conducting financial institutions.

Where the subway turns from Forty-second Street into Broadway, under the north-east corner of those thoroughfares, is the only point along the entire route where the underground structure will support anything more than the street above it. There provision has already been made for the erection of a tall building at any future time when it may be regarded as profitable by the owners of the property.

MANILA, Oct. 10 -- Long Island boasts of being the wheelman's paradise, and so far as regards good roads, level country, and irrigation stations, where the dust may be washed out of the throat, it may still keep the championship. But for the rider who cares as much for strange scenery and queer experiences as he does for the riding the Philippine Islands are ahead.
The cornerstone of the first of the Carnegie libraries which are to be built in Brooklyn, was laid yesterday, afternoon by Mayor Low in the presence of several thousand people.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Nov. 28. -- That quality of the British people that makes them unsympathetic with progress and disinclined to take up with new things is playing an important part in the political campaign now proceeding in England.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While as a citizen of South Carolina, with her interests very much at heart, I am glad that her recent movement toward bringing about immigration into the Commonwealth is attracting attention in other parts of the Federal Union, I am sorry that the true purport of this movement is not exactly understood beyond her doors.
To the Editor of New York Times: Doubtless in thousands of churches throughout our land to-day has been sung the hymn beginning --

CAGAYAN, Mindanao, P.I., Sept. 27 1903 -- There have been many propositions as to the best methods of developing the Philippine Islands. Some of them have been advanced with a view to the betterment of the Filipino, and some with a view to reimbursing the American people for the trouble they have taken With the islands and the inhabitants.

The Foreign Trade Association of America, which will hold its first meeting on Tuesday to elect temporary officers, while organized primarily to promote export trade, does not propose to neglect the import field. That is one reason why the name, "Foreign Trade Association," was chosen instead of a title applying more particularly to the export field, as was it first proposed.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 28 -- Thanksgiving brought a surprise to the hotel men of this resort in the number of visitors. As a rule the hotels are almost deserted on that day so far as new arrivals are concerned, and many of those who are here for the Fall and Winter months either go to their homes for the distinctive, home holiday or to spend the day with friends at house parties.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Hunters' Champion Steep echase and a handicap for two-year-olds, the former being won by Almanzor and the latter by Graziallo, were the features at Bennings to-day.

Several recent commumty-of-interest operations, worked out without involving the actual consolidation of the plants concerned, but rather by means of devices effecting he substantial union of departments in which specific economies are taught have attracted considerable comment in financial circles recently as indicating possibly, a reaction from the craze of "trust" making.

Evening red and morning gray, Two sure signs of one fine day. One does not expect to find in a Government publication anything but hard facts. Certainly one would, not pick up one of these pamphlets in the hope of finding a collection of verses and folklore, but this is what the Department of Agriculture has in its Bulletin No. 33, just issued.

THE members of the Opera Club have reason to feel very comfortable in and contented with their surroundings. Manager Conried has made everything spick and span for them. In fact, he has left them quite undisturbed in their quarters, while the new smoking room he has arranged for the patrons of the Opera House is a little small and cramped.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- By a score of 40 to 6 the West Point football team defeated the Annapolis Naval Cadets today. As a spectacular affair the match was a success, and was witnessed by the large and fashionable crowd that usually gathers here on Franklin Field for this annual contest.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- A public meeting to protest against, the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's new regulation, which goes into effect to-morrow, substituting the Thirty-second and Market Street station for the Broad Street station as the terminal for passengers on through trains between Washington and New York, will be recommended to the Board of Directors of the Merchants and Travelers' Association by its Committee on Passenger Transportation on Monday evening.
HE WAS from the country and so was his wife. They were taking in the city under the escort of a city man who evidently enjoyed their astonishment and comments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- John W. Yerkes, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Treasury, shows that the total receipts of hls bureau for the fiscal year ending June 30 1903, were $230,740,925, at a cost of, collection of 2.07 per cent. The receipts for the-last fiscal year are about $41,000,000 less, than for the year 1902.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 28. -- Old residents of this city, recognise in Arthur Doming, who was arrested in New York City yesterday for annoying President Roosevelt and held for examination as to his sanity, a former Danbury man. Arthur Deming was educated for the ministry while a resident of Danbury.

Last week's events cannot be said to have altered the general situation in any important respect, but it contained one unusual incident illustrative of Wall Street's devious ways in general, and in particular of the artificial character, of current business upon the Stock Exchange.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Sir Thomas Lipton this morning received a telegram, from Lord Lonsdale notifying him that as illness had prevented Emperor William from meeting his yachting representatives it would now be too late to build boats in Europe and make the suggested 1901 race a success. So his Majesty decided to postpone offering his cup for a transatlantic race until 1905.

The feature of the bank statement to which most importance was attributed was the decrease in loans. This seemed to be the result, of liquidation, caused by the high rates for call money last week. Thirty banks showed decreases in loans and twenty-five reported increases.

HE said that his name was Rogor Williams Washington when he called into the office of the Outdoor Relief Department the other day and asked for transportation to Troy. He had been playing Uncle Tom in a traveling "Uncle Tom's Cabin" company, and nature, in anticipating his calling, had given him a very dark skin.

The native American playwright, bless his heart, how familiar he has made us all with his manifold and obvious woes -- the competition of foreign playwrights, the unintelligence of the managers. Year in and year out he dins them into our ears, until one sometimes wonders whether he has the least conception of his far more manifold and far more obvious opportunities.

Another ostrich farm is to be established in California -- in the Santa Clara Valley. The farm at Pasadena has been very successful as an attraction to tourists and a source of profit to its projectors.

SYDNEY, Oct. 19. -- Within the next few days the first Parliament of the Australian Commonwealth will have ceased to exist, but not before it has outlived any practical usefulness it may have possessed. It was elected under the glamour created by the unthinking enthusiasm which accompanied the birth of the nation, and very rarely did its proceedings rise above the level of those in a State Legislature.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The German Automobile Club this evening decided unanimously to hold the race for the James Gordon Bennett Cup next year over a course from Saalburg to Limburg, thence to Ober Ursel and to Saalburg. This action was taken after a commission appointed for that purpose had thoroughly examined the course, in connection with prominent foreign automobilists, including Fournier, who won the race from Paris to Berlin in June, 1901.

When the buildings planned to be erected on three corner plots at Sixty-seventh, Seventieth, and Eighty-first Streets, on Columbus Avenue, have been completed, there will be but one vacant lot on that thoroughfare from end to end, with the exception of both sides of the street between One Hundred and Ninth and One Hundred and Tenth Streets.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Indictments were voted by the Grand Jury to-day against Harvey Van Dein. Peter Neidermeier, and Emil Roeski, the three young bandits who were arrested yesterday at the close of a spectacular man-hunt in Indiana. An indictment was also voted against Gustave Marx, who murdered Officer Quinn, and who was with the others in the majority of their crimes.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Business on the Stock Exchange this week was not exciting. Trading was rather dull, and practically all stocks were quiet. Little was done in Americans, and virtually nothing in the last three days, owing to the Thanksgiving holiday in New York.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 28 -- An old-fashioned comfortable, which has done duty in one family for 135 years, and has had a remarkable history since the time it shielded a Revolutionary spy in the Winter of 1778, has just been sent to David Read of Anita, Iowa, by his sister, Mrs. Jesse Bilby, of Little Washington.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of last Sunday appears an article on "Chauffeurs Who Imperil Lives." A number of liverymen and others are interviewed, and one of the livery stable keepers says it seems to him "that sooner or later we shall have to adopt the course pursued by the Wisconsin farmers and pepper the offenders with buckshot, or rather pepper their tires."

In the final act of "Miss Elizabeth's Prisoner," at the Criterion Theatre, there is promise for a few brief minutes that a good, old-fashioned sword fight will serve to enliven things for those who like that particular sort of thing on the stage. Indeed, Miss Elizabeth herself does her very best to encourage the rival lovers of the play to "get together" after the accustomed manner of the heroes and villains of romantic plays.

THERE is a good deal of quaint dialogue in "The County Chairman." George Ade's new comedy of rural life in the Middle West, with its background of politics and its foreground of almost unbroken comicality save where the homely love interest of the two young people comes to the surface.

THE morning of her wedding day she expressed a desire to have a confidential chat with her mischievous little brother, and in expectation of some parting favor he readily followed her to a room where they could be alone.

Sir Mortimer Durand, G. C. M. G., K. C. S. I., K. C. I. E., the new British Ambassador to Washington to succeed the late Sir Michael Herbert, arrived here last night on the steamship Etruria of the Cunard Line. Lady Durand and the Ambassador's daughter, Miss Amy Durand, did not come over on the Etruria, but remained to spend a few weeks with friends in London.
HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Mrs. Ella M. Grover of Washington, D.C., the widow of Gen. Cuvier Grover, was badly hurt to-day.

Department stores of Europe, are being classified by the National Association of Manufacturers, and the list will be available for the use of the members. It is noted by the association that the Idea of these stores found its way from this country to Germany, where they have multiplied and prospered.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 28. -- The train bearing Oberlin M. Carter arrived in Kansas City at 6:30 this morning. The ex-officer and his little party immediately transferred to the regular east-bound Santa Fe train which started for Chicago at 7:35.

To these who remember the doubts that were entertained respecting Italian finance not very many years ago, the extraordinary revival of Italy will be not only very pleasing, hut also very surprising. Partly the revival has been due to the patriotism of the people, who were ready to make all sacrifices to rehabilitate the credit of the country.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The announcement made here that Frederick D. Colson, who has been assistant coach of the Cornell crews for three years, had been engaged to coach the Harvard crews caused much surprise and regret among the student body. Mr. Colson has so thoroughly mastered Mr. Courtney's methods and his system of handling crews that his position will be hard to fill as a coach.

The magnitude of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, to be held next year, is made apparent in a comprehensive report just submitted to President Roosevelt by President Thomas H. Carter -- of the National Commission in charge. The exposition will exceed in extent, value, and importance any other ever held.

OH, such fun as I have had these last two weeks! " exclaimed the bride to her girl friend. "How do you like the flat, now that it's all furnished? Those? Oh, those are two cardinal birds that I shot on this wonderful trip, and Tom had them mounted for me.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 18 -- Early in December the unique building which will represent the State of Maine at the St. Louis Exposition will begin to take shape not at St. Louis, but on the banks of a little lake far up in the wilderness of Northern Maine, almost to the Canada line.

How large an amount of river and harbor improvement work is now under way or is contemplated by the United States Government is indicated by the fact that at present ten suction dredges are being built, two of which will be sent to the great lakes, two to New York Harbor, two to the Mississippi River, two to Charleston, S.C., one to Galveston, and one to Savannah, Ga.

The largest Congregational Church of New Jersey has begun the erection of a People's Palace, in which there will be dancing and card games as well as church meetings and Sunday school. The cornerstone of the structure was laid yesterday on Jersey City Heights.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What are the ultimate objects of a protective tariff? Is one of them merely a "spite-your-face" policy to compel foreign producers to pay us a premium in order to sell us what we cannot make or cannot make as well? Is it an effort to discourage imports or a means of raising revenue, and nothing more?

What with the announcements of John Wanamaker's purchase of the Old London Street property and of the probable reconveyance of the Trinity Building to the United States Realty and Construction Company and reports as to W.R. Hearst's negotiations for the block bounded by Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 28. -- Interests controlled by Hill and Harriman railroad systems have started forth to obtain control of the coastwise traffic between Puget Sound and California, including the immense, traffic in lumber to San Francisco, San Pedro, and Port Los Angeles. About sixty vessels, including many steam schooners, are engaged in lumber traffic the year around.

The new East River, or Williamsburg, Bridge, the most imposing structure of its kind in the world, is to be formally opened to the public by an appropriate celebration on Dec. 19. Active preparations for this event are now in progress, and it is expected that the full programme of the Board of Aldermen's Celebration Committee will be announced within a few days.

IF THERE is anything that will cure one of envy it is to cultivate the person of whom one is envious," said the philosophical girl? "I never feel discontented very long if I only can get a nearer view of what has made me unhappy. Sometimes it seems as if I would be perfectly happy if only I had the leisure of some of my well-to-do friends.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The appeal of the United States Shipbuilding Company against the decision of Judge Kirkpatrick appointing James Smith. Jr., receiver for the corporation was to-day decided against the company. The opinion rendered by Circuit Court Judges Aeheson, Dallas, and Gray was filed by the former.

The fact is noted by London observers of the market for shares of the insurance companies that their unpaid liability is the chief drawback to their popularity, and yet it cannot be urged that this feature has any direct connection, as might be supposed, with the values at which they are held.

The appraisement of the estate of Collis P. Huntington was made public yesterday. It shows the real and personal property in this State left by the financier and railroad builder to be worth $28,301,765. This, it is understood, was distributed long since in accordance with the provisions of the will.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Subpoenas to-day were served on Postmaster General Payne and First Assistant Postmaster General Wynne to attend the trial of T.W. McGregor. former supply clerk of the rural free delivery service, on an indictment for conspiracy. The trial will begin in Baltimore on Monday.

Organized labor may find another cause for congratulation, and for cheers and other demonstrations of pleasure in the meeting of the Central Federation to-day, in the shut-down of the Townsend-Downey shipbuilding plant at Shooter Island. The company is admittedly in difficulties, but hopes to make satisfactory arrangements to continue business.

Organized labor may find another cause for congratulation, and for cheers and other demonstrations of pleasure in the meeting of the Central Federation to-day, in the shut-down of the Townsend-Downey shipbuilding plant at Shooter Island. The company is admittedly in difficulties, but hopes to make satisfactory arrangements to continue business.

There was much to interest the lover of the lyric drama in the first week's performances at the Metropolitan Open House; and there was abundant food for discussion. The disclosures that were made of the qualities of the new-comers in Mr. Conried's forces were most acceptable.

The fact is noted by London observers of the market for shares of the insurance companies that their unpaid liability is the chief drawback to their popularity, and yet it cannot be urged that this feature has any direct connection, as might be supposed, with the values at which they are held.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Nov. 28. -- A few minutes before 4 o'clock this morning Oberlin M. Carter, ex-Captain of Engineers, walked out of the portals of the Federal Prison at Fort Leavenworth, a free man. At the gates he was met by his uncle, L.D. Carter, and immediately driven in a hack to the Union Station in this city.

NEW BEDFORD, Nov. 28. -- After three hours conference to-day between representatives of the Cotton Manufacturers Association and delegates from the Textile Council the manufacturers declared that they could not, reconsider their action in declaring a 10 per cent, reduction in wages, beginning Monday, Dec. 7.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Accused of breaking and entering a house with burglarious intent, Amella Sutterlein, a twenty-two-year-old woman, was arrested here by the police to-day. Francis Simons appeared in court as complainant against her, and declared that she entered his home at night by breaking a rear window and secured a gold watch, several silver spoons, a breastpin, and a small amount of money.

A shower of electric sparks and a brief spell of excitement among six carloads of passengers followed the blowing out of a fuse on a south-bound Sixth Avenue elevated train shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Rear Admiral Sigsbee spoke on the necessity for an efficient navy at the "Founders' Day" banquet of the Union League to-night. He said in part:

The second day of the seventeenth annual convention of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and Maryland, held at Columbia University yesterday, was devoted to a discussion of the subject of "Athletics in Their Mutual Relation to Schools and Colleges."

PITTSBURG, Nov. 28. -- "The Federal National Bank will open its doors for business within the first ten days of December." said President J.A. Langfitt, who returned from Washington to-day with a committee of the officers of the institution. President Langfitt will retire.

The end of the movement of currency to the interior for the harvest of 1003 was recorded last week. The beginning of the returns to the financial heart of the nation of the currency that was sent out between Aug. 27 and Nov. 26, 1903, will appear throughout December, and during January the money will come back raster than it went.

SENDING their only daughter to college was no joke to Mr. and Mrs. Banister, but they solaced themselves with the thought that it was for her good. Mrs. Banister was sure it would give Amy poise and culture and place her among the foremost ranks of the highly educated women.
BUTLER, Penn., Nov. 28. -- Since the 15th of September this town has had more than 1,300 cases of typhoid fever and 15 deaths. One death was reported to-day and new cases continue to develop.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 28. -- A report to-night from Wadsworth, Nev., where the Harriman special with the railroad financiers who have been to Utah inspecting the Lucin cutoff across Great Salt Lake gives an interview with Mr. Harriman in which he says:

The annual dinner of the New York Alumni Association of the Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity, held in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria last night, was the occasion of a demonstration which was considered of good augury for the success of a possible movement to unify the college fraternity men of the city for good government.

The suits brought by the Texas State Insurance Department for the forfeiture of the charters of forty-three fire insurance companies for alleged violation of the Texas anti-trust law in connection with agreements as to uniform fire insurance rates have been carried over until the January term of the local courts.

Packing cases that tick are not considered desirable shipments by steamship owners, and one such consignment caused a small panic on the Old Dominion pier, at the foot of Beach Street, just before the steamship Monroe sailed for Old Point Comfort and Norfolk Friday afternoon.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Money was in firm demand and active in the market to-day, owing to the payment of new Treasury bills. The preparations for the month-end reduced the supplies materially, though the scarcity was mitigated by disbursements from the Bank of England. Discounts were steady.

A MIST hovered over the meadow, faintly veiling the spirea overtopping the blueberry shrubs, and giving a lavender tone to the rest of the eglantine. The spreading sumacs on each side of the narrow path reached out damp leaves that brushed her gown as she passed.

At the risk of being seriously injured, Deputy Police Commissioner Ebstein rescued a young woman last night. She was the occupant of a carriage that was smashed to bits by a south-bound Sixth Avenue surface car at Thirty-ninth Street.

ALBANY, Nov. 28. -- At the Executive Chamber and afterward at the Executive Mansion this afternoon, M. Linn Bruce, Chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, had a talk with Gov. Odell, which lasted for about four hours, and during which the situation of Republican politics was gone over very thoroughly.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 29 -- The recent announcement that a reduction of freight grates on iron and steel manufactures intended for exportation is being made by the railroads for the purpose of encouraging exports of American, iron and steel manufactures lends interest to some figures compiled by the Department of Commerce and Labor through its Bureau of Statistics regarding the commerce of the United States in iron and steel manufactures.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Nov. 29 -- Robert P. Skinner, United States Consul General at Marseilles, who has gone to Abyssinia to conduct negotiations with the Negus Menelik, reached Harrar yesterday.

MADRID, Nov. 29 -- It is stated that the Government has not withdrawn the exequaturs of all the Venezuelan Consuls in Spain, as was reported. Spain, however, will, it is asserted, refuse to grant fresh exequaturs to Venezuelan Consuls until the questions pending between the two countries have been settled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The report of Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Bristow on the postal investigation, given out to-day, shows that in 1893 a great conspiracy to loot the Government was Started in the Post Office Department. It shows that that conspiracy spread into division after division, until wholesale robbery of the people became a regular and recognized feature of the letting of contracts.

In the memorandum of the President and the report of Fourth Assistant Postmaster General BRISTOW, which it accompanies, the public gets for the first time a comprehensive view and a connected narrative of the frauds in the Post Office Department which have been for some months under investigation.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 29 -- It is announced that the Somerset Coal Company, the W. K. Niver Coal Company, and the Merchants' Coal Company, which own and operate a number of mines in the Meyersdale (Penn.) region, have decided to make a reduction of 10 cents a ton in the wages paid the miners.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 29 -- In a statement to the police late last night Mrs. Catherine Ray, who was arrested late Friday night charged with causing the death of her niece, Mary Couning, aged four years, at her home, 10 McWhorter Street, implicates her husband, Joseph Ray, in the affair, which she asserts was caused by an accident.

A peculiar accident happened at Tuscola, Ill., on Saturday in connection with a ring which was lost by Mrs. Joseph G. Cannon thirty-one years ago. At that time Congressman Cannon, now Speaker of the House of Representatives at Washington, was a practicing attorney at Tuscola. Shortly after his marriage to Miss Reed, the latter was in her husband's office one day when she accidentally dropped her engagement ring, perhaps in the waste basket.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The question is often asked, To whom should the public be grateful for the benefits we derive from Central Park, more especially since the death of Andrew H. Green? Permit me to give you a history which can be borne out by records of the period in which it was first originated:
SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Nov. 29 -- Gen. VVos y Gll arrived here last night on the German cruiser Falka. The Falka started at daylight this morning on her return to Santo Domingo.

-- It really does seem, when so many and such important problems concerning schools and colleges cry for solution, that it was a pity to waste the time of the educators now assembled in convention here with a long tirade against the newspapers for paying more attention and giving more space to the athletic sports of undergraduates than to their achievements as scholars.

TOLEDO, Nov. 29 -- H.S. Alward, representing Mrs. Langtry, has purchased two mares of George H. Ketcham, the owner of the trotter Cresceus, which are to be sent to her farm at Exerling, England. One of these mares is a seven-year-old chestnut with a trial mark ot 2:16. She is a half-sister of Cresceus, being by Robert McGregor and out of Eden Bell, 2:14 1/4, the dam of Clara D.
BUTLER, Penn., Nov. 29 -- Three deaths occurred here to-day from typhoid fever and new cases are being reported constantly. One doctor has sixty-five feyer patients, and cannot attend to all.

Senator TELLER pays to Mr. CLEVELAND the tribute of spiteful criticism. His rejoicing that the unprecedented public career of the ex-President is not to be renewed is natural and calls for no comment. But one of his remarks expresses a sentiment that is shared to some extent by thoughtless persons in the Democratic Party and is diligently cultivated by partisan opponents.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 29 -- By a decision "rendered yesterday by Judge Wyckersham at Valdez, the Havemeyers, the New York sugar refiners, are given undisputed title to rich bonanza copper mines located 160 miles from Valdez, on the Chittyna, a branch of the Copper River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- James H. Worman, United States Consul General at Munich, has reported to the State Department that the University of Munich has opened its doors to women students. "Hitherto no women were permitted to matriculate in the German universities," he says, adding:

After the United States Circuit Court of Appeals decided at St. Paul in April that the Northern Securities merger was illegal, Prof. C.C. Langdell of the Harvard Law Faculty contributed an article to The Harvard Law Review for June in which he analyzed and severely criticised the opinion and decree of the court.

It is suggestive of great possibilities that a Chinese gentleman who learned to play baseball in a Yankee school -- and learned it well -- should be the Minister of China to this country. Sir CHEN-TUNG-LUNG'S little speech at the Lotos Club on Saturday evening was at once sensible and witty, and stood comparison favorably with the utterances of his very popular predecessor.

A very interesting description of the aims of the immigration movement in South Carolina was given in our columns yesterday by Mr. CLARENCE CUNINGHAM of Charleston. We had formed an incomplete notion of the movement from the press report, and we are very glad to receive fuller information.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Republican National Committee will assemble to this city Dec. 11, less than two weeks from this time, to select a place and designate a time for holding the National Republican Convention. Already the canvass has begun for choice of cities. The principal contestants are likely to be Chicago, Milwaukee, and St. Louis.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company, at Mahwah, has announced that it will double the size of its works at once and employ 500 more men. As a result, land values have risen to such an extent that it is feared it will be impossible to build the homes that will be required for the new men.

The battleship Indiana, now anchored in the North River, is to be taken around to the Brooklyn Navy Yard in a day or two and placed out of commission. She is to receive a thorough overhauling, and the work to be done on her, it is believed, will cost about $700,000.

In a report to the Secretary of War, Gen. YOUNG, Chief of Staff, makes the following recommendations respecting the re-establishment of the canteen, abolished largely through the efforts of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union:
BOGOTA, Nov. 29 -- The following notes have been exchanged between United States Minister Beaupre and Carles Rico, the Colombian Foreign Minister.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- A verdict of guilty was returned to-day in the case of Alderman John J. Brennan and his two political friends, Charles McCarle and Herbert F. Kent, who have been on trial for violations of the election laws during the judicial election last June.

Last week's price movement indicates business small in volume, narrow in range and highly professional in characteristics. Only 79 stocks moved a point and advances and declines were as closely as possible there 40 advances. The upward movement was a little more emphatic among the bonds, there being in that market 23 advances and 18 declines.

PANAMA, Nov. 29 -- The newspapers of the Isthmus are asking the Government of the Republic of Panama to occupy and establish sovereignty over the Islands of San Andres, Providence, and Albuquerque as well as other smaller islands in the Caribbean Sea between the eighty-first and eighty-fourth degrees of longitude, as the territorial limits of the new republic lie between longitude seventy-nine degrees and eighty-four degrees.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Nov. 29 -- When ex-First Assistant Postmaster General Perry S. Heath, now proprietor of The Salt Lake Tribune, and also Secretary of the Republican National Committee, had read the report of Mr. Bristow and the comments of the President to-night, he said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The first week of real work in Congress ended to-day. Perfunctory as the Capitol performances have been, one surprising and unexpected fact has developed. It relates to one of the most interesting questions that the session has brought up, though not a question officially before Congress -- the question of the revival of Democracy under its two new leaders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- At the same time that the report of Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Bristow was made public to-day President Roosevelt's memorandum thereon was also given out. The President approves the findings of Mr. Bristow, and declares that the prosecution of the corrupt officials must be pushed with the utmost vigor.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 29 -- Morning papers will officially announce, the resignation of Frederick Courtney, third Episcopal Bishop of Nova Scotia, who has accepted the rectorship of St. James's Church, New York, offered him without soliciting. His resignation will take effect April 25, the sixteenth anniversary of his ordination as Bishop.

The quiet Bedford district of Brooklyn was thrown into a state of excitement yesterday morning by a fox hunt, in which two big policemen and a howling mob of small boys took part. The chase ended by Reynard landing in the clutches of the law, but there was no death, and the brush remained with him.

That the magnificent edifice of the First Church of Christ, Scientist, at Ninety-Sixth Street and entral Park West, which was dedicated yesterday, had been patterned according to plans divinely revealed to the Trustees, very much after the fashion in which the style of the Tabernacle was revealed to Moses on Mount Sinai, was the assertion made by Mrs. Augusta E. Stetson in her dedicatory address.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The future course of the stock market is now considered to depend to a great extent upon the Far Eastern situation. The previous week's revival made further progress last week, especially in the mining market. This had an encouraging effect all round, and should Russia and Japan arrive at an amicable settlement of their difficulties it is believed that a period would put to the long-continued depressions.

The political movement of the Central Federated Union, started the previous Sunday, vanished into thin air at its meeting yesterday. That the matter was not taken seriously and was merely the result of the enthusiasm caused by the golden accounts given by the delegates of the British Trades Union Congress to the American Federation of Labor of the political successes of the unions in England was soon made manifest.

The additional loops at the New York terminal of the Brooklyn Bridge have been in use long enough to permit the disinterested observer of the nightly conditions at that point to form a very correct judgment as to the extent to which they have relieved the congestion during the rush hours.

Alfred Waltz, who was employed as handy man about Gray Tower, the country home of William Welsh Harrison, at Glenside, near Philadelphia, and who disappeared on Thanksgiving Day simultaneously with $20,000 worth of Mrs. Harrison's jewels, was arrested here yesterday in a room on the fourth floor of the tenement house at 1,371 First Avenue.

Charles T. Yerkes, who arrived from London a few days ago, said yesterday that the surface and underground electric lines in and about London, which a syndicate of which he is the head is building at an expenditure of $85,000,000, and of which about $40,000,000 is American capital, would be finished about April next.
Senator Thomas C. Platt said yesterday in answer to a question:

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Peter Neidermeyer, one of the members of the quartet of young bandits who for the last six months have terrorized Chicago, in another confession to-day added several more crimes to the long list already charged against him and his companions, Van Dine, Merx, and Roseki.

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- Although the reasons of Emperor William for withdrawing his offer of a cup for a transatlantic yacht race are regarded by his yachting advisers as sufficient, there were other considerations that made a withdrawal of the trophy for next season the easiest way out of the tangle caused by the inability of the New York Yacht Club and the Atlantic Yacht Club to agree on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- "The country is confronted with a very grave problem," says Secretary of Agriculture Wilson in his seventh annual report, made public to-day, referring to the boll weevil in the cotton belt, "as the invasion of this insect must necessarily mean a complete revolution in present agricultural methods."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day affirmed the constitutionality of the eight-hour law of the State of Kansas, regulating labor on public works.

Mr. CHARLES F. MURPHY'S frank announcement that in appointments to the chief offices of the City Government the administration of Mayor McCLELLAN will give preference to Tammany district leaders may be read with surprise and disappointment in some quarters and among certain classes of citizens, but the voters who supported Mayor Low and labored to elect him will not share these emotions.

SHREVEPORT, La,. Nov. 30. -- In the presence of a crowd of about 1,200 whites and negroes, Phil Davis, Walter Carter, and Clint Thomas, all negroes, were lynched this afternoon about 1 o'clock within a short distance of Belcher, which is twenty miles from Shreveport.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- A very fashionable company assembled this afternoon at Corcoran house, where Miss Lydia Eustis gave a song recital from 4 until 5 o'clock. The company was seated in the famous ballroom, which has been the scene of more distinguished gatherings than any other private room in Washington.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 30. -- The first official action by the Government toward erecting a dam at Culloms Ripple, nine miles below this city, was taken to-day, when proceedings in condemnation were instituted in the United States Court to secure the property necessary for the erection of the dam.
WAUKEGAN, Ill., Nov. 30. -- The first person to report refusal on the part of Dowie's bank to turn over to him money which he deposited in it is A.W. Graham of Waukegan.

It was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the Building Trades Employers' Association, in the Townsend Building, that Benjamin J. Traitell and James K. Strong have been appointed by the association as delegates to a convention in Chicago, beginning Dec. 10, to form a National association of building contractors.

Columbia College freshmen fought a fight with their traditional enemies, the sophomores, yesterday. Night found them banqueting at the Ansonia depleted in number, but proud and flushed with victory. Up near the college ten of their men still lingered in a dungeon deep, but a hundred of them scratched and tuckered out, but creditable classmen, sat at the banquet board, indifferent to the sophomores who in the street were hooting and yelling in impotent wrath.

President Winthrop E. Scarritt of the Commonwealth Trust Company, which in the days of the United States Shipbuilding Company was the Trust Company of the Republic, announced yesterday that that institution, from the present time, would assume an active rather than a passive attitude with respect to the litigation in which the affairs of the bankrupt shipbuilding combination are now involved.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- It was announced to-day that many prominent Republican leaders in this part of the State would urge the nomination of Nevada N. Stranahan for Governor.

Myron T. Herrick, Governor-elect of Ohio, who was the guest of honor at the annual dinner of the Ohio Society of New York, which was held last night at the Manhattan Hotel, was asked during the evening if Senator Hanna would be a candidate for the Presidency. In reply he said:

Gen. Joseph E. Wheeler was at Fort Hancock, Sandy Hook, yesterday, making arrangements for the testing of a new gun by the Government authorities. The gun is the invention of a Cleveland man, and is said to be absolutely without recoil. Several private tests have been made with it, all of which, it is said, have been most successful.

MEDINA, Nov. 30. -- The Orleans County Board of Supervisors to-day retained an attorney and asked a thorough investigation of the jail and Sheriffs Office, which it is believed will result in charges being preferred to the Governor against Sheriff Fred Rice and possibly his deputies, Charles Reddy and Daniel Drennan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of late there have been various scandal disclosures in our newspapers. But none has reflected upon our public officials and men prominent in public affairs more than those connected with the postal system. The "trafficking" in Post Office appointments is justly condemned, and the attempt of any Government official to "hush up" the proper investigation has been rightly frustrated and the particular official severely reprimanded.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The United States Government has given directions looking to the recognition of King Peter Karageorgevitch of Servia.

C.H. Gillette, Secretary of the American Automobile Association, returned yesterday from Syracuse, where he attended the meeting of the New York State Automobile Association, which completed its organization on Saturday evening with the election of the following officers: President -- W.M. H. Hotchkiss, Buffalo Automobile Club; Vice President -- Charles M. Page, Albany Automobile Club; Secretary-Treasurer -- Frederick H. Elliott, Syracuse Automobile Club.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- The French Government, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, is determined to exclude the Dreyfus affair from discussion in Parliament, thus preserving its purely judicial character. It is the general feeling among the more enlightened and moderate of all parties that the affair must not again acquire political significance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Germany has recognized the Republic of Panama as a sovereign and independent State.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As a constant reader of THE TIMES, I would ask you to allow me a little space in your valuable paper to state the following:

PARIS, Nov. 30. -- The general belief prevails in well-informed circles that the commission appointed to pronounce upon the admissability of the request of Alfred Dreyfus for a judicial revision of his case will submit its conclusions to the Minister of Justice within a week, and some persons say before the end of the present week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 30. -- One of Harvard's oldest and most famous institutions is to be closed by order of President Eliot, who hopes in this way to eliminate one of the main sources of dyspepsia and indigestion among the students.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Following its announced policy of centralization, the International Harvester Company has decided to lay off 7,500 of its 19,000 employes and thus effect a saving of $5,000,000 a year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Several correspondents have made attempts to make arguments for the South's right to secede out of the Panama affair. The object of this letter is to point out the weakness of such reasoning, which is based upon numerous fallacies arising often from lack of due sense of proportion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Mabel Richardson won the chief event, a handicap for two-year-olds and upward, at Bennings today, and Gould took the hurdle race. Coppelia and, Nine Spot were the only successful favorites. Track fast. Summaries:

We have already made some comment upon the first Sunday census of church attendance taken by the Church News Association. That was for the part of Manhattan Island north of Central Park. The second census, taken on Sunday, Nov. 22, and of which the result was printed in yesterday's TIMES, dealt with what may fairly, though rather roughly, be described as the region abreast of the Park.

At their regular quarterly meeting yesterday the Directors of the Republic Iron and Steel Company determined to postpone the declaration of the dividend on the company's preferred stock, which in the usual course would be paid at the beginning of Jannary. In addition to this action, the Directors elected John W. Gates as a member of the board to succeed August Belmount who resigned.
BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- The new comic opera "My Lady Molly" was presented at the Park Theatre to-night, with Andrew Mack in the leading role. The opera is the work of Sidney Jones, author of "San Toy."

The second week of the opera season opened with the largest audience and the greatest demonstration of enthusiasm that have been in evidence at the Metropolitan since the opening night. The opera was "Alda," one of the surest of all the operatic manager's bids for public favor, especially when it is presented with the excellent singers and the luxurious scenic accessories that have of recent years been seen at the Metropolitan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- W.H. Landvoight, who was Superintendent of the Classification Division of the Post Office Department when removed from office, and who was Superintendent of the Registry System when the manifold paper was introduced there, which matter was a part of the Bristow report, to-night declared that Mr. Bristow offered no facts in his report as a reason for his allegations against him, (Landvoight,) and that what he did say was not true.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Conditions in the local market continued unchanged, trading being at a standstill. Local financial institutions are not encouraging operations in the market, as money is steadily working closer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is not the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES, issue of Monday, touching the statistics of church attendance in the Central Park region, somewhat misleading? On the face of the report it would seem to convey the impression that the figures embrace the total attendance for the entire Sunday.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 30. -- James Fullerton of Red Lodge, Mont., National President of the Sportsmen's Game protective Association, who announced that he would begin a fight against the abuses which he alleged exist in Yellowstone National Park, passed through the city to-day on route to Washington.

Speaking before the members of the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York, gathered at their one hundred and forty-seventh annual banquet at Delmonico's last evening, Andrew Carnegie and President Woodrow Wilson of Princeton University moved four hundred hearers to cheers time and time again.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Some new facts have come out to-day with regard to the House Committee on Naval Affairs, the scandals attaching to which department make a reform in the personnel possible.
LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Money was in strong demand in the market to-day. Discounts were steady.

Business went on as usual yesterday in Earlem, notwithstanding the fact that the descendants of the settlers of the land had come there from far and near to organize and claim as their own title to the fields that have born a great city of tall buildings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Major Gen. John R. Brooke, retired, ex-Governor General of Cuba, to-day gave testimony before the Senate Committee on Military Affairs which charged insubordination against Gen. Leonard Wood.

Miss Helen Gould yesterday authorized the publication of some correspondence between her private secretary. Miss Elizabeth Altman, and the Rev. Dr. Wilbert W. White, President of the Bible Teachers' Training School in this city, relative to an offer of prizes by her for the best essays on the origin and history of the different versions of the Bible used in the Roman Catholic and Protestant Churches.

MONTREAL, Canada, Nov. 30. -- R.E. See, Marshal of the Missouri Supreme Court, has been in conference the past few days with D.J. Kelly, legislative agent of the $20,000,000 Baking Powder Trust, who fled to Canada following his indictment by the Cole County (Mo.) Grand Jury on the charge of bribery growing out of the celebrated alum scandal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The publication of the Bristow report has revived talk about the continuance of Perry Heath as Secretary of the National Republican Committee.

COLON, Nov. 30. -- Luis Deroux, who was a member of the Colombian House of Representatives from Panama, who made a speech in the House on Oct. 2 warning Colombia to sign the Hay-Herran canal treaty immediately or she would lose the Isthmus the day Congress closed, and who was instrumental in bringing about the appointment of Gen. Obaldia as Governor of Panama, has arrived here from Bogota, whence he started Nov. 14.

Democrats from all five boroughs of the city, with a liberal sprinkling from up-State sections, gathered at the St. George Hotel, in Brooklyn, last night to do honor to State Senator Patrick H. McCarren for his leadership of the party to victory in the transpontine borough during the last municipal campaign.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30. -- Under the will of William Wyman, the philanthropist, probated to-day, Johns Hopkins University will receive his estate, valued at over $500,000, upon the death of his daughter, Mrs. Helen Wyman Rollins, widow of the Rev. Samuel Rollins.

BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- The money market continues dull and firm. Both the demand and the supply are small. Call loans, 5 1/2 @ 6 per cent.; time loans, collateral, 5 @ 6 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 6 @ 6 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 3 @ 6 per cent.: New York funds, 5c premium.

Critics of the Municipal Art Commission are dissatisfied with the new ceiling in the Aldermanic Chamber at the City Hall and have formally shown their disapproval by declining to accept the recommendation of its sub-committee that it be adopted. This develops a state of affairs in which it may be necessary for the artist, Taber Sears, to bring suit in order to get his compensation for the decoration.

The ill-considered talk of the Rev. THOMAS R. SLICER, D.D., in his address at Cooper Institute on Sunday night will not tend to the upbuilding of that gentleman's reputation for sane thinking. For example, the following would appear to the average reader as rather reckless generalizing:

With an average of .517, Giles, the third baseman of the Forest Hill Field Club, leads the Amateur Baseball League in batting. F. Quimby of the Crescent Athletic Club finished the season in second place with an average of .500.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The report of Assistant Postmaster General Bristow on the postal scandal throws little light on a phase of the subject concerning which here is as much popular curiosity as on any other -- namely, the relation of Congressmen to the graft conspiracy.

Judge Holt, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday appointed Henry E. Ide receiver of the Townsend-Downey Shipbuilding Company, the announcement of whose suspension of operations was made last Friday. The bond of the receiver was fixed at $100,000, and he will take full charge of the property of the company today.

With an average of .517, Giles, the third baseman of the Forest Hill Field Club, leads the Amateur Baseball League in batting. F. Quimby of the Crescent Athletic Club finished the season in second place with an average of .500.

There was sent out from the Detective Bureau yesterday a general alarm for E. Burke Scott, Treasurer of "The OfficeBoy," company, now appearing at the Victoria Theatre under the management of C. B. Dillingham. Mr. Scott disappeared Saturday night as completely as though the earth had swallowed him up.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1. -- The bull campaign of 1903-1904 in cotton was inaugurated to-day when W.P. Brown bid 11.95 for 25,000 bales for March delivery. This bid was at an advance of 29 points over the close of yesterday. Brown was a heavy buyer and bidder in January and May also.

Democrats of all sorts and denominations flocked to Tammany Hall yesterday to urge claims for appointments on Charles F. Murphy. They got very little satisfaction from the leader of the organization, however, who told them all that nothing would be decided about appointments until Mayor-elect McClellan resigns from Congress and turns his attention to municipal affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Mr. Grosvenor, in the House, while speaking of the action of the Senate in connection with the Cuban bill, said that the Senate reported the bill back and it was assumed that they wanted to stay here for some purpose, so they did not offer any resolution to Adjourn.

With a whirl of heavy-draught humor, a snapping of fiery temper, the throbbing of a large heart, and all the rest of the windwool effects of character as it is theatrically supposed to be in her own Middle West, Miss Alice Fischer made her second metropolitan appearance as a star last night at the Bijou in Leo Ditrtchstein's "What's the Matter with Susan?" and was uproariously greeted by her many friends.

INSULATING ELECTRIC WIRES. -- A company furnishing electric power, the Supreme Court of Arizona holds, in the case of Phoenix Light and Fuel Company vs. Bennett (74 Pacific Reporter 48,) is not guilty of negligence because in carrying Its wires into a building it falls to insulate against electricity having its origin in the clouds or atmosphere.

During the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday it was definitely agreed that all of the big public improvement propositions now pending will be allowed to go over to the McClellan administration, this being in accord with the policy outlined right after the election.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Senate Committee on Post Offices has discussed informally the necessity of investigation by Congress of the Post Office scandals and has got as far as a determination to institute a preliminary examination of the papers in the case.
Mitchell A.C. Levy has sold the southeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Third Street, a plot 50 by 100, to John McClelland Co., builders. A ten-story loft building will be erected on the site.

PARIS, Dec. 1. -- The Associated Press learns that Japan and Russia are on the verge of a settlement of the Far Eastern controversy which promises to dissipate the war cloud that has been hanging over both countries. This settlement will be the result of the negotiations which have been in progress for some time past, and which were assisted by the friendly representations of France to Russia and of Great Britain to Japan.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- The visitation to Gov. Odell by New York County Republican district leaders was continued to-day.

Policemen and their officers were tried yesterday at Police Headquarters in an effort to find out how it happened that 560 uniformed men failed to protect the President of the United States from the intrusion of a vendor of medicated charcoal while Mr. Roosevelt was attending the funeral of his uncle, James King Gracle, at the Church of the Holy Communion, Sixth Avenue and Twentieth Street, Friday morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- What appears to be the beginning of the end of Zion City and John Alexander Dowie's religious autocracy has come to pass, due in part to the failure of his recent trip to New York.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- The Supreme Court of Massachusetts to-day denied the motion of Kidder. Peabody Co. to dismiss the plaintiff's bill in the case of Doherty vs. the Mercantile Trust Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Speaker Cannon hast had more trouble in making up the Labor Committee than any other. The labor agitation of the past few months has inspired the belief that unless this committee is carefully handled it may be the source of considerable annoyance in Congress.

Assurance was given last night at the close of a number of conferences between representatives of the Moffly Committee of Philadelphia and interested parties here that a hopeful prospect lay before the reorganization plan for the Consolidated Lake Superior Company.

Outplayed by the superior balk-line method of Edward McLaughlin, the Buffalo professional billiard player, Byron Gillette, fell far behind last night in the first block of 300 points of their match. The two veterans with the cue met in Maurice Daly's academy. It was evident during the first few innings that Gillette was not versed in the latest carroms of the intricate mode of eighteen-inch balk line with two counts in balk.
LONDON, Dec. 1. -- With the month-turn to-day the pressure for money slackened in the market appreciably. Discounts were easier.

When the body Is clogged up by the use of improper food and sickness sets in there is nothing so good as a "house cleaning," and the right way to do this is to change the food, for although taking medicines may afford temporary relief, a complete change of food is much the surest and safest way.

YOKOHAMA, Dec. 1. -- A Japanese medical student was arrested to-day on suspicion of an attempt to assassinate the Marquis Ito. He carried a dagger concealed under his kimono when arrested at the Marquis's villa at Miso.

About eighty members and guests were present at the annual dinner of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club in the Hotel Manhattan, Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street, last night. The dinner was preceded by the annual meeting of the organization, at which officers for 1904 were elected, in addition to the amending of part of the constitution and some of the by-laws.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1. -- The transfer of money from New York to this city is said by local bankers to be of no serious significance. The greater portion of the coin is intended to supply a market that is slightly restricted on account of the recent heavy outlay for taxes and crop movement.

Trouble likely to interfere with the opera at the Metropolitan Opera House is impending because of the two women harpists in the orchestra. The Musical Mutual Protective Union. Local Lodge 310, of the American Federation of Musicians threatens to order the orchestra to strike unless the harpists join the union in short order.
In the City of Waterbury eight young men have been sent to jail to serve ten months' sentences for participation in the riots attending the street-car strike disturbances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Dr. Herran, the Colombian Charge d'Affaires, called at the State Department to-day for the first time in many weeks for the purpose, he said, of informing Secretary Hay of Gen. Rafael Reyes's arrival here, of the object of his mission, and to pay a friendly call upon the Secretary.

-- According to The Montgomery (Ala.) Advertiser, Northern critics who see in the Bassett episode an illustration of a Southern tendency to limit or deny freedom of speech "virtually claim that men like BASSETT should freely express their opinions, but the rest of us shouldn't criticise them, because that would be to 'suppress free speech.'"

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- H.H. Bender, Fiscal Supervisor of State Charities, issued a statement to-night in reply to charges published in certain newspapers regarding purchases of sugar, tea, and butter for the State charitable institutions under his jurisdiction. He denies absolutely the published statement that he sent the following telegram:

To the Editor of The New York Times: A correspondent in your paper of Nov. 28 complains of the injustice (?) done to churchgoing Protestants in the official reports, where their attendance at their respective edifices makes a poor showing compared with the attendance of Catholics at public worship.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 1. -- Althrough the features of the examination of ex-City Attorney Lant K. Salsbury in the water boodle cases in the police court today were lacking in sensational disclosures to compare with yesterday's startling revelations, his testimony was as interesting because of voluntary statements made while under cross-examination.
BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- The beginning of the last month of the year finds the money market quiet and firm. The supply of funds is small, but the demand is light.

State Senator McCarren's domination of the Brooklyn Democratic organization was made plain at the first meeting of the General Committee, elected at the last pri- maries, which, was held in the Thomas Jefferson Building, in Court Square, last night. The meeting was very largely attended, but conspicuous among the absentees was Richard W. Bainbridge, the Chairman of the old General Committee.

NEWPORT, Dec. 1. -- The project to close up the highways in the vicinity of the residence of Oliver H. B. Belmont and open a new highway through Mr. Belmont's land connecting Bellevue Avenue with Ocean Avenue was renewed before the Board of Aldermen this evening, but met with little favor, the Aldermen voting 3 to 2 to lay all petitions on the table.

Yesterday's prices upon the Stock Exchange continued their upward tendency begun upon Monday, and assumed a more wholesome tone. By this is meant that the stocks of industrials which are made artificially scarce were not leaders of the advance upon a market as narrow as manipulated.

The first for this season of the long established set of dances known as the Junior Cotillions took place in the large ballroom at Sherry's last evening. The members and guests were received by several of the patronesses, including Mrs. M. Dwight Collier, Mrs. Dallas Bache Pratt, Mrs. Arthur M. Dodge, Mrs. Charles A. Peabody, and Mrs. Francis V. Greene.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- To-day's card at Bennings proved a good one for the bookmakers, as not an actual favorite won. The steeplechase was one of the best jumping races ever seen here, and was decided only in the last sixteenth, Woolgatherer winning from Connover in a hard drive.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report of the attendance on the services in the churches of the Central Park district for Nov. 22, as printed in this morning's issue of THE TIMES is decidedly inaccurate in at least one instance.

CLEVELAND, Ohio. Dec. 1. -- A movement has been started to inaugurate a National amateur trotting racing circuit simliar to the Grand Circuit except that amateurs only will be eligible to drive and no pools will be sold or betting allowed. The races will be competed for with cups or plate as the only prizes, as money premiums will be prohibited.

Character of Trading. -- While in some respects the course of the market yesterday was less artificial than on other recent days, it still remained true that commission house business was small, and that the bulk of the trading represented, as heretofore, nothing more than transactions by the room traders.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- Increased activity, a better distribution of business, and a general tone of firmness characterized the trading in the local market today. Reading was in demand on a continuance of cold weather and the report that a large reduction in the coal in storage has been made the past week.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- "An English Daisy," one of Weber Fields's productions, was presented for the first, time in America before a crowded house at the Globe Theatre to-night. The piece is a beautiful comedy in two acts, and is the work of Seymour Hicks and Walter Slaughter. The cast included Christie McDonald, John C. Rice, Sally Cohen, and Charles A. Bigelow.

The position of Gen. REYES at Washington is for the moment ambiguous. Everything depends upon his instructions. If he seeks an interview with the Secretary of State to ask the good offices of this Government in arranging satisfactory terms of peace between Colombia and Panama, he will be received and his request hospitably considered.

The trading in curb securities yesterday was on a somewhat larger scale, and more than usual attention was given to the bond list. Gains were more numerous than declines, though the stocks which sold off were among those considered the more important issues. Northern Securities was an exception, advancing a point on small transactions.

Controller Grout was greatly interested yesterday in reports that the eight-hour law of the State of Kansas had been sustained by the Supreme Court of the United States, but declined to discuss the effect upon public works now in progress in this city should the decision of the Court of Appeal of this State, which have been against the New York law, be reversed by the highest tribunal of the Nation.

A gentleman residing in Panama, formerly engaged in the practice of such law as exists there, and at present known as "Minister of State" in the Government of the new republic, contributes to The North American Review an account of the situation in his native State.

Lively scrambles for safety by many persons marked three somewhat serious fires, all of unknown origin, in this borough, yesterday, and in one case several persons were in danger of perishing when they were rescued by a volunteer life saver. Herman Munn, day bartender in the Raine's law hotel, 2,150 Eighth Avenue, near One Hundred and Eleventh Street.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- Louis Engelhorn of New York, who was arrested at Southampton, Nov. 21, on the arrival there of the American Line steamed St. Louis on the charge of grand larcely, has refunded the money he was charged with having appropriated and has applied for the withdrawal of the proceedings against him, saying that he had cable dispatches to show his prosecutors had now no wish to press the case.

David Jones, alias Robert Powell, is locked UD in Ludlow Street Jail at the request of the British Consul General on the charge of embezzlement in Wales of u12,000, and he will be arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields on Friday morning for examination, at which time his extradition to England will be requested.

BOSTON. Dec. 1. -- Papers have been served upon Prof. Borden P. Bowne of Boston University calling him to trial before the ecclesiastical court of the Methodist Episcopal Church to answer to the general charge of heresy.

BROCKTON, Mass., Dec. 1. -- The Em pire Shoe Company closed' its doors yester- day discharging 400 employes. A keeper was installed on attachments served by the Shedd Leather Company of Boston and the American Hide and Leather -Company of Boston. The claim of the former is $2,200. The accounts of the firm are being audited, and efforts will be made to compromise.

Look in the big book for a definition of "winsome" and one will find an unusually lib'eral allowance of words synonomous with, or so nearly akin to it as to be adequately illuminative of the meaning. Delightful, pleasing, agreeable or attractive charming, winning, sweet all these are set down -- and of the show offered for the first time at the Casino last night they are quite descriptive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Nov. 30, 1903, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $925,829,410, which is an increase for the month of $5,426,909. The debt proper shows a decrease of about $4,000,000 for the month. It is recapitulated as follows:

BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 1. -- The Argentine gunboat Uraguay, with Dr. Otto Nordenskjold and the members of the antarctic expedition, arrived here to-day, and will enter the harbor at 5 o'clock to-morrow afternoon. A great celebration in honor of Dr. Nordenskiold and his fellow-voyagers is now in preparation.

The Foreign Trade Association of America, which was chartered a couple of weeks ago, under the laws of the State of New York, to promote the export trade of the country, held its first regular meeting at 66 Broad Street yesterday.

Sociologists, who attach a good deal of importance to the influence of suggestion upon large bodies of people, may find their doctrine indirectly supported by the remarkably extended series of investigations into the misconduct of public officers with which the newspapers have of late been crowded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- In the executive session of the Senate to-day the accumulating wrath of that body over what it regards as the audacity of Speaker Cannon and the President overflowed, and there was a deluge of denunciation.
LONDON, Dec. 1. -- A special to The Times announces that, according to present arrangements, Emperor William will go to Hanover on Dec. 18, and on the following day will review three regiments.

Nothing is ever settled till it is settled right. This truth is to the way to be kept before the French people, as-exemplified in the case of DREYFUS, until they pay heed and give effect to it. It would doubtless have been more convenient to the French politicians, civil and military, if DREYFUS had quietly died on Devil's Island instead of surviving to plague them.
Changes in stations and duties of officers of the Quartermaster's Department:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Treasury statement issued to-day shows that since ths 1st of November the available cash balance decreased $9,400,000, that balance now standing at $219,237,430, which is exclusive of the gold reserve fund.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- The Novoe Vremya of St. Petersburg, says a special to The Times, attacks Lord Curzon for admonishing pirate coast sheikhs not to enter into relations with any power but Great Britain.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 1. -- A cablegram received here to-day announces the death of H.C. Staymenter, an American missionary, and the drowning of twentythree of a native crew, by the capsizing of a boat on the Congo River in Central Africa.

The new buildings of the New York City Training School for Nurses, on Blackwell's Island, were formally opened yesterday afternoon. The dedicatory address was to have been made by Mayor Low, but an adjourned meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission, which he was obliged to attend, prevented his presence.

Yesterday was a day of teas and weddings. Among those who entertained for debutante daughters were John Turner Atterbury of 13 West Forty-ninth Street, Mrs. Lockwood De Forest of 7 East Tenth Street, and Mrs. F. Marshall Knights also gave a reception, at her residence, 235 West Seventy-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- W.R. Midgley's Tribes Hill, carrying top weight, made all the pace and won the Bennings Special at a mile and a half at the Bennings course to-day. Castalian proved the best sprinter of the three-year-olds, taking the lead at the start, and was never in danger. The track was fast and the weather cloudy.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association transacted the greater part of its business behind closed doors at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. John B. Saye of Buffalo, one of the old guard of trotting horse men, and who has been the leading spirit in the affairs of the Buffalo track for many years, made a brief visit to the members of the board, and was cordially greeted.
In its weekly review of the iron trade The Iron Age says:

Increased Activity. -- Those who had looked yesterday for a falling off from the relatively active pace which the stock market had shown on Tuesday were disappointed, or unexpectedly gratified, by a still further increase in transactions and a continued although somewhat irregular advance in prices.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 2. -- The present indications are that within a week or ten days nearly every industry in Braddock, Homestead, and the Turtle Creek Valley will be working double time with a full complement of men. The 28-inch mill of the Homestead Steel Works has resumed after being shut down for several weeks.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 2. -- The way was paved to-day for the taking of the dispute between the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Western Union Telegraph Company to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, and this will be done immediately.

Although there was a slight decrease in broadness in the trading in curb securities yesterday, improvement was shown throughout the list. This improvement was limited to fractional advances, except in Electric Boat preferred. The bond list was not given as much attention as on Tuesday, but prices held firm.

The excise problem was a prolific topic at meetings held yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the Citizens' Union in Union Square, and in the evening by the City Club in its rooms in West Thirtyfourth Street. That at the Citizens' Union was presided over by the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, and is said by listeners to have been a warmly interesting one.

DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 2. -- The Board of Trustees of Trinity College, after a session lasting until 2:30 o'clock this morning, declined to accept the resignation of Prof. J. S. Bassett. It had been tendered because of the criticism following a recent declaration by the professor that Booker T. Washington is the greatest man born in the South, with the exception of Gen. Lee, in the last century."

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 2. -- Ottawa University, one of the largest educational institutions in Canada, was totally destroyed by fire in two hours this morning. Sections of the walls are the only remains of the magnificent stone building which was one of the sights of the city. The loss is estimated at $500,000, and the insurance amounts to $200,000.
