L. J. Phillips Co. have sold for the Cate estate of Alton, N.H., to Daniel B. Freedman the lot, 25 by 100.11, on the north side of One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, 100 feet west of Fifth Avenue.

OFFICER'S RIGHT TO ACT FOR THE CORPORATION. -- The defense in an action on a promissory note brought by the Coney Island Automobile Race Company against Capt. Paul Boyton, was that the instrument in question was made in accordance with a written agreement by which the Captain, if he did not pay the first of two notes, was to forfeit $500 and return two autos and tracks, which were the subject of the transaction.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Senator Foraker does not believe the Republicans should shrink from a debate on the tariff which the Democrats of the House are holding up in the form of a challenge.

The annual report of the United States Reduction and Refining Company, published in Wall Street yesterday, shows the net earnings of the company for the year ended Aug. 1 to have been $837,604. From this amount there was paid on bond interest account $180,000, and for the common and preferred stock dividends $473,500, leaving a surplus for the year of $184,104, a decrease of $286,705 as compared with the previous year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- Of the 28,843 shares of different stocks dealt in on the local Exchange to-day, 15,395 shares were contributed by Reading common, 2,101 by Pennsylvania, 2,500 by Tidewater Steel, 1,603 by United Gas, and 1,400 by United States Steel preferred. These were the only active issues and United Gas the only one which substantially improved its price, closing with a net grain of 1 3/4.

As the result of a finding reached yesterday by Hamilton, Odell, as referee in the franchise tax collecting litigation long pending between the city and the Manhattan Elevated Road the Interborough Company, now owning the elevated system, will have to pay $307,185.13 into the City Treasury unless it can find relief through an appeal which possibly may be taken.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Census Bureau to-day issued a report on the quantity of cotton ginned from the growth of 1903 up to and including Nov. 14, showing total commercial bales of 7,070,437. Of these 6,519,332 were square bales, 510,550 round bales, and 40,555 sea island crop bales.

ALBANY, Dec. 2. -- Gov. Odell's hand was felt in no uncertain degree in the Republican Convention in Whitehall, Washington County, Monday, when James S. Parker of Salem was nominated for the Assembly vacancy caused by the death of Gen. W. H. Hughes.

Gov. Odell yesterday made the first move in his plan to bring about the complete reorganization of the Republican Party in the State. He brought about the retirement of M. Linn Bruce, the Chairman of the Republican County Committee, his action being taken in response to a challenge which was given him by the Platt men that he dare not openly declare for Mr. Bruce's removal.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 2. -- It is learned that the recent visit of high officials of the Rock Island to Galveston and their trip over the Houston and Texas Central is of more significance than they would have the public believe.

The action of the Trunk Line Association in granting the United States Steel Corporation, on a special list of iron and steel products, a freight rate on tidewater deliveries for export a third lower than the regular rate on like shipments for an equal distance has had the natural result of raising among those not thus favored the question whether this is not a discrimination forbidden in the inter-State commerce law.

The stock market yesterday lost its general strength, and assumed a spotty appearance, being strong in some conspicuous cases, without marked changes in many active representative properties, and weak or at least lower in cases enough to make intending buyers cautious and thoughtful.
Dr. Cyrus Edson, son of ex-Mayor Franklin Edson, died late last night in the Roosevelt Hospital from pneumonia.

Extensive plans of the New York City Street Railway, succeeding the Interurban and Metropolitan Companies, for the running of its various lines to a plaza at the Manhattan end of the new Williamsburg Bridge were the subject of a conference held yesterday afternoon at the Bridge Department.

Winter settled upon the city beyond a doubt last night, the roar of Broadway being muffled by the snow. Some sleighs went out and captured the magnums of champagne offered by the keepers of several resorts to the first to reach their places on runners, and juvenile New York sank to sleep to dream of arctic delights.
BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- The money market shows little or no change.

Lawyers F.M. Littlefield of 156. Broadway and James Demarest of 140 Nassau Street, representing the heirs-at-law of Mrs. Mary J. Oliver, the woman miser, whose estate is estimated to be worth from $90,000 to $125,000, called at the Register's office yesterday and asked to see the records of the transfer of the woman's real estate to Miss Mary E. Alderdice, with the result that they enlisted the services of District Attorney Jerome.

So far as this State is concerned we see nothing in the decision of the Supreme Court of the United States that can change the situation regarding the legal requirement of an eight-hour day on public work.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- At last the searchlight is to be thrown on the Zion City Bank, John Alexander Dowie's financial institution, and its ramifications are to be exposed.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- Mrs. Henry Clay Kelly of New York, who has a Summer home at Tioronda, a suburb of Matteawan, N.Y., is mourning the loss of her pet greyhound, Bonnie Briar, which had been poisoned by some unknown person.

In his capacity of manager of the spoken drama Mr. CONRIED may have occasionally bumped up, as what manager has not, against the restrictions of the Musical Mutual Protective Union and learned to regard it with that mixture of apprehension and disgust which it is so admirably calculated to inspire.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- The Moscow correspondent of The Times says inquiry at the Volunteer Fleet headquarters at Odessa has elicited the information that the delay in establishing the Russian line to New York will be of short duration.
Two new cracker factories are to be erected in Portland, Ore., by independent producers, and a price war with the trust on the Pacific Coast is expected as soon as they begin operations.

PARIS, Dec. 2. -- The Revision Commission assembled at 3 o'clock this afternoon in a special chamber of the Department of Justice on the Place Vendome. The six members of the commission sat around a table upon which were piled the papers in the various cases under consideration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Evidence is at hand to show that somebody tampered with Section 4 of the Platt amendment, as it was passed in the United States Senate, before the amendment was incorporated in the Cuban Constitution. It was supposed to be identical, but there is a marked difference between the two.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The annual report of Rear Admiral H.C. Taylor, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, made public to-day, makes a number of important recommendations, including the creation of a General Staff for the navy, the appointment of two Vice Admirals, one for the Asiatic Station and one for the North Atlantic Station, a material increase in the number of officers, and the addition of a number of ships to the navy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The postal scandal is touched upon in the annual report of Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Bristow, published to-day, and recommendations are made to purify the service and prevent a repetition of the corruptions recently laid bare.

Mr. CARNEGIE is not always profound in his generalizations, but he is never dull and rarely uninteresting. In his speech at the dinner of the St. Andrew's Society on Monday evening he said: "I pity the son of a rich man. The child of a millionaire can never know the true meaning of a mother and father."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Sir Henry Mortimer Durand, the successor of the late Sir Michael Henry Herbert as the Ambassador of Great Britain to the United States, was received formally by President Roosevelt at the White House at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon.
It is a poor time for the Citizens' Union to begin an agitation for a constitutional amendment looking to the city ownership of lighting, heating, transportation, and storage plants.

-- Sorrier business could hardly be Imagined than that in which certain members of the Board of Education and other school officials engaged on Tuesday when they devoted their powerful minds to the "trial" -- the word is not quite exact, but it will do -- or a teacher who had refused to resign after committing what the board's by-laws make the punishable offense of getting married.

In an editorial commenting on some statements in a paper before the Insurance Society of New York by Mr. C.J.H. WOODBURY we casually remarked that in view of the fact that the weight of copper wire in the long-distance telephone connection between Boston and Omaha was 565 1/2 tons, it seemed very like a miracle that the human voice could cause this immense mass of metal to vibrate in unison throughout its several parts.
PANAMA, Dec. 2. -- The Canal Treaty with the United States was ratified without amendment at 11:33 A.M. to-day.

What Daniel Leroy Dresser did with 316 bonds of the United States Shipbuilding Company, received from John W. Young under certain conditions, occupied all the time of contending counsel in the hearing before Referee Stanley W. Dexter yesterday of the reclamation proceedings connected with Mr. Dresser's bankruptcy.

Criticism of the painted ceiling of the Aldermen's Chamber in the City Hall is legitimate if it works an improvement in composition or the drawing of individual figures. But it comes now as a surprise from the New York Art Commission in view of the fact that the Commissioners have an office in City Hall, where the ceiling has been placed in position.

Corporation Counsel George L. Rives expected to hold court yesterday with Miss Mabel G. Graham, a stenographer in his office and the stepdaughter of Charles F. Murphy, leader of Tammany Hall, as the person to be arraigned before him, but Miss Graham declined to be arraigned.

Loyalty to the cause of amateur billiards was the theme of the meeting and banquet of the National Association of Amateur Bttllard Players last night. The meeting was held at the Leiderkranz Club. Fiftyeighth Street and Park Avenue, and was attended by thirty of the leading amateur and professional lovers of the game in this city.

Puccini's opera of "Tosca" was given last evening at the Metropolitan, and was the occasion of much interest on the part of a large audience in effecting the reentrance of Mme. Ternina as the heroine, and the appearance of Mr. Caruso in a role new to him here, that of Mario Cavaradossi.

The report was circulated in Wall Street yesterday by one of the news bureaus that it was "authoritatively informed that a prominent banking house has purchased the remaining issue of United States Steel Corporation 5 per cent, sinking fund bonds which were not purchased by the recent dissolved Steel syndicate."

Over a hundred athletes, comprising representatives from both Manhattan and Brooklyn Boroughs, assembled at the Bedford Rest, Brooklyn, last night, to complete arrangements for a new athletic club. Final action and election of officers were postponed until two weeks from last night, when another meeting will be held at the same place, and it is expected by that time that all the preliminaries now in the hands of several committees will be perfected.

-- Every once in a while, when one of our Police Magistrates has to deal with a criminal who is both particularly brutal and particularly cowardly -- a habitual wife-beater, for instance -- he delivers a little lecture to the effect that the legal penalties for such offenses are inadequate and that he yearns to impose upon the criminal physical suffering of exactly the sort endured by the scoundrel's victim.

The old-fashioned notion of the relation of the Government to the farmer, of which HORACE GREELEY was the chief apostle, was that the Government should provide home markets for the farmer by protecting from foreign competition the farmer's customers engaged in manufacturing.

The entire attention of traders in curb securities was centred yesterday in Greene Consolidated Copper, International Mercantile Marine, and Northern Securities. The entire list, with one exception, showed gains for the day, some of which were quite substantial. American Can issues showed only limited transactions, but the common advanced fractionally and the preferred 1 1/4 to 31 1/2.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 3 -- During the exciting times which marked the rapid rise in market prices of cotton to-day at the Cotton Exchange, farmers and merchants alike, who were watching the figures posted, gave rousing cheers for W.P. Brown, the man who successfully cornered the future cotton market and whose operations have been conspicuous in New York and New Orleans.

The question of permitting harness horse records made with wind shields and with the aid of advance runners, also the legality of Cresceus's work at Wichita, Kan., is likely to be settled at a conference of committees of the American Trotting Association, the American Trotting Register, and the "National Trotting Association, to be held in this city on Jan. 5.

Stocks strong. Call money firm, 6@7 1/2 per cent. Prices were strong again yesterday upon the Stock Exchange, more unmistakably and generally strong than during this week or perhaps this year. Advances ruled throughout the list to the average of nearly 3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- There will be determined opposition to the ratification of the treaty with Cuba providing for the recognition by the United States of the sovereignty of Cuba over the Isle of Pines.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The utterances of Senator Foraker in regard to Republicans shrinking from a debate of the tariff question meet with general approval among Republicans of the House.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-night gave out its report and recommendations on the Brooklyn Heights Railway.

Bulls Rejoicing. -- Those who for some little time past had been predicting a better market and arguing that prices ought to advance had much yesterday upon which to congratulate themselves. The movements of the previous days, although more or less toward improvement, were not sufficiently decided to entirely silence the doubting comments of tuose still committed to the bear side.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Three favorites, two second choices, and a well-played outsider won at Bennings to-day. The card was mostly of a selling variety, and a handicap, which was won by the Duke of Kendal, was the race of the day. Redfern rode throe winners and two placed horses out of five mounts. Track good. Summaries:

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 3 -- Litigation in this Slate over the $17,000,000 estate of the late Henry Bradley Plant will be ended if the petition filed late to-day is granted by Judge Cleaveland at a hearing to be held on Dec. 15.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 3 -- It was reported upon good authority to-day that the Pennsylvania Railroad had purchased 822 acres of meadow land in the vicinity of this city, for which $1,000 per acre was paid. The railroad company had an option on the property, it is said, which did not expire until August next.

The citizens of Passaic, to revivify civic spirit and to develop a new civic enthusiasm, last night gave a big dinner to themselves, at which President Woodrow Wilson of Princeton University was the principal guest and chief speaker.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.-- A little boom struck the local market to-day, and trading became more active than for several months.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 3 -- The Supao sedition case was opened here to-day.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 3 -- Francis B. Loomis, Assistant Secretary of State, intimated while here on private business to-day that the Administration wants Mr. Herrick, Governor-elect of Ohio, on the Republican National ticket next year with Roosevelt. No public officer in Washington is closer to the President than Mr. Loomis it is generally acknowledged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.-- Secretary Hay had a talk with the President to-day about the developments on the Isthmus of Panama. Secretary Moody dropped in while the subject was under consideration and joined in the conference.

From Yesterday's New York Herald. There is something as striking as it is disquieting in the contrast presented by Mr. Roosevelt's hesitation to walk in the paths of peace and his lack of hesitation when there was a risk of embroiling the United States over the Panama question. Before the new republic was twenty-four hours old Mr. Roosevelt was "backing it against the world."

The annual ante-holiday exodus from this country to Europe has begun, and bids fair to be greater this year than ever before. People of all nationalities are anxious to get back to their native countries before the holidays, and the steerage of every outgoing passenger steamer is crowded to its greatest capacity.

HOHOKUS, N.J., Dec. 3. -- The live stock on Brookside Farm was sold at auction to-day by Auctioneer Vanderbeeck, acting for Surrogate David A. Pell, who was appointed receiver for the live stock on it belonging to Mrs. Isabel K. Miller. The prices obtained were low, and the total realized was only $2,000, whereas the judgment received against Mrs. Miller for feed bought and money loaned was for $3,500.
BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- There was a large attendance this morning at the first meeting of the creditors of Philip Sachs before Referee Farmer.

In more than one of its aspects the controversy over the promotion of Gen. WOOD must excite the amazement of the impartial observer. If we assume that all these charges against Gen. WOOD are true, we are compelled to marvel greatly at the activity of the man. Amid his absorbing official duties how could he find time for the accomplishment of all these villainies?

Judge Henderson M. Somerville of the Board of United States General Appraisers handed down a decision yesterday of considerable interest to importers of goods into the composition of which more than one material enters. It affected the classification of articles composed in part of celluloid, in this case paper knives, figures, and thermometers composed of celluloid and metal or other materials, in which celluloid was the component of chief value.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3 -- The Louisiana Coal and Lumber Company, Limited, was organized at Mansfield, La., yesterday. It is capitalized at $600,000, with the right to increase it to $2,000,000.

The news from Chicago that the Executive Committee of the International Association of Bridge and Structural Iron Workers had ordered an international strike against the Iron League and the George A. Fuller Company which would affect 10,000 ironworkers directly was laughed at by the building contractors yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The arbitration commission in connection with the claims Santo Domingo Improvement Company against the Dominican Republic held its first meeting to-day in this city. The commission organized and Judge George Gray was elected President and Capt. Lemly Secretary.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 3 -- "Ed" Hanlon, manager of the Brooklyn Baseball Club and chief owner of the Baltimore Club, is up in arms against the proposed move in the American League to have the foul strike rule rescinded. Manager Kelley of the Cincinnati Club agrees with Hanlon on the subject.
BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- Chancellor von Bulow, as the Emperor's representative, opened the Reichstag in the White Hall of the palace to-day.
A copy of President Palma's message to the Cuban Congress on Nov. 19 has been received here, and gives details of the negotiations for the new Cuban loan of $35,000,000.

There was a distinct air of chill hanging over Webster Hall, in Eleventh Street, near Third Avenue, last night, when a few of the members of the Order of Acorns and still fewer of their guests got together for what they termed their first annual dinner. All told, some fifty persons dined, and about an equal number of telegrams and letters of regret were received.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- Announcement was made here to-day that the National Steel and Wire Company has increased its capital stock by $1,500,000 preferred, to $4,000,000, and $1,500,000 common, to $4,000,000, for the purpose of absorbing the Safety Insulated Wire and Cable Company of Bayonne, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs to-day resumed its hearing in connection with charges filed against Brig. Gen. Leonard Wood in opposition to his confirmation to be Major General.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Senator Fulton of Oregon had a conference to-day with the President and assured him that Oregon could be depended upon to support Mr. Roosevelt in the National Republican Convention, and to cast its Electoral vote for him in November next.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Money was in good supply and in moderate demand in the market to-day, owing to repayments to the Bank of England.

The case of that professor in a North Carolina college who had aroused the wrath of a neighboring editor by declaring BOOKER WASHINGTON the greatest man born in the South during the nineteenth century, Gen. LEE only excepted, has ended in a manner honorable to everybody concerned, excepting only the officious editor.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 3 -- The will of James King Gracie was admitted to probate to-day in the Nassau County Surrogate's Court at this place. President Roosevelt, his nephew. inherits $80,000, and Kermit and Ethel Roosevelt, two of the President's children, receive $5,000 each. The will is lengthy, and explains in full how the family heirlooms shall be divided.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- To awaken throughout the United States a popular sentiment which it is hoped will develop into a National demand for an arbitration treaty between the United States and Great Britain was the object of a gathering this afternoon at the residence of Gen. John W. Foster, ex-Secretary of State.

The snow in the streets yesterday bore no suggestion of the beautiful. The streets were ankle deep in dirty slush, threatening pneumonia to the wayfarer and making the footing of the horses so insecure that many fell. Even automobiles found difficulty in making progress. The street cars were not much delayed except on the Brooklyn Bridge and some parts of the Borough of Churches.

Before the American Society of Mechanical Engineers yesterday afternoon, in the assembly room of the Stevens Institute of Technology, Prof. Hans Goldschmidt of Essen, Germany, described and demonstrated the remarkable powers of thermit in an illustrated lecture on alumino-thermics and their application to engineering and metallurgy.

The magnitude of the electrical development in the United States is strikingly illustrated by the figures of a current Census Bulletin showing t in 1902 there were in operation 3,520 central station electric plants for power and lighting, representing in construction and equipment an investment of $504,740,352, and showing gross earnings of $485,700,352 per annum.

Cooper Union was filled to its capacity last night with men and women gathered to hear protests of speakers against that section of the immigration law which authorizes the exclusion and deportation of an alien because of his opinions as to governments.
BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- The local monetary situation is unchanged.
TRINIDAD, Col., Dec. 3 -- President John Mitchell and the National organizers and officials of District No. 15 to-day resumed the coal strike conference begun last evening.

What an unconscionable deal of statement and explanation it took to hide the real reason of Mr. LINK BRUCE'S retirement from the Republican County Chairmanship! A few days ago Mr. BRUCE declared that while he really ought to drop politics and return to his law practice, he was willing to retain the Chairmanship if the organization desired his services.
In an effort to avert a strike of the orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House, Director Nahan Franko has yielded to the demands of the Musical Mutual Protective Associaticn.

The movement for a liberalization of the Sunday laws has been very properly taken in hand by the City Club and the Citizens' Union. It is to be regretted that the outgoing municipal administration has not shown more interest in this matter. Undoubtedly the strict enforcement of the existing laws did have some part in the revulsion to Tammany, although nobody can accurately apportion its share in the lamentable result of last month.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3 -- The October Grand Jury to-day returned two Indictments against James L. Blair, former general counsel of the World's Fair, each charging forgery in the first degree. Each indictment is based on the alleged forgery by Blair of a deed of trust to secure a loan from the estate of Peter Blow of St. Louis, of which he, as a trustee, had charge.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- In denying a motion of Otto Kelsey, as receiver of the Manhattan Fire Insurance Company, to-day for an order authorizing him to pay Intermediate attorneys and stenographers' fees, not subject to the final accounting, Justice Herrick stated what he says will hereafter be a general rule with him in such cases.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A union of women's clubs, with headquarters in Washington, was formed here to-day to try to secure the expulsion of Senator Reed Smoot of Utah from the United States Senate.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 3 -- The British second-class cruiser Flora went on the rocks in a dense fog early to-day near Village Point, Denman Island, the place where the collier Willamette went ashore several years ago.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- John Alexander Dowie will be put on the witness stand before Bankruptcy Referee Sidney C. Eastman, and under oath will be required to answer all questions regarding the financial affairs of Zion City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Preliminary returns to the Chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the Department of Agriculture indicate that the actual growth of cotton in the United States in the year 1903-4 will amount to 9,962,039 bales of an average net weight of 490.8 pounds.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has decided not to ask for a rehearing before the United States Court of Appeals in the Western Union-Bell Telephone royalty case which was decided in favor of the plaintiff Oct. 7 last.

Prof, William H. Burr, who holds the chair of Civil Engineering at Codlumbia University, and who Is the head of the Burr-Hering-Freeman special commission on additional water supply, was the principal witness yesterday at the Aqueduct Commission's hearing into the Merchants' Association's charges of faulty construction on the Jerome Park reservoir.

MADRID, Dec. 4. -- Some plaster fell from an arch spanning the central nave of the famous Cathedral at Toledo to-day, disclosing several gaps in the stone work. Beyond showing the necessity for immediate repairs the injury is unimportant. The authorities have ordered a thorough inspection of the edifice, for which the Government has granted $24,000.

The renewal of the movement for a treaty of arbitration with Great Britain is timely so far as this country is concerned, though it may not so be regarded at this moment on the other side. It cannot be denied that the result of the Alaskan Commission and the recent operations of the United States Executive in Panama have aroused a certain suspicion as to the desirability of too close relations with our Government.

This contribution to the sum total or the information and the Joy of nations is fittingly dedicated to those unknown gods of literature, who, "If they are ever known to the ends of the earth, cannot be greater than they are now. If they are always unknown, to the people they are nobodies, but still just the same in themselves, and to have a work dedicated to them must make them quite pleased!"

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 4 -- Before adjournment to-day the Executive Committee of the recently organized Citizens' Industrial Association of America resolved against members placing the union label on articles of their own manufacture.

The November Grand Jury in Brooklyn handed up a presentation to Judge Crane, in the County Court, yesterday, in which they sustained the charges made by Deputy Water Commissioner Van Iderstine against the American Sugar Refining Company to the effect that the company has been, using water from unmetered taps to the value of $525,000, in the last five years, and recommending that the Corporation Counsel take steps to collect the amount.

Members of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday made distinct charges against the Department of Agriculture in Washington in connection with the rumors which circulated on the floor on Thursday, and which were to the effect that certain men directly interested in the market had from some unknown person received advance knowledge of the Government's crop report and had thereby greatly profited to the detriment of others.

Whatever the merits or demerits of this novel of the days or Queen Anne, it must be admitted that it does not lack incident, and that it is likely to be enjoyed by that section of the reading public which places the tempestuous above the technically correct, and the adventurous before the artistic.

THERE are very, few publications in the Christmas literature of this year in which the "gift book" element is not more or less pronounced. Standard literature takes on holiday dress with pictorial and bibliophile effects.

The Cooper Union meeting called to protest against the deportation of TURNER the Anarchist was in many ways curious and instructive. One glance into the faces of that audience should have taught the speakers that they were not addressing persons deeply interested in or loyal to American institutions.

Osborn W. Bright, Chairman of the Racing Committee of the Automobile, Club of America, yesterday issued the following statement of conditions governing, entries in this country for the race for the Bennett International Automobile Racing Trophy, to be held in Germany next Summer.

IN fifteen chapters it is not possible to put much of the opinions and experience of so busy and thoughtful a newspaper writer as was Julian Ralph, a man of prodigious energy, unquestionable desire and relish for adventure, the indomitable industry that he found necessary for success, and the good nature that is as indispensable to the journalist in China as it is at home.

Among the many books which have recently appeared dealing with the personality and adventurous career of unfortunate Mary Stuart are two of considerable historical interest and of pictorial attractiveness, dealing, respectively, with places associated with her name and with men who came under the spell of her fascination.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- There was less snap to the demand for local stocks to-day, especially for those issues which have been leaders in the movement, like Marsden and United Gas.

The American edition of Lord Ronald Sutherland Gower's " Records and Reminiscences " is published in this city by Charles Scribner's Sons. This volume, the author states in his prefatory note, is a combination of his " Reminiscences " which appeared twenty years ago and his volume of memoirs entitled " Old Diaries," which was issued last year.

There are several reasons why the two stories by Alice Duer Miller, included in the book called after the longer of the two novelettes "Calderon's Prisoner," are a delight to read. In the first place there is such an evident spontaneity in their telling. Mrs. Miller uses words only for the expression of her ideas, and one has not that depressing sensation alter closing the book that she has talked much without saying anything.
SUBJECT -- The Dedication of the Temple. I. Kings, viii., 1-11, 62-63.

NOT THE LEAST pleasant part of Mr. Corman's book is the dedicatory letter, several pages long, to his "Teacher and friend, George Robert Parkin," thanking him for the service which he did the writer, "next to the gift of life the greatest that one man can render another."

THERE are fewer fairy books than any other kind each year, but still the fairies have not gone out of fashion, and there are a goodly number books which tell old tales in new ways and with new pictures, and here and there is one quite new but never better than those which have been read by generations of children and for hundreds of years before, some of them.

THE DICKENS FELLOWSHIP. -- Some time ago, when the Dickens Fellowship was founded, I ventured to remark that it seemed to me that the idea was not a good one, that it was not a proper way to do honor to Dickens.

"Appletons New Spanish-American and English-Spanish Dictionary," compiled by Arturo Cuyas as a successor to Velazqucz's abridged dictionary, is as handy as it is timely. ($2.00. Appleton.) it is a fat 12mo, not too heavy to be easily held in the hand; it contains more than 4,000 modern words and 20,000 acceptations, idioms, and technical terms hot in the latest edition of any similar work.

THERE is certainly no lack of purpose in the first-named book -- it is intended as a rebuttal of Spiritism et al., and the et al. includes nearly everything that is generally believed and nearly everybody who has ever believed it.

Sustaining the stand taken early in the current year by Commissioner Robert Grier Monroe of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday adopted a report by its sub-committee recommending that all bids received by the city for gas and electric lighting be rejected, with the single exception of the New Amsterdam Gas Company's bid of $12 per gas lamp for its section of the city.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- What is considered by the United States Government Secret Service officials to be one of the most important raids that has ever taken place in the vicinity of Boston was successfully carried out to-day in the little town of Revere. Three men, all said to be well-known counterfeiters, were arrested and an extensive plant, with an enormous supply of paper for printing notes, was confiscated.

The two volumes of "Creevey Papers," which are being publishes by E.P. Dutton Co., are edited by the well-known English writer, Sir Herbert Maxwell, whose third volume of "Memories" were described in our last issue. The papers begin in 1802, with, the Addington Ministry in office, closing in 1838, a few weeks before the author's 'death, in February of that year.

Minority stockholders of the Compressed Air Company, through counsel, argued yesterday before Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court on an application for a receiver for the company. The ground of the application was that the Compressed Air Company had loaned all its available cash, to the Rome Locomotive and Machine Company, a constituent concern, which action prevented the parent company from paying the last two semi-annual interest coupons on its first mortgage bonds.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The rise in cotton caused intense excitement in Manchester and Liverpool yesterday American cotton advanced 28 to 41 points over Thursday's closing prices.

The desertions from Local No. 2 to the New York Housesmiths' Union all this week were so numerous that the latter organization has taken the first steps toward forming a new international association by sending men to nearby cities.

A clever reflection of "The Arabian Nights," (not those of Bagdad, but Stevenson's,) calculated for the meridian of Leland Stanford Junior University. At least one infers as much from the frequent mention of that seat of learning, whose foster son, moreover the Irish hero is. Not that this hero is really Irish, save in being cheerful and freckled and having red hair.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 4 -- The most interesting features in the water boodle scandal to-day were the confessions of ex-Alderman Ghysels of the Sixth Ward, and Corey P. Bissell, former member of the Board of Public Works, that they accepted the bribes mentioned by Salsbury in his confession.

Mr. Locke has again written an effective and brilliant story, one that lives up to its happy title and motto. He opens in a fashion always alluring, with a conversation, and by conversation do the characters reveal themselves just as characters do in life. There is only so much of description as is needed to adjust them to the reader's thorough comprehension.

"Danny" Maher, successor to Tod Sloan as the most successful and popular American jockey on the English turf, and Lucien Lyne arrived in New York as passengers on the White Star Line steamship Arabic, which got in from Liverpool yesterday morning.

The drastic municipal ordinance recommended by Mayor HARRISON of Chicago for the suppression of crimes against the person by discouraging and penalizing the ownership and carrying of deadly weapons of offense or defense does not seem to have evoked a chorus of enthusiastic popular approval.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A circular letter has been sent to every seed house in the country by representatives of prominent wholesale and retail seedsmen who have become dissatisfied with the dilatory tactics of the committees of the Wholesale Seedsmen's League and the American Seed Trade.

GP. PUTNAM'S SONS will not bring out the third and last volume of John Boyd Thacher's work on "Christopher Columbus" until next month. The delay has been caused by the preparation of an elaborate and comprehensive index.
BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- The money market continues quiet with rates unchanged. Some bankers, however, think they see a slightly easier tone.

Senator Lodge's entertaining history of the Revolution, written several years ago, makes its appearance again in a new and handsome edition, a single goodly octavo volume of about 600 pages, containing all the original illustrations, nearly 200 in number. Including several moat interesting reproductions of original documents.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 4 -- The decision of Victor Herbert to quit the Pittsburg Orchestra at the expiration of his contract, in March, has left the orchestra in uncertainty as to its existence after that date. Until the guarantee is secured nothing can be done toward securing a successor to Mr. Herbert.

There are 172 text and full page pictures and two photogravure frontispieces in the Countess of Warwick's two-volume work on "Warwick Castle and Its Earls." Not only are members of the half dozen families of Warwicks portrayed, but also contemporaries and the rulers of England at certain periods.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: A number of young men of a literary turn of mind, who have formed themselves into a literary society, find the need of some guide to a course of reading in the essayists, and I wish to appeal in their behalf to THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS for a list of authors whose works it would be desirable to consider for study.

DOVER, Del., Dec. 5 -- When Gov. Samuel W. Pennypacker of Pennsylvania appeared here to-day wild rumors arose that he had come to "have it out" with Gov. John Hunn as the result of their recent correspondence regarding the requisition of a negro, when the Keystone State Executive said he was afraid to let the negro go back to Delaware, for fear he might be lynched.

Although, as Mrs. Anna Bowman Dodd says in the preface to her book on "The Palaces of the Sultan," she had the "very unusual opportunities," as a guest of Ambassador Porter, to visit and transcribe her impressions of the Sultan's palaces, there were barriers in the form of an unknown tongue and a limited time to travel which prevented her from having a truer insight into the life of the Turkish people.

A new edition of the Standard Dictionary (Funk Wagnalls Company) is published with many changes and additions as "The Twentieth Century Subscription Edition "; it is bound, as before, both in one volume and in two, stout quartos, full Russia leather covers and marginal index. The various departments have become so numerous that a table of contents has been added of necessity.
In its issue of to-day The Wall Street Journal reviews the movement of currency during the week, as follows:

ALTHOUGH thirty-seven years have elapsed since the sudden death of Gov. Andrew, his only biography is the memoir prepared at the request of the Massachusetts Historical Society by the late Peleg W. Chandler and published in 1884 by the firm of Roberts Brothers.

It was reported about the District Attorney's office late yesterday afternoon that an arrest was likely to be made as soon as a result of the inquiry now in progress to determine the rightful owners of the property left by the aged miser, Mrs. Mary J. Oliver. This step seemed to be foreshadowed by the developments of the last twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The State Department has issued a warrant for the surrender to the British authorities of David Jones, who is held, under arrest in New York on a charge of perverting the sum of $60,000 while acting as trustee in the town of Lianrwst, Wales.
RICHARD L. MAKIN, author of "The Beaten Path," pubished by The Macmillan Company, was born in this city in 1837. His father was an Englishman and his mother a cousin of the late John Fiskc.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- That a widespread curtailment of production by cotton mills in the United States will be found necessary during the next few months on account of the great cost of the raw material, is the opinion of leading mill men in this city, from which the policy of many cotton mills in the North is directed.

This latest edition to Appletons Series of Historic Lives is one of the most informing and carefully written of the set. In addition to the fact that translations of some new portions of Chaplain's writings are given, the author has used excellent judgment in selecting from the works of well-recognized authorities just such facts as were necessary to round out his own investigations and to complete the short life of his hero.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Speaker Cannon ran up against the interests of organized labor to-day, and there was a scene in his room.

IN "Three Hundred Things Which a Bright of the book, Do," the editor of the book Lilla Elizabeth Kelley, has not omitted much in the way of work or play that a woman, young or old, might care to undertake.

The Philharmonic Society presented the second of its series of conductors at the public rehearsal yesterday afternoon -- a concert which again showed by the numbers and close attention of the audience how great is the interest in the scheme that is now in process of fulfillment.

TWO harmless looking little volumes published in Chicago by Herbert S. Stone Co., help to show us once more the persistence of professional American humor, toward the discountenancing of which a needless generation has never taken a step.

Prof. Mommsen was always an enthusiastic member of the faculty of the Berlin University. The same was true of the well-known philosopher Zeller, who is still living at Stuttgart at the age of ninety. Much to the surprise of every one, one day Zeller missed a faculty meeting because he had a toothache, and Mommsen, as dean of the faculty, announced his absence in the words of Shakespeare:
First Lieut. Herman W. Schull, Ordnance Department, will proceed to the works of the Bethlehem Steel Company on business pertaining to the inspection of ordnance material in process of manufacture.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 4 -- The last racing day but one of the last meeting of the Eastern turf in the season of 1903, held here to-day, was distinguished by one of the most sensational results of the Washington meeting, when Princelet, running in the name of Thomas E. Mannix, and starting at 50 to 1, after having been backed down from odds of 100 to 1, finished first in the fourth race.

THIS WORK, compiled at the request of the Master, Wardens, and Court of Assistants of the Worshipful Company of Pewterers, and printed at their direction, exhibits the history of the company from its numerous records but, unfortunately, their transcription is brought to a close with the year 1760, a period of much interest to collectors of old pewter on this side of the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Necessity for enlarged facilities for construction of naval ordnance is pointed cut in the annual report of Secretary of the Navy Moody, made public to-day.

SALINA, Kan., Dec. 4 -- Fire that started here at noon to-day, and which for a time threatened the entire business district, destroyed the four-story building occupied the H.D. Lee wholesale grocery company, damaged the building and contents of the H.D. Lee Hardware Company, and burned several smaller buildings, causing an aggregate loss estimated at $500,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Senator Platt of New York called at the White House today. He was not there over fifteen minutes, and it is stated that the visit related to some Federal appointments.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- Judge McPherson in the United States District Court to-day appointed the Tradesmen's Trust Company receiver for the Pennsylvania Erecting Company, and granted an order restraining various firms which secured attachments against the company from any further proceedings.

WELL accoutred, both mentally and physically, must be the traveler who plunges through the difficult passes of the mountains of Thibet. He has all the responsibilities of an officer in command of a reconnoitring party, and his followers are not always amenable to discipline.

BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 4 -- The Grievance Committee of the Fairfield County bar today filed a complaint against Attorney George W. Carey of Stratford, whose law office is in this city. The charges, if proved, will not only disbar the young attorney, but will commit him to State prison.

UNDER the loggia del Lanzi in Florence stands a bronze image of Perseus with winged cap and strangely curved sword, at his feet the body of a decapitated woman, and high in his left hand the head of Medusa.

In his later years Ruskin was accustomed to disparage "The Seven Lamps of Architecture," the publication of which by Longmans, Green Co. as Vol. VIII. in the library edition of his works was announced last week. The book was written in the Winter of 1840, in the house on Grosvenor Square, London.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your issue of Nov. 21 you published a letter from Frederick S. Dickson impugning the claims we make for our edition of the complete writings of Henry Fielding.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your New York correspondent's "Opinion No. 4" she pertinently observes that selection of companions and books for the child is one of the most effective means within the power of the parent; and she further advises every "young" person, at the proper age, varying with individuals, to read "Adam Bede."

The disposition of Prof. BASSETT'S case by the Trustees of his college, so creditable to that body, has a comic sequel much less creditable to the North Carolina Editorial Association. Editor DANIELS of The Raleigh News had been foremost among those who demanded that the professor should pay for his freedom of speech by the forfeiture of his chair.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- The Public Schools Athletic League of Manhattan was incorporated to-day. "to promote useful athletics and gymnastics among the attendants of the public schools of the City of New York and in connection therewith to co-operate and sunport school athletic associations, provide athletic grounds and teachers, organize games, offer prizes, and conduct competitions."

Lord Wolseley, in the second volume of hia autobiography, " The Story of a Soldier's Life," which Charles Scrlbner's Sons will publish next week, speaks of his visit to the United States at the time of the civil war. He had frequent Interviews with Gen. Robert E. Lee at the headquarters of the Confederate Army, and expressed much admiration for him.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 4 -- The naval tug Peoria, towing the submarine torpedo boat Adder, has arrived at the Navy Yard here. The Adder was saved by the heroism of Boatswain Deering of Brooklyn, who responded to a call for volunteers, and swam 100 yards with a line to the Adder from the tug and pulled a hawser after him.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Negotiations begun yesterday by the powers may result in an international administration for Macedonia along the lines observed in the present government of the Island of Crete.

"For I heard once," says she, "that the sea was all as sweet as tea, but 'twas made salt by the sailors' wives aweeping on the shores of it." Which is a pretty enough Irish sentiment for anybody, and comes in with the pouring of tea from a broken pot in the story in this collection, which is entitled "The Lights of Sitka."

It has been said that the history of the world consists in the lives of a few great men, and we are forcibly reminded, in looking at the contents of this book and its half dozen names, that the thinkers are the real makers of history and fill the largest permanent places in it. Here are represented poetry, art, philosophy, letters, music, prophecy, in Dante, Michael Angelo, Fichte, Hugo, Wagner, and Ruskin.

Kalman Foldossy, the Hungarian whose peculiar actions in the crowd that saw President Roosevelt at the funeral of his uncle in this city caused his arrest, was arraigned yesterday before Justice Fitzgerald in the Supreme Court and committed to the Manhattan State Hospital for the Insane.

The stock market gained in activity yesterday, and lost only little of its aggressive advance, but it gained nothing of wholesomeness. For example, three stocks contributed nearly one-half to the day's business of over a million aggregate shares.

MR. BIGELOW'S untiring efforts in furtherance of a better understanding on the part of the English-speaking race of German history, character, and politics are well known. This present volume is another step in that direction.

Henry Holt Co. have just sent their automobile romance, "The Lightning Conductor," to press for its fourteenth time. They also report that "The Holladay Case" went into its second edition on the day of publication.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The President and Senator Hanna had a conference this evening lasting from a few minutes after 9 until 11 o'clock in regard to the retention of Perry S. Heath as Secretary of the National Committee.

THERE is a fascination about the details of a marine battle which, from the very genesis of warfare, has riveted the attention and aroused the interest and enthusiasm of mankind to an extent possible in the culmination of no other human effort.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Discounts were steady to-day, in spite of the abundance of money in the market.

In the vast army of present day novel writers there are a few whose names are a guarantee of something original. interesting, out of the common, and one conies into possession of a book by any one of them with a delightful assurance, the result of numerous confirmations in the past, that the time spent in reading it win be well repaid.

"A Garden in Venice," by F. Eden, is being published by Charles Scribner's Sons in this country. The volume is copiously illustrated with full-page plates in photogravure and other pictures, the former giving views of the garden described by the author. This garden, according to the author, was once a bank of mud.

In his "History of Socialism in the United States," Morris Hillquit treats a multiform topic in a fairly concise manner. It cannot be said that Socialism has as yet any well-marked plans. There is a great deal of generalization without definiteness. Treating of another work on the same topic published some thirty years ago, the author of this book writes that then "the modern Socialistic movement was almost unknown in this country."

"Canada in the Twentieth Century," the new book by A.G. Bradley, author of "Wolfe," "The Fight with France for North America," , will be issued next week in the United States by E.P. Dutton Co. The volume is a picture of life in the older Canadian provinces and treats of the Northwest in "the only fashion one very well can treat of a country in the making within brief compass."

The Louisiana convention to discuss the boll weevil and take steps for its immediate control and ultimate suppression in that State seems to have been purposeful and practical. In this respect it compares more than favorably with the convention recently held in Texas for the same purpose.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- Despite the protest and negative vote of Commissioner Kraft at to-day's meeting of the State Civil Service Commission, the revised municipal civil service rules of the City of New York, as adopted Oct. 26, 1903, and amended in minor details at the suggestion of the State Commission, were approved.

IN essaying to write a life of Voltaire Mr. Tallentyre chalenges comparisons that might well have made him doubt his wisdom in undertaking an enterprise so heroic -- in its proportions. He is not the first by any means to burst into this troubled sea.

KATRINA TRASK'S new novel, "Free Not Bound," (Putnam's,) is a live book, and seems to me to deserve a more extended notice. The characters are living. The descriptions are graphic. The action compels the reader's attentiot from start to finish, without the timeworn accessories of battle, murder, and sudden death.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: IF we care to take the trouble, it is possible to call to mind the titles of a dozen or more volumes which during our Juvenile days furnished us with entertainment and diversion.
MONTREAL, Dec. 4 -- In the course of the next few days the Canadian Pacific Railway Company will make an issue in London of $14,040,000 4 per cent. consolidated debenture stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A long drawnout quarrel in the Woman's Auxiliary to the Spanish War Veterans seems likely to be terminated by the decision of the officers and members of the Mary Sherman Miles command to disband.

"Political Parties and Party Policies in Germany," by James Howard Gore, is published to-day by G.P. Putnam's Sons in their series of books on Questions of the Day. This brochure is the result of investigations made by the author at the last elections in the Reichstag on the attitude of the political parties in Germany toward the United States and other nations.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The new edition of Thomas Carlyle's "Life and Letters of Oliver Cromwell," which will be issued next year, will contain many letters of Cromwell hitherto unpublished.

DR. SAMUEL A. ELIOT'S accouunt of the "Great and Thursday Lecture" in the preface of this volume is brief but to the point. We are told that this lecture, established by John Cotton in 1631, "was in Colonial times the chief social and religious event in Boston."

Gen. Greene has devised a new excise plan for this city which, were it put into effect by act of Legislature, would place the solution of the problem in the hands of the citizens themselves with but slight change in the existing law. It would afford home rule, not only to the city itself, but to the different districts of the city in regard to hours during which liquor might be sold.

The "jockey manager," a fruitful source of trouble and complaint for horse owners and trainers, and an evil of the turf that frequently in the past has called for official action to keep in check the rapacity of individuals whose only claim to consideration was the influence they happened to wield over the race riders temporarily in fashion, is scheduled to receive the attention of the stewards of the Jockey Club this Winter.

The bare official summaries are almost cruel in the completeness with which they dispose of the assertions and predictions which have been most vehemently put forward during the agitation of the past few months. We were exhorted to believe that a country, which has a great excess of imports is in a very had way, and that the merits of protection are exhibited by the manner in which it discourages this undesirable arrangement.

The work of completing the giant White Star Line steamship Baltic, which was recently launched at Belfast, Ireland, is being rushed with all possible speed, in order to have her in the service between this port and Liverpool by the end of next June. With the placing in commission of this ship the total tonnage of the line will be raised to about 350,000 tons.

With the development of the modern tall building, one of the chief directions in which great advancement, has been made over the older kinds of construction has been in the methods of subdividing the building's interior. Whereas formerly many of the interior partitions were of solid brick, many inches in thickness, and just as essential to the support of the building as were its outer walls, to-day they play no such part.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 5. -- Six of the men charged by Lant K. Salsbury in his first confession to the Prosecuting Attorney with accepting bribes from him for supporting the project to supply the city with water from Lake Michigan appeared in the Superior Court to-day and pleaded guilty before Judge Newnham, as their attorney had announced they would do.

Heinrich Conried had a new problem to solve last night at the Metropolitan Opera House when he was confronted by an irate mother and her two musical children, who wanted to occupy three seats on one coupon. Before the trouble was over the part of the audience occupying the rear orchestra seats were more interested in the obstreperousness of the irate mother than they were in "Alda."

ALBANY, Dec. 5. -- The smallest railroad in New York State, the Schoharie Valley, which is 4.38 miles long, and is equipped with one locomotive and one car, takes the longest time of any company reporting to the State Railroad Commission to make its annual report. The fiscal year ended June 30, and the big trunk lines with their hundreds of miles of tracks made, their reports to the Commission two months ago.

The decision of the Citizens' Industrial Association to urge all who are opposed to trades union tyranny to refuse to allow the goods they make and sell to bear the union label is a natural reaction from the high-handed measures by which organized labor has sought to force its labels upon manufacturers, dealers, and consumers.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Dec. 5. -- The question as to who is Prosecuting Attorney of Cole County will be a matter of consequence in the hearing of William Ziegler, baking powder manufacturer, who is wanted here on a charge of bribery, when the extradition proceedings shall be heard before Gov. Odell at Albany Monday.

To followers of baseball the batting, pitching, and fielding averages of the American League players for the season of 1903, which have just been announced, will be a source of interesting information and afford the close observers of the game an excellent opportunity for making comparisons as to the relative abilities of their favorite players and those more fancied by others.
TWO girls cluns to the strap in the trolley car, when the conductor called out "Hold fast!" in what sounded like a foreign language.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 5. -- A Children's World international Exposition was opened to-day in the Tauride Palace with great ceremony by Elizabeth Mavrickievna. The opening was a brilliant function and was attended by the State Ministers, members of the Diplomatic Corps, including United States Ambassador McCormick, military officers, and high Government functionaries in full uniform.

HEIGHO! "For a horse or a hawk or --" "A husband," Jean Darrow supplemented lightly. "That's it exactly! Now, here am I at five and thirty a veritable old maid and likely to remain so -- unwept, unwedded, and "unsung!"

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 5. -- The continued advance in price of raw cotton has caused the Mount Vernon Woodberry Cotton Click Company the last few days to advance the price of cotton ducks from 1 to 2 cents a pound. The entires advance in the price of cotton ducks this year has been from 3 to 4 cents a pound.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 6. -- While Daniel Ruth and his family were sitting last night in their home at Hibernia, a village about nine miles from here, a shot rang out and nine-year-old Elsie Ruth fell to the floor. A pistol bullet had passed clear through her head.
MANILA, Oct. 16. -- Last week 100 Filipino students left Manila to be educated in the United States at the expense of the Government.

Seven men, who are alleged to be members of the gang of counterfeiters whose workshop at Revere, near Boston, was raided on Friday, were arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields in the Federal Building yesterday and held for examination Thursday afternoon. They were all arrested in this city simultaneously with the three prisoners taken at Revere.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The last count, made on Nov. 22, of the attendance at church showed 25 per cent. of the entire population of that district as present. This might convince the reader, upon first thought, as leaving 75 per cent. as non-churchgoers. This conclusion would, of course, be incorrect and misleading.
NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 5. -- J. Stewart Barney has rented for the season of 19O4 Mrs. Julia H. Eldridge's villa at Ochre Point, which he occupied last Summer.

If one should ever write a play and be lucky enough to get a manager to say he would consider it, there is just one question that manager would ask. And it is certain, too, that he would ask the question before he read the manuscript. This would be his inquiry:

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 5 -- The most important event of the week was the reception given by Mrs. Elbert S. Kip and Miss Anna Elizabeth Kip Tuesday afternoon. The function was at Ruremont, the beautiful home of Mr. George G. Kip on Madison Avenue, and never was the place more beautiful.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- On all the German Bourses there is this week one subject of predominant interest. The newspapers were able on Sunday morning to print' the announcement that a "community of interest" agreement had been arranged between the Dresdner Bank and the Schaaffhausen Bankverein.

Currency transfers to San Francisco during the past week assumed large proportions, nearly $2,000,000 being reported as the shipment for a single day, attributed to seasonable demands for moving crops, not only of grain but of fruit. Growth in the fruit-raising industry of California has been on a steadily progressing scale, subject, of course, like all other products depending on climatic conditions, to considerable fluctuation.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Coaching parties have been a pleasant diversion for Lake-wood visitors this week. The coach Lakewood left the Lakewood Hotel with a merry party on Thursday for a twelve-mile drive to Tom's River, where the oyster boats come in. Robert Ellison of New York drove and Miss Grace Reddington of Philadelphia sat on the box seat.

Acting for the city in the capacity of a transportation expert, Samuel Whinery, civil engineer, has submitted to Dock Commissioner McDougall Hawkes a comprehensive report on the proposed Chelsea Improvement along the Manhattan shore of the North River, contemplating, from Twenty-third Street south to the north side or Gansevoort Market, an extension of the pierhead line far enough out into the North River to permit of the building of piers 1,000 feet long.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- Referring to the London report that Germany may object to the proposition of Russia and Austria for an international administration of Macedonia on the lines of the present Government of Crete, the Foreign Office here said to-day that, on the contrary, Germany had done all in her power to secure the acceptance and enforcement of the Muerzteg programme, which remains the basis of Russo-Austrian action.

THE fad for pets is growing all the time, and every young woman has a dozen or more animals of various species upon which she lavishes much affection. The raccoon is one of the new ideas. They are considered extremely neat, as they persist in washing all the food given to them before eating it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The ordinary man, often heartbroken, disgusted with things in general, will raise this interrogation: "Does it pay?" When one is deep in the slough of despond, so natural is it to cry out "Does it pay?" Exertion ill-spent brings this exclamation. We hear it so frequently that we begin to feel there must be some ground for complaint.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The charge that a leak in the cotton estimate has occurred again caused a stir in the Department of Agriculture to-day.

Wages, have been cut about 15 per cent, in some of the silk mills at Paterson and elsewhere, and there are many idle looms in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Connecticut, according to the manufacturers, commission men, and selling agencies in this city. Dullness in the trade is admitted on all sides, yet the situation is declared to be less gloomy than it might seem at first glance

Lhasa, literally "God's ground," the Mecca of Lamaism, lies near the southern edge of the great Thibetan Plateau of Central Asia, on a small upland plain, surrounded by barren rocky hills, 12,000 feet above the sea. It is shut in by natural barriers on all sides from the outside world.

Physical culture in all its different phases is to be brought more prominently before the attention of New Yorkers than ever before by the Physical Culture Exhibition to be held for one week in Madison Square Garden beginning Dec. 28. In many respects this will be a novel exhibit in this city, for nothing on exactly the same lines has been attempted here before.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A writer in your last Sunday's issue, who signs his letter "S.K.B.," claims that Republicans are better morally and intellectually than Democrats. He seems to be one of those "stand-off-I-am-holier-than-thou" fellows. And yet, after all, take all the members of both, parties and shake them up in a bag, and there is not much difference to be found among them.

ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass., Dec. 5. -- After an investigation of nearly a week into the attempt on Sunday last to burn the private sanitarium of Dr. James M. Solomon of this town, in which there were twenty-five patients the State police to-day took into custody Mrs. Margaret Giles, a native of New Hampshire, and for many years the chief cook at Dr. Solomon's institution.
WHEN Danvers and his friend Barlow came into the car Danvers was talking.

Returns compiled showing the developments of passenger results on the country's system of railroads bring out some striking, not to say startling, facts. This branch of the service is of course one of great importance, a big medium for bringing in revenue, and, although it is claimed that the passenger department is more an ornament than a profit-making agency, there is no doubt of its indispensable qualities.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Of all the developments of the week in London I doubt not that Americans will be most interested in what, to borrow the classic language of Silas Wegg, may be spoken of as the fall off of the silk hat.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Invoking a section of the New Jersey laws which up to that time had been more honored in the breach than in the observance, President John P. Haines of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, aided by the county authorities, vetoed a hunt which was to have taken place here with a tame deer for a quarry.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the courts have decided that Mme. Wagner cannot restrain the projected performance of the "Parsifal" in New York, I have been daily waiting for some American Wagnerian to raise his voice in protest. I have waited with a growing wonder at the silence.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 5. -- A thirty-six-hole team match was played to-day on the links of the Country Club of Lakewood, between eight members of the home club and an equal number from the Nassau Country Club of Glen Cove, L.I. The Lakewood golfers won by a total of 16 points to 4, the Nassau system of scoring being used.

The new stable now in course of erection on the south side of Thirty-first Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, will probably be unique. Owned by William H. Seaich, the building will accommodate 600 horses at one time. Six stories in height, there will also be ample room for the storage of a great number of cabs and carriages when not in use.

YORK, Penn., Dec. 5. -- John A. Hoober, attorney for the Metropolitan Printing Company of New York City, issued an at- tachment for $1,100 against Robert E. Johnson, manager of the Carrie Nation show, which appeared here in the Opera House this afternoon and evening. The entire box receipts, ($300,) the scenery, and all appurtenances carried by the company were levied upon.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- The death of M. Puibaraud, who was at the head of the French detective system, solves a difficult administrative problem. As in Rome there are three Popes, the White, the Red, and the Black Pope, so the French police service in France is governed by three potentates, each of whom, is to some extent independent of the other.

Herbert W. Bowen, the United States Minister to Venezuela, who has been looking after the interests of this country and of Venezuela at The Hague Tribunal, returned to this country yesterday on the Campania. Accompanying him was udge Penfield, who made one of the arguments for this country before the tribunal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Charles F. Murphy came to Washington to-day to attend the Gridiron Club dinner. He went to the Shoreham, where Mayor-elect McClellan is staying. Philip F. Donahue and August Belmont came over on the same train.

It seems that the appointment of the State Commission on the law's delays was not appointed in vain, and that it is not likely to be as barren of results as so many efforts in the same direction that have preceded it. Such a comparative showing as Mr. HAYES has elicited concerning the working of our judicial system appeals directly to the legal profession and to the lay public.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES has published figures showing that the Protestant Church attendance is poor, to say the least, and not encouraging when compared, with the figures of the Roman Church, The fact itself is, to my mind, not a new one, but the repeated demonstration of it may, indeed, set "those most immediately concerned" to do some hard thinking.

Falling in an effort to acquire the cigar factories of Germany, according to the tobacco press of that country, the American Trust, is now said to be engaged in a movement to gain the control of the Sale of the Kentucky and Virginia smoking product in Emperor William's domain.

With the excellent programme of world's fencing championships that has been ar- ranged for the Olympic games at the St. Louis Exposition next September, the regular competitions during the Winter are sure to be well contested, for they will all be in a measure, preparatory to the world's fair events, and the leading fencers will be anxious to get all the practice that is possible.

The insurgent bands in Macedonia are in organization and method of operation developed from the system used in Bulgaria before Bulgaria became free. At that time the bands were formed in Roumania and used Roumania as their base. The traditions of the leaders of those old Bulgarian bands are celebrated in song and story, and many of the chiefs after Bulgaria became free occupied important posts in the administration of the new country.

MAN is a very unreasonable being. He is always adjuring woman to let business, politics, and such things alone, and pay attention to matrimony and kindred affairs which properly come within her sphere. Yet she can't even get into a coal hole to see a wedding without his beginning to criticise her.

THE WEEK'S OPENINGS. "QUEEN OF THE WHITE SLAVES," Grand Opera House, Monday. "MAM'SELLE NAPOLEON," Knickerbocker, Tuesday. "DER STROM," Irving Place, Tuesday. "CANDIDA," Princess, one special matinee, Tuesday afternoon.

It was a halcyon and vociferous week. It is beyond the truth to say that everything is higher than a week ago, but it is altogether true that according to The Wall Street Journal's averages industrials closed higher every day. Railways also averaged higher every day except Wednesday, when there was a decline of .05 per cent.

George R. Sheldon will not serve as Treasurer of the Republican General Committee of the County of New York after Dec. 17, at which time the committee to serve for 1904 will assemble at the United Charities Building, Fourth Avenue, corner Twenty-second Street, and perfect its organization by balloting for a President and minor officers.

The sensational estimate of the Chief Statistican of the Department of Agriculture on the cotton crop, based on the reports made by Government agents all through the South, has caused a good deal of discussion regarding the value of such reports. The Government report indicated a much smaller crop than it had been generally expected that it would show.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- There was a lull in local speculation to-day, and prices moved with some irregularity, a few stocks receding slightly, while others made small gains.
MISS EMILY CAREW, sister of Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, was a guest recently at a dinner party, and during its course the conversation fell upon "Strange things I have seen."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The word "panama" got into the French language long ago, as it did into many others, to signify a well-known kind of costly hat. Since the Panama scandal, which brought such disaster to poor old Ferdinand de Lesseps, the word has been adopted in French printing offices as the name for any kind of atrocious "bull" that involves serious loss.

President William R. Harper did not announce any more big gifts to Chicago University in his speech yesterday afternoon before the Eastern Alumni Association, which held its annual luncheon at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Before that function he replied to a question as to whether John D. Rockefeller had made a donation to the university by saying:

While the immediate question before students of railway earnings is the question of what gross and net results will be scored in the next few months when the depressed condition of our industries is expected to find reflection in the volume of traffic, the really vital consideration concerns not the figures for the balance of the Winter, but the later prospects, based upon the probable resumption of general business activity.
To the Editor of The New York Times: To those who reside in New York there really seems to be no limit to individual license to make a noise.

The holiday business in furs, which ought to have been, well under way last week, is backward, and unless it takes, a turn for the better during this week the manufacturers have little hope that this season's business will be up to the average.

TOKIO, Nov. 8. -- The vexed and much discussed subject of politics has for a week given place to the celebration of birthdays and garden parties, and I fancy all the world is the happier for the change. It was a treat to many to see the Emperor riding about receiving acclamations of a far more enthusiastic nature than is usually accorded his appearance.

CELIA, the well-preserved spinster of the quiet little village, has escaped all the rrecent entanglements of the sly god Cupid -- not perhaps because she so desired, but because fate so willed it. And, perhaps it was because, she had a will of her own and was not easily pleased.

Indications all point to a building movement of large proportions on the upper east side and in Harlem within the next few months. Bricks at $9 a thousand is not condition that tends to brighten the outlook for flat and tenement builders, but the accumulation of vacant property by operators goes right ahead, in anticipation of the time when the material market will get back to a lower level.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- "The Maximum," at three miles, was the feature on the programme for the closing day of the Fall meet at Bennings to-day. River Pirate, Circus, and Carbuncle were the only entries, and the race resulted in an easy victory for the latter. Burns had the winner under wraps all the way, and readily drew away when called on.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a great deal in the metropolitan press concerning the alleged, enormous adulteration of whisky in this country, but the basic reason for it does not seem to be understood.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in regard to the Art Commission in this morning's issue is of considerable interest from the fact that the very men who were most hasty in the saddling of this city with an Art Commission composed of creative artists are now eager to criticise their own creation.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 28. -- An interesting report has just been published by the Congo Free State Government concerning the railway now being built in the Upper Congo; to this report is also annexed an account giving full information relative to big game shooting in the Free State. The new railroad from the Upper Congo to the great lakes will place Stanleyville in communication with Ponthierville by the left bank of the Congo.

Preliminary steps were taken last week for the organization of the National Association of Importers, which has been in contemplation for some time, by the issuance of a circular addressed to the importers of the United States, telling of the work accomplished so far, and setting forth the objects and aims of the proposed organization.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Speaker Cannon to-day showed how little he regarded the recent warnings to him delivered in executive session by the Senate.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The restrictions placed on immigration are ample, and any further restriction at the present time is entirely uncalled for and unadvisable.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a matter of public concern that some of the apparent errors that have recently appeared in the press regarding the county parkways of Essex County, N.J., be corrected.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 5. -- United States Minister Allen had a long interview with the Emperor of Korea to-day on the subject of the request of the United States for the opening of the commerce of the world of the port of Wiju, on the Yalu River. No definite decision was arrived at. The Government has been placed in a dilemma by the demand of the United States.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 5. -- Through the arrest of Howard R. Biddings and Leo Joseph Blough, two employes of the United States Express Company, the identity of the men who have been stealing packages handled by the company, it is alleged, has been brought to light, and many arrests are expected within the next twenty-four hours.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Without having heard Dr. Slicer's address on Sunday night or knowing anything whatever about the discussion, I desire to protest vigorously against THE TIMES'S slighting tone on the subject of Dr. Slicer's remarks to be found on the editorial page of to-day's TIMES.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, "Defendam," in the 29th of November issue, using the above caption, is like many Americans, under the delusion that the people of the United Kingdom are about to adopt protection as a policy. Not much, allow an old retired merchant to say.
