WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The Gridiron Club entertained more than 160 guests at its December dinner at the Arlington Hotel to-night. The evening was replete with unique features, in which public events and the alleged ambitions and aspirations of statesmen were made subjects of burlesque and good-natured ridicule.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: In your issue of Nov. 29 there is an editorial with the heading, "England and Russia in Asia," with whose tone I must strongly disagree. For its prevailing" sentiment is a Justification and indeed glorification of another of England's piratical attempts to seize the country and subjugate the people of a weak nation that has never done them or anybody else any harm.

HERE are some specimens of the kind of dialogue that John J. McNally had provided for the American version of the Drury Lane spectacle, "Mother Goose," now on view at the New Amsterdam Theatre. Jill enters with school books on her arm and Mother Goose asks her where she has been.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Commissioners from Panama decline liability for the Colombian external debt on the ground that "when the bulk of the money was borrowed Colombia did not include the Isthmus, which was separate and under Spanish Government." Allow me, please, to state that this allegation is absolutely baseless.

After prolonged controversy, the question as to the government of amateur billiard players appears to have been settled. The solution of the problem, and one which has already found a boat of enthusiastic supporters, lies in the establishment of an entirely new organization which will pass upon the amateur status of billiard players and govern amateur championships, sectional matches, and club tournaments.

THE pedestrian looked scornfully at the beggar who had accosted him. "You say you want money for your starving wife and family," he repeated. "I don't believe you have any." "Well, wot of it?" asked the beggar brazenly. "I believe you're lying," presisted the pedestrian with conviction.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Tour advice to the Citizens' Union on municipal ownership should be supplemented by your advice to that association how to gain influence with the masses and to become, like Tammany, a popular institution. In order to enjoy harvesting, planting is a required condition.

A prime reason why street traffic in this city is unsafe is that our police have been cowed. They have been under a regine which has sadly shaken their moral courage and left them trembling with fear. They have realized that if in making arrests they happened to tread on the toes of a relative or friend of Mr. Devery they night land next day in King's Bridge or Richmond."

While all would seem to be moving along gloriously with regard to our export iron and steel trade -- note that there was an increase in value for outward shipments of iron and steel for October, before the recent stir to reduce railroad rates on export freight -- there seem to lie ahead factors to be reckoned with which may not easily be brushed aside.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week-ended Tuesday:

FRAGMENTS of the conversation which floated out from a Hester. Street alley interested a passer-by to such a degree that he fell back among the irregular shadows of a housewall to listen. This is what he heard:

While waiting on Ellis Island for the United States Supreme Court to decide whether he is entitled to land here or must be deported to England, John Turner, self-confessed "philosophic Anarchist," is a prisoner in the strictest sense of the word. Two uniformed guards watch over him day and night.
CLIFFORD," said the stern parent, "go over and sit in that chair."
ROME, Dec. 5. -- It is now considered to be assured that Pope Pius, who already has created Mgr. Callegari, Bishop of Padua, a Cardinal, is about to call him to Rome definitely.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am much interested in the question of church attendance, which has been referred to in several of your issues lately. The census, however, showing the attendance at Catholic churches seems to me incorrect.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 5. -- The plunge into the icy sea by which Boatswain Patrick Deery of the United States naval tug Peoria saved the submarine torpedo boat Adder last Wednesday was the fourth time that the daring seaman has carried lines through raging waters to wrecks and drowning men during his twenty years' service in the navy.

If anything, this coming week promises to be duller than the week which has just passed into history. The debutantes have it all their own way. The days are taken up with receptions -- the last modern transformation of teas and kettledrums -- and the evenings with dinners and very small dances, at which the receiving party is augmented by some ten or twenty other guests.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am sorry to see in your Wednesday's issue that you favor a revision of some parts of the Bible, by the Roman Catholics and Protestants, so that it may be read in the public schools without offense to either of them. Such a revision could only be upon doctrinal parts, as I think they do not clash upon any other.

Something of that system of local option with which the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott would meet the Sunday saloon question in Greater New York is in operation all through the State of New Jersey. And yet it is not many years since the people of that rich little commonwealth indignantly spurned a specific bill permitting the localities to have what each desired in the way of Sunday saloon regulation.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Dec. 5. -- Following the suppression of an editorial in The Victor Herald, Provost Marshal McClelland threatened to cut off Cripple Creek from the outside world by looking up the correspondence of the Denver papers and to censor all matter to be sent to the Denver papers.

The bank statement was featureless. The increase in loans was less than was feared from the recent activity in the stock market end from the firmness of money. Out-of-town banks have been loaning rather freely from their New York deposits, and rates of exchange on New York at other cities indicate a desire to increase such deposits.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 5. -- Eighteen thousand deer, moose, and caribou were shot and brought out of the woods of Northern Minnesota during the twenty days' open season which ended last Tuesday. This is the estimate of the State Game and Fish Commissioners, and the same authority estimates that there are still 200,000 animals left in the State.

There has been a very considerable improvement in the coal trade, in both branches, during the past fortnight, and this has been laregly brought about by the change in climatic conditions, for while the anthracite is a fuel of the Eastern and Middle States, the greater portion of the States beyond New York and New Jersey use the bituminous variety.

As the price of exchange has been declining to the lowest level in over a decade there has been stimulated in the situation a great amount of "outside interest"; the interest of men not directly concerned with Wall Street affairs, but who are keen observers and students of all such remarkable situations as the present one.

ALWAYS the women had had the deepest sympathy for the night watchmen, those brave, strong, and tireless men who, wide awake while all the world slept, looked after its interest. She determined to devote a night or two to the study of their lives. On the corner next to her place of abode there had been for the past year a house in process of erection.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to call public attention to the fact that the Interurban Street Railway Company still refuses to issue transfers at a number of points of intersection of its lines in violation of law, thus causing great inconvenience to the people and great loss by them of money paid in extra fares, which are literally stolen from them by the company.
WHAT is a Theatre? A Theatre is a place where we pay a speculator two dollars and a half to witness an anatomical display called "Musical Comedy."

UMBRELLAS and questions of their ownership give rise to many friendship-straining suspicions, but seldom to any less well-founded than that which tell upon an elderly and respected citizen of Asbury Park when he made his quarterly pilgrimage to this city one day last week.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 5. -- Representative clergymen of Rhode Island, headed by the Right Rev. W.W. McVickar, Episcopal Bishop, who have been endeavoring for years to have the State divorce laws amended, have entered into an agreement regarding the matter of marrying divorced persons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The army and navy football game seems to present a favorable opportunity for putting in contrast the hygienic environments of the two seats of learning. Annapolis is a sea level situation, while West Point is located in the upper air of the Catskill Mountains.

"New York uses from 25,000 to 30,000 Christmas trees a year," said George A Blank, a West Street dealer yesterday. "The season is just opening. My first car came this week, and I expect to receive them in sufficient quantities to supply air most any demand from now on to the end of the season, which is usually Christmas Eve.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Speaker Cannon announced the various committees at the opening of the House to-day.

In her numerous student duels Germany supplies an unrivaled field for ear grafting, and the experiment has frequently been made by eminent surgeons there, but without success. The American ear which has just attached itself by natural processes of growth to a head different from the one on which it originally sprouted serves to show that the operation is feasible, and inserts a high feather in the cap of American surgery.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Speaker Cannon to-day announced the House committees for the Fifty-eighth Congress.
OGDENSBURG, Dec. 5. -- George W. Hurlbut, District Attorney of St. Lawrence County, has retired, and the Board of Supervisors has discovered a shortage in his accounts amounting to $599.93.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The report of David O. Watkins, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, recently submitted to Gov. Murphy, contains much data of interest relative to, the building and loan associations of the State.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- The week ends with the money market dull and firm. Call loans, 5 1/2@6 1/2 per cent.; time loans on collateral 5@6 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 6@6 1/2 per cent. Clearing House loans, 5 per cent. New York funds, 5 cents premium. Clearings, $21,172,019. Balances, $1,431,659.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In comparing the secession of Panama with the attempted secession of the South in 1861, the Republican Party has been charged with inconsistency in encouraging in 1903 what it resisted in 1861. The Republican Party has only itself and its arguments in 1861 to thank for this apparent inconsistency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Gen. Rafael Reyes, the special Minister from Colombia, practically initiated his mission when he called upon President Roosevelt at the White House to-day and told him why he had come to Washington. Gen. Reyes was accompanied to the White House from the State Department by Secretary Hay, who introduced him to the President, and by Dr. Herran, the Colombian Charge.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am aware that I am only resuscitating an old grievance of all music lovers and theatregoers when I ask you to publish this, my earnest protest against the objectionable habit of certain thoughtless or badly behaved people in our city who insist upon commencing preparations for leaving -- and actually leave-the concert, opera, or play before the last number or act is completed.

The coming of the young Irish writer, Mr. WILLIAM BUTLER YEATS, to these shores is interesting in itself, because as lecturer and writer Mr. YEATS is interesting; but it becomes more important when we consider him as YEATS the Forerunner, the voice crying in the desert which heralds the advent of Irish literature in the Western world.

COLON Dec. 5 -- Through a letter the Panama Government has discovered what is alleged to have been a plot against the life of Gen. Huertas, Commander in Chief of the forces of the Republic of Panama, and an effort on the part of a few army officers to persuade the garrison at Panama to revolt.

A fact that deserves frequent repetition is that a very large part of the community is directly interested in the profits or losses of the railway and other great corporations. The number of "railway barons" is exceedingly small; the number of fellow-partners of the railroad magnates and officers is notably large.
AT woman who moved from a steam-heated apartment in New York to a stove-heated house in Brooklyn was astonished when she answered the door bell and a girl not out of her teens said:
THE oath of Hippocrates is as modern as though it were written yesterday. The physician who keeps it faithfully thinks more of his fellow-creatures than of himself.

AND so they split," said Mrs. Meekin. "One-half of the managers wanted to do one thing and the other half wanted to do something else. They couldn't come to an agreement, so the dissenting faction cut loose from the original institution and founded a nursery of their own.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- Winter has come on rapidly, and already several deaths from cold are reported, but the temperature undergoes sudden changes from day to day. Official weather prophets declare Paris must be prepared for a ten years' spell of bad weather.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Senator Hanna denies the statement that he has told the President he would not act as Chairman of the National Committee in the next campaign. He said this morning:

A WRITER about things theatrical who supplies a New York letter to half a dozen papers throughout the country, in the course of his utterances has expressed the opinion that it is a pity a certain actress, recently married, is about to give up her stage career, pointing out that more brilliant triumphs probably awaited her than any she has yet enjoyed.

As was expected, Mr. Henry Arthur Jones's "Whitewashing Julia" has been no more heartily welcomed here than it was in London. From the outset it was evident that it lacked the comic force of "The Liars" and the rousing dramatic appeal of "Mrs. Dane's Defense." But the fact does not lessen one's admiring ardor in its behalf.

An interesting gift has just been presented to the New York Historical Society, being the old flintlock fowling piece once owned and used by Rufus King. The gun was evidently made over 100 years ago, for it is of English manufacture, the barrel and handle handsomely engraved with small hunting scenes, and the letters "R. K." in gold script are inscribed upon each side of the flintlock.

THE feminine frequenters of the opera having discovered that the red and gold decorations of the house are subdued enough in tone to admit of the wearing of other than white and pastel-tinted gowns to advantage, bright hues are again adding to the picturesqueness of the audiences.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Mr. Williams, the minority leader, asked and obtained unanimous consent, after the committees in the House had been announced to-day, that an hour be given to a general discussion, thirty minutes to each side.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial this morning you call a correspondent to task for "either knowing more than experts about the action of the telephone, or a good deal less."

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5. -- The imports of coffee to New Orleans yesterday passed the 1,000,000 bag mark, and the records in the Custom House to-day will show that the total receipts in the eleven months of the current year are four times what they were five years ago.

Surrogate Thomas yesterday appointed Adolph Herschel and Lorenzo Semple administrators of the estate of Maximilian Herschel, once a tobacco peddler, who died in St. Luke's Hospital last July, and ordered that they file a bond in the sum of $250,000.

Surrogate Thomas yesterday appointed Adolph Herschel and Lorenzo Semple administrators of the estate of Maximilian Herschel, once a tobacco peddler, who died in St. Luke's Hospital last July, and ordered that they file a bond in the sum of $250,000.

Inventive genius in America to-day is being persistently and effectively discouraged, instead of stimulated, by existing conditions both inside and outside the United States Patent Office, according to a prominent New York lawyer, who for twenty years was associated with that bureau as Chief Clerk, Assistant Examiner, and Principal Examiner, and who says that his views are shared by other persons familiar with the situation.

The character of last week's market is so well known that there will be no surprise at the fact that only ten stocks fell as much as a point, while 123 advanced a point or more. That it was a speculative rather than investment movement appears from comparison with the bond movement.

Portia before the Venetian Tribunal opposed bending the law to the Duke's authority. "'Twill be," she said, "recorded as a precedent, and many an error by the same example will rush into the State." The Benchers of Gray's Inn decline to admit a British Portia as a student there, and the House of Lords sustains the decision on the ground that there are no precedents for such admission and no reason to create one.

Through blind obedience to the dictates of Samuel J. Parks and his colleagues during the last Summer of idleness, at least 2,000 members of Local No. 2 of the ironworkers will be idle all Winter. Though Parks is in Sing Sing and his colleague, McCarth, is on Blackwell's Island, the effects of their influence on the union still remain.

A mass meeting under the direction of the Irish Industrial League of America was held in Carnegie Hall last night to indorse the efforts of the Irish Agricultural Organization Society in the development of an industrial Ireland. The hall was well filled when Justice Morgan J. O'Brien, the chairman, called the meeting to order.

A rival substance to radium in its interest to the public called actinium is now being experimented with by Dr. George F. Kunz, the chemist and diamond expert of this city. While little is known of the properties of actinium, Dr. Kunz said yesterday that a philanthropic organization in Buffalo has shown sufficient faith in its properties to offer to experiment with it in its cancer hospital.

That whatever influence Tammany Hall can bring to bear in the next Democratic National Convention will be for the nomination of Grover Cleveland was the explicit assertion last night of persons who are very close to Charles F. Murphy. That leader, it is asserted, believes that Mr. Cleveland, notwithstanding his recent letter to St. Clair McKelway putting aside all suggestion of further Presidential honors, should toe renamed as the party's standard-bearer.
A very interesting and encouraging account is given in the report of the Secretary of War of the progress of the system for placing the currency of the Philippines on the gold basis.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 6. -- The Winter schedule of the United States Steel Corporation, so far as its Western interests lie, is now fully in force. Every ship of the Pittsburg steamship fleet belonging to the corporation is laid up for the Winter. The number of these vessels has been variously stated.

As a result of investigations by the Fire Marshal and his assistants, reinforced by members of District Attorney Jerome's staff, Deputy. Assistant District Attorney Francis P. Garvan said yesterday that he expected that during the week charges of grand larceny against several public fire adjusters, fire insurance adjusters, three lawyers at least, and some members of the Fire Patrol would be presented to the Grand Jury.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 6. -- Fred Grant Gleason, director of the Auditorium Conservatory of Music, and one of the best-known teachers in the West, died early this morning. Mr. Gleason was born fifty-five years ago in Hartford, Conn. He inherited musical talent and went to Germany to complete his education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- In his annual report, made public to-day, Controller of the Currency William, B. Ridgely renews his recommendations contained in his report for 1902 for legislation in regard to liquidation and consolidation of National banks and extension of corporate existence.

-- A New York newspaper-the name we will be considerate enough not to mention, but really, it ought to have known better -- stated on Saturday, in the course of a short biography of WILLIAM ASTOR CHANLER, which it had occasion to print -- that he had "gained considerable distinction as a tiger hunter in Africa."

NEWARK. N.J., Dec. 6. -- Unless inclement weather interferes the big double-deck bridge of the Lackawanna Railroad will, on Dec. 20, be lifted from the stone pier on which the draw now stands, will be moved northward about fifty feet, and then lowered eleven feet. The draw weighs, about 2,000 tons, and when it was placed in the position it now occupies it was designed to do with it just what will be done.

YOKOHAMA, Nov. 11. -- "Demonstration Dinner" is the name given to the dinner at Tokio last night, at which the impatience of the Japanese people with the slow progress of the Russo-Japanese negotiations was expressed.

At the annual meeting of the Brooklyn Handball Club., which was held at the Degraw Street Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, the reports of the Secretary and Treasurer showed that the past year had been a prosperous one for this organization, which has among its members the oldest and stanchest supporters of the Gaelic game in the country.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Times denounces the reports concerning Emperor William's health which convey the impression that his Majesty's recovery is not proceeding satisfactorily and that he is in an alarming condition.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 6. -- Bishop Edwin S. Lines has reappointed the Rev. Dr. Alexander Mann, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Orange, an archdeacon of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark. The Rev. Dr. William R. Jenvey, rector of St. Paul's Church, Jersey City, has also been reappointed.

Andrew Carnegie's wish that the American Institute of Social Service should formulate a plan which would make Dumfermline, Scotland, his native town, a place in which life would be made more pleasant for the toiling masses -- a scheme toward which he recently transferred by trust deed Pittencrieff Park and Glen and $2,500,000 -- yesterday was made public by the organization to which he appealed for co-operation in the matter.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 6. -- Cardinal Gibbons in a sermon to a large congregation at the Cathedral to-day, made a vigorous attack upon the sweatshop system and strongly advocated what is known as union-made goods. The sermon was delivered by special request, the Cardinal being one of the Vice Presidents of the Consumers' League, which advocates the purchase of union-made goods.

Mr. FORAKER seems to have seen a certain light. He has learned from our experience with Porto Rico that relatively free trade with our dependencies does not hurt us and helps them greatly. He is ready to extend the same sort of freedom, and even a greater measure of it, to the Philippines.

The third of the concerts of the New York Symphony Orchestra, under Mr. Walter Damiosch, which was given yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, was devoted to the works of Hector Berlioz, to commemorate the hundredth anniversary of his birth, falling on Dec. 11. The concert was planned upon an unusually elaborate scale, enlisting the assistance of three solo singers and a chorus from the Oratorio Society.

In the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, the pastor, the Rev. Dr. David Gregg, read a letter announcing his resignation, to accept a call to the Presidency of the Western Theological Seminary, at Allegheny, Penn.

The latest announcement as to the Chamberlain campaign is puzzling. It is that Mr. CHAMBERLAIN agrees with, the Premier, Mr. BALFOUR, that there need be no appeal to the country for at least a year and preferably not before two years.

Nobody, soldier or civilian, who has had occasion to consider Secretary ROOT'S administration of the War Departament for these last years, can fail to regret that the reports of which we publish a summary this morning should be the last he is to render in his present official capacity.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- The final competition in the home-and-home court tennis matches arranged between "Ted" Johnson of the Princess Club, London, and of Tuxedo, and John White of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, but formerly of Hampton Court, England, was decided on the court of the Tuxedo Tennis and Racquet Club to-day in favor of Johnson, who gained a decisive victory over his opponent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- It still remains uncertain whether or not the President will undertake, to-morrow to carry out the plan of assuming the power to declare that a "constructive recess" of Congress exists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- This week's meeting of the Republican National Committee at the Arlington promises to be full of political interest. The committee has but two items of business in prospect. One is the selection of a city to entertain the next National Convention. The other is the fixing of a date on which the convention shall assemble.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Representative Grosvenor, Chairman of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, to which ship subsidy bills will be referred, said to-night that so far as he was concerned the published report that a compromise had been effected whereby no ship subsidy bill would be pushed at this session, but a commission, of investigation of the subject created instead, was erroneous.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 7. -- The Hubbard Shovel Works, one of the largest manufactories of its kind in the country, employing nearly 1,000 men, and covering a ground space of nearly five acres in Butler Street, near the Sharpsburg Bridge, was almost totally destroyed by fire which broke out at 11:30 o'clock last night.

Negotiations are now pending with a view to extending the benefits and usefulness of the Fur Merchants' Credit Association, by admitting to membership a number of other importing houses, so as practically to control affairs in this line.

GLENS FALLS, Dec. 6. -- James A. Emerson, banker, of Warrensburg and brother of ex-Congressman Louis W. Emerson, has announced his candidacy for the State Senate in the Thirty-first -- Warren, Essex, Clinton -- District, which is now represented by Spencer G. Prime of Upper Jay, Essex County.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Ex-Assistant Attorney General James N. Tyner, who is under indictment on the charge of conspiring with his nephew, Harrison J. Barrett, to connive at certain violations of the "fraud and lottery statutes," has addressed a letter to President Roosevelt. In it he takes exceptions to the denunciation of him by the President before an opportunity had been afforded to present his defense in court.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 6. -- After a wild ride from Rockaway to Morristown, Sheriff Abraham Ryerson landed Frank Vetzar, the Hibernia murderer, in Jail here, and prevented a threatened lynching. Vetzar is the Hungarian miner who shot nine-year-old Elsie Root last night. The child died at 5 o'clock this morning without regaining consciousness.

Four minutes after midnight this morning the eleventh annual international championship six-day team bicycle race was begun in the Madison Square Garden, and the, big amphitheatre was Jammed with a record-breaking crowd. Of the eighteen tearing, entered; seventeen started, the men being sent on their way by James J. Corbett, ex-heavy weight champion pugilist.

A pessimistic view of the political and social conditions in America was taken by Justice John Woodward of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in an address delivered by him before the Brooklyn Lodge of the Benevolent Protective Order, of Elks at their annual memorial service, held in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, Dec. 6. -- Arnous de Riviere, the manager of the forthcoming international chess masters' tournament announced this morning that only six players would be invited to take part in the congress, which is to begin in the first week of February and to conclude in the first week of March, the exact dates to be announced later.

While going through the third floor of Naething's restaurant at 118 Fulton Street, to get out the tenants during a fire there last night, Patrolman Frank J. Redican, twenty-nine years old, of the Old Slip Police Station, whose home was at 46 Rose Street, was suffocated by smoke and died in spite of the efforts of Drs. Wells and Sylvester of the Hudson Street Hospital.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 7. -- Chapter two of the Lake Michigan water scandal was opened to the public to-night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Mayor-elect McClellan to-night announced the appointment of John J. Delany to be Corporation Counsel for New York City.

The President sees extraordinary possibilities and potencies in the Bureau of Corporations which is a division of the new Department of Commerce created by the law of February, 1903. The chief of this bureau has authority to call upon corporations engaged in inter-State commerce to disclose to him pretty much everything he may want to know about their capitalization and operations.

Wall Street opened its new week with some change of details, but no change of heart nor any new tone of business -- nor unhappily of news. International Power rose 15, but was not exactly active. The next strongest stock on the list was Westinghouse, which rose 6, following a riser of 10 last week, and 25 for the preferred.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Dec. 7. -- A murderous assault was made on Father Roach of Cascade, Dubuque County, Iowa, Sunday afternoon, while he was at the altar celebrating vespers. The church was well filled, and just as Father Roach was ascending the altar steps to give the benediction of the Blessed Sacrament, a young man was seen to rise in a pew in the middle aisle, throw off his overcoat, and walk toward the door.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The funeral of former Representative William M. Springer of Illinois was held at the Metropolitan Methodist Episcopal Church to-day, the Rev. F.M. Bristol, pastor of the church officiating. There was a large attendance at the services, including many members of both houses of Congress, and the floral tributes were numerous.

MOSCOW, Dec. 7. -- The Town Council of Moscow is discussing a proposal to ask the Government's permission to import American street car rails, which are badly needed in consequence of the failure of Russian firms to supply the heavy rails required by the new lines. The failure is due to lack of proper machinery.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Vice Chancellor Reed to-day began to take testimony in the final hearing on the application of Edwin A. McAlpin and other stockholders of the Universal Tobacco Company for a receiver to take charge of the affairs and assets of the company.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 7. -- At a meeting of R.E. Lee Camp, United Confederate Veterans, the following resolutions were passed, and it was ordered that copies be sent to President Roosevelt, the President of Colombia, and United States Senator Culberson of Texas:...

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- In a statement, which places his assets at more than four times as much as his liabilities, John Alexander Dowie to-day, at a meeting attended by a majority of his creditors, submitted a proposal by which it is believed that the financial tangle at Zion City will be straightened in a satisfactory manner.
Capt. Joseph Burns of the Church Street Station, using a cab, raided, in rapid succession, two alleged poolrooms yesterday afternoon, capturing in each place the men he wanted and had warrants for.

ROME, Dec. 7. -- Signor Mascagni, in a speech which he delivered at a dinner given to him in Turin, said that his new opera, "Vestilia," was finished. He declared that he would not give it to any impresario, but would keep it for himself and for his own profit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs resumed the hearing of the Gen. Leonard Wood case this afternoon, occupying the peculiar position of investigating a nomination which had failed by reason of the expiration of the extra session of the Senate.
COLON, Dec. 7. -- A rumor is in circulalation here to the effect that 3,000 soldiers have left Cartagena for the purpose of invading the Isthmus.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The requisition of Gov. Dockery of Missouri upon Gov. Odell for the extradition of William Ziegler of New York upon an indictment in Cole County, Mo., on the charge of furnishing funds for the bribery of Missouri legislators in connection with Baking Powder legislation, was the subject of a hearing before the Governor to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7. -- The assertion that ideas on official corruption that were incorporated in the President's message were furnished by Circuit Attorney Folk of this city will be made to-morrow morning by a local newspaper.
BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- Frank G. Coburn of Brookline, contractor and builder, filed a bankruptcy petition to-day, showing liabilities amounting to $236,448. No assets are mentioned in the schedule.

Advance Renamed. -- In the light of yesterday's developments in the stock market. It would appear that Saturday's reactionary movement was nothing more than a half for breath, and not, as some were inclined to regard it, the culmination of an upward movement which had lasted nearly a whole week, having been sustained much beyond other recent recoveries in the stock market.

Assistant District Attorney Garvan, who as been investigating the alleged systematic swindling of fire insurance companies in this city by means of fraudulent claims of loss, last night gave some detail of the inner workings of the system and the latest of the frauds which had been disclosed by the investigation.

Whitehouse Porter have sold for the Travers estate to Walter J. Cohn and William Rosenzweig the plot, 195 by 100.5, on the south side of One Hundredth Street, 100 feet west of Madison Avenue, opposite the Mount Sinai Hospital.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The demand for money in the market to-day increased, owing to the Transvaal loan call to-morrow and anticipation of scarcity in connection with the Stock Exchange settlement. Discounts were firm on the weak tendency of New York exchange.

Mme. Tagliavia and Mme. Weill, the harpists of the Metropolitan Opera House, accompanied by Nahan Franko, appeared yesterday afternoon before the examining committee of the Musical Mutual Protective Association at the headquarters, in the "Old Homestead," Ninety-first Street and Third Avenue.

There was a fairly active market yesterday in the trading in curb securities. Imporvement was shown in a number of stocks, while the bond market was only moderately active. A good number were traded in with only one or two declines, Cuban 6s of 1896 still retain their prominence as the strongest bond in the list, selling 4 points higher, at 80.

Mr. ROOSEVELT is noncommittal as to the currency and indefinite as to the financial situation of the Government. The only specific recommendation he makes is that the Secretary of the Treasury be given the authority to deposit the receipts from customs as he can now deposit those from other sources.

The fact that Secretary ROOT has advised the President that he may make the nominations of Gen. WOOD and the rest of the army officers in the inappreciable space of time assumed to exist between the end of the extra session and the beginning of the regular session, disposes one to await the reasoning by which such advice is sustained before condemning it.

SHARON, Penn., Dec. 7. -- The Sharon works of the American Steel Foundries Company resumed operations to-day after being shut down some time on account of a scarcity of orders. The wage scale has not been adjusted, but the men will continue at work until some agreement is reached.

WESTCHESTER, Penn., Dec. 7. -- Aldred Sharpless, a well-known writer on reform and agricultural topics, and who gained a National reputation for his "John Ploughshare" letters, published many years ago, died here to-day, aged eighty-two years. He was a prominent mineralogist, and had a rare collection of relics relating to the aborigines.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- To-day's market would have been a dull one had not active trading been indulged in in the arbitrage stocks. The latter's number was the largest recently recorded, and was regarded as an evidence that there is an improvement in commission house business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Two curious features were noticeable in the comment on the President's message in the House of Representatives. One was that most of the Republicans had so little interest in it that they had not taken the trouble to read it or to listen to it when the message was read, and so had nothing to say about it.

Mayor Low yesterday declared himself heartily in favor of Gen. Greene's proposed amendment to the present excise law as outlined in Sunday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES. The salient features were to provide for local option, not only by the city itself, but by the different districts, on the questions of Sunday opening of the saloons, and a referendum at the coming election upon which shall depend the final adoption of the plan.

How does Mr. HAINES, the President of the S.P.C.A., know that it is cruelty to animals to hunt a stag with hounds and horses? He says it is, and he has succeeded in getting a local representative of his society in New Jersey to agree with him and to threaten the promoters of a stag hunt in that State with the penalties of a statute forbidding the "capturing, tormenting, or overdriving" of any animal.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The horses comprising the American racing stable owned by James R. Keene and trained at Newmarket by M. M. Allen, were sold at public auction by the Tattersalls Company at Newmarket to-day. The horses sold included a number of highly tried horses, among them three two-year-olds engaged in the Epsom Derby of 1904, and at present regarded as giving promise of developing into Derby material.

Jealous of the fame of the Terrible Nine -- those associated and amalgamated assassins at the Grand Opera House who make life exciting for "The Queen of the White Slaves" -- the gang of associated but not amalgamated murderers who on Monday nights are accustomed to infest the Broadway playhouses made a pilgrimage last evening to Eighth Avenue.

At midnight last night only fourteen of the eighteen teams which started in the international six-day team race twenty-four hours previously continued in the contest, which is attracting great crowds of spectators to the Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The report of E.C. Brandenberg, attorney in charge of bankruptcy matters in the Department of Justice, shows that 14,308 voluntary petitions in bankruptcy were filed throughout the United States for the year ended Sept. 30, 1903, which is more than 2,000 less than were filed during any of the preceding years since the enactment of the law on July 1, 1898.

It is pleasing to note that the trading in curb stocks yesterday was active, and that strength developed throughout the list. The bond list also continues to show considerable activity, though the market was not as broad as on a number of days during the last ten sessions. The copper stocks drew the most attention, owing to the early strength of Greene Consolidated and White Knob.

Rumors of the consolidation of the rival National and American Baseball Leagues which have been persistently circulated for some weeks-were denied by all of the representatives of the National League clubs who attended the first session of the annual meeting of that organization, which was held in the Victoria Hotel, Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street, yesterday.

There were several teas yesterday afternoon including tie first of two which will be given by Miss Nora Godwm for her niece, Miss de Castro. There was also the wedding of Miss Alice Hammond Drake and Alonzo Clark Robinson. The Tuesday Evening Dance was also on the schedule, With the exception of bridge parties and a few dinners and the opera there is nothing on for this evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Ohio delegation in Congress has been much wrought up all day and has been discussing the President with more heat than friendliness. Even his friends are displeased. The cause of the trouble is what the delegation considers an affront.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 8 -- Summoned by the ringing of the bell of the Berkeley Avenue Baptist Church to-night, a mob of white Democrats stormed the office of the Berkeley Improvement Board, in which were County Treasurer Lyons, Commissioner of Revenue Nicholas, Town Recorder Old, Deputy County Clerk W.H. Lyons, and nearly a score of negroes, and rushed the entire party from the building to the street.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 8. -- That a combination for the sale of all the book paper manufactured in the Northwestern States is being formed was the announcement made to-day at a meeting of the General Paper Company, the agency or selling trust formed to market all the print, fibre, and manila paper made in Wisconsin, Minnesota, and Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Further testimony was given before the Senate Military Affairs Committee to-day bearing on the acts of Brigadier Gen. Leonard Wood. Gen. James H. Wilson, United States Army, retired, was one of the witnesses. He charged Gen. Wood with causing attacks on other officers and attributed his advance to favoritism.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 8 -- The United States Court of Appeals to-day delivered a decision against trusts, giving to persons, or corporations, obliged, to pay excessive prices, the right to recover damages in three times the amount sustained.

On the steamship Yucatan, which arrived yesterday from Colon, were several persons who come from the interior States of Colombia. All of them predicted revolutions throughout the country against their treatment by Bogota. They said that the success of Panama had caused the other States which had planned revolution to take heart, as a result of which the entire country will soon be in a turmoil.

COLON, Dec. 8 -- A company of marines from the United States auxiliary cruiser Dixie, under command of Capt. Kirt McCreary, were landed here this morning and took a train for Empire, a town on the railroad near Panama, where a camp was established in the Canal Company's buildings. Another company of marines, to the number of fifty, from the Dixie left on the afternoon train for Empire.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 8. -- The Athletic Committee of Harvard University, which was asked by the Faculty of Arts and Science to report whether the big college football contests should be discontinued, reported to-day that it is not advisable at present to stop football games between university elevens. The report says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The annual report of Secretary of the Treasury Leslie M. Shaw, submitted to the Speaker of the House of Representatives to-day, shows a year of general commercial prosperity and lays particular stress on the fact that the tremendous depreciation of values in securities" now generally admitted to be inflated, has brought no general financial ruin in its train.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 8. -- E.H. Harriman, has failed in his mission to the Pacific Coast so far as if pertains to the war between the Southern Pacific and the Pacific Coast Steamship Company on one hand and the owners of steam schooners, who are cutting passenger rates up and down the Pacific Coast, on the other.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- John Alexander Dowie is again in control of Zion City and all its industries.

There are several passages in the message of the President that are extremely encouraging as showing his attitude toward the merit system and the marked progress it has made under his friendly Administration.
First Lieut, Augustus F.W. MacManus, Twenty-fifth Infantry, will report at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, for observation and medical treatment.
WASHINGTON, Dec., 8. -- What-the majority Senators have feared most happened to-day in the Senate. The Democrats took up the Post Office investigation and hammered hard on it.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 8. -- Brief in behalf of the Northern Securities Company and the Northern Pacific Railway Company in the case of the United States versus those two companies and the Great Northern Company were filed in the Supreme Court to-day. The brief of the Securities Company is a document of over 300 pages, and in it G.B. Young, the attorney, traces minutely the origin of the merger.
Charles F. Murphy yesterday held a private conference with Senator Patrick H. McCarren, and it was learned that they will probably go to Washington to spend Sunday with Mayor-elect McClelian.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 8. -- The United States flag over the Consulate at Alexandretta, Asiatic Turkey, has been, hauled down and Consul Davis has left his post for Beirut in consequence of a serious diplomatic incident during which he was insulted and assaulted by the local police.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- A technical point in the Dreyfus case, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, has aroused a controversy in the Paris press. The question is whether the decision of the Court of Cassation is final, or, if the Rennes court verdict is quashed, whether another court-martial will be necessary.

The St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad Company made public yesterday its plan for retiring the New Orleans extension purchase money collateral trust 4 per cent, gold bonds of 1942 and the preferred stock of the St. Louis, San Francisco and New Orleans Railroad Company. This is to be accomplished by an issue of 4 1/2 per cent, five-year gold notes, which in turn are "to be, retired by bonds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The second annual meeting of the Trustees of Carnegie Institute was held in this city to-day. There were two sessions, with a dinner following this evening. Andrew Carnegie, who set aside the fund for the institution, was present, as also was Alexander Agassiz of Cambridge, Mass., the President of the National Academy of Sciences.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8 -- Former Postal Clerks Thomas W. McGregor and Columbus Ellsworth Upton were convicted today, in the United States District Court, of conspiracy to defraud the Government in conrection with the purchase of 20,000 leather pouches for use in the free-delivery service.

Miles Helfer have sold for Dennison P. Chesebro to Ernest B. Wintersmith, 41 and 43 University Place, four-story buildings on plot 51 by 120 and irregular. Sailors' Snug Harbor leasehold. In part paymeat Mr. Chesebro takes two Brooklyn dwellings, one at the northwest corner of Bainbridge Street and Lewis Avenue, 20 by 100, and the other at the northwest corner of Sterling Place and Virginia Place, 20 by $5.

The steamship Kaiser Wilhelm II of the North German Lloyd Line arrived yesterday from Bremen with her cabins filled with what was said to be the largest number of passengers that has ever returned by one steamship at this season of the year. There were about 770 people aboard, exclusive of those in the steerage.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 8. -- The resignation of J.W. Castles, President of the Hibernia Bank and Trust Company of this city, the largest financial institution in the South, with resources of $14,000,000, is announced. He resigned to accept the Presidency of the Guarantee Trust Company of New York City, and will assume his new duties Jan. 1.

James S. Alderdice, who was counsel for Mrs. Mary J. Oliver, the Harlem recluse who died Nov. 9, was arrested yesterday by Detective Bernard A. Flood of the District Attorney's office on a warrant issued charging him with uttering forged deeds.

ALBANY, Dec. 8. -- The attempt of Robert E. Niles to win from the New York Central Railroad Company and the, successors of Drexel, Morgan Co. damages for the absorption of the New York and Northern Railroad Company was defeated by a decision of the Court of Appeals to-day, which sustains the lower courts in decisions adverse to Niles's claim.
The influence of food upon the brain and memory is so little understood that people are inclined to marvel at it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The House today delivered another blow at the Senate, and this time it was a body blow.

The Seventh annual dinner of the Bible class of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church was held last evening at the Hotel Vendome, at Broadway and Forty-ninth Street. At the guests' table were the officers of the church and of the Sunday school, Chauncey M. Depew, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., the Rev. Dr. R.P. Johnston, pastor of the church, his assistant, the Rev. W.S. Richardson, and William D. Murphy, who acted as toastmaster.

-- About as funny as anything that has recently found its way into print is the assertion, ascribed in the brief reports of the addresses made before the National, Indian Association to Mr. DARWIN R. JAMES, that "the Indians are living in ease and luxury on incomes derived from the leasing of their land, and the only way to remedy this evil is to instill a certain amount of selfishness into them by education."

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8. -- Four favorites, two of which were at odds on in the betting, won at the Crescent City track this afternoon. The defeat of Big Ben and Rainland, both of which were heavily backed at a short price, helped to even up the score for the books. The racing was tame.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Carnegle gave a large dinner party this evening in the private suite of the New Willard, at, which their guests were chiefly the Directors of the Carnegie Institute. Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Carnegie were entertained at a luncheon at the White House to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the excitement caused by the recent Government report on the cotton crop, can you or any of your readers tell me whether there is anything more than an accidental coincidence between the following facts:

The above figures from the annual report of the Secretary of the Treasury are the most striking and interesting features of the report. The difference as between 1903 and 1904 is $40,000,000, caused by a decrease in the revenues, chiefly customs, of $20,000,000 and an increase all along the line in expenditures of $20,000,000.

GALVESTON, Texas, Dec. 8. -- Bids for raising the grade of the entire City of Gal veston seven feet to a level with the sea wall so as to prevent flood by tidal waves have been opened, showing that the lowest bid is from P.C. Goodhart and Linden W. Bates of New York, who offer to place the required 11,000,000 cubic yards of filling for 18 1/2 cents a cubic yard.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 8. -- Peace between Russia and Japan is now believed to be assured, as the result of the action of the Czar at Tsarskoye Selo, where he and Foreign Minister Lamsdorf have considered the reply to the Japanese proposals. If Japan is willing to accept some modifications there is nothing to stand in the way of a complete agreement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The following bills were introduced in Congress to-day:

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Herbert Spencer, the philosopher, died this morning at his home, in Brighton. His health bad been failing for Some months. The illness took a critical turn a few days ago, and he became unconscious last night, passing away without pain.

HERBERT SPENCER dying at eighty-three, had survived beyond the usual span of life the maladies that for years made him almost an invalid, just as his system of philosophy has survived nearly half a century of examination and attack, until it has come now to such wide acceptance that of habit and almost unconsciously it guides the thinking of a great part of intelligent mankind.

While attempting to cross the Third Avenue elevated tracks at One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Third Avenue last evening Charles A. Hartman, a watchman in the employ of the company, was run over and killed by a south-bound train of six cars.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- Thirty-eight different stocks were dealt in to-day at the Iocal Exchange -- an unusually large number. The increase came almost wholly from New York stocks, in which the arbitrage houses did an active business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Under weather conditions which were regarded as perfect, the Langley airship or aeroplane, was given a second trial to-day a short distance from Washington down the Potomac. The result was the complete wreck of the airship.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 8. -- Cotton manufacturers representing over 1,000,000 spindles and 25,000 looms, met here to-day, and after much, discussion adopted the following resolution:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The American National Red Cross Society, in annual meeting here to-day, decided to grant the request of the opposition for an investigation as to the condition of the work of the society. Not one of the twenty-three former members who were suspended, and later invited to return, was present at the meeting.

Senator Nathaniel A. Elsberg, who arrived from Europe yesterday on the Kaiser Wilhelm II., is reported to be the choice of Gov. Odell to succeed M. Linn Bruce as President of the Republican County Committee. Senator Elsberg was one of the three Senators who last session rebelled against Senator Platt.
BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- The local market again shows increased firmness. The strength is confined largely to call loans, and is due partly to the revived interest in the stock market.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Senator N.A. Elsberg of the Twenty-ninth District, who has just returned from Europe, his return being much earlier than he expected when he went abroad, had a long conference with Gov. Odell at the Executive Chamber today. Gen. Francis V. Greene had a conference with the Governor afterward.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- The Massachusetts Gas Companies informed counsel, representing Receiver Pepper of the Bay State Gas Company of Delaware, that unless the receiver before to-morrow enters injunction proceedings to prevent the same, it will immediately proceed to consolidate the several Boston gas companies in accordance with the act passed- by the last Massachusetts Legislature.

Negotiations are under way for the consolidation of two of the larger though lately organized trust companies -- the McVickar Realty Trust Company and the Empire State Trust Company. Neither of these institutions is much more than a year and a half old, although the predecessor of the McVickar Trust Company had existed before that time as a real estate firm for forty-five years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Senator Hoar to-day, and Senator Morgan of Alabama, both took occasion severely to criticise the relations of the Administration with Panama. Senator Hoar's criticism took the form of a resolution, which requested a complete account of the negotiations. Mr. Morgan, in discussing the Cuban bill, frequently referred to the Panama treaty, and in that connection condemned what he called "Presidential usurpation."

HAVANA, Dec. 9 -- United States Minister Squiers arrived here to-day from the United States on a flying trip In the middle of his vacation. Mr. Squiers declined to disclose the object of his visit, but he had an Interview with Foreign Minister Zaldo in connection with Isle of pines matters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Mr. Teller in the Senate to-day again took up the question of the activity of Gen. Wood, while acting as Governor of Cuba, In behalf of Cuban reciprocity with the United States. He said there were official records to show that the Cuban Government had paid to exceed $13,000 in that Interest during Gen. Wood's administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Publicity as a remedy against unfair dealings, dishonesty, and corruption in the conduct of the affairs of large corporations is one of the most important recommendations contained in the first annual report of the newly created Department of Labor and Commerce which was given cut for publication to-day.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times quotes a leading native journal, which says that the court will soon move to Singan-Foo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Criticism of Senator Hanna's action in appointing William F. Stone of Maryland Sergeant at Arms of the Republican National Committee will enliven the session of that body on Friday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- By forming a league with building trades unions and supply companies throughout the whole country, it is expected that the prospective National alliance of building contractors' associations will have the effect of freezing out independent contractors, non-union workmen, and building material concerns not affiliated.
CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 9 -- With official Chicago and citizen organizations alike determined to crush "the thug," efforts to that end were begun in many quarters to-day.
TRINIDAD, Col., Dec. 9 -- While a number of deputies and clerks were driving from Berwind to Tobasco this afternoon they were fired upon by several men concealed behind rocks and brush.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Bureau of Navigation, which is charged with the general supervision of the commercial marine and merchant seamen, except in certain particulars was transferred from, the Treasury Department to the Department of Labor and Commerce at the close of the fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- H.D. Dumont, a representative of the Merchants' Association of New York, protested to the President to-day against a recent decision of the Board of United States General Appraisers that silk ribbons must be classified as trimmings. In effect the decision increases the duty on silk ribbons from 50 per cent, to 60 per cent, of their value.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The Times's Russian correspondents say a curious thing has befallen the new Orenburg-Tashkent Railway, which, when completed, would shorten the distance and lessen the difficulties in transporting troops to the Afghan frontier and the Pamirs and cut down the railway distance between the heart of Russia and the Chinese frontier to two thousand miles.

In the course of the examination, yesterday afternoon before Magistrate Breen in the Centre Street Court of James S. Alderdice, charged with forging four deeds to the property, of Mrs. Mary J. Oliver, Mrs. Emma Jacobsoh, a granddaughter of the dead woman, said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Incidental to the general investigation being conducted by the Interior Department into the land frauds In the "West, an Inquiry is being made of the records in the General Land Office in "Washington by inspectors detailed for that purpose.

Business, upon the Stock Exchange on Tuesday and Wednesday had more resemblances than differences. There was the same unmistakable profit taking on both days, under cover of conspicuous strength in several specialties, while the wheelhorses of the market were stolid with inclination toward weakness.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for the estate of Adolph Bernheimer to Abraham Ruth the southwest corner of St. Nicholas Avenue and One Hundred and Twelfth Street, a plot of about seven and one-half lots, having frontages of 118 feet on the avenue and 148 feet on the street, with a southerly line of 209 feet The sellers have owned the property since 1871.

Those for whom the subtle problems of telephony have interest will read with the satisfaction of approval or disapproval as may be the letters which our editorial comments on the remarks of Mr. C.J.H. WOODBURY of the American Bell Telephone Company are calling out. Such a discussion is interesting, if not quite conclusive.

Trading in outside securities yesterday was about as broad as on Tuesday, but there, was a decrease in activity. Higher prices ruled throughout the list and several issues made large advances in sympathy with the higher prices on the board. Brooklyn Rapid Transit 4s were very active, about $116,000 selling 3/4 of a point up, at 77 1/2, while Interborough Rapid Transit advanced to 94 1/4, a gain of 1 1/4

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 9 -- C.S. Mellen, the new President of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, assured the members of the Chamber of Commerce to-night, at a banquet, that the personality of the men in charge of the road had changed, and that efficient and satisfactory service would be given hereafter.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- Money rates hold firm, and except in call money business is very quiet.

Trading Centralized -- Apart from the traction stocks yesterday's market was irregular and very much less active than it was the previous day. The advance in the group of stocks which were the leaders of the market were large enough to make the whole market fairly strong, but in other stocks the advance was not as well maintained as in the tractions.

It would serve no useful purpose to say anything which would increase the disappointment and mortification of Prof. LANGLEY at the instant and complete collapse of his airship, which broke in two and dropped into the Potomac, carrying Prof. MANLY to his second involuntary cold bath in that stream.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 -- War has been declared by the National Biscuit Company, with headquarters in Chicago, against the local cracker manufacturers.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Gov. Odell today appointed Clarence S. Ferris of Potsdam as District Attorney for the County of St. Lawrence, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of George W. Hurlbut.

Presbyterian union and the educational work of the denomination were discussed at representative meetings at the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue, yesterday, where it was also announced that on Monday the Rev. Dr. George Alexander pastor of the University Place Church and a Director of the Princeton Theological Seminary, had been elected President of the Board of Foreign Missions to succeed the late Rev. Dr. John D. Wells, who held that position for nineteen years.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- Considerable strength was displayed in the local market to-day, although extreme advances were not maintained in the active stocks. United Gas advanced easily 2 1/4 points, to $4 3/4, but under late realizing sales fell off 3/4. American Railways rose 1, Electric Storage Battery, 1 1/2, Reading later 1/2, and Welsbach Collateral Trust 5s 3 3/4, to 55.

At the treading to-day of Miss Rosalie Moran, daughter of Mr. Amedee Depat Moran, to Edward S. Knapp, at the ,Churci of the' Incarnation, as already announced Miss Marie L. Moran will be maid of honor. The bridesmaids are to be Miss Cornella Bryce, Miss Evelyn Parsons, Miss Liliias Livingston, and Miss Mary D. Lee.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day, and supplies were fairly abundant. Discounts were steady, though there was much nervousness on account of New York's demand for gold, notwithstanding the fact that the exchange rate was higher.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 9 -- The International Iron Molders' Union has begun proceedings to put a stop to a system of extortion, which, it is claimed, is practiced by foremen of foundries all over the country, of making men pay for their positions. It is asserted also that the foremen, not satisfied with receiving money for giving a man a place, demand further payments from employes who wish more profitable piecework.

Additional purchases of real estate by the New York Central Railroad incidental to its plan for straightening its line at Spuyten Duyvil include nearly all of the water front property along Spuyten Duyvil Creek where it curves around the northerly side of Marble Hill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Langley aerodrome will be repaired and another trial will be made within a few days.

Charles Barker won the 14.2 balk line billiard tournament last night in the Knickerbocker Billiard Academy, Brooklyn, by defeating C.E. White by 200 points to 173. Barker ran out his limit in fifty-four innings. In the series Barker has won five games and lost one. Dr. Jennings and White are tied for second place, with four victories and two defeats each, and they will play off Monday night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Count Cassini, the Russian Ambassador, has heard nothing from St. Petersburg regarding the report that a Russian fleet has arrived at Chemul-Po.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A brief in behalf J. Pierpont Morgan, Robert Bacon, and Daniel S. Lamont, appellants, with others, in the case of the United States vs. The Northern Securities Company, was filed in the United States Supreme Court to-day by Attorneys Francis Lynde Stetson and David Wilcox.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary Root to-day denied the application of the City of New York for an extension of the pier-head line in the Hudson River, which has been under consideration for some time.

One does not expect too close an adherence to logic or to law from an assemblage of women. But now that the R.E. Lee Camp of United Confederate (male) Veterans in Texas have publicly congratulated the Daughters of the Confederacy who lately met at Houston upon their "prompt and felicitous message to President ROOSEVELT," they bring the subject matter of the message into legitimate discussion.

The Executive Committee of the New York Paint, Oil and Varnish Club met yesterday at the Drug Club, 100 William Street, and began an agitation for the reformation of a Cuban trade abuse which is working serious injury to American exporters in all lines of trade.

The fact that a memorial addressed to Mayor-elect McCLELLAN recommending the appointment of Mr. EDWARD F. CROKER as Fire Commissioner received in less than half a week the signatures of the officers and managers of practically every fire insurance company doing business in New York is extremely significant.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10 -- Big Ben was the only winning favorite to-day. Mynheer, who won the first race, with considerable backing, showed such remarkable improvement that the race is held up for investigation by the Stewards. Alpaca and Lelia May were as good as left at the post in the third.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- It was decided to-day that white granite should be used instead of marble in the construction of the new Pennsylvania and Baltimore and Ohio Railroad union station here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- All the members of the Republican National Committee are here. The few principals, who are absent, will be represented by proxies. Senator Penrose holds the proxy for his colleague, Senator Quay.

Nearly 500 Brooklyn citizens of all political parties met at a complimentary banquet last night in honor of Borough President J. Edward Swanstrom. The dinner was held in the Assembly, in Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn. Justice William W. Goodrich presided and acted as toast master, and in his Opening address paid an eloquent tribute to the guest of honor.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec.10 -- Judge H.D. McDonald of Paris, Texas, general attorney for the 'Frisco lines in this State, was here to-day and filed for record in the Secretary of State's office the charter of the Houston, Beaumont and Northern Railway Company. This is one of the most important developments in some time in the plans of the 'Frisco in this State.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- The money market continues very firm. Call loans 6@6 1/2 per cent. Time loans collateral, 5@5 1/2 per cent. Time loans mercantile paper, 6@7 per cent. Clearing house loans, 6 per cent. New York funds, 162-3@20c. Clearings, $21.131,038. Balances, $1,534,064. The foreign exchange market is steady.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The sub-committee of the Executive Committee of the National Afro-American Council to-day decided to hold the next meeing of the council at St. Louis Sept. 4, 1904, and appointed a committee of five to appear before the Platform Committee of the next National Republican Convention to urge that it take vigorous action in reference to the practical denial in a number of States of suffrage to the negro.
BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- Two of the most interesting personalities to German politics, Chancellor von Bulow and Herr Bebel, the Socialist leader, engaged in the Reichstag this afternoon in a lively debate.

Friends of the Rev. Dr. George R. Van De Water, rector of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, were much concerned yesterday over the position in which the clergyman is placed as the result of an interlocutory judgment for absolute divorce which the Supreme Court of Orange County has granted to Mrs. Adele F. Watt against Archibald Watt.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- The local market hesitated to-day in sympathy with the decline in New York, traders being uncertain as to whether the movement in that market was only a natural reaction or the culmination of the advance. Prices did not recede much -- 1/2 in Cambria Steel, 3/8 in Consolidated Lake Superior preferred, 1/2 in General Asphalt preferred, and smaller fractions in United Gas.

The Sheriff yesterday received a writ of replevin for $3,159 against property in possession of William Travers Jerome, as District Attorney, in favor of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company, for property of the corporation which was seized in a raid at West Thirty-ninth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Money was in moderate supply in the market to-day, and the demand increased owing to Stock Exchange requirements. Discounts were easy on the improvement in the rate of New York exchange, this being interpreted as indicating a cessation of the United States's demand for gold.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- John P. Jaeckel, as President of the State Prison Commission, strongly condemned in his report to the commission to-day the city workhouse and the county penitentiary on Blackwell's Island, and the condition of Sing Sing prison. His report on the Tombs prison, with the exception of the women's section in the old part, was most favorable.
Details will be found in another column relative to the purchase of 860 Fifth Avenue by Charles T. Yerkes, through John N. Golding.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The House to-day adopted a resolution directing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the official-conduct of Charles Swayne, Judge of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida, and "to report whether the action of the House is requisite."

The Fifty-eighth Congress is undoubtedly in a holiday humor. About the first thing it did when it met in November was to take $190,000 out of the Treasury to make whole its members who had traveled, it is officially presumed, at an expense of 20 cents a mile, to get to Washington, and to provide them with a like amount to enable them to return to their homes after adjournment.

The announcement of Prof. JOHN DILL ROBERTSON, in his paper before the Chicago Eclectic and Surgical Society, that when people abandon the pernicious habit of bathing there will be little or nothing for the doctors to do, was unexpected, and we are not surprised to learn that it was startling.
ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Gov. Odell this morninig intimated very strongly that he had never asked Senator N.A. Elsberg to become President of the New York County Republican Committee.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 10 -- Lawrence B. Kemp has resigned the Presidency of the Commercial and Farmers' National Bank because of criticism of the concern's management. His successor will be chosen tomorrow.

Resolutions calling upon the Government and upon Congress to take immediate steps to stop the disenfranchisement of the negro in the Southern States and to secure for all voters of that race the rights assured by the Federal Constitution, were adopted last night by the Union League Club at a meeting attended by about three hundred members.

Stocks weak. Call money easier, 4@5 1/2 per cent. There was nothing surprising nor alarming about the weakness of yesterday's stock market. An average fall of about a point after a fortnight's much larger rise is nothing more than is natural, and should be welcome even to advocates of higher prices upon values.

Happily, the impeachments of Federal Judges have been so rare in our history as to have furnished a very scanty supply of precedents. That fact was what was mainly elicited by the debate in the House yesterday upon the question whether a basis had been laid for the impeachment of Judge SWAYNE of the District Court for the Northern District of Florida, and it ought to be a gratifying fact.

When the steamship Pretoria arrived here yesterday afternoon from Bermuda, Central Office Detectives Moody and Leason arrested William Lambert, twenty-eight years old of Hamilton, Bermuda, and William Watkins, nineteen years of age, negroes, of this city, whom they charged with having committed a burglary in a jewelry shop in Bermuda.

-- While considering solutions of the excise problem, it would be worth while to give at least a little consideration to the report from the Schuylkill coal region that, as a result of the temperance campaign recently conducted by the Miners' Union, one-third of the saloon keepers in Schuylkill County have found business unprofitable and will abandon it at the end of the year.
The first, for the present season, of the Dinner Dances organized two years ago by Mrs. Erederic J. de Peyster and J. Montgomery Strong, took place last evening at Delmonico's.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial on Herbert Spencer in to-day's issue of your paper you quote the following sentences from the "Principles of Psychology" as presenting his views on the question of the possibility of science bridging the gap between the inorganic and the organic in nature:

The full text of the decision of the United States Supreme Court declaring the Kansas eight-hour law constitutional reached this city yesterday. Pending the arrival lawyers were unwilling to express any opinion as to whether it would have any bearing on the eight-hour law here, which, as well as the prevailing rate of wages and the cut stone law, has been declared unconstitutional by the Court of Appeals of the State.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 10 -- Carl Schurz, at the twenty-third annual meeting of the National Civil Service Reform League, which began here to-day, advocated the elimination of the spoils system from politics and alluded to Senator Thomas C. Platt and to the postal frauds as an illustration of its evils.

A few minutes before midnight last night the field of competing teams in the six-day international bicycle race at Madison Square Garden was reduced to eleven, the youngest pair, Root and Dorlon, having withdrawn. Dorlon sustained injuries to his leg and thigh in a fall which disabled him, and as Root had no other available rider with whom to double up both had to retire from the race.

While the majority of the guests of the women's hotel, the Martha Washington, were away shopping yesterday afternoon, Harry McAuley, one of the elevator boys, and William Morrisey, day captain of the bell boy squad, became engaged in a quarrel, which resulted in McAuley shooting the other.

CHRISTIANIA, Dec. 10 -- The Norwegian Parliament has awarded the annual Nobel Peace Prize of $39,150 to William R. Cremer, M.P., publisher of The Arbitrator, of London, for his work on behalf of international arbitration.

Representatives of the Knickerbocker, Mohawk, Olympic, and St. Peter's football teams met at the Park Row office of President Wise of the Watertown Athletic Association, under whose auspices the football tournament will be held at Madison Square Garden next week, and completed all arrangements for deciding the championship of New York.

Market's Opening -- The strength which has been given to the opening of the market on most days recently by the higher prices for American stocks sent over from London was denied the market yesterday, as the international list in London even before the opening of the market here gave-signs of London's disposition to take profits on some of its recent purchases.

Robert C. Ogden, who is President of the Southern Education Board, said last night that he regarded the action of the Union League Club in adopting the resolutions it had as a great mistake, and regretted gravely that he had been prevented from attending the meeting.

The White Star Line steamship Oceanic arrived yesterday, renamed the Matchmaker, because of the number of women on board who had at some time during the trip resolved to intrust themselves for all time to the care of certain other male passengers. It was said that no fewer than four youngr women aboard would shortly change their names.

Even before the creation of the Department of Commerce and Labor we had in this country a very considerable body of law for the regulation of corporations. When Boards of Directors adopt sinful courses, whether with or against the advice of counsel, they often find themselves in the witness chair facing a particularly inquisitive and bothersome lawyer.

The world has become altogether too well used to Russian, diplomacy to disbelieve a credible story simple because it is officially denied from St. Petersburg. The story of the assemblage of a formidable Russian squadron in Korean waters came from several sources at once, or rather through several channels at once.

The first of the suits to be brought by the Commonwealth Trust Company, formerly the Trust Company of the Republic, against parties connected with the flotation of the United States Shipbuilding Company was made public yesterday, when Hornblower, Byrne, Miller Potter, counsel for Harris, Gates Co., acknowledged service of papers instituting the action.

The Committee on Excise of the Citizens' Union yesterday decided to urge on the Legislature the changes in the excise law proposed at the last session by District Attorney Jerome. The reform measures proposed by Police Commissioner Greene, placing the authority to regulate Sunday traffic in the hands of a board composed of the Mayor, the Controller, and the Commissioner of Police, was discussed, but the vote of the committee was against it.

On Tuesday of this week the elevated railroads carried what a year ago would have been the impossible multitude of 973,000 passengers. This broke all previous records. The largest passenger movement in one day by the Manhattan system last year was 935,000. The memorable congestion of Dewey Day was the result of the movement of 830,000 passengers.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- The speech of Gov. Albert B. Cummins of Iowa on "Our Foreign Trade," which was to have been delivered to-night at the banquet of the Merchants' Association at the Hotel Somerset, was read by Charles S. Hamlin, Gov. Cummins having been called home by the impending death of his brother.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Fire broke out early this morning at Sandringham, and Queen Alexandra and her secretary, Miss Charlotte Knollys, had narrow escapes.

Members of the Union College Alumni Association, at their annual dinner held last night at the Hotel Manhattan, had the privilege of seeing a pair of sleeve buttons which at various times had been the property of George Washington and Benedict Arnold, and listened to the story, of how the historic trinkets had passed from, the possession of the founder of this country to that of the speaker, Gen, James Grant Wilson.
