SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 10 -- The latest sensation in the Elkhart Bank failure came to-day after Judge F.F. Oldham, Chief of the Insolvency Bureau of the Treasury Department, left Elkhart after two day's conference with Receiver Bosworth and Attorney Perry L. Turner regarding the failure.

The trading in curb securities yesterday underwent a change in character. Greene Consolidated was the leader of the market for some time past, but yesterday Manhattan Transit assumed the position of first importance. The trading was fairly well distributed, with considerable improvement in a number of issues which have been neglected of late, but which formerly were quite active and among the features of the market.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y. Dec. 10 -- The second annual amateur court tennis tournament of the United States for the Gold Racquet, held under the management of the Tuxedo Tennis and Racquet Club, opened on the court here this morning. The amateur champion, Joshua Crane, Jr., of Boston, was hard pressed by T. Suffern Tailer, but Crane won by the score of 6 -- 1, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Returns to the Chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the Department of Agriculture indicate that the newly seeded area of Winter wheat is about 32,000,000 acres, a decrease of 6 per cent. from the area estimated to have been sown in the Fall of 1902. The condition of Winter wheat on Dec. 1 was 86.6, as compared with 99.7 in 1902, 86.7 in 1901, and a nine-year average of 92.7.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- Nearly $9,000 was realized for 226 lots of the third part of the Howard T. Goodwin library, which were sold at Davis Harvey's rooms this afternoon. Prices were more than ordinarily good.

The members of the West Side Association still continue to manifest a gratifying interest in the replanting of trees along the Boulevard over, the subway. A meeting of women residents of the west side will be held on Friday evening to arrange a plan for tree planting in the small parks which have been established between and around the ventilating shafts of the tunnel.

Predictions made earlier in the week that the advance that occurred in foreign exchange on Tuesday would stop, for the time being at least, the engagement of gold for import have been falsified by the success of several New York bankers in securing further amounts of gold in London, notwithstanding the efforts made to prevent the precious metal from leaving that city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The State Department has received from Minister Beaupre, under date of Bogota, Oct. 16, the text of the report of the committee of the Colombian Senate on the proposed law to confirm the disapproval of the canal treaty by the Senate and to authorize the President to make a new treaty.

What Wall Street thinks of Mr. ROOSEVELT is a matter of very slight consequence. What the country thinks of him is important and vital. If the people of the country want him to be their President during the four years from March 4, 1905, to March 4, 1909, the opposition of Wall Street would be futile.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A big crowd filled the corridors of the Arlington to-day several hours before the National Republican Committee convened. The talk indulged in regarded more the favorable action of the next convention than the action of the committee on the selection of a convention city, and Mr. Roosevelt's chances of getting the nomination were generally regarded as certain as Chicago's likelihood of setting the convention, which is conceded.
ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Henry J. Coggeshall of Waterville, Oneida County, who represented his district in the Senate 1884-1900, was a caller on Gov. Odell on Wednesday.

At least four of the twelve items in the sale of Shakespeare relics, held in London on Monday of this week by Messrs. Sotheby, sold very well. The highest-priced lot in the sale was a copy of the Fourth Folio. edition of Shakespeare's plays, 1685, with the rare imprint: "Printed for Henry Herringman and are to be sold by Joseph Knight and Francis Saunders."

AROUND Thomas Creevey there revolves an extended circle in which figure many important personages of the last 100 ber of Parliament. You may read the chronicles of his times from his entrance into Parliament up to the time of his death, in 1833.

THE Bureau of Equipment has added Mr. Hapgood's brief life of Paul Jones to the books supplied to the naval libraries, and Miss Edith Guerrier, the librarian at the North End Mission, has written the most original fairy book that Boston has seen for many a day, "Wanderfolk in "Wonderland."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Ex-Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff talked about Republican politics in the State to-night, saying that he knew of nothing except harmony, explaining why Jacob Brenner was chosen Chairman of the committee in Kings and stating that Senator Elsbergwould not be made Chairman of the New York County Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A new member of the House, Alian Benny of Bayonne, N.J., to-day surprised that body by making an attack upon Col. Hepburn of Iowa, that terror to new members, and routing him. The rugged old Iowan likes nothing better than to toss some novice out of his way.

The compilation of this record of the debt which literature owes to New York must have taken considerable time, and necessitated not a little research. Every item is set forth, from the first contribu- tion of Jacob Steendam, who in Peter Stuyvesant's time sang "The Complaint of New Amsterdam," to that of the newspaper writer of the present day who introduced "Chimmie Fadden" to an appreciative public.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 11 -- Authority having been granted by the Controller of the Currency, the Federal National Bank, which closed its doors in October, will resume business next Monday with Col. Hugh Young, for twenty-five years Bank Examiner of this district, as President.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 11 -- The Nassau County Grand Jury, after a long investigation directed by Justice Maddox, yesterday returned a presentment censuring the former and present Boards of Supervisors of the county and the two Clerks for not properly keeping the books and records of the county.

FREDERICK A STORKS Company announce the publication of a now Library of Standard Blographles. The first volume presents the whole ten books of Bourrienne's "Memoirs, of Napoleon" in a condensed form. It contains an appendix, notes an index; and a chronological list of events in the life of Napoleon.
SUBJECT -- The Queen of Sheba Visits Solomon, Kings, x., 1-10. GOLDEN TEXT -- When the righteous are in authority the people rejoice. Prov. xxix., 2.

CENTURY ago, and even less than that, the Rocky Mountain region of the Dominion of Canada was almost unknown, for the reason that access to it was difficult. Even to-day, with a railway connecting the Atlantic with the Pacific, there are many parts of the country still unvisited.

A series of straightforward and practical talks with young men by the author of one who has already published several books intended to benefit those engaged in business pursuits. The present volume, addressed particularly to those who stand upon the threshold of the business life, shows the necessity of self-study, of weighing one's individual capabilities, and forming definite plans before entering any business.

Dr. John Edwin Sandys writes in the preface to his "History of Classical Scholarship, from the Sixth Century B.C. to the End of the Middle Ages," published by the Macmlllan Company in this country, that this volume is to be followed shortly by another, in which he will deal with the history of scholarship from Petrarch to the present day.

COLON, Dec. 11 -- The mystery surrounds ing the movements of Colombian troops which were reported to have landed at the mouth of the Atrato River, with a view to an attack on Panama, was cleared up today after the arrival of the French steamship Fournel from Savanilla and Cartagena.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The following bills were introduced in Congress to-day:
Buster Brown ribbon comes about four inches wide, a white ground with Buster and sprays of holly in red. It is 45 cents a yard. Buster looks very much like himself too.

The North American Trust Company is the defendant in a suit instituted yesterday in the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New York, by Gardiner Hall of South Wallington, Conn., to recover $225,000 which he says he invested in the first mortgage bonds of the defunct White Mountain Paper Company, floated, as it is asserted, through the defendant corporation.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- An imperial grant in aid of cotton growing in British West Africa will be proposed in the course of the coming session of Parliament, and it is understood that the suggestion has been favorably received by the Government departments concerned.

The "Proceedings" of the sixth annual convention, and the "Annual Report" of the National Live Stock Association, held at Kansas City, Mo., Jan. 13 to 16, 1903, have been officially compiled by Charles F. Martin, Secretary of the association, whose headquarters are in the Quincy Bulding, Denver, Colo.
THE WORLD OF W.W. JACOBS -- I wish that one might enter the Jacobs world now and then, instead of going to Switzerland, or Scotland, or the other dull countries where one makes formal holiday.

"The American Horticultural Manual" is published by J.L. Budd, emeritus Professor in Horticulture in the Iowa State College at Agriculture, and Prof. N.E. Hansen, who heads the same department in the South Dakota Agricultural College. (New York: John Wiley Sons. $1.50 each.)

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: What your Brooklyn correspondent undoubtedly needs for his Young Men's Club is a book of selected English essays. Few libraries of less than 50,000 volumes contain even some of the works of all the English essayists of importance. In fact, I know of a library of 125,000 volumes which does not contain part of the works of all the twenty-three essayists I list below.

Judge Henderson M. Somerville of the Board of United States General Appraisers handed down a decision yesterday further defining the dutiable status of commissions on which there has been much controversy. His decision overruled appeals by Davis Horton, Stix, Baer Fuller, and the Standard House Furnishing Company against the Collector of Customs at Port Townsend, Washington, and the Surveyor at St Louis.

Elsie English's translation of Emile Boutmy's book on "The English People: A Study of Its Political Psychology." will not be published by G.P. Putnam's Sons until after the holidays. The book opens with the "Physical Environment" of the English people -- their will, sensation and perception, creative imagination, and power of abstraction.

We cannot think that the Union League Club would greatly advance the true interests of the colored men in the South or in the rest of the country if it could induce the Republican Party to take up and carry out the policy advocated in the resolutions of Thursday evening.

In the nature of things, this book of somewhat daring literary personalities is chiefly interesting to a class. The class in question is the little army of those who make a living by writing books and other things in this City of New York. We may call them, for convenience, authors and critics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The name of Gov. Lucius F.C. Garvin of Rhode Island has for several days been seriously under consideration for President by many Democrats in Congress. A speech by Representative Granger, the Democratic Congressman from that State, to-day gave new impetus to the Garvin talk.

Presumably when a woman writer disguises both her identity and her sex by using either a masculine pseudonym or one that may denote either gender, she is flattered when reviewers call her "Mr." She must desire her writing to be taken for a man's work. We have known a thoroughly competent reviewer to call Miss Violet Paget "Mr. Vernon Lee" or "Mr. Lee" a dozen times in the course of a review of moderate length.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Permit me through your columns to express my thanks to your readers who have replied to my query which you published Nov. 1 and who have not sent name and address. Those whose addresses I have I shall acknowledge individually. Accept my thanks for your extreme courtesy in pub lishing my inquiry.

For-years Scandinavia has been the recreation ground of the Englishman. Mr. E.B. Kennedy's volume is written for those "who, by reason of being much engaged at home rush off for their short but well-earned holiday." As a thorough sportsman, the author will tell them where they may go to find the salmon, the trout, or the grayling.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Messrs. Longmans, Green Co. are publishing a posthumous work of the late Bishop Stubbs consisting of essays relating to the history of Europe from the date of the retirement to his semi-religious seclusion in Spain of the great Emperor, Charles V. A large part of the book is devoted to a review of the Thirty Years' War.

The new International Encyclopaedia (Dodd, Mead Co.) is now almost complete; in the last few weeks Volumes XII., XIII., and XIV. have been issued, and only three more are planned. This set is full of valuable information and biographical data.

GEN. PHILIP SCHUYLER was not a lucky man, and it is a large part of the business of the present biographer to set forth the difficulties with which his hero had to contend as commander of the Northern Department during the earlier years of the Revolution.

DONE into PurPle and stamped on the back with the double eagle of Austria, this book celebrates the virtues of the denn of European Emperors and the pride of the House of Hapsburg, especially the pride of that formidable Archduchess Sophia, the mother, of the royal and imperial Francis Joseph.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Major Estes G. Rathbone to-day addressed the following letter to Secretary Root:

Miss May Harper, eighteen years old, of 1,401 Dean Street, Brooklyn, was confined to her home yesterday as a result of a bold assault and robbery almost in front of the New York Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church on Thursday night, in which she figured as the victim.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 11 -- On the grounds of gross neglect and cruelty Mrs. Gloria Marie Calcutt, daughter of W.J. White, the wealthy chewing gum manufacturer, was granted a divorce from her husband, James F. Calcutt, a society man of Toronto Ontario.

EVERY business man who advertises, and every business man who has neglected to advertise and wishes to advertise wisely, will be persuaded to become a student of psychology after he has read this very readable and instructive volume.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- This was a field day for issues in the Senate. Democrats vied with each other in bringing them to the front until there was a broad smile all over the Republican side of the Chamber.

Yesterday irregularity marked the trading in securities dealt in on the curb. Declines were made in a number of the more important issues with the extreme break of 25 points in Cuban 6s. With the exception of Cuban 6s the bond list held firm or advanced, the largest gain being 1 point in Brooklyn Rapid Transit 4s, of which a single lot of five bonds sold at 79.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The President acted to-day in the matter of charges against Postmaster Clayton McMichael of Philadelphia, and the incident is closed with the record showing that Col. McMichael made a good and sufficient defense. The Civil Service Commission had unanimously urged the removal of Col. McMichael who is a Quay man.

The incompleteness of the new bridge which is formally to be opened next week in spite of its incompleteness has perhaps been quite sufficiently insisted upon. Nobody will attend the opening ceremonies without ample notice that what be goes out to see is not a bridge with two roadways and half a dozen tracks complete and trolleys and steam cars running, and an ample promenade.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Your correspondent "G.L.B." has written admirably of Mrs. Trask's wonderful book. "Free, Not Bound," is pre-eminently a living book, a book with a soul, and like all soulful things, it reveals a new beauty, a deeper meaning, the more intimately it is known.

In Part I. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday Judge McMahon disposed of a large number of alleged gambling cases in which the District Attorney believed no conviction could be had. Among the cases disposed of was that of Samuel Hitchings, charged with being the doorkeeper of a gambling house at 33 West Thirty-third Street, which was raided on the same night that Canfield's was raided.

At least one record price was given at the fine sale of rare books held Friday afternoon and evening, Dec. 4, by the Anderson Auction Company, in West Twentyninth Street. The best price of the two sessions was $425, given for a remarkable copy of Thackeray's "Vanity Fair," complete in the original parts, as first issued, with all the covers and advertisements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Cuban Reciprocity bill came up for discussion in the Senate to-day, and Mr. Bard, Republican, California, who said that he stood alone on his side of the Chamber, spoke in opposition to the measure. Mr. McCreary, Democrat, Kentucky, in his first address to the Senate supported the bill, and his speech was listened to with close attention.

The doctrine that the mortal body is no more than a temporary instrument in the hands of the spirit is one which has more theoretical adherents than practitioners. The "life radiant" of the title is that which the author conceives will result from the practical recognition of the fact that the real man is rather a creature of spirit than of flesh.
MANILA, Dec. 11 -- Major Gen. Leonard Wood has proclaimed in the Moro provinces an anti-slavery law, passed in October by the Legislative Council of the provinces.

LIE METCHNIKOFF is a biologist and pathologist who has achieved a high position for the originality and importance of his work. His discovery of the function played by the white blood cells in inflammation and immunity was in a degree epoch-making, and has given him his particular distinction. But he has not proved himself entirely inerrant, and some of his cherished views in pathology have not been accepted.

An anonymous letter received at the office of the Pinkerton National Detective Agency in this city on Thursday brought to a successful end what threatened to be a long hunt for $7,000 worth of securities which were stolen from the Merchants' National Bank in Baltimore a week ago.

The author and publisher of this little book confesses to a purpose. He says he has desired to get before the public some reflections on things in which he conceives many men and women are interested. And he is of opinion that a story with "enough of incident and narrative to attract attention" is the best vehicle for these reflections.

Plans for a complete redistricting of the police precincts in Manhattan between Fourteenth and Fifty-ninth Streets, by which the present Tenderloin Precinct will be wiped out and other important alterations effected, were presented by Police Commissioner Greene yesterday to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

Hugh Blank in a letter to Fleming H. Revelt Company, his American publishers, writes that his new volume, "Work," is going there (in Edinburgh) very well. The first edition was 7,000, and they have now printed a second edition. His "Friendship" is said to be doing even better in this country.

Messrs, Sotheby's sale of Dec. 11-15 includes an unusual number of interesting literary autographs. There are three letters of Tennyson, one of them written to Gustave Dore in reference to the latter's illustrations for "Idylis of the King." Lot No. 857 is a portion of "The Princess," eight lines of the original manuscript, given by the poet to Mrs. Brookfield, beginning:

Amos K. Fiske, whoso book on "The Modern Bank "will be added in January to D. Appleton Co.'s Business Series, is the chief editorial writer for The Journal of Commerce and Commercial Bulletin. As he says in the preface to his book, he has some chapters on elementary principles and general methods and gives a rapid sketch of the development of banking and of existing systems.

The Lotos Club is holding, a small exhibition of paintings by one American landscapist which rarely if ever has been surpassed by the shows held heretofore in the little "dining room gallery." Thirty paintings by the late Homer D. Martin have been borrowed from the private collections of half that number of art lovers.

The plan of raising the grade of the City of Galveston to conform to that established by the new sea wall is one of the curiosities of modern engineering. During the great inundation of 1900 the greater part of Galveston was submerged nearly sixteen feet, the tidal Wave rising nearly sixteen feet above mean lowwater level.

Leopold Well has sold for Max Marx to Jesse I. Straus of R.H. Macy Co. a plot of about two and one-half block fronts on Audubon Avenue, extending from about One Hundred and Ninetieth to One Hundred and Ninety-third Street, with a depth of 100 feet. Mr. Straus gives in part payment the Arlington apartment house, in Brooklyn, a ten-story structure at 62 and 64 Montague Street.

The "Special Commissioner" sent to South Africa by The London Engineer is an eminently practical parsonage, and his volume is a review of engineering and industrial work as carried out south of the Zambesi River. Conditions are changed in South Africa to-day. The importance of Capo Colony in a political sense may be considered in a certain way to be of the past.

"Shipmates in Sunshine," by that very genial gentleman who wrote the story of Oliver Goldsmith in "The Jessamy Bride," the romance off Sheridan in "A Nest of Linnets," and a highly romantic novel in "Castle Omeragh," is neither biographical nor historical. Represented as a kindly gentleman bent on securing copy, the author takes a trip to the West Indies on board the steamer Avon, sailing from England.

The question of the length of the college course, whether it shall be four years or three or two, was, it will be recalled, much thrashed out last Summer. These are the papers in which the various sides of it were, stated by men in authority. President Eliot explains the then Harvard system and theory of three years.

"Bryan's Dictionary of Painters and Engravers" has been the standard source of information on the facts and lives of the artists with whom it deals for almost a century. First revised in 1849 by Stanley, and again in 1876 by Ottley, it was almost rewritten and doubled in size by Graves and Armstrong, who finished their revision in 1889.

The conditions existing at Butler, Penn., as revealed by the appeal for a relief fund of $100,000 to aid in suppressing the epidemic of typhoid fever, are deplorable. The mortality has been large: more than 1,200 persons are now reported ill, suffering exists among the poor, and there is reason to fear that the epidemic has not reached its worst stage.
BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- The money market remains quiet and firm. The supply of loanable funds is not large, and the banks show no disposition to put out money even at the prevailing high rates.

The new edition of Cyrus Townsend Brady's novel, "The Quiberon Touch," published by D. Apploton Co. in 1901, will appear late in the Winter under a new title, "Little France," retaining, however, the first name as an associate title. The edition will also have a new preface, in which Mr. Brady gives his reasons for changing the title.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Money was in increased demand in the market to-day.

SOMETHING quite new for the little people is books which have readable rhymes and are at the same time books of paper dolls. And that is not all, for one is a boy's book, and intended for the small boy to play with while his sister is cutting out her dollies and their frocks.

In the crisp December air a group comprising Singhalese, Arabs, Egyptians, Malays, one Zanzibari, and one Eurasian, stood and shivered near the Battery yesterday morning. They were the crew, thirtyseven in all, of the British steamship Nithensdale, now lying at the Arbuckle sugar docks, Brooklyn.

THE many readers of Sir George Trevelyan's first volume on the American Revolution have looked forward with genuine interest to the appearance of the second installment of that work. After five years of waiting we now have Part II., in two volumes, embracing altogether 700 pages.

The Churchman in this week's issue says: "One of the most interesting and valuable monographs on early American affairs is a History or the Mississippi Valley from Its Discovery to the End of Foreign Domination,' (A. S. Cark, 174 Fulton Street, New York City, $5,) by John R. Spears, in collaboration with A.H. Clark.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11 -- The recovery by the Merchants' National Bank officials of the $7,000 securities stolen from the bank runner and efforts made to prevent the prosecution of "Doc" Bliss, who is charged with complicity in the robbery, and the hunt for J.F. Pearson, a companion of Bliss, will probably result in a serious difference between the Pinkerton Agency and the Baltimore City detectives and the United States Secret Service men.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- An article in the Aurora by Anatole France on the question whether Dreyfus ought again to be tried by a court-martial is quoted by the Paris correspondent of The Times. M. France says:

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- In the course of a discussion on the maltreatment of private soldiers in the army in the Reichstag today Baron von Kardorff alluded to the enormous increase in the German Socialist vote. He said he would not assert that the army had grown untrustworthy, but he declared that its ranks were filled with Socialists, who were increasing in numbers with the growth, of their party.

G.P. Putnam's Sons publish this week the first volume on "Mezzotints." (octavo.) in the Connoisseur's Library, edited by Cyril Davenport of the British Museum. This is No. 15 and is by the editor. It will be followed by Volume XVI., on "Miniatures," by Dudley Heath; Volume IV., on "China and Porcelain," by Edward Dillon; Volume VII., on "English Furniture," by P.S. Robinson.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: MR. H.G. WELLS is in search of an American publisher, and incidentally he has been led to discuss the general relations of publisher and author. He finds them, of course, very unsatisfactory, but he differs perhaps from the majority of those who hold that opinion, in describing this unsatisfactoriness to the system in vogue rather than to the mental and moral defects of the publishing trade.

"The Captain's Daughter," by Gwendolen Overton, can be highly recommended as a book for the young person, for not only is it eminently proper reading, but it conveys also a most excellent moral to young ladies rather overconfident of their own judgment in matters of importance. And this is not saying that the book will not be enjoyed by an older reader.

With the exception, of an occasional flurry caused by some one of the more intrepid riders trying to gain a lap on their fellows, the six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden was more monotonous yesterday than on any day since the contest began. Eleven teams kept up the continuous grind which has been sufficiently slow to leave them over 300 miles behind the record established by Miller and Waller four years ago.

BACHELOR maids have been in fashion so long that they ought to be getting old-fashioned. We all know all about them -- how they defy conventions, ride in hansom cabs, and make short purses go a long way.

The remarkably fine performance of "Tosca" that is to be seen, at the Metropolitan Opera House this season attracted a numerous audience last evening at its third repetition. The cast was the same as at the previous representations. Mme. Ternina was in better voice than she has been at any time since her reappearance, which was noted by all her admirers with heartfelt satisfaction.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- The State Board of Canvassers, to-day canvassed the vote, cast for and against the proposition to bond the State of New York for $101,000,000 for the improvement of the State canals by enlarging them so as to accommodate barges. The proposition was carried, by 245,312. The vote as canvassed by counties was as follows:

R.C. Gillie's new book, "The Kinsfolk and Friends of Jesus," published by the Macmillan Company, is a sequel to his "Story of Stories," but he says in his preface, each may be read independently. His aim is to present complete sketches of the companions of Jesus in a fashion attractive to children.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Dec. 11 -- On a tract of land recently purchased by a number of New York men, it is declared a country club for Tammany Hall members is to be opened the coming Spring at South Farms, adjacent to the widely known Seven Springs of Morris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The marked reduction in the exports of cotton goods from the United States to China in 1903, compared especially with 1902, has been the occasion of considerable anxiety and inquiry both on the part of manufacturers and those generally interested in the development of the foreign commerce of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. John W. Foster entertained at dinner this evening in honor of the Russian Ambassador.

In the article on "Parsifal" in the December Critic, A.I. Du Pont Coleman seems to side with those persons who object to the performance of the buhnenweihfestspiel out of Baireuth. His point of view, however, is aesthetic, or sentimental, and not commercial. The article is beautifully illustrated with reproductions of the FantinLatour lithographs.

FEWER calendars this year than usual bear the imprint of private printers, who on former occasions put forth some of their finest, efforts in the expression of more or less artistic pictorial data for the coming year.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11 -- The twenty-third annual convention of the National Civil Service Reform League concluded to-night with a banquet at the Lyric Music Has Charles J. Bonaparto presided, and Robert Adams, Jr., made an address on" Consular Reform." Other speakers were Wayne MacVeagh, John R. Proctor, and Eugene F. Ware. Dr. Daniel C. Gilman was reelected President, and the following Vice Presidents were named:

RICHARD DALLAS." who relates "the story of a crime," entitled "A Master Hand," which is published by G.P. Putnam's Sons, has now confessed that he is N. Winslow Williams, a Baltimore lawyer, clubman, and society man.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec, 11 -- Little Jack Horner, Lev Dorsey, Ascension, Charlie Thompson, and Agnes Brennan were the winning favorites to-day. Alfio, the only beaten favorite, sulked from start to finish. Weather clear; track fest Summary:

IT IS NOT so much the post in Syria and Palestine as the present to which Mr. William Eleroy Curtis devotes his attention. In a prior volume, "The Turk and His last Provinces," Mr. Curtis showed his acquaintance with Eastern Europe.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12.-- For illegal acts as a corporate body $1,000 fine was imposed upon Franklin Union No. 4, Press Feeders, by Judge Holdom to-day. The court found the union guilty of contempt of court for violating an injunction restraining it as an organization from interfering with the business of employes of ten printing firms, members of the Chicago Typothetae.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Poor old England has need of such counsel and advice as a few of the great tariff sharps might give her. She is puzzling over fiscal problems in a most pathetic fashion.

The purchase of 860 Fifth Avenue by Charles T. Yerkes, the sale of the new Department hotel at 12 to 16 East Thirty-First Street, the announcement in some detail of the plans for the new Trinity Building project and for a new theatre at Broadway and Sixty-second Street, have contributed to the real estate gossip of the last few days an unusually large number of items of individual interest.

Seven Governors of States, either in person or by proxy, attended the fifth annual banquet of the Pennsylvania Society which was held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. They represented, in the language of Robert C. Ogden, who presided, the various Commonwealths which in the early times of this country loved Pennsylvania so well that they wanted to cut slices out of its territory.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- With the near approach of Christmas, that most Parisian form of entertainment, the "Revue," has made its appearance on the Paris stage. In every quarter, however poor, the little local theatre has mounted its "Revue" and draws a full house. However tawdry and poor the setting, however indifferent the acting, the success of these little pieces is always phenomenal.

No novelties are announced for the coming week at the Metropolitan Opera House. On Monday evening the double bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" will again be presented. "Rigoletto," with a cast including Mme. Sembrich and Mme. Louise Homer, Messrs. Caruso, Scotti, Journet, Dufriche, will be the bill on Wednesday evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Mrs. Roosevelt has issued cards for an "at home" Friday afternoon, Dec. 18, complimentary to the members of the Diplomatic Corps and ladies of their respective families, the occasion being her first afternoon reception of the season.
BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- Emperor William and the Empress arrived here this afternoon from Potsdam, Their Majesties were warmly greeted by the crowds in the streets.

Again New York is to have a musical comedy from the prolific pen of Harry B. Smith. Its chief characteristics are said to be "originality, plausibility, and wholesomeness." If it possesses all these qualities it surely ought to be successful. Irene Bentley sings and plays the title part. The underlying theme of the entire play may be said to be contained in the one word "Dixie," this being the refrain of Miss Bentley's song.
PHILIP, why don't you marry -- it's what you need -- some nice, sweet girl to take care of you?"

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections met to-day to outline policy to be pursued in Investigating the protests filed against Senator Reed Smoot being permitted to retain his seat. The committee decided that before taking further steps in the matter Senator Smoot should be given opportunity to make reply to the charges.

Flogging was advocated by President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University before the fourth annual luncheon of the Principals' Club yesterday afternoon, at which the majority of those present were women. The suggestion, however, met with but faint applause, and when it came the turn of Dr. William H. Maxwell, City Superintendent of Schools, who was the guest of honor, to speak, he repudiated it in unmistakable terms.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The perfect weather during the week end drew out a large, fashionable gathering to the clubhouse to enjoy the skating, coasting, and sleighing, which are now most attractive.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are some persons, even among those who believe in law, who think that it is wrong to strictly enforce the law. To strictly enforce the law is, so far as possible or practicable, to prevent all persons from violating the law. Why should this not be done?

The Christmas holidays being close, entertainments this week as well as the following, will bring several affairs for young people. With the exception of debutante functions and dinners and private dances for young people, entertaining will be confined to the country, where many are remaining until after the new year.

Friezes for next Fall's trade have been reduced 5 cents a yard by the American Woolen Company, which opened these lines last week. The new prices on the more popular numbers are: X 55, 28 ounces, piece dye, 92 1/2 cents; X 27, 32 to 33 ounces, piece dye, 97 1/2 cents; X 6812, cotton carded, 32 ounces, mixture, $1.

"The time is coming, and it is not so far off, either," said a large importer of furs the other day, "when our American manufacturers of furs will invade the Canadian market. Many men in the trade agree that this will happen eventually, but I think that it is coming much faster than many of them imagine.

The concerts to-day and this evening at the four Proctor houses will have some unusually good features. The Twenty-third Street Theatre will have Ross and Fenton, Ferguson and Mack, the Bard Brothers, Julius Tannen, Walthour and Kreamer, and twenty other acts. At the Fifth Avenue the offering will include Milton and Dolly Nobles, the Nichols Sisters, the Juggling Johnsons, and twenty other acts.

While prices of cotton cloths have been soaring, in sympathy with the movement in the raw material, yet the mills arc selling only goods on hand, and since the beginning of last week have declined to accept contracts for future delivery. Manufacturers and selling agents agree that the situation is the most puzzling of any within their recollection.

A team of German polo players for America is the latest announcement in the polo world. This probability has more than ordinary indications of realization, and if the team comes it will take part in a big international tournament at the St. Louis World's s Fair, which is now being planned by a number of polo men both in this section of the country and in St. Louis.

The business is wash shirtwaists, which is usually well under way by this time, is backward this year, and the manufacturers are all at sea as to the styles and fabrics that will be popular. They expect now that there will not be much business done before Jan. 1.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- Surveys for the first actual work on the barge canal improvement will begin on Monday morning. State Engineer Bond said to-day that six parties, about fifty men in all, would begin the surveys in the Fort Bull-Oneida, Savannah, Rochester, Medina, and Tonawanda sections.

Within less than two months New York may have a theatre like the one conducted years ago by Lester Wallack, equipped with a competent stock company, that will present a repertoire of plays of real dramatic value at prices much lower than those now prevailing in New York. Sydney Rosenfeld is at the head of the movement and matters have so far progressed that half of the capital stock has already been subscribed.

A complimentary dinner was given by the West End Association last night at the Ansonia, Broadway and Seventy-second Street, to Cyrus Clark, who has been President of that body for the past fifteen years, and has been prominent in the work of improving the west side. Among those who responded to toasts were Bishop Henry C. Potter, the Rev. Robert Mackenzie, Col. Ethan Alien. John C. Coleman, and Mr. Clark himself.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the agitation about the reorganization of the County Committee began I have been asked so many questions about the Direct Nomination Republican League and the form of its organization, , that I take this way of answering, and trust that yon will find this copy available for your valuable columns.

WHILE she waited for him she took in with a tender sympathy and amusement the meagre, comforts of his small parlor, The table littered with newspapers and magazines, the dust in the corners, the chimneypiece cluttered with stray pipes, tobacco jars, a shoebrush, Poor's Manual, a nickeled alarm clock, a beer mug.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- There was a stir in the Senate to-day over an incident reminiscent of the days when the North and South were unfriendly.

MISS ANNIE BEST wore at a recent dance an Empire princess robe of white net with lace appliques over white chiffon and satin. Several overlapping lace flounces over chiffon finished the lower edge, above which were tiny garlands of small pink roses, with-out foliage.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Nov. 27 appears an editorial headed "Porfirio Diaz." and in estimating the fitness of Gen. Bernado Reyes for the Presidency in comparision with Senor Limantour you say of Gen. Reyes he "is a bluff, agreeable old gentleman with a fine war record, but his age and his inexperience in the problems of finance and commerce make his candidacy an academic discussion."

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- At the last meeting of the Board of Directors of the World's Columbian Exposition a final dividend of 4.65 per cent, on the capital stock was declared. The dividend is equal to 46 1/2 cents per share, and is payable on March 1, 1904. The transfer books of the stock company close on Jan. 2, 1904.

Gustave F. Kogel, who conducted the last rehearsal and concert of the Philharmonic Society, will again direct the orchestra at the third rehearsal and concert on Friday afternoon and Saturday evening. The programme will consist of Brahms's Symphony in C minor, "A Faust Overture," by Wagner, and Liszt's symphonic poem, "Les Preludes."

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Summer weather, or something closely approaching it, has now-arrived after the short spell of snow and slush. The vagaries of the temperature are consequently the chief topic of conversation.

The ease with which the London gold market on Monday and Tuesday of last week was manipulated in such a way as to prevent our securing more than a scant amount of the metal, draws attention sharply to the importance to ourselves of the agitation now being carried on in England to allow the Importation of Asiatic labor to work the mines in the Transvaal.

THERE was an awful big noise before daybreak in Kris Kindle's home. It was Kris Why It Kindle's Snowed, mother suddenly remembering that it was getting near Christmas: and in her hurry to waken her lazy boy -- the great Santa Claus of the world -- she stumbled over everything in the way.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Republican National Committee adjourned to-day to meet a week before the National Convention, which it had decreed should be held at Chicago on June 21, 1904.

BOSTON, Dec. 12. -- The rapid development of Costa Rica as a fruit-producing country and the steady increase of tourist travel to that part of Central America have led to the establishment of a regular steamship service between Boston and Port Limon, the principal port of entry of that republic.
GEE WHIZ!" The homely phrase sounds strange now, breaking in upon the flow of the stately Georgian dialogue.

Willle De Lisie came up from Lakewood yesterday thoroughly disgusted. When he reached his Fulton Street place he kicked Billy, the cat, over the stove, threw his fifty-dollar overcoat into a pan of frying fat, and swore at the French cook.

For the next three years, and perhaps longer, the Faculty of the Yale Law School is to select the editorial board for The Yale Law Journal. It is hoped thus to have a fair and impartial trial for the positions. There will be a competition for seniors, and another, distinct, for middlers and juniors.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12. -- Advices from Honolulu say many phenomena have been observed recently in various parts of the islands, which are believed to indicate severe volcanic or seismic eruptions to the north of the island, probably in the Aleutian group. The tide gauge in Honolulu Harbor on Nov. 29 noted a succession of severe disturbances far exceeding any variations ever noted there in the tides.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 12. -- The fight between the Louisville Gas Company and the Kentucky Heating Company, a natural gas concern, was settled, temporarily at least, to-day, when the Court of Appeals reversed the decision of the Circuit Court in the case of the Calor Oil and Gas Company, controlled by the Louisville Company, against W.C. McGehee.

BOSTON, Dec: 12. -- The money market is extremely firm. Call loans, 6@7 per cent,; time loans on collateral, 6 per cent.; loans on mercantile paper, 6@7 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 6 per cent.; York funds, 15@20c discount. Clearing, $22,073,722; balances, $1,551,201.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial and news article in yesterday's issue on the life and labors of Herbert Spencer, though necessarily made brief by journalistic limitations of time and space, were unprejudiced and appreciative reviews of the work of the great evolutionist. It is manifestly impossible.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Lakewood is preparing to entertain a great host of visitors over the holidays. The advance bookings at the Lakewood Hotel, the Laurel House, and the Laurel-in-the-Pines give assurance that these hotels will be crowded with patrons. It is becoming the fashion more and more each year for city folks to spend the Christmas vacation in the country.
THE happy-looking young matron was talking to a neighbor suburbanite as they sat together on an outgoing train one afternoon.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 12. -- The first genuine blizzard of the season prevails, in portions of Northern, Central, and Western Kansas to-night, having raged for the past twelve hours. Since midnight lost night the thermometer at some points dropped forty degrees, and to-night stands at 10 degrees above zero.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The records of the Prebyterian Hospital show that Dr. Washburn was a patient in that institution on two different occasions. The last time was Jan. 2, 1902, when he was admitted for treatment by Dr. N. Senn. It appears that Dr. Senn was called away from the city about that date, and was unable to attend Dr. Washburn.

On the Hamburg-American Line steamship Altal, which sailed from this port yesterday for Cartagena were four of the Commissioners who came to Washington from Colombia a few weeks ago in regard to the Panama affair.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the recent immense Anarchistic meeting in Cooper Union would bring forth such a fulminant editorial as appeared in your last Saturday issue was to be expected. If it had not been for lack of accommodation the whole audience, I presume, could have been arrested and held for trial under strict interpretation of our new law against disbeliefs.

VALPARAISO, Ind., Dec. 12. -- Rusty forceps, alleged to have been left in his side after an operation conducted by the late Dr. Christian Fenger at the Presbyterian Hospital in Chicago, caused the death of Dr. I.B. Washburn of Rensselear, Ind., in a private hospital here Friday.

The breaking of the fifty-foot boom of a derrick on the new building of the Williamsburg Trust Company, at the junction of Willoughby, Adams, and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, precipitated a load of beams of several tons in weight into Adams Street, breaking trolley, telephone, and electric light wires and filling the street with hissing electric flames.

AND now is the time for the Christmas lists for the employes and servants at the various clubs. At every one of the different clubs these lists adorn a conspicuous place. It is against the very first principle of club etiquette to fee a servant. This is an axiom. The sum subscribed by the various members is always divided pro rata.

Discussion began past Winter, after the Senate had ratified the treaty with Colombia, in regard to the manner in which the stipulated payment of $40,000,000 to the Panama Canal Company should be made.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Democratic Senators in caucus to-day decided to submit no amendments to the House Cuban Reciprocity bill, and this action assures the passage by the Senate of that bill next Wednesday, when the final vote on the measure is to be taken in the upper House.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12. -- Rain fell after the third race to-day, but not in sufficient quantities to spoil the speed of the track for the Preliminary Derby Handicap, for two-year-olds, at six furlongs, and worth $2,205 to the winner. Capt. S.S. Brown's pair, Exclamation and Safety Light, were favorites in the betting at 9 to 2, while the Schorr entry, Dutiful and Monastic, opened at fours and receded to sevens.

THE question of entertaining children out of school hours, when they have passed the nursery age, is one that all mothers are racking their brains to solve. In a crowded city the solution is more difficult than in the country. The city child has no recourse to the big yard, which is the happy hunting ground of his country cousin.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Only illness would have kept me from sooner applauding the letter that appeared in your paper a week or more ago, entitled, I think, "Clerks at Christmas-tide," even while experiencing keen regret that the cry for consideration should have come from Texas instead of right here in the midst of this great metropolis.

The new edition of The Messiah," prepared by Prof. Ebenezer Prout, which was used last year by the Oratorio Society of New York for the first time in this country, (only a Queen's Hall performance in November, 1902, under Prout's baton, preceded it in London,) will be again employee at the performances on Dec. 29 and 30, subject to slight modification.

In the minds of some people recent price movements in Brooklyn Rapid Transit have revived the old question as to how to apply the gauge to non-dividend paying stocks in order to ascertain their approximate value. Unfortunately, it is so often the case that between price and value there is such a great gulf that the question might well be dropped and no attempt be made to answer it.

There is a myth that that delicious Irishman, Mr. George Bernard Shaw clad in motley, burst through a hoop in the circus of British public opinion, shouting to an audience of churchgoers, class worshippers, and beef-eaters that he was an atheist, an Anarchist, and a vegetarian.

Last week we had a series of almost million-share days, marked by wide fluctuations, and yet the price averages were altered between Monday and Friday scarcely more than 1 per cent. Doubtless many will be surprised at such an apparently insurprised sequel to at week of better sustained volume of business, with a more contentious market than we have had recently.

Stuart, a clerk, of 122 West One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, last night went to the home of his brother-in-law, where his wife and baby were living, and, standing on the street in front of the door, shot himself in the temple.

One of the most interesting debates that have occurred for a long time in the German Reichstag was that which was carried on within the week between Count VON BUELOW and Herr BEBEL. Herr BEBEL is the "terrible child" of that body.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12. -- An examination, by Yalo officials of the damage caused by the fire at Marsh Hall, the Yale Forest School Building, to-day, indicated that the first estimate of $100,000 was much too large.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the construction of the east half of the river portion of the Harlem River tunnel in this city for the rapid transit railroad, I am prepared to say that the method I have adopted therefor and am now carrying out will be a great improvement on the novel method under which I successfully constructed the west half of the river portion of said tunnel.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Money was plentiful in the market to-day, and discounts were easy, being dominated by the condition of New York exchange.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While it is true that Christmas to thousands in our favored land and time is a season filled to the brim with joy and brightness, yet it is equally true that, unless some early and practical help is brought to many, it will be a season clouded with sorrow and distress.

WATERLOO, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- Delegates favorable to the nomination of ex-Senator J. Sloat Fassett for Congressman from the Thirty-third District were selected at the Seneca County Republican Convention held here to-day, which assures him of the nomination.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- The market here was lifeless, the arbitrage stocks alone showing any animation. Price changes were unimportant, hardly exceeding eighths and quarters. The apparent failure of the Consolidated Lake Superior plan failed to stimulate trading in those stocks, while the New York reports that the 1904 dividends on Pennsylvania Railroad stock were recognized as bear ammunition only.

It may be that after all the admirers of Mme. Melba will have an opportunity to hear her in grand Opera here before the end of the season. Though, according to har present arrangements, she is to be in London by Jan. 7, it is understood that she may change her mind and decide to give her services for the remainder of the season to Manager Conried.
Last week witnessed the culmination of a "movement," a phenomenon which is always a joy to the Wall Street man with a "system."

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 12. -- The distinctive borne holidays of Thanksgiving and Christmas falling so close together generally means a dull season at the pleasure resorts during December, tout the exception to prove the rule has been found this month in Atlantic City. The arrivals during the past few days have been unusually Heavy for this time.

Mrs. James Speyer of 257 Madison Avenue, the Treasurer of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following contributions to the "Woman's Fund" of the general collection to date:

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Professional cracksmen, who are supposed to be the same men who blew up the safe in the Clarksborough Post Office last week, wrecked the safe in the office of the Pennsylvania Railroad at Pavonia, a suburb of Camden, early this morning. The burglars opened fire on the operator in the signal tower and he narrowly escaped with his life.

Amid the deafening cheers of some 15,000 wildly excited spectators the international six-day bicycle race was brought to a sensational finish in Madison Square Garden last night, the winning team being "Bobby" Walthour of Atlanta, Ga., and "Benny" Munroe of Memphis, Tenn. George Leander of Chicago and Nat Butler of Boston took second honors, and Floyd Krebs and his teammate, Alexander Peterson of Newark, N.J., finished third.

The second of Frank Damrosch's symphony concerts for young people will be given at Carnegie Hall next Saturday afternoon. The programme illustrates early opera, oratorio, and early symphony, carrying out the historical scheme of this year's series. As an example of early opera the entire second act of Gluck's "Orpheus" will be given, with Miss Marguerite Hall as soloist.

Wielding a silver pickaxe, Borough President Jacob A. Cantor yesterday morning broke ground, figuratively speaking -- it had been broken previously with a more serviceable pick in the hands of a laborer -- for the extension of Riverside Drive, while other city officials and a crowd of interested spectators applauded.

AN American curio collector recently read of the obscure death in Italy of a once widely known English art swindler, and laid down his newspaper with a smile. "That fellow's death reminds me," he said, of the formation of my first art collection.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 12. -- The Canadian Association of Amateur Oarsmen has asked President James Pilkington of the National Association to appoint a sub-committee at their annual meeting to meet with a like committee from the Canadian Association of Amateur Oarsmen in Buffalo at an early date to confer upon be date for holding the two great rowing events -- the National and the Royal Canadian Henley.

Disturbed by the repeated publication of newspaper articles to the effect that the Williamsburg Bridge is not anything like ready for the "opening" that has been planned for it on Saturday next with an elaborate display, Mayor Low yesterday made a personal inspection of the structure. He was accompanied by Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal.

During the holidays the Piper Children in "Babes in Toyland" will give out presents to all children who attend the special holiday matinees. On account of this a rearrangement of the last act is necessary. New songs, a pretty and unique Christmas dance, and a Christmas tree loaded down with gifts will be introduced.

Though the actual installation of safety appliances in the Rapid Transit Subway has not been begun, the officers of the operating company have placed orders with steel manufacturers for all the complex machinery necessary, and according to General Manager Edward P. Bryan the system adopted for protecting patrons of the underground road is so complete that it will leave hardly any precaution in the hands of the men who run the trains.

TUESDAY, DEC. 15. -- By Richard V. Harnett Co., public auction sale, 574, 570, and 578 Eleventh Avenue, east side, 25 feet north of Forty-third Street, each 25 by 65 by 100, three five-story brick flats.

Charles H. Murray, leader of the Eighth District, was selected by the caucus of the Republican County Committee yesterday afternoon at the Filth Avenue Hotel, to succeed M. Linn Bruce as President of that body. The election is to take place Thursday night next at the United Charities Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, when President Bruce retires and the terms of the other officers of the committee likewise end.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- The competition for the Russian emigrant traffic has assumed a new phase. The German steamship companies, which have long enjoyed the predominant share of this traffic, have at last succeeded in stopping one loophole through which emigrants from the northern half of the Continent reached competing lines.

C.A. Ludlum has been appointed Assistant Secretary of the Home Insurance Company.

THE fashionable shade of hair this Winter is gray -- that is, for matrons. The red hair craze, has gone out of fashion. There is a story floating around society that the reason there for has been the illness of two very promirent matrons who are frequently seen in the parterre boxes.

Mr. Shaw had this to say of the matter in his report:

As a result of the recent visit of Secretary C.H. Gillette of the American Automobile Association to Boston, where he met representatives of the leading automobile clubs of Massachusetts and discussed with them the advantage of forming a Massachusetts State Automobile Association, in affiliation with the American Automobile Association, it was decided that the proposed organization should be effected.

To the Editor of the New York Times: I read in THE TIMES of Saturday last an editorial on the meeting which was held at Cooper Union to protest against the intended deportation of Mr. John Turner. Knowing that you are never averse to the expression of a difference of opinion, and feeling that the other side should also have their innings, I beg your editorial leave to say a word for them.

According to the official canvass for Mayor of all the votes cost at the November election, George B. McClelian received a plurality of 62,690 over Seth Low. The canvass for this office was completed yesterday by the Board of Elections, sitting as the city canvassing board, and will be certified to on Tuesday nest as soon as the vote for the rest of the city offices has been completely canvassed.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- The Countess Diane Ogier d'Ivry, the beautiful young daughter of Count Ogier d'Ivry, died in a hospital here yesterday under remarkable circumstances. Last night at 8:30 o'clock a pony cart, driven by a handsomely dressed young man, accompanied by a groom, collided with a heavy vehicle near the Avenue du Bois de Boulogne.

People who are troubled about women growing, out of their proper sphere would have been interested in the exhibition of the work of the Hebrew Technical School for Girls in the ballroom at Delmonico's yesterday afternoon. There was a large variety of work shown, and the greater part of it was in various forms of hand sewing.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- There have been no striking developments in the stock markets this week. The growing anxiety concerning the situation in the Far East has been a disturbing factor, causing prices to fluctuate moderately in accordance with the construction put on telegrams from St. Petersburg, Peking, and Tokio.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Judson W. Lyons, the colored National Committeeman from Georgia, was invited with, the other Republican Committeemen to Senator Hanna's dinner at the Arlington to-night. Early in the day it was rumored that, although Lyons had been invited, a gentle hint would be dropped to him that he might dis- cover a previous engagement.

The Iron Age offers a suggestion to the unions representing skilled labor in the several branches of the building trades which should commend itself to their thoughtful consideration, in view of the conditions with which they find themselves confronted. It admits that most of them are strong, and that some have gained undisputed control of skilled labor in the trades they represent.
