GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- Mrs. Adele Force Watt was granted an absolute divorce from her husband, Commodore Archibald Watt, at a special term of the Supreme Court, at which Justic William J. Gaynor presided, in Goshen to-day. Justice Gaynor heard the argument of opposing counsel, and after due deliberation granted the final decree as provided in the interlocutory judgment of Justice Albert A. Sewall in Brooklyn on Sept. 3.

From the Biographical Column of The Scribbler. FERDINAND THOMPSON, whose charming verses entitled "When Tommy Went A-Fishing" appeared in a recent number of Merry Days, has been contributing to prominent periodicals for several months. Among these we may mention The Nickel Magazine, Comfort, and The War Cry.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After serving as juror for the last November term, I feel that I would like to express my opinion, which I think will benefit the citizen as well as the court in obtaining talesmen. To my astonishment I saw a string of talesmen at the opening of the term going into line to offer their reasons to be excused from doing jury duty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is now the second occasion in a short space of time when the American public is stirred by incidents occurring in Asiatic Turkey and Syria. Any one who does not know the circumstances and the reasons for the occurrences will probably think that that part of the world is wholly inhabited by wild Indians, and that there is no security whatever.
YOU will ablige me exceedingly," said the youngman, as he fumbled at the tails of his dress coat, "if you will tie this handkerchief around your throat," and he produced a square of Yale blue silk.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Colombian Legation to-night received a cablegram from Gen. de Castro, Commander in Chief of the Colombian Army, dated Port Limon, Costa Rica, to-day, conveying the information that the results of the election for President held throughout the country on Dec. 8 show a complete triumph for Gen. Reyes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was surprised on reading the editorial which you published last Saturday, Dec. 5, entitled "In Defense of Anearchy," As a rule I find myself either in complete accord with your editorials or impressed by the force of their arguments, but in this instance, to use a legal phrase, I except to the article, and to each and every part thereof.

The week closed with continuance of the reactionary tendency of its latter half. The list showed no large advances of general interest, but there were declines in such properties as Pennsylvania and Brooklyn Rapid Transit. On the other hand, although the advance in the Steels reached only a fraction, it is no slight matter that the decline was checked.

The annual rush of Christmas mall to and from foreign ports is nearing its. height, and at the present rate it will exceed that of any past year. Employes of the Post Office Foreign Department, have been reinforced, and are working night and day to keep up with the great pile of mail that is continually accumulating.

The sleepy province of Oldenburg, tucked away in one of Germany's flap pockets, has a history which is very small of its age and rarely comes into attention in association with anything more important than a grand ducal marriage or funeral, and even to those functions little interest appertains beyond the State's somewhat restricted boundaries.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- The Vienna house which is publishing Lieut. Bilse's book announces in a circular that the demand is so enormous that it is unable to meet it, although five printing establishments and binderies are kept busy day and night.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- State Banking and Insurance Commissioner David O. Watkins Has sent to the Controller of the Currency the last quarterly statement for the year of the State banks, trust companies, and savings banks of New Jersey.

-- There is significance of various kinds, perhaps, in the distribution made this year by the Norwegian Parliament of the five Nobel prizes. These were established with a fine disregard of national lines, of which of course there is none, or ought to be none, in philanthropy, science, and literature, but it will be noticecd that one of the prizes goes to a Dane, Dr. FINSEN; one to a Swede.

A meeting of the New York Public School Athletic League will probably be held within a short time to del definitely upon some of the suggestions made by the Secretary, Dr. Luther Halsey Gulick at the meeting last week, when the organization was perfected. These suggestions concern the general work of physical culture for which the league is primarily formed.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 12. -- The Building Traces Employers' Convention to-day declared that all members of the new association shall be free to compete with each other in any city of the land. This decision stunned the New York delegation, and caused one of the Easterners to make the observation that the Chicago contractors were using the organization movement to further their own selfish motives.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The United States Naval Observatory to-day announced the details of its scheme to send telegraphic time signals throughout the world to mark the beginning of the new year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The President has selected William Insco Buchanan of New York to be the first United States Minister to Panama.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is very interesting, and withal somewhat tragic and dramatic, to read day after day this week of the finding of the skulls and other bones of "Dutch malefactors," of "revolutionary prisoners," and other unauthenticated people in the excavation for the subway station in the City Hall Park.

Dr. Holbrook Curtis and Dr. Lewis Rutherford Morris, the physicians in attendance on Senator William A. Clark of Montana, announced last night that the operation on the patient's ear performed last Wednesday had been entirely successful. They said that the Senator was resting easily and would be able to leave his bed in about three weeks if complications did not occur.

Odd as it may seem, there must have been a time when the old clo' man was a novel personage, as he was the first in the business. Since then second-hand dealers have become more common. But even now most persons would stare at a sign reading:

The management of the Metropolitan Opera House announces for to-night a concert under the direction of Mr. Felix Mottl. The singers of the evening will be Miss Olive Fremstad, Miss Delsarte, Mr. Pol Plangon, Mr. Rossi, while a special attraction will be added in the first appearance at these concerts of Mr. Jacques Thibaud, the French violinist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- An order will be prepared shortly in the War Department announcing changes in the present military departments. It is the understanding that there will be established five divisions embracing twelve departments.

The four annual reports of railroads issued this week are remarkable for their similarity in several important details and are interesting because they throw new light upon railroad conditions. The companies in question are the Iowa Central Railway, the Minneapolis and St. Louis, the Long Island Railroad, and the Kansas City Southern Railway.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 12. -- In a report made by State Inspector Henry B. Hines to Gov. Beckham of an investigation of the Department of State Auditor, which he made at the instance of the Chief Executive, the Inspector charges very gross irregularities in that department.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- A New York girl, Miss Marguerite Melville, a talented pianist and composer residing in Berlin, recently received an invitation to go to Athens to play before the King and the royal family of Greece.

An important golf event of the coming holiday season will be the annual meting of the Intercollegiate Golf Association. These meetings are usually held in this city at the Holland House, and no announcement has been made that a different plan will be adopted this year. There will probably be a general change in officers, as many of the present members will be graduated in June.

The Captains of the Harvard elevens of the past seventeen years, together with prominent coaches and players, will meet in Boston next Wednesday to discuss a definite system by which future Harvard football teams can be developed. The fact that Harvard has won but three victories in twenty-five years in competition with the Yale eleven has thoroughly convinced the Crimson graduates that there is something radically wrong with the Harvard system.
SENATOR QUAY, who passes much of his leisure at his bungalow in Florida, tells this story of an old negro who came to a watchmaker with the two hands of a clock.

The committee of the Produce Exchange recently appointed to consider the advisability of adopting a plan extending the system of grain deliveries to Buffalo and other points in this country has completed its organization and will take up the matter early in January.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Dec. 12. -- An accident, which occurred at the Pensacola Navy Yard yesterday afternoon badly damaged the two naval floating docks at that place. The workmen were taking out the smaller dock on the large one brought here recently from Havana, and repaired at a cost of $75,000, when the blocks slipped, the small dock crushing through the pontoons and otherwise badly damaging the big dock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The recent talk in Washington of opposition to the nomination of President Roosevelt by the National Convention recalls to Senator Cullom a story connected with the opposition to President Lincoln to a renomination in 1861. Mr. Cullom believes, as in the case of Lincoln, when the convention meets at Chicago next June there will be no candidate proposed against Mr. Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- A blizzard struck Illinois to-day, and already has overspread the entire Northwest, and a severe cold wave is following fast in the wake of the storm. A temperature of 20 degrees below zero is reported from North Dakota, and at St. Paul, where the thermometer registers 2 degrees below zero, the weather is rapidly growing colder.
The small reduction in loans shown by the bank statement was the resultant of many changes by individual banks, thirty of them reporting decreases and twenty-five having increased their loans.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Gen. William H. Carter of the United States Army, who has been investigating the remount system of the British Army with a view to reporting to the General Staff of the United States Army, had a farewell interview with War Secretary H.O. Arnold-Forester yesterday, and leaves England this week for the Transvaal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13.-- Representative Williams of Mississippi is quite optimistic on the outlook for the Democrats next year, for the reason that factional and other differences have been removed, and the party is united and harmonious to a degree that has not been known in twelve years.

Two explosions occurring between midnight and dawn yesterday morning in two unfinished buildings nearly a mile apart, both of which have been for months past scenes of dispute between Parks's old Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union, known as Local No. 2, and the newly formed New York Housesmiths' Union, led the police to the conclusion that the use of dynamite as an argument in labor disputes in this city has begun.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Considerable comment was occasioned here to-day by reports that Secretary Root, at a dinner held last night by the Carabao Society, an organization of army and navy officers who have seen active service in the Philippines, had predicted that a war would come "soon" between the United States and some foreign power.

Frank Buchanan, President of the International Association of Bridge and Structural Ironworkers, was allowed the privilege of the floor at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union to make a final plea to the unions to save Local No. 2 from extinction. He was accompanied by General Organizer Fitzpatrick of the International Association.

-- Of the innumerable shapes in which hysteria manifests itself, perhaps none is so distressing to people with the normal amount of self-control as that under the influence of which women of repute and for most of the time entirely sane cast sense and decency aside in demonstrating for criminals an interest with, difficulty distinguishable from affection.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent correspondent says: "What a fall from Lincoln to Roosevelt" Doubtless he is young or has a poor memory. When Lincoln was a candidate for President, and long after his election, he was belittled by political enemies far worse than Roosevelt has ever been.

Manager McGraw of the New York National League baseball team has made the first consummate deal of the season in the exchange of players. At the Victoria Hotel yesterday Mr. McGraw announced that he had traded Pitcher "Jack" Cronin and Shortstop Charley Babb to Manager Hanlon of the Brooklyn Club in exchange for the services of "Bill" Dahlen, who, without doubt, is one of the best shortstops in the country.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 13 -- "The assassination of a great and good President has placed at the head of our Government a modern Caligula. The party of Abraham Lincoln, which successfully fought the doctrine of secession in this country, exhibits the example of a strong Government planting, nourishing, and fostering secession in another and weaker republic."

The usual retrospect of last, week's business upon the Stock Exchange does not confirm the doubtless general recollection of it as a week of reactionary price movement. Of the stocks which moved so much as a point 47 advanced, and only 38 declined. Among the bonds 34 advanced and 22 declined.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Carroll D. Wright, United States Commissioner of Labor, spoke to-day before the Ethical Culture Society on the issue between capital and labor. He contended that labor has been taught to feel that it is a social as well as economic power in a community, and that an educating process has gone on, until the demand of labor is for a reasonable margin beyond that fixed by the iron law of wages.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Congressman Gillet and his friends will not abide by the Result of the convention held yesterday at Waterloo, at which the delegates were instructed to vote for J. Sloat Fassett for Congress, thereby giving Fassett a majority of the delegates from the Twenty-ninth District, which Mr. Gillet has represented for six terms in the lower house.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the ever-present realization on the part of the city of the failures of past administrations to provide for the future of the city's requirements and growth, it seems most peculiar that we should continue the same policy of procrastination and allow future generations to provide for themselves.

By what he said formally and informally, Andrew Carnegie added interest to the annual meeting of the Educational Alliance, held last night in its building, at Jefferson Street and East Broadway. Mr. Carnegie was present, as he said, to follow the example of Abram S. Hewitt, which he had found to be a good thing to do.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The President in his recent message called the attention of Congress to the recently discovered frauds in the manufacture, issue, and sale of counterfeit and altered naturalization certificates. These frauds have become so bold and extensive as to render an immediate change in the law as to their form, issue, and distribution absolutely imperative.

In the killing of a man in Main Street early yesterday morning by an assassin the Brooklyn police find themselves with another puzzling. Italian murder mystery. The murdered man was first identified as John Buffalo of 50 Main Street, but several hours later it was found that this identification was wrong, and that Salvatore Especiale of the same address was the man who had been killed.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Atlantic Transport Line steamer Menominee, from London Dec. 3 for New York, which put into Falmouth to-day, reports that she encountered heavy gales, and that when 560 miles west of the Scilly Islands on Dec. 7 she had a terrible experience.

Investigations by the Merchants' Association of New York into the proceedings for the acquiring of lands in the Croton Valley for the purpose of water supply result in the assertion that out of the total of in the assertion that out of a total of the creation of the commission and the end of the year 1902 $10,579,942.34 was paid for the property acquired, while $3,384,404.04 was paid for the expense of acquiring it.

MIDDLEBOROUGH, Mass., Dec. 13 -- Harry Haskins and Frank Alien of this place were rescued from a floating piece of ice to-day, only to lose their lives when the boat used by their rescuer was swamped by a squall.

A fairly cheerful situation seems to have presented itself to the Civil Service Reform League when it met last week for its twenty-third annual meeting in Baltimore. Certainly so far as the National service is concerned there has been notable progress.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Under authority from M. Delcasse, Minister of Foreign Affairs, E. Spencer Pratt, ex-United States Minister to Persia, who is now residing here, is making extensive researches in the archives of the Foreign Office relative to the transfer of the Province of Louisiana by France to the United States.

Nellie Dunbar, twenty-six years old, who lived at Little West Twelfth and Greenwich Streets, died of acute alcoholism in St., Vincent's Hospital on Nov. 22. Her beauty so struck Coroners' physician O'Hanlon, as he officially examined her after death, that he wrote on the death certificate: "One more unfortunate gone to her rest."

In obedience to the instructions of the July Grand Jury, the Commissioner of Public Works for Manhattan, Mr. LIVINGSTON, has presented to President CANTOR a valuable report discussing the whole subject of asphalt street pavements and outlining a plan for the organization of a municipal repair plant.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 13 -- The New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association has announced the league baseball schedule for next season as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The trend of opinion among the members of the National Committee who talked of the President's Panama policy was strongly in support of what has been done. This circumstance gives interest to the statement of a gentleman who was conversant with the views of President McKinley as to what the course of the United States should be toward Colombia in regard to the control of the Isthmus.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 13 -- The stakes for the Spring meeting of the New Louis ville Jockey Club have been announced by Secretary Price. They are ten in number, including a stake for the jumpers. No purse less than $400 will be given, with handicaps in proportion. The meeting begins on May 2 and continues for fifteen racing days.

Great reticence was observed yesterday by all concerned in the suit begun in the Supreme Court of Westchester County by Mrs. Helen Villard Bell, only daughter of Henry Villard, to set aside her father's will. The papers in the suit were filed last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A public meeting called by the Inter-Denominational Congress of Women of Washington for the purpose of protesting against Senator Reed Smoot retaining his seat in the Senate, was held here to-day in the Metropolitan Methodist Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Washington is the Lakewood of the coming McClellan administration. The only difference is that, whereas in 1897 it was the Tammany boss and not the Mayor-elect who held court at Lakewood, this year it is the Mayor-elect who holds court in Washington and the Tammany leaders come to see him.

SALEM, Mass., Dec. 13 -- Miss Mary A. Narbenne, widely known among antiquarians, and whose home at 71 Essex Street, built previous to 1680 and preserved on its original lines, is of great historic interest, was attacked by a housebreaker early today and beaten into insensibility. Her condition is critical.

We alluded some time since to the peculiar experience Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN had had in the past in the matter of "dumping," as to which he is so exercised. At present he is preaching all over the United Kingdom that the English markets are being invaded by cheap goods which foreign manufacturers, protected by their own tariffs, can afford to sell in England below cost.

Startling gyrations on the part of an automobile cab at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, about 8 o'clock last night, frightened a young woman inside it, the chauffeur, and a big crowd of spectators until it whirled itself into a position where it could not move.

COLON, Dec. 13 -- Through the examination of the San Blas coast made by the United States cruiser Atlanta and the converted cruiser Mayflower, both of which vessels have returned here, it has been clearly established that the Colombian cruisers General Pinzon and Cartagena appeared in the Gulf of Darien about thirty-six hours after they were reported as having left Cartagena.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The annual report of Secretary of the Interior Hitchcock has been presented to the President Among its interesting features are the chapters dealing with pensions, irrigation, Indian affairs, patents, and the experiment in Government ownership of telegraph lines now being made in Porto Rico.

The sympathy felt and expressed for the miners in their great struggle in the anthracite region last year to improve their condition, and wherever they have made an effort for higher wages, is not likely to be manifested again very soon in view of their attitude in placing as many obstacles as possible in the way of a full production of coal.

The Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by the National Academy of Science of Washington against the assessment of 45 per cent. duty, as "partly manufactured metal articles," on a set of dies for striking a medal which is awarded biennially to the person making the most important astronomical discovery.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 14. -- A heavy track upset all calculations to-day, and in each race the favorite met defeat. Safety Light was the only well-supported winner. There was quite a demonstration after the first race. Diaphanous had been well backed and he and Bronx finished heads apart on opposite sides of the track.

Johann Palojnar of Krain, Austria, should to-day reach Cleveland, Ohio, the termination of a journey filled with what to him were frightful adventures. His departure from Ellis Island yesterday afternoon was the occasion of unusual ceremonies. The William Fletcher was there to convey him to the Erie depot, and he was accompanied to the boat by two very polite officials in the uniform of the United States Treasury Department.

Although men of all political faiths apgeared before the Railroads Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday urging that the committee report favorably on the application of the New York and Port Chester Railway Company for the right to cross some sixty streets in the Bronx, the committee declind to take any action.

BOSTON, Dec. 14. -- Ex-State Treasurer Elliott Danforth and Mrs. Danforth of New York are at the Touraine, Mr. Danforth having come here to testify in the Wentworth will contest. While in the city Mr. Danforth has talked with, a number of leading Boston Democrats, and has endeavored to sound them as to their attitude toward Judge Alton B. Parker of New York as a Democratic Presidential, candidate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The great interest felt in the outcome of the Northern Securities merger case, in which the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Railroad Companies, J. Pierpont Morgan, James J. Hill, Daniel S. Lamont, and others are on one side, and the United States on the other, was exhibited to-day by the unusually large attendance in the Supreme Court, this being the day fixed for argument.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 14. -- Two hundred taxpayers of Nassau County met in the Supreme Court's room in the Court House to-day to discuss the much muddled state of the county's finances. A committee of three was appointed to consider the matter. Townsend Scudder, Congressman from the district, presided, and United States Distriet Attorney William J. Youngs took an active part in the consideration of the affairs.

Mrs. Carrie Nation, the star in the old play of "Ten Nights in a Barroom," revived at the Third Avenue Family Theatre, began a week's engagement there yesterday, opening with a matinee and following it with a grand performance in the evening. In the two entertainments Mrs. Nation smashed enough bottles to fill a wagon with broken glass.

ROCHELLE PARK, N.J., Dec. 14. -- There was a head-on collision on the Susquehanna Division of the Erie Railroad near here this evening, and a fireman and about twenty Italians were hurt. Some of the most seriously injured were taken to Paterson hospitals.

According to a decision handed down yesterday by Justice Roesch, in the Fourth Municipal District Court, musical conductors have a legal right to take whatever liberties they may deem artistically proper with motifs, movements, , of orchestral compositions, even though in doing so they wound and lacerate the artistic feelings of performers under the swing of their batons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of the $150,000,000 gold reserve in the Division of Redemption, shows:

Plain business men may find it hard to follow the reasoning of Mr. CARROLL D. WRIGHT in respect to labor. New doctrines often perplex old-fashioned minds. There will not be the slightest difficulty in accepting what Mr. WRIGHT has to say about the commodity theory of labor. We have effectually come up to that.
Jacob Rosenbaum has resold for Harry Matz the plot on the north side of One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, 100 feet west of Madison Avenue, 100 by 100.11.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 14. -- After an exciting fight of four hours in the bitter cold today firemen succeeded in subduing one of the most stubborn and dangerous fires the department has been called upon to handle for some time. Spontaneous combustion is the only cause given for the fire, which was first discovered on the seventh floor of the Arrott Power Building, located between Penn Avenue and Duquesne Way, and between Sixth and Seventh Streets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Senator and Mrs. Alger entertained a large dinner party this evening, their guests including Senator and Mrs. Wetmore, Senator and Mrs. Spooner, Senator and Mrs. Foraker, Senator and Mrs. Depew, Senator Frye, Senator Hale, Senator Allison, Senator Aldrich, Mrs. Stanley Mathews, Mrs. Richard Clover, and Miss Poe.

Quiet, Strong Market. -- Only during the first and last hours of trading was there any animation in yesterday's market, the intervening period being characterized by more or less listless trading, which dragged along to such an extent that between 1 and 2 o'clock the transactions fell short of 70,000 shares.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the management of the elevated roads care nothing for the comfort of their patrons was manifested in a very marked degree during the rush hours on Saturday evening.

Miss Bertha Galland opened last night at the New York Theatre in the title role of Paul Kester's dramatization of "Dorothy Vernon of Haddon Hall," and was welcomed with an enthusiasm showing that both author and actress have many friends and that they are continuing to make them.

Further hearings in the suit of the four first mortgage bondholders of the United States Shipbuilding Company to make permanent the receivership, which has been in progress for weeks past before Special Examiner Henry D. Oliphant, will not be held in the law library of Samuel Untermyer, counsel for the complainants, but in some public place, presumably a court room of the United States Circuit Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The strongest speech yet heard from the Democratic side in the debate on the Cuban treaty resolution was made to-day by Senator Bailey, who for three hours held the Senate in close attention.

The Cotillion of Eighty, under the management of the New Amsterdam Club, had its first dance of this season last evening at Delmonico's. James Clark McGuire led the cotillion, having Miss Baylissa Myles of New Orleans as his partner. Mr. McGuire introduced-several new figures, and ideas during the cotillion.
LONDON, Dec. 15. -- The various units of the British expedition to Tibet are concentrating in the Chumbi Valley, where Cols. Younghusband and Macdonald are awaiting them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- If elected to the Presidency of Colombia by the overwhelm- ing majority which Bogota dispatches in- dicate, Gen. Raefel Reyes, Colombian Min- ister to the United States, would regard this call of his country as a command which it would be difficult for him to refuse to obey.

Curb securities were traded in yesterday on a moderately active scale, with slight recessions ruling. There was no particular stock that drew any large amount of attention, and price movements were limited, except in one or two issues. The copper stocks were little changed, with Greene Consolidated the most active, closing at a loss of one-eighth, at 11 7/8.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The National Suffrage League convention, (colored,) was held here to-day, and police had to be called in to preserve order.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Secretary of War Root to-day sent a letter to Senator Proctor, Acting Chairman of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, that is investigating the case of Gen. Leonard A. Wood, in which he says that the information that has been furnished the public concerning the testimony taken before the committee is untruthful.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14. -- Notification of a decison of the Missouri Supreme Court which brings into question the legality of hundreds of arrests and convictions recently made in the boodle cases on information instead of indictment, and which, according to Circuit Attorney Folk, opens the doors of the penitentiary, through writs of hahere corpus, to many others, was received here to-day by Mr. Folk.

Vincinzio Battaglio, allas Grippo, who says he is living on East Twelfth Street, near First Avenue, was arrested by Detective Sergeants Petrosino and Bonnoil yesterday charged with having murdered a man named Eugenio with poison at Palermo, Italy, on May 5, 1894. It is asserted that Battaglio, in collusion with the wife of Eugenio, formed a plot to poison Eugenio, which the two did successfully.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 14. -- The Gross Strauss Company, retail dealer in ladies' furnishings, on Washington Street, has assigned for the benefit of creditors to J.P. Morse of Boston. The liabilities are estimated at about $150,000. An account of stock is being taken, and in a day or two the amount of assets will be known.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 14. -- In a fit of despondency over a long-continued illness James Hervey Agens, who was nearly eighty years of age, committed suicide this morning by hanging himself in his barn with a piece of clothes line. He sustained a stroke of paralysis four years ago, and locomotor ataxia developed.

The week opened with a distinct check to the reactionary tendency which was characteristic of the closing days of last week. This was discoverable throughout the list, and was most noteworthy in precisely those securities which had been chosen by the bears as the most promising for their campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- The local market was practically without feature. There was no disposition to trade, and, while prices held firm, it was due to the absence of selling pressure. United Gas Improvement and Philadelphia Company were both higher, but these were about the only stocks for which the commission houses had legitimate buying orders.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 14. -- The completion of the great project for the electrical development of the falls of the Susquehanna River, on the Niagara plan, is now assured toy the announcement to-day that Anthony N. Brady of New York and associates have taken over $1,000,000 stock in the United Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore, controlling the lighting of this city.

Mr. R.E. GOSNELL, the Secretary of the British Columbian Bureau of Information, has published an extremely interesting account of the position of Canada, particularly with reference to annexation to the United States. It is in the form of an interview with an American inquirer.

A special meeting of the stockholders o the International Bank and Trust Company of America, which operated a chain of banks in Mexico in connection with the Corporation Trust Company of Delaware, with headquarters here, and went into a receiver's hands early in the Fall, was held in the parlors of the Astor House yesterday afternoon for the purpose of considering a reorganization plan proposed by the President, William Hill Hunt.

The measures proposed by the Health Department to stamp out smallpox in New York should receive the cordial and intelligent co-operation of all classes of citizens. New York is peculiarly exposed to imported infection, and from the nature of many of its most populous districts this disease, if it gains a foothold, is extremely difficult to eradicate.
LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Money was in fair demand in the market to-day, but the supply was not abundant. Discounts were easy, owing to rumors that an additional u500,000 in gold was coming from India.

-- When a barge hand falls into the East River just before daylight on a particularly stormy Winter morning he takes about all the chances of a watery death that are available to any except the most determined of suicides, and those who jump into the water to rescue him take at least as many.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- Emperor William, at the Castle, this morning received in audience the President and Vice Presidents of the Reichstag. In the course of conversation his Majesty emphasized the necessity for Germany to concern herself with over-sea politics. He referred to the importance of the cultivation of cotton in the German colonies and the completion of the railroads in the African colonies.
LONDON, Dec. 15. -- The terms of Russia's reply to Japan were communicated yesterday to the Japanese Minister here, Baron Hayashi, by the Government at Tokio.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Representative Robert Baker of Brooklyn made his maiden speech in the House to-day, and got its undivided attention and considerable Democratic applause.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- The Moscow correspondent of The Times says the existence of a well-organized Armenian revolutionary plot in the Caucasus has been officially recognized by the Minister of the Interior, M. de Plehve.
Details of the plan for the financing of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company which is proposed by the committee headed by James A. Blair were made public yesterday.

Several hundred employes of the American Sheet Steel and the American Tin Plate Companies are to be moved from this city to Pittsburg on Jan. 1, 1904. Their wholesale removal is due to the consolidation of the two companies, resulting from the efforts of the United States Steel Corporation, of which they are constituent companies, to effect large savings in operating expenses.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Dec. 14. -- Because one of the members was taken ill with smallpox en route, the Bennett and Moulton Theatrical Company was last night kept out of Milton by armed guards, compelled to walk about in the freezing cold for hours, and finally allowed to spend the night in a side-tracked passenger coach.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 14. -- Judgment was rendered to-day at Austin in favor of the State of Texas against the Southern Pacific Company, perpetually enjoining the company from "purchasing or acquiring any stock of the San Antonio and Aransas Pass Railway." The judgment also enjoins the "San Antonio-Aransas Pass Company, or its employes, from in any way recognizing the Southern Pacific Company as the owner of San Antonio and Aransas Pass Railway stock."

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- The court which has been hearing the arguments in the suit of "Tod" Sloan, the American jockey, against the French Jockey Club for $40,000 damages, for being warned off the turf in connection with Rose de Mai's winning the Prix de Dlane at Chantilly in May last, today found in favor of Sloan, and condemned the Jockey Club to pay the costs, which will be assessed later.

Suddenly, as if by magic, the entire social kaleidoscope has been changed. People are coming in from the country, opening their town houses, and entertaining. Even the Christmas holidays do not interfere. Sunday dinners, musicales, and bridge parties are all in vogue. There were many dinners given at Sherry's on Sunday, and one of the largest of last Sunday was that of P. Fenelon Collier for Mrs. Burke-Roche and Mrs. Frederic Neilson.

Mr. PARKERSON, a Louisiana Republican of more or less eminence, has, as have many other American citizens, a public grievance against the President for his procedures relating to the Isthmus of Panama. We strongly suspect Mr. PARKERSON of having a private grievance also.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- The invasion of the municipal service by labor unions was today ordered brought to a halt by Mayor Harrison. "In the mechanical branches of the city's service," said the Mayor, "where the employe is simply a workingman, it is all right for him to belong to a union, but where the man belongs to a department, like the firemen or policemen, he has no right to have a divided allegiance.

A Dominican plot to assassinate William F. Powell, United States Minister to Haiti, and Charge d'Affaires at Port au Prince, Santo Domingo, was announced yesterday in a communication from a high official of the present Dominican Government to a Dominican citizen in this city, who formerly was an official under Wos y Gil, the recently deposed President of the republic.

DENVER, Col., Dec.; 14. -- Reports persist that the new management of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company has been unable to bring an exact balance in the books of the company and its subsidiary concerns.

In St. John's Cemetery, Newtown, yesterday afternoon there was laid to rest "Jimmy the Paup," one of Brooklyn's oddest characters, who of his own will had been an inmate of Raymond Street Jail for thirty years. He died on Saturday night, and his death caused genuine sorrow among the keepers and jail attendants.

Announcement was made in this city last night that President Carruth of a Toronto trust company had been appointed by the Court at Toronto General Liquidator of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company. This appointment represents the latest step on the part of the reorganization committee in its efforts to protect the stockholders of the company as far as possible.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 14. -- John C. King, a policeman, is dead by his own hand, and H.J. Kressenberg, a well-known business man and member of the City Democratic Committee, is probably fatally wounded as the result of a sensational double tragedy enacted here last night.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15 -- The resignation of Mrs. James L. Blair as President of the Board of Lady Managers of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition was received and accepted to-day by the board, which is in convention here.

Mrs. Mabel Parker, who is on trial in the Court of General Sessions on a charge of forgery, will probably know her fate today, as the case will go to the jury some time this afternoon. Yesterday she bowed and smiled to those about her when she was called to the witness stand to testify in her own behalf.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Premier Combes to-day communicated to the Council of Ministers the text of a bill forbidding all teaching by the religious orders, even those now actually authorized, which will be presented in the Chamber of Deputies Friday next.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The tariff question was resurrected to-day in the Senate while Mr. Patterson of Colorado was speaking against the Cuban bill. Mr. Patterson said that he would be willing to liave the tariff on sugar reduced if there could be a corresponding reduction on other articles of import, when Mr. Aldrich interrupted him to ask if he were willing to make ad valorem rates on sugar as on other articles.

The conditions which resulted in the recent establishment of the Republic of Panama were discussed last night at a banquet of the Qufll Club, at the Hotel Manhattan, by Francis B. Loomis, Assistant Secretary of State of the United States, and Philippe Bunau-Varilla, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Panama to the United States, who were guests of the club.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15 -- Hands Across and Siddons were the only winning favorites to-day. Lev Dorsey was well backed in his race and nosed out a victory for his supporters. Autumn Leaves was cut down in her race. Weather clear; track lumpy and slow. Summary:
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Sardou's "La Sorciere" was produced by Sarah Bernhardt to-night at her own theatre, and achieved a great triumph for both author and actress.

"The Sacrament of Judas," Louis Tiercelin's tragedy in miniature, which Kyrle Bellew prefixed to "Raffles" last night at the Princess, is one of those outputs of French dramaturgy which delight, even astonish, by their masterly technical force of concentration, but, unlike so many such, the characters and the emotions dealt with are sane and normal, and work together to produce a moment of the highest spiritual exaltation.

Yesterday's stock market was weak in the same manner that Monday's market was strong. That is to say, the prices registered indicate merely the balance of business between professional traders, with remotest and smallest basis for inference regarding values. It is agreeable to add that the selling movements now occurring are not even alleged to indicate anything of the nature which in recent months used to add terrors to every point's decline.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- A lengthy letter from the Council of Foreign Bondholders, personally addressed to President Roosevelt, putting forward the British bondholders position anent Panama and Colombia, has been forwarded by the Foreign Office to Ambassador Durand, who has been instructed to hand it unofficially to the President.

When the club owners of the American Baseball League meet in their annual session at the Auditorium Annex, Chicago, to-morrow morning, the schedule and the foul strike rule will be the main subjects for discussion. According to President Johnson, however, the schedule will be arranged for 140 games and the season will end considerably in advance of the National League.

Gen. F.V. Greene yesterday corroborated telegraphed reports that he would take charge of the work of the Albright-Hayes Power Company, which is building a plant on the Canadian side of Niagara Fails. Gen. Greene added that he would leave this city to make his permanent home in Buffalo on Jan. 2.

The stockholders' committee, which undertook an investigation of the American Ice Company after the annual meeting last March, at which protest was made against the present management, made public its report last night.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 15 -- A deputation of some of those interested in the Consolidated Lake Superior properties called on Premier Ross this afternoon. They declined to say with what result. It is stated that over $1,500,000 held by Canadian shareholders has been lost. There is, it is said, not a cent's worth of protection.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15 -- At the elections held this afternoon George H. Coughlin, 1905, of Norristown, Penn., was elected manager and Warren Calvin Whitney, 1906, of Norwalk, Ohio, assistant manager of the Princeton football team for next year. To-day for the first time at these elections the Australian ballot system was used.

Decreased activity was shown in the trading in curb securities yesterday. Improvement in prices was not general throughout the list, but the recessions were few and but slight in extent. The stock which drew the most attention was Buffalo Gas, which advanced to 9, but later reacted on active trading to 1 3/8, a loss of 3/8.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15 -- After greeting a bank examiner who had come unannounced to examine his accounts, Asa C. Bushnell, cashier of the Yale National Bank, at State and Chapel Streets, this city, went into the basement of the bank this morning and shot himself, death ensuing an hour and a half later at Grace Hospital.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 15 -- Attorneys for J. Edward Addicks in the Federal court to-day filed his answer to the suit brought by George Wharton Pepper of Philadelphia demanding the return of $75,000,000 in the stock of the Bay State Gas Company, which the receiver alleges was issued fraudulently to Addicks.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- Local stock market conditions were unchanged to day. Little legitimate business was transacted. Manipulation was undertaken in Philadelphia Company, but it collapsed before the close, the price being rushed up a full point, then, under real selling, losing the entire advance.

Eagles, the baldheaded outside guard of Part I. of the General Sessions Court, had seated himself comfortably in the old arm chair behind the door, where he could keep his left ear against the crack to listen to trials while at the same time keeping his eye on the chair warmers who were trying to pass him without giving the proper countersign.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- A petition that the Manuel J. Portuondo Company of Philadelphia, cigar manufacturers, be adjudged bankrupt, was filed in the United States District Court to-day by John Dickey, Jr., counsel for creditors representing $66,000 of the $85,000 liabilities.

HAVANA, Dec. 15 -- In the House of Representatives to-day the debate was continued on the bill for the annulment of the contracts made by Gen. Wood in 1902 with the Church authorities, under which $190,000 is to be paid annually for five years as the rent of several buildings occupied by the Government at Havana and elsewhere.
Formal announcement of the new stock issue of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company was made yesterday, and a special meeting of the stockholders has been called for Dec. 30 to ratify the plan.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The rates for money were easy in the market to-day, and the supplies increased. Discounts were weak.

With great propriety and just indignation the Secretary of War calls the attention of the Senate Committee on Military Affairs to the activities of the industrious but unskillful falsifier who is peddling out the secrets of the Senate room to the press in a manner to do what damage he can to the reputation of Gen. LEONARD WOOD.

Bids for the construction of the Pennsylvania Railroad's fifty-million-dollar tunnel connecting New Jersey with Long Island by way of Manhattan Island were opened yesterday at the company's offices, 85 Cedar Street, in the presence of the chief operating officials and engineers, and it was announced by the officials that a cursory examination showed them to be within the company's estimate.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 15 -- The Naval Academy eight-oared crew will row races with Yale, Pennsylvania, and Georgetown on the Severn River next Spring. The exact dates for the races have not yet been fixed, but Midshipman H.E. Kimmel of Kentucky of the first class, manager of the navy crews, stated that the contests would take place some time in May.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of the $150,000,000 gold reserve in the Division of Redemption, shows: DENVER, Dec. 15 -- The special meeting of the stockholders of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, called for to-day, was adjourned until Jan. 12.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- The Democrats won an overwhelming victory in the municipal election to-day. Mayor Patrick Collins being re-elected by 26,565 plurality, the largest ever given a Mayoralty candidate in the history of the city.

Just after it had acquired at foreclosure sale the assets of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company pledged as security for the $5,050,000 loan of the Speyer syndicate, yesterday, the banking firm of Speyer Co., syndicate managers, announced that it was seeking the consent of participants in the loan to a plan admitting stockholders in, the giant corporation to participate in a scheme of liquidaton or reorganzation.

One of the curious facts in connection with the pension roll is the variation in what may be called the matrimonial habit of the warriors in the several wars. Thus, of the Revolutionary War, which closed 120 years ago, there are no survivors, but there are drawing pension two widows.

The steamship Umbria of the Cunard Line arrived here yesterday morning, completing a very rough voyage. The vessel was forty-eight hours behind her regular schedule, all of which time was lost during the first three days of the trip, when she was tossed and battered by heavy seas, which at times swept her deck, so that it was necessary for all of the passengers to confine themselves to the cabins.

The toughest argument against his protection policy with which Mr. CHAMBERLAIN has had to deal is that it will expose the Legislature of the United Kingdom to the demoralizing intrigues of special interests scrambling for tariff favors. The example of the United States has, naturally, been cited often.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The President is troubled over the situation in Alabama, where it looks as though anti-Roosevelt delegates would be elected to the National Convention.

The four-story brownstone-front dwelling 2 East Thirty-fifth Street, 28 by 98.9, adjoining the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue, has been sold by Frederick N. Goddard. It is said that the transaction also involves some adjoining property, but beyond the fact that the buyer is a realty company no particulars regarding the deal were obtainable yesterday.

District Attorney Jerome last evening was placed at the head of a committee appointed by the Excise Committee of the Citizens' Union to wage a vigorous campaign to put his excise plan into practice. The project includes the bringing about of legislative modifications of the present excise law, providing for Sunday opening of saloons from 1 o'clock in the afternoon to 11 o'clock at night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Mr. Simpson, the United States Consul at Puerto Plata, Santo Domingo, has cabled the State Department under to-day's date that a revolution has broken out at Santiago and that the movement is extensive and serious.

The Merchants' Association has made some interesting discoveries of abuses in connection with the condemnation of lands needed for public use or the protection of the watershed which show how badly the Aqueduct Commission has worked for the public interest. In the case of land acquired in Westchester and Putnam Counties to protect the watershed, for each $100 paid to landowners $51.06 was paid to Commissioners, counsel, experts, clerks, and for incidental expenses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Secretary Root will be called to-morrow as a witness before the Senate Committee on Military Affairs in its hearing of the Gen. Wood case.

Firm Opening. -- The strength of the market on Monday, and the apparent failure of the bears to carry very far their campaign against prices, inclined most traders to the long side of the market yesterday, and in consequence opening prices generally compared favorably with the final figures of Monday.

MANCHESTER, England, Dec. 15 -- A well-attended conference of Southeast Lancashire master spinners here this afternoon considered the present stage of the cotton trade and passed a resolution as follows:

Members of the Board of Aldermen indulged in a little farce comedy yesterday, with Alderman Peter Holler, the Chairman of the committee in charge of the Williamsburs Bridge celebration, as the butt of the Jokes. It all started when Alderman Sullivan objected to the souvenirs that had been handed out to the members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Rural free delivery, reciprocity with Canada, and the new Republic of Panama were topics of discussion in the House to-day. The debate was all based on the Pensions Appropriation bill, which was in Committee of the Whole.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The debutante tea, which in late years has lost its fashionable favor, was revived in all its old-time glory to-day, when an exceedingly fashionable company, numbering 400 guests, called to welcome Miss Alice Gordon Parker, daughter of Representative Richard Wayne Parker of New Jersey, to Washington society.
In the United States Circuit Court yesterday five appeals in customs cases were argued, and in each case a decision was made against the Government by Judge Platt.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 15 -- The following charters were issued to-day:

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- Though money is returning from the West and the demands of the South are more than offset by the sold from abroad, the money market is firm. Business is very dull. Call loans, 6 @ 6 1/2 per cent. Time loans, 5 1/2 @ 6 per cent. Time loans, mercantile, 6 @ 7 per cent. Clearing House loans, 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Democratic unity at both ends of the Capitol, with the purpose of making aggressive war on the Republicans, was practically accomplished to-day when the Democratic Senators at last managed to agree on procedure that would enable them to act in concert. They adopted a resolution by which a two-thirds vote in a caucus declaring party policy will bind all those who take part in it.

What is termed "the body of the law" is of comparatively slow growth. The Courts deal tentatively, as the rule, with new social conditions of all kinds, and it frequently takes them several years to reach conclusions which may be regarded as settled beyond dispute. The constantly changing point of view of litigation gradually results in the definition of what at the outset was extremely nebulous.

The principal guest and speaker at the dinner of the Republican organization of the Thirty-sixth Assembly District to the Captains of the election districts of that district was Gov. B.B. Odell, Jr., who was down on the toast list to respond to "Our Party."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The pledges made by President McKinley to the people of Cuba are on the verge of fulfillment. The Senate at 5 o'clock to-night, by a vote of 57 to 18, seven Democrats voting with the majority and one Republican with the minority, passed the joint resolution approving, the reciprocity treaty ratified by the Senate last March and by the Congress of Cuba subsequently.

The lines of the Kings County Elevated Railroad, in Brooklyn, running to East New York, Brighton Beach, and Coney Island, were tied up for two hours early last night by the burning out of the feed cable at the power house, Third Avenue and Second Street.

The General Sessions Court Judges have learned of a new game which certain criminals have been working for the purpose of gaining sympathy and escaping punishment for crimes. It is known as the "phony marriage game." The criminal under arrest makes arrangements with some woman to enter into marriage with him and have the ceremony performed in a cell of the Tombs.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 16 -- William H. Rafford, a Deputy Sheriff and Warden of the County Jail, was shot and killed this morning by Tuthill Reeve, a farmer of Aquebogue, three miles from Riverhead. Reeve to-night is besieged in his home by Sheriff Preston and an armed posse, which does not dare approach within gunshot of the house.

An outsider who undertakes to form a definite opinion as to the policy of the French Government and the Roman Church in France toward each other is exposed to a good deal of error whichever side he adopts. The situation is confused at best, because both parties to the contest are hot with passion, and because their pretensions are quite irreconcilable with each other.
LEEDS, Dec. 16 -- Chamberlain addressed two immense audiences here to-night, making the last speeches of his fiscal campaign for the present year.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Fire started in the Skillman Hardware Company factory this morning and despite the efforts of the Fire Department the building was gutted. While the firemen were fighting the flames there was a tremendous explosion in the cellar of the big fire truck and engine house, which is located in the centre of the town, at Willow and West Hanover Streets.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Evidence tending to show that a forgery was committed in the entry in the records of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, New York City, of the marriage of Baron August von Glahn and Mrs. Martha McCabe was produced in the County Court here to-day by David N. Carvalho, the New York handwriting, expert.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- It is a common remark in London that Americans are not sensible to the grave importance of the fiscal contest in progress in this country. It is said that they do not appreciate the American trade involved in the tendency here toward the abandonment of free trade and the erection of a tariff retaliatory against the tariffs now confronting Great Britain.

The lines of the Kings County Elevated Railroad, in Brooklyn, running to East New York, Brighton Beach, and Coney Island, were tied up for two hours early last night by the burning out of the feed cable at the power house, Third Avenue and Second Street.
LEEDS, Dec. 16 -- Chamberlain addressed two immense audiences here to-night, making the last speeches of his fiscal campaign for the present year.

We know not from what State of this Union the hand of the appointing power plucked Mr. FRANCIS B. LOOMIS to adorn the civil service of his country in the post of Assistant Secretary of State. We resolutely refuse to consult any reference book which might give that information.

W. Bourke Cockran will be nominated by Tammany Hall to succeed Mayor-elect George B. McClellan as the Representative from the Twelfth Congressional District, as soon as Mr. McClellan resigns his seat to undertake his duties as the municipal executive. That was determined yesterday afternoon at Mr. Cockran's office, where he met Charles F. Murphy and gave the Tammany Hall leader his consent to run.

BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- Convicted of maltreatment of soldiers on 1,520 counts and abuse of authority on 100 counts, an ex-Sergeant named Franzki, formerly of the Eighty-fifth Infantry, has been sentenced to five years' imprisonment and dishonorable discharge from the army by a court-martial at Rendsburg.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs to-night concluded its investigation of charges against Gen. Leonard Wood, filed for the purpose of preventing his confirmation as Major General.

MELBOURNE, Victoria, Dec. 16 -- The first of the Commonwealth general elections at which women exercised the right of suffrage was held to-day, with the result that all political calculations were upset.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Fire started in the Skillman Hardware Company factory this morning and despite the efforts of the Fire Department the building was gutted. While the firemen were fighting the flames there was a tremendous explosion in the cellar of the big fire truck and engine house, which is located in the centre of the town, at Willow and West Hanover Streets.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 16 -- William H. Rafford, a Deputy Sheriff and Warden of the County Jail, was shot and killed this morning by Tuthill Reeve, a farmer of Aquebogue, three miles from Riverhead. Reeve to-night is besieged in his home by Sheriff Preston and an armed posse, which does not dare approach within gunshot of the house.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The report of Mr. Conrad and Mr. Bonaparte on their examination of the Bristow report indorses that report generally, but non-concurs as to certain passages and recommends prompt publication of the report. It suggests that the Bristow report should note how gravely the statute of limitations has interfered with the punishment of notorious offenders exposed in the report, and suggests that the statute term be lengthened to at least five years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Evidence tending to show that a forgery was committed in the entry in the records of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, New York City, of the marriage of Baron August von Glahn and Mrs. Martha McCabe was produced in the County Court here to-day by David N. Carvalho, the New York handwriting, expert.

BERKELEY, Cal., Dec. 16 -- W.A. McKowen, Secretary of the Board of Regents of the State University, confessed to-day to President Benjamin Ide Wheeler that he was a defaulter to the amount of $20,000, and possibly more.

We know not from what State of this Union the hand of the appointing power plucked Mr. FRANCIS B. LOOMIS to adorn the civil service of his country in the post of Assistant Secretary of State. We resolutely refuse to consult any reference book which might give that information.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Findings that "deplorable and gravely discreditable abuses" existed in the Washington Post Office and the office of the First Assistant Postmaster General in 1898, 1899, and 1900, and that high officials of the Government -- even the Postmaster General -- were cognizant of them, are the contribution of Holmes Conrad and Charles J. Bonaparte to the postal scandal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Findings that "deplorable and gravely discreditable abuses" existed in the Washington Post Office and the office of the First Assistant Postmaster General in 1898, 1899, and 1900, and that high officials of the Government -- even the Postmaster General -- were cognizant of them, are the contribution of Holmes Conrad and Charles J. Bonaparte to the postal scandal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The full report of Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Bristow was made public to-day, with the exception of the exhibits, which are withheld because of the pending criminal cases. It reveals many new facts brought out by the months of investigation and not embodied in the official abstract made public a fortnight ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The report of Mr. Conrad and Mr. Bonaparte on their examination of the Bristow report indorses that report generally, but non-concurs as to certain passages and recommends prompt publication of the report. It suggests that the Bristow report should note how gravely the statute of limitations has interfered with the punishment of notorious offenders exposed in the report, and suggests that the statute term be lengthened to at least five years.
MANILA, Dec. 17 -- An agreement has been reached by Gov. Taft and the friars providing for the settlement of the friar "land question."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The full report of Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Bristow was made public to-day, with the exception of the exhibits, which are withheld because of the pending criminal cases. It reveals many new facts brought out by the months of investigation and not embodied in the official abstract made public a fortnight ago.

The situation is confused at best, because both parties to the contest are hot with passion, and because their pretensions are quite irreconcilable with each other.

Much difference of opinion exists in Wall Street both as to the outcome of the present consideration of the Northern Securities case by the Supreme Court and as to the effect upon the market should a decision be rendered against the company. Many are inclined to the belief that in its present form or in another the merger will stand, and that therefore an adverse decision will involve a technical rather than a real change.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- Justification of the revolution in Panama and the course of the United States Government in connection therewith were the purpose of a speech made before the Academy of Political and Social Science in Griffith Hall to-night by M. Bunau-Varilla, the Minister from Panama.

Charles Buck has sold the Hotel Brayton at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street, an eleven-story structure on lot 24.9 by 95, to Mrs. E.J. Smith, for about $250,000. Mrs. Smith gives in part payment a piece of property on Fulton Street, Brooklyn, Edward N. Crosby and W.M. Martin were the brokers in the transaction.

BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- In a running fight early this morning between five burglars who had broken into an office in East Boston and two policemen, one of the burglars was shot dead. The others escaped, but it is thought possible that some of them were wounded. The identity of the dead burglar is not known.

The Tokio correspondent of The London Times furnishes that journal with the first intelligible statement we have seen of the actual question between Russia and Korea directly, but indirectly and much more to the purpose between Russia and Japan.

COLON, Dec. 17. -- The United States cruiser Atlanta, Commander William H. Turner, returned here last night from the Gulf of Darien. She discovered on Dec. 15 a detachment of Colombian troops, numbering apparently about 500 men, but, according to their statements, totaling 1,500 or 2,000 men, at Titumati, on the western side of the gulf, just north of the mouth of the Atrato River and due east from Yaviza.

NEW ORLEAXS, Dec. 17. -- Huzzah and New York were the winning favorites today. The Stewards were dissatisfied with the performance of Bengal, favorite in the third race, and suspended C.B. Burnett Co., the owners, and Livingston, the jockey, pending an investigation. Weather clear; track fast.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt opened their series of state dinners for the present season this evening when they entertained in honor of the Cabinet.

Yesterday only eight properties reached a volume of 10,000 shares each. Seven of them declined, the maximum being 1 1/8 for Sugar. The only one to advance was the most active of them all, Steel, which advanced a fraction for the preferred and fell a fraction for the common. Business was a trifle larger than on the previous day, but only about one-half of the corresponding day last week.

The new Lyceum Theatre was turned into a fortress yesterday afternoon, with Daniel Frohman, J.W. Rumsey, and other officers of the theatre as defenders, and the Gerry Society agents and half a dozen policemen as besiegers. The cause of all the trouble was the choir of forty-two boys, who sing regularly at Calvary Church, and who were brought down to the Lyceum yesterday to assist in the illustrated lecture of Helen Rhodes on "Parsifal."
OMAHA, Dec. 17. -- The United States Grand Jury to-day made its report to the court, returning nineteen true bills, including an indictment against United States Senator Charles H. Dietrich.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 17. -- William B. Whitmore, who runs the Sturtevant House at Lawrence, drove to the court house to-day behind a fast horse in a light road wagon. He had a roll of bills in his pocket, and was prepared to pay out a portion of it as a fine. His money is now in the Sheriff's care, for Whitmore left here by train to spend a year in the penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day gave a hearing on its proposed requirement that after Jan. 1 the tariffs on export and import traffic be published and filed with the commission, the same as domestic tariffs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- The owners of American League baseball clubs at the annual meeting of the League, at the Auditorium Annex to-day, struck out the foul-strike rule from the playing rules, which was adopted last year as an experiment. The rule is as follows:

It was thought at first that on securing George W. Perkins as a witness in the shipbuilding inquiry the complainants would bring out the whole story of the part played by J.P. Morgan Co. in the formation and brief career of the shipyards combine, but the testimony given by Charles Steele yesterday showed that he and not Mr. Perkins was the Morgan partner who participated in all the negotiations of the banking firm.

The football team of the University of Michigan is almost certain to play on an Eastern gridiron next year. This information was given by T.H. Owens, Treasurer of the University of Michigan Club of this city, at the bi-monthly dinner of the club at the Hotel Albert, University Place and Eleventh Street, last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Debate on the Isthmian canal question to-day in the Senate brought forth three notable speeches which aroused remarkable interest in the Chamber and provoked widespread discussion after adjournment.

Two associations of manufacturers of steel products held meetings in this city yesterday. One of them was what is commonly known as the Steel Elate Pool. The members of this association held their meetings at the Holland House. They decided that in view of the slightly improved demand they would not come down 1 cent from the schedule approved in November.

Referring to the comment in these columns on the facts and figures gathered by the Merchants' Association relative to the unreasonable cost of condemnation proceedings in the matter of lands needed for purposes connected with the water supply of New York, our attention is called to the fact that the fault lies in the provisions of the statutes and not in the discretion of the Aqueduct Commissioners.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- The following are among those who have already accepted positions on Mr. Chamberlain's commission of experts which is to inquire into the condition of British trade and report thereon, with the object of drawing up a tariff reform measure:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- President Roosevelt signed the Cuban Reciprocity Treaty this afternoon, and issued his proclamation, in conformity with the act of Congress, proclaiming the convention between the United States and Cuba to be in effect on the tenth day from the date of its issuance.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- Dullness increased at the local Exchange to-day, sales falling to 13,501 shares and $51,100 bonds. Two-thirds of the trading were in five stocks, of which three were of the arbitrage class. Philadelphia Company and Consolidated Lake Superior common were the only other stocks which displayed any life.

BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- A denial of the charges made by Receiver Pepper of the Bay State Gas Company of Delaware against Henry H. Rogers of New York was filed to-day in the Supreme Judicial Court of the Commonwealth.

Attachment for $5,000 upon the property of Jacob F. Adler, the Jewish tragedian, and an injunction restraining him and his brother-in-lay, Jacob Newls, from further interference with the affairs of the Grand Theatre Company, lessees of the Grand Theatre, at Grand and Forsyth Streets, was secured yesterday from Justice Fitzgerald of the Supreme Court.

Seeking to remedy the congested conditions existing on its street surface lines, conditions which Thomas F. Ryan frankly admits to be "justly termed intolerable," the Metropolitan Street Railway interests have determined to enter the field of subway building, and yesterday that intention was officially laid before the Rapid Transit Commission.

There is but one right and safe course for the Administration in respect to the frauds and stealings in the Post Office Department, President GARFIELD'S order, "Cut the ulcer to the bone," given to the Attorney General when the prosecution of the Star Route thieves was undertaken, must be repeated now.

-- That there is content -- accent on the first syllable, please -- in a name was denied by Juliet, but she was a young thing, not very wise, even in her own remote day, and folks know better now and in New York, when and where names have enormous significance, especially in the lower end of the city and of checks.

Course of Prices. -- United States Steel preferred alone of yesterday's active stocks ended the day with a net gain. All the others showed losses amounting in some to more than a point, and the changes among the less active issues showed a sufficient preponderance of declines to mark the day as one of reaction.

Senator HOAR must really pardon the ladies of the Orange Political Study Club. He admonishes them that it is improper for them "to petition the Supreme Court, either to hasten judgment, or in regard to what judgment they should render in cases pending there." Of course, it is a gross solecism to hand up promiscuous public petitions to the court.

DUBOIS, Penn., Dec. 17. -- Four Italians were killed and two probably fatally injured by a dynamite explosion at Cramer, ten miles from here to-day. The men were blasting for the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Road. The dynamite was frozen, and when they attempted to thaw it the explosion followed, shaking the ground and buildings for nearly a mile.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- Money was fairly plentiful in the market to-day, though there were indications of a reduction in the supply. The demand was better, thus stiffening quotations. Discounts were somewhat harder.

The story of the battle of Manila Bay was related yesterday before Judge and jury in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court by a man who had fought with Dewey on the battleship Olympia, yet was on trial for his life on n charge of murder.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 17. -- Tuthill Reeve, the demented farmer who yesterday shot and killed Deputy Sheriff William H. Rafford, warden of the county jail, while the latter was trying to serve an execution for debt, surrendered this morning to Sheriff Preston after an all-night's siege and after he had been wounded with Bird shot.

John Steil, Chairman of the Registration Committee of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, has reinstated the Anchor Athletic Club basket ball team of Jersey City, which was suspended for having played a game with the Seventeenth Separate Company, team of Flushing, L.I.

That the Musical Art Society enters upon its eleventh season with a prestige greater than ever, and with manifestations of an undiminished interest on the part of its supporters and friends is something to make glad the hearts of music lovers. It has kept its standard steadily at the very high plane upon which it was started, and has made no concession to any assumed desires of a popular taste.

More than 500 bankers of New York laid aside the cares of business last night and assembled in the beautifully decorated ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria at the annual dinner of the Associated Banks of the City of New York, known as "Group VIII." of the New York State Bankers' Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Gov. Taft has informed the War Department that an agreement has been reached for the sale of the friar lands in the Philippines, there remaining only some small differences to be adjusted.

When the Aqueduct Commissioners resumed their hearing relating to the charge of faulty construction on the Jerome Park Reservoir yesterday William R. Hill, formerly chief engineer of the commission, was again placed on the stand.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Dec. 17. -- Enraged at the refusal of his chief to immediately restore him to duty from which he had been temporarily suspended for intoxication. Police Officer Gardner Northup tonight shot Chief of Police William F. Dinneen.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- Mayor Weaver vetoed the Loan bill for $16,000,000 today, and in a half hour after his message was received both branches of Councils, under the lash of the political leaders, passed the ordinance over the veto with only sixteen dissenting votes cast by Common Councilmen.
BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- Money market conditions are unchanged. Rates hold very firm and business is extremely dull, except in call money.

Trading in curb securities yesterday was moderately active, though the list was not as large as a number of days last week. The bond list resumed the narrowness of tone that characterized its movements during the Summer months, and only two smaller sales occurred. Buffalo Gas was one of the weakest stocks and sold off very easily.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The Second United States Cavalry will leave Fort Myer to-morrow morning for New York, where the regiment will embark on the transport Kilpatrick for the Philippines. The Kilpatrick is expected to sail on Saturday night or Sunday morning for Manila, via the Suez Canal.
HOMESTEAD, Penn., Dec. 17. -- Pupils attending parochial schools were debarred from the Charles M. Schwab manual training school last night by a vote of 10 to 3 at a meeting of the School Board.

Several decisions were handed down yesterday by the Board of United States General Appraisers. The one of most general interest was by Judge Henderson M. Somerville dismissing a protest by the Carriage Supply Company against the Surveyor at Cincinnati. The protest was accompanied by a statement by the Surveyor that the requirements of the law as to filing the protest had been complied with.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 18. -- The cotton market to-day, under stimulus of large supporting orders from the bull contingent and further covering on the part of shorts, together with a broadening amount of speculation all over the country, sold up to the highest point of the present season, with March and May in New York both above the 13 cent mark and to the highest point at this time of the year for twenty-two years.
Money on call on stock collateral loaned at 3@5 per cent., with the last loan at 3 per cent. Most of the day's loans were at 4@4 1/2 per cent.

Specifications of objections to the discharge in bankruptcy of Daniel Le Roy Dresser and Charles E. Reiss, who composed the firm of Dresser Co., commission merchants in hosiery, silks, and webbing at 15 Greene Street, were filed yesterday by two creditors, the First National Bank of Boston, $10,000, and the Cambridge Trust Company of Cambridge, Mass., $4,890.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18. -- Secretary Hester's weekly New Orleans Cotton Exchange statement, issued to-day, shows for the eighteen days of December an increase over last year of 170,000 bales. For the 109 days of the season that have elapsed the aggregate is ahead of the same days of last year 102,000.

INQUIRY at D. Appleton Co.'s has brought forth the fact that Herbert Spencer's autobiography will not appear until late Spring, possibly not until next September. The late philosopher took the same pains in setting right the story of his life that he did in revising his "system."
Two explosions of dynamite occurred in the Borough of the Bronx yesterday morning, and one man was killed.
Bishop Burgess of the Long Island Diocese, preaching at the noon services in St. Paul's Chapel yesterday, renewed his criticism and denunciation of the opera "Parsifal."

Folk who went from home last night, especially if they had been indoors for several hours, found a weather surprise awaiting them outside their front doors in the shape of a sudden drop in the mercury. Frequently they stopped on the doorsteps, shivered a moment, and went back for their ulsters.

Cotten futures for all the months from March to July, inclusive, crossed the thirteen-cent mark yesterday. It was expected that following the big rise on Thursday there would be a reaction yesterday, especially as the crop movement continued heavy, with the total amount brought into sight this year exceeding the last year's movement by 30,000 bales.
"J.T.W.," Brooklyn, N.Y.: "I have had recommended to me Prentice Mulford's works. Recently I was told that he committed suicide. Can you spare space to give a brief outline of his career?"
