NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18. -- Montebank and Sarah Maxim were the winning favorites to-day. Sadducee was well supported in his race. The suspension of C.E. Burnett Co., Jockey Livingston, and the horse Bengal has been raised. Livingston will, not, however, be permitted to ride Bengal in the future.

IT IS to be ignorant not to appreciate the physical power of Russia. Bear in mind that this is a State (homogeneous or not, that makes no difference) which has an area far greater in solid dominion than that built up by old Rome, and surpassed only by the Greater Britain of to-day.

JOHN BACH McMASTER, Professor of American History at the University of Pennsylvania, is reading the proofs for the sixth volume of his "History of the People of the United States," which, beginning publication in 1883, reaches its fifth volume three years ago.

A dinner was held last night in the Cafe Francis, 53 West Thirty-fifth Street, in honor of William De Leftwich Dodge, the artist who obtained an injunction from Justice McCall, in the Supreme Court, restraining the Tiffany Studios from interfering with or altering his paintings designed, for the Prince Edward Hotel, in Toronto, Canada.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- If the Democrats should succeed in defeating the Panama treaty by the application of the caucus rule Republican leaders say that other steps can be taken which will result in building the canal without much delay.

BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- Following close after the raid on counterfeiters at Revere, two weeks ago, the United States Secret Service agents arrested in Boston to-day two men, who, they say, are as dangerous a pair of counterfeiters as the Government has had to deal with for a long time.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 18. -- The ice boating season on the North Shrewsbury River was formally opened to-day by several yachts of the mosquito fleet. The ice is better than it has been for years. It is four inches thick, and there is a continuous ice yachting field from this place to Oceanic, a distance of four miles.

The three chapters on "The French Revolution," drawn from Lecky's "History of England During the Eighteenth Century," which D. Appleton Co. have announced for independent publication, will not appear until February. The volume is edited by Prof. Henry Eldridge Bourne of Western Reserve University, who also provides the historical notes and an introduction.
ROME, Dec. 18. -- According to the Tribuna the Vatican had sudden wealth poured into its coffers to-day.

MR. T. JENKINS HAINS, the writer of stories of the sea, the men who follow it for a livelihood, and the creatures who inhabit it, has just barely escaped death in a shipwreck. We heartily congratulate Mr. Hains both on his rescue and on the inevitable increase of public interest in his books which the incident will cause.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18. -- Gov. Charles B. Aycock of North Carolina made a profound impression here to-night, and made notable the first annual dinner of the North Carolina Society of Baltimore, when he propounded his solution of the negro problem.

James K. Hackett has found a new play. It is by George Broadhurst, and is called "The Crown Prince." Mr. Hackett will produce it at Springfield, Mass., Christmas Day. Miss Charlotte Walker will be the leading woman.

Lovers of Pepys and lovers of music ought to be equally interested in the little volume "Samuel Pepys, Lover of Musique," which Sir Frederick Bridge has written and Messrs, Scribner have imported. Lovers of both will be delighted. As the Englishman said, about the sheepshead, there is "fine confused feeding" in Pepys about a great many things.

Early in March the only extant portion of the original manuscript of John Milton's "Paradise Lost," eighteen pages, small quarto, comprising ,the First Book of the ode, will be sold at auction at Sotheby's, in London. It is not in Milton's autograph, of course, for when "Paradise Lost" was published the poet was blind.

"Washing Taken In Here," is the sentence on the outside of a washing list. These have linen covers, hand-painted, and this one shows a line of clothes and a goat "taking in," in large mouthfuls, one of the garments. He is half way down the line, and the progress he has made is shown by the tattered appearance of the pieces he has passed.

Daniel B. Freedman has bought 121 to 127 Manhattan Street, old buildings, on plot 100 by 75.3, at the north-west corner of Old Broadway, and extending to within 47 feet of Broadway. Mr. Freedman has also bought from the O'Brien estate 85 Manhattan Street, a four-story building, on lot 25 by 100.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Slavery still exists under the American flag, according to a communication made to the Interior Department by William A. Davis, Principal of the United States Public Schools at Unalaska, Alaska. He charges that in that territory little Aleutian girls are sold to well-to-do families as slaves.

The Bank Money Order Committee of the American Bankers' Association, which has been in session for three days at the New York National Exchange Bank, yesterday announced a plan in regard to money orders which will be submitted to the Executive Council of the association at its annual meeting next April.

It has long been a matter of speculative interest as to what disposition would eventually be made of the remarkable collection of books, manuscripts, and autographs formed by the late Bishop John F. Hurst of the Methodist Episcopal Church. He was for many years one of the most persistent book hunters in America.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day for holiday purposes, and the supply was diminished. Discounts, consequently, were firm.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18. -- The local ticker was silent long and frequent periods to-day, so dull was the trading. The Steels and Reading in the arbitrage group and the Consolidated Lake Superior stocks were alone active. The latter continued to be well taken, the preferred by a pool of insiders who are confident that the necessary financial relief will be forthcoming.

ALBANY, Dec. 18. -- An important aspect of city taxation is involved in the decision of the Court of Appeals banded down today affirming the judgment of the courts below in the case of the City of Rochester versus Kappell.

Notwithstanding the efforts of counsel for the United States Shipbuilding Company to prevent the introduction of papers showing transactions of the law firm of Alexander Green, the lawyer for the complainants, in the shipyard case, managed to disclose at yesterday's hearing the contents of some of the cable dispatches and letters sent from Paris in 1902 by Charles B. Alexander, then having the mission of making the French underwriters pay their obligations.
Copyright, 1903, by John R. Whitney. SUBJECT -- Review. David and Solomon. GOLDEN TEXT. -- The mercy of the Lord is from everlasting to everlasting upon them that fear Him. Psa., cill., 17.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The House today by resolution authorized the Committee of Expenditures of the Post Office Department to request the Postmaster General to furnish that committee with the papers in connection with the recent Post Office investigation.

The "Text-Book of Geology," for advanced students, by Profs. Thomas C. Chamberlin and Rollin D. Salisbury of the University of Chicago, will not be published by Henry Holt Co. until the first of the year. It will be in two volumes, and will be included in the American Science Series.

Water Register Robert A. Kelly summoned several of the Inspectors in the Water Department before him yesterday at his office, in the Park Row Building, and questioned them in regard to reports that had come to him to the effect that attempts had been made by Inspectors to blackmail business men.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Mrs. Roosevelt opened her season of afternoon receptions to-day when she gave a tea at 5 o'clock to the members of the Diplomatic Corps.

Detailed plans for the $100,000,000 additional water supply project for Greater New York, by which an increased supply of 500,000,000 gallons daily may be obtained by the year 1925, were submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment by the Burr-Hering-Freeman special commission, named more than a year ago by Mayor Low.

WITH Mr. Arthur Howard Noll's short history of Mexico some of us are acquainted. Readers with more leisure will welcome "From Empire to Republic," by the same author, which gives in detail the lone struggles for constitutional rights carried on by our sister republic.

The settlement of the vexed question of the friars' lands in the Philippines is in accordance with the ideas of Secretary ROOT and Gov. TAFT and adopted by the Administration some three years since. It is honorable to the United States Government, highly creditable to the authorities of the Church at Rome, and as nearly satisfactory to the friars as could be expected.

The zealous leaders of the American Protective League and the Home Market Club must regard Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S latest move with envious eyes. Never in their own palmiest days have they been invited by a statesman aiming at complete control of the Government to get up a tariff to suit themselves, with an implied promise that it would speedily be enacted.

THE new naturalists who approach the brute beasts rether as friends than scientists intent on classifications and cold zoological facts, are, at all events, vastly more entertaining to the laity than those others of the old school.
In the principal dimensions in which the new Williamsburg Bridge appears as a work of greater importance than the old Brooklyn Bridge the two structures compare as follows:

The Burlington Magazine for Connoisseurs does not compete with other monthlies. It never tries to be "first in the field." In fact, the November number has just been distributed in this country. But this periodical is worth waiting for. In this number an article on an exhibition of eighteenth century English portraits in Birmingham is illustrated with nine reproductions of paintings by Gainsborough, Hoppner, Raeburn, Reynolds, and Romney.

Henry Holt Co. report that the demand for "The Lightning Conductor," the automobile love story of a noble Englishman who stooped to conquer an American girl, continues. It has been sent to press for the fifteenth time. The same house has also sent to press for the third time Elizabeth Godfrey's love story of two wandering musicians.

THERE are two more of the small books for children in the size that they like. These are little volumes bound in cloth-covered boards, about five inches long by three wide. They are easy to handle, with many pictures and large print.

Thomas F. Ryan's statement, in behalf of the surface traction interests which he represents, that the Metropolitan Securities Company would like to enter the tunnel building field in this city, caused August Belmont to make a statement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Col. George B. McClellan denies that he has completed his slate. He will leave Washington tomorrow and will not come back. He is to attend the Grout dinner in the evening. After that he will remain in New York until the time comes for him to assume the duties of the Mayoralty.
[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Dec. 18. -- English readers have taken very kindly to Carl Snyder's "New Conceptions in the Science," first published in the United States, the author's home.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 18. -- The Dobbs Ferry police and those of this place and near-by villages are anxiously awaiting the return to consciousness of Otto Gilbert, who is in the hospital in Dobbs Ferry unable to tell what happened to him.

The London Academy has been asking prominent literary folks to name two books published this year which they have read with interest and pleasure. Austin Dobson responds with a characteristic note, which will strike a responsive chord in the bosoms or many who have a taste for the things Mr. Dobson writes and the books he reads:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The seventeenth annual report of the Inter-State Commerce Commission was transmitted to Congress yesterday. The report discusses various features of inter-State traffic and decisions rendered under the inter-State commerce law.

WE ARE greatly indebted to Miss or Mrs. Sara Welss, (or perhaps "Mr.," for contemporary authors seem to delight in confusing reviewers as to their sex,) for a great deal of interesting information in regard to the planet that we, in our ignorance, call Mars, the real name of which, bestowed presumably by its sponsors in baptism, is Ento.

The effect of opening stockholders meetings with prayer was discussed yesterday at a meeting of investors in the defunct Golden Rule Copper Company, held in the offices of Thomas Gilleran, 51 Chambers Street. About thirty stockholders were present, including four women. Of the one-million-dollar corporation, in which many church folk placed their money, it is alleged nothing is left but a twenty-flve-dollar roll-top desk and a number of ore specimens.

The new edition, of the late W. Robertson Smith's book on "Kinship arid Marriage in Early Arabia," edited by Stanley A. Cook, is being published in this country by the' Macmillan Company. The present volume contains many notes made by Prof. Smith before his death, which led to the conclusion that he intended to revise the first edition and bring out a new one.
ODD CRAFT. By W.W. Jacobs. One volume. Pp. 341. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $1.50.

AN accusation of "judicial murder" directed toward the Sultan of Turkey is a dire charge. The volume under notice, "The Life of Midhat Pasha," has for sub-title, "A Record of His Services. Political Reforms, Banishment, and Judicial Murder."

A fire which started on the first floor of a double brick dwelling house 54 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, at midnight, resulted in fatal injuries to Lieut. John Freel of Engine Company No. 109, and created much excitement and considerable suffering among the tenants.

IN HIS -- interesting book on "The Art of Cross- Examination," Francis L. Wellman, who was formerly an Assistant District Attorney for the County of New York, has taken the unusual course of permitting some other lawyer to begin his first chapter and to close his last.

BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- The local money market holds firm. Business is quiet and consists chiefly of renewals. Boston banks are carrying large New York balances, and in consequence the local supply is rather small. Call loans, 6@7 per cent.; time loans on collateral at 5@ 6 1/2 per cent.; time loans on mercantile paper, 6@ 6 1/2 per cent. Clearing House loans, 6 per cent.

Mr. Alfred Harmsworth of London has lately been prodding the British public to emotional and intellectual outbursts on the important subject of reading in bed. Mr. Harmsworth's widely circulated newspaper, The Daily Mail, began the business by urging its readers to express their opinions on the dangers and benefits of reading yourself to sleep.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Alden calls for the "Sherlock Holmes" written of by story writers before "Poe's day." He also rates our poet-ro-mancer's M. Dupin as the original of Gaborlau's Inspector Lecoq. I beg to differ from him in his further surmise that Dupin inspired Dickens for the portrait of Inspector Bucket.

HE actually belived in democracy is Prof. Dodd's final word on this North Carolina farmer-statesman. When Jefferson was President, Nathaniel Macon was SpeaKer of the House of Representatives, and his service in Congress extends uninterruptedly from 1791 to 1828.

The third part of the Howard T. Goodwin library, sold by Stan. V. Henkels Dec. 10-12 in Davis Harvey's auction rooms, Philadelphia, realized a total of about $18,200 for 426 lots. The total for the entire collection was $48,000, a sum which is said to be about one-fifth of the actual cost to Mr. Goodwin.

THE writers of historical fiction found Richard II. this year, and "Long Will" and "The Little Queen" made him a self-consistent figure, perhaps more true to Shakespeare than to history, but still very moving even in his ignorance of common humanity.

Character of Market. -- Business on the StocK Exchange yesterday lagged about as much as it had on the earlier days of the week. The exception of course was Steel preferred, but even with the very heavy sales of this stock the total for the day was not greatly in excess of those of Wednesday and Thursday.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 18. -- United States Commissioner Hall to-day gave his decision in the case of State Senator George E. Green of this city, charged with bribery and conspiracy to defraud the Government in connection with the sale of time recorders and canceling machines, holding the defendant on all five counts of the indictments for trial in the City of Washington, and placing the bail at $4,000 on each count.

Sir Leslie Stephen's Ford Lectures, delivered at Oxford, England, on "English Literature and Society in the Eighteenth Century," will appear in this country after the holidays. They will bear the imprint of G. P. Putnam's Sons. The book will, be uniform with the author's "Studies of a Biographer." In the opening chapter Sir Leslie Stephen speaks of the critic, the poet, the historian.

The British Columbia Copper Company has issued a circular to its stockholders, in which attention is called to the fact that at the last annual meeting the capital stock of the company was increased to 400,000 shares, with the object of acquiring additional mining properties, enlarging the smelting plant, providing a converting plant, and for other minor purposes.

Every point made by Senator HOAR in his speech, every argument, every ground of objection he set forth against the rough and lawless measures of the President upon the Isthmus of Panama, have been repeatedly presented in THE TIMES, in The Evening Post, and in other newspapers which have criticised the Administration policy.

Arrangements were completed yesterday for the celebration in connection with the Williamsburg Bridge "opening" to be held to-day, with Alderman Peter Holler and Mayor Low as the central figures, Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal and other dignitaries being placed a trifle to one side.

The following officers will report to the examining board appointed to meet at the Presidio of San Francisco for examination to determine their fitness for advancement: First Lieut. George P. Peed, Assistant Surgeon, and First Lieut. Henry D. Thomason, Assistant Surgeon.

Stocks higher. Call money easier, 3@5 per cent. Yesterday's stock market upon its surface was the reverse of Thursday's in tone. That is to say, the advance on Friday was not far from the fall on Thursday. But looking below the surface the market is seen to be of the same contracted, professional sort, with the only two rises worth mentioning in the stocks notoriously oversold.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- William E. Brockway, the counterfeiter, will complete a ten years' sentence in State prison here next Wednesday morning, and at that time, if he pays his fine of $1,000, he will come out of prison. He has all along declared his inability to pay, and may take the poor-convict oath.

PARIS, Dec. 19. -- A private letter received here from a leading American diplomatic official in Japan says that, while there are continued hopes of peace, the Government is making final preparations for the eventuality of war. Preparations in the various branches of the army and navy are proceeding with the utmost energy.
FOR the space of five minutes the tall girl nibbled the penholder. "I don't believe I'll say that," she decided presently. "It sounds too much like Mary Brennan."
LIVERPOOL, Dec. 19. -- The cotton market to-day opened 8 to 12 points higher, advancing on reports of shorts covering, December going to 7.09d. amid ironical cheering.

Shoe manufacturers are finishing up the Winter business and have also begun work upon the Spring and Summer orders. Several of the larger makers of shoes who were seen said that the coming season's orders are fully up to expectations, and they look for a busy and prosperous year.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It would seem that those whom the gods have first made mad are more than destroying themselves. They are making the Roosevelt election sure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire space in your columns to take exception to one or two points in your leader of this morning, in which you oppose the views expressed by Carroll D. Wright in his latest speech on wages, You state that no member of a labor union has a right to make a contract for himself.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The tariff reformers of England are emitting a vast amount of rhyme designed to aid the cause of fiscal reform. The newspapers teem with verses of the Fiscalitis order -- songs, parodies, nonsense, rhyme, and even productions of a serious order.

With the single exception of a large transaction on Thirty-fourth Street, near Fifth Avenue, details of which will be found below, last week's activities in the real estate market developed only an increased volume of business of the same sort that has prevailed since Oct. 1. About 75 per cent. of the dealing is still confined to the upper east side and Harlem.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19. -- Witful, the Crescent City Derby winner, added another stake -- the Crescent City Handicap -- to the Hildreth roll to-day. The event was worth $1,950 to the winner, and apart from being one of the principal stakes of the meeting it was notable for the masterly performance of Jockey Grover Cleveland Fuller, who made his initial appearance in the saddle at the meeting.

Did Edward VII., when he was Prince of Wales, ever wear a dress suit in the afternoon, and did he sanction this attire before sundown by appearing in it, as Mr. Higgenbothen did on the occasion of the visit of Princess Eulalie to Chicago?

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- What might have proved an accident costing many lives, was averted here to-day by the calmness and nerve displayed by Thomas McGovern, the engineer in charge of Train No. 916 of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, who, at the risk of losing his own life, deliberately brought about a head-on collision between his own locomotive and a "wild-cat" train of freight cars.

All careful observers agree that prices have been driven down entirely too low. The protraction of the liquidation so discouraged the market at large that the "bears" were allowed to get the upper hand, and they knocked down prices indiscriminately. That there must be a very considerable recovery from the present low levels is obvious.
Miss Ethel Ingram to Mr. Thomas Payson, New York:

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- The opening race of the season of the North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon. The ice was like glass in its smoothness, but the wind was light and variable, shifting from north to southeast. Many of the owners of the third-class yachts were unable to get their craft ready for the contests, and there were only four entries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Interesting information is contained in a report to the State Department by United States Consul Jackson, at La Rochelle, France, regarding Drouillard's drifter balloon float, an apparatus designed to carry from a vessel in distress to land, or the reverse, a rope by means of which the passengers and crew of the vessel can be rescued.

Mrs. Inez Hyland of 227 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street was taken from her residence to the Mercer Street Station yesterday and locked up on a charge of grand larceny involving jewelry said to be worth more than $16,000. The complainant against her is J.A. Fysh, an Englishman, who says he is a mining broker of 872 Broadway, and who lives at 70 West Forty-sixth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to call attention to the words used by Mr. William O'Brien, M.P., as reported in a cable dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES, reproduced by The Irish World of New York without comment.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 10. -- David Barnes, a farmer of Manhasset, who seems to be the chosen victim of electrical motors, was convicted of assault in the third degree before County Judge Seabury last night for resenting injury by one of them and fined $50.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 4. --The first performance of Ernest Chausson's "Roi Arthus," on Monday, was the most interesting premiere given at the Monnaic Opera since Vincent d'lndy's "Fervaal," six years ago. Two hundred persons, representing the elite of French intellectual, dramatic, and literary circles, journeyed to Brussels for the occasion.

PANAMA, Dec. 19. -- By means of gun boats Rear Admiral Glass is keeping in almost daily communication with the two American outposts on the Bay of San Miguel. One of these, composed of 100 marines and four fieldpieces, is well and comfortably located at Yaviza, and the other, numbering 100 and composed of marines and bluejackets, and which also has fieldpieces, is stationed at Real Santa Maria, ten miles from Yaviza.

The National Academy of Design will show its annual collection of paintings during January in the American Fine Arts, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The Inness Gold Medal and the Thomas R. Proctor Prize of $200 will be awarded. Three Hallgarten prizes of $300, $200, and $100, and the Thomas B. Clarke Prize of $300, which have been decreed for many years, will not be lacking.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The concert of the Yale Glee Club at the new Willard Hall to-night was made the occasion of much entertaining among the young people of resident Society.

IT WAS Christmas Day. In the waning twilight, Mr. Robert Ferris sat before a bright fire in his comfortable library. His usually serene countenance wore an expression of gloom and he restlessly tapped the arm of the chair in which he was seated with the paper knife he had intended to use to disclose the contents of a favorite magazine.

The letter of Mr. GEORGE WESTINGHOUSE to The Evening Post under date of Dec. 14 makes some suggestions which do not appear to have been well considered. The fact that the Pennsylvania Railroad Company is considering the advantages of the overhead conductor is interesting.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The Queen has this week been making her Christmas purchases. She does not buy her gifts like an ordinary woman, who takes a hansom or four-wheeler and drives about town, stopping here and there to rummage among the beautiful and useful things with which the shops are filled.
THERE are red-letter days in every life. Days on which some event has left a mark so decided that they stand out sharply, needing no effort of memory to recall them from the past.

Brokers and trading companies engaged in the exportation of cotton fabrics have matched with apprehension the unusual condition of the raw cotton, market and the results felt by the spinners and weavers. The export business, which was at flood tide a year ago, has receded until it is now at the lowest ebb in a long time.

When the last curtain descends at the Belasco nowadays some of those in the audience may be seen groping dreamily on the floor for overshoes that are not there; and as the departing playgoers reach the outer lobby others may be heard absently lamenting forgotten umbrellas.

It may be doubted whether any week this year left the price averages so little altered by its events as last week. Yet the week was not without incidents affecting values as well as prices. The decision of the several branches of the steel trader to maintain their schedules, and the strong movement upward of cotton to the highest prices for over twenty years would alone distinguish the week.
JAMES, "said Gerry Talbot suddenly, looking up from the telegram he had just received, "you needn't mind about the rest. The dinner will not come off after all."

Recent changes in financial and industrial conditions which have altered so much the appearance of the stock market and practically forced the managers of corporations to adjust themselves to a new condition of things are regarded in some quarters not as the advent of a period of depression, but merely as a return from abnormal to normal business activity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The present week at the White House will be given over very largely to preparations for Christinas, when all the Roosevelt children will be at home for the first time since last Spring, the two boys, Theodore, Jr., and Kermit, having already arrived from Groton, where they are at school.
ABILENE, Kan., Dec. 19. -- It is estimated that 3,000,000 bushels of wheat are piled on the prairies of Western Kansas under the open sky, awaiting cars for shipment to market.

THE display of jewels the past week at the Metropolitan Opera House has been most lavish. Mrs. John R. Drerel made her first appearance on Monday evening with her famous diamonds and turonoises. Mrs. Gould wore her pearls and a very odd diamond ornament in her hair.

Complaints which have been current in the pottery trade for many months of alleged undervaluation of pottery by certain importers culminated early this month in the open charge at the annual convention of the National Potters' Association in Washington that systematic undervaluation was being practiced by certain importers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- President Roosevelt to-day transmitted to the House the third instalment of papers relating to the recent events on the Isthmus. The papers consist of 120 letters and telegrams exchanged between Secretary Hay and Minister Beaupre, at Bogota, from March until November.
PARIS, Dec. 19. -- The weather during the week has been so foggy as to suggest London on a fine day.

To-night's concert at the Metropolitan Opera House will be under the direction of Mr. Arturo Vigna. The soloists will be Mme. Louise Homer. Miss Marion Weed, Mr. Pol Plancon, and Mr. Guardabassi. The "Danza delle Ondine," from Catalani's "Loreley," and the scherzo "La Poule" will be repeated by request.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 19. -- At the regular Saturday golf handicap of the Country Club to-day ten cards were returned. Lloyd Davison and F.A. Potts tied for the new score prize, both scoring 79 strokes. The gross score prize went to Lloyd Davison, who scored 87. The summary:

College men are already beginning to discuss with a great deal of interest the possibilities of the football rules of next season, in view of the changes in the game as disclosed by the new gridiron rules that went into effect last Fall. It is commonly believed by those who know that there will be many more changes in the regulations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Gen. John C. Black has accepted the offer of the Civil Service Commissionership, and the President will send in his nomination when Congress reconvenes Jan. 4.
BANGOR, Me., Dec. 19. -- The State Grange of Maine is threatening a "political revolution" for the Pine Tree State, and declares it is able to bring it about.

The new bridge received its baptism of fire in the evening, and the attending ceremonies, although not entirely flawless as to the work of the electrical decorators, furnished one of the most gorgeous and impressive marine spectacles ever witnessed in the Harbor of New York.

THAT "All the world loves a lover" is one of the facts which writers of plays, though they may be lacking in many of the other essential qualifications for successful effort, must certainly realize in a degree before they can expect to arouse any sort of interest on the part of those upon whom they depend for support and encouragement.

United States Vice Consul E.E. Osgood of Calcutta, India, in a recent communication, says that while there is an enormous business in piece goods in that country, yet it is almost entirely in the hands of the English and Germans. The few American cotton goods that reach there find their way through English commission houses. A New York representative of a large cotton print interest said:

As to holiday markets and January rises, precedent counts for little. Records are highly interesting, but not very valuable as a basis for expectations. Their teaching is that expectation must have a more substantial basis than the facts which have gone before and have been used up at the time of their appearance.

HAVE you a department store education? If you have, you needn't put on airs in the presence of clerks and cash girls; they can spot that species of culture every time. At any rate, a nice-looking girl in the fur department of a Sixth Avenue shop says they can.

A sharp clash between Charles L. Eidlitz, President of the New York Building Employers' Association, and John Mitchell, President of the United Mine Workers of America, marked the dinner given in the small concert hall at Madison Square Garden last night by the New York Civic Federation to the Executive Committee of the National Civic Federation.

BOSTON, Dec. 19. -- Charles Frohman telegraphed Manager Rich to-day that on Jan. 4 he would produce here a new romantite comedy in four acts by Gladys Unger, entitled "Richard Brinsley Sheridan." William Faversham is to have the title part, and Hilda Spong will head the supporting company.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19. -- Representatives of three nations, possessors at different times of the territory which Napoleon ceded to Jefferson, joined hands to-day with the people of Louisiana in the second day's celebration of the centennial of the transfer.

Laighton Foulke, members of the New York Cotton Exchange and of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange, announced their suspension yesterday, because their solvency had become doubtful through the defalcations of a trusted employe. The man who is considered responsible by the firm is John H. Laing, thirty-two years old, of 624 East One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street.

PARIS, Dec. 19. -- About midnight to-night a miserably clad man fired two shots from a revolver at Max Nordau, the litterateur and Vice President of the Congress of Zionists, at a Zionist ball at the Salle Charras.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 19. -- The Directors of the Hampden Trust Company voted this morning that, in their opinion, the bank was not in a position to continue its business, and that notice should be sent to the Savings Bank Commissioners of its condition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the unprecedented condition of the cotton market, and an almost absolute unanimity of opinion concerning the future course of prices, a few words showing the reverse of the medal may not be uninteresting. The present range of values is predicated on a crop of about 10,250,000, and a consumption in excess of these figures.

We were pointing out yesterday some of the improvements which made the Williamsburg Bridge an advance upon the older East River Bridge as an achievement of engineering. It would be gratifying to find a similar advance in it considered as a monument, as a public work worthy, as a work of art, of its great conspicuousness.
WHY will she say them not, the words I crave -- That she is mine? I am her abject slave. To apprehend each wish, ere words express

BOSTON, Dec. 19. -- The money-market remains quiet and firm, though the, tone is a shade easier than it was a week ago. Call loans, 6@6 1/2 per cent. Time loans, collateral, 5@6 1/2 per cent. Time loans, mercantile paper, 6@7 per cent. Clearing House loans, 6 per cent. New York funds, par @ 5c, premium.

THIS promises to be emphatically a fur season. People donned furs unusually early, or during the first "cold snap," and have not since ceased wearing them, even during the numerous warm days that have intervened. This craze for fur is carried into hats and the trimmings of gowns to a much greater extent than last Winter, and there is no question as to its universal becomingness.

Notwithstanding the fact that the arguing of the Northern Securities case before the Supreme Court last week excited immense interest outside of Wall Street, most of the criticism and comment on the arguments of both the prosecution and the defense have emanated from that locality, and while various positions on the case have been taken by various writers, nearly all the articles on the subject have been from a Wall Street point of view.

CLUBMEN are bringine out books in quite a rapid manner. Walter Winans of London has resurrected a religious work of his grandfather, the late Ross Winans, and is issuing it in a new edition, and Henry P. Toler, whose plans for the taking of Harlem by the original Dutch and French settlers' descendants did not gain the approval of Mrs. Mary Baker Eddy, is out with another book on Christian Science.

There is usually but little doing socially Christmas week. It is a time consecrated to the home and to family meetings and to house parties. More and more are New Yorkers spending the holidays on their country estates. Great preparations are being made by the Vanderbilts at Newport for the celebration of the festival among the farm hands on the property owned the younger members of the family.

-- In reflecting upon the curious fact that the late Cardinal HERRERA left or is said to have left, $10,000 to be paid to the first Spanish General who lands on United States territory an army strong enough to avenge the Spanish defeats in Cuba and the Philippines, one's first impulse is to congratulate the Spanish bank in which the $10,000 is to remain until the avenging is done.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- A strip of land 300 feet in width and 10 1/2 miles in length extending across the northeastern section of the city in a course resembling the contour of a grayhound's hind leg, and known as the Torresdale Boulevard, is the main contention between Mayor Weaver and the Republican city organization.

ROME, Dec. 19. -- The statement of The Tribuna yesterday that Cardinal Gotti, Prefect of the Propaganda, had handed Pope Pius X. $9,000,000 in banknotes, said to have been confided to Cardinal Gotti by Pope Leo XIII., with instructions to turn the money over to his successor after a period of four months had elapsed, was denied to-day at the Vatican.

George A. Cormack, Secretary of the New York Yacht Club, when asked last night if a letter had been received from Sir Thomas Lipton concerning another challenge for the America's Cup, replied that a letter had been received, but that it contained nothing about a challenge, and that its contents would not be made public until it had been laid before a meeting of the club.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Senator William B. Allison of Iowa spoke before the Bankers' Club of this city to-night upon "Our Currency System and Our National Finances."

THURSDAY, DEC. 24. -- By Peter F. Meyer, foreclosure sale, Joseph M. Schenck, referee, King's Bridge Road, east side, 50.4 feet south of One Hundred and Eighty-fourth Street, 25.2 by 96.3, four-story brick flat. Due on Judgment, $2,258.

To the Editor of The New York Times: All Americans, irrespective of political parties, want to think well of National official representatives, whether members of the House of Representatives, or Senate, or the President.

This years' indoor football tournament in the Madison Square Garden was closed yesterday with a double session, two games being played in the afternoon and three at night. There were many enthusiasts in the big building on both occasions, but the attendance fell far below the standard which the contests deserved.
HE placed the money in the little thin hand she held up high over her shawl-coveered head. He smiled at her, she had to make such a stretch for the coin.
HAVANA, Dec. 11. -- In Havana and throughout Cuba one is often reminded of the air in the "Bohemian Girl," "I dreamt that I dwelt in marble halls." But here the dream is a reality.

We urge all Northern men to weigh candidly and carefully the statement of GOV. AYCOCK of North Carolina as to the way in which he thinks the "negro problem" has been "solved" in his State, and can be solved in other States. There is an element in it that will offend many in the North.

HANOVER, Germany, Dec. 19. -- Emperor William attended to-day the one hundredth anniversary of the formation of the former Hanoverian regiments, and ordered that a jubilee medal be struck in commemoration of the event.
John M. Whitton Co. of this city have been appointed New England agents of the Concordia Fire Insurance Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad awarded to the Thompson-Starrett Company of New York the general contract for the erection of the new union station in Washington, which is to cost $4,000,000, and is to be the handsomest and most expensive railroad station in the world devoted exclusively to terminal business.

The declaration of the management of the Interurban system of its readiness and purpose to compete for the construction and operation of such new north and south rapid transit subways as may be built is not calculated to excite any popular apprehension that the municipal interests are jeopardized thereby.

The new hockey team of the New York Athletic Club made a poor showing last night at the St. Nicholas Rink against the Yale seven, which was defeated two weeks ago by the Hockey Club of New York by a score of 18 goals to 1. The best that the wearers of the winged foot could do was to make a draw by a score of 3 goals to 3.

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- Emperor William, it is said, has issued a secret order to the higher officers of the German Army with regard to the recently published book of Lieut. Bilse, "The Little Garrison," describing conditions the writer claims existed at the Forbach garrison.

The statements of recent travelers across Manchuria that the Russian railway is worked to its utmost capacity for the conveyance of Russian troops eastward have been accompanied by concurrent statements that Russia is dispatching all her available naval force to the Asiatic coast of the North Pacific.

United States General Appraiser Hay yesterday Overruled a protest by Platt Co. of Minneapolis on the assessment of 30 per cent, duty on an importation of fresh frozen smelts as "fish in packages containing less than half a barrel." The importers claimed that the fish were of the herring family and were therefore entitled to classification as herrings at a quarter of a cent a pound.

The attitude of investors and speculators is as changeable as the winds. Time was when a railroad bond issue was signal for a stock boom. More recently the mere suggestion of even the smallest bond sale was enough to precipitate a sharp slump. Most fresh in memory is the violent break in Atchison stock in August last, under the accompaniment of bond-issue rumors and discredited denials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The House was in session twenty-seven minutes to-day, but before it adjourned it passed a Democratic resolution. Incidentally, it nullified the victory won yesterday by Mr. Wanger of Pennsylvania and left that gentleman outside the breastworks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19. -- Lord Melbourne to-day gained his fourth victory within a week, when he beat Claude a neck in the $1,000 handicap at Ingleside. The event was the main attraction, and a field of eight went to the post, with Claude favorite. He led until the stretch was reached, when Lord Melbourne caught him.

An invention, for which the bold assertion is made that it marks as great a step in advance of present methods of printing as the linotype was an advance over the old method of hand composition, has been tested at the works of the Sackett Wilhelms Lithographing and Printing Company, at Grand Street and Morgan Avenue, Brooklyn.

The committee of the newly organized National Amateur Billiard Association is actively engaged in preparing for the coming National championship series of matches that will be held at the Liederkranz Club. Weekly meetings of the committee are rapidly bringing the business of the championship to a focus and making sure of the number and quality of the men who will compete for the honors and the gold cup.

A runaway horse drawing a newspaper delivery wagon plunged into the thickest of the crowd of Christmas shoppers in Herald Square yesterday afternoon, killing one woman and injuring two other persons so seriously as to necessitate their removal to the New York Hospital. There were others who were hurt, but so slightly that they went away without revealing their names.

At last, after months of delay, the old Trinity building is to be razed and a new structure is to rise in its place. This announcement, which has been awaited ever since the United States Realty and Construction Company's connection with the property became known, carries with it a. project of great interest for all those whose business calls them to the lower Broadway district.

From the multitudinous details of the story of Parzival, and Perceval, and the Knights of the Grail, as handed down to us by Wolfram von Eschenbach and Chretien de Troyes; Wagner has disentangled a few characters, a few incidents, upon which to base his music drama of "Parsifal."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 18. -- Morristown is to have a new country club. The organization is already formed under the name of the Whippany River Country Club, with Benjamin Nicoll, President; Robert H. McCurdy, Vice President, and Walter Kemeys Treasurer. The club has taken a five years' lease of the Higgins property on Emmett Avenue, and work is already begun in fitting up the place.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Canon Hensley Henson, preaching to a large congregation in Westminster Abbey, chose for his text, "Take heed and keep yourselves from all covetousness; for a man's life consisteth not in the attendance of the things which he possesseth."

KOBE, Nov. 20. -- Once again the Jap has taken his self-styled superior from the West into camp, and proved that there are more things in tent and field than are dreamed of in his philosophy. The Autumn manoeuvres did this, and they opened wide the eyes of the onlookers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After a few weeks' absence from home, I discovered last Sunday that two overcoats left hanging in a coat closet at my residence had disappeared. After some discussion with my family, we decided that the negro man employed to care for the furnace was the thief.

The steamship Lucania of the Cunard Line made her way up the bay yesterday morning on her arrival from Liverpool will hulk, superstructure, and spars coated with a heavy layer of ice. Her resemblance to the "Flying Dutchman" was relieved only by her two great red funnels.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest your editorial in today's issue commenting on Carroll D. Wright's late speech in Philadelphia on the labor problem, but like most of your editorial utterances on economic questions, you appear to have viewed the subject mainly from the capitalist standpoint.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 19. -- Incidental to its work of fostering the commerce of two oceans and the Gulf and the great lakes the United States Government is the heaviest contractor in the dredge business.

Mayor-elect George B. McClellan returned from Washington yesterday afternoon and will remain in New York from now until the close of his administration, of city affairs. His resignation as a member of Congress will be forwarded to Gov. Odell at Albany to-day and will take effect immediately on its receipt to-morrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- A firmer tone characterized the local trading to-day, and some of the inactive stocks advanced sharply, Minehill rising 3/4, Philadelphia Traction 1, Philadelphia Company 1, United Gas 7/8, American Railways 7/8, Cambria Iron 1/2, and Lehigh Navigation 1/2. An Investment demand, coupled with a scarcity of stock, was the cause of the advance.

As usual, Christmas week promises to be a dull one from the viewpoint of theatre-goers. There is not a single important opening, if one excepts the beginning of the English grand opera season in Harlem, which is not a dramatic so much as a musical event. Next week will be much more lively, and several new plays will have their first appearance in New York.

Tong Chew, a young Chinese reformer from one of the first families in the Flowery Kingdom, arrived in New York yesterday to fill the position of editor in chief of a new Chinese newspaper soon to be started here. He came from Yokohama, Japan, by way of San Francisco, and was greeted by the most distinguished of his countrymen in this city.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Money was in fair demand in the market to-day, and borrowers were increasingly dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were slightly harder.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As to "Courteous Girls in Cars," I wish to give you a few of my own ideas and observations. Undoubtedly some of your feminine readers will coincide with my views.

Historians of the Williamsburg Bridge will find many striking parallels in the incidents attending its construction and those which marked the progress of the work on the Brooklyn Bridge. Like problems were met and solved by the engineers, and fires seriously interfered with the operations on each.

If there was one feature of the vaudeville bill at Proctor's Twenty-third Street Theatre last week that impressed itself more strongly than another it was the exceptional excellence and interest of its acrobatic features. And, peculiarly enough, though one ordinarily associates extraordinary ability in gymnastics with male performers, in both of the turns especially successful at Proctor's last week the chief performers were women.

SANTO DOMINGO, Republic of Santo Domingo, Dec. 17. -- Gen. Pimentel has raised a force against the Provisional Government at Haina, near this city. Arrests are being made, and many persons have left the city to join the rebels. The city otherwise is quiet. The Provisional Government is taking all the precautions possible.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having read the editorial, "How it Would Work," concerning the action of the Union League Club toward advancing the true interests of the negroes in the South, I cannot but hold adverse views to those stated in THE TIMES on the subject.

Within twenty-five years the candy industry has increased from almost nothing to about $150,000,000 a year. A quarter of a century ago there was not an exclusive candy manufacturer in a large way of business. The candy manufacturers of those days usually made crackers or similar sweetmeats, together with cigars and other goods of that character.

Stockholders of the American Ice Company received last Monday the report of the Stockholders' Committee to the shareholders of the company. Doubtless few people knew that such a committee existed, and many who saw the twenty-three-page report probably passed it by without reading it.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 19. -- While returning to his home in this city a few evenings ago William Blackman saw a long, dark object tossed ashore by the waves on the beach at Ventnor. On examination he discovered it to be a species of sea serpent about 15 feet in length, and with a head 12 inches from ear to ear.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Undertakers' wagons and street cars were used to convey the dead to the cemeteries to-day. In nearly every instance the funerals were watched by union pickets, who were there to see that no livery carriages formed a part of the funeral procession.

Admiral SCHLEY made a suggestive Remark the other day in Cincinnati when he spoke of the great unlikelihood of future wars lasting long. The speculation is trite enough, but the Admiral's reason for his belief is newer. Most observers have concluded that future wars would be quicker than past wars because the first battle will be more apt to be destructive and so more decisive.

ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- In the State departments in the Capitol, the State Hall, and the State Museum the personnel has changed greatly in the past few years. Gradually, but surely, the number of woman clerks has increased, and complaint is heard frequently because some of the women get salaries larger than some of the men in the same department.

Muschenheim Castle, the home of William Muschenheim at One Hundred and Ninety-fifth Street and Fort Washington Road, one of the most beautiful residences along the banks of the Hudson River, was destroyed by fire, with its valuable collection of paintings and bric-a-brac, early yesterday morning.

Amid the thunder of cannon and the cheers of a vast multitude of enthusiastic people assembled from all parts of the greater city and its suburbs, while a huge American flag was unfurled on each of the towers, Mayor Low, at 2:43 o'clock yesterday afternoon, pronounced the new Williamsburg Bridge open to public use.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Holiday visitors are crowding into Lakewood in great numbers, and present indications are that the resort will be crowded over Christmas and New Year's. The leading hotels will be filled with patrons, and nearly all the cottagers are planning to entertain parties during Christmas week.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 19. -- An entirely new idea in American foreign mission work is behind the venture which an association of well-known Yale alumni has just planned for China.

Compared with the crop of industrial concerns launched on what may tie called the last movement, covering the period from 1899 to 1902, those making their appearance on the movement preceding, which terminated with the 1893 panic, made a very poor showing numerically. As to capitalization and many other features it of course was an inferior one, and inferior still the record for any earlier period.
DETROIT, Dec. 19. -- John Kernell, the veteran Irish comedian, died to-day at Grace Hospital. He had been suffering from acute nephritis for a week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Dr. Edward Bedloe, who has returned from Japan, where he investigated the silk culture with special reference to its introduction and propagation in the United States, says:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- "Let Colombians take the initiative," is the restraining keynote of specific instructions which Secretary Moody has cabled to the American naval commanders in Isthmian waters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Navy Department to-day received a cablegram from Rear Admiral Glass, commanding the naval forces on the Isthmus, giving a general summary of the Conditions that prevail there and of the various steps that have been taken by the navy.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- British newspapers take all sorts of liberties with Mr. Bryan's initials. They call him J.W. Bryan, J.H. Bryan, and even H.J. Bryan. Once in a while he appears in print with his own initials, but it is charitable to assume that this comes through accidental exactitude.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 9th inst. the editor of "Topics of the Times" made some comments upon certain remarks of mine made in the presence of the National Indian Association at its annual meeting on the evening of the 6th inst. Your journal has kindly given space to correspondents who have made replies.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The Times's Russian correspondents say further details are available in regard to the reports from the Governors of provinces in which Jews are allowed to reside.

In a desperate battle with revolvers last night between the police of the Oak Street Station and five men who had entered the offices of Isaac A. Sheppard Co., in the four-story building at Peck Slip and Pearl Street, and had blown open the big safe there, securing one of the strong boxes, two men were shot, although neither was dangerously wounded.

Regardless of the weather, thousands of persons crossed, or attempted to cross, the new Williamsburg Bridge yesterday, the great majority of the pedestrians being the small boys and girls of the east side. They made it a gala occasion.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- A law passed by the National Assembly in 1851, and unaltered at any subsequent date in essentials, provides that the beautiful products of the State porcelain factory of Sevres and of the tapestry works of Gobelins and Beauyais may be used for diplomatic presents, charitable works, and rewards to persons who have been of use to the State, as also for the encouragement of arts, sciences, trade, and agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The letter of Secretary Root to Senator Proctor, Acting Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs, dated Nov. 18 last, giving a resume of the military record of Gen. Leonard Wood and stating the chief considerations which led to his nomination as a Major General, was made public to-day.

A "Jack the Ripper" murder was committed in the Cherry Hill district yesterday, and the perpetrator escaped. Late last night the detectives obtained an identification of the victim as Sarah Martin, well known for fifteen years in the part of the city in which she met her death. She was married and her husband's name is Martin Larson, a deep sea sailor.

If one sees a handsome pen handle or pencil made apparently of gold it is not safe to take it for granted, for it Is quite as likely to be of brass. The baser metals are having their innings, and if one has a brass desk set, it is a pretty idea to have the smaller things to match. That has been seen in gun metal, but not so much in the brighter material.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The shifting of the 985-ton double-decked draw span of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad over the Passaic River was accomplished to-day, and trains were operated over the new elevated structure tonight. All traffic over the bridge was temporarily suspended, the last train to use the Broad Street Station having passed over the bridge at 2 o'clock this morning.

"The Maccabean Rebellion," a religious drama in four acts, was rendered by the children of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday afternoon in the presence of a large gathering of members and friends of the institution.

The business upon the Stock Exchange last week was unusually concentrated. Twelve stocks contributed 2,177,486 shares to the total sales of 2,630,640 shares. If the market were natural the twelve stocks ought to include at least one decline, for assuredly there always will be declines, just as there were declines among the half million shares distributed throughout the list, except the leading twelve.

The second annual report of the Philippine Civil Service Board to the Governor of the Philippine Islands, embracing the period from Oct. 1, 1901, to Oct. 1, 1902, shows a decided increase in the number and kinds of examinations held, due to appointments resulting from promotions and the extension of the civil service law to the provincial service, the police force, the firemen in Manila, and the prison guards.

SAN JUAN, Dec. 20 -- The Cuban steamer Julia, from Santo Domingo and Haiti, arrived here to-day, having on board Senor Espaillat, ex-Minister of War of Santo Domingo; Commander Perez of the Dominican Army, Capt. Seirra, Col. Espaillat, and other supporters of ex-President Wos y Gil.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of late the agitation regarding the dangers of the "third rail" for elevated and surface transportation has called forth many opinions from the press, some of which are wise and otherwise. As is well known, the current to the car motors is furnished over a "third rail" and returned by the two "traffic rails."

Alexander Hass, who was arrested by the Post Office Inspectors in this city four months ago, charged with rifling the foreign mails, shot and killed himself last evening while standing under a tree at the corner of One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street and Broadway, in front of the Montefiore Home.

The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst preached yesterday morning in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church from the text, "And the Word was made flesh and dwelt among us." In the course of a plea for a fuller recognition of the divinity of Christ he said:

Although it is the custom for most of the athletic clubs in Greater New York to hold cross-country or road runs every Sunday during the Winter season, the weather was so inclement yesterday that none but the Mohawk Athletic Club of the Bronx had the temerity of sending out some of their distance men.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 -- Under the sunny skies to-day the Stars and Stripes rose gracefully to the top of the tall staff in the historic Place d'Armes, amid the ringing of cathedral bells, the roar of cannon, and the shouts of the spectators, and the centennial celebration of the Louisiana transfer ended in a burst of patriotism.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Patrick B. Delany, the electrical engineer who invented the multiplex telegraph system, by which six messages can be telegraphed over a single wire at the same time, says that his latest invention, the automatic machine telegraph, has been perfected.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The members of the Senate of the United States, save the aged and peculiar old man whose attitude in the Philippine and Panama difficulties indicate to many that he loves his own opinion better than his country, will be much astonished if they familiarize themselves with the utterances, violent and vituperative in language, which Dr. Hale has made about eminent public persons.

In the hope that another international handball championship contest may take place within the next four months, negotiations are in progress between the representatives of "Mike" Egan of Jersey City, who has earned and defended the title of champion, and William Herlihy, Jr., of Cork, Ireland, the latest aspirant to the honor.

Are we actually at war with Colombia? If a state of war does not exist, the dispatches from Washington are unintelligible. High officers of the Navy Department were in consultation on Friday, and the conclusion was reached that "if present conditions on the Isthmus of Panama continued" we must send reinforcements.

Expert accountants were busy all yesterday examining the books of Laighton Foulke, the suspended cotton brokerage firm, to ascertain the extent of the firm's losses. Both Mr. Laighton and Mr. Foulke went to their offices at 3 William Street at an early hour and remained till late in the day.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- Maitre Labori, the eminent and courageous barrister, will be in no way connected with the pending reopening of the Dreyfus case. It is understood that the Dreyfus family, acting on the advice of Joseph Reinach, will engage the exclusive services of Maitre Demange

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- The Rev. Dr. William T. Manning of New York, in a sermon to the Pennsylvania Society, Sons of the Revolution, in old St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, where the anniversary of Valley Forge was celebrated to-day, severly censured the apathy shown by respectable people regarding the evils of political conditions.

CHICAGO, Dec, 20 -- "The New World was discovered by Catholics and the Cross was planted in the name of the Church. We cannot get it out of our heads that Catholics will yet claim the New World again."

OTTAWA, Dec. 20 -- It is understood, although nothing official can be obtained, that the Dominion Government has now under consideration the question of annexing Newfoundland and Greenland to Canada. The decision of the Alaska Boundary Commission has not only set the Government thinking but working.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- A rather striking effect of the tariff reform agitation is the determination of the London County Council to revise its policy in regard to the equipment of tram lines, and, instead of ordering rails from Belgium, from which country the lowest bid came, it will buy from a British firm.

The "general jollification" in Memphis and other centres of raw cotton speculation over the fact that the staple has responded to large supporting orders from the bull contingent and heavy covering purchases from the shorts, and reached the highest price attained at this date in something over twenty years, shows how the judgment is shaped by the point of view.

As the result of a church case of considerable perplexity in Utica it is learned that there survives in that cultured and urbane municipality, its pinnacles yet glowing like weathercocks after sunset with memories of the inflammable ROSCOE CONKLING, a doctor of medicine who believes that a powder composed of ipecac, opium, and potash will cure dyspepsia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Commerce between Canada and the United States shows a rapid gain, both in the figures of the year about to end and those of the decennial period which ends with the present year. The year's commerce with Canada, as shown by the figures of the Bureau of Statistics, will aggregate nearly $200,000,000, against less than $100,000,000 in 1893.

PEKING, Dec. 20 -- The report cabled from Tien-Tsin to London yesterday to the effect that Japan had sent an ultimatum to Russia is discredited here, and no information of a corroborative nature is in the possession of the legations.

Owen Ziegler, formerly a lightweight pugilist, was the complainant last evening against Pauline Cooper, sixteen years old, who said her home was at 708 North Second Street. Philadelphia, and who was locked in the West Thirtieth Street Station just before midnight on a charge of vagrancy.

OMAHA, Dec. 20 -- The Jacksonian Club of Nebraska, one of the leading Democratlc organizations of the West, and one of the first to declare for Bryan, has, after seven years, recognized that those Democrats who failed to support Bryan and the Democratic National platform in the last two campaigns were sincere in their convictions.

Brailsford is an English name all right and Ebbw Vale cannot exist outside of Wales, but if Mr. BRAILSFORD, Chairman of the Ebbw Vale Steel, Iron and Coal Company is not a native of Pennsylvania, he has fully absorbed the spirit of that highly protected community.

Mayor-elect George B. McClellan's first day in New York after his resignation from Congress was quietly spent and no further inklings of appointments got out. During the day Col. McClellan spent most of his time trying to get his new home, at 10 Washington Square North, settled, but he had a short interview during the afternoon with Charles F. Murphy and other personal friends.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Frederic R. Coudert, the New York lawyer, died at 7 o'clock this morning at his Washington home, 1,843 S Street. He came to Washington and fitted up the S Street house about six weeks ago, intending to spend the Winter here.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Reuter's Telegram Company has learned that considerable anxiety exists in the best-informed circles of London regarding the possible outcome of the situation in the Far East.

The hearing yesterday in the Jefferson Market Court in the case of Mrs. Inez Hyland, the young Englishwoman who was arrested on Saturday afternoon at her home in Harlem on a charge of having stolen jewels valued at $16,000 from Capt. John A. Fysh, formerly of the British Army, developed some interesting information concerning not only the prisoner, but also the complainant.

At a special meeting of the Atlantic Yacht Club, held at the New York Club, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, last night, important changes in the racing rules and racing classification of the club were made, with a view of inducing uniformity among the various yacht clubs in the vicinity of this city.

Course of Prices. -- Reflecting the vary ing influences of the day, prices yesterday showed much irregularity. Traders seemed inclined at the opening to work for higher prices, and during the first hour their efforts met with some success, but later, as the market grew duller, prices went off so easily that in most of the active issues the closing sales showed losses instead of gains.

No one knows the interest people feel in lucky emblems until it is seen how much they are willing to pay for them. Some of the finest umbrellas have crystal handles. These are in various forms, the umbrella made of fine silk, with a plain wooden stick, the crystal as a rule in a knob, carved or plain, on the end of the handle.

Mayor-elect McClellan last night announced the above as the second installment of his official appointments to take effect with his inauguration as Mayor on Jan. 1. His first installment was sent out from Washington more than two weeks ago and contained the one name of John J. Delany to be Corporation Counsel. No further appointments will be announced by the Mayor-elect until Wednesday evening.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 21. -- At the annual session of the Southern Collegiate Association to-day, the charges of professionalism brought against Cumberland University were dismissed. The recommendations to blacklist Central University of Kentucky and South Carolina College were approved.

Old Chelsea Village is in a fair way to lose what little there is left of its old-time bucolic character through the early accomplishment of a long-contemplated scheme of the great steamship lines now controlled by the International Mercantile Marine Company to set possession of a great part of the North River water front from Gansevcort Market to Twenty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Col. Wallace, with headquarters and four troops of the Fifteenth Cavalry, arrived here yesterday and will constitute the garrison at Fort Myer. The regiment has been for two years in the Philippines, and has had hard service among the Moros.

A quarter of a million dollars' damage was done by fire last night to the factory and warehouses of the H. Hermann Lumber Company, 368 Broome Street. That company, of which Rosa Hermann, a widow living at 230 East Fifteenth Street, is President, owns three large buildings extending from Broome Street, along the east side of Mott Street nearly to Spring.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The breaking up of the ice in the Pequannock and Ramapo Rivers, due to Sunday's rains, caused flood in the valley, and scores of men worked to-day and evening to avert a threatened calamity, and succeeded.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 21. -- Walter L. Taylor, after, being acquitted on four indictments last week, charging him with simple assault on Representative Lamar, was to-day convicted on a charge of assault with intent to murder. Judge Malone sentenced him to five years in the State prison.
LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The Times reproduces, "with reserve," the following, received by prominent members of the Jewish community in London:

Henry W. Savage's English Grand Opera Company began yesterday at the West End Theatre what is referred to in the programme as a "five weeks' grand operatic festival." The selection for the opening night was Verdi's lyric drama, "Othelio," and it cannot be said that this selection was a particularly happy one.

We are pained to observe that Bishop POTTER begins his admirable "Christmas greeting" in our esteemed contemporary The Sunday World in these terms, "All Hail, Anno Domini, Nineteen Hundred and Four!" What does that mean, the reader asks. "Why not Anno Mundi, or Anno Jovis, or Anno Republicae?"

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The trial of Albert C. Twining and Davis C. Cornell, President and Treasurer, respectively, of the Monmouth Trust Company of Asbury Park, on an indictment charging them with falsifying the reports and minutes of the company, was begun here to-day before Judge Heisley in the Monmouth County Court.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Charles Frohman produced at the Vaudeville Theatre to-night a new musical comedy entitled "The Cherry Girl," by Seymour Hicks and Ivan Caryll. The principal parts were in the hands of Seymour Hicks and his wife, Ellaline Terriss. The piece is melodious and vivacious, and was charmingly mounted.

PANAMA, Dec. 21. -- There is no truth in the report that Americans have been told to leave the Darien district within twenty-four hours. There are less than a score of Americans in the entire district, and practically all of them are at Cana, where they are engaged in mining. Cana is about three days inland from Yaviza.

Details will be found in another column relative to the erection of a new building at 19 West Thirty-fourth Street for Revillon Freres, and also regarding the purchase of a four-inch strip of ground fronting on Seventh Avenue, just south of Fiftieth Street.

Dr. Gorham Bacon and Mrs. Bacon gave a reception and dance last evening in the white and gold ballroom at Sherry's to introduce their second daughter, Miss Ruth Bears Bacon. The reception was preceded by a dinner, which was quite informal, and to which relatives, the young women who received, and a few others were asked.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A marble statue of the late "War Governor," Francis H. Pierpont of West Virginia, was placed in statuary hall at the Capitol today under the invitation of Congress to each of the States to place in the Capitol statues of two of its "illustrious sons." The statue completes West Virgnia's quota, one of ex-Senator Kenna having a place in the hall.
Brig. Gen. Thomas H. Barry, United States Army, will proceed to Atlanta, Ga., for the purpose of securing suitable rooms for the accommodation, of the headquarters, Department of the Gulf.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 21. -- It was stated here to-day that Dr. W.T. Howard, city bacteriologist and a professor of Western Reserve University, had discovered the smallpox germ, and that an announcement of his find would be made known very soon.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21. -- Some heavy trading in Reading and United States Steel preferred gave to the local market an appearance of activity. Very little was done, however, outside of these two stocks, although trading was more animated in Marsden and International Smokeless Powder.

CERRO GORDO, Tenn., Dec. 21. -- "Tom" Sinclair who was arrested and placed in the local jail Saturday night, was found dead in his cell Sunday morning with a bullet in his brain. Fellow-prisoners were awakened just before dawn by a single shot, which was followed by the flight of a person dressed as a female.

To the Editor of The The New York Times: There have been so many people who, during the past weeks, have called attention to the many (?) serious and flagrant mistakes made at the opera since Mr. Conried assumed its management, that one who desires justice and who is a music lover and a critical listener of opera in New York during the past twenty years wishes to lift up her voice in protest.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 21. -- Falernlan and The Regent were the only winning favorites at New Orleans to-day, and The Regent shared betting honors with Satin. Most of the winners were well backed. Weather clear. Track lumpy and slow. Summary:

In a letter to THE TIMES a reader inquires whether we are aware that it is reported and generally believed that Judge PARKER voted for Mr. BRYAN in 1900, and whether in our opinion a Democrat who voted for Mr. BRYAN is fit to be the party candidate for the Presidency next year.
The interests which have been trying for more than a year to obtain control of the Hackensack Meadows Company have finally accomplished their purpose.

Superintendent of Tolls William W. Sheffield of the New East River Bridge at 5 o'clock yesterday morning turned over to the ticket taker at the Brooklyn end of the structure a pad of green tickets. Ten seconds later a big fifty-six horse power automobile passed the ticket man and plunged forward over the pitch dark roadway in the direction of New York.

Mrs. Alberta C. Fysh, whose husband, Capt. John A. Fysh, caused the arrest of Mrs. Inez Hyland last Saturday on the charge of appropriating Mrs. Fysh's jewels, worth $16,000, assumed a very conspicuous and dramatic part at the examination of Mrs. Hyland before Magistrate Flammer yesterday in the Jefferson Market Court.

The very strong movement undertaken by the commercial organizations of the country for the reform of the Consular Service will be, or ought to be, greatly aided by the report of Assistant Secretary of State PEIRCE, who last Summer made a tour of inspection of the Consulates in Europe.

KISHINEFF, Bessarabia, Dec. 21. -- Two Russians named Gnetschin and Marosjeik, who have been on trial charged with murder as the authors of the massacre of Jews here last Spring, were sentenced to-day to seven and five years' penal servitude respectively.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- London has been sputtering all day long over the speech by Emperor William at Hanover in which he declared that the incomparable deeds of the German legion saved the English from destruction at Waterloo.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 21. -- Surrogate Nathan D. Petty of Suffolk County has entered a decree settling the second judicial accounting of the executors and trustees of the Austin Corbin estate. The estate has dwindled to a fraction of what it was originally.

It is a principle of international law that weak nations are entitled to be treated with justice and courtesy. That principle has been disregarded in our recent dealings with the Republic of Colombia.

COLON, Dec. 21. -- Information has been received here that about 100 Colombian troops have landed on the Island of Pines, northwest of Cape Tiburon, which is situated at the western entrance of the Gulf of Darien.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 21. -- In a wreck to-day at Godfrey, Kan., of the "Meteor," a St. Louis and San Francisco fast passenger train from the South, ten persons were killed and thirty-two were injured. Of the injured, four probably will die, while fourteen were severely hurt.

ALBANY, Dec. 21. -- Supt. C.R. Skinner of the State Department of Public Instruction appealed before the joint Legislative Committee on the Educational System today when it resumed sessions after the adjournment.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day, and borrowers were entirely dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were firm, owing to the condition of the short-loan market and Continental Exchanges.
It is reported from Halifax that extraordinary catches of cod are being made by the fishermen off that coast. The catches off the Norway coast have been very poor.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Picketing, whether peaceful or violent, of houses from which funerals are to start, by the union livery drivers, who went on strike four days ago, is to be prevented by the police under direct orders issued to-night by Chief of Police O'Neil.

Trading in curb stocks during yesterday's session was on a more narrow scale, but quite a few stocks showed considerable activity. There was but a single movement in prices of more than usual interest, and that was the activity and strength of Seaboard Air Line preferred. The copper stocks were given quite a good deal of attention, Greene Consolidated being the most active, and closing at the lowest for the day.

Business upon the Stock Exchange yesterday gives no lead to any doubting traders, but affords room to expect that, barring accidents, there will be little doing until after the turn of the year, and the clearing up of the several cloudy points in the situation. Possibly nothing was more discussed or less influential upon prices than the Eastern situation, and the war talk which London telegrams said was disturbing business there.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Determined that the striking livery drivers and the resulting famine of carriages should not interfere with his wedding, Antonio Locasco, manager for a commission firm, hired a hospital ambulance and drove his prospective bride and a bridal party in triumph to the Church of the Assumption, where the ceremony was performed.

The National Sculpture Society is in the habit of giving a large, important exhibition every two or three years, or whenever funds enough accumulate in its treasury to meet the expenses of elaborate shows with a background of architecture, trees, and flowers.
