New York scarcely appreciates what has been accomplished since the foundation of this society, hardly realizing that it is the only city in the world which has ever had the like.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Miss Rhona K. Adair. the champion woman golf player of Ireland and England, who has just returned here from a visit to the United States, brought back most pleasant impressions of the American girl golfer, whom she describes in an interview as being "a thorough sportswoman, equally pleasant as a partner or as an opponent.

Since we commented the other day upon the distribution of $250,000 among its employes by a Chicago business house certain facts regarding that house have come to our knowledge which lead us -- not at its request, or even suggestion, by the way -- to present the case anew and in a light essentially different.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 22. -- W.T. Sherman-Doyle, the well-known Washington (D.C.) lawyer, counsel for the Consolidated Street Railways of that city, had a pleasant social game of whist with several well-dressed strangers whom he met on a train between Chicago and Omaha last night.

Dr. NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER spoke some plain truths to the New England Society of Brooklyn on Monday evening, and though his hearers probably need that kind of exhortation as little as any class in the community, it is well for them to listen to it and take it out with them into the life of the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The Ambassador from Austria-Hungary, who has been seriously ill with bronchitis, is able to attend to official business, but is accepting no invitations for the present. The first entertainment of the year at the embassy will be the party Thursday afternoon, when Baroness Hengelmuller will have a few of her personal friends to see the lighting of the Christmas tree for her little daughter.
BOGOTA, Saturday, Dec. 19. -- Dr. Luis Carlos Rico, Minister of Foreign Affairs, has cabled Gen. Reyes at Washington, under date of Dec. 16, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- To keep a plucky and determined Kentucky girl from going to the Philippines to marry the man of her choice, Secretary Root to-day, after consulting with Gen. Young, the Chief of Staff of the Army, cabled a private soldier there to send in his application for honorable discharge and it would be favorably considered by the department.

The steamship Belgravia of the Hamburg-American Line arrived here yesterday after the most stormy voyage that has been reported by any ship this season. From the time she left Hamburg on Dec. 5 until she came within the shelter of the Long Island coast she was thrown about in a sea which rolled mountain high, the winds coming from every quarter.

BOSTON, Dec. 22. -- The money market is much easier in tone, but rates are not materially changed. The local banks are in fairly good shape, but the preparations for the January disbursements prevent any increased disposition to put out funds.

Small declines scattered throughout the list were the result of the trading in outside stocks yesterday. Movements in price were very narrow, and, with the exception of Greene Consolidated Copper, activity was at a low ebb. Standard Oil continues its seesaw movements of the past ten days, and yesterday sold down 4 points, to 670, closing at the lowest.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- It was announced to-day at the forty-ninth convocation of the University of Chicago that donations amounting to $1,850,000 had been received from John D. Rockefeller, founder of the university. Of this amount $1,500,000 in real estate in the immediate vicinity of the university was formally transferred by Mr. Rockefeller.

It is given to few men with or without the impediment of a benign polypus on their vocal cords, to waken such far resounding and angry echoes as the German Kaiser has stirred up in the United Kingdom. It Was his toast to the (Hanoverian) German Legion that did it, and the toast was in these words:

The continuation of the examination yesterday afternoon before Magistrate Flammer, in the Jefferson Market Court, of witnesses in the case of Capt. John A. Fysh, late private in the United States Army and a volunteer in the Boer war, against Mrs. Inez Hyland, whom he charged with stealing his wife's jewelry, brought out many new features and resulted in the woman's being held in $10,000 bail for trial.

Trading Monotonous. -- Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday fell to such a low ebb that in the hour between 1 and 2 the transactions amounted to only about 14,000 shares. During the entire day the sales amounted to about 225,000 shares, or only a little more than the business transacted during the first hour on Monday.

HAVANA, Cuba, Dec. 19. -- Contracts were signed to-day for the construction of a modern hotel for Havana, the largest and most complete in this city, and, in fact, on the whole island. Its location is in the centre of the most fashionable quarter of the city, the proposed building having a frontage on three streets, with the main entrance on Prado.

Shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday somethins queer happened in the cotton market. Up to that time the trading had been dull and uneventful within a narrow range of prices. But at the hour named the bulls suddenly began to show activity. They bid for options in a most determined and confident way, and the price responded at once, especially as the ticker from New Orleans showed that a similar movement had started on that Exchange.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 22. -- Literary people of New England sent congratulations to Col. Thomas Wentworth Higginson, who observed to-day the eightieth anniversary of his birth. Col. Higginson received his friends at his home, on Buckingham Street.

With a laugh on his lips and airily wishing the jurors a merry Christmas, Frank H. Burness, self-confessed murderer of four men, in the Kings County Court yesterday afternoon received a verdict which will send him to the electric chair in Sing Sing. The jury found the man guilty of murder in the first degree for the killing of Capt. George B. Townsend of the schooner Charles K. Buckley on Nov. 10.

Incidental to a suit to recover $75 which was tried before Justice Van Wart, in the Second District Municipal Court, Brooklyn, on Monday, testimony was given showing that the name of R.A. Blakelock, the landscape painter, had been forged to paintings executed by his twenty-three-year-old daughter Marian in order to enhance their value.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 22. -- State Bank Examiner Vredenburgh again testified today at the trial of Albert C. Twining and David C. Cornell, formerly President and Treasurer of the Monmouth Trust Company, charged with having falsified the reports and minutes of the company. The examiner, after saying his investigation had failed to show how Cornell was to have derived any benefit from his dealings with Twining, was excused.

ROME, Dec. 22. -- It is reported that Cardinal Merry del Val, the Papal Secretary of State, will soon leave the Borgia apartment in the Vatican, the occupation of which by the Cardinal has gives rise to so much discussion.

Despite the fact that Corporation Counsel Rives yesterday sent a report to the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen, holding that the board had the right to take up and pass the Port Chester Railroad permit, Chairman Diemer of the committee did not get a meeting of the body, and consequently no report was made to the board on the subject.

There is substantially nothing to be said regarding yesterday's stock market, except reference to the facts to make good that proposition. Brokers' offices were deserted, the tape boys read novels over the silent ticker, and room traders swapped jokes instead of contracts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- President Roosevelt, according to report, will not advance Gen. Wood beyond the rank of Major General in the event of the latter's confirmation in that grade.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Residents in the aristocratic Netherwood region of this city are up in arms over the announcement to-day that local colored people had purchased the Darling property, situated in their midst, for the purpose of turning it into a home for colored working girls imported from the South.

The three labor men on the General Arbitration Board of the Employers' Association apointed to try and save Local No. 2 from annihilation made a final plea for the members of the union before the Executive Committee of the Iron League yesterday. Both sides were pledged to secrecy, but it is believed that propositions were considered which, if accepted by both sides, will lead to the end of the long fight within forty-eight hours.

With his former friends glaring at him, but apparently little disconcerted by their looks of hatred, the counterfeiter who turned State's evidence after the recent raid in Revere, Mass., took the witness stand before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday morning, and told his story of the gang headed by John Davis that was rounded up here and in Revert.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- There was an increased demand for money in the market to-day, owing to the holiday requirements, the payment of $7,500,000 of call loans, and the outflow of cash to the provinces. Discounts fluctuated.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22. -- Silver Mead and Little Jack Horner were the winning favorites to-day. The other winners carried but little money and the ring fared well. Weather clear; track fast Summary:

George E. Smith ("Pittsburg Phil") will be compelled to wait a while longer before being placed in good standing again on Jockey Club tracks. At a meeting of the Stewards of The Jockey Club, in the apartments of James R. Keene, at the Waldorf-Astoria, on Monday evening. Smith asked for a hearing, but the matter was laid on the table.
PARSIFAL. A Solemn Festival-Play, in Three Acts. Music And Book by Richard Wagner.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 22. -- President Herrmann of the National Baseball Commission made a decision to-day in the case of W. D. Scanlon of the Ilion (N.Y.) Club. He was claimed by Pittsburg, as that club had begun negotiations for him. In view of the fact, however, that no purchase price had beeh paid, the claim of Pittsburg was not allowed, and Scanlon's name was ordered placed on the reserve list of the Ilion Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- The feature of the local market was the break in Philadelphia Rapid Transit from 9 3/4 to 8 1/4, the result of the $5 assessment called, and which is payable Jan. 20. The fact that only thirty days' notice was allowed the stockholders instead of sixty, as was the general impression, induced selling by holders who had thought the price might be advanced before payment of the call was due.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- Kogoro Takahira, Japanese Minister to the United States, at the annual dinner of the New England Society of Pennsylvania to-night, delivered an address which touched upon Japan's attitude toward her immediate neighbors in the Far East. Mr. Takahira stated it to be Japan's desire that neighboring people should enjoy to a certain extent her own civilization, which she had adapted from Western models.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 22. -- On petition of Mrs. Ella S. Russell of Killingly, widow of ex-Representative Charles A. Russell, a temporary receiver was appointed to-day for the Windham County National Bank of Danielson.

BALITMORE, Md., Dec. 22. -- Trading on the Stock Exchange was meagre, involving in all 151 shares of stock and $59,000 of bonds. An absence of pressure to sell is noted, and there is a somewhat more cheerful feeling, partially owing to the discharge to-day by the court of the Union Trust Company receivership and the proposed resumption of business by that company to-morrow morning, after having had its doors closed since Oct. 19.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The action of the Louisiana Legislature in instructing the Senators from that State to vote to ratify the Panama treaty when that convention should come up in the Senate was a sharp surprise to the Democratic Senators who remained in Washington. It was not expected that the Legislature would take up any other subject than the extermination of the boll weevil.

After having declined consistently to answer through an interview the charges made against him in connection with the Shipbuilding Trust, Charles M. Schwab told his story for the first time yesterday in a cross bill filed with the Clerk of the United States Circuit Court of the Southern District of New York.

The customary diversion for our citizens in the way of manhole explosions, which usually begins about the first of December and lasts until Spring, is now in progress -- like a continuous performance of vaudeville. Every day or two we have a change, of programme, but so far as the gas company is concerned it is the same old song and dance turn.
The story of the discovery of radium is full of interest, and my readers may pardon me even if it is again told; for it forms the first chapter in a volume of which many have still to be written.

Something new in the way of handbags to be seen in the smart shops is the leather handle on the bag of other and more frivolous materials. For instance, there is a charming little square bead bag, the foundation black beads and a design of red poppies, also in beads. The handle to this is a strap of black patent leather.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The brief of the State of Minnesota in the appeal from the Federal Circuit Court decision, setting aside the suit of that State against the Northern Securities Company, was filed in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day by Attorney General Douglass and M.D. Munn and George B. Wilson.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- The resignation of George B. McClellan as member of Congress from the Twelfth District of New York on account of his election as Mayor of New York City, was received by Gov. Odell and filed with the Secretary of State this morning. Gov. Odell will order a special election to fill the vacancy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter signed ''Lex Medico" appeared in a late edition of the Sunday TIMES, and while logical and interesting in the main, the writer would like to submit a misinterpretation at fact in one of its arguments in support of the theory that it is possible, without resort to bribery, to enforce the laws in this city.

The annual dinner of the New England Society, held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, was pronounced to be the most notable held during the ninety-eight years since the incorporation of the society. There were 554 diners gathered in the banquet hall, which was a fluttering mass of American flags from the tables to the topmost gallery.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for William Hall's Sons the new six-story American-basement dwelling 6 East Sixty-second Street, on lot 27 by 100.5. The buyer, said to be a prominent New Yorker, will occupy the house. The property has been held at $300,000, and compares favorably with any of the fine residences put up by speculative builders in the upper Fifth Avenue section.

It was announced at the office of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company yesterday that the shoppers' specials on the Sixth Avenue Elevated Road, had been increased in number from five to eight, which, with twenty-four trains on the old Franklin Street service, gives the retail district considerable relief from the old-time rush-hour congestion.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 22. -- The New England Society of the Oranges to-night held its thirty-third annual dinner in commemoration of Forefathers' Day, in Commonwealth Hall, East Orange. A congratulatory telegram was sent to the New York society, and its answer was read. President Isaac C. Ogden acted as toastmaster.

Owing to a hitch over the selection of a Police Commissioner, Mayor-elect McClelian may not be able to announce his choice for that important office when he gives' out his third installment of appointments this evening.

From the list of appointments by the Mayor-elect yesterday morning we single out the name of Mr. T.C.T. CAIN for comment of a different and more hopeful nature than it is possible for us to make upon any of the other appointments. Mr. CRAIN is appointed to be Tenement House Commissioner, an office of very great importance, since the enforcement or non-enforcement of the new tenement house law depends in the main, upon the incumbent.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 22. -- While playing polo on the Georgian Court field here last April young Jay Gould, the fifteen-year-old son, of George J. Gould, was struck in the knee, with a polo ball. The blow caused the youngster considerable pain, and a short time afterward the knee become swollen and inflamed.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- A feature of the local market was the selling of securities which are believed to have come from the estate of the late William L. Elkins, as the deceased was before his death connected directly or indirectly with the various companies whose securities came upon the market to-day.
LONDON, Dec. 24. -- The British Foreign Office declines to discuss the statements made in The Associated Press dispatch from Berlin yesterday on the ground that "the contingency is too hypothetical."

The Rev. Dr. Cortland Myers, President of the New York Society for the Enforcement of the Criminal Law, has addressed an open letter to Gen. Francis V. Greene, Police Commissioner, declaring that it is not true that he will hand over a clean and corrected city to the McClellan administration, and giving him a list of 59 places in Manhattan and 15 places in Brooklyn where gambling on the horse races may be carried on.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 23. -- Under an order of court, Receiver McLane of the Maryland Trust Company has secured possession and clear title to securities of the Vera Cruz, and Pacific Railway, pledged with the Maryland Trust as security for its advances to the railroad. The full amount of these advances, including $910,516 interest, is $6,224,588.

Capt. John H. Rice, Ordnance Department, will make not to exceed four visits per month, during January, February, and March, to the works of the Mansfield Engineering Company, Mansfield, Ohio, and the works of the Morgan Engineering Company, Alliance, Ohio, and not to exceed four visits per month during the same period to the works or the Coxey Steel and Silica Company, Mount Vernon, Ohio, on business pertaining to the inspection of ordnance material.

LONDON, Dec. 23. - A dispatch to Lloyd's from Flushing, Holland, says the German steamship Preussen is ashore near Zoutelande. Assistance will be sent to her immediately. The weather is thick and foggy.

With a crash that could be heard for blocks the walls and framework of the old Thirteenth Regiment Armory, which is being razed to make way for the new Long Island Railroad Station at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn, suddenly collapsed yesterday afternoon, falling upon a dozen workmen, two of whom were killed while seven others were more or less seriously injured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The settlement of the long controversy over the friars' lands in the Philippines is Bearing the end. A cablegram was received at the War Department to-day from Gov. Taft sailing that an agreement had teen reached to pay in bonds the sum of $7,239,784 for 391,000 acres involved in the purchase.

PEKING, Dec. 23. -- It is positively known here that Japan has drawn the line for a settlement with Russia beyond which she will not make any material concessions, and that she is determined to fight before yielding what she considers to be her vital interests.
DULUTH, Minn., dec. 23. -- Close: Wheat, to arrive, No. 1 hard, 82 1/8c: No. 1 Northern, 80 5/8c: No. 2 Northern, 78 1/8c: December, 80c; May, 82 1/8c.

The North German Lloyd liner Hohenzollern was nearing Nantucket before dawn on Monday morning when a bark was sighted flying signals of distress. When the liner came nearer the Captain of the disabled vessel shouted that he wanted some men to help him navigate his ship. Capt. Miessel of the Hohenzollern lined up his crew and called for volunteers, but not a man would offer his services.

Standard Oil interests are said to be behind the new Inter-State Securities Company, which was incorporated at Albany on Tuesday with a capital of $2,500,000. The company was provided with a blanket charter which permits it to a general business of financing corporations, industrial and railroad, and also allows it to act as a holding company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- "War on Panama means war with the United States," is the substance of cablegrams which Gen. Rafael Reyes. the Colombian Minister, is sending to the Bogota Government and to his more influential followers throughout Colombia.
LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Money was in increased demand in the market to-day, and the supply was more plentiful, owing to large borrowings from the Bank of England. Discounts were easier.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The War Department has made public the following letter, dated at Manila, July 28, 1903, from Gen. Leonard Wood to Adjt. Gen. Corbin:
BOSTON, Dec. 23. -- The money market continues easier, but business is very quiet. The demand is light, and banks do not appear anxious to put out loans.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23. -- Huzzah was the only winning favorite at the Crescent City track to-day. The defeat of Barbara Frietschie, backed from fours to 8 to 5, was a heavy blow to the talent. Weather clear; track fast. Summary:

The position of China in a contest of which the ultimate issue is whether or not she shall be dismembered is intolerably pathetic. The latest advices are that our Minister at Peking, who is supposed to command the confidence of the Empress Dowager in so far as any foreigner can command it, has been instigated by WU TING-FANG to wait upon that besotted old woman on the chance of bringing her to her senses.

After an interesting series of games the New York Bowling League's tournament was finished on Amann Triess's alleys last night. The New Jersey team took first honors, having only lost one game out of the fourteen played. The Algonquin team was second, with eleven games won and three lost, while the Metropolitans and Fidelias have to play off a tie for third place, each having won ten and lost four games.
PEKING, Dec. 23. -- The new Board of Commerce, has promulgated the railway laws compiled by Wu-Ting-Fang, ex-Minister at Washington, and now Vice President of the board.

Lawrence, Son Gerrish have won their appeal from a decision of the Board of United States General Appraisers, assessing a duty of 7 cents a yard and 25 per cent ad valorem on imports of Chinese floor matting from Canton. Judge Hazel, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday handed down a decision reversing the board and fixing the duty at 3 cents a yard.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 23. -- One of the worst wrecks in the history of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad occurred at 7:45 o'clock to-night at Laurel Run, eight miles west of Connellsville, on the Pittsburg Division of the Baltimore and Ohio. The "Duquesne Limited," the fastest train on the road, was wrecked, killing sixty outright, fatally injuring eighteen, and slightly injuring more than fifty.

An English physician has raised a hornet's nest about his own ears and greatly excited the Scottish subjects of his Majesty by gravely asserting in the columns of The London Daily Mail that instead of being a wholesome and nutritious food oatmeal porridge is rapidly attaining the proportions of "a national curse."

Probably the descendants of New Englanders were somewhat surprised by the figures that Mr. WHITELAW REID placed before them at their annual banquet revealing the extent to which the Yankee element, and, for that matter, the American element in our population seems to be losing its relative importance.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 23. -- The Tartar Generskat Kirin reports that an indecisive battle has occurred between four battalions of Chinese from Hung-Chun and 1,500 Koreans who invaded Chinese territory from Kyeng-Chung, in Northeast Korea.

Yesterday's stock market was appropriate to the season. There was some increase of activity, and a general rise in prices, thus dispersing general cheer more befitting holiday humor than a too severe inquiry into justification for market temper all would glady see supported by conditions.
LONDON, Dec. 23. -- "Mme. Sherry" was produced at the Apollo Theatre to-night under the joint management of Charles Frohman and George Edwardes.

Yesterday was full of excitement in the cotton market. Not that the sales were very heavy; on the contrary, they were comparatively light, but the fluctuations were more severs than they have been at any time during the recent bull campaign. At one time the quotations established new high records, but at the close a reaction of nearly 30 points brought some of the options down to below Tuesday's close.

Trading in curb securities yesterday was very limited. With the exception of the strength of Hackensack Meadows and the weakness in the Seaboard Air Line issues, there were no movements in price, of any special interest. Interborough Rapid Transit recovered some of its recent loss, and on the sale of 400 shares sold as high as92 5/8, an advance of 1 5/8.

Commissioner WILLCOX brought up yesterday before the Board of Estimate that official labor of his by which his term of office, excellently as it has been administered, is likely to be longest remembered. Under the charter, the Commissioner of Parks for Manhattan is also Commissioner for Richmond.
The following securities were sold at auc- tion yesterday at the New York Real Estate Salesroom by Adrian H. Muller Son:

William McAdoo, who was Assistant Secretary of the Navy under President Cleveland, and is one of the best-known Democrats of the country, will be at the head of the Police Department in the new city administration, according to an announcement made by Mayor-elect McClellan last evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- A Democratic Senator who was asked regarding the candidacy of Senator German for the Presidency said that Mr. Gorman seemed to be unaffected by the discussion in the newspapers of his chances for the Democratic nomination next year.

A Merry Christmas Market. -- The wave of strength which carried the stock market up yesterday and which at times suggested a state of mind among traders bordering on enthusiasm was by many, attributed to a desire to put into the market something of the holiday spirit. Many look for some such movement as Christmas approaches, and it has happened often enough to make the expectation a reasonable one.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Another important victory for Mr. Chamberlain and tariff reform was won yesterday in the Parliamentary bye-election in the Ludlow division of Shropshire. Rowland Hunt, the Unionist candidate, was chosen to succeed the late Jasper More, Unionist.

Emanuel I.S. Hart, a lawyer of 267 West Twenty-third Street, appeared in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday and startled Judge McMahon by declaringthat he (Mr. Hart) was going to make an effort to set a ruling on the burning domestic question, "Should a wife be compelled to support her husband?"

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- At a meeting tonight of the employers affected by the fight between the Liverymen's and Undertakers' Association and the Livery Drivers' Union, which for six days has seriously interfered with the burial of the city's dead, it was voted to renew business to-morrow without recognizing the strikers, and to employ either union or non-union men.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The Secretary of the Interior to-day refused the application of the City off San Francisco for permission to begin the necessary construction toward obtaining a water supply from the Yosemite National Park. The city proposed to expend about $30,000,000 on the water works.

The Democrats of the South are running away from the Panama issue. Mr. WILLIAMS, the Democratic leader in the House, has a fantastic notion that he can keep the question of the Panama Republic and the question of the Panama Canal entirely separate. He is for the canal, but against the way taken by the President to get it built.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 23. -- President Liginger of the Amateur Athletic Union has received a letter from Gustavus T. Kirtoy, Chairman of the Advisory Committee of Columbia University, to send Archie Hahn, the champion sprinter of the West, to New York to compete in the Amateur Athletic Union championship indoor games to be held in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 30.

Gov. ODELL, in the past has not been counted among the enthusiastic friends of the 1,000-ton barge canal. It has been easier for him to repress his zeal than to dissemble his lukewarmness -- we might even call it his hostility. He has a duty to perform now which will test the sincerity of his more, recent expressions of interest in the improvement.

Chicago so clearly takes the lead in the barbarity of organized labor that it has been a question of some curiosity at what point the limit of public and official acquiescence in the demands of the unions would be reached, or whether there was any at which, in the official mind, forbearance would cease to be a virtue.

The decision of Judge Kirkpatrick, in the United States District Court in New Jersey on Tuesday, authorizing Receiver Tatnall of the Asphalt Company of America to make an assessment of 80 per cent upon the stock of that corporation, is expected to bring out a series of interesting litigations.

PEKING, Dec. 23. -- The intelligent Chinese officials await developments in the Far Eastern situation with deepest anxiety. They foresee the many, perils, menacing China in the event of war and the possibility that the partition of the empire may result from China's inability to maintain the neutrality of her harbors and subjects.

With her port propeller broken and with tales of a tempestuous voyage the North German Lloyd liner Kronprinz Wilhelm, from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg, reached her dock at 9 o'clock last night, a day late. She had on board 1,153 passengers, the largest number ever brought into this port at any time during Christmas week.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24. -- Supported by an authoritative report, the opinion prevailed on the floor of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange to-day that the old bull ring of last season had been reorganized.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 24. -- Local cotton brokers say they have been victimized by ginning men of the South. It is claimed that short-weight bales have been received, the shortage varying from 40 to 100 pounds. It is asserted that the ginning men make up the sortage in weight by using an unusually heavy wrapping of cheap burlap.

Friday, Jan. 29. -- Ten-mile championship, American Automobile Association; free for all. Class A. One-mile motor cycles, handicap, best two in three heats. One mile 56 seconds class. Class A. Ten miles, invitation. Class B. Twenty miles, handicap. Classes A and B. Five miles, for two passenger runabout. Class B. Kilometer and mile record trials.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 24. -- The Democratic Party in Wyoming, having been defeated successively since 1896, when Bryan carried the State, is practically disorganized. A strong effort, however, will be made by ex-Gov. J.E. Osborne, the sheep raiser, to pull the party together for a vigorous campaign in 1904.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 24. -- Arthur Pue Gorman, for over twenty years leader and practically ruler of the Democratic Party in Maryland, is the choice of the rank and file of the Democracy of his State for the nomination for President.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- Orange Lake yachtsmen to-day experienced the unusual occurrence of two extremes, sailing one race in almost a dead calm and another in one of the stiffest breezes of the season. The first event was for the Jackson Cup, distance ten miles, to be sailed inside of thirty-five minutes or no race, The wind was from the south and the ice slightly wet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Besides the active politicians few Illinois Democrats have given much thought as yet to the question of candidates for President. There has been a deal of talk among the party leaders and their lieutenants about the possible chance of Illinois furnishing the next standard bearer, but no concerted action has been taken.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Dec. 24. -- D.V. Rieger, formerly President of the Missouri National Bank of Kansas City, who was pardoned by President Roosevelt yesterday, left the penitentiary to-day upon the arrival of his wife from Washington with the pardon. Both departed immediately for their home in Kansas City, where Mr. Kieger said he would begin life anew.

For the first time since it was first produced in Baireuth in 1882, Wagner's "Parsifal" was performed yesterday outside of the Festival Playhouse for which the master composed it. A vast assemblage was gathered at the Metropolitan Opera House to witness it -- an assemblage most brilliant in appearance and in quality, following the drama with the keenest attention, with breathless silence, and submitting eagerly to its spell.

Declaring that the present Brooklyn Bridge must be partially rebuilt so as to provide a double-decker structure if the congested conditions of to-day ever are to be adequately relieved, Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal yesterday sent to Mayor Low the drawings and plans for the reconstructed bridge as he has prepared them.
The Railroad Gazette in estimating the car and locomotive output for the year 1903, says in its issue of this week:

This is Christmas Day, but not Christmas weather, and if faith be put in ancient weather proverbs, fat graveyards will follow. All day yesterday ominous clouds hovered over the housetops and toward nightfall a fine rain began to fall, which boded ill for the coming holiday.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 24. -- For some months sentiment in Georgia has been crystallizing in favor of the nomination of Senator Arthur Pue Gorman of Maryland by the Democratic Party in 1904. Always very popular with Georgia Democrats, Senator Gorman was greatly strengthened as a Presidential favorite by the result in Maryland in November.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 24. -- While two or three miles out of her course, the Erastus Corning of the Starin line from New Haven to Kew York, struck a jagged reef known as Copp's Rocks, just outside Norwalk Harbor, shortly after 2 o'clock this morning and sank in fifteen feet of water.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 24. -- In the morgues and hospitals here this evening a poll of the victims of last night's wreck of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's "Duquesne limited" was completed. It showed that there were sixty-rour persons dead and nine injured.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- A young illustrator, who says he is Leo R. Brennan, was arrested to-day as he was leaving the Chicago Post Office upon a charge of having written to J. Pierpont Morgan, Andrew Carnegie, John D. Rockefeller, Marshall Field, and others high in financial circles of New York and Chicago, letters demanding sums ranging from $25,000 to $50,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24. -- It was a holiday market here to-day in every sense of the word, trading falling to 11,277 shares and $69,300 bonds. Good buying developed in Marsden, its price advancing a fraction, while International Smokeless Powder preferred was up 4 points. Consolidated Lake Superior preferred was lifted a point above last night's close.

"With, a view to ascertaining the sentiment of the Democracy of the country on the subject of a candidate for President in 1904, THE NEW YORK TIMES recently sent instructions to its correspondents in the principal cities of the forty-five States to get expressions from the leading Democratic politicians in their commonwealths and to report the consensus of opinion.

In "Parsifal" Wagner carried out in a way as masterly as in "Tristan;" "Die Meistersinger," and the "Nibelungen" trilogy, his system of leading motives. As in those works, the orchestra unfolds a vast fabric of symphonic music, woven of the themes which represent the chief components of the drama -- personages, the Holy Grail itself, ideas, beliefs, characteristics, emotions, sufferings that control its development.

Mayor-elect MCCLELLAN has proved that he is man enough to appoint a Police Commissioner of his own choice against the opposition of the chief men of the organization that put him in power. The appointment of Mr. MCADOO is really excellent. The Mayor deserves full credit for making it.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24. -- Parisienne and Colonel Tyler were the winning favorites to-day. In the third race Higgins, on One More, crowded Meistersinger into the fence, and was suspended for three days for foul riding. Radford in the same race excited the suspicion of the Stewards, who thought him under the influence of drugs, and they ordered the refusal of all entries in the future from the stable of J.J. Gilmore, his owner.

The dispatches we print this morning from all the States reveal a healthy array of favorite sons, but the unmistakable conclusion to be drawn is that the Democrat who can carry the State of New York will be most acceptable throughout the Union as a candidate of the Democracy.

A board, to consist of Capts. Beverly W. Dunn, Colden Ruggles, and Tracy C. Dickson of the Ordnance Department, is appointed to meet at the Sandy Hook proving grounds. New Jersey, Dec. 28. to prepare an examination for Lieutenants of the line of the army who may apply for detail in the Ordnance Department.

Samuel Green has bought 60 Cortlandt Street, adjoining the northwest corner of Greenwich Street, a four-story building on lot 21.1 by 56 by 17.3 by 55.8. The elevated railroad management is seeking to secure the consents of property owners at that point to permit the building of an additional stairway to the Cortlandt Street station of the Ninth Avenue line.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- On the supposition that Great Britain as a last resort might threaten forcibly to interfere in the Russo-Japanese dispute, the United States Naval Attache here, Capt. Charles H. Stockton, pointed out to a press representative yesterday that Great Britain's extraordinarily developed naval mobilization at the present moment was a great factor in favor of peace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The Administration is evidently acting on the old adage, "in time of peace prepare for war," as far as the Republic of Colombia is concerned.

WASHINGTON, Dec., 24. -- Christmas cheer pervaded the White House to-day. There was nothing doing with affairs of State, and on all sides preparations were in evidence for the good cheer of the season. Nearly 1,500 pounds of turkey were distributed by direction of the President to the officials and employes, every man receiving a good-sized fowl.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Secretary Shaw to-day rendered a decision sustaining the Board of General Appraisers in its decision that certain silk ribbons involved in cases brought before the Board were dutiable as trimmings and not as articles of manufactured silk. The effect of the Board's decision was to increase the duty on this class of ribbons from 50 to 60 per cent, ad valorem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- A dispatch of importance to commercial interests has been received by Acting Secretary Loomis from Mr. Steeper, United States Charge at Havana, in relation to the application of the new Cuban reciprocity treaty.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- Ex-Capt. Dreyfus, accused of treason to his country, degraded, dismissed from the French Army, and most bitterly punished, will have another trial, this time by a civilian tribunal.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 24. -- During the gubernatorial contest Henry Walterson's name was mentioned in connection with the Democratic nomination, for President. In a characteristic editorial in his paper, Col. Watterson denied that he sought such preference from his party, and declared that he could not be dragged into the filth and slime of a scramble for that office.

With the announcement of the above appointments, as supplemental to the lists which he had given out earlier in the week, Mayor-elect George B. McClellan said yesterday that he would rest from his appointment-making until after Christmas.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 24. -- A charter was granted to-day in New Jersey to the Manufacturers' Window Glass Company, the proposed combination of the principal glass interests of the country. The capital stock is $1,000,000.

Cross-questioning Alfred Rose, expert accountant connected with the New York Audit Company, Lawyer William D. Guthrie at the hearing yesterday before Special Examiner H.D. Oliphant of the suit against the United States Shipbuilding Company forced the witness to admit that he failed to take future profits into account when he was delegated to examine the condition of the Bethlehem Steel plant.

Commissioner LINDENTHAL is evidently entitled to congratulate his department and the public upon the demonstration that the Williamsburg Bridge "meets a long-felt want." On the second day the tolls taken show that with only one roadway available the new bridge accommodated 40 per cent, of the vehicular traffic of the old, with the advantage of two roadways and of twenty years of habit.

LAKEWOOD. N.J., Dec. 24. -- When George J. Gould, Jr., who is six years old, wakes up to-morrow morning to see what Santa Claus has brought him he will find among his gifts the most perfectly appointed miniature railway train ever built. It was imported from Germany expressly for young Mr. Gould at a cost of $500.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- A dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company from Tokio says Premier Katsura and War Minister Terauchi this morning visited the Marquis Ito, President of the Privy Council, and the Marquis Yamagata, Chief of the Council of Field Marshals, at their villas, two hours' distant by rail from Tokio.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Fred B. Whitney, clerk to the House Committee on Naval Affairs, and Mr. Porter established the world's record to-day for a long-distance run in an electric automobile upon a single charge of battery. A.L. Cline, President of the Washington Association, acted as referee.

Nothing in yesterday's stock market will disturb anybody's Christmas, the dealing's being scarcely adequate in volume or positive enough in tone to alter market views, whatever they may be. If only the blackboard were all there is in the situation all might feel happier, the prices being such as to encourage everybody who is not troubled with a memory and feels under no necessity to exercise foresight.

We have not always the satisfaction of being able to approve the performances of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. It is the greater gratification to be able to congratulate that body upon its reported determination to put a stop to the practice of mutilating horses by docking their tails.

Trading yesterday in curb securities was more active and somewhat irregular. Two of the most important stocks, Greene Consolidated Copper and Interborough Rapid Transit, declined sharply on the largest volume of business of any day this week. To offset in some degree these losses were small gains of 1/2 or thereabouts in about half a dozen issues, the principal ones being Northern Securities, Havana Tobacco preferred, and the Seaboard Air Line stocks.

Controller Grout yesterday declared that there was no occasion for the wholesale cut in the work of the schools decided upon by the Board of Education, and in language surprisingly bitter when coming from him scored the management of the various bureaus of the Department of Education and sharply criticised Dr. William H. Maxwell, City Superintendent of Schools.

Christmas comes but once a year, and is a jolly day for children. There were many Christmas trees yesterday, and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt gives one to-day for her children and the two Herbert boys, who arrived, on the Kronprinz Wilhelm on Tuesday. There are many family dinners at the residences of Mrs. Astor, Mrs. N. Baylies, Mrs. Robert G. Remsen, Mrs. Peter Moller, Adrian Iselin, Mrs. Frederick Kernochan, Mr. Henry Barbey, and others.

From the point of view of society, the audience was not as brilliant as has been seen on other occasions this year at the Metropolitan Opera House. Two empty boxes in the parterre was the keynote to this impression. These boxes were those of Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry and Mr. and Mrs. R.T. Wilson.
LONDON, Dec. 24. -- The Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe received, a great deal of social attention in London last week. They were twice guests at dinners at which they were invited to meet the King.

Mr. WILLIAM MCADOO is a man of courage, of probity, and of positive force of character. If there is a man in the Tammany organization or acting with it from whom the community would have the right to expect a better administration of the Police Department than from Mr. MCADOO we do not know who he is.

Announcement of the programme of races and other events for the second annual automobile race meet of the Florida East Coast Automobile Association, to be held on the Ormond-Daytona Beach, Florida, from Jan. 25 to Feb. 6, inclusive, has been made by W.J. Morgan, the local representative of the Florida Association, as follows:
The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company received a sharp rebuke at the hands of the December Grand Jury of Kings County in the presentment handed up by that body yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24. -- The Democrats of California are showing singular apathy in regard to a candidate for the next Presidential election. There are no indications that any one is working for the nomination except William R. Hearst. If he can mask his work a few more months he may succeed in forming a strong organization, but if he gets out into the open he will arouse the fierce antagonism of the old-line Democrats.
LONDON, Dec. 24. -- Money was in increased holiday demand in the market today, but the supplies exceeded the requirements, the banks lending freely.

Even the most attached readers of Michel de Montaigne -- more than any other Frenchman he has the gift of attaching his readers -- have felt inclined to take with a grain of allowance the famous avowal of the Introduction to the first edition. In 1580, "Je veuix," he wrote, "qu'on m'y veoye en ma facon simple, naturelle et ordinaire, sans estude et artifice; car c'est moy que je peinds.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Dec. 25. -- Resolutions have been adopted by the Chamber of Commerce of Pensacola urging the representatives of Florida in Congress to vote for the ratification of the Panama treaty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- California is a State which has been giving considerable uneasiness to the Republican managers. Although a few years ago it was so debatable that Gen. Stoneman, a Democrat, was elected Governor, of late years it has been regarded as solidly and safely Republican.

The Salvation Army's annual Christmas feast to the poor was given last evening in the Grand Central Palace, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street. Never before in the army's history has it conducted a Christmas banquet on a scale so extensive. Approximately 4,000 persons -- men, women, and children -- found places at sixty long tables set on the main floor of the hall and extending practically from one side of it to the other.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt as well as society generally celebrated Christmas in a purely domestic fashion, all the higher officials of the Government dining at home and, as a rule, entertaining few guests.

These two imposing volumes deal with Parliamentary representations and procedures from the thirteenth century to the nineteenth, that is, from the beginnings of the House of Commons in England to the Reform act of 1832. The Parliaments of Scotland and of Ireland also are traced from their beginnings to the respective unions with that of England in 1707 and 1800.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25. -- Superior team work and an abundance of tricky plays, coupled with more thorough training, gave the Carlisle Indian football team a decisive victory over the all-California eleven this afteroon. The score was 23 to 0.

The first collection of American poetry was issued in Litchfleld, Conn., in 1793, with the title, "American Poems, Original and Selected." The editor, Dr. Ellhu H. Smith, who later wrote a play now treasured by collectors of early American drama. Included poems by Trumbull, Dwight, Barlow, Hopkins, Hopkinson, Humphreys, Livineston, Mrs. Morton, and others.

The superiority of intimate standard literature printed in volumes of light weight and brief proportions is strikingly emphasized by the new set of Charles Lamb which is confine from the editorial pen of William Macdonald, a conservative, but thoroughly gentle, sympathetic, and resourceful critic.

VERY splendid books these are, bound in green buckram and white leather, and lettered in gold and red. Inside is an exceedingly interesting collection of pictures, and every chapter has set before it a passage from some ancient writer, rendered quaint with long "8'8" and relating generally to the all-important subject of clothes.

The interesting facts about birds we have always with us, (says Abbie Farwell Brown.) We can find them out for ourselves, which is a very pleasant thing to do, or we can take the word or others or which there is no lack. But it is the quaint fancies about birds which are in danger of being lost.
JOHN CALLCOTT HORSLEY, R.A., a distinguished painter, died last October in the house in which he had dwelt for seventy-five years, in Kensington, London. His father was Horsley the musical composer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see by the papers that the Board of Aldermen has voted to erect a monument to the memory of the members of the Fire Department who have died while in the performance of their duties. To some people this plan will no doubt seem as the best way of showing the public appreciation of the heroic deeds of our ever-brave "fireladdies."

"English Sport," edited by Alfred E.T. Watson, is being published by the Macmillan Company. Most of the sixteen illustrations in the volume are colored, some of them being reproductions of paintings by G.D. Giles, J.M.W. Turner, T. Blinks, and other English artists. The subjects include fox hunting, wild stag hunting, shooting, racing, fishing, cricket, polo, motoring, rowing, falconry, skating, steeplechasing, football, golf, billiards, and chapters on hunting the Spanish ibex and shooting in Somaliland.

-- Our own respect for hens or all sorts, old and young, feathered and featherless, is so very great that we are quite unable to see why Bostonians in general and Mayor COLLINS in particular should object to the holding in Faneuil Hall by the New England Light Brahma Club of its annual exposition.

THE Macmillan Company will bring out next month "The Policy and Administration of the Dutch in Java," by Dr. Clive Day. This is said to be a careful study of all phases of the subject. The first chapter describes "The Native Organization," that preceded Dutch rule.

Christmas was celebrated by the clay target shooters of the Crescent Athletic Club at the Bay Ridge traps yesterday, and the sport was kept up from 10:20 o'clock in the morning until 4 o'clock in the afternoon. The weather conditions were unfavorable for good marksmanship, and all the morning competitions and one or two in the afternoon were contested in the rain.

To many readers of Napoleonic history the most interesting portion of the unfolding of on absorbingly interesting career is not that which treats of Bonaparte, the great Emperor, warrior and Kingmaker, but rather that of Bonaparte, the First Consul, the man, who, with many apparent disadvantages, typified "Fortune seized by genius; genius justifying Fortune."

THE conditions of a conquered country just after a war are vividly pictured by Mr. E. F. Knight. His "South Africa After the War" reveals the bad feeling of the Boers and their contempt for the English in certain portions of South Africa, and particularly in Cape Colony.

We do not think that the tone of Controller GROUT'S criticism of the Board of Education and the general management of the public schools is calculated to breed confidence in the soundness of his judgment. It is not the tone of a judge at all, but that of a partisan with rather deep prejudice to give sharpness to his comments.

In a hearing given by the Borough President of Manhattan on a petition of property owners and tenants for the asphalting of Park Row, the consensus of opinion was emphatically against the asphalting of that or any street in the business district of New York. The petition was favored by those whose interests were represented by the owners or occupants of office buildings because asphalted streets are pleasanter for pedestrians than streets otherwise paved.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25. -- Witful added another victory to her already long list this afternoon when she galloped home three lengths in front of her field in the Christmas Handicap, worth $1,537 to the winner. The track was heavy, Witful broke from the outside, was outrun through the first quarter, and only became a serious factor as the horses turned into the stretch.

With thirteen of the passengers of the Atlantic transport steamer Menominee, who had an exciting shipwreck story to tell, and several distinguished passengers besides, aboard the Cedric, came into port yesterday, one day late. Joshua Levering of Baltimore, the Prohibition candidate for President in McKinley and Bryan campaign, was among the arrivals.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Dec. 25. -- Thomas Hardy's drama called "The Dynasts," already mentioned in these cable dispatches, has been finished and will soon be published. The action passes in the time at the Napoleonic wars.

Though folk-lorists may not accept Mr. Adolph Roeder's theory as developed in his "Symbol Psychology," the ingenuity of it and its high moral tendency cannot be denied. In the introduction to the volume he gives the gist of his argument. Here is a dent on a bone; what brought about that dent? Certainly it arose from a physical cause.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The Department of Agriculture has made arrangements to establish a novel clearing house for plants on the Pacific Coast in connection with the expert station at Berkeley, Cal. The aim is to facilitate the introduction of tropical plants of all sorts, both ornamental and useful.

It is unfortunate that the theme chosen for this novel of Elizabethan days is one which cannot arouse interest or sympathy, for in the working out of that theme there is much which deserves commendation. Those portions of the book which deal with the religious conditions of the period are written not only with skill, but with sanity.

MEMPHIS, Term., Dec. 25. -- Christmas Day was celebrated here with great enthusiasm. In this section of the cotton belt almost unprecedented prosperity has followed in the wake of the rapid rise in the market price of the fleecy staple, and many fortunes have been won.

Dr. William H. Maxwell, City Superintendent of Schools, will address the People's Forum at New Rochelle to-morrow afternoon on "Education After the Elementary Day Schools." Whitelaw Reid will preside over the meeting, which will be held in the Public Library Hall in Main Street at 3 o'clock.

FIELD MARSHAL VISCOUNT WOLSELEY was born in 1833 in the County of Carlow, in Ireland. The family was originally English. In William III.'s time Brigadier-Gen. William Wolseley had followed the King through the Irish campaign.

The first volume of Dr. Vincent Henry Stanton's work on "The Gospels as Historical Documents," is published by the Macmillan Company. The author here examines the traces of the use of the Gospels and the indications of the manner in which they were regarded, afforded by the remains of early Christian literature; that is, the dates and the trustworthiness of the Gospels so far as these depend upon external evidence.

Prof. Wallace in a revised edition of his book, "The Wonderful Century," wrote four new chapters, and in the course of the studies which he made for those chapters he found that almost all writers on general asironomy, from Herschell to Newcomb, stated as an indisputable fact that our sun is situated in the plane of the Milky Way and very nearly in the centre of that ring.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The City of New York has just made the Borough of the Bronx a Christmas present of another little park.

AFTER a long period of reflection and keen observation of the habits and idlosyncrasien of his fellow creatures, Probate Judge Robert Grant has begun to put forth in monthly installments another study, in the form of fiction, of human aspirations, and shortcomings in the present hour, which promises to be as coherent and veracious and, to persons deeply interested in their fellow men, as absorbingly interesting as the same author's "Unleavened Bread."

Mrs. Gilman arraigns the home as it is, with an irresistible array of facts and with not n little pungent wit. She contrasts the home of universal idealization with the home of reality, and after the manner of Thackeray as regards gentlemen, practically invites us to take the fingers of one hand and count the happy homes we have known.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Prime Minister Balfour added considerably to the fun at Daly's on Saturday night by his manifest amusement at the references to him in Rutland Barrington's song, " It will all come right in the future." This song is one of the features of the "Country Girl," which is sure to provoke enthusiastic applause.

WASHINGTON, Des. 23. -- The President decided on a Christmas present for James Tanner, better known as "Corporal" Tanner, in the shape of an appointment to the office of Register of Wills for the District of Columbia. Louis A. Dent, the present Register, who was appointed by President Cleveland, has tendered his resignation, to take place in April.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- The anonymous letter-writer whose work has scandalized local society for several years has resumed his, or her, task and this week several men and women received notes about persons soon to be married. These notes in the past have usually been designed to injure brides and have caused much heart burning and directed some criticism to the postal inspectors who failed to put a stop to the writing.

THE characteristic material problem, of the nineteenth century," says the author in the preface to this little book, "was rapid transit, and it promises to be one of the most prominent sciences of the twentieth."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 -- Proper, the favorite, won the Christmas Handicap at Ingleside to-day. The race was somewhat marred by an accident at the start, which resulted in Oarsman, the second choice, being practically left at the post. Forest King collided with him, and Wonderly was content to gallop him after the field, as his chances were ruined.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The inventors of the airship which is said to have made several successful flights in North Carolina, near Kitty Hawk, are anxious to sell the use of their device to the Government. They claim that they have solved the problem of aerial navigation, and have never made a failure of any attempt to fly.

It will probably be recalled that about a year ago Longmans, Green Co. brought out in this country two volumes of diplomatic reminiscences by Sir Horace Rumbold. They will publish a further installment early in the new year. Sir Horace resumes his story in the Spring of 1873, when he was appointed British Minister at Santiago de Chile.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: IN YOUR review on Dec. 5 of my "Palaces and Prisons" of Mary Stuart, you make her last prison the Tower of London. Please pardon me, but the book holds no such statement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Exports of boots and shoes from the United States show a steady growth, and will for the calendar year about to end aggregate more than $7,000,000 in value. In 1893 they were less than three quarters of a million dollars in value.

The arm chair made from the wood of "Shakespeare's mulberry tree," which, was sold for u145 at Sotheby's last March, was again offered Dec. 7 at Puttick Simpson's auction rooms, London. This time the highest bid was u80, at which' sum it was apparently bought in by the owner, Mrs. Hillier, wife of the Rev. W. Hillier, rector of St. Luke's, Sheffield, and niece of one of the original possessors.

News which transformed the Christmas which she had expected would be the happiest of her life into the saddest, came to Lillian Bennett, a blue-eyed English girl, who arrived here yesterday on the Cedric. She was the betrothed of Ambrose Good, the young ironworker who was killed on Wednesday night in the wreck of the express train near Connellsville, while hurrying here to meet her.

Robert Fraser, D.D., Domestic Prelate of his Holiness Pius X., has translated into English "Studies on the Gospels," by Prof. Vincent Rose of the University of Fribourg. It is published in this country by Longmans, Green Co. In it are described a few circumstances of the life of Christ, while one or two chapters are given to His revelation.

VARIOUS are the results which may proceed from a novel' Miss Mary Catherine Crowley's "Love Thrives in War," a story of the Northern frontier in 1812, has aroused a Mr. Norton of Martha's Vineyard to the investigation of his family history, in which he has discovered some surprising things.
Copyright, 1903, by John R. Whitney. SUBJECT -- The boyhood of Jesus. -- Luke, ii., 40-52.

Because Congressman Timothy D. Sullivan and his big following have teen ignored by Mayor-elect McClellan and Charles F. Murphy in dealing out the patronage of the incoming administration, it is said that secret, but none the less bitter, protests have been made by friends of the Bowery politician to the powers of Tammany Hall.

Mr. HENRY WHITE, the Secretary of the United Garment Workers of America, is one of the most intelligent as well as one of the bravest of those identified with the leadership of the labor movement in this country. In a signed editorial article in The Bulletin of the Clothing Trades he says:

Joseph Buchanan has been a leader and organizer of laboring men. Much of his work for "the cause" was accomplished at a time when the labor movement in this country, was in its formative period and the struggle for recognition was keen and the campaign to convince and convert was intense.

The National Century Road Club Association will be governed next year by prominent cyclists, all of whom are hard workers for the interest of the wheel. At the annual meeting of the association these officers were elected:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Government having expended over two million dollars in publishing the official records of the civil war, both Union and Confederate, and placed the 129 volumes containing them in the libraries of every State, there is no excuse for writers on the war misstating the essential facts of any campaign.

In his new book, introduced with a modest yet sufficiently assertive preface, the author of "The True Napoleon" has compiled what may be well characterized as a "busy man's anthology" of English and French authors well worthy of remembrance. ("My Favorite Bookshelf." By Charles Josselyn. Cloth bound, with cover design by Gordon Ross. San Francisco: Paul Elder Co. $2 net.)

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in to-day's TIMES on "Conditions of Rapid Transit" is a welcome reference to a condition of affairs that demands the most careful attention of our city authorities who should take such conditions under advisement, with an eye to the needs of the near future, as well as to the present time.

THIS stout volume contains a collection of Col. Watterson's trenchant lectures and addresses. It enjoys the distinction in the realm of books of being the first hostage which the distinguished Louisville journalist has given to fortune.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Inquiry among Democratic Senators and Representatives shows that there exists a strong feeling of hopefulness for the success, of the Democratic candidates for President and Vice President at the election of 1904. This feeling is based on the belief that the Democrats are at least approximately harmonious, and that whatever factional feeling remains will be obliterated by the action of the National Convention in selecting candidates and formulating a platform.

Mrs. Logan informs her readers that her first introduction to life in Washington began in 1858, when Gen. Logan was a member of Congress. As the wife of a Senator, she became "an interested observer of passing events." The lady passed through many stormy political times. Her acquaintance was large, including all the prominent statesmen, the foreign diplomats, the commanders of the army and navy, with famous men of science and letters.

Urged on by his old time followers who have nothing to gain and everything to lose through the ascendancy of Gov. Odell to the State leadership of the Republican party, Senator Thomas C. Platt to-day will make his first active step toward overcoming the powers that the Governor has been taking to himself during the last few weeks.

This is a book about actors made, up of attractive pictures and some harmless facts and gossip. To begin with, the frontispiece is Julia Marlowe, looking quite, her best, and the first chapter, on Maude Adams, contains a number of very pleasing, reproductions of photographs of that actress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are many complaints about the quality of the gas furnished to consumers in this city, and there is plenty of cause to find fault. We are getting some gas, with a large percentage of wind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Herbert H.D. Peirce, Third Assistant Secretary of State, who has been investigating the case of Georgo E. Baldwin, United States Consul at Nuremberg, in connection with the inquiry into alleged Post Office frauds, has submitted to President Roosevelt a report fully exonerating the Consul.

II. The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Fred Lawrence challenges me, in his letter of the 12th inst., to state whether my "so-called" logic applies to the use of "we all" and "they all," as well as to the use of "you all." My "so-called" logic will not, nor will any other kind of logic.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 25. -- F.W. Vaille, Assistant Superintendent of the Railway Mail Service of this district, has been offered the position of Director General of the Postal Service in the Philippines. The position carries with it a salary of $6,000 per year.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 25. -- In connection with the Hanna boom for the Republican nomination for the Presidency next year, an interesting statement was given out here to-night by Perry S. Heath. He declared that it was the belief of President McKinley, just before he met his death at Buffalo, that Senator Hanna would be the next nominee of the Republicans and would be elected.

LONDON, Dec. 26. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says it will probably be a few weeks before the Court of Cassation takes up the Dreyfus case. Should it decide to send the case to a new court-martial another few weeks will elapse before the military tribunal assembles, so the final issue of the case is not yet at hand.

IT may be novel to most of us to learn that, according to prof. Edward Granville Browne of Cambridge, the number of believers of the Beha'i religion are now to be counted by the thousands in the United States.

This small volume of 145 pages ("Bismarck's Letters to His Wife from the Seat at War -- 1870-71." Translated by Armin Harder, Introduction by Walter Littlefield, New York: D. Appleton Co., $1 net.) fills an interesting hiatus in the large and authorized collection of Bismarckian correspondence published two years ago by Harper Brothers.

This book, one of a series on "American Philanthropy of the Nineteenth Century," is the story of work done and attempted in charity and correction along the lines of education and reform. It is very concise, being only a pocket volume, yet comprehensive, strictly to the point throughout, and free from, verbiage.

Christmas is less marred by bad weather than any other festive occasion, being essentially an indoor holiday, and that was the saving feature of yesterday. Rain and mud in town and country made going about anything but pleasant, and there was no snap in the air to give zest to the day. Railroads reported the usual exodus of New Yorkers, and in the city the day was one of quiet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- After a long conferecce to-day with Senator Warren of Wyoming regarding the latter's interest in a building leased by the Government for the Post Office at Cheyenne, Postmaster General Payne intimated that the case was closed. He said that before the expiration of a previous lease on March 1, 1800, the lessors wanted the rent raised from $1,400 to $1,900.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of this morning I notice a long editorial screed entitled "Is Oatmeal a Curse?" -- a headline which is borrowed from The London Mail, and introducing a subject which The Mail undertook to sensationalize, but which it found healthier to drop.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We are told that Christianity has effaced all traces of paganism, effectually doing away with hatred, and that the Golden Rule, if not lived up to, is practiced in most instances. Churches, temples, cathedrals galore we have preaches. Doctors of Divinity, and spiritual shepherds very numerous to guide our steps, and through their teaching give us better equipment to wage the warfare with sin.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- The jury of award in the water color exhibition has voted the following gold, silver, and bronze medals in the exhibition of the American Art Society, which closes at the New Rosenbach Galleries on Thursday next.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- Hampton L. Carson, Attorney General of Pennsylvania, is about to dispose of his collection of valuable prints and autographs, mainly Americana.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was surprised to see that you should so dignify the recent speech made by his Imperial Majesty the Emperor of Germany concerning the battle of Waterloo as to make it worthy of editorial comment.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 26. -- In the annual report of the Bureau of Labor and Statistics, which has just been sent to Gov. Murphy, the section dealing with child labor starts with the statement that this evil does not exist to any alarming extent in the State of New Jersey, and that as a concrete proposition it is not undesirable that children should be put to work in factories at an early age.

GOTHAN, Ala., Dec. 26. -- A cyclone passed over Dundee, a small place on the Central of Georgia Railway, yesterday. Several houses were blown down and two children of John Draughus were killed. A number of other persons were badly hurt.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26. -- Big Ben, favorite at evens, scored easily in the New Orleans Handicap, worth $1,290 to the winner, to-day. The favorite went to the front at once and was never in trouble, though Robbins made a show of riding him at the end when Captain Arnold was coming fast.

BREMEN. -- I visited the pleasant little village of Grambke, near Bremen, the other day, which has now become famous as the home of the "sleeping woman" Gesine Meyer, who has now awakened from her seventeen years' sleep.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 26. -- J.J. Carlisle, who was recently arrested in Washington, and brought here for trial, has been identified, according to the police, as Harry Silberbury, a swindler. The prisoner, suffering from recent exposure and disease, has collapsed and is believed to be dying.

In the museum of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences is now to be seen what, according to Its donor, is the most complete collection of representative chinaware on exhibition in the world. On the shelves in artistic arrangement are pieces coming from every factory that has made china from the earliest times of its European manufacture to the present day.

Among the measures which failed of passage in the last Congress, and have again been introduced at the present session is the one known as the Brownlow bill for National Aid in Road Building, prepared and introduced by Representative Walter P. Brownlow of Tennessee, which proposes the appropriation of $24,000,000 for division among the various States in proportion to population.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 26. -- Beautiful weather and the holiday season have made the past week one of unusual gayety. The Christmas greens, holly, and mistletoe, which grow in such abundance here, greet one everywhere and numerous informal social events have filled in the time. The popularity of the weekly hops at the Holly Inn is now well established and the Saturday afternoon teas at the Golf Clubhouse are much enjoyed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- A "Secret Service" organization which is intended to comprehend every law and order loving resident of Chicago is being formed by the Citizens' Anti-Crime Committee of twenty-five. Hundreds of letters to-day were prepared and signed by President Murry Nelson of the committee in prosecution of this plan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to a letter in to-day's issue signed "A Democrat," in which he prefers Olney or Gorman to Judge Parker as a candidate for the Presidency on the Democratic ticket and states that Judge Parker's principal qualification is only that of being an eminent jurist, while Olney and Gorman are eminent statesmen.

Haying been denied a laborer's job on the tunnel, he went up to the corner of Twentieth Street and Second Avenue, where he found Lawyer Joe Moss and a party of friends seated around a table in a rear room.

BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- For over sixteen weeks the attention of the German people has been directed to Krimmitschau, a textile centre in Saxony, where a most bitter strife is going on between labor and capital. The final outcome of this relentless contest will be followed by the most serious consequences, whatever party may win the fight.

The recognition of Panama by Great Britain completes the round of greetings from the great Powers to the new little republic. Next to ours Great Britain's recognition is the most important of all, since British diplomacy is punctilious in these matters and adheres to the correct practice of withholding recognition until the new Government has given evidence of ability to defend and maintain the sovereign status.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In common with many readers of THE TIMES, I was greatly surprised to notice, in the edition of last Sunday, the quite vigorous attack on the Rev. Edward Everett Hale. Such words coming from any one would contain a large element of the unexpected.

George Johnson, ten years old, of 25 East Twenty-fourth Street, yesterday attended the indoor sports of the Public School Athletic League in Madison Square Garden. He was in a balcony seat when Edward Flegenheimer, fifteen years old, of 891 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, in passing down an aisle brushed against him.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- The New York State fish hatchery at Rockland, Sullivan County, will probably be abandoned, and it is extremely unlikely that anything more will be attempted toward the propagation of fish in this locality. The Sullivan County hatchery has been a failure from the start, every season's work, it is said, having been nearly a total loss.

JAMES RANDOLPH CURTIS is a promising young man. He works for Smith Eldridge, dealers in mines of various assortments, oil wells, and stone quarries. Mr. Smith is manager of the firm. He likes James Randolph, and says that if he didn't have such an unmentionable kind of a fool for a wife he would amount to something some day.

THERE is much talk of forming an automobile club at Newport, Col. John Jacob Astor is one of the leading spirits. There is to be located a place for an extensive garage, and the building will be fitted up as a clubhouse. Col. Astor has sonic eighteen ears now in his garage at Ferncliff, which is the largest one in this country.
LEW DOCKSTADER runs into New York more or less these days on business connected with the engagment of his minstrels at the Victoria Theatre, which begins Jan. 4.

The past week has seen the unusual spectacle of coicident advances to high record figures of three great staples, each of which is dealt in on different exchanges in this city, namely, cotton, wheat, and coffee. Two of these commodities are articles of export, and the other, coffee, is a leading import.

President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University is the latest devotee of athletics at the Morningside institution Believing thoroughly in the tenet of a sound mind in a sound body he has very recently been an attendant at gymnasium work under the direction of the university instructors.

The boy was not known to be in the stable when on Christmas evening some men unhitched their horse from the truck. When they backed in Ferrogari was leaning against a post in the dark, and the hub of the rear wheel caught him and crushed him against the post.

NELLO swung his pushcart a little closer to the curb to escape the wheels of a passing dray, at the same time hurling a flood of objurgation at the driver. But there was no anger in his face, only a merry, good-natured alertness, mingled with the satisfaction of a profitable day and the joy of what was to come.

[Copyright, 1903.] LONDON, Dec. 26. -- King Edward's programme for the holiday season is quite consistent with the trend of his everyday life as disclosed in the news columns of the London papers. It illustrates the relation he sustains to his people in a very striking way.

An appeal for more members has just been made by the United States Golf Association, and at the same time Secretary Maturin Ballou of this city has announced that the annual meeting will be held on Thursday evening, Feb. 11, at Delmonico's. This is somewhat earlier than last year, and it will give the clubs selected to hold the annual championships so much more time to prepare for those events.

Before the Iowa Senators return to "Washington after the holiday season they will have been made aware, if they have not already had it impressed upon them, that Iowa people are more interested in the pending treaty to cede to the Republic of Cuba the celebrated Isles of Pines than are residents of any other State of the Union.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 26. -- The Pittsburg Athletic Club hockey team defeated the Princeton players at Duquesne Garden to-night by a score of 6 to 4. The local team scored twice in the first half and four times in the second. The Princetons made their first score in the first half and three in the last half.

For that large class of men and women whose lives are generally devoted to entertaining others the holiday season does not came as an unmixed blessing. It is more likely to be, on the contrary, a period of financial and mental depression.

A storm that originated somewhere out in South Dakota and wrought considerable damage as it moved eastward, reached this city early yesterday morning, carrying with it a cold wave that caused a big drop in temperature, and a sharp flurry of snow.

"A little over thirty years ago I had a strenuous adventure that might be interesting at this time, when there is so much doing in the new Republic of Panama," said Capt. J.C. Febiger of the New Orleans Naval Brigade, a son of Admiral Febiger, who was a hero of the war between the States, and for many years in the United States Navy.
