A report published yesterday told of James Gordon Bennett's idea of laying out a public park on his property, between Broadway and the Boulevard Lafayette, north of One Hundred and Eighty-second Street, as a memorial to his father. The report apparently was based upon the appearance of Mr. Bennett's representatives at a recent meeting of the Board of Estimate to make objections to a new street map which affects the territory in question.

I DO NOT believe a boy ever existed who some time during his childhood did not experience sensations of fear when left in the dark. It seems to be an inherent attribute of youth. I know how it was with my own childhood, and doubt if that of others has been much different.
President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard University has accepted an invitation to address a regular meeting of the Boston Central Labor Union to be held on Sunday, Feb. 7.

To The Editor of The New York Times: In the returns of your canvass of the States regarding the choice of a Democratic candidate for the Presidency there is a sad note from the Southern States. Nearly forty years ago the civil war ended, and yet there comes from a great historic State this report:

DIDO NATALI, a little three-year-old child, when being taught the Lord's Prayer, obediently repeated it after her mother until, coming to "Thy will be done," then with a reproving glance at her mother, she continued, "Thy will be finished." In vain her mother remonstrated with her.

The mystifying contradictions in the year's results in the railroad and in the financial world were added to by the reports from the various Vanderbilt railroads issued during the week. The development which attracts investigation is, of course, the increased dividend declared upon Lake Shore stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Fully 500 children were presented to Mrs. Roosevelt at the party given at the White House this afternoon, and such a patter of small feet has not been heard in the old mansion since the days of President Tyler, when another memorable children's party took place.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 26. -- A few nights ago one of the Sunday schools in South Orange had a Christmas tree festival, and small calibre rifles were given to several of the star pupils. Since that time there have been alarming events in South Orange. Window glaziers have done a rushing business, and several persons have been "winged."

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 26. -- It is very probable that the Silent Five basketball team of New York City, which was suspended last season for playing unsanctioned games, will be reinstated by the Amateur Athletic Union and permitted to arrange a series of games through the West and Middle West.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- The Erie station at Union was robbed yesterday for the second time within a few weeks, and the method employed by the thieves was very similar to the first robbery. This time the thieves made a haul, owing to the large amount of express packages on hand, but the exact amount taken cannot be learned.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26. -- Kenilworth won the six-and-a-half-furlong race, which was the feature of the card at Ingleside today. It was a lucky victory, as Gold Money, who was beaten half a length, was knocked on the fence at the start and thrown out of the race. It was her first start here, and she was plunged on.
PARIS, Dec. 26. -- Exceptionally dull and foggy weather has characterized Christmas.
AN Englishwoman visiting in New York last year was more impressed with the size and number of our candy stores than with almost anything else the metropolis possessed.

By far the most significant of last week's real estate doings were centred in the block on Thirty-fourth Street between Broadway and Fifth Avenue. The erection of a new building on the Loomis property, running through from Thirty-fourth to Thirty-fifth Street, will bring to that thoroughfare perhaps the largest mercantile house that has yet taken up quarters there, and is likely to exert a very strong influence in shaping the lines of its future development.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 26. -- Ideal weather has favored the great host of holiday visitors here. Riding, driving, skating, golf, and trap shooting are some of the diversions that furnish day enjoyment for them, and in the evening there are concerts and dances at the hotels and bridge whist parties.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 26. -- Eastern investors are turning from speculative stocks and asking for Western farm mortgages. Agents in Central Kansas are receiving many applications for such investments, and are doing a larger business than for two years.
ROME, Dec. 26. -- Ex-Premier Zanardelli died this evening at Maderno, near Brescia, sixty miles from Milan. He was seventy-four years old.

ALBANY, Dec. 27. -- By a divided vote the State Railroad Commission has denied the application of the New York City Interborough Railway Company for permission, under Section 59 of the railroad law, to construct its railroad in the Borough of the Bronx, Commissioners Dunn and Baker voting against and Commissioner Dickey for the application.

The West Side Lyceum, a four-story building at the northwest corner of Fifty-second Street and Seventh Avenue, was destroyed by fire yesterday afternoon. The structure contained a large hall on the second floor, used for rehearsals and entertainments, and the offices of several theatrical companies.

A GROUP of three brown gowns were seen together at a luncheon during the week. One, of golden brown broadcloth, had a narrow band of sable perhaps six inches from the skirt's edge. The Eton coat had wide, turned back revere bordered with sable, and the outer sleeves, which flowed from the elbow, were also bordered with fur, as was the wide collar.

BROCKWAY the counterfeiter, now at Trenton nearing the end of one of his numerous terms of imprisonment, stands as an emblem of antiquity as well as crime, and Eld, the hoar, that in the vauntward bore the banner before death, could hardly have presented a figure of more uncompromising mid-Winter aspect.

Beautifying a State. WHENEVER I see any of these propagandas for beautifying a city," said Senator Perkins of California the other night, "I always think of the work done to beautify the State of California by a citizen of Altadena, which is hard by Pasadena.

ROME, Dec. 26. -- The Osservatore-Romano, the Vatican organ, contains another and, it is said, more important answer to that part of the speech of Count Coluchowski, the Austrian Foreign Minister, delivered Dec. 16, which referred to the veto of Austria against Cardinal Rampolla at the last conclave.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The resume in your issue of Dec. 18, under the title of "A New London Disease," of recent correspondence in The London Daily Mail on the subject of "brain fag" can hardly fail to have interested a large number of similar sufferers on this side of the water.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- A State official with conscientious scruples unbosomed himself to-day in a matter which he said had frequently come into his thoughts. He confessed that many public officials, judicial, State, and county, draw on expense funds for their personal expenses.
SENATOR STEWART, while traveling in Nevada, stood on the platform of the coach and was approached by a conductor.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 26. -- All of the hotel men report the largest number of visitors over the holidays they have ever known here. The day was observed in all the hotels with sumptuous dinners, and a mammoth tree was erected at the Hotel Jackson. The colored servants of the Hotel Wiltshire gave an old-fashioned minstrel show and were rewarded by the guests with substantial purses.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- Figures of the foreign trade of Philadelphia during 1903, compiled by Collector Thomas, with December estimated, show a slight decrease in the total as compared with 1902. This is due almost entirely to the falling off in the exports of wheat, lard, and one or two other articles.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

While irregularities in the lines of a building site may very often make almost insurmountable structural difficulties, on the other hand they may prove of inestimable value when the building stands completed. That this is true in the case of the new building of THE NEW YORK TIMES can be realized by the veriest layman when its great espanse of frontage is taken into consideration.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 26. -- Wheat exporters here say they have never seen a holiday demand for grain from the other side the Atlantic as exists now. Usually at this season the foreign buyer is quiescent. Now he is sending in bids on an allrail basis that could be worked if there were the wheat on hand.

BOSTON, Dec. 26. -- In the blinding snowstorm which swept Boston Harbor this afternoon the new Clyde Line steamship Kiowa, inward bound from Jacksonville, Fla., and Charleston, S.C., was rammed and sunk by the steamship Admiral Dewey of the United Fruit Company line, outward bound for Port Antonio and Jamaica.

"If one wants to get plenty of excitement let him try to catch a runaway engine," said a railroad engineer the other day. "I had the experience some years ago, and I shall always remember it as one of the principal events of my career as an engineer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- A statement made by Senator Stone of Missouri, published here to-day, explaining the attitude of Democratic Senators toward the Panama treaty attracted attention and excited general comment.

After an extended tour through the county Eleanor Robson comes here to the Garden Theatre to appear in Israel Zangwill's "Merely Mary Ann." Were success, "in the provinces" always a forerunner of success in New York, Miss Robson would have no chance of being unfavorably received when she made her appearance to-morrow Evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The public is often apt to criticise unjustly a politician or statesman whose name happens to be before the people. When he has been dead so long that he cannot hear their praises they pass resolutions and erect monuments and tear themselves to pieces in an effort to do justice to his memory.

Just after midnight this morning there was a fire at the bachelor apartment house 39 West Thirty-sixth Street, which owing to its peculiar situation, the extreme cold weather, and the bursting of several lines of hose made the blaze an awkward one for the firemen to fight.

The crowning feature of the coming week at the Metropolitan Opera House will, of course, be the second performance of "Parsifal." Public interest in Richard Wagner's master work has only been whetted by the first representation and is likely to grow deeper and keener the more the wonderful festival play becomes familiar. "Parsifal" will be interpreted on Thursday next, Dec. 31, by the artists who were heard at the first performance.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 26. -- Favorites won the first two races at Ascot Park today and well-played second choices were successful in all the others excepting the fifth. This went to Hartin Brady at 20 to 1, and was the biggest upset of the day. Ransch's riding of F.E. Shaw and Bragg, both of which he landed in front, was the popular feature of the day.

SO near is glory to our dust." Once in a while, from out the dreary every-dayness of our bread-and-butter lives flashes this truth, and for an hour thereafter commonplaces wear halos and every mud puddle seems to mirror a morning star. But between flashes we forget.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If in asserting in your article on Herbert Spencer that his philosophy has survived attack you mean only that it has retained its vogue, notwithstanding such attacks as have been considered by those who still adhere to their belief in it, the fact is too nearly self-evident to admit of question.

The break-up of the United States Ship-building Company promises to be productive of litigation historic both for multiplicity of actions and complication of issues involved. This needs little comment after the months of newspaper stories about the case, but it may not be untimely to point out in this gigantic legal tangle certain phases that are of interest by way of warning to the different classes of people who suffered financially in the enterprise.

PARIS, Dec. 15. -- Whether or not the Bonapartist party is gaining ground in France, it is certain that the anniversary of Dec. 10, 1848, when Prince Napoleon was elected President of the French Republic by over 5,000,000 votes, was celebrated by far greater numbers of persons this year than ever before.

There is now pending in the House of Representatives of the United States a little bill appropriating a couple of thousand dollars or so "for the relief of the Methodist Episcopal Church, (colored,) corner of Fifth Avenue and East Second Street, Rome, Ga." The claim has a curious history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Rear Admiral Stirling, temporarily in command of the Asiatic station, cables the Navy Department announcing the departure of the gunboat Vicksburg to-day from Shanghai for Chemulpo, Korea, where she has been ordered at the instance of Mr. Allen, the American Minister at Seoul.

BARTOW, Fla., Dec. 26. -- Shortly after dark on Thursday night twenty-five ,or thirty armed men came into this city, and for a time it was thought that they would be able to get Berry Henry, the negro who is in jail here on a charge of shooting and wounding Col. and Mrs. John Beatty on that day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Grand Trunk Railway Company has deposited with the Government of Canada $5,000,000 in value of its first mortgage bonds as security for the prompt construction of a railway from Port Simpson, at the entrance of Portland Channel, on the Pacific, to the City of Quebec.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -- Judge Isaac E. Johnson to-day heard the application for the appointment of a receiver for the Tidewater Steel Company of Chester. The hearing lasted from 9 o'clock in the morning until far into the evening. His decision, he said, would be given on Monday.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- It was learned in authoritative quarters to-day that Japan is about to send a large military force to Korea, for the purpose of restoring and maintaining order at the disturbed ports. The departure of this force is imminent. It will probably consist of a division of 15,000 men.

The name "Republic of Colombia" conveys but a vague idea to even our most intelligent citizens. In a hazy way, a picture of a vast undeveloped country, a land of dense tropical forests, and great rivers, a fabled El Dorado, above all a country of revolutions and turbulent political conditions, rises dimly before one.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- The inquiry in the Fair will case closed here this afternoon, when Edmund Kelly, counsel for Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr., and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, delivered an argument before Judge Eissler, the commissioner appointed to take testimony in the case, in which he endeavored to show that Dr. Perrlque, who testified that Mrs. Fair died last, made an inconsistent statement.
THE Philippine Archipelago might be called the Rip Van Winkle of the seas, though instead of only twenty years its people have slumbered for hundreds.

The intense cold weather and a wind blowing at the rate of between fifty and sixty miles an hour did not deter what are termed the "staiwart" shooters of the Crescent Athletic Club from participating in the usual weekly competitions at the Bay Ridge traps yesterday. Yet, with the rather severe handicap, fourteen shivering shooters took part in one or more of the six events, and acquitted themselves creditably.

Men in the silk trade are somewhat agitated by the Russian-Japanese situation. While the war talk has not yet had any apparent effect upon the market, yet the possibilities are being considered and quietly discussed among manufacturers and importers. The danger of an armed conflict, which might have a most important bearing upon their business, is in the minds of all, as a prominent merchant expressed it.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I was much interested in your editorial on Panama and Secession. In spite of your argument, it seems to me that the recognition of Panama is a recognition of the fact that secession is permissible when possible, and that the action of the United States at this time is in direct opposition to its avowed principles regarding the issues of the civil war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The report of Major Little and his force of inspectors who are investigating conditions in the New York Post Office, will probably be made in two or three weeks. The investigation has been suspended during the Christmas holidays.

The line of "old gold men" stood eight deep in the shop of the Maiden Lane smelter, each awaiting his turn while the bustling, little fat man behind the screen weighed and tested the yellow cast-offs and decided how much to pay for each lot: Not until the last speculator had swept some twenty dollars off the counter, the product of his preceding day's work, did the smelter find time to talk.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 26. -- A man of medium size, well-dressed, with sandy hair and smoothly-shaven face, entered a pawnshop adjoining Havlin's Theatre last Thursday morning and told a story that touched a sympathetic spot in the pawnbroker's heart.

On the broken week's business there is not a point's difference in the average values of either industrials or railways. It is difficult to imagine a smaller price movement, or with less significance. Doubtless this will surprise many who have received an impression of general activity and wide price changes from the spectacular ups and downs of a few specialties.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 26. -- Fresh denials of any intention to charge exorbitant rates during the Republican National Convention next Summer were made to-day by the managers of the Chicago down-town hotels.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent compilation of the church statistics of Manhattan Island tends toward an optimistic view of the religious situation. Especially is this true when we recall the visit of Dowie and his Zionists to the "unregenerate city." In fact, it seems that Dowie was not apparently interested so much in the "unregenerates" as in a continuous tirade against newspaper men and various well-known divines.

The holidays bring a breathing spell in which, to "loaf and invite the soul," or if not, to loaf, then at least to invite the shy imaginings of the two modern playwrights who are more purely and resolutely spiritual than any of their fellows, and whose souls, being mystical in their bent by theory as well as by practice, elude pursuit as surely as they challenge it.

THE Warren family are very artistic. Whitney Warren is an architect and Lloyd Warren is also interested in the arts. For the coming out of Miss Warren her family arranged several original entertainments. These included a theatre party to the French play and a costume dance.

Certainly no dramatic performance, "lyric" or other, has ever been more extensively advertised in advance than the first production of "Parsifal" in New York. It may be questioned whether any other has ever been so extensively advertised. For over twenty years the "sacred festival play" has been performed in the little Bavarian Mecca, to the stage of which the author intended it to be confined.

Wholly aside from the advantages which new streets may possess, as affording more direct lines of travel, the opening of them through built-up sections of the city is a matter of special interest to real estate men on account of the many peculiar bits of property usually developed in the process.

In the rear of a little restaurant in East Twenty-third Street last night sixty-six young women who are anxious to represent New York at the physical culture show which is to take place at the Madison Square Garden this week posed before a jury of sculptors and illustrators. The announcement had been made that it was to be a dress rehearsal, but it proved the opposite.

The statement that the initial set of games of the Public School Athletic League of the City of New York, which were held yesterday afternoon and evening at Madison Square Garden, was the most important athletic meeting which has ever taken place in the United States would scarcely be an exaggeration.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- It can truly be said that the new Minister of War, Gen. von Einem, literally won his present position by a neat speech. In the last session of the Reichstag, while assistant to the then Minister von Gessler, he answered a Socialist member of the House with a very happy quotation from Schiller.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the saying that "the field is the world" is true of anything it is true of labor and capital. There is no tariff on either, and in this age of steam and electricity all nations are neighbors and supply follows demand so rapidly that commerce has become a constantly turning kaleidoscope presenting a new view at every turn.

Just now this community seems to be suffering from an epidemic of attempted blackmail through the medium of threatening letters. It is the natural development of the no longer profitable expedient of collecting money by means of the begging letter, which has been worked to exhaustion and lost its power to elicit satisfactory responses even from the sympathetic.
NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 26. -- Major and Mrs. Theodore K. Gibbs gave a children's entertainment at their cottage on Gibbs Avenue this afternoon in honor of their adopted daughter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It may interest some of your readers to learn that the gallant Southern soldier Gen. Henry Kyd Douglas, who died in his home at Hagerstown, Md., on Friday last, was, like his famous commander, "Stone-wall" Jackson, in the Confederate Army, of Irish descent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The War Department's mail from the Philippines to-day includes copies of The Manila Times, containing an account of an execution by garroting, which seems to show that in unskillful hands the garrote is an ineffective instrument.

Her Charms. HE is like all lovers, and can talk of nothing besides the young woman to whom he is devoted. He sat in the club window smoking and thinking of her; then suddenly he blurted out, directing his remarks to the man who was deep in the news of an evening paper:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Gen. Serrell, published in the Sunday TIMES on the Darien-Mandingo Canal, leads me to express the regret, which any one who is acquainted with that project must feel, at the disregard shown by Congress of the natural and commercial advantages afforded by the San Blas route.

WOODLAWN, Wis., Dec. 26. -- At a meeting held at Sandusky the Lone Rock Valley Railroad Company was organized with William Reuschlein, M.R. Prouty, W.M. Rowe, Henry Kohlmeyer, C.E. Bohn, John Doyle, Edward Roach, Henry Duren, Lee Fisher, N.L. James, and George Jameson as Directors.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- "It is preposterous to talk about a 'short session' of the Legislature this year," said Gov. Odell this afternoon. "I believe the coining session will be one of the most important in recent years. It is absurd to attempt to sit down in December and say either what will be done or how long the session will last."
YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Word has been received here from Charleston, W. Va., that Mrs. Albert W. Lilienthal has received, a divorce from Capt. Albert W. Lilienthal of this city.

To the Editor of The New York Times. In commenting upon the remarks made by Senator Platt on Thursday last as to the proposed amendment of the liquor tax law permitting saloons to be open on Sunday from 1 to 11 P.M. the Senator assumed the attitude of the saying, "I am the State."

A correspondent signing himself "Democrat," and hailing from Connecticut, where the breed of Democrats is usually sturdy, writes us that he thinks "perhaps it may be better that we [the Democratic Party] should not succeed next year."
Charles F. Murphy, State Senator Patrick H. McCarren; and Mayor-elect George B. McClellan kept much to themselves yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- It is already becoming tolerably evident that Senator German's leadership is likely to receive another setback. He is unlikely to be able to hold his followers in their attitude of what the South regards as hostility to the Panama Canal.

The Central Federated Union yesterday agreed after a long debate to stand for another mass meeting to be called and paid for by the Free Speech League to protest against the deportation of Turner, the English Anarchist.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Dec. 27. -- A dispatch from, South McAlister, Indian Territory, to The Record says: " A bold bank robbery, attended by a desperate battle between a posse of citizens and robbers, occurred at Kiowa, a small town sixteen miles south of this city, to-day. The robbers secured and destroyed about $28,000 which was in the bank.

There were two holidays last week, and the volume of business was smaller than for several years. The tone of business, however, was strong, although professional, and markedly so among the specialties which were marked up on narrow dealings. The concentration of the market appears from the fact that only 56 stocks moved as much as a point, and of them 45 advanced.

The Slavs of Ohio have founded a Slavic Alliance in Cleveland with the ostensible purpose of holding exhibitions, publishing reports, and delivering lectures, the burden of which is to be what clever people the Slavs really are and how mistaken are the impressions that Americans have gained concerning them from their many ill-wishers in Europe, impressions very much the opposite of the facts.

PARIS. -- Colonel Renard, the aeronaut, and M. Surcouf, an engineer, have invented a new "auto-motor railless train," which, according to M. Maurice Levy, of the Academy of Sciences, will revolutionize road traffic, and may one day to some extent supersede railways. Small models were first built, but a full-sized train of ten cars, weighing thirty tons, has been now constructed, and tested, and will be exhibited at the Automobile Salon.

A new epoch in sport is promised by the Physical Culture Exhibition Company at the Madison Square Garden this week, beginning to-day, and the programme comprises almost every form of competitive exercises, in which leading performers in their various lines will demonstrate their prowess.
LONDON, Dec. 3. -- Readers of The Times this morning were puzzled to find the following mysterious notice on the front page:
Footpads were busy in Brooklyn early yesterday morning, two men being knocked down and robbed in front of their homes, their alleged assailants falling into the clutches of the police.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many Democrats believe that they will elect their candidate for President next year, provided that Judge Parker or some equally strong man is nominated. For one, I am perfectly indifferent, and think perhaps it may be better that we should not succeed next year.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 13. -- The Radical and Socialist newspapers throughout the country have begun a violent anti-royalist and republican campaign against King Leopold as a result of the sovereign's address to the Senators in response to their congratulations on the birth of Prince Albert's second son.

The Automobile Club of America is taking considerable interest just now in commercial vehicles of the light and heavy types and proposes to give a practical demonstration of their usefulness. The Contest Committee of the club, at a recent meeting, selected March 15 and 16 for a contest between such vehicles, and it is expected many of the kind will be exhibited.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27. -- Gen. MacArthur returned to-day on the steamship Siberia, from the Hawaiian Islands, where he has been making a military inspection. The General is in good health, enjoyed his trip, and was greatly pleased with the islands, which he termed "a most valuable acquisition to the United States."

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The Peking correspondent of The Times urges that the British should make preparations to meet the situation in the Far East which is likely to arise in case of war between their ally and Russia.

State Committeeman Timothy E. Ellsworth, representing in that capacity the Counties of Niagara, Livingston, Orleans, Genesee, and Wyoming, visited Senator Thomas C. Platt at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, as did Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott and Deputy Secretary of State J.H.B. Mongin, leader of Seneca. To-day the Senator expects half a dozen leaders to call upon him, and about the same number each day from now until Jan. 4.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Representative James D. Richardson of Tennessee will retire from public life with the termination of the Fifty-eighth Congress, which will give him twenty-six years of continuous service in Congress. Having been chosen Supreme Commander of the Southern Jurisdiction of the Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite, Mr. Richardson decided upon giving up politics and devoting himself to his Masonic duties.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The Dally Mail's Kobe correspondent asserts that the Japanese Army authorities have requested the newspapers to refrain from publishing news concerning the movements of troops or other warlike preparations.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 27. -- The death list resulting from the head-on collision between two Pere Marquette Railroad passenger trains near East Paris early yesterday evening stands to-night at twenty-two, four of whom are unidentified. Twenty-nine persons were injured, several of them probably fatally.

ALBANY, Dec. 27. -- The rate of wages in New York City has increased over 10 per cent. since 1897, While in the same time the proportion of working time lost by organized wage earners has declined from 3O.3 per cent. to 13.9 per cent. This, combined with the advance in rates of wages, yields an estimated increase in yearly, earnings of 36 per cent., which is much larger than the increased cost of living.

-- Ever since the North German Lloyd steamer Hohenzollern came in last week with the story of how her sailors had refused to answer the request of the master of a disabled bark, encountered off Nantucket, for three men to help him into port, people whose knowledge of nautical matters is a quantity either extremely minute or actually minus have been bow-wowing vehemently in many newspapers about the display of disgraceful cowardice then made.

when the question is asked, Who is to be the Presidential candidate of the Democracy next year? many names are "mentioned," but Democrats the country over seem to be agreed upon one thing. They favor the nomination of "anybody who can carry New York." It ought not to be put that way.

ALBANY, Dec. 27. -- Results of the first month's operation of the new child labor law show a decline from 831 to 595, a reduction of 30 per cent. in the number of employment certificates issued to children. The falling off, which is chiefly in New York City, is largely due to the stricter educational requirements now in force.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Preparatory to leaving for Australia, John Alexander Dowie bade farewell to his Chicago adherents at a meeting in the Auditorium to-day.

GALVESTON, Dec. 27. -- Whether Granville W. Garth, President of the Mechanics' National Bank of New York, was the victim of self-destruction or an accident while a passenger on board the steamship Denver, on the way from New York to Galveston, may never be known. That he met his death by drowning is declared by every one on board the steamship, which was delayed two hours searching the sea in the night for the body.

The veteran correspondent of The London Times in China, according to our cable dispatches, is urging the British Government to take prompt steps to cheek the policy of Russia toward the Government of Peking in view of a possible conflict between Russia and Japan. He reports that the Japanese Minister, Mr. UCHIDA, at the Chinese capital, is exhausting every means to check the plans of Russia to involve China.
Dr. Still's theory that evildoing in children is not "naughtiness" but "moral imbecility" has presented an absolutely new problem to the mothers of Great Britain.

At no time since the present handball season opened has such a large gathering of visitors and experts attended the regular Sunday games in Casey's Brooklyn court as that which crowded the gallery and peeproom there yesterday. Many interesting matches were played, but the one which attracted the greatest amount of attention was the one in which two of the youngest players in the Brooklyn Handball Club met and defeated two much older experts.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- The man arrested yesterday at Niagara Falls, Ontario, under the name of "F.S. Hall," admitted to-day that he is James Nelson Abeel, against whom an indictment is pending in New York for impersonating J. Ogden Goelet in an effort to marry Miss Eleanor Anderson of New York.
CAPE TOWN, Dec. 27. -- A general insurrection has broken out among the Bondelzwarts tribes in Great Namaqualand, German Southwest Africa.

The Rev. Dr. Cortland Myers, pastor of the Baptist Temple, Brooklyn, who on Wednesday last sent a letter to Police Commissioner Greene, calling his attention to the existence of seventy-two alleged poolrooms in the city, and asserting that the Commissioner had been lax in suppressing such places, last night gave out another long statement in criticism of the Commissioner and Deputy Commissioner Piper.

Our Albany dispatches this morning give some interesting facts from the latest bulletin of the State Department of Labor. On the one hand it is reported that the proportion of working time lost by organized workingmen during the year ending with September was but 13.9 per cent., as compared with 30.3 per cent. in the year 1897, while the rate of wages has advanced 10 per cent.

Tony Pastor, who refuses to grow old because every Sunday following Christmas he seizes the chance to appear in his own theatre as Santa Claus, minus the gray beard, was the master of ceremonies yesterday afternoon at a performance, billed as a "sacred concert and Christmas festival of the little children of the stage."

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 27. -- Winton C. Garrison, Chief of the State Bureau of Labor and Statistics, expressed astonishment to-day at the criticisms that had been passed on his report, which, he said, were not justified.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 27. -- Gen. John Newman Andrews, aged sixty-five years, died to-day at Montpelier, Va., where he had been visiting. His home was near this city.

We trust that the article by Mr. CARL SCHURZ in the January number of McClure's, entitled "Can the South Solve the Negro Problem?" will be read widely in all sections of the country, and especially in the South. It is the candid and reasoned appeal of a statesman of great ability and of extraordinary experience and knowledge of his subject, to the reason and conscience of the intelligent men of the South.

SENOIA, Ga., Dec. 27. -- Fire early to-day totally destroyed the cotton warehouse of Couch Co. with 250 bales of cotton and 350 tons of guano, entailing a loss of $50,000, partially covered by insurance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The official receptions of New Year's Day will be more elaborate than in many years, and will call out the entire body of official society either as visitors or to assist in receiving.

According to a report made yesterday to the Central Federated Union by James P. Archibald, representing a committee of the central body appointed to try to induce the Iron League to recognize Local No. 2 in some way, it was useless for the committee to continue its efforts.
BOSTON, Dec, 28 -- The easy tone which characterized the money market last week has given way to a firmer one.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The Times's correspondent at Tangier says that Kaidel Mahediel Menebhi, the retiring Minister of War, left Tangier yesterday for Mecca. Before starting he distributed a large sum of money and a quantity of clothing to the Mohammedan poor.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- David Belasco and John Luther Long's Japanese play, "The Darling of the Gods," which was produced at His Majesty's Theatre last night by Beerbohm Tree before a distinguished audience that filled every part of the house, promises to be one of the greatest successes yet achieved in London theatricals.

COLON, Dec. 28 -- Rear Admiral Coghlan's flagship, the cruiser Olympia, arrived here this afternoon from Cartagena bringing A.M. Beaupre, United States Minister to Colombia, and Mrs. Beaupre. Minister and Mrs. Beaupre arrived at Cartagena from Bogota last Saturday and boarded the Olympia on her arrival yesterday afternoon.

Senator Platt's conferences were continued yesterday, and a dozen up-State leaders visited the Senator, both at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and at his office at 49 Broadway. Some of them were men classed as Odell leaders, but all ostentatiously waved the olive branch about the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel and insisted that Platt still is the leader.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 28 -- The committee of the Canadian Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which met the National Association representatives recently, did not fix permanent dates for the two regattas, but the National committee was willing to allow the Canadian dates in the first week of August to stand.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day for year-end requirements. Discounts were easy.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- Plans for the extension of the Broad Street train shed across Filbert Street to Cuthbert Street, from Fifteenth to Seventeenth Street, were disclosed by the Pennsylvania Railroad today in opposing the proposed boulevard from City Hall to Fairmount Park at a hearing before the Board of City Surveyors.

Roger Morris Park, in which is situated the historic Jumel Mansion, was formally opened yesterday afternoon. The park, which is about two blocks square, runs between One Hundred and Sixtieth and One Hundred and Sixty-second Streets, along Jumel Place. It comprises all that is left of the large estate originally owned by Roger Morris, an officer in the British Army, who went to England at the close of the Revolutionary War.
John H. Berry, has sold for the Brogan Construction Company, for about $125,000, the new six-story elevator apartment house 540 and 542 West One Hundred and Twelfth Street, 50 by 100.

A lively discussion occurred yesterday at the regular meeting of Methodist ministers at 150 Fifth Avenue over the question as to whether the so-called "amusement paragraph," otherwise Section 248 in the Book of Discipline of the Methodist Epis- copal Church, should be eliminated or amended.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- According to Representative John Dougherty of Missouri, Senator Cockrell's boom for the Presidency, is seriously meant and is a thing to be reckoned with.

To make a new charge against the newspapers would probably be impossible, but Dr. PARKHURST succeeded Sunday evening in giving a new twist to the old accusation that our interest is all for criminals and calamities, and that we have no attention to bestow upon virtuous folks and benign events.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- The auxiliary cruiser Dixie sailed from the League Island Navy Yard to-day for Colon, carrying 600 marines and five months' living and fighting supplies for 1,000 men. Six companies of marines divided into two battalions sailed on the Dixie, in command of Col. Elliott.
PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The grounds upon which Dreyfus depends for vindication and restoration to the army have been communicated to The Associated Press.

There is one phase of the working of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S proposed plan of protection to which not so much attention has been paid as it deserves. It is the possible effect in changing the fiscal policy of our own country.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 -- Capt. S.S. Brown's Docile, which ran gamely but had poor racing luck in the first race, was the only beaten favorite to-day. Weather clear; track fast. Summary:

Business Broadening -- Nearly twice as much business was transacted on the Stock Exchange yesterday as had been done the day before Christmas, and, instead of a continuation of the reactionary tendency which appeared at the close of that day, prices resumed the advance with very little hesitation and closed much above the final prices of last week.

The Visible Typewriter Company, with salesrooms at 243 Broadway, factory at 338 Pearl Street, and branch sales offices in Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago, and Detroit, is temporarily embarrassed and unable to meet maturing obligations. A petition in bankruptcy was filed against the company yesterday by Frank L. Crocker, attorney for Jonathan H. Holmes, a creditor for $2,000 on assigned claim for money loaned to the company by William F. Cochrane, Jr.

The Cuban reciprocity treaty, in accordance with the terms of which there is a reduction of 20 per cent, in the duty on sugar, tobacco, and other Cuban staples imported to this country, went into effect yesterday morning. In consequence the customs officials were kept busy making collections on sugar and tobacco stored in the bonded warehouses, the importers being allowed to obtain it on the payment of the new and lower duties.

There were three debutantes! dances last evening, and these made the events of the day. The last of the Monday musicales at the Waldorf-Astoria was given, and there was a large and fashionable audience present. Mrs. Dwight Arven Jones will give a dance this evening, and there will also be the second of the fortnightly dances at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ROME, Dec. 28 -- After long discussion with experts, principally with the famous composer, the Abbe Perosi, Director of the Sistine Choir, the Pope has issued of his own accord a note on the subject of sacred music in churches.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28 -- Nearly 1,000 members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science gathered here today at the first session of the fifty-third annual convention of the association, which will remain in session, the rest of the week.

Arrangements for the inauguration of Mayor-elect McClellan at noon on Friday were completed yesterday, when Mayor Low received John H. O'Brien, Secretary to Col. McClellan, and together they mapped out the programme. The general procedure was suggested by Mayor Low, and agreed to by Mr. O'Brien, acting for the Mayor-elect.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- Transactions were not large in the aggregate, but they included a larger number of different issues than is usual. Prices were firm to strong. General Asphalt preferred being a feature, with an advance of 3 3/4 points; American Railways and American Cement rose fractionally, while Lehigh Valley moved up easily 1 1/8 per cent.

Directors of the Mechanics' National Bank, at 33 Wall Street, the President of which, Granville W. Garth, was drowned in the Gulf of Mexico from the Mallory Line steamship Denver on Christmas night, held a special meeting yesterday morning, in which they confirmed the statement given out by Vice President Alexander E. Orr on Sunday, and adopted resolutions of sympathy with the family.

The officially announced appointments added yesterday to the list of Mayor McCLELLAN are of little importance and of no great interest except as showing that the standard of selection does not improve as the number of vacant places lessens and the pressure of the machine is iutensified.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 28 -- In official circles here the delay in presenting Russia's reply to Japan is not regarded as ominous. On the contrary, the fact that Russia, in accordance with Japan's request, is actually reviewing the matters in dispute is regarded as a favorable sign.

Owing to a hitch over the selection of a Street Cleaning Commissioner Mayor-elect McClellan did not announce the remainder of his slate last night. Patrick H. Keahon, the Tammany leader in the Seventh District, still is an active candidate for the place; but in Tammany circles last night it was said that his chances of appointment are not as bright as they appeared to be two or three days ago.

MEDIA, Penn., Dec. 28 -- Judge Johnson to-day refused the application of the investment company of Philadelphia for the appointment of a receiver for the Tidewater Steel Company of Chester. The plaintiff company alleged that the Tidewater Company had been insolvent since its foundation.

Stocks strong. Call money steady, 4 1/2 @6 per cent. Yesterday's stock market highly pleased those who are "bulls upon prices," meaning that the speculative situation and the prolonged decline warrant a market advance irrespective of values.

We have already alluded to the provisions of a bill introduced by Mr. HILL of Connecticut relating to the subsidiary coinage, provisions that would undoubtedly be very advantageous to general trade. The same bill, which is modestly entitled "To Improve Currency Conditions," contains other features of considerable importance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 -- The racing at Ingleside to-day was marked by close finishes, four of the events being taken by narrow margins. Position won the fourth race by a neck from G.W. Trahern. Illowaho, favorite, made a poor showing. Summary:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- All fashionable Washington gathered at the Peruvian Legation this afternoon, where the Minister and Mme. Calderson gave a very pleasant reception in honor of their second daughter, Miss Rosita Calderon, who enjoy's the distinction of being the only debutante from the diplomatic circle.
Frank H. Burness, who has confessed to the killing of four men, was arraigned for sentence yesterday morning before Judge Crane.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The Daily Telegraph's Tokio correspondent says:

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 28 -- Albert C. Twining, ex-President of the defunct Monmouth Trust Company of Asbury Park, and David C. Cornell, ex-Treasurer of that institution, to-day were found guilty by a jury before Judge Heisley of having falsified the accounts of the company. The convicted men were allowed to go under bail to await sentence.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., Dec. 28 -- John M. Glover, formerly Representative from Missouri, to-day defied the militia, barricaded himself in his office, and surrendered only after receiving a bullet wound in the arm.

The Board of City Magistrates last evening got into a deadlock over the successor to Joseph M. Deuel, who has been the President of the board for nine years, and who was recently appointed a Justice of Special Sessions to fill the unexpired term of Justice Mayer, resigned.

The Spring and Summer options of the cotten market in this city yesterday crossed the fourteen-cent mark with a rush. This not only represents the highest prices for the season, but establishes higher prices than at any time since the year 1875, when cotton sold for 17 cents.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 28 -- Nat C. Goodwill to-night produced a curtain raiser by Lee Arthur entitled "The Man Who Makes You Laugh." The Nixon Theatre was filled by an audience which appeared impressed. Mr. Goodwin takes the part of a playwright who is in love with an actress for whom he writes a play.

One of the few things about the Russo-Japanese situation that are not left in doubt by the press dispatches is that the Russian official communications show an increasing arrogance of tone and a diminishing desire to conciliate Japan. This is quite the most serious feature of the business.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The note which Gen. Reyes, representing Colombia, last week placed in Secretary Hay's hands has been indirectly and in part made public.

Six Central Office detectives were hurried over to Brooklyn yesterday to search for two men who were alleged to have kidnapped six-year-old Thomas Hendrick, whose father, Dr. Charles C. Hendrick, figured in the conspiracy to get possession of the estate of the late Henry C. Bennett for Laura Biggar.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- J.E. Grille, sporting editor of The Cincinnati Commercial Tribune, was elected President of the American Association of Baseball Club to succeed Thomas J. Hickey, resigned, at the annual meeting of the association to-day. George Lennon, owner of the St. Paul Club, was made Chairman of the Board of Directors.

WELLAND, Ontario, Dec. 28 -- James Abeel was brought here to-day by an officer of the frontier police and Detective Sergeants Collins and Vallely of New York to appear before a County Judge on a warrant charging him with having forged the name of a Western Union official while posing as "J. Ogden Goelet."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Some of the Southern and Western Democrats who are disposed to sneer at the talk of Patrick H. McCarren for Chairman of the National Committee are not believed to be on the inside of things. They say that a job of that kind requires a National figure, and inquire scornfully if McCarren knows his way to Chicago.

One is not obliged now to hunt up brass shops on the lower east side to find Russian brass candlesticks. Those that are in the regular shops are not old brass, to be sure, but then neither are most of those on the east side. The bargains there were gone long ago, and the brass pieces are made most of them in the neighborhood.

Mr. Clyde Fitch was in his Fitchiest vein of detailed character comedy last night in "Glad Of It" at the Savoy, in spite of the fact that for the nonce he abjured altogether those people sometimes called the Four Hundred, and bent his powers of whimsical and accurate observation to the depiction of shop girls and ladies of the chorus.
TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 28 -- Chairman Albaugh has issued a call for the Republican State Committee to meet in Topeka, Jan. 5.

We perceive a disposition to admit the truth about the Panama transaction. "The people, who are impatient for the canal, will not heed supersensitive opinions on the methods of bringing the treaty about," says the Hon. STEPHEN B. ELKINS, Senator from West Virginia. Senator ELKINS is a euphemist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- At a meeting of the Cabinet called by the President for 4 o'clock this afternoon the Panama situation was the principal subject under consideration. All members of the Cabinet except Secretary Hay, who is ill; Secretary Shaw, and Attorney General Knox, who are out of the city, were present.
LONDON, Dec. 29. -- Money was increasingly wanted in the market to-day, and was borrowed largely from the Bank of England. Discounts were weak, in anticipation of easier money next week.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- A local newspaper publishes the following:

Yesterday the trading in curb securities was on a broader scale, though there was a slight decrease in activity. The results of the day's transactions show the entire list, with one or two unimportant exceptions, to be net advances. The largest advance was in American Can preferred, which on a few sales sold up to 34, as compared with Monday's closing of 31 3/4.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- The Chemung County Republican Convention, for the purpose of selecting delegates to the two State, Congressional, and Senatorial conventions, was held to-day.

For the first time this season there was good sleighing in Central Park, along Seventh Avenue, and on the Harlem Speedway yesterday afternoon. Road drivers and light harness horsemen in general, who for weeks have eagerly awaited an opportunity to test the speed and qualities of their trotters and pacers over the snow, turned out in full force.

Radium as a cure for cancer has been tried with astonishing results by Dr. William H. Van den Burg of 30 West Forty-ninth Street upon his uncle. William Hoffman, sixty-two years old, a contractor, of 19 West Miller Street, Newark, N.Y., who has returned to his home with hardly a visible trace left of a malignant growth which had spread over the right side of his head from the mouth up.

The health authorities of Orange, N.J., nave been investigating the causes of a recent increase of typhoid fever in that city. It was at first believed to be due to a contamination of the water supply, but this was not sustained by the results of bacteriological examinations. The local health officer says:

PITTSBURG, Dec. 29. -- For twelve hours, commencing at 6 o'clock this morning, thirteen engine companies battled with a stubborn fire in the six-story storage warehouse of Haugh Keenan, at Third Street and Duquesne Way. Crossed electric wires is given as the possible cause of the conflagration.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29. -- Cotton futures opened steady with prices 9 to 11 points lower. Liverpool cables were disappointing to the long side, as only slight advances were shown. Private advices from the English market were bearish, and heavy American selling was reported, with a general desire to liquidate.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- Further improvement was made in the local market to-day, prices generally displaying considerable strength. International Smokeless Powder preferred, on small transactions, sold at 49, against 42 on Dec. 21, no sales having occurred in the meantime. The common improved 1/2, Cambria Iron 1/2, Cambria Steel 7/8.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 29. -- The Standard Oil Company has reduced the price of oil 5 cents in the East and 2 cents in the West. This comes as a disagreeable surprise to producers in the Northwestern Ohio field.
John H. Berry has sold for Dr. John H. Woodbury to Richard Bozine, for $75,000, 25 West Nineteenth Street, a four-story dwelling, on lot 25 by 92, adjoining the Cluett Building.

It is one of the innumerable benefits which the city owes to the present municipal administration that it has completed the acquisition for the public of that historical house which has for two generations been absurdly miscalled the "Jumel mansion," but to which its proper title is now restored by the official designation of it and its inclosing grounds as "Roger Morris Park."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The year book of the Carnegie Institution, which will be issued in a few days, makes interesting announcements of the work and plans laid for scientific research throughout the world in many different branches of science. It shows that the institution has total assets of $10,101,500, and a balance on hand in the treasury on Nov. 1 last of $445,472.

The Board of Reappraisement of the United States General Appraisers yesterday, after a hearing lasting two days, reversed the finding or Appraiser Whitehead in advancing the values of large importations of enameled iron kitchenware by Stransky Co. of 9 Murray Street. This marks the close of another chapter in one of the bitterest lights between domestic interests and importers that has ever taken place.

Leave of absence without pay until Aug. 28, 1904 is granted Cadet William B. Dunn, fourth class, United States Military Academy, with the understanding that he will resign his commission as a cadet on March 1, provided it develops at that time that he will be unable to return to the academy in August of that year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The declaration of Perry Heath that President McKinley in a conversation at the White House informed Heath that he desired to have Senator Hanna succeed him in the Presidency is generally accepted as correct. But Mr. Heath is in error as to the time when, and the place where, the alleged interview took place.

Harrison Grey Fiske has cut the prices for admision into his Manhattan Theatre. Beginning Monday evening, with the first performance of "The Virginian," orchestra seats wil be sold at $1.50. Other seats will be proportionately cheap. This cut in the prices of one of the first-class New York theatres seems to have a very close relation to the "hard times" in the theatres this season.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- As a result of the high price of cotton 4,000 men, women, and children employed in textile mills in this city have been laid off indefinitely. Several thousand other textile mill employes have been idle since Christmas, while the mills and machinery are being repaired.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- The Most Rev. Francis Bourne, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster, was enthroned in the new Cathedral of Westminster this morning with the impressive ceremony incidental to such occasions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Additional evidence that Colombia was warned that Panama would secede in case the canal treaty with the United States was rejected appears in correspondence, heretofore not made public, which passed between Secretary Hay and Minister Beaupre -- and which, along with dispatches already published, was sent to the Capitol by the Public Printer to-day.

Interest in the Stock Exchange bowling tournament waned last night on account of the team usually representing Domnick Domnick not putting in an appearance. There was an unusually large crowd of spectators at the Broadway Arcade Alleys, and all were disappointed, as they expected to see three well-contested games, the scheduled teams being fairly even in playing ability.

Unless there is a complete change of plans by Mayor-elect McClellan during the next twenty-four hours, Commissioner Woodbury, Mayor Low's appointee to the Street Cleaning Department, will be allowed to retain his office. This is despite the fact that practically all the district leaders of Tammany Hall yesterday made the hardest kind of a fight to have Patrick H. Keahon named.

Chief Inspector Cortright and Inspector Brooks walked into Police Commissioner Greene's office at Headquarters yesterday and asked the Commissioner to step into the trialroom a moment, as they had an important matter to discuss.

Holiday bargains, midsummer muslins, and automobile furs are crowding each other in the shops. There was a time, not so very long ago, when February was the month when the wash goods began to creep gently into the windows. Now they come in with a rush, and do not even wait for the new year.

Play in the intercollegiate chess tournament between four students each from Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton was resumed at the Columbia Grammar School in this city yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock, when Columbia met Yale and Harvard was pitted against Princeton, the order of play being as follows:

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Dec. 20. -- One man was killed, two seriously injured, and seven others more or less hurt in a head-on collision between Pennsylvania Limited Train No. 5, west bound, and an east-bound freight train at Larwill, thirty miles west of here, at 6 o'clock this morning.

BOSTON, Dec. 29. -- Money rates show a disposition to advance. Call loans are now generally quoted at 6 per cent., and but little money is put out below that figure. Most bankers do not look for materially lower rates until about the middle of next month.

H.G. Squiers, American Minister to Cuba, came yesterday to New York from Washington in response to an invitation by members of the Merchants' Association of this city who are dissatisfied with the tariff changes that are proposed in Cuba. The merchants talk strongly of demanding the abrogation of the treaty.
MONTREAL, Dec. 29. -- The Canadian customs authorities have decided that the Grace George posters for "Pretty Peggy," which, is coming here next week, cannot be allowed in Canada.

GALVESTON, Texas, Dec. 29. -- Capt. Evans and other officers of the steamship Denver, as well as all others in a position to know, say that all reports that Granville W. Garth, President of the Mechanics' National Bank, New York, was seen alive after the night of his disappearance from among the steamer's passengers, are false.

Mr. AHEARN, the President-elect of the Borough of Manhattan, has announced his enthusiastic concurrence in the project of acquiring for municipal uses the remainder of the block bounded by Broadway, Chambers, Reade, and Centre Streets, now partly occupied by the new Hall of Records.

David Cohen has sold a plot of eight lots, running through from One Hundred and Thirty-seventh to One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Streets, between Fifth and Lenox Avenues. The buyers, Halprin, Levine Diamondston, will erect four six-story tenements on the property.

That much of the recent buying of United States Realty stocks has been for the account of Harry S. Black and his friends, constituting the Fuller contingent in the company, was a report current yesterday and very generally credited. About 88,000 shares of the company's securities have been dealt in during the last four days, the prices for both issues making substantial advances, although there was a slight decline in yesterday's quotations.

The Carnegie Institution at Washington is undoubtedly the chief benefaction of Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE, his greatest gift to his fellow-men. The yearbook, a summary of the contents of which was printed in THE TIMES of yesterday, gives the public more definite and comprehensive knowledge than it has hitherto possessed of the aims and achievements of the Institution.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Owing to the recent events in Panama the annual meeting of the Panama Canal Company this afternoon developed unusual interest and excitement. Prior to the opening efforts were made to secure enough proxies to overrule the existing management of the company, which is favorable to the sale of the company's property to the United States.

In the history of disasters involving the destruction of places of public entertainment, fires in theatres and opera houses hold a most unenviable pre-eminence. Only one, the Ring Theatre fire in Vienna, in 1881, compares in point of loss of human life with the horror in which the audience of the Iroguois Theatre in Chicago was overwhelmed.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Money was not plentitul in the market to-day, in spite of heavy borrowings from the Bank of England.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 30 -- Benjamin Marshall, the young Chicago architect who designed the Iroquois Theatre, left here for Chicago to-night. Mr. Marshall is likewise the architect of the Nixon Theatre in this city. He was overwhelmed by the news of the disaster.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The published interview with ex-Lieut. Gov. Woodruff regarding Kings County politics was called to Gov. Odell's attention to-day, especially Sir. Woodruff's statement that the Kings County organization would brook no interference with its autonomy, and that "the appointment of Jacob Worth to any position whatever would be accepted as a casus belli."

Several changes were made yesterday in the personnel of the officials of the Seaboard Air Line at a meeting of the Board of Directors of the company. John Skelton Williams, heretofore President of the system, was elected Cairman of the Board of Directors of the road, a position especially created for him by an amendment of the by-laws.

Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH is a man whose deliverances are usually listened to with respect in this country. He has been much quoted by the press of the United States, and claims a knowledge of American events which he has not always been able to vindicate as a trustworthy contemporaneous historian.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 30 -- In the medal play qualification rounds in the inauguration tournament begun here to-day Walter J. Travis, the amateur champion, was the winner of the gold medal offered for the best gross score, with two even rounds of 78 each, eleven strokes better than his nearest opponent, W.C. Fownes, Jr., of the Highland Golf Club of Pittsburg, Penn.
Brig. Gen. Carle A. Woodruff, retired, will report to the Governor of North Carolina at Raleigh for duty with the organized militia of that State for a period of four years, unless sooner relieved.

By serving notice upon Commissioner Robert Grier Monroe that the courts would be asked to make him pay the city's lighting bills at the lighting combination's figures for the past year the Consolidated Gas interests showed yesterday that they would fight to a finish any reduction in the rates they offered when their bids were submitted a year ago.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Eddie Foy, the comedian, who had one of the principal parts in "Mr. Bluebeard," and who was the man who ordered the curtain runs down and helped the women on the stage to escape, to-night gave a vivid account of the disaster as he saw it. Said Mr. Foy:

Among the prettiest things in the frills for the young woman are the matinee jackets of lace. They are short jackets, reaching a little below the waist line, shaped a bit to the figure, with long sleeves, with something of a bell flare around the lower edge and large enough to slip on easily over a pretty waist of some dainty color.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Manager Davis of the theatre said:

TROT, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Besides causing the death of Moses T. Clough and William Shaw, the fire which partially destroyed the Troy Club at an early hour this morning, cost the life of Benjamin W. Kinney, manager of the Fuller-Warren Company of Boston, Mass. Mr. Clough was the Nestor of the Rensselaer County Bar, and the sole survivor of the class of 1834 of Dartmouth College.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- One hundred and thirty-five bodies to-night lay on the floors in the morgue of C.H. Jordan, 16 Madison street, and in the temporary annex across the alley. The first were brought in am- bulances and police patrol wagons. Later, all sorts of conveyances were pressed into service, and for more than two hours there was a procession of two-horse trucks, delivery wagons, and cabs, all filled with ghastly loads.

HAVANA, Dec. 30 -- An official statement given out at the palace to-night is to the effect that President Palma, in response to suggestions from the United States Government, is preparing a message to the Senate advising care and caution in amending tariff rates in order to avoid any changes that might be contrary to the spirit of the treaty of reciprocity between Cuba and the United States.

Stocks irregular. Call money firm, 3@7 per cent. The stock market yesterday lost even its appearance of strength. Irregularity is perhaps the softest word to use regarding declines among properties whose prices have relation to anything else than their own affairs, with advances chiefly among specialties which are moved as puppets, or with reference to relations with other concerns.

The first of the subscription dances of the Ladies' Auxiliary Association of the Catholic Summer School of America was given last night in the ballroom of the Hotel Majestic, Seventy-second Street and Central Park West. It was very well attended by the resident members, and by women from other cities, as the membership extends from Montreal, Canada, to Dallas, Texas.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- The scenes in Thompson's restaurant, adjoining the theatre, were ghastly beyond words. Few half hours in battle bring more of horror than the half hour that turned the place into a charnel house, with its tumbled heaps of corpses, its shrieks of agony of the dying, and the confusion of doctors and nurses working madly over bodies as they strove to bring back the spark of life.
The Portable Electric Safety Light Company, Jersey City; capital, $250,000. Incorporators -- Duncan L. McLaren, Henry H. Graff, and Joseph Du Vivier.

The city expressed its appreciation for the many services of the late Andrew Haswell Green, and its sorrow for the tragic manner of his death, by a memorial service which was held yesterday afternoon in the Aldermanic Chamber of the City Hall. The service was the result of a resolution adopted by the Board of Aldermen within a week after Mr. Green had been shot by the negro Williams, on Nov. 13.

A metropolis which is by this time as familiar as it deserves to be with the lightness and fragrant humor of Miss Fay Davis's comedy impersonations was yesterday given a chance to see the pathetic and emotional side of her temperament at its best.

Sports on horseback, in addition to a number of novel riding features, formed the attractions last night at the sixteenth annual Christmas ride of the Durland Riding Academy, West Sixty-sixth Street. One of the most interesting events to those who love to see fine horses in action was a series of manoeuvres by women riding tandem.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Between 550 and 600 lives were lost in ten minutes in a fire and panic in the new Iroquois Theatre between 3:15 and 3:25 yesterday afternoon. The Iroquois Theatre as the newest, the largest, and as far as human power could make it, the safest theatre in Chicago.

Statistics compiled by the New York State Commission on Lunacy show that there has been a disquieting increase in the number of insane in this State during the past year. The increase has been some 40 per cent, above the normal. The State is now caring for about 26,000 insane patients.

-- By reasoning not at all easy to understand, the Kansas members of the Grand Army have decided that it is an affront to them that the bones of the murderous raider, QUANTRELL, should be preserved and exhibited in the rooms of the State Historical Society at Topeka, and on that ground the veterans have demanded that these unpleasant relics of a most unpleasant man be removed and put permanently out of sight.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 30 -- There was less snap to the local market to-day, and business was not as well distributed as yesterday, the bulk of the dealings being in the Steets, Reading, Philadelphia Rapid Transit, Pennsylvania Railroad, Philadelphia Electric, and United Gas. The latter was very strong, advancing 2 points, the high point being reached in the late dealings.

His pockets stuffed with jewelry valued at $75,000, a negro was about to leave the apartments of Mr. and Mrs. Algernon K. Boyesen, at 7 East Thirty-second Street, last night, when Mr. Boyesen surprised him, thrashed him until resistance ceased, made him give up the plunder and turned him over to the police.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The Japanese Minister here, Baron Hayashi, yesterday declared that he had the best authority for saying that in the event of war France would not join forces with Russia, even should China co-operate with Japan, and that the Triple Alliance would preserve strict neutrality.

Fire Commissioner Sturgis said to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES last night that he thought such a disaster as that reported from Chicago might occur in the same way here. He said that more than one theatrical manager here is violating the rules of the Building and Fire Departments, to the immediate and great danger of those who patronize their houses.

Herr Reinhardt Zollikofer, who owns a farm in Burlington County, N.J., reached New York about noon on Tuesday after telling folks all along the line that he was coming here to get a fortune left to him by his mother, who died recently in Germany. He mingled with the passengers on the train, and exhibited a draft for $1,300 drawn on the banking house of Knauth, Nachod Kuhne of 13 William Street.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 30 -- As near as can le estimated about two thousand perions were in the theatre. Three hundred of these were on the first floor, the rest being in the two upper balconies and in the hallways back of them. The theatre is modeled after the Opera Comique, in Paris, and from the rear of each balcony there are three doors leading out to passageways toward the front of the theatre.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 30 -- The money market remains firm, little business being done except in call money. Call loans are generally quoted at 6 @ 6 1/2 per cent.; time loans, with collateral, at 5@6 per cent.; time loans, mercantile paper, 6 @ 6 1/2 per cent.; Clearing House loans, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 16 2-3c discount.

Many members of the incoming Board of Aldermen have signified their willingness to assist in obtaining funds to continue the vacation schools, vacation playgrounds, and evening recreation centres. Clergymen, politicians, educators, business and professional men have been called upon and have almost unanimously expressed their desire to assist in the movement to save these branches of the Department of Education.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- When the appalling danger of the fire was flashed abroad, the police came on the heels of the firemen, intent on the work of rescue. Chief O'Neill and Assistant Chief Schuettler ordered all Captains from a dozen stations to bring their men. They rushed to the theatre and led the police up the stairs to the landing outside the entrance to the first balcony.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The political year in Spain ends in profound pessimism, says the Madrid correspondent of The Times. "What next?" is the universal inquiry, for stability, amid the warring elements, is shattered.

Cooper Union could not hold the crowd that flocked to the mass meeting held there last night for the purpose of registering a protest against the threatened massacre of Jews at Kishineff, and appealing to the Government at Washington to use its good offices with the Czar to prevent the impending slaughter.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The British cotton manufacturers are much exercised on account of the speculation in their raw material in the United States. Many of their mills are idle, and in some districts the idle hands are dependent on charity.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- An improvised hospital in Marshall Field Co.'s store was crowded to its capacity during the fire. The west room and employes sitting room, on the eighth floor, were filled within thirty minutes after the work of rescue began. The maids in charge of the toilet rooms acted as nurses.

Nos. 27 and 20 Thompson Street, for a six-story brick tenement, with stores, 40.3 by 87; Pachtman Levin of 246 Stookton Street, Brooklyn, owners; Sass Smallheiser of 23 Park Row, architects; cost, $40,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- One of the largest audiences ever seen in the Garrick Theatre, which is on the same street as the Iroquois and less than one block distant, sat in complete ignorance of the awful tragedy which was being enacted 200 feet away.

COLON, Dec. 31. -- Information reached Gov. Melendez last night from Carti, a tiny village near the Island of Pines, in Panama territory, that Colombian troops landed there on Dec. 21 and conferred with the Indian Chief, Inanaquina, who was afterward taken aboard a vessel, and, it is thought, conveyed to Cartagena.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Although the Iroquois Theatre was undoubtedly the safest theatre in Chicago, it became evident today that the City Building Department had not strictly enforced one or two sections of the building ordinances.

ASHTABULA. Dec. 31. -- The east-bound limited train No. 22 on the Lake Shore Road was wrecked two miles west of this place to-day while running at a high rate of speed. The train ran into an open switch, and three persons were killed and several others injured.
HAVANA, Dec. 31. -- Fargo Squiers, the eldest son of United States Minister Squiers, was accidentally shot and killed to-day by Gaston Michaud, a French chauffeur employed by his father.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Senator Smoot, with the assistance of his attorneys, is engaged in preparing to defend himself against the charges which challenge his eligibility. Ex-Senator Cannon, who publishes a newspaper in Utah, in a recent issue charged that Mr. Smoot was here to represent the Mormon Church.
LONDON, Jan. 1. -- King Edward and Queen Alexandra have sent telegrams of sympathy to the United States Government through Lord Lansdowne, the Foreign Secretary, to the sufferers of the Chicago fire.
LONDON, Dec. 31. -- The Treasury Department to-night issued an account of the revenue of the United Kingdom for the first nine months of the fiscal year of 1903-4.

Nicholas J. Hayes, the new Fire Commissioner, announced yesterday that his first official act would be to order an immediate investigation of all the theatres in the city to ascertain whether or not they are so constructed and so equipped as to safeguard human life in case of fire or other causes of panic.
LONDON, Dec. 31. -- Japan has renamed the war ships she has purchased from the Argentine Republic the Kassaga and the Nishni. It is expected that they will sail from Genoa for Japan next week.

TUXEDO PARK, Dec. 31. -- The annual New Year's Eve dance, given by the Tuxedo Club, took place here to-night. For a week the clubhouse has been filled with many well-known New Yorkers, and to-night not a room is vacant, and many have been unable to obtain accommodations. Some of the colonists who returned to town early in the season have opened their cottages for the occasion.

Mayor-elect McClellan, shortly before midnight last night announced the remainder of his slate for appointments, and decided the hot fight over the Commissionership of the Street Cleaning Department by detaining Major Woodbury as his selection for that place. The Mayor-elect, through his secretary, John H. O'Brien, announced that Major Woodbury was not reappointed, and would receive no commission, but would merely be allowed to remain as a hold-over.
High carnival, with the tin horn sounding the basic note of revelry, ushered in the fourth year of the twentieth century Last night.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 -- At to-day's session of the American Economic Association the following officers were elected: President -- Frank W. Taussig of Harvard; First Vice President -- Irving Fisher of Yale; Second Vice President -- John H. Gary of Northwestern University; Third Vice President -- John Graham Brooks of Cambridge, Mass.; Secretary and Treasurer -- Frank A. Fetter of Cornell.

ALBANY, Dec. 31. -- Several of the State departments issued for publication to-day brief statements of their work during the past year, most of them in the nature of abstracts of their forthcoming annual reports to the Legislature.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 31. -- The Princeton hockey team again beat Yale to-night, by a score of 2 to 1. At many stages of the came the play was rough, but the enthusiasm of the spectators was never allowed to lag. The first goal was made by Rowland of the Yale team, but in almost less than a minute Zahniser of Princeton put the puck into Yale's goal.

William H Ellis, the first American to visit King Menelik of Abyssinia at his court, returned to this country yesterday on the steamship Majestic with glowing accounts of the African country, and of the great wealth within its borders. Mr. Ellis passed Consul Skinner, who is on a Government mission to King Menelik, on Nov. 29 while the Consul had still about 570 miles to go to reach the capital of the country.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Lying on a cot in the Michael Reese Hospital, badly burned about the upper portion of his body, James H. Strong told to-night how he tried in vain to force open one of the exits leading from the first balcony.
The second performance of "Parsifal" at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday was in every way an occasion as notable as the first. In some respects it was technically better executed.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 31. -- Miss Katie Daffan of Ennis, President of the Daughters of the Confederacy; Texas Division, to-day forwarded by mail to President Roosevelt the following communication, transmitting therewith the resolutions adopted at the recent Houston meeting touching the recognition of Panama:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 31. -- United States Senator Carmack of Tennessee asserts that President Roosevelt is a lawbreaker, as guilty as any unfortunate who may trespass against the laws of the country. The Senator says:

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Stunned by the Iroquois Theatre disaster, the striking livery drivers and their employers have each made preparations to supply carriages to meet the emergency.
