Commission houses were nearly in every case unwilling to recommend to their customers any participation in the market in view of the short day and the possibility of war news that might unsettle foreign markets or some other unfavorable influence over Sunday.

C.M. Daniels of the New York Athletic Club broke all American tank records from 150 to 300 yards in a special match race with J.W. Spencer of Columbia University at the swimming entertainment of the New York Athletic Club last night. Daniels swam with a steady and powerful stroke, and from the first lap of the twenty-five-yard tank to the finish he held the Columbia student safe.
PITTSBURG, Feb. 13. -- A cut all along the line has been made in petroleum rates by the Standard Oil Company, going into effect to-day. A reduction of 5 cents a barrel was made.

After forty minutes of fast and generally clean hockey, such as is seldom seen in New York, the Crescent Athletic Club seven last night defeated the visiting Montreal team at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, by a score of 3 goals to 0.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The State Department has received a report by mail under date of San Domingo, Feb. 2, from United States Minister Powell, of the killing by insurgents of J.G. Johnson, the second-class machinist of the American cruiser Yankee, on the morning of that date.

TOKIO, Feb. 12. -- Japan is bitterly resentful over the sinking of the merchant vessel. Zensho by four Russian cruisers, which yesterday attacked the Zensho and her companion, the Naganoura while they were on their way from Sakata to Otaru, on the Island of Hakkaido. The Foreign Office has issued the following statement regarding the sinking of the Zensho:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- It is apparent at midnight to-night that Senator Hanna's condition is most critical. Two sinking spells, one this morning and another this afternoon, have left him in such a weakened condition that it is feared recovery is impossible. In fact, since 8:30 o'clock hope has been virtually abandoned.
It is reported from Tien-Tsin that the Siberian Railroad has been wrecked in six places, covering a distance of seventy miles.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14. -- Society here has had a day of rest after the gayety of yesterday. In the rotundas capitalists discussed the significance of the visit of the Southern Railroad officials to Palm Beach and other points along the Florida East Coast Road. The officials were accompanied by Adrian Iselin, Jr., James T. Woodward, E.D. Randolph, H.C. Fahnestock, George F. Batter, and Thomas E. Jevons of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- It is not likely that the good roads propaganda will win its fight in Congress this session. The plan has been this session to attach a good roads amendment to the Agricultural Appropriation bill. This bill, having passed the House, will be reported from the Senate Committee on Agriculture this week.

BRIGHAM CITY, Utah, Feb. 14. -- Wholesale expulsions from the church art threatened as the result of the efforts of the Mormon priesthood to enforce implicit obedience to their mandates in business and politics. The younger element of the Church in this city is hotly opposed to the methods of President Keily and his councilors, who have interfered to an extent unprecedented for many years in politics and commercial affairs.

After an exciting chase, which began in a Ninth Avenue elevated train and was continued through the streets and several cross-town cars, a man who gave his name as Frank Munroe of 336 West Thirty-first Street was finally caught and locked up in the West Thirty-seventh Street Station, charged with stealing the pocketbook of a fellow-pasenger.

CHE-FOO, Feb. 14. -- Capt. Gunderson of the Norwegian collier Bygdo has been imprisoned at Port Arthur for four days for having in his possession a chart of a coaling station west of Port Arthur and showing the chart to the Japanese.

Although the end of the indoor athletic season is not yet in sight, and hockey, tank swimming, and indoor athletics are yet in full swing, the college athletes are now intent on plans for the coming season in baseball, rowing, and track and field sports, while practice for baseball is already under way at Cornell and Yale, and begins this week at Harvard.

Never before have the Public School children of Greater New York had such an opportunity as they now have for learning all about the clever work done by the North American Indians in pottery and textile goods. For now there is accessible to them at the Museum of Natural History a large and rare collection of all kinds of jugs, jars, vases, robes, blankets, saddle-girths, sashes, and innumerable other things.

Here is a charming parasol in the way of a valentine for the woman. Or, if there is any one who does not believe that the valentine season holds through the month, then there is Washington's Birthday to celebrate. Anyway the parasols are infinitely more worth while than gifts of flowers, and the flowers are there anyway, handpainted on white silk as natural as life and nearly as large.

Our Berlin dispatches report that the sentiment in the ruling class in Germany is one of dread at what is called the "Yellow Peril," and the cause of Russia is favored in the belief that Russia can and will repress the aggression of the Asiatics under the lead of Japan.

In his sermon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, last evening the Rev. Walter E.C. Smith, the assistant rector, commented upon what he called the growing spirit of materialism in the Protestant churches.

" Dan" Bruder, the champion player of the Harrison Handball Club, was a visitor at the Jersey City Handball Club court on Mercer Street, Jersey City, yesterday, and with J. Egan as a partner, played a close game with E. Corrigan and G. Murray, which was finally won by the latter pair. Later Bruder played a single-handed series with E. Ficke, and won after losing the first game.
In an interview in Cleveland on Saturday Senator FORAKER, in explaining his proposed amendment of the anti-trust law, used the following language:

The State Charities Aid Association, in its report to the State Board of Charities for the year ended Nov. 1, 1903, reviews the work of the association and treats of legislation, proposed and enacted, affecting itself. Concerning the bill relating to the establishment of hospitals or camps for pulmonary tuberculosis patients, which became a law, the report says:

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times, cabling last Thursday, says that the Russian gunboat Mandjur, which before the war began was preparing for sea, has now gone several miles up the Wu-Sung River, where she is likely to remain unless objections are raised by the Chinese authorities.

Battalion Chief Duane of Engine Company No. 1 narrowly escaped being burned to death in a small fire at 49 West Twenty-ninth Street last night. The flames were discovered by Policeman Keenan of the West Thirtieth Street Station, who sent in an alarm. When the firemen arrived it was found that the flames had started simultaneously both in the front and rear of the cellar.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Naval officials say that while the Prairie, with the 450 marines from Colon aboard will touch at Santo Domingo, the real destination of the vessel is the naval station at Guantauamo. The purpose of taking the men there, they say, is to give them a change of climate and surroundings.

Several thrilling rescues which occasioned considerable excitement and elicited cheers from a large crowd of spectators were made yesterday afternoon at a fire in the five-story tenement house 730 Columbus Avenue.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 14. -- A large Sound steamboat has been noticed all day to-day apparently stuck in the ice between Captain's and Little Captain's Islands off Greenwich. She was headed westward. The snowstorm hid her from view most of the day, but at intervals she could be seen in the same position, about a mile south of the lighthouse.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- At Port Arthur on Feb. 8, says the Tokio correspondent of The Times, the Russians had in action all the battleships at the port except the Sevastopol, together with the armored cruiser Bayan, the protected cruiser Askold, and the Diana, Pallada, and Novik.
We are advised by Washington dispatches that the issues upon which the President will make his campaign are these:
Having noticed the interest which you always display in "English as she is spoke," I venture to send you the following brilliant specimen:

Considerable opposition has developed among lawyers to the bill now before the Legislature providing for the appointment in New York and Kings Counties of Supreme Court Commissioners to perform most of the duties now allotted to referees, including the hearing of foreclosure and partition suits, examinations of accounts, divorce actions, condemnation proceedings, and all proceedings for street openings and park sites.

-- Though forced by circumstances to think long and hard, just now, about a great many things of most vital importance to their present and future, the people of Baltimore have evidently found or made time to devote a remarkably large amount of attention to what may be called the manners of the commander of Maryland's National Guard, Gen. LAWRASON HIGGS.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- The final round in the tournament for the gold racquet championship brought together to-day Milton S. Barger and E. Edwards of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club. The men have played before in their own courts with about equal results, but on new courts to-day Barger showed his superiority and justly earned the title of gold racquet champion.

The concert given in the Metropolitan Opera House last evening was devoted to the works of American composers, except for the last number, which was the Rakoczy march from Berlioz's "Damnation of Faust." This replaced the movements from Prof. MacDowell's orchestral suite, which were withdrawn at his desire, an outcome of his disapproval of "American composers' concerts."

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 14. -- Early this morning the game between Marshall and Schlechter in the sixth round of the international sexangular chess tourney was concluded, the contest ending in a draw. The position of the leaders remains, therefore, unaltered, as will be seen from the scores up to date, as appended:

NAGASAKI, Feb. 14. -- The survivors from the cruiser Variag and the gunboat Korietz, the Russian vessels that were sunk by the Japanese fleet at Che-mul-pho last Tuesay, still remain on board the British cruiser Talbot, the Italian cruiser Elba, and the French cruiser Pascal. The situation is becoming acute, as the Japanese have twice made demands on the commanders of the three foreign vessels that the Russians be surrendered as prisoners of war.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 14. -- Advance sheets of The Fireproof Magazine give the result of a visit by a body of experts, made to determine the effect of the recent fire here on the modern steel structure. The report says in part:
LONDON, Feb. 15. -- It is reported from Tien-Tsin that the Siberian Railroad has been wrecked in six places, covering a distance of seventy miles.

Now that the annual contest for the national billiard championship is at an end, and after competing for the honors many years J. Ferdinand Poggenburg, champion of the Liederkranz Club, has won the much coveted trophy, the players have begun to figure the percentages and averages and make the comparisons with other tournaments.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 14. -- As a sequel to yesterday's personal encounters in the secret meeting of the State Republican Executive Committee and the ousting of "Goose Neck Bill" McDonald from a place in that body, the friends of E.H.R. Green are in open revolt against State Chairman Lyon, who had been unopposed for National Committeeman from Texas.

Last week's markets were characterized by a surplus of news, a deficiency of business, and something like immobility of prices. The war, the Baltimore fire, and the commotion in the commodity markets -- especially in the cotton market following the ginners' report -- are fresh in everybody's recollection.

To-night begins the sale of the paintings left behind by John H. Dolph, N.A., a genial soul, if ever there was one, and a man who at an early period in his artistic career gave up the aspirations that beset most artists and buckled down to work of the sort the world about him demanded.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- Manager Harry F. Vincent of the Cornell baseball team has announced the following schedule for the coming season:

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The Frankfurter Zeitung's Salonika correspondent telegraphs that a Bulgarian band numbering 100 has been attacked at Djumabala by Turkish frontier guards, who were reinforced by two companies of infantry.

Ten days ago Russia had four fine warships in the harbor of Vladivostok -- the Gromoboi, the Rossia, and the Rurik, armored cruisers, and the Bogatyr, a protected cruiser. The three first-named are larger and more heavily armed than were the Spanish cruisers sunk at Santiago, while the Bogatyr is somewhat superior to the United States cruiser Olympia.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 14. -- For the past three days the messenger boys and other youngsters of Hazleton have been dazzled by a Croesus of sixteen, in short trousers, who entertained them with lavish hand.

ROGERS, Ark., Feb. 14. -- A railroad war is on in Washington and Benton Counties. Two short line roads to connect with the 'Frisco and the Kansas City Southern are being projected. The starting points are Springdale and Rogers, while Silom Springs is the objective point for both roads. "Coin" Harvey is father of the line to be built from Springdale.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 15. -- 2:45 A. M. -- A communication from Viceroy Alexieff just received confirms the report of the landing of 19,000 Japanese troops at Che-mul-pho. The Viceroy adds that reports have been received of attempts to cut the telegraph wires along the Chinese Eastern Railway and also to destroy one of the abutments of the Sungari Bridge.

In accordance with Leader Charles F. Murphy's plan to have "big" men represent the eleven districts of Manhattan and the Bronx in the United States House of Representatives, it is understood that the New York City delegation will be subject to the greatest shake-up this Fall New York delegations have known in years.

Regular patrons of the vaudeville houses have come to expect as a feature of almost every bill at least one of the so-called dramatic sketches, which, though they are most often not dramatic at all, serve to provide a string of more or less attenuated dialogue upon which the "artists" are enabled to hang their specialties and fill out the requisite amount of time demanded for each turn by the management.

While a number of the new cars which are to be used in the subway were being tested on the express track of the Third Avenue elevated line, between Fifty-ninth and One Hundred and Sixteenth Streets, yesterday afternoon, Harry Ward, who is employed as a chief clerk by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, was knocked down and badly injured.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- There has lately been a good deal of serious heart searching and taking account of stock by Democratic statesmen on the subject of the issues in the next campaign. It has become apparent that the Democracy must choose between two sets of issues, and it has also become apparent that they must menoeuvre carefully to prevent the Republicans naming the issues and forcing the fight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- The city authorities have prevented the use of a "spot light" in Sir Henry Irving's production of "The Bells," and have compelled the stage management to use instead, in the dream scene, a strong incandescent light.

Viola Allen, the actress, who has been playing in "Twelfth Night" at the Knickerbocker, was operated upon for a malady of the mastoid bone at the Eye and Ear Infirmary, at Second Avenue and Thirteenth Street, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. The operation was performed by Dr. E.B. Dench of 17 West Forty-sixth Street, assisted by two house physicians of the institution.

Regarding a recent letter in your columns about the danger to health that lurks in unclean money permit me to submit some comments. There seems to be really no very serious obstacle in the road of minimizing what is a very formidable menace to public welfare, if a little co-operation on the part of the banks and the depositotrs was exercised.

Three big transatlantic liners -- the St. Paul, the Main, and the Manitou -- experienced extremely rough weather on the voyages from European ports which they finished here yesterday. The St. Paul was one day and several hours behind her ordinary time, while the others were three and four days behind time.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- Attempts are being made, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, to diminish the impression produced by Japan's initial successes and to counteract the pro-Japanese tendencies evinced in the greater part of the Austro-Hungarian press.
BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The newspapers here discuss the question who took the initiative in proposing that Chinese neutrality be respected in the Russo-Japanese war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Senator Marcus Alonzo Hanna died at 6:40 o'clock this evening at his apartments in the Arlington Hotel, after an illness extending over nearly two months, filled with apparent recoveries, followed by relapses, and finally drifting into typhoid fever, which in his weakened condition he was unable to withstand.
TOKIO, Feb. 14. -- Marquis Ito to-day gave the Associated Press a written expression of his sentiments toward the American people as follows:
CHE-FOO, Feb. 15. -- The steamer Wen-Chow, arriving from Port Arthur, reports that eleven Russian ships were struck in the engagement last Monday and Tuesday.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The great mass of the Czar's subjects, says the Moscow correspondent of The Times, are almost as uninterested and indifferent as if Japan were operating against China or landing troops at Honolulu.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15. -- To-day, the fairest of the season, was marked by the greatest number of arrivals for the year. There is great activity on the golf links, and the busiest day of the season on Lake Worth. Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Travis arrived this morning. Mr. Travis is getting into form for the Florida championship tournament, which begins Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Dr. Edward Perkins Carter of Cleveland, one of the attending physicians, to-night made the following statement regarding Mr. Hanna's illness:

In compliance with disposses notices received from the James D. Murphy Company, contractors, of 1,181 Broadway, thirty-two families living in Lexington Avenue, between Twenty-fifth and Twenty-sixth Streets and west on these streets to within 100 feet of Fourth Avenue, were moving their belongings yesterday, and all last night vans were kept busy carrying furniture to the various storehouses.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Both houses of Congress will adjourn to-morrow immediately upon the announcement of the death of Senator Hanna. No business will be transacted in either house.

An elderly man, who said he was Frank H. Potter, a member of the Brillant Buhler Company, having offices at 14 John Street and residing at 36 West One Hundred and Thirtieth Street, appeared in the Tombs Court yesterday as complainant against Miss Irene Stewart of 130 West Eighty-fourth Street, charging her with the larceny of $1,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- A new high record price was reached to-day by wheat for May delivery, 98c. a bushel. With the war advancing foreign grain markets, the visible supply diminishing, and with crop prospects in the Southwest threatened by the cold weather, short selling of the May option was practically abandoned, July absorbing most of the new business.

Baseball men are now anxiously awaiting the decision of Chairman Herrmann of the National Commission regarding the right of the New York American League Club to play Sunday games at Ridgewood, L.I. According to President Pulliam of the National League and one of the Commissioners the whole drift of the argument centred on Section 2, Article 5, of the peace agreement, which reads:

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- After a session of three hours the conference of Republican leaders, called by Gov. Odell to meet to-day in the Executive Chamber for the purpose of considering the advisability of granting a larger measure of home rule to the cities of the State, adopted the following resolution:

Yesterday's business was a demonstration that it takes more than news to make a market. There were several developments yesterday well adapted to move many stocks, but they were offset by others of different tenor, and hence the situation was confused rather than clarified. Take the Baltimore news, for instance.

To say that the stock market yesterday was duller than it was on Saturday is to brand it as the most uninteresting day that Wall Street has seen in a long time, but such was the case. During the first two hours less than 80,000 shares were dealt in, and the total for the whole day was only 172,812 shares, the smallest total shown since Oct. 30 last, when 167,451 shares were traded in.
SEOUL, Feb. 12. -- A detailed account of the battle off Che-mul-pho, which resulted in the loss of the Russian cruiser Variag and the gunboat Korietz, has reached here.

Miss Dorothy Dix in your paper of this day ends a long discourse reciting her mistaken suppositions on the subject of "The Reason Men Do Not Marry," by saying that the real reason is because they do not want to. That is about the only correct idea in her whole article.

NIU-CHWANG, Feb. 14. -- About fifty Japanese men on their way to Tien-Tsin were arrested at Tai-Hih-Chou on Friday, with their women, and arrived here in custody. The American Consul, Henry B. Miller, procured the release of the women, but Viceroy Alexieff ordered their rearrest and transportation to Port Arthur, together with all the Japanese in Manchuria.

Representatives of the gas companies of New York City, in applying to the Corporation Counsel's office yesterday for a postponement of their mandamus proceedings to compel the Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas, and Electricity to sign their contracts for 1903 on the same basis as 1902, practically promise to make important concessions to the city and come to an agreement on the entire gas situation.

A 200 horse-power-motor boat is likely to be seen in local waters this coming season. This boat will be imported by an automobile firm that deals in Italian motors. The boat is now practically ready for use. It was made in Turin and will be a competitor in the big race of nearly 100 miles to be held at Monte Carlo within the next two months.
The well-known Paris writer on foreign politics, J. CORNELY, in a dispatch to our neighbor The Herald, makes this comment upon Secretary HAY's circular note:

A highwayman with a revolver held up two men last night, one at a time. The first hold-up occurred about 9:30 o'clock, when Louis Schweirs left the store of Neuss Brothers at 171 Duane Street, where he works, locked the store door and started for home. He had not gone ten feet when a big man emerged from behind a post and pointing a revolver at his head commanded him to hold up his hands.

Determined to increase the efficiency of the New York Fire Department by drawing on the North and East Rivers for salt water with which to fight fires on Manhattan Island, Mayor McClellan has sent a letter to Fire Commissioner Hayes, to Water Commissioner Oakley, and to Borough President Ahearn, calling on them for suggestions as to the best methods of procedure.
An official Russian telegram says that mounted patrols, believed to be Japanese, were seen on Sunday in the vicinity of Sin-Ming-Tung, northwest of Mukden.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- A leading Polish Conservative organ, the Czas of Prague, publishes a St. Petersburg dispatch, quoted by the Vienna correspondent of The Times, concerning the Russian commissariat and means of transport.

Frank Bartunek killed his wife, Rosie, and mortally wounded his stepson, Vincent Hornick, yesterday afternoon at their home, 345 East Seventy-third Street. The man was thirty-eight years old, his wife thirty-two, and the stepson twelve years old. Bartunek's five-year-old son Rudolph escaped from his father through the courage of his stepbrother.

Fire caused by defective insulation of an electric light wire caused a small-sized panic last night at the Lexington Opera House, Fifty-eighth Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues, while the entertainment and reception of the Anawanda Club was being held.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A remarkable and probably unprecedented scene in the House of Representatives was witnessed to-day when Representative John F. Shafroth (Dem.) of Colorado, declaring that he had been convinced he was illegally elected, gave up his seat to the Republican contestant, Robert W. Bonynge.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- The Foreign Office today confirmed the announcements made in these dispatches on Saturday that Russia and France approve of the United States' note on the subject of Chinese neutrality, with a reservation excluding Manchuria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Public men, without distinction of party, unite to-night in deploring the death of Senator Hanna. In his death, they declare, the country has lost one of its most useful and individual citizens. Volumes might be written regarding these expressions of regret. A few of them follow:

All that glitters may not be gold; but "Glittering Gloria," which opened last night at Daly's, has a full complement of the paste jewels of what the French call vaudeville comedy; and merrily scintillant gems those are.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Postmaster General Payne, Vice Chairman of the Republican National Committee, has sent the following telegram to each member of the committee:

A conference of the Philadelphia reorganization interests in the Consolidated Lake Superior Company and members of Speyer Co. was held at the offices of the banking house yesterday, and a request was made by the Philadelphians for a short extension of time on the pending offer to take up the securities originally pledged on the Speyer syndicate loan and purchased by the bankers under the foreclosure sale.

It is a matter of interest and a cause for congratulation that the Reform Club is, domiciled in a new home at 2 East Thirty-fifth Street, and is established upon a basis which promises a continuance of its career of usefulness. After full consideration the members of the club have decided to maintain its social features, including provision for recreation and refreshment, upon a scale sufficient to make the clubhouse attractive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Senate agreed to-day to take the vote on the Panama treaty a week from to-morrow. This agreement was reached in executive session immediately after the Senate was called to order at noon. The Chaplain, Edward Everett Hale, spoke feelingly of Senator Hanna in the opening prayer.

With subscriptions largely exceeding the amount offered, the $35,000,000 Cuban loan was placed yesterday by the banking firm of Speyer Co., the successful bidders, through a syndicate of interests here and abroad formed by the bankers for that purpose. The offerings of bonds were said to have been applied for with an eagerness seldom shown on similar proposals.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- Prices on the Stock Exchange to-day opened firm, but toward the close consols and foreign securities fell slightly, on a repetition of the unconfirmed rumors regarding the ill-health of Emperor William of Germany, which had been current for some days.

How Actor Harry Nelson lost his trunk was told yesterday in the General Sessions, where Andrew Maxwell was placed on trial on a charge of grand larceny, it being alleged that he had intercepted the trunk, which had been shipped from Bridgeport to 25 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, a boarding house.
CAPE TOWN, Feb. 15. -- The Parliamentary elections just held in Cape Colony have resulted in a Progressive majority of five over the Afrikander Bond.

POGGENBURG'S victory, in the so-called "amateur" tournament at the "fourteen-two" game, was figured out in our columns yesterday to denote a clear advance upon the performance of his predecessor in the championship. His "high run" was exactly equal to MULLEN'S. But that does not count.

TOKIO, Feb. 14. -- Kogoro Takahira, the Japanese Minister at Washington, has officially advised his Government that he is receiving numerous offers of large contributions to the war fund from Americans, and requests instructions as to the policy of the Government in the matter.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Utica curlers carried off the honors at Rutgers Rink to-day in the Mitchell Medal contest. They defeated the curlers from New York, Jersey City, and Yonkers, and the two Utica rinks will play off the final round to-morrow. Keen playing was the result of the game between the Thistles of New York and Utica Rink No. 1. Utica won by excellent playing of Skip Ridings.

Another heavy decline was registered yesterday in the prices of cotton futures, quotations of the active near months showing losses of from 90 to 109 points, while the far months declined 50 to 70 points. The market, however, was not in such a fever of excitement as a week ago, and the declines were not interrupted by violent reactions.

PRINCETON, Feb. 15. -- At a meeting of the Princeton University Athletic Committee held recently, it was decided to take the hockey, basket ball, and gymnastic teams into the association. This matter is to be voted upon at a mass meeting of the three upper classes, but there is no danger of the vote not being favorable.

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- The Lothrop Publishing Company, 530 Atlantic Avenue, has assigned to Fred Williams, a lawyer in the Tremont Building. No statement could be secured at the offices of the company this afternoon, but the liabilities are roughly estimated at $150,000. A definite statement will be ready for creditors in a few days.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- M. Jaures, leader of the Socialist Party, which holds the balance of power in Parliament, and until recently Vice President of the Chamber, has made a declaration contemplating the immediate denunciation of the Franco-Russian alliance, which has attracted a great deal of attention in diplomatic circles.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 15. -- Had the New York bowlers played as well in the championship games as they did early yesterday morning in the contest with the all-star team of Chicago, they, instead of Anson's team of Chicago, would have won the National championship. So well did the New Yorkers bowl that the Chicago men gave up at the end of the fourth game, saying they were clearly outclassed.

We have received no confirmation of the report that the Russians recently destroyed three of their own torpedo boats by gunfire from the Port Arthur forts; but, as such a mishap is one of the desperate chances that necessarily belong to torpedo boat service, there is no improbability in the story.

Marcus A. Hanna represented a high type of American citizenship. It is not meant that he was typical of the average of American citizens; rather typical of citizenship possibilities in America. A remarkable career of unbroken successes, yet his was a career such as any American young man possessed of sterling qualities and a will to work might aspire to.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- A dispatch from The Times's correspondent, dated at Port Arthur Feb. 13, via Peking the 15th, says the Japanese have been driven from the railway near Kin-Chau, just north of Dalny.

Siegmund Bergmann has sold the plot, 60 by 100, on the east side of St. Nicholas Avenue, at its junction with St. Nicholas Place and opposite One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street. The plot adjoins the three lots sold recently by the White estate.

A defense of the new course of study in elementary schools and the department system of teaching occupies the greater portion of City Superintendent William H. Maxwell's annual report on the condition of the public schools for the year ended July 31, 1903, which was made public yesterday. Of the new course he says:

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The press attaches the greatest significance to the departure of Viceroy Alexieff from Port Arthur, and comments upon the sudden throwing of Russian troops into Niu-Chwang as indicating Russian apprehensions that Port Arthur is in danger, and that the Japanese attack may not, after all, be made where it is now expected, on the Yalu.

NIU-CHWANG, Feb. 16. -- Atrocities are daily perpetrated on foreigners and natives, both by the organized police and by incoming troops, which make it impossible for the Civil Administrator of Niu-Chwang to control the situation. It is feared that a reign of terror will be precipitated if the neutral powers remain inactive.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- The Spring municipal election was held to-day, and all the candidates on the Republican ticket were elected. The proposed $16,000,000 loan for municipal improvements was approved by a large majority. The successful candidates were Harry D. Beaston for Receiver of Taxes; Leslie Yates and John Mecleary, Republicans, and Joseph S. Boyle, Democrat, for City Magistrates.

The terms of subscription to the proposed issue of $1,440,000 of new stock of the Greene Consolidated Copper Company were decided upon at a meeting of the Directors yesterday. Fifty per cent. is to be paid when subscription is made, and the balance is divided into two payments of 25 per cent. each, one in thirty and the other in sixty days.
ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Ex-Secretary of War Elihu Root came to Albany to-day and called on Gov. Odell.

TOKIO, Feb. 16. -- The Government is receiving additional circumstantial reports of the alleged cruelty of the Russians toward Japanese refugees from Manchuria. The Japanese Consul General at Tien-Tsin has just telegraphed the authorities here giving a recital of the story told by thirteen women who have just arrived at Shan-Hai-Kwan.

As a result of the recent amateur championship billiard tournament, held in this city at the Liederkranz Club, a movement is on foot to offer a challenge cup to be played for between the amateurs of this country.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Feb. 16.-- The ice situation about Nantucket was worse to-day than at any time this Winter, and the island is held firmly in the grasp of a fourth blockade. The immense floes are piling upon each other, and as seen from the life-saving stations the ice on the shoals is a least fifty feet high.

"I believe our country is right in this struggle," Consul General S. Uchida of Japan declared at the Quill Club dinner last night. "It is a life and death struggle for her, but God seems to be against Russia. He seems to say that Russia is wrong. That is shown by Russia in destroying her own ships by her own mines."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- M. Bunau-Varilla, the Minister from Panama, has received word from the Minister of Foreign Affairs that the constitution adopted by the convention called for that purpose was officially promulgated by the Junta to-day. It now becomes the organic law of the Republic of Panama.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 16. -- Developments in the suit brought by Mrs. Dodge-Morse of New York for divorce from her first husband, Charles F. Dodge, lead those who have followed the progress of the case in Atlanta to believe that some interests are anxious to keep Mrs. Dodge-Morse legally bound to Dodge.

Let me keep my grip on the high schools, Superintendent SKINNER may be supposed to say, and I care not who controls the universities. Mr. LEWIS'S amendment to the Unification bill has been drawn in this sense. The bill remains a flagrantly political measure, without a scrap of patronage erased or a single campaign contribution blotted out.

The Rev. R.C. Fillingham, Vicar of Hexton, England, who, when he was here last June visited the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, and later sent a letter of protest to Bishop Potter against ritualism as he says he found it practiced there, and who declared before leaving that he would return "to root priestcraft from the Protestant Episcopal Church," arrived yesterday on the Cunard Line steamship Ivernia.

Those who talk about "the yellow peril" as if Chinese immigration and Japanese military success were different aspects of the same danger, overlook one of the most important factors in the situation. The assumption that the two nations are of the same race would be vehemently resented by representatives of each.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16. -- Suffering with fever and in poor health, Louis E. Sears, a passenger on the steamship Martinique, bound from Havana to this port, plunged into the sea from the aft saloon deck of the vessel about 6:30 o'clock last night, and was drowned. Several passengers witnessed the act, but were unable to prevent the leap into the sea, where the body now lies.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 16. -- A fireman was killed and heavy damage was caused by a fire which destroyed the grandstand and pavilion and a portion of the famous Vailsburg Board Track at an early hour to-day. The fire is believed by many to have been of incendiary origin. Henry Yung, a pipeman, was crushed under heavy timbers when a portion of the burning building fell in.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- After a debate of several hours on the Educational Unification bill the Senate this afternoon voted down the amendments proposed by Senator Grady, the minority leader, and the bill was advanced to third reading by a party vote. It was said by Republican members of the Senate this evening that Gov. Odell would probably send to the Senate to-morrow an emergency message calling for the immediate passage of the bill.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 16. -- The Russian second class cruiser Boyarin was blown up by a mine Feb. 13 in the same manner as was the Russian torpedo transport Yenisei. She had on board 197 officers and men, all of whom, it is understood, were lost. No details of the disaster have been given out.

The trial of Miss Sara J.J. McCaffery, who has been for the last thirty-three years the Principal of Public School No. 116, continued yesterday afternoon before the Elementary School Committee of the Board of Education. District Superintendent Stitt, who preferred the charges of insubordination against Miss McCaffery, was cross-examined by James Clancey for the defense.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 16. -- A cablegram was received to-day by the Foreign Mission Board of the Southern Presbyterian Church announcing the safety of the missionaries in Korea. The message is from Secretary Bull, and dated at Kunsa. There are seventeen missionaries in the Korean field, and the cablegram says they are undisturbed.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Gov. Odell to-day defined clearly his views on home rule for New York on the excise question. From what he said on the subject it is plain that as a result of the discussion at yesterday's conference and his own further consideration of the matter the Governor's opinion as to what is best to be done to arrive at a satisfactory solution of the problem has undergone some changes.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- France, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, has decided to charter the Steamship Cholon to transport to the Far East 900 men with officers, of the Forty-sixth Colonial Regiment.

Mayor McClellan, after a conference yesterday with Police Commissioner McAdoo, Deputy Commissioner McAvoy, and Police Inspectors Brooks and Cortright over the subject of the three-platoon system for the police force, said the three-platoon system would be restored at the earliest possible moment, the only delay now being over details.

BERLIN, Feb. 16. -- Impressionistic art and its place at the St. Louis Exposition were debated in the Reichstag to-day, Herr Singer, (Socialist,) leading the attack on the Government for excluding, as he said, impressionistic paintings from the German exhibit.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Feb. 16. -- A decree has been issued by the Sultan commanding the Turkish press to refrain from publishing comments unfavorable to Russia during the war.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 16. -- Lieut. Gen. Ivanoff, Governor General and commander of the troops in Turkestan, has gone to Tashkend, with Gen. Sakharoff, Chief of the Staff of the Military District of Turkestan.

The board sidewalk on the corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street echoes to the tramp of feet, but few of the passers realize that below them is an art gallery fitted with some of the latest creations of the men and women who furnish illustrations for books and magazines; otherwise their tread might be lighter and more reverent.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- According to The Times's Tokio correspondent, the Emperor of Korea has congratulated the Japanese on their victory, declaring that in view of Korea's position, her satisfaction equals Japan's.

ROME, Feb. 16. -- Deputy Barnabei, formerly Director of Fine Arts, interrogated the Government in the Chamber to-day concerning the alleged surreptitious exportation to the United States of a Greek archaic chariot which was discovered in the Department of Umbria.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 16. -- The news of the death of Senator Hanna was first conveyed to Mrs. McKinley by a newspaper bulletin. Mrs. McKinley a short time thereafter received a message from Secretary Cortelyou also telling her of the passing away of Senator Hanna.

We pointed out on the morrow of the terrible conflagration in Baltimore that one lesson at least was to be drawn from it for this city, the imperative need of an unquestionably adequate supply of water available at all times and in every place in the city. This we do not possess, and the relative insufficiency of water is bound to be worse with the increase of areas closely occupied with valuable property.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- An investigation of the Consolidated Gas Company's monopoly in New York City by a legislative committee seems to be a probability, in view of a statement made to-day by Chairman Malby of the Senate Finance Committee at the hearing on the Martin resolution calling for an investigation of the quality of gas furnished to consumers of New York.

G.G. Cameron, the star bicycle rider of the Eighth Regiment, and Oscar Goerke of the National Athletic Club, Brooklyn, also known as a very difficult indoor competitor to beat, furnished the most stirring finish in the athletic events last night in the Ninth Regiment Armory, West Fourteenth Street, held under the auspices of Company G. Goerke had a handicap of twenty yards, while Cameron started from scratch in the two-mile bicycle race.

Efforts made yesterday by some of the professional set to lift the market out of the extreme dullness into which it had gradually fallen, and which reached its culmination on Monday when the trading for the whole day was scarcely enough to make an active hour, were for a short time successful.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16. -- Walter J. Travis to-day established the amateur record of the golf links here, doing the course in 66.

The twelve years' mystery of the disappearance of the fortune of the late Thomas Wilson of the village of Westchester was solved yesterday when his granddaughter, Mrs. Elizabeth Pell, found $26,500 in bonds in his name and a number of other papers, which, it is believed, will lead her to the remainder of the $100,000 estate which her ancestor is supposed to have possessed.

The market continues to demonstrate its lack of claim to rational consideration. One ingenuous bulletin yesterday explains the torpidity and inconsistency of present business upon the Stock Exchange by lack of factors to cause fluctuations. To be sure, nothing has happened recently but the war and the fire at Baltimore and convulsions in several commodity markets.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The Peking correspondent of The Times says the Japanese Consul at Che-foo reports that a British steamship arrived there yesterday with 340 Japanese refugees from Port Arthur, including 100 from the interior of Manchuria. With the exception of 100 who are returning via Niu-Chwang, all Japanese residents of Manchuria have now withdrawn.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Marcus T. Hun, who made an argument against the constitutionality of the Educational Unification bill at the hearing last week, to-day sent the following letter to Chairman Lewis of the Joint Educational Committee:

The conduct of Mr. SHAFROTH of Colorado, in being the first to proclaim that his apparent majority was obtained by fraud, and in declining to take advantage of the fraud, is justly claimed as an act of honor and integrity. It may be no more, it is no more, than an honest man in Mr. SHAFROTH'S position was bound to do.

"Larry" Summerfield, who is now under $30,000 bail, pending a decision on a certificate of reasonable doubt issued by a Supreme Court Justice following his recent conviction on a charge of grand larceny, was arrested yesterday afternoon in Wall Street by Detective Sergeant McConville, charged with attempted grand larceny.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 16. -- The value of the estate left by the late Senator Hanna is estimated at from seven to eight millions of dollars. It is stated that he owned at least 15 per cent. of the stock of the Cleveland Electric Railway, capitalized at $23,500,000.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- British sympathy for the Japanese is manifested in the remarkable response to an appeal recently made for a fund for the widows and families of soldiers and sailors. Japanese are accosted in all parts of London by persons desiring to contribute to the fund.

More progress was made yesterday in the trial of Martin Cohn and Charles C. Browne for alleged silk importation frauds than in any day since the trial began four weeks ago. Browne's defense was all put in, and Frank H. Platt almost completed his opening address for Cohn.

BERLIN, Feb. 16. -- Although it is denied in Constantinople that Russia has asked permission to pass her ships through the Dardanelles, it is known here that as soon as England takes any steps to change her present position in Egypt and the Mediterranean Sea, in violation of the Berlin Congress, Russia will pass her vessels through the Dardanelles.

The fact that the managers of the local gas business are beginning to show anxiety as to their position and a desire to avert by tardy concessions the danger of competition from a municipal plant is instructive. The offer of more satisfactory terms to the city for the gas needed for municipal lighting is a step in the direction of sanity in the management of their business which is at least encouraging.

ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 16. -- Henry Williams, a burly negro who on Jan. 30 last entered the home of George J. Shields, a well-known business man, and murderously assaulted Mrs. Shields and her three-year-old daughter with a hatchet, razor, and pocket knife, was sentenced by Judge Woods in the Corporation Court to-day to be hanged March 18 next.

While our West Hoboken friend presents the basis for a sound argument in taking the stand that the decisions and decrees of the civil courts to-day prompt the dissatisfied spouse to rush for legal advice on slight provocation, he has, I fear, failed to argue the true reasons why the major portion of the young men of New York are reluctant to marry.

The Wanderers Hockey Club team of this city defeated the seven of the Brooklyn Skating Club at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, last night by a score of 2 to 1, and thereby advanced a step toward the championship of the Amateur Hockey League. The Wanderers have now won six games, tied one with the Brooklyn Skating Club, and lost none.
LONDON, Feb. 17. -- Russian irritation toward the United States seems to be gaining in intensity, says the Paris correspondent of The Times.

The announcement is made from the office of the Subway Construction Company that it will not be possible to open the subway for public use before June 1 at the earliest, and that it may be necessary to delay the opening until July 1.

BOSTON, Feb. 17. -- American dog shows are deprived of one of its greatest competitors, as Glen Monarch, a champion bull dog owned by Thomas W. Lawson, died on its way from New York to the Dreamwold Kennels, situated at Scituate.
With the exception of the reception given by Mrs. Hubert Vos, at which M. Gilibert sang, and a few dinners yesterday being Ash Wednesday, was a dies non socially.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 17. -- Zero weather and a northwest hurricane that drove the particles of snow like cutting sand through the atmosphere could not cool the affection of little Olive Palmer, fourteen years old, and Andrew Finner, sixteen years old, of Palmerville.

It is true, as Mr. Charles J. Murphy says in your issue of this day, that a Russian fleet visited our waters during the Winter of 1862-63, (it is all a matter of record at Washington,) for I, but a boy then, accompanied my father, when, with a party of army and navy officers and a generous sprinkling of the fair sex, he paid his respects aboard the flagship to the Russian Admiral commanding.
TOKIO, Feb. 17. -- A heavy storm spared the Russians from a desperate torpedo attack at Port Arthur on the morning of Sunday.

Capt. DAYTON of the Governor's staff must be credited with sincerity in his statement that the "Russian occupation of Manchuria has been a splendid thing [for Americans] from a commercial point of view." 'As he was traveling in that country last year, his statement has the value of personal observation. But it does not agree with the facts as officially reported by our responsible agents there.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17. -- Mrs. Benjamin Thaw gave an elaborate luncheon this noon to sixteen ladies. The room was decorated with huge palms and bunches of violets were the favors. A negro quartet sang during the luncheon. Mrs. P.F. Knox had the seat of honor, The other guests were Mesdames Henry Clay Frick, John Moller, Jr., Robert Watson, Samuel Andrews, J.W. Scully, Frederic Sterry, Fremont Smith, A. Karsner, and Smylie C. Carbart.

BAKU, Transcaucasia, Feb. 15. -- During a patriotic service in the Armenian Church here to-day, just as the clergy had ended chanting a Te Deum and praying for the success of the Russian arms, a bomb was thrown at the officiating priest. Two persons were killed and several were injured.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 17. -- There is a growing feeling here that, the question of a successor to the late United States Senator Hanna will not precipitate such a fight as had been expected. It is now believed that when the time for the balloting arrives Representative Charles Dick will be chosen.

Yesterday's market confounded not a few of Wall Street's wise men and prophets. With almost one accord they have been minimizing the war and the Baltimore fire, taking the buoyant view that at worst they were negligible factors, and that it might almost be possible to regard them as blessings in disguise.

Those were most interesting suggestions which Mr. CHARLES R. LAMB laid before the Municipal Art Society, at its meeting on Tuesday, looking to an amendment of the existing street plan of Manhattan. That plan was never intelligently adapted to the needs of the community, and has now bcome conspicuously inadequate to those needs.

BERLIN, Feb. 17. -- The Marine Rundschau, the semi-official publication of the Admiralty, has issued the first of a series of pamphlets designed to keep German naval officers informed as to what is happening in the Far East and the meaning thereof.

MILAN, Feb. 17. -- "Madame Butterfly," an opera by Giacomo Puccini, was produced for the first time at the Scala Theatre here to-night. It was received rather coldly, the public thinking the music too reminiscent of other works by the composer.

Next to the Sunday baseball playing difficulty between the New York American League Club and the Brooklyns of the National League, which is now in the hands of "Garry" Herrmann, Chairman of the National Commission, for decision, the subject of the playing schedules is the most important that the officials of the two big leagues have to deal with.

Prof. Singer of Dresden is the Curator of Prints in the Royal Museum of Saxony and has done his country a service and New York a good office by bringing over a collection of etchings and lithographs by contemporary German artists, which is shown at the Keppel Galleries, 20 East Sixteenth Street. Sixteen artists are represented.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 17. -- In accordance with the wishes of the Hanna family it has been decided that no remarks of a eulogistic nature shall be made in St. Paul's Church at the funeral services over the body of Senator Hanna, which will be held Friday, and the service will be simply that of the Episcopalian Church, Bishop Leonard and Dean Williams officiating.

The United States Board of General Appraisers yesterday announced a decision regarding what is called compressed sole leather, which consists of scraps or skivers of leather, with starch and other cohesive substances, pressed into flat sheets. It was assessed at 35 per cent. ad valorem as a manufacture of leather.

Columbia defeated Princeton in a rough and unscientific game of hockey at the St. Nicholas rink last night by a score of 3 to 1. This victory gives the local university third place in the Intercollegiate Hockey League series, with two games won and two lost. Yale still leads, with three games won and none lost, and Harvard is second, with two won and none lost.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The crises in the cotton trade was the subject of a question in the House of Commons to-day, in reply to which Home Secretary Akers-Douglas, in behalf of the Government, said that although it was recognized that the situation undoubtedly was the cause of anxiety, it could hardly be amended by legislation respecting gambling in futures.

The Department of Education will ask the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to issue corporate stocks to the value of $12,167,000 for the purchase of school sites and for the erection and improvement of school buildings and additions to schools during the coming year. The number of new sittings to be obtained by the building of schools and additions is estimated to approach 91,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- Col. George W. Dunn, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, and William Barnes, Jr., Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Republican State Committee, both said to-day that they thought the selection of Gov. Odell as Chairman of the National Committee would be wise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Taking advantage of Russia's preoccupation in the Far East, Turkey is preparing for war with Bulgaria. It is learned that a march into Bulgarian territory is likely to be made very soon.

Referring to "An Admirer of the English Language's" letter in your issue of the 15th, under the above heading, I was much amused at the attempts of some Spanish firms to write some advertisements in English, but I wish to point out to your correspondent that this is only another case of the Biblical "beam and mote."

Net losses were general in yesterday's stock market. In most instances the losses were not of great importance, but the disposition of the market to sell off as soon as the advance had gained even modest proportions was once more exemplified and resulted in many adopting the opinion that nothing good could be expected of the market as long as it remains as professional as it is at present.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- Assistant Corporation Counsel Guy to-day appeared before the Assembly Committee on Water Supply, Gas and Electricity and made a vigorous protest against favorable action by the committee on the bill introduced by J.T Smith of Dutchess County for the protection of water rights in Dutchess County.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Feb. 17. -- Matti Kurrikki, head of the Labor Party in Finland, is in Vancouver.

Through the opposition made by influential members of the Manhattan Club and by John B. McDonald, the subway contractor, who also is a member of the Finance Committee of Tammany Hall, the plan of the Tammany leaders to have enacted a bill to give Mayor McClellan the power of removal over the Aqueduct Commissioners so that Commissioners Curtis and Ryan could be replaced has been blocked.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- Col. George W. Dunn, the Chairman of the Republican State Committee, who presided over the "home rule" conference held in the Executive Chamber last Monday, and who was empowered to appoint a committee to consider the whole question and report to an adjourned meeting of the conference with recommendations, said to-day that he would announce his committee to-morrow.

The recommendation of Mayor McClellan in regard to the use of river water for fires in New York should receive prompt attention. This is a plan the has been often suggested and its development would not only provide the city with an abundant supply of water for fire purposes, but, which is almost as important, would provide a vastly improved method of street cleaning, at little comparative cost.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 17. -- In the courtyard of the Winter Palace the Czar to-day reviewed the Third Battalion of the First Siberian Rifles, which is proceeding to the Far East.

Action was taken yesterday afternoon by the Board of Directors of the New York Ear and Eye Infirmary, whereby the scope of that institution will be narrowed after March 1, and may be even further curtailed after May 1, in the event that funds for the hospital's maintenance are not forthcoming. This decision was reached only after a long session, which did not end until evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The study of miliatarism, "since it is a menace to the republic, with a view to obtaining universal peace," was advocated in a resolution passed at to-day's session of the National Woman's Suffrage Association.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 17. -- Russia's reply to Secretary Hay's note on China will probably be made in a few days. It will acquiesce in principle, but with certain reservations regarding Chinese administrative control over the region in Manchuria leased to Russia or covered by the Chinese Eastern Railroad, in order to safeguard existing Russian interests.

"St. Louis in July!" exclaims THE NEW YORK TIMES, in horror of supposed high temperature during the meeting of the National Convention. "For the visitor," says THE TIMES, "does usually find the combination of St. Louis and July extremely trying -- to linen, temper, ability to work, and half a score more things."

BOSTON, Feb. 17. -- Secretary of the Navy Moody, speaking at the annual dinner of the New England Rubber Club at the Hotel Somerset to-night, strongly advocated a large navy, and in the course of an earnest speech declared that if the United states desired to maintain peace it must be known that at all times it was ready for war.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- One of the most important steps yet taken toward carrying into effect the people's approval of the $101,000,000 canal scheme will be taken tomorrow morning, when Gov. Odell sends to the Senate the names of the Special Advisory Commission of five expert engineers, under whose eye the barge canal plans will be carried out.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- District Attorney Jerome appeared before the Senate Committee on Codes to-day to make all argument in favor of the bowling bill to amend the Penal Code in relation to the privileges of witnesses in investigations and proceedings for violations of the statutes against gambling.

Mayor McClellan gave out last night the details of the plan evolved through Commissioner Best of the Department of Bridges and through O.F. Nichols, the Chief Engineer of that department, for solving the Brooklyn Bridge crush problem. This plan, which will be formally submitted to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on Friday, includes plans and specifications for the enlargement and reconstruction of the Manhattan terminal.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 17. -- The following address was issued from the National headquarters of the United Mine Workers of America to-day:

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- In the Assembly today the Finch bill, providing for old-age pensions to Judges of the Court of Appeals and the Supreme Court, was the subject of a long debate and finally failed to pass. Mr. Finch declared that New York ought to place the judiciary in a position never to be influenced by ulterior considerations, and remarks of a similar nature were made by Messrs. Hornidge, Wainwright, Bostwick, O'Neill, and Prince.
PARIS, Feb. 17. -- An official dispatch received here this morning from Tokio announces that one of the most important movements of Japanese troops yet made is taking place to-day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Thousands today paid their tribute of respect to the memory of Senator Marcus A. Hanna. In the Senate Chamber, where sat the President of the United States and his Cabinet, the two houses of Congress, the Supreme Court, the Diplomatic Corps, and the members of Mr. Hanna's family, impressive services testified to the universal esteem and affection felt for the dead Senator.

The movements of Japanese troops reported to-day distinctly mean one thing, and that is that, in the opinion of the Japanese General Staff, Russia has ceased to be formidable at sea. As was foreseen and foretold by disinterested military critics before the outbreak of the war, Japan could take no steps to invade either Korea or Manchuria until she had clearly proved her superiority at sea.

Capt. Alfred T. Mahan, United States Navy, in a copyrighted article in the number of Collier's Weekly issued to-day reviews the operations of Russia and Japan so far as they have progressed and estimates their probable strategic importance. Capt. Mahan, who was a member of the Naval Advisory Strategic Board during the Spanish-American war and is a recognized authority on naval matters, says:

TOKIO, Feb. 17. -- The Emperor, the Supreme Council of War, the Privy Council, and a majority of the Cabinet will probably depart on Feb. 20 for Kioto, where it is planned temporarily to establish the imperial headquarters. The date, however, has not yet been definitely decided upon.

Randolph Guggenheimer and Isaac Untermyer have sold to Adelheid Tietenberg the buildings at the corner of Park Row and New Bowery on a triangular plot of irregular dimensions. The properties are known as 229 and 231 Park Row and 66 and 68 New Bowery.

BERLIN, Feb. 17. -- Before leaving Berlin M. Kurino, the retiring Japanese Minister to Russia, said that Japan, having gone to war with Russia for the defense of the sovereignty of the Korean and Chinese Empires, would religiously respect that sovereignty if she were victorious.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says the "yellow peril" is freely expatiated upon in some Paris papers, in accordance with a mot d'ordre from St. Petersburg reinforced in Berlin.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- Dispatches published in London newspapers this morning continue to give descriptions of the embarking of Japanese troops. Instead of this embarkation taking place secretly from Ujina, as was the case during the Chino-Japanese war, the transports, according to dispatches published in The Daily Telegraph and The Daily Mail, are openly embarking troops at Nagasaki, Moji, Kobe, and elsewhere.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- Losses by the recent great fire in Baltimore suffered by the fire insurance companies incorporated in this State and by those of foreign countries having headquarters in this State are estimated in a statement issued to-night by State Superintendent of Insurance Francis Hendricks. No other companies are included in his estimate.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17. -- Having permitted William J. Bryan to hold "the stage" for several weeks, Grover Cleveland has evidently concluded that the time has come for Democrats of opposite views to take their turn before the public.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- Corruption within the ranks of the United Mine Workers of Illinois was charged in open convention today by W.D. Ryan, who declared that delegates were bribed to secure the passage of a resolution that would create for a Chicago company a monopoly of furnishing legal talent to represent miners in damage suits against the mine operators.

PINEHURST, N.C., Feb. 17. -- Close scores were the feature in the medal play qualification rounds of the club handicap tournament which started on the links to-day. The event was open to men and women. The men who qualified were:

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 17. -- The departure of Vice Admiral Makaroff, (the icebreaker specialist of the Russian Navy and until recently Commander in Chief at Kronstadt,) to take the place of Vice Admiral Stark, (in command of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur,) was marked by impressive scenes.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 17. -- Alderman John F. Donohue, who was re-elected to-day for another term of five years, thirty-three in all, is the famous thrasher of wife beaters. Years ago he made his reputation by descending from his magisterial bench, doffing his coat, and giving a chronic wife beater such a trashing that the man has not beaten his wife since. Finding that method effective, Donohue has applied it many times since.

The Chairman of the General Loss Committe of the fire insurance companies, Mr. PAUL TURNER, announces the conclusion that the loss of the Baltimore fire is as nearly as it is possible to estimate it $125,000,000, and the insurance due only about one-half this amount. There is some difference of opinion as to salvage.

It would be rash to assume that Russia will be seriously hindered in the prosecution of the war with Japan by lack of money. Her trouble is much more likely to be in the lack of knowledge how to use her money to the best advantage. The national debt in Russia is not excessive as compared with her resources, about $3,550,000,000.

May I supplement your interesting reply to the Brooklynite who charged that Dewey attacked the Spaniards at Manila treacherously, unexpectedly, and before war was declared, by giving for his edification, some extracts from the amusing pronunciamento that Gov. Don Augusti put forth when Dewey was on the way from Hongkong? It said:

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- Five important bills affecting street railroads will be introduced by the Chairmen of the two Railway Committees of the Senate and House to-morrow. The first bill is designed to make it possible for investors to ascertain whether corporate powers have been kept alive that would menace a new road and that such corporations have legal existence.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 17. -- Application was made to-day for the appointment of a receiver for the Old Town Fire Insurance Company of Baltimore. The bill of complaint alleges that the company is insolvent and unable to pay the claims against it by reason of the fire. The company is said to have assets of $124,970 and liabilities of $254,970.
ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- The Educational Unification bill passed the Senate to-day by a strictly party vote of 28 to 18, the bill being rushed through by virtue of an emergency message from the Governor.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 17. -- A dispatch has been received here from Major Gen. Pflug. Chief-of-Staff to Viceroy Alexieff, saying that Yuan Sha Kai, Commander-in-Chief of the Chinese Army and Navy, has ordered 2,500 men to Tsin-Chou, to maintain order.

Christopher Dunn, sixty-two years old, an up-State farmer with long chin whiskers, walked into the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Police Station Tuesday night and asked for shelter. He said he had tramped from Owego, doing odd jobs in farming all the way, and now wished to go to Buffalo, where he had friends who would care for him.

His Imperial Highness the German Emperor is intemperate in characterizing the work of the German impressionists as "gutter art." Moreover, the term is not accurately descriptive. There is a realism about the gutter which is not reflected in anything characteristic of impressionism in art. Had he said tomato mayonnaise art he would have made a characterization which many would recognize as describing much landscape work of this general class.

The backbone of the intense cold wave which swept over New York on Monday night was broken yesterday afternoon, when the thermometer, after several jumps, recorded a temperature which could reasonably be called wintry, but which fell short of biting discomfort. The most disagreeable feature of yesterday's weather was the brisk northwest wind which prevailed all day.

BOSTON, Feb. 17. -- Alonzo E. Locke was appointed receiver of the New England Brick Company by Judge Colt in the United States Circuit Court to-day on application of the Old Colony Trust Company, which holds a first mortgage on the concern for $850,000.

After having been on trial for ten days in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court on a charge of shooting and killing her husband, and while the jury was voting to convict her of murder in the second degree, Mrs. Della Lupo pleaded guilty yesterday to manslaughter in the first degree, thus escaping a life sentence in prison.

John Keenan, who was indicted twenty-one times on the charge of bribing the "boodle Board of Aldermen," was directed by Supreme Court Justice Giegerich yesterday either to pay to Michael Connolly, the surviving member of the firm of N.K. M. Connolly of Montreal, Canada, the sum of $18,000 with interest from Jan. 1, 1891, or to surrender to Connolly the premises at 227, 229, and 231 East Eighty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The squadron under Admiral Wise consists of the following vessels: The Minneapolis, (flag ship,) Buffalo, Columbia, Hartford, Monongahela, Topeka, and Yankee.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 17. -- George W. Lewis, who committed suicide at Niagara Falls two weeks ago, left an estate worth $953,058. Most of it he willed to his sisters, Mrs. Julian of New York and Mrs. Gooderham of Toronto.
With interest I have read the comments on the bachelors in to-day's issue. I have asked a number of my bachelor friends the reason for their single state.

HALIFAX, N.S., Feb. 18. -- After nearly foundering on one side of the Atlantic, the Hamburg-American liner Pallanza, which arrived to-day from Hamburg, was seriously threatened by a fire which broke out when the steamship was within 500 miles of the American coast.

Joel M. Marx. Special Assistant United States District Attorney in charge of the naturalization prosecutions, and Special Employe Meetze of the Department of Justice have found that fully one-fourth of the "white wings." who are Italians, have fraudulent papers, through which they secured their positions in the Street Cleaning Department.

The fourth evening concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra last evning in Carnegie Hall was notable for giving its first hearing in this city to Richard Strauss's vast symphonic poem "Don Quixote," the only one of the young composer's remarkable series of works of that kind that had never been played here.

At the time of the Crimean war, a former Lord Chancellor of England, Baron Lyndhurst, delivered a speech on the perfidy of Russia in her war against Turkey. Though this speech was made on June 19, 1854, it applies with considerable force on Feb. 19, 1904; only in place of the Crimea, read Manchuria; for Constantinople, Tokio; for Turkey, Korea.

Those who are disposed to resent as officiously paternal some of the new rules of the Board of Health, should not forget that there are others than themselves who may be conspicuously benefited thereby. A case in point is the rule forbidding street car conductors wetting their thumbs in their mouths when they detach transfer slips from pads.

The famine in white paper was the subject discussed yesterday at the concluding sessions of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association. The following resolution, introduced by Conde Hamlin of The St. Paul Pioneer Press, was unanimously adopted:

Your admirable and comprehensive editorial, "Salt Water for Fires," in to-day's TIMES, recalls the efforts of the late Luke F. Cozzans, when he was a State Senator from this city, to have passed by the Legislature an act embracing the very scope suggested by THE TIME'S editorial, for the use of river water in cases of fire and for other purposes.
LONDON, Feb. 19. -- Wiring on Tuesday, the Tokio correspondent of The Times says it is reported that the Russian shells broke up against the Japanese armor in the action at Port Arthur on Feb. 9.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 18. -- The Goulds' Western Maryland Railroad Company has won its preliminary fight with the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, which has been interposing objections to its plans for running along the line of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. The Senate Finance Committee this evening reported favorably both Western Maryland Railroad bills.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 18. -- Gov. Peabody and other State officials, who returned to-day from a tour of the Cripple Creek district, had a narrow escape from being killed or maimed by the wrecking of their train on the "high line" electric road between Cripple Creek and Victor. A pilot car which preceded the Governor's special found a loose rail at a very dangerous point.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 19. -- Owing to existing conditions in the field and the difficulties in the way of providing suitable accommodations, Viceroy Alexieff has recommended that the Foreign Military Attaches should not join the Russian Army until about March 4, and the Viceroy's views on this matter will be communicated to the Governments which have applied for the privilege of observing the war from the Russian side.
The Mannado's Realty Company has sold to Sigmund Wechsler the six-story elevator apartment house at the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, 100 by 100.11.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. H.M. Flagler gave a dinner this evening to Sir Gilbert Carter and Lady Carter. The other guests were Mrs. Adair, Miss Post, and William F. Breese, all of London; F.T. Martin, Mr. and Mrs. W.A. Dick, and D.C. Mitchell.

It is perhaps a little out of date to bring up now the question of the proper apportionment of the money allowed the Board of Education, and we may not be thought sufficiently disinterested in the matter, still I think one phase of it deserves more consideration than it has yet received. I refer to the proposed shortening of the free lecture course.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- Ellenville, Ulster County, was visited to-day by a fire which entailed a property loss of about $75,000, and nearly proved fatal to a number of people.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18. -- A net profit for the college year 1902-3 of $1,014.37 is shown by the annual report of the Yale Financial Union, which includes football, baseball, and athletic associations and the boat club.

Since the Russian cruisers -- the Gromoboi, the Rossia, the Ruvik, and the Bogatyr -- captured a Japanese merchant steamer near the Tsugaro Straits the only news made public about them has been an official report concerning the difficulties they had met in steaming to the westward in the teeth of a strong gale in the Japan Sea.

As war news seems to be the only topic that newspaper readers seem to be interested in at present, allow at few words on the solution of the "Far Eastern question" by a civilian who makes no claim to statesmanship.

Having been defeated in his attempt in Montana courts to prevent the payment to the Amalgamated Copper Company of dividends in the stocks of the Boston and Montana and Parrott Companies, John MacGiniss, the lieutenant of F. Augustus Heinze, has carried his fight into New York, and yesterday obtained from Judge Gildersleeve of the Supreme Court a temporary injunction restraining the Boston and Montana Company from transferring any of its property to the combination.

Chinese Government officials and prominent merchants, who for several days have been holding their New Year festivities -- this being the thirty-first year of the Emperor and the 2,049th year of Confucius -- were, in accordance with custom, entertained yesterday by General Passenger Agent F.W. Dudley and Assistant Traffic Manager E.V. Skinner of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, at the company's offices, 458 Broadway.

There is no need of directing the attention of our readers to the significance of the news we printed yesterday about the intention of Turkey to put an end, once and for all, to the pretensions of Bulgaria to dictate to Turkey how Turkey shall treat her non-Mohammedan and non-Turkish subjects and dependents.

Never before has there been such a scarcity of fish in New York as there is at present. Prices on all kinds have advanced, and are higher now than they have ever been. Some kinds of fish cannot be obtained at any price, and dealers at the wholesale market, are asking for what, are known as the popular kinds from five to ten cents more a pound than they were asking two weeks ago.

Mountain and Lee, the Chicago bowlers, turned the tables on the New York players at the Harlem Circle Alleys last night. Linden and Shiman, however, made highest score in the two-men team match, their 439 being an excellent display. Tournament scores follow:

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18. -- Herself in need of aid to rehabilitate her stricken fire district Baltimore is being called upon to help the unemployed who have flocked here by the hundreds in expectation of getting work. An increasing army of mechanics and other workmen is steadily pouring in, only to find that there is nothing for them to do.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Feb. 18. -- President Ban Johnson of the American League arrived here this afternoon and said that the League has abandoned all further consideration of schedules between the two Leagues until there has been a satisfactory settlement of the Ridgewood matter. All parties concerned in the Ridgewood controversy are to have another hearing before President Garry Herrmann of the Cincinnati Club renders a decision.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 18. -- An official proclamation explaining the unpreparedness of Russia for war and the necessity for patience on the part of her people has been issued here. It says:

As a result of Mayor McClellan's veto of the Aldermanic grant to the New York, Westchester and Boston Railroad Company to cross streets in the Bronx in the construction of a railroad there is a strong probability that the Board of Aldermen will at an early date pass in a different form like permits both to the Westchester Road and to the New York and Port Chester Company, which long has sought the same privilege.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 18. -- A gift of $250,000 has just been given by J. Ogden Armour to the Armour Institute of Technology, a large portion of which will be used entirely for athletics. Dr. Frank W. Gunsaulus, President of the Institute, in announcing this munificent gift to-day said:

The Albany Journal reproves THE TIMES for mentioning Superintendent SKINNER in connection with the Lewis Unification bill. Our Albany contemporary points out that "the bill specifically provides, in accordance with Mr. SKINNER'S suggestion, that the present incumbent of this office shall not be eligible to appointment to the corresponding office sought to be created"; and it observes that "THE TIMES is developing a deplorable disregard of facts of which this is not the first manifestation."

Nearly everything that is used in the world of sport will be seen attractively displayed this evening in Madison Square Garden when the tenth annual Sportmen's Show opens at 8 o'clock.
