The great attraction will be the lake, larger than in all former years, occupying a space of 190 feet long by 70 feet wide on the main floor.

Four large vessels and many smaller craft were caught by the ice in the harbor yesterday and left stranded and helpless on the Staten Island shore when the tide carried the big floes down that way. Every inlet and nook from Raritan Bay to Sandy Hook were jammed and vessels were unable to move.
LONDON, Feb. 19. -- The papers this morning comment upon the activity which is seen at Woolwich and elsewhere in refitting the navy in preparation for any emergency.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 18. -- Dr. Henry H. Rusby, Professor of Botany and Materia Medica in the New York College of Pharmacy, will hereafter be personally conducted in Pittsburg. He was to have lectured a few days ago before the Academy of Art and Science in the Carnegie library lecture rooms, but through the carelessness of a street car conductor he disappointed a large audience and landed at the Western penetentiary.

For the first time Ernst Kraus sang last night the role of Tamino in "Die Zauberfloete." This opera was performed at the Metropolitan for the benefit of the German Press Club. The house was packed to the very doors and the receipts were about $10,000.

Capt. George R. Jennings, head of the Jennings Adjustable Shade Company, was shot and killed yesterday afternoon in his office, at 105 Liberty Street, Brooklyn, Frank McNamara of Elgin, Ill., being arrested for the shooting, the cause of which appears to have been trouble over money matters.

By the narrow margin of a single point, scored within less than a minute of the end of the game, the hockey team of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn won, by the score of 4 to 3, from the seven of the Hockey Club of New York at the St. Nicholas Rink last night, and so remained a factor in the race for the championship of the Amateur Hockey League.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Jewish Chronicle says the commission now sitting at St. Petersburg charged with the revision of the laws in force against the Jews proposes to recommend that in ten provinces of Poland where hitherto Jews have enjoyed unrestricted rights these rights shall now be restricted in every respect to conform with the regulations obtaining within the "pale of a settlement."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Spirited discussion of the Philippine question and a lively political debate attended the consideration of the Fortifications Appropriation bill to-day by the House, which eventually passed the measure.

Accusations of antagonism to the interests of New York City are being made against the Pennsylvania Railroad by some of the other trunk lines, and as a basis for their charges they cite the efforts of the Pennsylvania Railroad, yielding to pressure of Philadelphia commercial interests to establish a differential rate for that city on certain class of freight, a differential which would, it is claimed, result to the detriment of New York City.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 18. -- Information contained in press dispatches from Washington that Secretary Hay had announced that the negotiations in connection with his note to the powers on the subject of the integrity of China to be closed without awaiting Russia's formal response came as a surprise to official circles here.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- It has been generally understood here that "the black horse cavalry" was conducting a campaign against Senator Russell's Car-Heating bill, and the action taken on the bill by the Assembly has created the suspicion that the guerrilla tactics of this organization have met with at least temporary success.

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 18. -- The final round of the international chess tournament was duly played at the International Sporting Club in this city to-day, with the result that Maroczy beat Marshall, Gunsberg disposed of Swiderski, and Schlechter administered defeat to Marco.
LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The Japanese Legation to-day gave out an official cable dispatch received from Tokio, as follows:

PARIS, Feb. 18. -- The publication by the Figaro this morning of the details of an interview between the late President Felix Faure and the late Count Muravieff, who was then Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs, with reference to the Fashoda incident, is of capital importance at the present juncture.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Col. George W. Dunn, who acted as Chairman of the "home rule" conference called by the Governor, and who was empowered to appoint a committee to investigate the subject of how far under their existing charters the cities of the State are deprived of home rule, and report whatever recommendations they saw fit with regard to an extension of the present powers of the municipalities, to-day announced his committee.

The Chairman of the Sub-Committee on Height of Buildings of the General Citizens' Emergency Committee of Baltimore has presented a report proposing an amendment to the building laws of the city to the effect that hereafter no building not of approved fire-resistant construction shall be permitted to rise more than one hundred feet above the sidewalk level, and that no building of any construction shall be more than 175 feet high.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Representative Goldfogle's resolution aimed at the discrimination of the Russian Government against Jewish travelers of foreign birth was taken up to-day by the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, which granted a hearing on the subject. Addresses were made by Representatives Goldfogle and Harrison of New York and by Simon Wolf of this city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- President Roosevelt's efforts to make an "open shop" of the Government Printing Office have not met with unalloyed success. The union men cannot openly antagonize the President, but they are accomplishing their ends by strategy.

As a consequence of the Baltimore fire, the Greenwich Insurance Company of New York has reinsured all its present outstanding risks in the Commercial Union Assurance Company of London. The affairs of the Greenwich will be placed in voluntary liquidation.

Mayor McCLELLAN has a highly intelligent sense of the interests which it is his duty to defend, and his veto of the Aldermanic ordinance granting to the New York, Westchester and Boston Railway Company the right to use certain streets in the annexed district shows that he has the courage to perform that duty.

Manager Edward Hanlon of the Brooklyn Baseball Club denies the statement of President Gordon of the New York American League Club that he had entered into an agreement with Frank Farrell to be a party with the Greater New York Baseball Club in the playing of Sunday games at Ridgewood Park, L.I., during the coming Summer.

District Attorney Jerome returned from Albany yesterday. He said he felt assured that the measure known as the Dowling bill would become a law. "If it becomes a law," said the District Attorney, "I will be able to get at the big gambling houses in New York. At present it is difficult to get evidence against these places.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18. -- In a high wind seventy-five golfers strove to qualify to-day for the championship of Florida and the President's, Secretary's, and Seminole Cups. Sixteen players qualified for each cup, the first sixteen at medal play being eligible for the President's Cup. The features of the day's play were the excellent rounds of Travis, Brokaw, and Cory, and the dropping of Arthur Havemeyer from the first class.

OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- Miss Bertha C. Lewis, who had been missing since Wednesday last, when she went to New York to take a music lesson, returned to her home here soon after midnight this morning. She had come by train from New York and was accompanied by a woman friend.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day announced that, as a result of its investigation of the feasibility of requiring railroads to publish their tariffs for the movement of export and import traffic, it has decided to leave the matter in abeyance for a time.
LONDON, Feb. 19. -- Discussing the Russian proclamation issued yesterday, a military correspondent of The Times says:

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 18. -- A long official dispatch from Viceroy Alexieff, recounting the details of the fight of Feb. 9 at Port Arthur, was given out to-day. It enumerates the Russian casualties, and says it is known that a number of Japanese ships suffered, which accounts for their not following up the attack.

Ex-President CLEVELAND speaks with his accustomed wisdom and sound sense. He tells his party that "obsolete issues and questions no longer challenging popular interest should be manfully abandoned." This consigns Bryanism and its principles to the rubbish heap. Mr. CLEVELAND tells specifically what he means when he says, "Our fighting forces will respond listlessly and falteringly if summoned to a third defeat in a strange cause."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 18. -- The American Institute of Mining Engineers, which adjourned this evening, decided to make a pleasure trip through the West Indies. The start will be made on March 8 in the steamer Princessin Victoria Louise. The officers elected included: President -- James Gayley; Secretary and Editor -- R.W.R. Raymond, and Treasurer -- Frank Lyman, all of New York
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 18. -- William Jennings Bryan, who arrived here to-day from Florida, speaking of the article by Grover Cleveland published in a Philadelphia periodical, said:
HOUSTON, Texas, Feb. 18. -- In a statement given out to-day John H. Kirby said of the recent application for a receivership for the Kirby Lumber Company and the Houston Oil Company:

Jesus of Nazareth, during His Ministry of three years, preached many sermons. Nearly, thirty of them are recorded in the Gospels with considerable fullness. None of them, however, has received a distinctive name excepting this to the conclusion of which our attention is now directed. It is also more fully recorded than any other.

The purpose of the volumes in the "Story of the Nations" series is to enter more closely and familiarly than is usually the case in formal histories into the lives of the people that make the nations. Of course the life of a nation may be written in many ways -- in terms of economic development, of political growth, of educational progress.

Reporting to the Mayor on the financial conditions of the New York Fire Department life insurance and relief funds during the last two years, John C. Hertle and William Harmon Black, the Commissioners of Accounts, have some hot shot for ex-Commissioner Thomas Sturgis. The Commissioners report that since 1901 128 names have been added to the pension list, and $101,123.34 has been added to the annual amount for which the relief fund is obligated.

When the average citizen buys a dozen American Beauty roses and pays from $6 to $12 for them, he utters a groan over his extravagance and flees, full of melancholy, from the florist's shop. Maybe it will console such infrequent buyers to hear that they are miserly spendthrifts compared to hundreds, even thousands of folks who habitually disgorge dollars by the score for rare blossoms.

It would require more than one reading to understand more than dimly what this book is about. The author believes in the disjointed method to such an extent that your head spins around and grows dizzy in the attempt to follow him as he skips, like the famous bullfrog, from bank to bank. However, this much is clear.

Edward Marshall is bringing out, through G.W. Dillingham Co., a new romance, entitled "The Middle Wall." This is a story of adventure in South Africa, London, at sea, and on Cape Cod. After making a fortune in diamonds in South Africa, Parton, the hero, returns to London, to find his mother married to an unscrupulous barrister, who is the uncle of the young man's sweetheart.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The New York delegation in Congress to-day began its campaign for a new Post Office by appearing before the House Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds and urging the city's need for better mail facilities.

A bill to retire Judges of the Court of Appeals and Supreme Court Judges on half pay after sixteen years' service, at the age of seventy, or after twenty-five years' service at a less age, has failed in the Assembly for lack of the constitutional majority, though it had a numerical majority.

Amid a delightfully piney odor that carried one back to camping days in the North Woods, with scenery so natural that one might imagine he could easily walk to a towering ridge of rugged mountains, and with a real lake upon which real Summer resort launches flitted back and forth, the opening of the tenth annual Sportsmen's Show last night in Madison Square Garden was accomplished in a highly successful manner.

A petition is now being circulated for signatures advocating the passage of the Bostwick bill, relating to the taxation of mortgages. In reading the provisions of the proposed bill I have been struck by the possibilities of further tax evasion presented.

A NEW novel by Mrs. Everard Cotes (Sara Jeannette Duncan), "The Imperialist," is announced for immediate publication by D. Appleton Co. This is the first long story in some years from the brilliant author of "An America Girl in London" and "Those Delightful Americans."

Thomas Wright's new "Life of Edward FitzGerald" is now ready in the American edition, comprising two handsome octavo volumes, well printed and richly illustrated. These pictures, including portraits of FitzGerald's friends and acqaintances, and views of places, add greatly to the interest of the book. Mr. Wright has also reproduced some of FitzGerald's own sketches, and the appendices contain much matter of genuine interest.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 19. -- Rear Admiral James Sands, Commander in Chief of the coast squadron, and Capt. W.T. Swinburne, who are here on the battleship Texas, have offended Mayor Paul Capdevielle of New Orleans by their failure to make official calls. Mr. Capdevielle regards the incident as an official rebuke, and so exasperated has he been that he has avoided meeting them officially and at the opera.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 19. -- Prompt action by President Bonilla in calling, as a practical dictator, a constitutional convention at Tegucigalpa, the capital, has nipped in the bud a threatened revolution in Honduras.

The big plant of the F.W. Devoe C.T. Reynolds Company, paint manufacturers, in John Street, Brooklyn, was destroyed last night by fire, which, feeding on hundreds of barrels of linseed oil and a great quantity of paints, varnishes, and other highly inflammable stuff, raged fiercely for three hours.

The discussion of grammatical English seems to be the "order of the day," and the interesting correspondence published in the two last issues of THE REVIEW should be seriously considered by every person speaking or writing the language. Strange to say, ungrammatical English is not confined alone to the uneducated; their transgressions are pardonable.

Until the Japanese have transported to Korea and to the Liao-Tung Peninsula an aggregate of at least 100,000 troops, the progress of the war will probably drag somewhat slowly. The Russians have had too bitter a taste of the Japanese quality on the sea to be willing to attempt further naval operations unless and until their fleet be strengthened to a level of equality with their enemy.
JOHN STRANGE WINTER'S new novel, "Cherry's Child," is announced for publication by the J.B. Lippincott Company next week.

There has developed a curious opposition to the appropriation of money for the agricultural work of the Government. We think that most of it is unreasonable. Doubtless there is room for improvement in the work. It is easy to find fault with any work of this sort which is not under the direct influence of private interest and guided by practical business principles.

YOUR critic is as absolute as the gravedigger in "Hamlet." I understand his contention to be that to give a panoramic poem (which "The Dynasts" may perhaps be called) the form of a stage drama -- even a conventionalized form -- or to give such a form to anything whatever that is intended for the study only, is false in principle.

In the "Magazine Notes" last week mention was made of Alfred Russel Wallace's publication in The Fortnightly Review of an "unpublished poem by Edgar Allan Poe," which a deceased brother sent him from California about ten years ago, with this inscription: "Lines left by a wanderer at a wayside house in lieu of cash for board and lodging one night."

SOME writers have drawn a comparison between Caroline Matilda, Queen of Denmark and Norway, and the Empress Catherine. Force of circumstances as sometimes advanced as an excuse for the failings of both these women, also that they were married to worthless husbands.

You must be in error, I think, when you say that the poem by J.R. Lowell, entitled "After the Burial," refers to the death of his second child, Rose. There is a poem of an elegiac character called "The First Snowfall," in which he explains to his daughter Mabel about the snow, while he is thinking of the buried daughter, probably Rose, in "sweet Auburn."

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 19. -- Play for the cup offered by the Boston Athletic Association and the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, which carries with it the title of racquet champion of the United States, began on the courts of the Boston Athletic Association this morning. The number of entries is the largest ever seen in this annual competition, but there was only a small gallery of spectators on hand when play began.

" The Vanguard" is the title of James S. Gale's new Korean story, which the Fleming H. Revell Company will issue in the Spring. The hero, Willis, is a missionary to the Koreans. He falls in love with an American girl, who cannot join him, but stays true to him until his first public jubilee, when she comes to him.
Counsel on both sides in the trial of Martin Cohn and Charles C. Browne for alleged silk importation frauds spent all of yesterday in summing up, and Judge Thomas will charge the jury this morning.

G.P. Putnam's Sons will publish in this country late in the Spring a volume of poems by Enid Welsford. It will have an introduction by Reginald Bosworth Smith, author of "Mohammed and Mohammedanism," "Carthage and the Carthaginians," "The Life of Lord Lawrence," and a contributor to English periodicals.

The little Republican comedy as to the granting of home rule to the City of New York goes merrily on. While Gov. ODELL is toying with his conference committee and getting Mr. RAINES to put in a few experimental bills, his wicked partner at Washington is denouncing any and all concessions, especially on the excise law.

Charles W. Morse appeared yesterday at the Criminal Court Building with his counsel, Samuel Untermyer, and after a long consultation with Assistant District Attorney Rand was taken to the Grand Jury room, that body having subpoenaed him to answer questions as to the present whereabouts of Mrs. Dodge-Morse-Dodge.

Frank McNamara of Elgin, Ill., who was arrested on Thursday, charged with the murder of George R. Jennings, a manufacturer of patent window shades, who was shot in his office, 103 Liberty Street, Brooklyn, that afternoon, was arraigned in the Adams Street Court yesterday morning and held for examination next Friday by Magistrate Steers, who presided. Addressing the Magistrate, the prisoner said:
LONDON, Feb. 20. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say the recent official communication regarding the war was preceded in the St. Petersburg Viedomosti by the following: ...

WHEN a diplomatist favors the world with his reminiscences public curiosity is excited, for what secrets can there be which he does not know? Sir Horace Rumbold is, however, discreet. Of course, he met many distinguished personages whose business it was to represent the leading European States, and he describes them.

" When It Was Dark" is a four-o'clock-in-the-morning book. Admitted that its plot is improbable, unreasonable; granted that the book is written from the point of view of a narrow-minded curate in a small English urban parish, the fact remains that the book is throughout intensely interesting and dramatic. It is also well written, but it would probably be successful were it not.

Those who know the Caribbean Sea may be interested especially in the story of Morgan, the pirate, as told by "Sir Henry Morgan -- Buccaneer," and may ask for information about the tides in that Mediterranean of the New World.

Spirited tennis, that was unusually high class, marked the opening contests yesterday in the fifth tournament for the indoor championship of the United States. The tournament, as heretofore, is being played on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue.

On Feb. 6 an article "Literature and Grammar," by Ellen E. Kenyon Warner, contained this phrase, "the children 'got' no primary teaching in grammar." This reminded me that I had intended to ask you in regard to the misuse or inelegant use of the word "got." The above is a glaring example.

Lawyer Mary Coleman became highly indignant yesterday over Recorder Golf's rulings in a case which she is trying, with her father, in Part I. of the General Sessions, and, grasping her picture hat from the counsel's table, she jabbed a halpin into it and declared with dignity that she would withdraw from the case.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Secretary Hay to-day laid before the President the formal reply of Russia to the note regarding the neutrality of China.

Most of the famous historical disputes over charges of plagiarism have never been settled. In the latest number of that excellent Southern quarterly, The Sewanee Review, Alphonso G. Newcomer brings up again, in a careful paper, the remarkable case of Edgar Allan Poe and Thomas Holley Chivers. There is no doubt whatever that Chivers imitated Poe. As to whether or not Poe ever, consciously or unconsciously, imitated Chivers there can never be an agreement.

PARIS, Feb. 19. -- The speech of Deputy Jaures denouncing the Franco-Russian alliance continues to be a subject of universal discussion, and next Monday a full meeting of the members of the Radical Left will be held to condemn it.

District Attorney Jerome will inquire into the Shipbuilding Trust without reference to any investigation that may be made by the State authorities. Mr. Jerome's inquiry will be started early next week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- A stir was created to-day while the House, in Committee of the Whole, was discussing the Naval Appropriation bill, by Representative Fitzgerald (Dem.) of New York, who declared that it was the evident intention of this Government to acquire a navy bigger than Germany's, and that the belief was growing that President Roosevelt was likely to involve the United States in a war with some other nation.

It was the short cut to India Columbus sought. When he reached the insignificant Cat Island there loomed before him the idea that he was near Cathay. Mr. Reuben Cold Thwaites writes: "Columbus went to his grave probably unconscious of the fact that he had discovered a new continent; and the belief that America was merely a projection of Asia was long after persisted in by geographers."

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 19. -- The Government to-day received from the officers of the Variag and Korietz, who are now at Shanghai, their account of the fight at Che-mul-pho on Feb. 8. The account shows the admirable handling of the two Russian warships in the face of overwhelming odds.

THE WOES of the gentleman who writes under the name of R. Andom were set forth in a letter the other day. He had sent a story to the editor of a certain weekly publication, and after waiting six weeks for an acknowledgment of it wrote to the editor inquiring the fate of his manuscript.

Mrs. Harriott (Clara Morris) is better when relating some reminiscences of her remarkable career or describing the people whom she met than when dealing with pure fiction. There is a lack of cohesion about "Left in Charge," her latest book, that in a certain measure distracts the reader's thoughts.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 19. -- The last services over the body of Senator Marcus A. Hanna were held here this afternoon at St. Paul's Episcopal Church. Nearly all business was suspended for the entire afternoon. Street railway and steam road traffic on every line in the city was stopped for the five minutes from 1 to 1:05 o'clock.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19. -- After conferences extending over the past three days, the Committee on Church Co-operation and Union of the Presbyterian Churches of the United States and the Committee on Fraternity and Union of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church unanimously adopted an agreement as a basis of the union of the two Churches.

Nero needs a good word, if any wretch needs it. But his apologist in your issue of Feb. 13 has not perfectly succeeded. One might admit that it was not impossible for some mediaeval monk of exceptional genius to imitate the style of Tacitus, and so to interpolate the story of Nero's burning the Christians.

Gov. Odell came to town yesterday in the interest of his personal affairs. He registered at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and may remain until to-morrow. To-day he will meet many of the local leaders. A few conferred with him yesterday.

Encouraged by the demand for his book, "Japanese Physical Training," H. Irving Hancock is rapidly completing a volume which G.P. Putnam's Sons will publish as soon as possible under the title, "Physical Training of Women by Japanese Methods." It will be a companion to the first book, and will also be illustrated from photographs, fifty in number.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- The London branch of Messrs. Harper Brothers will publish soon "Greater America" by Archibald R. Colquhoun, well known to American readers as the author of "The Key to the Pacific" and "The Mastery of the Pacific."

" Home Mechanics' for Amateurs," by George M. Hopkins, is a book of 370 pages with 326 illustrations. (New York: Munn Co. $1.50).) Any one who likes to tinker about the house will be grateful to the author for spotting the very things, little in themselves, yet so vexatious to the inexperienced mechanic.

The Century Company publish to-day "Tillie: A Mennonite Maid," by Helen R. Martin, with illustrations in pen and ink on tinted paper by Florence Scovel Shinn. The scene is laid in the Dutch-belt in Pennsylvania and, besides Tillie, a sweet Dutch, lass, one meets among the characters her brutal, ignorant father, a shaggy old country doctor, and a young Harvard man, who happens to be teaching school in the district.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19. -- Dr. Oscar Lovell Triggs, instructor in English at the University of Chicago, has been dismissed from the Faculty. In some quarters of the university community the action of the Trustees is regarded as a direct refutation of Dr. Harper's recent statement that any professor was at liberty to express any opinion he saw fit concerning Mr. Rockefeller or any other subject without fear of dismissal.

It is to be hoped that the report which comes from St. Petersburg may prove to be authentic which sets forth that M. WITTE is about to resume his old place in the councils of the Russian Empire as Minister of Finance.

The first six volumes of the new Kensington edition of Thackeray, edited by Edward L. Burlingame and arranged under the supervision of Mr. Arthur Scribner, have come to hand. Three volumes are devoted to "Vanity Fair," and three to "Pendennis." These will be followed by "The Newcomes," in three volumes; "Esmond," two volumes; "The Virginians," three volumes, and "Philip," two volumes.

The Knoedler Galleries have another setting this week in the splendid frames and brilliant pictures and portraits fashioned by M. Theobald Chartran, the French painter so well known to New York and Washington. His present exhibition has more variety than usual; this time it is not exclusively one of portraits.
LONDON, Feb. 20. -- The complete lull in war news leads the newspapers this morning to discuss the political aspects of the struggle in the Far East, as they are likely to affect Great Britain.

AS the story of a Russian Jew from his birth in a little town in Lithuania to his marriage in this country to a girl of Christian parentage and Russian race "The Fugitive" may be considered sociologically interesting beyond the measure of its literary value, which is not-great. The story purports to be autobiographical, and the writer is presumably a Russian and a Jew.

DR. GEORGE M. GOULD, to the first volume of whose "Biographic Clinics" we extended last year a cordial if somewhat surprised welcome, has just issued a second volume of the same work which is equally astonishing, and, we doubt not, equally valuable .
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- President Roosevelt to-day signed the Urgent Deficiency bill.

The Southerners who have risen indignantly to protest against the Criticism of their peculiarities of speech may console themselves with the thought that they are one in speech, if not in heart, with those perfect grammarians, the educated Bostonians. The latter drop all their "g's," flatten their "a's," and eliminate their "r's." I am greeted every morning with, "Haow you all feelin' this mornin'?" When in Boston it was, "Haow yu feelin' this mornin'?".

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times says the Chinese authorities are exercised about the arrival at Woo-Sung yesterday of the Japanese cruiser Akitsushima. They connect it with the presence of the Russian gunboat Mandjur, which, in the absence of orders, remains anchored off the Bund.

Edinburgh University has put forth a textbook on economics which at once becomes the standard. Prof. Nicholson has based it pon his three-volume "Principles of Political Economy," not, however, as an abstract. The longer work is historical in its method, and the present volume is refined gold resulting from that process smelted anew, simply cast, and beautifully concrete.

THE President of Marietta College is not in the least exuberant when he writes that "Gen. Rufus Putnam was a man to delight the soul of a historian." He accomplished great deeds and kept a careful record of his work.

M. Anatole France of the French Academy is one of the most brilliant and most admired writers of the day. His criticism -acute, discriminating, delicate, and sympathetic -- is in its way more enlightening than that of his celebrated predecessors, since it yields less to the exactions of system and expresses engagingly the matured impressions of a sensitive and highly trained mind.

In your issue of the 6th inst. under the caption "Mystic Rites of the Indians," you mention that George Catlin, who had lived among the Indians, had described the sun dance and other features in entertainments, principally given in England. I remember attending one, an anticipation in miniature of our contemporary Buffalo Bill, but it must be sixty years ago.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- Before a large and enthusiastic audience Siegfried Wagner's new opera, "Der Kobold," ("The Goblin") was presented last Thursday at the Hamburg Stadt Theatre. In a front box sat Frau Cosima Wagner with her daughters, and among others present were Humperdinck, Wagner's old teacher; Director Elmbadt, manager of the Stockholm royal theatre; Balling, the successor of Felix Mottl in Karlsruhe, and other musical celebrities.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19. -- Six men were shot, one perhaps mortally, and several others were injured by flying missiles in a riot late to-day which attended a raid on a poolroom at Madison, Ill., just across the river from St. Louis. After a hot battle lasting ten minutes, in which seventy-five shots were exchanged, the poolroom was closed.

If the very crude and primitive method of removing snow from the streets by cartloads and spadefuls must be adhered to, why has it never occurred to our authorities that time and expense could be saved by lowering the bodies of the carts to a level beneath that of the axles, as is done in New England in the case of load carts?

The third series of Dr. Edward Moore's "Studies in Dante," containing miscellaneous essays, is being published by Henry Frowde at The Clarendon Press. The book opens with a study of the astronomy of Dante in "Divina Commedia." Dr. Moore explains all the astronomical passages which usually offer difficulties to the general leader.

W. Matches does me wrong. He shouldn't. He really should not "do" me so. I never, no, never, assured our dear Review of Books that the pronunciation of the cultivated New Yorker is the best standard possible for Americans. I did say that if New York lay south of Mason and Dixon's line, I should probably reply to certain criticisms of New York pronunciation in a certain way, which is quite a different thing.

Beginning with the statement that the accepted law of the motions of the moon yields no general law for the motions, velocities, and distances of satellites with regard to the planets they attend upon, the present author proceeds to attack the problem in a manner somewhat different from that adopted by other theoretical astronomers and mathematicians.

I WISH to call attention to an error of fact in Chancellor E. Benjamin Andrews's book "The United States in Our Own Time." On page 488 he says: Hon. William E. Chandler, Secretary of the Navy under President Arthur, deserves the honor of being the first pungently to urge the building of a new navy worthy the American Nation.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 19. -- The Russian Government to-day abolished the censorship upon all news and other telegrams going abroad.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19. -- In the midst of excitement unequaled since the days of the Leiter deal of 1898, the price of wheat for May delivery touched the dollar mark to-day, and, not content with this achievement, continued its upward march until $1.03 was reached.

The study of Hebrew, once the strange alphabet is mastered, is not so very difficult if one has any taste for languages or knack in acquiring them. But even the most diligent and enthusiastic student will find it difficult to follow the pace set by the author of "A Primer of Hebrew," Charles Prospero Fagnani, professor at the Union Theological Seminary in this city.

This excellent and instructive essay, in its original form a dissertation offered for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy at Harvard, supplies in a form, much more attractive than is the average way of these professional monographs, the story of the Continental army considered as a military organization from its beginning with the raw recruits Washington found camped about Boston to the end of the War of Independence.

" Joan of the Alley," by Mr. Frederick Orin Bartlett, is another of those "first novels" that in these days are constantly startling one with their excellence in both manner and matter, and in any period less prolific in ephemeral literature than our own it would be taken as the sure promise of later masterpieces from the same pen.
It is interesting to remark that in London the view taken of the Russian proclamation is that it is intended to presage another conflict like that of 1812.
